Propositions: Students with criminal convictions have limited eligibility for federal student aid.
Students need to understand their status regarding criminal convictions.
Students should not assume they cannot get federal student aid.
A student's eligibility for federal student aid can be affected by incarceration.
A student's eligibility for federal student aid can be affected by the type of conviction the student has.

The resource 'Federal Student Aid Eligibility for Students Confined in Adult Correctional or Juvenile Justice Facilities' provides information for incarcerated individuals on federal student aid eligibility.
If a student is incarcerated, the student has limited eligibility for federal student aid.
Once a student is released from incarceration, most eligibility limitations for federal student aid will be removed.
A student can apply for federal student aid before being released from incarceration so that the aid is processed in time for the student to start school.
If a student's incarceration was for a drug-related offense, the student's eligibility for federal student aid may be limited.
If a student is subject to an involuntary civil commitment for a sexual offense, the student's eligibility for federal student aid may be limited.
If a student is on probation or parole, the student may be eligible for federal student aid.
If a student is living in a halfway house, the student may be eligible for federal student aid.
If a student was convicted of a drug-related offense, the student's eligibility for federal student aid may be limited.
If a student is subject to an involuntary civil commitment for a sexual offense, the student's eligibility for federal student aid may be limited.
A student's eligibility for federal student aid might be suspended if the drug offense occurred while the student was receiving federal student aid grants, loans, or work-study.
When completing the FAFSA form, a student will be asked whether the student had a drug conviction for an offense that occurred while the student was receiving federal student aid.

If a student answers 'yes' to the drug conviction question on the FAFSA form, the student will be provided a worksheet to help determine whether the conviction affects the student's eligibility for federal student aid.

If a student's eligibility for federal student aid has been suspended due to a drug conviction, the student can regain eligibility early by successfully completing an approved drug rehabilitation program.

If a student's eligibility for federal student aid has been suspended due to a drug conviction, the student can regain eligibility early by passing two unannounced drug tests administered by an approved drug rehabilitation program.

If a student regains eligibility for federal student aid during the award year, the student should notify the student's financial aid office immediately so the student can get any aid the student is eligible for.
If a student is convicted of a drug-related offense after submitting the FAFSA form, the student might lose eligibility for federal student aid.
If a student is convicted of a drug-related offense after submitting the FAFSA form, the student might be liable for returning any financial aid the student received during a period of ineligibility.

If a student has been convicted of a forcible or nonforcible sexual offense, and the student is subject to an involuntary civil commitment upon completion of a period of incarceration for that offense, the student cannot receive a Federal Pell Grant.
Financial aid is money to help pay for college or career school.
Grants, work-study, loans, and scholarships help make college or career school affordable.
A variety of financial aid sources are available to help you pay for college or career school.
Financial aid can come from federal, state, school, and private sources to help you pay for college or career school.
Besides financial aid, you should also think about what you can do to lower your costs when you go to college.

A grant is a form of financial aid that does not have to be repaid unless, for example, you withdraw from school and owe a refund, or you receive a TEACH Grant and do not complete your service obligation.

A variety of federal grants are available, including Pell Grants, Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grants (FSEOG), Teacher Education Assistance for College and Higher Education (TEACH) Grants, and Iraq and Afghanistan Service Grants.
Many nonprofit and private organizations offer scholarships to help students pay for college or career school.

Scholarships are a type of free money, which is sometimes based on academic merit, talent, or a particular area of study, that can make a real difference in helping you manage your education expenses.
The Federal Work-Study Program allows you to earn money to pay for school by working part-time.
When you receive a student loan, you are borrowing money to attend a college or career school.
You must repay the student loan as well as interest that accrues.
It is important to understand your repayment options so you can successfully repay your student loan.
Federal Student Aid (FSA) routinely conducts program reviews.
The program reviews confirm that a school meets FSA requirements for institutional eligibility, financial responsibility, and administrative capability.
During a program review, reviewers evaluate the school's compliance with FSA requirements.
During a program review, reviewers assess liabilities for errors in performance.
During a program review, reviewers identify actions the school must take to improve its future administrative capabilities.
After completing a program review, Federal Student Aid issues a Final Program Review Determination (FPRD).
The FPRD is a report that includes each finding identified in the program review report.
The FPRD includes the school's response.
The FPRD includes the Department's final determination.
The FPRD identifies liabilities, if any, calculated based on the findings of the program review.
The FPRD provides instructions for the payment of liabilities, as appropriate.
The FPRD notifies the institution of its right to appeal the existence and amount of any liabilities identified, as appropriate.
The FPRD closes the program review, if appropriate.
The FPRD may or may not require additional action by the institution.
Future FPRDs will be posted regularly.
To access all documents associated with focused-Clery Act reviews, visit the "Clery Act Reports" page.
To locate Final Program Review Determinations from completed third-party servicer program reviews, visit the "Third-party Servicer Program Reviews" page.
An overview of the top program review and audit findings by fiscal year is also available.
The annual reports detail by frequency the most common findings identified in the annual compliance audits conducted by independent auditors.
The annual reports detail by frequency the most common findings identified through program reviews conducted by the Department of Education at institutions of higher education.
Aidan is a virtual assistant that can answer questions about federal student aid.
Aidan uses advanced technology artificial intelligence and natural language processing to answer questions.
Aidan can answer common questions about financial aid.
Aidan can help find pages on the Federal Student Aid website.
Aidan can retrieve loan balance on a user's account.
Aidan can allow users to make a payment.
Aidan can provide information about a user's repayment plan.
Aidan can find customer support information.
Aidan can identify a user's loan servicer(s).
Aidan is in the early stages of development (beta mode).
Aidan is still learning and acquiring new skills.
The conversations with Aidan are recorded.
The recorded conversations help improve quality assurance, maintain an accurate log of requests, and identify new skills for Aidan to learn.
Aidan cannot be used by someone else on a user's phone or computer if the user protects their username and password.
Users should log out of their account after chatting with Aidan and never share their account username and password.
Aidan is secure and private.
Federal Student Aid will handle and store the data from interactions with Aidan securely and will never share it with third parties.
Aidan currently speaks only English.
Aidan's beta version is currently available only to a pilot group of users when they are logged in to their accounts.
Users can look for the Aidan owl icon in the bottom right-hand corner of any page of the Federal Student Aid website on their desktop or mobile device to access Aidan.
A Co-Signer is the spouse of an applicant who initiated an Income-Driven Repayment Plan Request.
As a Co-Signer you are not obligated to repay this loan by signing a borrower's IDR application.
The IDR applicant should have provided you with a Reference Number / Co-sign Code.
If you do not have the Reference Number / Co-sign Code, contact the IDR applicant.
An e-mail containing the Reference Number / Co-sign Code was sent to the IDR applicant.
The IDR applicant can also access the Reference Number / Co-sign Code by logging in to StudentAid.gov and clicking on the appropriate link.

If the IDR applicant completed an Income-Driven Repayment Plan Request that was not part of a Direct Consolidation Loan Application, the IDR applicant will click on "Income-Driven Repayment Plan Requests" under "My Loan Documents" to locate and provide you with the Reference Number you need.

If the IDR applicant completed an Income-Driven Repayment Plan Request as part of a Direct Consolidation Loan Application, the IDR applicant will click on "Direct Consolidation Loan Applications" under "My Loan Documents" to locate and provide you with the Co-sign Code you need.
The spouse of an applicant who initiated an Income-Driven Repayment Plan Request should complete the Co-Sign process.
The entire Co-Sign process must be completed in a single session.
Most people complete the Co-Sign process in 10 minutes.
You must be logged in with your own unique FSA ID in order to Co-Sign the applicant's IDR Request.
You need a verified FSA ID to Co-Sign.
You need the Reference Number/Co-Sign Code to Co-Sign.
You need the IDR applicant's SSN to Co-Sign.
You need financial information only if you file income taxes separately from your spouse to Co-Sign.
After you submit your Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) form, you will get a Student Aid Report that summarizes the information you provided on your application.
You should review your Student Aid Report carefully to make sure it is correct and complete.

Your Student Aid Report (SAR) is a paper or electronic document that gives you some basic information about your eligibility for federal student aid as well as listing your answers to the FAFSA questions.
Whether you receive your SAR online or on paper depends on whether you provide an email address on your FAFSA form.
If you provide a valid email address, you will receive an email from noreply@FAFSA.gov with instructions on how to access an online copy of your SAR.
If you do not provide a valid email address on your FAFSA form, you will receive either a SAR or a SAR Acknowledgement via postal mail.
The SAR lists your FAFSA information and provides space for you to make corrections.
You will receive a paper SAR if you file a paper FAFSA form and do not provide an email address.
The SAR Acknowledgement lists your FAFSA information, but you will need to make any corrections at fafsa.gov.
You will receive a SAR Acknowledgement if you file an electronic FAFSA form and do not provide an email address.

If you have an FSA ID username and password and your FAFSA information has been processed, you can log in at fafsa.gov to view SAR information regardless of whether you filled out the FAFSA form online, on the myStudentAid app, or on a FAFSA PDF or whether you provided an email address or not.
The school you list on your FAFSA form will have access to your SAR data electronically within a day after it is processed.
If your FAFSA application is complete, an Expected Family Contribution (EFC) will display in the upper right-hand corner of your SAR.
If your FAFSA application is incomplete, your SAR will not include an EFC, but it will tell you what you need to do to resolve any issues.
The SAR contains a four-digit Data Release Number (DRN), which appears on the first page in the upper right corner of the paper SAR and SAR Acknowledgement.
On the electronic SAR, the DRN is located in the box that contains the Application Receipt date, below the EFC.
You will need the DRN if you choose to allow your college or career school to change certain information on your FAFSA form.
Your SAR might also contain a note indicating that you have been selected for verification.
When you get your SAR, you should review it carefully to make sure it is correct and complete.
The school you listed on your FAFSA form will use your information to determine your eligibility for federal and possibly nonfederal financial aid.
A school may ask you to verify the accuracy of your FAFSA data, so you need to be sure the information is correct.
If you do not have any changes to make to the information listed on your SAR, you should keep it for your records.
If you review your SAR and find a mistake, you will need to correct or update your FAFSA form.

Once your FAFSA form or FAFSA correction has been processed, you can get a copy of your SAR by logging in to fafsa.gov using your FSA ID and selecting the "View or Print your Student Aid Report (SAR)" option near the middle of the "My FAFSA" page.

Alternatively, you can get a copy of your SAR by contacting the Federal Student Aid Information Center at 1-800-4-FED-AID (1-800-433-3243) or TTY for the deaf or hard of hearing at 1-800-730-8913 and requesting a copy be sent to you via U.S. mail (allow 10-14 days for delivery).
You may still be eligible to receive a Direct PLUS Loan.

To become eligible for a Direct PLUS Loan, you may take one of the following actions: obtain an endorser, dispute incorrect information causing the adverse credit decision, provide proof of extenuating circumstances relating to the adverse credit history, or complete PLUS Credit Counseling.
An endorser is someone who does not have an adverse credit history and agrees to repay the Direct PLUS Loan if you do not repay it.
The endorser may not be the student on whose behalf you are requesting the Direct PLUS Loan.
You may provide a statement that contains an explanation of your extenuating circumstances and the documentation applicable/appropriate to support your claim.
The Secretary of Education is able to use discretion and, based on your circumstances, consider whether extenuating circumstances allow you to qualify for a Direct PLUS Loan.
Loss of a job, poor economy, etc. alone are generally not considered extenuating circumstances.

You have one or more of the following debts with a combined total outstanding balance greater than or equal to $2,085: charged off account, collection account, or account that is 90 or more days delinquent.
Debts listed above are not considered to be adverse credit if the combined total outstanding balance of those debts is less than $2,085.
A charged off account is any account open or closed that has been charged off/written off during the two years preceding the date of the credit report with a balance greater than zero.
A collection account is any account open or closed that has been placed in collection during the two years preceding the date of the credit report with a balance greater than zero.
An account that is 90 or more days delinquent is any open account that is currently 90 or more days past due.

Proof of extenuating circumstances for charged off accounts, collection accounts, or accounts 90 or more days delinquent includes: borrower is authorized user on the account, account has been paid in full, satisfactory repayment arrangement has been established and six months of voluntary, consecutive, on-time, full monthly payments have been made, account/debt included in a Chapter 13 Bankruptcy, debt consolidation, divorce, federal student loan has been consolidated, or federal loan is no longer in default.
Proof of extenuating circumstances for garnished wages includes: garnishment has been released.

Proof of extenuating circumstances for repossession or involuntary repossession includes: account has been paid in full, satisfactory repayment arrangement has been established and six months of voluntary, consecutive, on-time, full monthly payments have been made, borrower is authorized user on the account, divorce, or car loan has been reinstated.
Proof of extenuating circumstances for any Title IV debt that is currently in default includes: federal student loan has been consolidated or loan is no longer in default.

Proof of extenuating circumstances for mortgage account with foreclosure process started includes: divorce, loan modification agreement, mortgage is paid-in-full, or short sale has been approved and completed.

Proof of extenuating circumstances for deed in lieu reported in the past 5 years includes: divorce, mortgage is paid-in-full, short sale has been approved and completed, or timing issue regarding deed in lieu.

Proof of extenuating circumstances for foreclosure in the past 5 years includes: short sale has been approved and completed, mortgage was paid in full before foreclosure, or timing issue regarding foreclosure.
Proof of extenuating circumstances for discharged Chapter 7, 11 or 12 Bankruptcy in the past 5 years includes: timing issue regarding bankruptcy or bankruptcy chapter conversion.

Proof of extenuating circumstances for State, County or Federal Tax Lien in the last 5 years includes: satisfactory repayment arrangement has been established and six months of voluntary, consecutive, on-time, full monthly payments have been made, account/debt included in a Chapter 13 Bankruptcy, lien was incorrectly filed, or lien has been released.

If you do not wish to document extenuating circumstances, you have the following options: obtain an endorser and complete PLUS Credit Counseling, notify the school's financial aid office of your decision, or not pursue a Direct PLUS Loan at this time and discuss other options with the school's financial aid office.
Emails will be sent to the provided email address, and to prevent emails from going to spam or junk mailbox, add StudentLoanSupport@ed.gov to your trusted senders list.
Generally, in order to be eligible for funding under the Higher Education Act Title IV student assistance programs, an educational program must lead to a degree at a non-profit or public institution.

Generally, in order to be eligible for funding under the Higher Education Act Title IV student assistance programs, an educational program must prepare students for gainful employment in a recognized occupation.
With very few exceptions, any non-degree program offered by non-profit or public institutions must lead to gainful employment.
All educational programs offered at for-profit institutions must lead to gainful employment.

Subpart Q of the Student Assistance General Provisions establishes Debt-to-Earnings rates (D/E rates) to determine whether a gainful employment (GE) program prepares students for gainful employment in a recognized occupation.

A D/E rate is based on the typical loan debt and earnings of a cohort of the program's former students who completed the program, usually those who completed during a two-year period concluding two years prior to the D/E rate calculation year.
The delay in calculating the D/E rate is to account for the ramping up of the students' earnings upon completion of the program.

Two D/E rates, the Annual Earnings Rate and the Discretionary Income Rate, are calculated for each program as a measure of the ability of program completers to reasonably repay the educational debt incurred for their attendance in the program.

For the Annual Earnings Rate, the numerator is the calculated annual loan payment amount (an estimate of the annual loan repayment amount based on the median educational debt of the members of the cohort).
For the Annual Earnings Rate, the denominator is the higher of the cohort's mean or median earnings obtained from the Social Security Administration (SSA).
The Discretionary Income Rate uses the same annual loan payment amount in the numerator as the Annual Earnings Rate.
For the Discretionary Income Rate, the denominator is the higher of the mean or median earnings minus 150% of the poverty guideline.
Annual Earnings Rates of less than or equal to 8% are considered passing rates.
Annual Earnings Rates greater than 8% but less than or equal to 12% are zone rates.
Annual Earnings Rates greater than 12% are failing rates.
For the Discretionary Income Rate, rates less than or equal to 20% are passing rates.
For the Discretionary Income Rate, rates greater than 20% but less than or equal to 30% are zone rates.
For the Discretionary Income Rate, rates greater than 30% are failing rates.
D/E rate data is available for the 2015 debt measure year.

The Debt to Earnings data spreadsheet includes institution information, program information, D/E Annual Earnings Rates and D/E Discretionary Income Rates including transitional rates for relevant programs with the numbers used to calculate those rates, earnings data, and program appeal status.
On April 25, 2018, program appeal status information was updated to reflect decisions made to date.
Some appeals remain subject to review and, consequently, no decisions have been made on those appeals.
Appeals classified as abandoned represent those instances in which a school submitted a notice of intent to appeal but did not subsequently submit required information by the deadline.
Appeals classified as approved are instances in which the schools met the requirements for the U.S. Department of Education to grant the program appeals.
As of April 25, 2018, no appeals that have been reviewed have been denied.
On the Debt to Earnings data spreadsheet, a single asterisk (*) indicates that the information presented in the field has changed from what was presented prior to the April 25, 2018, update.

On the Debt to Earnings data spreadsheet, a double asterisk (**) indicates that the program rates were recalculated after the final rates were issued to correct for errors in the data reported to the NSLDS database.

The Social Security Administration (SSA) calculates and returns to the U.S. Department of Education the mean and median annual earnings of a cohort of students who completed the GE program during a specified cohort period.
At least 10 completers from a program must be matched for SSA to return mean and median earnings information for disclosure purposes.
There must be at least 30 students in the cohort sent to SSA for the Department to calculate D/E rates.
In calculating a GE program's D/E rates, the Department uses the higher of the SSA-reported mean or median earnings.
SSA does not provide the Department individual earnings data or the identity of any students.
Earnings data from the 2014 calendar year is available for informational purposes only.

The GE program earnings data spreadsheet includes OPEID and institution name, program identifiers (Classification of Instructional Program (CIP) code, credential level, and CIP code program name), the number of completers matched with earnings data by SSA, along with both the mean and median SSA earnings for the GE program.
2011 GE Informational Rate data is also available.

The 2011 GE Informational Rate data was prepared to provide institutions and the Department with preliminary information about the performance of institutions' GE programs based on the 2011 GE regulations, which have since been vacated.
A loan servicer is a company that the U.S. Department of Education assigns to handle the billing and other services on your federal student loan on its behalf, at no cost to you.
Your loan servicer will work with you on repayment options such as income-driven repayment plans and loan consolidation and will assist you with other tasks related to your federal student loans.
You should keep your contact information up to date so your loan servicer can help you stay on track with repaying your loans.
If your circumstances change at any time during your repayment period, your loan servicer will be able to help.
You should never pay an outside company for help with your federal student loans.
Your loan servicer will help you for FREE.
You should contact your servicer to apply for income-driven repayment plans, student loan forgiveness, and more.
The U.S. Department of Education will assign your loan to a loan servicer after your loan amount is first disbursed (paid out).
Your loan servicer will contact you after that.
To find out who your loan servicer is, you should call the Federal Student Aid Information Center (FSAIC) at 1-800-433-3243.
The following are loan servicers for loans that the U.S. Department of Education (ED) owns.

If your loan is for the current or upcoming school year, you should contact your school's financial aid office directly for information about loan status, the timeframes for cancelling all or part of your loan or loan disbursement, and loan disbursement amounts and timing.
Only your school's financial aid office can provide this information.

If your loan was disbursed in a past school year and you're still in school, you should keep your contact information up to date with your school and contact your loan servicer when you withdraw, graduate, drop below half-time enrollment, or stop going to school.

If you're no longer in school, you should contact your loan servicer when you change your name, address, or phone number; need help making your loan payment; have a question about your bill; or have other questions about your student loan.
If you have FFEL Program loans that are not owned by the U.S. Department of Education, you should contact your servicer for details about repayment options and tools.
If you're not sure who your servicer is, you should look for the most recent communication from the entity sending you bills for your loan payments.

If you have Federal Perkins Loans that are not owned by the U.S. Department of Education, you should contact the school where you received your Federal Perkins Loan for details about repaying your loan.
Your school may be the servicer for your Federal Perkins Loan.
If you have HEAL Program loans and you're not in default, you should contact your loan servicer for help with account-related questions.
You should use the contact information your loan servicer provided to you.
If you have HEAL Program loans and you're in default, you should contact the Debt Collection Center for help with account-related questions.
The contact information for the Debt Collection Center (if you have HEAL Program loans and you're in default) is provided.
In some cases, the U.S. Department of Education needs to transfer loans from one servicer to another servicer.
If your federal student loans are transferred from one servicer to another servicer, your loans will still be owned by the U.S. Department of Education.
The transfer to another servicer simply means that a new servicer will provide the support you need to fully repay your loans.
If your loan is transferred to a new servicer, you will receive an email or a letter from your assigned servicer to inform you about the transfer.
If your loan is transferred to a new servicer, you will receive a welcome letter from the new servicer after the new servicer receives your loans.
The welcome letter from the new servicer will provide you with the contact information for the new servicer and inform you of actions that you may need to take.

All of your loan information will be transferred from your assigned servicer to your new servicer, but you may only be able to see online information that covers the period since your new servicer took your loans over.
There will be no change in the terms of your loans if your loans are transferred to a new servicer.
Your previous loan servicer and new loan servicer will work together to make sure that all payments you make during the transfer process are credited to your loan account with the new servicer.
After you receive the welcome letter from your new servicer, you should begin sending your loan payments to your new servicer.

After you receive the welcome letter from your new servicer, you should update the new servicer's contact information with the bank or bill paying service if you use a bank or bill paying service to make your loan payments.

After you receive the welcome letter from your new servicer, you should follow the new servicer's instructions for creating an online account so that you can more easily communicate with the new servicer and keep track of your loan account.
You don't have to pay to receive help with loan services such as consolidating your federal student loans or applying for an income-driven repayment plan.
If you are contacted by a company asking you to pay enrollment, subscription, or maintenance fees to enroll you in a federal repayment plan or forgiveness program, you should walk away.
These services and more can be completed by your servicer for free!
If you withdrew from school and the school did not make a required return of loan funds to the loan servicer, you might be eligible for a discharge of your federal student loans.
Learn more about the unpaid refund discharge to see whether you might qualify.

If you withdrew from school after receiving a loan made under the William D. Ford Federal Direct Loan (Direct Loan) Program or Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) Program, the school may have been required under federal regulations to return some or all of the loan money to your loan servicer.
If the school did not make a required return of the loan funds after you withdrew, you might be eligible for a discharge of the portion of your loan that the school failed to return.
If the school that you attended is still open, you should contact that school and attempt to resolve the issue with the school before applying for an unpaid refund discharge.
If the school that you attended has closed, you should first determine if you may be eligible for a closed school discharge instead.
Contact your loan servicer for more information about determining if you are eligible for a closed school discharge.
Find out who your loan servicer is by logging in to My Federal Student Aid.
If you are ready to apply for the unpaid refund discharge, you must complete the Loan Discharge Application: Unpaid Refund and send the completed form to your loan servicer.
Only the portion of your loan that your school should have returned will be discharged.
Contact your loan servicer for more information about how much of your loan will be discharged if you are approved for a loan discharge.

If you are a parent who received a Direct PLUS Loan to help pay for your child's education and your child withdrew from school but the school did not make a required return of your parent PLUS loan funds, the amount of the loan that the school should have returned will be discharged.

Contact your loan servicer for more information if you are a parent who received a Direct PLUS Loan and your child withdrew from school but the school did not make a required return of your parent PLUS loan funds.
Loan Simulator is a new tool to help you make decisions about your student loans.
You can use Loan Simulator to find a repayment plan that meets your needs and goals.
You can use Loan Simulator to decide whether to consolidate your student loans.
Loan Simulator will guide you through a series of questions based on your selection.
If you want to find the best repayment strategy, Loan Simulator will recommend a repayment plan based on your needs and goals.
If you want to find the best repayment strategy, Loan Simulator will help you explore options like making extra payments or consolidating your loans.
If you are struggling with your payments, Loan Simulator will help you decide whether you want to temporarily stop payments or lower your monthly payment instead.
If you are struggling with your payments, Loan Simulator will help you consider a new repayment plan instead of suspending payments.
If you are struggling with your payments, Loan Simulator will help you find out about the impacts of suspending payments.
If you are struggling with your payments, Loan Simulator will help you learn how to avoid loan default.

If you want to simulate borrowing more money, Loan Simulator will help you find out what happens when you borrow more money to pay for educational expenses, returning to school, or finishing your studies later than expected.
To get the most realistic results, you should provide complete and accurate information when using Loan Simulator.
Loan Simulator cannot predict your future payments with 100% accuracy.
Loan Simulator makes several assumptions as it calculates monthly repayment amounts.
The results of Loan Simulator are for informational purposes only and should not be considered financial advice.
You are encouraged to review all available options and make decisions about borrowing and repayment that align with your individual goals.
You can contact the creators of Loan Simulator to share your feedback, ask questions, and request new features.
The creators of Loan Simulator invite you to share this tool with friends and family.
The colleges or career schools you list on your Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) form will use several pieces of information to calculate your aid.
If you meet the basic eligibility criteria for federal student aid, the financial aid office at your college or career school will determine how much financial aid you are eligible to receive.
Your eligibility depends on your Expected Family Contribution, your year in school, your enrollment status, and the cost of attendance at the school you will be attending.
The financial aid staff starts by deciding upon your cost of attendance (COA) at that school.
The financial aid staff then considers your Expected Family Contribution (EFC).
The financial aid staff subtracts your EFC from your COA to determine the amount of your financial need and therefore how much need-based aid you can get.
To determine how much non-need-based aid you can get, the school takes your cost of attendance and subtracts any financial aid you've already been awarded.
Your cost of attendance (COA) is the amount it will cost you to go to school.

If you're attending at least half-time, your COA is the estimate of tuition and fees, the cost of room and board or living expenses for students who do not contract with the school for room and board, the cost of books, supplies, transportation, loan fees, and miscellaneous expenses including a reasonable amount for the documented cost of a personal computer, an allowance for child care or other dependent care, costs related to a disability, and/or reasonable costs for eligible study-abroad programs.
Your Expected Family Contribution (EFC) is an index number that college financial aid staff use to determine how much financial aid you would receive if you were to attend their school.
The information you report on your FAFSA form is used to calculate your EFC.
The EFC is calculated according to a formula established by law.
Your family's taxed and untaxed income, assets, and benefits such as unemployment or Social Security all could be considered in the EFC formula.
Your family size and the number of family members who will attend college or career school during the year are also considered in the EFC formula.
Need-based aid is financial aid that you can receive if you have financial need and meet other eligibility criteria.
You can't receive more need-based aid than the amount of your financial need.
The need-based federal student aid programs are Federal Pell Grant, Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grant (FSEOG), Direct Subsidized Loan, Federal Perkins Loan, and Federal Work-Study.
Your school determines how much non-need-based aid you can get by using the formula: Cost of Attendance (COA) - Financial Aid Awarded So Far = Eligibility for Non-need-based Aid.
Non-need-based aid is financial aid that is not based on your EFC.
The non-need-based federal student aid programs are Direct Unsubsidized Loan, Federal PLUS Loan, and Teacher Education Access for College and Higher Education (TEACH) Grant.
The Graduated Repayment Plan starts with lower payments that increase every two years.
Payments are made for up to 10 years between 10 and 30 years for consolidation loans.
If your income is low now, but you expect it to increase steadily over time, the Graduated Repayment Plan may be right for you.

The following loans from the William D. Ford Federal Direct Loan Program are eligible for the Graduated Repayment Plan: Direct Subsidized Loans, Direct Unsubsidized Loans, Direct PLUS Loans, Direct Consolidation Loans.

The following loans from the Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) Program are eligible for the Graduated Repayment Plan: Subsidized Federal Stafford Loans, Unsubsidized Federal Stafford Loans, FFEL PLUS Loans, FFEL Consolidation Loans.
Under the Graduated Repayment Plan for Federal Education Loans except Consolidation Loans, your monthly payments start out low and increase every two years.

Under the Graduated Repayment Plan for Federal Education Loans except Consolidation Loans, payments are made for up to 10 years for all loan types except Direct Consolidation Loans and FFEL Consolidation Loans.
Under the Graduated Repayment Plan for Federal Education Loans except Consolidation Loans, your monthly payments will never be less than the amount of interest that accrues between your payments.
Under the Graduated Repayment Plan for Federal Education Loans except Consolidation Loans, your monthly payments won't be more than three times greater than any other payment.
Under the Graduated Repayment Plan for Consolidation Loans, your monthly payments start out low and increase every two years.
Under the Graduated Repayment Plan for Consolidation Loans, payments are made for a period of between 10 and 30 years for Direct Consolidation Loans and FFEL Consolidation Loans.
Under the Graduated Repayment Plan for Consolidation Loans, your monthly payments will never be less than the amount of interest that accrues between your payments.
Under the Graduated Repayment Plan for Consolidation Loans, your monthly payments won't be more than three times greater than any other payment.

If you have a Direct Consolidation Loan or FFEL Consolidation Loan, the length of your repayment period under the Graduated Repayment Plan will depend on the amount of your total education loan indebtedness.
Your total education loan indebtedness under the Graduated Repayment Plan for Consolidation Loans includes the amount of your consolidation loan and your other student loan debt.

Other student loan debt under the Graduated Repayment Plan for Consolidation Loans includes any federal student loans that are not included in the consolidation loan, as well as private education loans that are not eligible for consolidation.

The maximum amount of other student loan debt that may be considered in determining your repayment period under the Graduated Repayment Plan for Consolidation Loans may not exceed the loan amount you are consolidating.

To include other student loan debt in the determination of the repayment period for your Direct Consolidation Loan under the Graduated Repayment Plan, be sure to list those loans on your consolidation application in the section for listing loans that you do not want to consolidate, but want considered in the determination of your repayment period.
Your loan servicer, the company that handles the billing and other services on your federal student loan, can help you choose a loan repayment plan that's best for you.

Before you contact your loan servicer to discuss repayment plans, use the Loan Simulator to get an early look at what repayment plans you may be eligible for and to receive a comparison of estimated monthly payment amounts for all federal student loan repayment plans.

The comparison of estimated monthly payment amounts for all federal student loan repayment plans from the Loan Simulator is important because the Graduated Repayment Plan may not provide you with the lowest payment amount based on your individual circumstances.
You may find that your payment will be lower under another repayment plan compared to the Graduated Repayment Plan.
A school aid offer tells you what financial aid you can receive at a particular college or career school.
A school aid offer is sometimes called an award letter.
If you have applied to several schools, be sure to compare aid offers to see which school will be the most affordable.
If you listed a school on your Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA), you might get a tentative aid offer from that school.
A tentative aid offer from a school might change later.
A tentative aid offer from a school might change later if you indicated that you plan to live on campus when you submitted your FAFSA form but then later decided to live off campus.
A tentative aid offer from a school might change later if you are selected for verification.
Your financial aid package is created for you.
Your financial aid package is based on the cost of attending a particular school.
Your aid amounts will vary from school to school.
To figure out your net price or net cost for each school, follow these steps: Find the cost of attendance for your program on the aid offer.
If the school does not list the cost of attendance on the aid offer, ask the financial aid office for this figure.
The cost of attendance should include amounts you will pay to the school directly such as tuition and fees, as well as other costs such as living expenses, books and supplies, and transportation.
Subtract the grant and scholarship amounts on your aid offer from the cost of attendance amount.
Also subtract any savings you have available to put toward your school costs for the school year.
The remaining amount is your net or out-of-pocket cost.
Compare the net costs for the schools you are considering.
The net cost is the amount you will have to pay out of your pocket, using earnings from work or loan funds that you borrow.
If you have any questions or do not understand what is in your aid offer, contact the financial aid office at the school.
The financial aid office at the school is there to help you understand your aid offer.
It is important to understand what you are being offered in your aid offer, e.g., which items in the offer are grants and which are loans.
You also need to think about which aid to accept in your aid offer.
Because your aid offer might include student loans, it is important for you to compare the amount of debt you would be taking on at the schools you are considering.

If you find that you will need to take out a larger amount in private loans at one school than at another, you should pay special attention to the terms and conditions of the private loans so you understand what your obligations would be.
If your federal student loan payments are high compared to your income, you may want to repay your loans under an income-driven repayment plan.
Most federal student loans are eligible for at least one income-driven repayment plan.
If your income is low enough, your payment could be as low as $0 per month.
An income-driven repayment plan sets your monthly student loan payment at an amount that is intended to be affordable based on your income and family size.
The Revised Pay As You Earn Repayment Plan (REPAYE Plan) is an income-driven repayment plan offered by the U.S. Department of Education.
The Pay As You Earn Repayment Plan (PAYE Plan) is an income-driven repayment plan offered by the U.S. Department of Education.
The Income-Based Repayment Plan (IBR Plan) is an income-driven repayment plan offered by the U.S. Department of Education.
The Income-Contingent Repayment Plan (ICR Plan) is an income-driven repayment plan offered by the U.S. Department of Education.
If you'd like to repay your federal student loans under an income-driven plan, you need to fill out an application.
Your loan servicer will help you for FREE with applying for income-driven repayment plans, student loan forgiveness, and more.
If you're seeking Public Service Loan Forgiveness, you should repay your federal student loans under an income-driven repayment plan.
Generally, your payment amount under an income-driven repayment plan is a percentage of your discretionary income.
The percentage used to calculate your payment amount is different depending on the income-driven repayment plan.
Depending on your income and family size, you may have no monthly payment at all under an income-driven repayment plan.

For the IBR Plan, you're considered a new borrower on or after July 1, 2014, if you had no outstanding balance on a Direct Loan or FFEL Program loan when you received a Direct Loan on or after July 1, 2014.
You can use the Loan Simulator tool to estimate your monthly payment amount for all federal student loan repayment plans, including income-driven plans.
Income-driven repayment plans have different repayment periods.
Under all four income-driven repayment plans, any remaining loan balance is forgiven if your federal student loans aren't fully repaid at the end of the repayment period.

For any income-driven repayment plan, periods of economic hardship deferment, periods of repayment under certain other repayment plans, and periods when your required payment is zero will count toward your total repayment period.
Whether you will have a balance left to be forgiven at the end of your repayment period depends on factors such as how quickly your income rises and how large your income is relative to your debt.

Your loan servicer will track your qualifying monthly payments and years of repayment and will notify you when you are getting close to the point when you would qualify for forgiveness of any remaining loan balance.

If you're making payments under an income-driven repayment plan and also working toward loan forgiveness under the Public Service Loan Forgiveness (PSLF) Program, you may qualify for forgiveness of any remaining loan balance after you've made 10 years of qualifying payments, instead of 20 or 25 years.
Defaulted loans are not eligible for repayment under any of the income-driven repayment plans.
Any borrower with eligible federal student loans can make payments under the REPAYE Plan.

To qualify for the PAYE or IBR Plan, the payment you would be required to make under the PAYE or IBR plan based on your income and family size must be less than what you would pay under the Standard Repayment Plan with a 10-year repayment period.

Generally, you'll meet the requirement to qualify for the PAYE or IBR Plan if your federal student loan debt is higher than your annual discretionary income or represents a significant portion of your annual income.

To qualify for the PAYE Plan, you must also be a new borrower, meaning you must have had no outstanding balance on a Direct Loan or FFEL Program loan when you received a Direct Loan or FFEL Program loan on or after October 1, 2007, and you must have received a disbursement of a Direct Loan on or after October 1, 2011.
Any borrower with eligible federal student loans can make payments under the ICR Plan.
The ICR Plan is the only available income-driven repayment option for parent PLUS loan borrowers.

Parent borrowers may consolidate their Direct PLUS Loans or Federal PLUS Loans into a Direct Consolidation Loan and then repay the new consolidation loan under the ICR Plan, though not under any other income-driven plan.
Under all of the income-driven repayment plans, your required monthly payment amount may increase or decrease if your income or family size changes from year to year.
Each year you must recertify your income and family size, even if there has been no change in your income or family size.
Your loan servicer will send you a reminder notice when it's time for you to recertify your income and family size.
To recertify, you must submit another income-driven repayment plan application and indicate that you are submitting documentation of your income for the annual recertification of your payment amount.

If your income or family size changes significantly before your annual certification date, you can submit updated information and ask your servicer to recalculate your payment amount at any time by submitting a new application for an income-driven repayment plan.

Under the PAYE and IBR Plans, your monthly payment amount will be based on your income and family size when you first begin making payments, and at any time when your income is low enough that your calculated monthly payment amount would be less than the amount you would have to pay under the 10-year Standard Repayment Plan.

If your income ever increases to the point that your calculated monthly payment amount would be more than what you would have to pay under the 10-year Standard Repayment Plan while on the PAYE or IBR Plan, your required monthly payment will be the amount you would pay under the 10-year Standard Repayment Plan, based on the loan amount you owed when you first began repayment under the PAYE or IBR plan.
Under the REPAYE and ICR Plans, your payment is always based on your income and family size, regardless of any changes in your income.

If you don't recertify your income by the annual deadline under the REPAYE Plan, you'll be removed from the REPAYE Plan and placed on an alternative repayment plan where your required monthly payment is not based on your income.

If you don't recertify your income by the annual deadline under the PAYE Plan, the IBR Plan, or the ICR Plan, you'll remain on the same income-driven repayment plan, but your monthly payment will no longer be based on your income and instead will be the amount you would pay under a Standard Repayment Plan with a 10-year repayment period, based on the loan amount you owed when you initially entered the income-driven repayment plan.

If you don't recertify your income by the annual deadline under the REPAYE, PAYE, and IBR plans, any unpaid interest will be capitalized (added to the principal balance of your loans), increasing the total cost of your loans over time.

If you don't recertify your family size each year under any of the income-driven repayment plans, your servicer will assume that you have a family size of one, which could result in an increased monthly payment amount or loss of eligibility to make payments based on income if your actual family size is larger.
The chart in the document shows the types of federal student loans that you can repay under each of the income-driven repayment plans.

If a loan type is listed as eligible if consolidated, it means that if you consolidate that loan type into a Direct Consolidation Loan, you can then repay the consolidation loan under the specified income-driven plan.
Only federal student loans can be repaid under the income-driven plans. Private student loans are not eligible.
Income-driven repayment plans usually lower your federal student loan payments, but you will likely pay more in interest over time, sometimes significantly more.

Under current Internal Revenue Service rules, you may be required to pay income tax on any amount that's forgiven if you still have a remaining balance at the end of your repayment period under an income-driven repayment plan.
If you have only Direct Loans, you can choose from all four income-driven repayment plans.

If you're not sure which income-driven repayment plan to choose, you have the option of requesting the plan that provides the lowest payment amount, and your servicer will determine which plans you qualify for and place you on the plan with the lowest monthly payment.

If you have FFEL Program loans, your only income-driven repayment plan option is the IBR Plan, but if you consolidate your FFEL Program loans into a Direct Consolidation Loan, you'll then have access to the REPAYE, PAYE, and ICR plans.

To apply for an income-driven repayment plan, you must submit an application called the Income-Driven Repayment Plan Request, which you can submit online or on a paper form obtained from your loan servicer.

When you apply for an income-driven repayment plan, you'll be asked to provide income information that will be used to determine your eligibility for the PAYE or IBR plans and to calculate your monthly payment amount under all income-driven repayment plans.

If you filed a federal income tax return in the past two years and your current income isn't significantly different from the income reported on your most recent federal income tax return, your adjusted gross income (AGI) will be used.

If you haven't filed a federal income tax return in the past two years, or if your current income is significantly different from the income reported on your most recent federal income tax return, alternative documentation of your income will be used to determine your eligibility and calculate your monthly payment amount.
If you currently receive taxable income, you must submit a paper Income-Driven Repayment Plan Request with alternative documentation of your income, such as a pay stub.

If you currently don't have any income or if you receive only untaxed income, you can indicate that on the online or paper application, and you're not required to supply further documentation of your income.

If you are currently repaying your loans under a different repayment plan, your loan servicer may apply a forbearance to your student loan account while processing your request for an income-driven repayment plan.

If an income-driven repayment plan isn't right for you, you can contact your loan servicer to discuss other repayment options, such as the Extended Repayment Plan, loan consolidation, deferment, or forbearance.
Exit counseling provides important information to prepare you to repay your federal student loan.
If you have received a subsidized, unsubsidized or PLUS loan under the Direct Loan Program or the FFEL Program, you must complete exit counseling each time you drop below half-time enrollment.
If you have received a subsidized, unsubsidized or PLUS loan under the Direct Loan Program or the FFEL Program, you must complete exit counseling each time you graduate.
If you have received a subsidized, unsubsidized or PLUS loan under the Direct Loan Program or the FFEL Program, you must complete exit counseling each time you leave school.
The FFEL Program ended June 30, 2010 and no new loans have been made under the FFEL Program after that date.
Students who have received a subsidized, unsubsidized or PLUS loan under the Direct Loan Program or the FFEL Program, must complete exit counseling each time they drop below half-time enrollment.
Students who have received a subsidized, unsubsidized or PLUS loan under the Direct Loan Program or the FFEL Program, must complete exit counseling each time they graduate.
Students who have received a subsidized, unsubsidized or PLUS loan under the Direct Loan Program or the FFEL Program, must complete exit counseling each time they leave school.
The entire counseling process must be completed in a single session.
Most people complete counseling in 20 - 30 minutes.
A verified FSA ID is needed to complete exit counseling.
For most students planning to attend college or career school, financial aid is essential.
We'll walk you through how financial aid works, resources to pay for college, and loan repayment options.
Plan how to pay for college before you start.
Ask school counselors and the college financial aid office about state grants, college grants, and nonprofit grants and scholarships you can apply for.
Be sure to meet application deadlines for grants and scholarships.
Start saving before you get to college.
Consider prepaid tuition plans and education savings 529 plans.
Before each year of college, apply for federal grants, work-study, and loans with the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) form.
Your college uses your FAFSA data to determine your federal aid eligibility.
Many states and colleges use FAFSA data to award their own aid.
After submission of the FAFSA form, you'll receive your Student Aid Report.
Your aid offer explains the types and amounts of aid a college is offering you, and your expected costs for the year.
If you've been accepted to multiple colleges, compare the costs and aid offers.
Accept the aid from the school that's best for you and inform them of other sources of aid such as scholarships you expect to receive.
Your financial aid office will apply your aid to the amount you owe your school and send you the remaining balance to spend on other college costs.
One of the requirements to maintain financial aid eligibility is that you must make satisfactory academic progress.
Don't forget to complete a FAFSA form each year!
As you prepare to graduate, get ready to repay your student loans.
Federal student loan borrowers have a six-month grace period before you begin making payments.
Use the six-month grace period to get organized and choose a repayment plan.
If you start falling behind on your student loan payments, contact your loan servicer to discuss repayment options.

Under the Teacher Loan Forgiveness Program, if you teach full-time for five complete and consecutive academic years in a low-income school or educational service agency, and meet other qualifications, you may be eligible for forgiveness of up to $17,500 on your Direct Subsidized and Unsubsidized Loans and your Subsidized and Unsubsidized Federal Stafford Loans.

If you have a Direct Consolidation Loan or a Federal Consolidation Loan, you may be eligible for forgiveness of the outstanding portion of the consolidation loan that repaid an eligible Direct Subsidized Loan, Direct Unsubsidized Loan, Subsidized Federal Stafford Loan, or Unsubsidized Federal Stafford Loan.

You must not have had an outstanding balance on Direct Loans or Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) Program loans as of October 1, 1998, or on the date that you obtained a Direct Loan or FFEL Program loan after October 1, 1998.
You must have been employed as a full-time, highly qualified teacher for five complete and consecutive academic years, and at least one of those years must have been after the 1997-98 academic year.
You must have been employed at an elementary school, secondary school, or educational service agency that serves low-income students (a "low-income school or educational service agency").
The loan for which you are seeking forgiveness must have been made before the end of your five academic years of qualifying teaching service.

If you were unable to complete a full academic year of teaching, that year may still be counted toward the required five complete and consecutive academic years if: (1) you completed at least one-half of the academic year, (2) your employer considers you to have fulfilled your contract requirements for the academic year for the purposes of salary increases, tenure, and retirement, and (3) you were unable to complete the academic year because (a) you returned to postsecondary education, on at least a half-time basis, in an area of study directly related to the performance of the teaching service, (b) you had a condition covered under the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 (FMLA), or (c) you were called or ordered to active duty status for more than 30 days as a member of a reserve component of the U.S. armed forces.
A teacher is a person who provides direct classroom teaching, or classroom-type teaching in a nonclassroom setting.
Special education teachers are considered teachers.

To be a highly qualified teacher, you must have attained at least a bachelor's degree, received full state certification as a teacher, and not had certification or licensure requirements waived on an emergency, temporary, or provisional basis.
You are considered to have received full state certification even if you received your certification through alternative routes to certification or by passing the state teacher licensing examination.

If you are a teacher at a public charter school, you are considered to have received full state certification as a teacher if you meet the requirements set forth in the state's public charter school law.

To be considered highly qualified as an elementary school teacher who is new to the profession, you must also have demonstrated subject knowledge and teaching skills in reading, writing, mathematics, and other areas of the basic elementary school curriculum by passing a rigorous state test.

The rigorous state test for elementary school teachers who are new to the profession may be a state-required certification or licensing test or tests in reading, writing, mathematics, and other areas of the basic elementary school curriculum.

To be considered highly qualified as a middle or secondary school teacher who is new to the profession, you must also have demonstrated a high level of competency in each of the academic subjects in which you teach.

To demonstrate a high level of competency as a middle or secondary school teacher who is new to the profession, you may either pass a rigorous state academic subject test in each of the academic subjects in which you teach or successfully complete an academic major, a graduate degree, coursework equivalent to an undergraduate academic major, or an advanced certification or credential in each of the academic subjects in which you teach.

The rigorous state test for middle or secondary school teachers who are new to the profession may be a state-required certification or licensing test or tests in each of the academic subjects in which you teach.

To be highly qualified as an elementary, middle, or secondary school teacher who is not new to the profession, you must also meet the applicable requirements for an elementary, middle, or secondary school teacher who is new to the profession or demonstrate competence in all the academic subjects in which you teach based on a high, objective, uniform state standard of evaluation.

The uniform state standard of evaluation for teachers who are not new to the profession must: (1) involve multiple, objective measures of teacher competency, (2) be set by the state for both grade-appropriate academic subject matter knowledge and teaching skills, (3) be aligned with challenging state academic content and student academic achievement standards and developed in consultation with core content specialists, teachers, principals, and school administrators, (4) provide objective, coherent information about your attainment of core content knowledge in the academic subjects in which you teach, (5) be applied uniformly to all teachers in the same academic subject and the same grade level throughout the state, (6) take into consideration, but not be based primarily on, the time you have been teaching in the academic subject, and (7) be made available to the public upon request.

The school or educational service agency must be listed in the Teacher Cancellation Low Income (TCLI) Directory, which is published by the U.S. Department of Education each year, to be considered a low-income school or educational service agency.
If the TCLI Directory is not available before May 1 of any year, the previous year's directory may be used for that year.

Any questions about the inclusion or omission of a particular school in the TCLI Directory must be directed to the state education agency contact in the state where the school is located and not to the U.S. Department of Education.

State education agencies are responsible for determining which schools or educational service agencies are eligible to be reported to the U.S. Department of Education for inclusion in the TCLI Directory.

If your school or educational service agency is included in the TCLI Directory for at least one year of your teaching service, but is not included during subsequent years, your subsequent years of teaching at the school or educational service agency will still be counted toward the required five complete and consecutive academic years of teaching.

Teaching service performed at an educational service agency may be counted toward the required five years of teaching only if the consecutive five-year period includes qualifying service at an eligible educational service agency performed after the 2007-08 academic year.

All elementary and secondary schools operated by the Bureau of Indian Education (BIE) or operated on Indian reservations by Indian tribal groups under contract with BIE qualify as schools serving low-income students, even if they are not listed in the TCLI Directory.
The maximum forgiveness amount is either $17,500 or $5,000, depending on the subject area taught.
If you have eligible loans under both the Direct Loan Program and the Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) Program, $17,500 or $5,000 is a combined maximum forgiveness amount for both programs.

You may receive up to $17,500 in loan forgiveness if you were a highly qualified full-time mathematics or science teacher who taught students at the secondary school level, or a highly qualified special education teacher at either the elementary or secondary level whose primary responsibility was to provide special education to children with disabilities, and you taught children with disabilities that corresponded to your area of special education training and demonstrated knowledge and teaching skills in the content areas of the curriculum that you taught.
If you did not teach mathematics, science, or special education, you may receive up to $5,000 in loan forgiveness if you were a highly qualified full-time elementary or secondary education teacher.
You can potentially receive forgiveness under both the Teacher Loan Forgiveness Program and the Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program, but not for the same period of teaching service.

If you complete five consecutive years of qualifying teaching and receive forgiveness of your Direct Loans under the Teacher Loan Forgiveness Program, any payments you made on your Direct Loans during that five-year period cannot be counted toward the required 120 monthly payments for the Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program.
To receive Public Service Loan Forgiveness, you would need to make 120 more qualifying monthly payments after receiving forgiveness under the Teacher Loan Forgiveness Program.

If you are an AmeriCorps Program volunteer, a period of teaching that qualifies you for a benefit through the AmeriCorps Program cannot be counted toward the required five consecutive years of teaching for the Teacher Loan Forgiveness Program.
PLUS loans for parents and graduate or professional students are not eligible for teacher loan forgiveness.
Federal Perkins Loans are not eligible for teacher loan forgiveness.
However, you may be eligible to have all or a portion of your Federal Perkins Loan canceled based on your employment or volunteer service or discharged under certain conditions.
If you are in default on a loan, you are not eligible for forgiveness of that loan unless you have made satisfactory repayment arrangements with the holder of the defaulted loan.

You apply for teacher loan forgiveness by submitting a completed Teacher Loan Forgiveness Application to your loan servicer after you have completed the required five consecutive years of qualifying teaching.

The chief administrative officer of the school or educational service agency where you performed your qualifying teaching service must complete the certification section of the Teacher Loan Forgiveness Application.
If you are applying for forgiveness of loans that are with different loan servicers, you must submit a separate Teacher Loan Forgiveness Application form to each of them.
Financial aid works.
You can estimate what aid you may be eligible for when you check out FAFSA4caster.
Grants are typically based on need and don't typically have to be repaid.
Scholarships are based on academic or other achievements, or on financial need, to help pay for school.
Scholarships are free money.
Work-Study Jobs are a way to earn money to help you pay for school.
Loans are money you borrow to pay for college or career school.
You must repay your loans and the interest that accrues.
The Federal government besides Federal Student Aid provides more resources for aid.
State government provides more resources for aid.
College or career school provides more resources for aid.
Nonprofit or private organizations provide more resources for aid.

The following situations could affect your eligibility for aid: Military family members who are homeless, Students, Students enrolled at international schools, Students with a parent killed in Iraq or Afghanistan who are or have been in foster care, Non-U.S. citizens, Students with intellectual disabilities, Students with criminal convictions.
The Master Promissory Note (MPN) is a legal document.
In the Master Promissory Note (MPN), you promise to repay your loan and any accrued interest and fees to the U.S. Department of Education.
The Master Promissory Note (MPN) explains the terms and conditions of your loan.

You may receive more than one loan under a Master Promissory Note (MPN) over a period of up to 10 years to pay for your or your child's educational costs, as long as the school is authorized to use the Master Promissory Note (MPN) in this way and chooses to do so.
The school will tell you which loans, if any, you are eligible to receive.
The Direct Loan MPN for Undergraduate Students is used for Direct Subsidized Loans or Direct Unsubsidized Loans available to eligible undergraduate students.
The Direct Loan MPN for Graduate/Professional Students is used by graduate or professional degree students to borrow federal student loans.
Graduate/professional students can be eligible for Direct Unsubsidized Loans, Direct PLUS Loans, or both.
Graduate/professional students need to complete a Master Promissory Note (MPN) for each loan type they intend to receive.
Graduate/professional students should request Direct Unsubsidized Loans up to their full eligibility before borrowing Direct PLUS Loans.
The Direct PLUS Loan MPN is used for Direct PLUS Loans available to eligible parents of eligible dependent undergraduate students.

The 2011 Gainful Employment Downloadable Spreadsheet provides the public with information about educational programs that prepare students for gainful employment in a recognized occupation (GE Program).
Under the regulations that go into effect on July 1, 2012, the US Department of Education calculates metrics for GE Programs each year.
These metrics include a Repayment Rate, two Debt-to-Earnings Ratios, and three student loan medians.

The 2011 GE Informational Rate information included on the downloadable spreadsheet was produced for the purpose of providing institutions with preliminary information they can use to assess their GE Programs in preparation for the official gainful employment metrics that will first be calculated in 2013.
These FY 2011 GE Informational Rates are for informational purposes only and, as such, do not invoke any regulatory requirements, sanctions, or other adverse action.

These informational rates were prepared in advance of the years in which programs that fail the debt measures will be required to provide debt warnings and may lose eligibility after failing three out of four consecutive years.
The 2011 GE Informational Rates were not calculated for a GE Program if the program had 30 or fewer former students in the relevant two-year period.

Beginning next year, official gainful employment debt measures will include small programs using a four-year period if that four-year period results in more than 30 former students for the GE Program.

After publishing the informational rates, the Department determined that the posted Median Title IV Loans amount reflected student debt information from the most recent loan award year, but did not include debt information from previous years.
On October 25, 2012, the Department posted an updated spreadsheet.
Column V reflects the median loan debt over the course of enrollment in a program.
Column W reflects the one-year median loan debt.

The Median Private Loans, Median Institutional Loans, and Median Title IV Loans were calculated for disclosure purposes and are NOT the medians that were used in the Repayment Rate or Debt-to-Earnings Ratio calculations.
The 2011 Gainful Employment Informational Rates were prepared to provide institutions with preliminary data about the performance of their GE Programs.

The calculation of the 2011 Gainful Employment Informational Rates did not include a process for institutions to receive draft debt measures and to submit challenges, as the institutions will for official rate calculations.

For these reasons, the 2011 Informational Rates are not intended to form a basis for making any general or specific assumptions or determinations about specific GE Programs, or in making projections about future years' rates.
Vous pouvez apporter des corrections si vous avez fait une erreur dans ce que vous avez déclaré sur le formulaire FAFSA.
Si vous avez rempli un formulaire FAFSA en utilisant un numéro de sécurité sociale incorrect, vous pouvez corriger votre numéro de sécurité sociale en soumettant un nouveau formulaire FAFSA en ligne.
Vous pouvez demander au bureau d'aide financière d'une des écoles figurant sur votre rapport d'aide étudiant (Student Aid Report ou SAR) de changer votre numéro de sécurité sociale pour vous.
Vous pouvez changer votre numéro de sécurité sociale sur votre SAR papier, le signer et l'envoyer par courrier à l'adresse indiquée sur le SAR.
La plupart des informations ne peuvent pas être mises à jour car elles doivent être exactes au jour où vous avez initialement signé votre formulaire FAFSA.
Vous devez mettre à jour tout changement de votre situation de dépendance, par exemple si vous êtes enceinte ou sous tutelle légale, sauf un changement de situation matrimoniale.
Si votre situation matrimoniale change, vous devez en parler au bureau d'aide financière pour déterminer si vous pouvez mettre à jour le formulaire FAFSA.

Si et seulement si vous êtes sélectionné pour la vérification, vous devez mettre à jour votre formulaire FAFSA s'il y a un changement dans le nombre de membres de la famille dans le ménage de vos parents ou dans votre ménage.

Si le nombre de membres de la famille change en raison d'un changement de votre situation matrimoniale, vous devez en parler au bureau d'aide financière de l'école que vous prévoyez de fréquenter pour déterminer si vous pouvez mettre à jour le formulaire FAFSA.

Si et seulement si vous êtes sélectionné pour la vérification, vous devez mettre à jour votre formulaire FAFSA s'il y a un changement dans le nombre de personnes dans le ménage de vos parents qui sont à l'université ou dans le nombre de personnes dans votre ménage qui sont à l'université.

Si le nombre de personnes à l'université change en raison d'un changement de votre situation matrimoniale, vous devez en parler au bureau d'aide financière de l'école que vous prévoyez de fréquenter pour déterminer si vous pouvez mettre à jour le formulaire FAFSA.
Si vous voulez rendre vos informations FAFSA disponibles à une école supplémentaire après avoir rempli le formulaire FAFSA, vous pouvez ajouter le code fédéral de cette école.

Vous pouvez apporter des modifications de l'une des manières suivantes : faire des modifications sur fafsa.gov, écrire les corrections ou mises à jour sur votre SAR papier, le signer et l'envoyer par courrier, ou vérifier auprès du bureau d'aide financière de l'école que vous prévoyez de fréquenter.
The most vital step in applying for federal grants, work-study, and loans for college is the Free Application for Federal Student Aid FAFSA form.
The FAFSA form allows students to request federal grants, work-study, and loans, all in one application.
The FAFSA form allows students to request federal grants, work-study, and loans, all in one application.
The first step in the aid application process is to get prepared by gathering the documents you'll need.
The second step in the aid application process is to complete the FAFSA form by applying early to maximize your aid.
The third step in the aid application process is to review the Student Aid Report and make corrections, if necessary.
The fourth step in the aid application process is to respond to the aid offer by accepting the aid you want.
The fifth step in the aid application process is to receive aid from your school.
The sixth step in the aid application process is to renew your FAFSA form by reapplying each year.
The Higher Education Act of 1965, as amended (HEA), allows institutions of higher education to outsource any aspect of the institution's participation in federal student aid programs.

The Higher Education Act of 1965, as amended (HEA), allows institutions of higher education to outsource services and functions necessary for the institution to remain eligible to participate in the federal student aid programs.
The Higher Education Act of 1965, as amended (HEA), allows institutions of higher education to outsource services and functions necessary to determine a student's eligibility for federal student aid.
The Higher Education Act of 1965, as amended (HEA), allows institutions of higher education to outsource services and functions necessary to account for federal student aid funds.
The Higher Education Act of 1965, as amended (HEA), allows institutions of higher education to outsource services and functions necessary to deliver federal student aid to students.

The Higher Education Act of 1965, as amended (HEA), allows institutions of higher education to outsource services and functions necessary to perform any other aspect of the administration of the federal student aid programs.

A third-party servicer may be an individual that enters into a contract with an eligible institution to administer, through manual or automated processing, any aspect of the institution's participation in any federal student aid programs.

A third-party servicer may be a state that enters into a contract with an eligible institution to administer, through manual or automated processing, any aspect of the institution's participation in any federal student aid programs.

A third-party servicer may be a private, profit organization that enters into a contract with an eligible institution to administer, through manual or automated processing, any aspect of the institution's participation in any federal student aid programs.

A third-party servicer may be a private, non-profit organization that enters into a contract with an eligible institution to administer, through manual or automated processing, any aspect of the institution's participation in any federal student aid programs.
When contracting with an institution, a third-party servicer must comply with the various Title IV requirements applicable to its servicing agreement with the school.
When contracting with an institution, a third-party servicer's contractors must comply with the various Title IV requirements applicable to its servicing agreement with the school.
A third-party servicer is jointly and severally liable with the institution for any violation of Title IV requirements resulting from the functions performed by the third-party servicer.
