If a student's legal parents are not married to each other and live together, the student must answer the questions about both of them, regardless of whether the student's parents are of the same or opposite sex.
If a student's legal parent is widowed or was never married, the student must answer the questions about that parent.

For FAFSA purposes, a student's married parents are separated if they are considered legally separated by a state, or if they are legally married but have chosen to live separate lives, including living in separate households, as though they were not married.
When two married persons live as a married couple but are separated by physical distance or have separate households, they are considered married for FAFSA purposes.
If a student's parents are divorced or separated and do not live together, the student must answer the questions about the parent with whom the student lived more during the past 12 months.

If a student lived the same amount of time with each divorced or separated parent, the student must give answers about the parent who provided more financial support during the past 12 months or during the most recent 12 months that the student actually received support from a parent.

If a student's divorced parents live together, the student will indicate their marital status as 'Unmarried and both legal parents living together', and the student will answer questions about both of them on the FAFSA form.

If a student's separated parents live together, the student will indicate their marital status as 'Married or remarried' (NOT 'Divorced or separated'), and the student will answer questions about both of them on the FAFSA form.
If a student has a stepparent who is married to the legal parent whose information the student is reporting, the student must provide information about that stepparent as well.

For the FAFSA form questions about the student's parents' education level, the student's parents are considered to be the student's birth parents or adoptive parents (the student's stepparent is not the student's parent in these questions).
Including a student's stepparent's information on the FAFSA form helps create an accurate picture of the student's family's total financial strength.

If a student's stepparent was married to the student's parent but is now widowed, that stepparent does not count as a parent on the student's FAFSA form unless the stepparent has legally adopted the student.

Same-sex couples must report their marital status as married if they were legally married in a state or other jurisdiction (foreign country), without regard to where they live or where the student will be going to school.
The FAFSA questions use gender-neutral terminology for married parents ('Parent 1 (father/mother/stepparent)' and 'Parent 2 (father/mother/stepparent)') instead of 'mother' and 'father'.
It does not matter which parent completes which set of questions on the FAFSA form.
A student must report information about the student's parents even if the student does not live with the student's parents.

The following people are not a student's parents unless they have legally adopted the student: grandparents, foster parents, legal guardians, older brothers or sisters, uncles or aunts, and widowed stepparents.

For each parent, a student will report similar information to that the student reports for the student: basic information about the parent's identity (e.g., name, date of birth, and Social Security number if the parent has one); living situation (e.g., marital status, state of residence, household size); and financial circumstances (e.g., tax information, certain assets, certain untaxed income).

In situations such as the student's parents being incarcerated, the student having left home due to an abusive family environment, the student not knowing where the student's parents are and being unable to contact them and not having been adopted, or the student being older than 21 but not yet 24, unaccompanied, and either homeless or self-supporting and at risk of being homeless, the student may be able to submit the FAFSA form without parent information despite being considered a dependent student.

If a student is filling out the FAFSA form online or on the myStudentAid app and is unable to provide information about the student's parents, the student will have the option to indicate that the student has special circumstances that make the student unable to get the student's parents' information.

If a student submits the FAFSA form without parent information due to special circumstances, the student's FAFSA form will not be fully processed, and the student will not receive an Expected Family Contribution (EFC).

If a student submits the FAFSA form without parent information due to special circumstances, the student must immediately contact the financial aid office at the college or career school the student plans to attend.

The financial aid staff may ask a student who submitted the FAFSA form without parent information due to special circumstances for additional information to determine whether the student can be considered independent and have an EFC calculated without parent data.

A student who submitted the FAFSA form without parent information due to special circumstances should gather as much written evidence of the student's situation as possible, such as court or law enforcement documents, letters from a clergy member, school counselor or social worker, and/or any other relevant data that explains the student's special circumstance.
The financial aid office's decision about a student's dependency status is final and cannot be appealed to the U.S. Department of Education.
A student cannot be considered independent of the student's parents just because the student's parents refuse to help the student with the FAFSA form.

If a student's parents are not supporting the student at all and refuse to provide their information on the student's FAFSA form, the student can select the 'I am unable to provide information about my parent' option when filling out the FAFSA form online or on the myStudentAid app.

If a student's parents do not support the student and refuse to provide their information on the FAFSA form, the student may submit the FAFSA form without parent information, but the student will not be able to get any federal student aid other than an unsubsidized loan, and even that might not happen.

If a student submits the FAFSA form without parent information because the student's parents do not support the student and refuse to provide their information, the decision about whether the student may receive an unsubsidized loan is up to the financial aid office at the college or career school the student plans to attend, and that decision is final and cannot be appealed to the U.S. Department of Education.

If a student submits the FAFSA form without parent information, the student will not receive an EFC, which means the student will not be considered for some state- or school-based aid programs that look at the EFC to determine eligibility for their funds.
A student's parents' citizenship status does not affect the student's eligibility for federal student aid.
The FAFSA form does not ask about a student's parents' citizenship status.
If a student's parent does not have a Social Security number (SSN), the student should enter all zeroes for that parent on the FAFSA form where it asks for the SSN.
A student should NOT enter a Taxpayer Identification Number in the SSN field on the FAFSA form for a parent who does not have an SSN.

If a student's parent does not have an SSN, the parent will not be able to create an FSA ID (which requires an SSN) and therefore will not be able to sign the student's FAFSA form electronically either online or via the myStudentAid app.

If a student's parent does not have an SSN and cannot sign the FAFSA form electronically, the student can print a signature page, have the parent sign it, and then mail it to the address indicated so that the student's FAFSA form can be processed.

If a student's parent does not live in the U.S., the student should select 'Foreign Country' from the dropdown box for the question that asks about the parent's state of legal residence on the FAFSA form.

If a student's parents live and file taxes in a foreign country and do not file U.S. taxes, the student will have the opportunity to indicate that the student's parents have filed their taxes on the FAFSA form.

When the FAFSA form asks whether a student's parents filed a Puerto Rican or foreign tax return, the student should select 'Yes' if the student's parents live and file taxes in a foreign country and do not file U.S. taxes.

If a student's parents live and file taxes in a foreign country and do not file U.S. taxes, the student should convert the amounts on the foreign tax return into U.S. dollars as directed by the FAFSA help and hints.

If a student's parents live in one of the Freely Associated States, they should enter the 'Amount of Wages Earned' from their Freely Associated States tax form in the field where the FAFSA form asks for adjusted gross income.
If a student's parent does not file taxes at all, the student should select 'Not going to file' for the question that asks whether the parent has filed taxes on the FAFSA form.

If a student's parent does not file taxes at all, the student will be asked for information about how much the parent earned from work on the FAFSA form, rather than being asked for information about specific items on a tax form.
Find and apply for as many scholarships as you can.
Scholarships are free money for college or career school.
Start researching early, and meet deadlines, and you may be on your way to scholarship success.
Scholarships are gifts.
Scholarships don't need to be repaid.
There are thousands of scholarships.
Scholarships are offered by schools, employers, individuals, private companies, nonprofits, communities, religious groups, and professional and social organizations.
Some scholarships for college are merit-based.
Merit-based scholarships are earned by meeting or exceeding certain standards set by the scholarship-giver.
Merit scholarships might be awarded based on academic achievement or on a combination of academics and a special talent, trait, or interest.
Other scholarships are based on financial need.
Many scholarships are geared toward particular groups of people.
There are scholarships for women or graduate students.
Some scholarships are available because of where you or your parent work, or because you come from a certain background.
There are scholarships for military families.
A scholarship might cover the entire cost of your tuition, or it might be a one-time award of a few hundred dollars.
It's worth applying for a scholarship, because it'll help reduce the cost of your education.
You can learn about scholarships by contacting the financial aid office at the school you plan to attend and checking information in a public library or online.
You don't have to pay to find scholarships or other financial aid.
You should check out information on how to avoid scams related to scholarships.

Free sources of information about scholarships include the financial aid office at a college or career school, a high school or TRIO counselor, the U.S. Department of Labor's FREE scholarship search tool, your state grant agency, your library's reference section, foundations, religious or community organizations, local businesses, or civic groups, organizations including professional associations related to your field of interest, ethnicity-based organizations, your employer or your parents' employers.
The deadline for applying for scholarships depends on each scholarship.
Some scholarship deadlines are as early as a year before college starts.
If you're in high school now, you should be researching and applying for scholarships during the summer between your junior and senior years.
If you've missed the early scholarship application window, don't give up.
Look at scholarship information to see which ones you can still apply for.
Each scholarship has its own requirements for applying.
The scholarship's website should give you an idea of who qualifies for the scholarship and how to apply.
Make sure you read the scholarship application carefully, fill it out completely, and meet the application deadline.
The scholarship money might go directly to your college, where it will be applied to any tuition, fees, or other amounts you owe, and then any leftover funds given to you.
The scholarship money might be sent directly to you in a check.
The scholarship provider should tell you what to expect when it informs you that you've been awarded the scholarship.
If the scholarship provider doesn't tell you how you'll receive the money, make sure to ask.
A scholarship will affect your other student aid because all your student aid added together can't be more than your cost of attendance at your college or career school.

You'll need to let your school know if you've been awarded a scholarship so that the financial aid office can subtract that amount from your cost of attendance and from certain other aid, such as loans, that you might have been offered.
Any amount left after subtracting the scholarship from your cost of attendance can be covered by other financial aid for which you're eligible.
If you have questions about how a scholarship affects your other student aid, ask your financial aid office.
Are you a federal student loan borrower?
Are you confused about the student loan repayment process?
Don't let the student loan repayment process overwhelm you.
Use this checklist to help you manage and repay your federal student loans.
Be an informed borrower by learning about your loans and what to do for a smooth repayment experience.
As you work through this checklist, you'll find out how to make payments and figure out which repayment plan is best for you.
As you work through this checklist, you'll know what to do if you're having trouble making payments or think you might be eligible for loan forgiveness.
You never have to pay for help with your student loans.
Review your federal student loan history before you graduate or leave school.
Get your loan history by logging in to "My Federal Student Aid".
You'll need to create an FSA ID if you don't already have one.
As you review your information, note the current loan balance and interest rate for each loan.
As you review your information, note the loan type.
Depending on when you went to school and what loan programs your school participated in, you may have loans from different federal student loan programs.
The types of loans you received can affect what benefits are available to you.
As you review your information, note the name of the loan servicer for each loan.
A loan servicer is a company that handles the billing and other services on your loans.
Generally, you'll have one servicer for all your federal student loans, but there is a chance you could have more than one.
Get to know your loan servicer.
Your servicer helps you with your student loans for FREE.
It's important that you know who your loan servicer is and how to contact them because you will eventually be making your loan payments to your servicer.
Take this opportunity to save your servicer's phone number in your phone.
Create an online account on your servicer's website.

You can find the most detailed and up-to-date information about your loans, make your payments, and manage your loans (for example, change repayment plans or apply for a deferment) on your loan servicer's website.
When you create your account, be sure your contact information is correct.
All federal student loan borrowers must complete exit counseling before you graduate or leave school.
Exit counseling provides important information you need to help you prepare for repayment of your loans.
Check with your school to find out how they want you to complete exit counseling.
Schools have different requirements for completing exit counseling.
If you can afford it, make loan payments while you're in school, especially if your loans are accruing interest.
Making payments early can reduce the interest you pay and the cost of your loan over time.
Know when you have to start making payments after you graduate or leave school.
For most loans, you'll have six months after you graduate, leave school, or drop below half-time enrollment before you must begin making your loan payments.
For Federal Perkins Loans, you'll have nine months after you graduate, leave school, or drop below half-time enrollment before you must begin making your loan payments.
Take this time to make a plan for repayment after you graduate or leave school.
Create a budget after you graduate or leave school.
Create a budget to determine how much you can realistically afford to pay monthly toward your student loans.
Get help creating a budget.
Consider loan consolidation after you graduate or leave school.
A Direct Consolidation Loan allows you to combine all of your federal student loans into one loan with one monthly payment.
Loan consolidation can be helpful if you have multiple servicers, loans from the Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) Program, or Federal Perkins Loans.
Loan consolidation can increase your chances of qualifying for an affordable repayment plan and loan forgiveness options.
Loan consolidation may not be the best option for you.
Learn more about loan consolidation.
Set a goal for repayment after you graduate or leave school.
After you know how much you can afford to pay each month, set a goal for repaying your loans.
To begin setting your goal, ask and answer this question: Do I want to repay my loans quickly, or do I want to pay as little as possible per month?
You can't choose both options of repaying your loans quickly and paying as little as possible per month.
Any time you lower your payment, you'll be in repayment for a longer time and you'll pay more interest on your loans.
If your financial situation changes, you can change your repayment plan at any time.
If you have questions about your loan repayment options or the process, contact your loan servicer.
Select an affordable repayment plan after you graduate or leave school.
Now that you've set a goal for repayment, you can find a repayment plan that fits your goal using Loan Simulator.
If you want to pay your loans off quickly and you can afford to do it, select the Standard Repayment Plan.
Unless you consolidate, your loans will be paid off after 10 years of payments under the Standard Repayment Plan.
If you want to have the lowest monthly payment or can't afford to make payments under the Standard Repayment Plan, select an income-driven repayment plan.
Income-driven repayment plans set your payment at a percentage of your income.
Income-driven repayment plans will usually have a lower monthly payment than other plans.
Income-driven repayment plans can have payments as low as $0 per month.
With income-driven repayment plans, you'll be in repayment for up to 20 or 25 years.
If your loans are not repaid in full after 20 or 25 years under an income-driven repayment plan, the remaining balance will be forgiven.
Learn more about income-driven repayment plans.
If you don't select a specific repayment plan, your loan will be put on the Standard Repayment Plan.
You can switch to a different repayment plan at any time by contacting your loan servicer.
Know whether you are eligible for loan forgiveness based on your employer or your job after you graduate or leave school.
You may qualify for the Public Service Loan Forgiveness (PSLF) Program if you are employed by a government or a not-for-profit organization.
To qualify for the PSLF Program, you must make 120 qualifying payments under an income-driven plan.
Learn more about the PSLF Program.

You may qualify for the Teacher Loan Forgiveness Program if you teach full-time for five complete and consecutive academic years in certain elementary and secondary schools and educational service agencies that serve low-income families, and meet other qualifications.
Get the details of the Teacher Loan Forgiveness (TLF) Program.
Find out more about forgiveness, cancellation, and discharge of student loans.
Teachers may qualify for both the PSLF and TLF programs, but not for the same time period.
Make on-time payments to your loan servicer when it's time to start making payments.
Your loan servicer will provide you with a loan repayment schedule that tells you when your first payment is due, the number and frequency of payments, and the amount of each payment.
Contact your loan servicer if you haven't received the loan repayment schedule information.
Make repayment simple and save on interest by enrolling in automatic debit.
Once you enroll in automatic debit, your payments will be automatically taken from your bank account each month.
Enrolling in automatic debit will help you to stay on track with your payments.
As an added bonus, you may get a 0.25% interest rate deduction if you have Direct Loans and enroll in automatic debit.
Check your servicer's website for details on the interest rate deduction for enrolling in automatic debit.
Know your options if you can't make your loan payment.
If you don't pay the full amount due on time or if you start missing payments (even one), your loan will be considered delinquent.
Late fees may be charged to you if your loan is delinquent.
If you can't make your payments, contact your loan servicer immediately for help.
Your servicer can offer you temporary or long-term options, such as changing repayment plans, deferment, forbearance, or loan consolidation, if you can't make your payments.
Get details about what to do if you are having trouble making your payments.
You may be eligible to deduct a portion of the student loan interest you paid on your federal tax return.
Student loan interest payments are reported both to the IRS and to you on IRS Form 1098-E, Student Loan Interest Statement.
Check with the IRS or a tax advisor to see if you qualify for the student loan interest deduction.

If you are totally and permanently disabled, you may qualify for a discharge of your federal student loans and/or Teacher Education Assistance for College and Higher Education (TEACH) Grant service obligation.

A total and permanent disability (TPD) discharge relieves you from having to repay a William D. Ford Federal Direct Loan (Direct Loan Program loan), a Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) Program loan, and/or a Federal Perkins Loan or to complete a TEACH Grant service obligation.

To qualify for a TPD discharge, you must complete and submit a TPD discharge application, along with documentation showing that you meet the requirements for being considered totally and permanently disabled, to Nelnet, the servicer that assists the U.S. Department of Education with the TPD discharge process.
The words "we", "our", and "us" refer to the U.S. Department of Education throughout this page.

You can show that you qualify for a TPD discharge by providing documentation from one of three sources: the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), the Social Security Administration (SSA), or a physician.

If you are a veteran, you can qualify for a TPD discharge by providing documentation from the VA that shows you have received a VA disability determination because you (1) have a service-connected disability that is 100 percent disabling; or (2) are totally disabled based on an individual unemployability rating.

If you are eligible for Social Security Disability Insurance or Supplemental Security Income, you can qualify for a TPD discharge if you provide a copy of your SSA notice of award or Benefits Planning Query showing that your next scheduled disability review will be five to seven years or more from the date of your last SSA disability determination.
The U.S. Department of Education works with the VA and the SSA to identify those who qualify for a discharge based on their status with the VA or the SSA.

If the U.S. Department of Education receives information from the appropriate agency indicating that you qualify for a TPD discharge, they will send you a letter notifying you of your eligibility for discharge, along with a TPD discharge application.

If you want to apply for a TPD discharge based on VA or SSA documentation, all you need to do is complete and submit the discharge application, without having to provide any additional documentation of your eligibility for discharge.

You can also qualify for a TPD discharge by having a physician certify on the TPD discharge application that you are unable to engage in any substantial gainful activity due to a physical or mental impairment that (1) can be expected to result in death; (2) has lasted for a continuous period of at least 60 months; or (3) can be expected to last for a continuous period of at least 60 months.
Substantial gainful activity is a level of work performed for pay or profit that involves doing significant physical or mental activities, or a combination of both.
The physician who certifies your TPD discharge application must be a doctor of medicine (M.D.) or doctor of osteopathy/osteopathic medicine (D.O.) who is licensed to practice in the United States.

To apply for a TPD discharge, you need to complete a TPD discharge application and send it, along with any required documentation of your eligibility for discharge, to Nelnet, the TPD discharge servicer.
The TPD discharge application applies to all of your federal student loans and TEACH Grant service obligations.

Nelnet assists the U.S. Department of Education in administering the TPD discharge process and communicates with borrowers and TEACH Grant recipients on behalf of the U.S. Department of Education concerning TPD discharge requests.
To learn more about applying for a TPD discharge and to obtain a TPD discharge application, visit the TPD Discharge website at disabilitydischarge.com and select "Application Process".
You can let Nelnet know that you want to apply and request a TPD discharge application by phone or email.

If you let Nelnet know that you want to apply for a TPD discharge, any required payments on your federal student loans will stop for 120 days to give you time to submit your application and any required supporting documentation.
You can contact Nelnet by email at disabilityinformation@nelnet.net and by phone at 1-888-303-7818 Monday-Friday from 7 a.m. to 2 a.m. Eastern time (ET), and Saturday from 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. ET.
For additional ways to contact Nelnet and to get more information about applying for a TPD discharge, visit the TPD discharge website.
You can designate an individual or organization to complete and submit your TPD discharge application on your behalf, and assist you throughout the discharge process.
To designate a representative, you and your representative must complete an Applicant Representative Designation form.
Nelnet must receive and process the Applicant Representative Designation form before working with your representative.
You must submit the Applicant Representative Designation form even if your representative already has a power of attorney to act on your behalf in other matters.
To download the Applicant Representative Designation form, visit the TPD Discharge website at disabilitydischarge.com and select "Forms".
After your TPD discharge application is received, Nelnet will explain the process for the review of your application.
You will not be required to make any payments on your loans while your discharge application is being reviewed.

If the U.S. Department of Education determines that you are totally and permanently disabled based on documentation from the VA, Nelnet will notify you that your loans and/or TEACH Grant service obligation have been discharged and instruct your loan holders to return any loan payments received on or after the effective date of the VA's disability determination to the person who made the payments.

If the U.S. Department of Education determines that you are totally and permanently disabled based on SSA documentation or a physician's certification, Nelnet will (1) notify you that your loans and/or TEACH Grant service obligation have been discharged; (2) instruct your loan holders to return any loan payments received after the date Nelnet received the SSA documentation or the date the physician certified your discharge application to the person who made the payments; and (3) notify you that you will be subject to a three-year postdischarge monitoring period that begins on the date the discharge is approved, and that your obligation to repay your loans or complete your TEACH Grant service obligation will be reinstated if you do not meet certain requirements at any time during this monitoring period.

Your obligation to repay your loans or complete your TEACH Grant service obligation will be reinstated if, at any time during the three-year postdischarge monitoring period, you (1) receive annual earnings from employment that exceed the poverty guideline amount for a family of two in your state, regardless of your actual family size; (2) receive a new federal student loan under the Direct Loan Program or a new TEACH Grant; (3) receive another disbursement payment of a Direct Loan or a TEACH Grant that was first disbursed before your discharge was approved, and the new disbursement has not been returned to the loan holder or to the U.S. Department of Education within 120 days of the disbursement date; or (4) receive a notice from the SSA stating that you are no longer disabled, or that your next scheduled disability review will no longer be five to seven years from the date of your last SSA disability determination.
During the postdischarge monitoring period, Nelnet will require you to submit documentation of your annual earnings from employment on a form that Nelnet will provide.
If you do not submit the form with the required documentation of your income, your obligation to repay your loans or complete your TEACH Grant service obligation will be reinstated.
The poverty guideline amounts are updated annually by the Department of Health and Human Services.
Nelnet will notify you of the current poverty guideline amounts during each year of the postdischarge monitoring period.
For detailed information regarding the three-year postdischarge monitoring period requirements, visit the TPD Discharge website at disabilitydischarge.com and select "Monitoring Period".
If you are a veteran whose TPD discharge application is approved based on documentation from the VA, you are not subject to a postdischarge monitoring period.

If your obligation to repay your loans or satisfy your TEACH Grant service obligation is reinstated, you will again be responsible for repaying your loans in accordance with the terms of the promissory note that you signed, or satisfying your TEACH Grant service obligation in accordance with the terms of the TEACH Grant Agreement to Serve that you completed.
If you applied for a discharge of loans, your loans will be returned to the status they were in before you applied for discharge.
If a loan was in default before you applied for a TPD discharge, it will be returned to default status if your obligation to repay your loans is reinstated.

If your obligation to repay your loans or complete your TEACH Grant service obligation is reinstated, Nelnet will explain the reason for the reinstatement and provide information about what you can do if you have questions about the reinstatement or if you believe the reinstatement was based on incorrect information.

If the U.S. Department of Education determines that you do not qualify for a TPD discharge, Nelnet will (1) notify you of the reason for the denial of your discharge application; (2) explain that you may ask the U.S. Department of Education to reevaluate your discharge application if you provide new information that supports your eligibility for discharge within 12 months of the date you are notified that your discharge application has been denied; (3) explain that if you do not request reevaluation of your discharge application within 12 months of the date you are notified that your discharge application has been denied, and you still want the U.S. Department of Education to reevaluate your eligibility, you must submit a new TPD discharge application with new information about your disabling condition that was not provided with your prior discharge application; (4) explain that you are again responsible for repaying your loans, and that your loan holder will notify you when your first payment is due; and (5) explain that if you applied for a discharge of a TEACH Grant service obligation, you are again responsible for meeting the terms and conditions of the service obligation.
If you received a TPD discharge but want to go back to school, you can take out more student loans or TEACH Grants, but with some conditions.

If you received a TPD discharge based on VA documentation, SSA documentation, or a physician's certification, you must give your school a letter from a physician stating that you are once again able to engage in substantial gainful activity, and sign a statement acknowledging that you cannot get a TPD discharge of the new loan or TEACH Grant based on a disabling condition that already exists when you receive the new loan or TEACH Grant, unless that condition substantially deteriorates in the future.

If you received a TPD discharge based on SSA documentation or a physician's certification and your three-year postdischarge period has not ended, you must also resume repayment on your previously discharged loans or acknowledge that you are once again responsible for meeting the terms and conditions of your TEACH Grant service obligation.
If you received a TPD discharge of a loan before January 1, 2018, the loan amount discharged may be considered income for federal tax purposes under Internal Revenue Service (IRS) rules.
If you received a TPD discharge of a loan during the period from January 1, 2018 to December 31, 2025, the discharged loan amount will not be considered income for federal tax purposes.

For purposes of determining whether a loan amount discharged due to TPD may be treated as taxable income for federal tax purposes, the date you are considered to have received the discharge is different depending on how you qualified for the discharge.

If you are a veteran who showed that you are totally and permanently disabled based on a disability determination by the VA, you are considered to have received the discharge for federal tax purposes on the date the U.S. Department of Education approves the discharge.

If you showed that you are totally and permanently disabled based on documentation from the SSA or a physician's certification (meaning that you are subject to a three-year postdischarge monitoring period), you are considered to have received the discharge for federal tax purposes at the end of the postdischarge monitoring period.
If you receive a Form 1099-C, you should keep the form for your records, but you do not need to include it when filing your federal tax return.
Loan amounts discharged due to TPD may still be considered income for state tax purposes.
If you receive a TPD discharge of a federal student loan, you may want to consult with your state tax office or a tax professional before you file your state tax return.
For more detailed information about TPD discharge, visit the TPD discharge website at disabilitydischarge.com.
There are steps you can take to repay your federal student loan successfully.
There are steps you can take to avoid going into default on your federal student loan.
Understanding your loan agreement can help you avoid default on your federal student loan.
Staying on top of your loan information can help you avoid default on your federal student loan.
Making sure to contact your loan servicer if you are having trouble making payments can help you avoid default on your federal student loan.
If you don't make a payment on time on your federal student loan, your loan is delinquent.
If you miss making a payment on your federal student loan, your loan is delinquent.
If your federal student loan is delinquent, late fees may be assessed.
Even if you are delinquent on your federal student loan, you may still be able to avoid default.
It's important that you contact your loan servicer immediately if you are delinquent on your federal student loan.
You should avoid default on your federal student loan.
You should take the time to fully understand your loan agreement for your federal student loan.
You should take the time to fully understand the types of loans you are receiving for your federal student loan.
It's important that you not borrow more than you need for your federal student loan.
It's important that you not borrow more than you expect to be able to repay for your federal student loan.
You should develop a sound and realistic financial plan for your federal student loan.
If your federal student loan is delinquent, you should check out the Student Loan Debt Collection Assistant.
The Student Loan Debt Collection Assistant was developed by the U.S. Department of Education in partnership with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.
The Student Loan Debt Collection Assistant provides information about how to access the full range of special repayment options available to you for your federal student loan.
You should understand the type of aid you are receiving for your federal student loan.
Loans, unlike most grants, scholarships, or work-study funds, must be repaid.
You should know the type of loan you are receiving for your federal student loan.
You should understand the costs of getting the loan for your federal student loan.
You should understand the interest rate for your federal student loan.
You should understand the repayment terms for your federal student loan.
You should read 'Know Before You Owe' from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau for your federal student loan.
You should read your promissory note for your federal student loan.
A promissory note is a legal document for your federal student loan.
Signing a promissory note means you agree to repay the loan according to the terms of the note for your federal student loan.
You must repay all the loans you receive for your federal student loan, even if you don't complete your education.
You should borrow only what you need to pay for your college expenses for your federal student loan.
You should create a budget to determine how much you really need to borrow for your federal student loan.
You should contact your school's financial aid office to request a lower loan amount instead of borrowing the maximum amount you might be eligible to receive for your federal student loan.
You should complete Financial Awareness Counseling for your federal student loan.
You can find information about all of your federal student loans from the U.S. Department of Education by logging in to 'My Federal Student Aid'.

You should keep the following important documents in an organized file for your federal student loan: financial aid offers, loan counseling materials (entrance counseling and exit counseling), your promissory note(s), amount of all student loans you borrow, account number for each student loan you receive, loan servicer contact information, loan disclosure(s), payment schedules, record of your monthly payments, notes about any questions you ask about your student loan (the answers, and the name of the person to whom you spoke), deferment or forbearance paperwork and notes of any phone calls to the loan servicer, documentation that you paid your loan in full.
You should tell your loan servicer when you need help making your monthly payments for your federal student loan.
You should tell your loan servicer when you graduate for your federal student loan.
You should tell your loan servicer when you withdraw from school for your federal student loan.
You should tell your loan servicer when you drop below half-time enrollment status at school for your federal student loan.
You should tell your loan servicer when you change your name for your federal student loan.
You should tell your loan servicer when you change your address for your federal student loan.
You should tell your loan servicer when you change your Social Security number for your federal student loan.
You should tell your loan servicer when you transfer to another school for your federal student loan.
You should tell your loan servicer when you experience a change in your life that might impact your loan payments for your federal student loan.
If you are having trouble making your monthly payments for your federal student loan, you should contact your loan servicer immediately.
Your loan servicer can help you understand your options if you are having trouble making your monthly payments for your federal student loan.
You may be able to switch repayment plans to get a lower monthly payment if you are having trouble making your monthly payments for your federal student loan.
You may be able to consider an income-driven repayment plan if you are having trouble making your monthly payments for your federal student loan.
You may be able to change your payment due date if you are having trouble making your monthly payments for your federal student loan.
You may be able to get a deferment or forbearance if you are having trouble making your monthly payments for your federal student loan.
You should never ignore delinquency or default notices from your loan servicer for your federal student loan.
You might wish to combine your multiple federal student loans into a single Direct Consolidation Loan to simplify repayment.
There may be tradeoffs to combining your multiple federal student loans into a single Direct Consolidation Loan.
You should understand the advantages and possible disadvantages of consolidation before you apply to combine your multiple federal student loans into a single Direct Consolidation Loan.
Before repayment begins, develop a plan that puts you on track to pay back your loan on time and in full.
Understanding the details of repayment on your federal student loan can save you time and money.
Find out what repayment plan options are available.
Find out when you must begin making payments.
Find out how to make your payment.
Find out how to pay your loan off faster.
Find out what to do if you have trouble making payments.
The resource 'Federal Student Loans: Repaying Your Loans' provides information about federal student loan repayment plan options, finding loan history and loan servicers, and making payments.
Learn more about Repayment Plans.

Your federal student loans can't be canceled or forgiven because you didn't get the education or job you expected or you didn't complete your education unless you couldn't complete your education because your school closed.
Once you graduate, drop below half-time enrollment, or leave school, your federal student loan goes into repayment.
If you have a Direct Subsidized, Direct Unsubsidized, or Federal Family Education Loan, you have a six-month grace period before you are required to start making regular payments.
If you have a Perkins Loan, you have a nine-month grace period.
If you have a PLUS loan, you will go into repayment as soon as the loan is fully disbursed which means once it's paid out.

If you are a graduate and professional student PLUS borrower, you will be placed on an automatic deferment while in school and for six months after graduating, leaving school, or dropping below half-time enrollment.
When your loan enters repayment, your servicer will automatically place you on the Standard Repayment Plan.
You can request a different repayment plan at any time.
You can make prepayments on your loan while you are in school or during your grace period.
Any prepayment you make will not count as a qualifying payment in any loan forgiveness programs.
Your loan servicer will provide you with a loan repayment schedule that states when your first payment is due, the number and frequency of payments, and the amount of each payment.
Your billing statement will tell you how much to pay.
Your monthly payment amount depends on your repayment plan.
If you signed up for electronic communication, pay attention to your email.
Most loan servicers send an email when your billing statement is ready for you to access online.

For most federal student loan types, after you graduate, leave school, or drop below half-time enrollment, you have a six-month grace period (sometimes nine months for Perkins Loans) before you must begin making payments.
This grace period gives you time to get financially settled and to select your repayment plan.
Not all federal student loans have a grace period.
For most loans, interest accrues during your grace period.
You can choose to pay the interest that accrues during your grace period.
Paying the interest that accrues during your grace period prevents that interest from being added to the principal balance (also known as interest capitalization).
Direct Subsidized Loans and Direct Unsubsidized Loans have a six-month grace period before payments are due.
PLUS loans do not have a grace period.
If you received a PLUS loan as a graduate or professional student, you'll automatically get a six-month deferment after you graduate, leave school, or drop below half-time enrollment.
No payments are required during this six-month deferment period for graduate or professional student PLUS borrowers.

If you're a parent borrower who took out a PLUS loan to pay for your child's education, you can request a six-month deferment after your child graduates, leaves school, or drops below half-time enrollment.
If you received a Federal Perkins Loan, check with the school where you received your loan for information about the grace period.
If you are called to active military duty for more than 30 days before the end of your grace period, you will receive the full six-month grace period when you return from active duty.

If you reenroll in school at least half-time before the end of your loan's grace period, you will receive the full six-month grace period when you stop attending school or drop below half-time enrollment.

If you consolidate your loans during your grace period, you give up the remainder of your grace period and begin repayment after your Direct Consolidation Loan is processed unless you request to have the processing of your consolidation loan delayed until closer to the end of your grace period.

The U.S. Department of Education uses several loan servicers to handle the billing and other services on loans for the William D. Ford Federal Direct Loan (Direct Loan) Program and for loans that were made under the Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) Program and that the U.S. Department of Education later purchased.
Your loan servicer will set you up under the Standard Repayment Plan unless you tell your loan servicer you want a different repayment plan.
If you schedule an automatic monthly electronic debit of your loan payment from your checking or savings account, you receive a 0.25% interest rate deduction on Direct Loans.
To make a payment by postal mail, contact your loan servicer for the mailing address.
To discuss repayment plan options or change your repayment plan, contact your loan servicer.
You can use the Loan Simulator to get an early look at which repayment plans you may be eligible for and see estimates for how much you would pay monthly and overall.
You can make payments before they are due or pay more than the amount due each month.
Paying a little extra each month can reduce the interest you pay and reduce the total cost of your loan over time.
If you are having trouble making your loan payment, contact your loan servicer as soon as possible.
If you are having trouble making your loan payment, you may be able to change your repayment plan to one that lowers your monthly payment and, in some cases, may be based on your income.
If you are having trouble making your loan payment, you can also ask your loan servicer about your options for a deferment or forbearance or loan consolidation.
The resource 'Trouble Making Your Federal Student Loan Payments?' provides information on what to do if you are having difficulty making your student loan payments.
If you've missed one or more loan payments, stay in touch with your loan servicer especially if you are struggling to make payments on your loans.

If you've missed one or more loan payments, your loan servicer will explain your repayment options, such as applying for an income-driven repayment plan or a forbearance or deferment, to help you stay on track or get back on track when you fall behind.
If you've missed one or more loan payments, you definitely want to avoid going into default which occurs when you are at least nine months past due on your student loan.
The consequences of default include damage to your credit rating and future borrowing ability.
The consequences of default may also include garnishment of your wages and withholding of your tax refunds.
If you can't make payments, contact your loan servicer to find out your options.
You are generally required to repay your student loan, but in certain situations, your loan may be forgiven, canceled, or discharged.
The Tuition Assistance Top-Up program provides more money to help pay for school if the college tuition cost is more than what is covered by the Tuition Assistance (TA) program.

To be eligible for tuition assistance, a person must be approved for federal TA and meet both of the following requirements: The person qualifies for Montgomery GI Bill Active Duty (MGIB-AD) or Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits, and the cost of the course and fees is more than TA will cover.
Veterans are covered by the Tuition Assistance Top-Up program.
The Tuition Assistance Top-Up program provides more tuition funding to cover the difference between the full cost of a college course and the amount covered under active-duty TA for up to 36 months.
To get the benefits of the Tuition Assistance Top-Up program, a person needs to apply.
If a person is using the Montgomery GI Bill, the Tuition Assistance Top-Up program will pay the difference between the DoD payment and the total cost of the course.
If a person is using the Post-9/11 GI Bill, the Tuition Assistance Top-Up program will pay back the school the difference between the DoD payment and the authorized approved maximum tuition and fees.

It is important for a person to talk with their education officer and use the GI Bill Comparison Tool before applying for benefits through the Tuition Assistance Top-Up program, as using Top-Up will affect the person's GI Bill payments.

If a person uses the Montgomery GI Bill for the Tuition Assistance Top-Up program, the Montgomery GI Bill benefit will be reduced, or charged, one month of entitlement for each payment received that is equal to the full-time monthly GI Bill rate.

If a person uses the Post-9/11 GI Bill for the Tuition Assistance Top-Up program, the Post-9/11 GI Bill benefit will be charged based on training time no matter how much money is paid back, with half-time training rates reducing the GI Bill benefit by a half-month for each month the person is enrolled.
In no case will the combined amount paid by DoD and VA through the Tuition Assistance Top-Up program be more than the total cost of the course.
More information about the Tuition Assistance Top-Up program can be found in the Top-Up fact sheet PDF.
You have 60 days from the date on your decision to request a Board Appeal.
You have the option to add new evidence for a judge to review.
You will have to submit this evidence within 90 days from the date VA receives your Board Appeal form.
Adding new evidence will take longer.
You have the option to request a hearing with a judge.
A video conference hearing will take place at a VA location near you.
Requesting a hearing will take longer.
At a hearing, you and the judge will have a conversation.
The judge will listen to your testimony.
The judge may ask you a few questions.
If you have a representative, your representative may help you at the hearing.
The hearing will be transcribed and added to your appeal file.
You can add new and relevant evidence within 90 days after the hearing, but it is not required.
To request a Board Appeal, you need to fill out the Decision Review Request: Board Appeal VA Form 10182.
You can download VA Form 10182 in PDF format.
To appeal with a Veterans Law Judge, you have three options: Direct Review, Evidence Submission, or Hearing Request.
Direct Review means a Veterans Law Judge will review your case as quickly as possible.
Evidence Submission means you have additional evidence for a Veterans Law Judge to review.
Hearing Request means you want a video conference hearing with a Veterans Law Judge at a nearby VA location.
At your hearing, you and a Veterans Law Judge will have a conversation, and they will ask you questions about your appeal.
Your hearing will be transcribed and added to your appeal file.
In Part III of VA Form 10182, you need to list the issue(s) you want to appeal.
You can include all or just some of the issues VA has decided.
For each issue, you need to list the issue you disagree with and the VA decision date.
To apply, you can fill out VA Form 10182 and submit it by mail, in person, or by fax.
To submit by mail, send the completed form and any supporting documents to the Board of Veterans Appeals at PO Box 27063, Washington, D.C. 20038.
To submit in person, bring your completed form to a regional benefit office.
You can find a regional benefit office near you.
To submit by fax, fax your completed form to 844-678-8979.
You can also ask a regional benefit office for a copy of VA Form 10182 to fill out.
Alternatively, you can call the VA toll-free hotline at 800-827-1000, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. - 9:00 p.m. ET, to request a form.
If you disagree with the Board's decision, you can appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims.
You can hire an attorney to represent you, or you can represent yourself.
You can learn more about filing a Court Appeal.
You have 120 days from the date on your decision to file a Court Appeal.
Note: A Court Appeal must be filed with the Court, not with VA.
After you request a decision review, you do not need to do anything while you wait unless VA sends you a letter asking for more information.
If VA schedules exams for you, be sure not to miss them.
You can track the status of your appeal.
A Veterans Service Organization or VA-accredited attorney or agent can help you request a decision review.
You can get help requesting a decision review.
You can get answers to frequently asked questions about decision reviews.
VA assigns a disability rating based on the severity of the disability.
VA expresses the disability rating as a percentage, representing how much the disability decreases overall health and ability to function.
VA uses the disability rating to determine the disability compensation rate, so VA can calculate how much money will be received each month.
VA uses the disability rating to help determine eligibility for other benefits, like VA health care.

VA bases the rating on: The evidence given, like a doctor's report or medical test results, The results of the VA claim exam (also called a compensation and pension, or C&P, exam), if VA determines this exam is needed, Other information VA may get from other sources like federal agencies.
If there is more than one disability, VA uses a method called the whole person theory to determine the combined disability rating.
VA does this to make sure that the total VA disability rating does not add up to more than 100%, because a person cannot be more than 100% able-bodied.
If there is a disability that existed before entering the service and got worse because of the service, VA bases the monthly compensation amount on the level of aggravation.
Level of aggravation means how much worse the preservice disability got because of the military service.
In addition to the disability rating, VA may increase or decrease the compensation amount in certain situations.
After getting the disability rating, there are certain expectations about what happens next.
If there are more than one disability, VA uses the combined ratings table to calculate the combined disability rating.
The combined ratings table is separated into smaller tables, based on the percentage of the most severe, or highest rated, disability.
The full combined ratings table is available as a PDF download.
If there are 2 disabilities, each rated at 10% disabling, the combined disability rating is 19%.

To use the combined ratings table, VA follows these steps: 1) Put the disability ratings in order, from highest to lowest percentage. 2) Look for the highest rating in the left column and the next highest rating in the top row. 3) Find the number where the left column and top row meet, which is the combined value of the 2 ratings. 4) If there are 2 disabilities, round that combined value to the nearest 10% to find the combined disability rating. 5) If there are more than 2 disabilities, repeat the process for each additional disability, taking the combined value before rounding of the first 2 disability ratings and then combining that with the third highest rating, and so on until all disability ratings are added. Then round the final value to the nearest 10% to get the combined disability rating.
VA provides videos to learn more about how VA disability ratings and compensation work.
To get a VA-backed home loan as the surviving spouse of a Veteran, you'll need a Certificate of Eligibility (COE) to show your lender that you qualify for this benefit.
You'll also need to meet your lender's credit and income requirements to get a loan.

You may be able to get a COE if you're the spouse of a Veteran, and at least one of the following descriptions is true for the Veteran: The Veteran is missing in action, The Veteran is a Prisoner of War (POW), The Veteran died while in service or from a service-connected disability and you didn't remarry, The Veteran died while in service or from a service-connected disability and you didn't remarry before you were 57 years old or before December 16, 2003, The Veteran had been totally disabled and then died, but their disability may not have been the cause of death in certain situations.
A surviving spouse who remarried before December 16, 2003, and on or after their 57th birthday, must have applied no later than December 15, 2004, to establish home loan eligibility.
Applications received after December 15, 2004, from surviving spouses who remarried before December 16, 2003, will be denied by the VA.
If you're receiving Dependency & Indemnity Compensation (DIC) benefits, you'll need to fill out a Request for Determination of Loan Guaranty Eligibility Unmarried Surviving Spouses VA Form 26-1817.
You'll also need the Veteran's DD214 or other separation papers if available.
You can submit the form and discharge or separation papers to your lender for processing online, or to the VA regional loan center that serves your state.
If you're not receiving DIC benefits, you'll first need to fill out an Application for DIC, Survivors Pension and/or Accrued Benefits VA Form 21P-534EZ.
You'll also need the Veteran's DD214 or other separation papers if available, a copy of your marriage license, and the Veteran's death certificate.
You should submit the form and documents to the VA pension management center that serves your state.
Applying for your COE is only one part of the process for getting a VA-backed home loan.
Your next steps will depend on the type of loan you're looking to get and on the private bank or mortgage company that's serving as your lender.
If you already have a VA-backed loan and you're having trouble making your mortgage payments, the VA can help you avoid foreclosure and keep your house through VA financial counseling.
You can submit a military records request to get your DD214 or other military service records through the milConnect website.
To use the milConnect website to request military service records, you will need a Premium DS Logon account.
Your My HealtheVet or ID.me credentials will not work on the milConnect website.

To request your DD214 or other military records on milConnect, you need to sign in, go to Correspondence/Documentation, select Defense Personnel Records Information (DPRIS) from the drop-down menu, choose the Personnel File tab, select Request My Personnel File, fill out the form, check the boxes next to the documents you want to request, and click or tap on the Create and Send Request button.

Through the milConnect website, you can request documents from your Official Military Personnel File to view and download, including your DD214, DD215, Report of Separation, other release papers, orders and endorsements, performance reports, awards and decorations, commendatory items, qualifications, licenses, and certificates, and security clearance.

After you request your military records on milConnect, you will receive an email letting you know your request is being processed, and a second email when your request is complete and your files are ready to view and download.

You can also check the status of your military records request and view and download your files on the Personnel File tab within the Defense Personnel Records Information (DPRIS) section of milConnect.

In addition to using milConnect, you can request your military records by mailing or faxing a Request Pertaining to Military Records Standard Form SF 180 to the National Personnel Records Center (NPRC), writing a letter to the NPRC at 1 Archives Drive, St. Louis, Missouri 63138, visiting the NPRC in person, contacting your state or county Veterans agency, or hiring an independent researcher.

If you are a family member planning a burial for a Veteran in a VA national cemetery, you can call the National Cemetery Scheduling Office at 800-535-1117 to get the Veteran's DD214 or other discharge documents.

If you are the next of kin of a Veteran who has passed away, you can request a copy of the Veteran's military records by mailing or faxing a Request Pertaining to Military Records Standard Form SF 180 to the NPRC, writing a letter to the NPRC at 1 Archives Drive, St. Louis, Missouri 63138, visiting the NPRC in person, contacting your state or county Veterans agency, or hiring an independent researcher.
You may be considered the next of kin of a Veteran if you are the Veteran's surviving spouse who has not remarried, parent, child, or sibling.
If the Veteran was discharged more than 62 years ago, you can order a copy of their military records from the National Archives, as all records are opened to the public 62 years after discharge.
If the Veteran was discharged less than 62 years ago and you are not the Veteran's next of kin, you may be able to request limited information from their Military Personnel File.
If you qualify for VA health care, you'll receive coverage for the services you need to help you get and stay healthy.
Each Veteran's medical benefits package is unique.
Your medical benefits package will include care and services to help: Treat illnesses and injuries, Prevent future health problems, Improve your ability to function, Enhance your quality of life.
All Veterans receive coverage for most care and services, but only some will qualify for added benefits like dental care.

The full list of your covered benefits depends on: Your priority group, The advice of your VA primary care provider (your main doctor, nurse practitioner, or physician's assistant), The medical standards for treating any health conditions you may have.
Being signed up for VA health care meets your Affordable Care Act (ACA) health coverage requirement of having minimum essential health coverage.
If you're just separating from active duty and don't know where to start, VA can help you learn about and apply for VA health care benefits.
A member of VA's Concierge for Care (C4C) team will call you soon after your separation from military service.
The Concierge for Care (C4C) team can answer any questions you may have, process your application over the phone, and help you schedule your first VA medical appointment.

VA covers preventive care services, like: Health exams including gender-specific exams, Health education including nutrition education, Immunization against infectious diseases like flu shots, Counseling on genetic diseases (diseases that run in families).

VA covers inpatient hospital services, like: Surgeries, Medical treatments, Kidney dialysis, Acute care (short-term treatment for a severe illness or injury or after surgery), Specialized care including organ transplants, intensive care for mental and physical conditions, and care for traumatic injuries.

VA covers urgent and emergency care services, like: Urgent or emergency care at some VA health facilities, Urgent care for injuries and illnesses that need attention right away, but aren't life threatening, at urgent care locations that are part of VA's contracted network.
To use VA urgent care services, you'll need to be enrolled in VA health care, and you'll need to have received care from VA within the past 24 months.
VA covers emergency care in a non-VA hospital, clinic, or other medical setting only under certain conditions.
For VA to consider covering non-VA emergency care for a non-service-connected condition, you'll need to meet several requirements.

VA covers other services and needs, like: Mental health services to treat certain issues like posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), military sexual trauma (MST), depression, and substance use problems, Assisted living and home health care depending on your needs and income as well as space in the programs, Prescriptions written or approved by a VA doctor.

VA may cover services that your VA primary care provider concludes you need to support your treatment called ancillary services, like: Tests used to diagnose health conditions, including blood work, X-rays, and ultrasounds, Therapy and rehabilitation services, including physical therapy, vision rehab, and therapy for traumatic brain injury, Additional services, including prosthetic items, audiology care for hearing loss, and radiation oncology cancer care.

You may be able to get help with some non-medical services, like: Beneficiary travel benefits (help paying for travel related to treatment), Caregiver support (help for the person who cares for you), Veterans transportation service (help getting to and from appointments).

You can contact the patient advocate at the VA medical center where you go for care to get foreign language or American Sign Language services to help you or your family members understand your medical or health care benefits.
VA covers routine eye exams and preventive tests.
In some cases, you may get coverage for eyeglasses or services for blind or low-vision rehabilitation through VA.
In certain cases, you may receive dental care as part of your VA health benefits.
As a Veteran, you may be able to get assisted living, residential live-in, or home health care through VA.

Services not included in your VA medical benefits package: Abortions and abortion counseling, Cosmetic surgery (unless VA concludes that it's medically necessary), Gender alteration (gender reassignment surgery), Health club or spa membership, Medicines and medical devices that aren't approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) (except in 2 special cases: You're in an approved clinical trial, or You're seriously ill and your VA health care provider prescribes a new, unapproved medicine because there are no other comparable treatment options), Inpatient hospital or outpatient care if you're a patient or inmate in a non-VA government agency institution, if that agency must provide the care or services by law.

VA will fill prescriptions by a non-VA community provider only if: You're enrolled in VA health care, You have an assigned VA primary care provider, You've given your VA provider your medical records from your non-VA provider, Your VA provider agrees with the prescription.
Whether you need to pay a VA copay will depend on factors like your income level, disability rating, and military service history.
Most Veterans need to complete a financial assessment when they enroll to determine if they qualify for free VA health care.
At VA, they take a team approach to health care with you at the center.
Research shows this kind of team approach leads to better quality care, more satisfied patients, and fewer hospital visits.
When you sign up for VA health care, you become part of the country's largest integrated health care system with more than 1,200 care locations serving nearly 9 million Veterans each year.
If you have other forms of health care coverage like a private insurance plan, Medicare, Medicaid, or TRICARE, you can use VA health care benefits along with these plans.

If you're an eligible American Indian or Alaska Native Veteran, when you receive care through an Indian Health Service facility or Tribal Health facility that has a reimbursement agreement with VA: You don't need VA to approve or "preauthorize" your care before you get treated, and You don't need to pay a VA copay.

If you live in Alaska, you may be able to receive care through an Indian Health Service facility or Tribal Health facility even if you're not an eligible American Indian or Alaska Native Veteran, but you'll need to get preauthorization before you receive care, and you may need to pay a copay for your care.
If you're signed up for the VA health care program, you can manage your VA health and benefits online: Refill your prescriptions, Send a secure message to your health care team.
If you're signed up for the VA health care program, you can also check the status of a disability or pension claim online.
You can change your VA direct deposit information for disability compensation, pension benefits, or education benefits online.
To change your information for disability compensation and pension benefits, you can update your VA.gov profile.
To change your information for GI Bill and other education benefits, you'll need to sign in to eBenefits.
The direct deposit feature on VA.gov is being tested out.
If you see the direct deposit feature in your VA.gov profile, you can update your direct deposit information from there.
If you don't see the direct deposit feature in your VA.gov profile, you need to go to eBenefits and sign in to change your direct deposit information.
To change your direct deposit information on eBenefits, you'll need your bank's routing number as well as your account number.

To cancel your direct deposit payments, switch from paper checks to direct deposit, or change the address on your paper checks, you need to call VA at 800-827-1000 or go to your nearest VA regional office.
To change your VA direct deposit and contact information online for education benefits, you'll need to sign in to eBenefits.
To use the eBenefits feature for changing direct deposit and contact information, you'll need a Premium DS Logon account.
Your My HealtheVet or ID.me credentials won't work on the eBenefits website.
To change your information on eBenefits, you'll need your bank's name, address, phone number, and routing number as well as your account number.
You can change your VA direct deposit or contact information by mail or phone.

To change your information by mail, you need to fill out a VA Direct Deposit Enrollment VA Form 24-0296 and mail the completed form to: Department of Veterans Affairs, 125 S. Main Street, Suite B, Muskogee, OK 74401-7004.
VA Form 24-0296 is a PDF that you can download.
To change your information by phone, you need to call VA at 800-827-1000 or TTY: 800-829-4833.
You can sign in to VA.gov and change your address or other contact information in your VA.gov profile.

Changing your address or contact information in your VA.gov profile will update your information across disability compensation, pension benefits, claims and appeals, Vocational Rehabilitation & Employment (VR&E), and VA health care.

You should contact VA if you have other changes to your information, such as a change in marital status, having a baby, adopting a child, or any other life change that could affect your rating or payment.

If you move or change your mailing address, you need to update your contact information so VA sends information about your benefits and services as well as any prescriptions, lab test results, or appointment reminders to the right location.
If you have a disability rating of 30% or higher, you may be able to add eligible dependents to your VA disability compensation to get a higher payment (also called a benefit rate).
If your disability gets worse, you can file a claim for an increase in benefits.
After you apply for VA health care benefits, VA will send you a letter in the mail to let you know if your application has been approved.
If more than a week has passed since you gave VA your application and you haven't heard back, please don't apply again.
If more than a week has passed since you gave VA your application and you haven't heard back, you should call VA's toll-free hotline at 877-222-8387.
If VA approves your application, you should wait for your welcome call from VA.

During the welcome call from VA, VA will welcome you to the VA health care program, help you with scheduling your first doctor's appointment, and answer any questions you may have about your health care benefits.
If VA approves your application, you should read your Veterans Health Benefits Handbook.
The Veterans Health Benefits Handbook will be sent to you by mail.
The Veterans Health Benefits Handbook will explain your specific health care benefits based on the priority group VA assigned you, how much you'll pay in copays, and other helpful information.
If VA approves your application, you should get your Veterans Health Identification Card (VHIC).
The VHIC is the card you'll use for ID and to check in at your VA health care appointments.
To get your VHIC, you should contact your local VA medical center and speak with the enrollment coordinator.
The enrollment coordinator at your local VA medical center will help you arrange to have your picture taken for your new VHIC.
You can also request your VHIC at your next VA health care appointment.
If VA approves your application, you should go to your first VA doctor's appointment.
If you requested a doctor's appointment when you applied, VA will set up an appointment for you with a VA doctor or provider and send you a notice with your appointment time in the mail.
If you didn't ask for a doctor's appointment when you applied, VA will help you set up your appointment during your welcome call.
If you have other questions, you should contact your local VA medical center or clinic and ask for the enrollment coordinator, the urgent care clinic, or the emergency room.
If you want to know more about your VA health care benefits, your health care team, and where you'll go for care, VA can help.
If you're signed up for VA health care, you can manage your VA health and benefits online through VA.gov.
Through VA.gov, you can refill your prescriptions, send a secure message to your health care team, and check the status of a disability or pension claim.
If you need help accessing services, you should call VA's toll-free hotline at 877-222-8387, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. ET.
To update your personal information, such as income, address, and insurance, you should fill out a Health Benefits Update Form VA Form 10-10EZR.
The Health Benefits Update Form VA Form 10-10EZR can be downloaded as a PDF.
You should mail the completed Health Benefits Update Form VA Form 10-10EZR and any supporting materials to: Health Eligibility Center, 2957 Clairmont Road, Suite 200, Atlanta, GA 30329.
You can also get help updating your personal information by visiting your local VA facility.
If you disagree with VA's decision, you can file an appeal.
VA will send you a letter with the reason they are not approving your application.
The letter from VA will include instructions on how to appeal the decision.
VA's 'How Do I Appeal?' booklet can be downloaded as a PDF.
To appeal VA's decision, you should gather any evidence to support your eligibility to stay enrolled in VA health care and send it to VA.
Evidence to support your eligibility may include documents like doctor's reports, medical tests, or military service records.
You will have 60 days from the date you received VA's letter to send them this evidence before they make their final decision.
During these 60 days, you will keep and can continue to use your VA health care benefits.
If VA decides not to keep you enrolled in VA health care after this time, you have the right to appeal their decision.
You can learn how to appeal a VA decision from the PDF.
You can cancel, or decline, enrollment in VA health care at any time.
To cancel your enrollment in VA health care, you should submit a signed and dated document like a letter telling VA that you want to cancel your coverage.
You can bring the document to cancel your enrollment to a VA medical center or mail it to: VA Health Eligibility Center (HEC), 2957 Clairmont Road, Atlanta, GA 30329.
Canceling your enrollment in VA health care may impact your health care coverage requirements under the Affordable Care Act if you don't have other health care.
You may reapply for VA health care at any time.
If you reapply for VA health care, VA will consider you a new applicant.
If you reapply for VA health care, VA will base your eligibility on the eligibility requirements at that time.
With VA Appointments tools, you can schedule some VA health care appointments online.
With VA Appointments tools, you can view details about upcoming appointments.
With VA Appointments tools, you can organize your health calendar.
To find out if you are eligible to use VA Appointments tools and how to sign up to begin using these tools, you can visit the My HealtheVet health management portal.
If you are a Veteran in crisis or concerned about one, you can connect with Veterans Crisis Line responders for confidential help.
Many of the Veterans Crisis Line responders are Veterans themselves.
The Veterans Crisis Line service is private, free, and available 24/7.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night, you can call 800-273-8255, then select 1.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night, you can start a confidential Veterans chat.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night, you can text 838255.
If you have hearing loss, you can call TTY: 800-799-4889 to connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder, you can also call 911.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder, you can also go to the nearest emergency room.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder, you can also go directly to your nearest VA medical center.
It does not matter what your discharge status is or if you are enrolled in VA health care to connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder.
You can find your nearest VA medical center.
The fastest way to make all your VA appointments is usually to call the VA health facility where you want to receive care.
If you cannot keep an existing appointment, you should contact the facility as soon as possible to reschedule or cancel.
You can find your VA health facility's phone number.
