You can view your VA appointments online.
You can schedule or cancel a VA appointment online.
VA Appointments tools offer a secure, web-based way to schedule, view, and organize your VA appointments online.
With VA Appointments tools, you can schedule some of your VA medical appointments online.
With VA Appointments tools, you can reschedule and cancel appointments made online.
With VA Appointments tools, you can view appointments on your health calendar.
With VA Appointments tools, you can find the location of the VA facility for your appointments.
With VA Appointments tools, you can set up email reminders for upcoming appointments.
With VA Appointments tools, you can print a list of your future appointments.
With VA Appointments tools, you can look up past appointments from the last 2 years.
With VA Appointments tools, you can add non-VA appointments to your health calendar.
You can use VA Appointments tools if you are enrolled in VA health care.
You can use VA Appointments tools if you are scheduling your appointment with a VA health facility that uses online scheduling.
You can use VA Appointments tools if you have had an appointment at that VA health facility within the last 2 years.
You can apply for VA health care.

To use VA Appointments tools, you must have one of the following free accounts: a Premium My HealtheVet account, a Premium DS Logon account used for eBenefits and milConnect or that you can create on VA.gov, or a verified ID.me account.
There are 3 different My HealtheVet account types.
You can check the list of VA facilities that are currently using the online scheduling tool.
The number of VA facilities and types of appointments available for online scheduling may expand in the future.
You can view a list of VA facilities currently using online scheduling.
The types of VA medical appointments you can schedule online will depend on the VA health facility where you are receiving care.
You may be able to schedule outpatient appointments for primary care, mental health, optometry, and audiology online.
You should check with the specific facility where you are receiving care to ask about scheduling appointments online.
You can see which VA facilities currently use online scheduling.
You can find a VA health facility.
You cannot use VA Appointments tools to schedule non-VA appointments.
You can learn more about getting care from non-VA providers.
If you use Secure Messaging with your VA health care team, you may be able to use this service to schedule and cancel appointments.
You can learn more about Secure Messaging.
The VA Appointments website is a secure website.
The VA follows strict security policies and practices to protect your personal health information.
Only you and your VA health care team will have access to your secure messages.
If you print or download any messages, you will need to take responsibility for protecting that information.
You can get tips for protecting your personal health information.
You can get answers to your questions about VA Appointments tools within the My HealtheVet web portal.
You can read VA Appointments FAQs.
You can contact the My HealtheVet Help Desk.
You can find out how to contact the My HealtheVet Help Desk online.
You can call the My HealtheVet Help Desk at 877-327-0022.
For TTY, you can call the My HealtheVet Help Desk at 800-877-8339.
The My HealtheVet Help Desk is available Monday through Friday, 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. CT.
Military sexual trauma (MST) refers to sexual assault or repeated, threatening sexual harassment that happened while a Veteran was in the military.
This can happen to both women and men.
If you were involved in any sexual act against your will during your time in the military, you may have experienced MST.
Find out how to access our free services that can help you recover.
If you're a Veteran in crisis or concerned about one, connect with our caring, qualified Veterans Crisis Line responders for confidential help.
Many of them are Veterans Crisis Line responders themselves.
This service is private, free, and available 24/7.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night: Call 800-273-8255, then select 1.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night: Start a confidential Veterans chat.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night: Text 838255.
If you have hearing loss, call TTY: 800-799-4889.
You can also: Call 911.
You can also: Go to the nearest emergency room.
You can also: Go directly to your nearest VA medical center.
It doesn't matter what your discharge status is or if you're enrolled in VA health care.
Find your nearest VA medical center.
We provide free, confidential private counseling and treatment to male and female Veterans for both mental and physical health problems linked to MST.
Our services include: MST-related treatment and support at every VA medical center, and providers knowledgeable about treating the aftereffects of MST at each facility.
Our services include: Specialized outpatient mental health services focused on sexual trauma at many VA locations.
Our services include: Counseling with professionals who are specially trained to treat conditions related to sexual trauma at Vet Centers across the country.
Our services include: Specialized MST treatment in a residential live-in or inpatient setting including gender-specific programs for Veterans who need more intensive care.
Our services include: Treatment and support for health conditions linked to MST, like: Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).
Our services include: Treatment and support for health conditions linked to MST, like: Depression.
Our services include: Treatment and support for health conditions linked to MST, like: Substance use problems.
If you're a Veteran who has experienced MST, you can get help through VA.
You don't need to have a service-connected disability rating, and you may be able to get MST-related care even if you don't qualify for other VA services.
You also don't need to have reported the MST or have other proof that it happened.
Here's how to access VA services for MST: If you have a VA primary care provider, talk to that professional about what you've been through.
All our primary care providers are trained in MST and can help you figure out if you have related issues, like PTSD or depression.
Your provider will offer treatment and support as needed.
If you don't have a VA primary care provider, call your nearest VA medical center and ask to speak to the MST coordinator.
You should feel free to ask for a provider of a specific gender if that makes you feel more comfortable.
Find a VA medical center near you.
If you'd prefer to receive MST-related care outside of a medical setting, get free confidential counseling, alcohol and drug assessment, and other support at one of our 300 community Vet Centers.
Find a Vet Center near you.
If you're homeless or at risk of becoming homeless: Contact the National Call Center for Homeless Veterans at 877-424-3838 for help 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
A trained VA counselor will offer information about VA homeless programs, health care, and other services in your area.
The call is free and confidential.
Visit our website to learn about VA programs for Veterans who are homeless.
Learn about our homelessness programs.
Call or visit your local VA Community Resource and Referral Center.
Even if you don't qualify for VA health care, our staff can help you find non-VA resources you may qualify for in your community.
Find your local Community Resource and Referral Center.
You can also call the VA general information hotline at 800-827-1000, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. ET.
See our Guide to VA Mental Health Services PDF.
You can't get compensation for the traumatic event itself.
But you may be able to get disability compensation for conditions resulting from MST like PTSD the most common mental health condition linked to MST.
Find out if you can get disability benefits for PTSD.
Or get help applying for disability compensation by: Reading our fact sheet on disability compensation for conditions related to MST.
Read the fact sheet PDF.
Or get help applying for disability compensation by: Talking to the MST coordinator at your nearest VA regional office.
Find an MST coordinator near you.
Download our military sexual trauma brochure for Veterans: In English PDF.
Download our military sexual trauma brochure for Veterans: En español PDF.
Download our educational brochure for men who've experienced MST: In English PDF.
Download our educational brochure for men who've experienced MST: En español PDF.
Watch a video about MST, its effects on survivors, and VA services available to Veterans who've experienced MST.
Access more fact sheets, articles, and resources, and learn more about our programs and services.
Get VA information about mental health.
Go to our Make the Connection website to hear stories from Veterans about their own experiences with the effects of MST, and find more resources and support.
Visit Make the Connection.
Go to the Department of Defense (DoD) Safe Helpline website, a crisis support service for members of the DOD community affected by sexual assault.
When you contact the Safe Helpline, you can remain anonymous meaning you don't have to give your name.
You can get 1-on-1 advice, support, and information 24/7 by phone, text, or online chat.
You can also connect with a sexual assault response coordinator near your base or installation.
Visit SafeHelpline.org.
VA provides a disability compensation benefit known as an annual clothing allowance.
The annual clothing allowance is for veterans whose prosthetic or orthopedic device such as a wheelchair or skin medicine damages their clothes.

To get the annual clothing allowance, the veteran must meet both of the following requirements: The veteran's prosthetic or orthopedic device or skin medicine causes damage to the veteran's clothes. The veteran needs the prosthetic or orthopedic device or skin medicine because of an injury or illness related to the veteran's military service called a service-connected condition.
The annual clothing allowance benefit covers veterans.
The annual clothing allowance benefit can be a one-time payment or a yearly payment.
The current annual clothing allowance rate is $817.48.
To get the annual clothing allowance benefits, the veteran needs to file a claim for disability compensation.
To get the annual clothing allowance benefits, the veteran also needs to fill out an Application for Annual Clothing Allowance VA Form 10-8678.
The veteran needs to bring the Application for Annual Clothing Allowance VA Form 10-8678 to the prosthetic representative at the veteran's local VA medical center.
To get the yearly annual clothing allowance payment, the veteran needs to qualify by August 1 of that year.

The veteran may be able to get more than one annual clothing allowance payment if at least one of the following is true: The veteran has more than one prosthetic or orthopedic device. The veteran has more than one skin medicine. The veteran's device or skin medicine affects more than one type of clothing.
If the veteran qualifies for the annual clothing allowance, the veteran will receive payments between September 1 and October 31.
The veteran can use VA's facility locator to find the nearest VA medical center.
For more information about the annual clothing allowance, the veteran can call VA at 800-827-1000, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. ET.
VA collects applications for the annual clothing allowance throughout the year and holds them until the August 1 closing date.
Posttraumatic stress can happen after someone goes through a traumatic event such as combat, an assault, or a disaster.
Most people have some stress reactions following trauma.
If the reactions don't go away over time or they disrupt your life, you may have posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).
You can get disability compensation or benefits if you have symptoms of PTSD.
If you're a Veteran in crisis or concerned about one, you can connect with Veterans Crisis Line responders for confidential help.
Many of the Veterans Crisis Line responders are Veterans themselves.
The Veterans Crisis Line service is private, free, and available 24/7.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night, you can call 800-273-8255, then select 1.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night, you can start a confidential Veterans chat.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night, you can text 838255.
If you have hearing loss, you can call TTY: 800-799-4889 to connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night.
You can also call 911, go to the nearest emergency room, or go directly to your nearest VA medical center to get help.
It doesn't matter what your discharge status is or if you're enrolled in VA health care to get help.

You may be able to get disability benefits from VA if you have symptoms related to a traumatic event (the stressor) or your experience with the stressor is related to the PTSD symptoms, and you meet all of the requirements listed.

For getting disability benefits from VA, all of these must be true: The stressor happened during your service, you can't function as well as you once could because of your symptoms, and a doctor has diagnosed you with PTSD.
VA considers any of these to be a traumatic event: You suffered a serious injury, personal or sexual trauma, or sexual violation, or you were threatened with injury, sexual assault, or death.
Veterans are covered for VA disability benefits for PTSD.
The kinds of disability benefits you can get from VA for PTSD are health care, compensation payments, and treatment for PTSD.
To get these benefits from VA, you'll need to file a claim for disability compensation.

When you file a disability claim with VA for PTSD, you'll also need to fill out one of these additional forms: A Statement in Support of Claim for Service Connection for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (VA Form 21-0781) or A Statement in Support of Claim for Service Connection for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder Secondary to Personal Assault (VA Form 21-0781a).
In VA's screening process for PTSD disability benefits, they'll focus on getting a full understanding of your PTSD to help determine your eligibility for disability benefits.
VA won't offer you treatment during the screening process for PTSD disability benefits.
If you're looking for treatment options, you should talk with your health care provider or learn more about accessing VA services for PTSD.
If you're in crisis and need to talk with someone right now, you can connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder any time, day or night.
VA has made great progress in treating PTSD and has brought more mental health providers to VA medical centers to help give the best care to Veterans with PTSD.
You may be able to get disability benefits if you have an illness or other condition believed to be caused by your contact with an environmental hazard while serving in the military.
This may include contact with particulate matter or large burn pits in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Djibouti in the Horn of Africa.
This may include contact with a large sulfur fire at Mishraq State Sulfur Mine near Mosul, Iraq.
This may include contact with hexavalent chromium at the Qarmat Ali water treatment plant in Basra, Iraq.
This may include contact with pollutants from a waste incinerator near the Naval Air Facility at Atsugi, Japan.
Veterans are covered for disability benefits related to environmental hazards.
The disability benefits that can be received include health care and compensation payments.
To get these benefits, you will need to file a claim for disability compensation.
When filing the claim, you will have to show that your health problems are linked to your contact with certain environmental hazards while serving in the military.
You should send in all information such as the Burn Pit Registry supporting your claim that you came into contact with certain environmental hazards.
You can check the Burn Pit Registry.
You have 1 year from the date on your decision to request a decision review, unless you have a fiduciary claim or a multiple party claim.
There are rare situations where the 1 year deadline for requesting a decision review does not apply.

The decision review options are: add new and relevant evidence by filing a Supplemental Claim, ask for a new look from a senior reviewer by requesting a Higher-Level Review, appeal to a Veterans Law Judge by requesting a Board Appeal.
To file a Supplemental Claim, you are adding new evidence that supports your case or identifying evidence for review.
A reviewer will look at all the evidence for a Supplemental Claim and determine whether it changes the decision.
You can file a Supplemental Claim within 1 year of a decision if you have new evidence.
You cannot file a Supplemental Claim if you have a fiduciary claim or you are one of multiple people claiming the same benefit.
To request a Higher-Level Review, you are asking for another review of the same evidence.
A senior reviewer will take another look at your case for a Higher-Level Review and determine whether the decision can be changed based on a difference of opinion or an error that VA made.
You can request a Higher-Level Review of an initial claim or Supplemental Claim decision.
The Higher-Level Review option is not available after a Higher-Level Review or Board Appeal.
To request a Board Appeal, a judge at the Board of Veterans Appeals in Washington, D.C., will review your case.
You can request a Board Appeal after an initial claim, Supplemental Claim, or Higher-Level Review decision.
You cannot request 2 Board Appeals in a row.
If you disagree with the Board's decision and have new and relevant evidence that supports your case, you can file a Supplemental Claim.
You can also appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims after a Board decision.
You do not need to do anything while you wait for a decision review unless VA sends you a letter asking for more information.
If VA schedules exams for you during a decision review, be sure not to miss them.
You can track the status of your claim or appeal during a decision review.
A Veterans Service Organization or VA-accredited attorney or agent can help you request a decision review.
There are frequently asked questions available about decision reviews.
How to apply for the GI Bill and related benefits is a topic.
The GI Bill is a VA education benefit.
A person can find out how to apply for the GI Bill and other VA education benefits as a Veteran.
A person can find out how to apply for the GI Bill and other VA education benefits as a service member.
A person can find out how to apply for the GI Bill and other VA education benefits as a qualified family member.
Before starting an application, a person needs to find out if they are eligible for VA education benefits.
Before starting an application, a person needs to gather the documents and information listed that they will need to apply for education benefits.
Before starting an application, a person needs to see what benefits they will get at the school they want to attend.
A person needs to use the GI Bill Comparison Tool before starting an application.

To apply for Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (also called Chapter 31) or educational and career counseling (also called Chapter 36) benefits and services, a person needs to use a different application.
A person needs to find out how to apply for Vocational Rehab and Employment.
A person needs to learn more about Educational and Career Counseling.
The documents and information a person needs to apply include their Social Security number.
The documents and information a person needs to apply include their bank account direct deposit information.
The documents and information a person needs to apply include their education and military history.
The documents and information a person needs to apply include information about the school or training facility they want to attend or are attending now.
A person can apply for the GI Bill and related benefits by mail.
A person can call 888-GI-BILL-1 (888-442-4551), Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. ET, to request that the VA send the application to them.
A person needs to fill out the application and mail it to the VA regional claims processing office that is in the same location as their school.
There is a list of regional claims processing offices.
A person can apply for the GI Bill and related benefits in person.
A person can go to a VA regional benefit office and have a VA employee help them apply.
There are VA regional benefit offices near the person.
A person can work with their school's certifying official, who is usually in the Registrar or Financial Aid office at the school, to apply.
A person can work with a trained professional called an accredited representative to get help applying for education benefits.
A person can get help filing their claim for education benefits.
After a person applies, they cannot make changes to their application.
If a person has questions about VA education benefits after applying, they can call 888-GI-BILL-1 (888-442-4551), Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. ET.
If the VA has asked a person for documents after applying, the person needs to upload them through the GI Bill website.
There is a GI Bill website.
You need to request changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits if you are transferring to a different school.
You need to request changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits if you are changing your educational, professional, or vocational goal.

You need to request changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits if you left your school or training program due to poor attendance, progress, or conduct, and you are now reentering the same program.
You need to request changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits if you were receiving VA education benefits as a Veteran, and now you want to receive benefits while on active duty.
If you are a Veteran or service member, you need to submit a Request for Change of Program or Place of Training VA Form 22-1995 to request changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits.
VA Form 22-1995 is a form that can be completed online.

If you are the dependent of a Veteran or service member, you need to submit a Dependent's Request for Change of Program or Place of Training VA Form 22-5495 to request changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits.
VA Form 22-5495 is a form that can be completed online.
To complete your request for changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits, you need your Social Security number.
To complete your request for changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits, you need your VA file number.
To complete your request for changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits, you need your bank account direct deposit information.
To complete your request for changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits, you need basic information about your service history.
To complete your request for changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits, you need basic information about your education or training plans and goals.
To complete your request for changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits, you need basic information about your current or former school or training program.
To complete your request for changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits, you need basic information about the new school or training program you plan to attend.

If you are the dependent of a Veteran or service member, you need the Veteran or service member's Social Security number or VA file number to complete your request for changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits.

If you are the dependent of a Veteran or service member, you need basic information about the Veteran or service member's service history to complete your request for changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits.
You can submit your request for changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits by mail.

To submit your request for changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits by mail, you need to download the appropriate form, fill it out, and mail it to the VA regional claims processing office that is in the same region as your school.
VA Form 22-1995 is the form that Veterans and service members need to download to submit their request for changes to their GI Bill or other VA education benefits by mail.
VA Form 22-5495 is the form that dependents of Veterans and service members need to download to submit their request for changes to their GI Bill or other VA education benefits by mail.
You can submit your request for changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits in person at a VA regional benefit office.

You can submit your request for changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits with the help of your school's certifying official, who is usually in the Registrar or Financial Aid office at the school.
You can work with a trained professional called an accredited representative to get help submitting your request for changes to your GI Bill or other VA education benefits.
Substance use treatment is available for Veterans.
Many Veterans have problems with the use of alcohol, tobacco, street drugs, and prescription medicines.
Veterans can connect with the Veterans Crisis Line responders for confidential help.
The Veterans Crisis Line is a private, free, and available 24/7 service.
The Veterans Crisis Line responders are caring and qualified.
Many of the Veterans Crisis Line responders are Veterans themselves.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night, Veterans can call 800-273-8255, then select 1.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night, Veterans can start a confidential Veterans chat.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night, Veterans can text 838255.
If Veterans have hearing loss, they can call TTY: 800-799-4889 to connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night.
Veterans can also call 911 to get help.
Veterans can also go to the nearest emergency room to get help.
Veterans can also go directly to their nearest VA medical center to get help.
Veterans can get help regardless of their discharge status or if they are enrolled in VA health care.
VA provides many options for Veterans seeking treatment for substance use problems ranging from unhealthy alcohol use to life-threatening addiction.
The services VA offers Veterans depend on their specific needs.
VA offers proven medication options to stop substance use safely and services to get stable.
VA offers medically managed detoxification to reduce cravings.
VA offers methadone and buprenorphine for opiate addiction.
VA offers drug substitution therapies and newer medicines.
VA offers nicotine replacement or other medicines for stopping tobacco use.
VA offers short-term outpatient counseling for substance use problems.
VA offers intensive outpatient treatment for substance use problems.
VA offers marriage and family counseling for substance use problems.
VA offers self-help groups for substance use problems.
VA offers residential live-in care for substance use problems.
VA offers continuing care and relapse prevention for substance use problems.
VA offers special programs for Veterans with specific concerns like women Veterans, returning combat Veterans, and homeless Veterans.
VA offers treatment and support for health conditions that can be related to substance use problems, like posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and depression.
To access VA services for substance use problems, Veterans first need to apply for VA health care.
Once Veterans have signed up for VA health care, they can talk to their VA primary care provider about their substance use.
The VA primary care provider can help Veterans get screened for substance use problems and related issues like PTSD or depression.
The VA primary care provider can offer treatment and support as needed for substance use problems.
If Veterans do not have a VA primary care provider or have never been seen in a VA hospital or clinic, they can find a Substance Use Disorder (SUD) program near them.
If Veterans do not have a VA primary care provider or have never been seen in a VA hospital or clinic, they can call the VA general information hotline at 800-827-1000.
If Veterans do not have a VA primary care provider or have never been seen in a VA hospital or clinic, they can contact their local VA medical center.

If Veterans served in Operation Enduring Freedom (OEF), Operation Iraqi Freedom (OIF), or Operation New Dawn (OND), they can call their local VA medical center and ask to speak to the OEF/OIF/OND coordinator.
Veterans may still be able to get care for substance use problems even if they do not have VA health care benefits.
If Veterans have served in a combat zone, they can get free private counseling, alcohol and drug assessment, and other support at one of the 300 community Vet Centers.
If Veterans are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless, they can visit the VA website to learn about VA programs for homeless Veterans.
If Veterans are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless, they can contact the National Call Center for Homeless Veterans at 877-424-3838 for help 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
The National Call Center for Homeless Veterans offers information about VA homeless programs, health care, and other services in the area.
The call to the National Call Center for Homeless Veterans is free and confidential.
Even if Veterans do not qualify for VA health care, the staff at the local VA Community Resource and Referral Center can help them find non-VA resources they may qualify for in their community.
Veterans can download the Guide to VA Mental Health Services PDF for more information and support.

Veterans can visit the Make the Connection website to hear stories from other Veterans about their experiences with overcoming drug and alcohol problems, and to get access to more resources and support.
Veterans can visit the self-help resources guide on the VA website to get links to books, web resources, and mobile applications that have been reviewed and recommended by VA experts.
Veterans can visit the resources section of the VA website to find more trusted resources outside VA that can offer information and support.
Veterans can download the Stay Quit Coach mobile app designed to help Veterans with PTSD quit smoking.
The Stay Quit Coach app is based on steps proven to work to help people quit smoking.
The Stay Quit Coach app includes tools to control cravings and manage smoking triggers, messages to keep Veterans going, medication reminders, and more.
The Fully Developed Claim (FDC) program is the fastest way to get a VA pension claim processed.
There is no risk to taking part in the FDC program.
Participation in the FDC program is optional and won't affect benefits.

If a claim is filed in the FDC program and the VA decides that additional documents exist that are needed to decide the claim, the VA will remove the claim from the FDC program and process it as a standard claim.
To turn in a claim under the FDC program, the claimant should send all supporting documents they have and provide information about supporting documents that they don't have.
To turn in a claim under the FDC program, the claimant should fill out an Application for Pension (VA Form 21P-527EZ).
When filing a claim under the FDC program, the claimant should turn in all necessary income and net-worth information.
When filing a claim under the FDC program, the claimant should turn in all private medical records related to the claim.
When filing a claim under the FDC program, the claimant should provide information about any health records available at a federal facility like a VA medical center or clinic.
When filing a claim under the FDC program, the claimant should go to any VA medical appointments required to decide the claim.
With a standard claim, the claimant will give the VA permission to gather evidence or records.
With a standard claim, the claimant needs to give the VA enough information about the evidence so the VA can request it from the right person or agency.

If a person or agency refuses to turn over evidence for a standard claim, asks for money for the evidence, or can't get the evidence, the VA will ask the claimant to try to get the evidence or records.
For a standard claim, it is the claimant's responsibility to make sure the VA receives all requested records that aren't at a federal agency or office.
To claim non-service-connected pension benefits, the evidence must show that the claimant's net worth and income are within certain limits.

To claim non-service-connected pension benefits, at least one of the following must be true about the claimant's service: the claimant served on active duty for any length of time during a period of war and was discharged due to a service-connected disability, or the claimant started on active duty before September 8, 1980, and served at least 90 days either all at one time or combined over time on active duty with at least 1 day being during wartime, or the claimant started on active duty after September 7, 1980, and served at least 2 years or the full period for which they were called or ordered to active duty, with at least 1 day being during wartime (some exceptions may apply to this longer minimum service requirement).

To claim non-service-connected pension benefits, at least one of the following must also be true about the claimant's current situation: the claimant is at least 65 years old, or the claimant is a patient in a nursing home for long-term care, or the claimant receives Social Security disability benefits, or the claimant is unemployable because of a disability that doesn't go away, or the claimant has a disability that doesn't go away and that makes it impossible for them to work, or the claimant has a disease or disorder that the VA determines causes permanent and total disability.

To claim non-service-connected pension benefits with Aid and Attendance or Housebound benefits, at least one of the following must be true: the claimant has corrected vision of 5/200 or less in both eyes, or the claimant has contraction of the concentric visual field to 5 degrees or less, or the claimant is a patient in a nursing home due to the loss of mental or physical abilities, or the claimant needs another person to help them with daily activities like bathing, eating, dressing, adjusting prosthetic devices, or protecting them from the hazards of their environment, or the claimant is bedridden and has to spend most of the day in bed because of their disability.

To claim increased disability pension benefits based on being housebound, at least one of the following must be true: the claimant has a single permanent disability that is 100% disabling, and the claimant is confined to their home, or the claimant has a disability rated 60% or higher in addition to the disability that qualifies them for a pension.
To claim benefits for a disabled child, the evidence must show that the child, before turning 18 years old, became unable to support themselves due to a mental or physical disability.
Under the FDC program, the VA will request relevant records that the claimant identifies and authorizes the VA to get from a federal facility like a VA medical center.
Under the FDC program, the VA will schedule a health exam or get a medical opinion for the claimant, if the VA decides it is needed for the claim.
With the standard claim process, the VA will request relevant records that the claimant identifies and authorizes the VA to get from a federal facility like a VA medical center.
With the standard claim process, the VA will schedule a health exam or get a medical opinion for the claimant, if the VA decides it is needed for the claim.

With the standard claim process, the VA will make every reasonable effort to request relevant records that the claimant authorizes the VA to get that aren't at a federal facility, such as records from state or local governments, documents from a private doctor, hospital records, or records from current or former employers.
Under the FDC program, the claimant needs to turn in the information and evidence at the same time as filing the claim.
If the claimant turns in additional information or evidence after sending in a fully developed claim, the VA will remove the claim from the FDC program and process it as a standard claim.

If the VA decides a claim under the FDC program before 1 year from the date the VA receives the claim, the claimant will have the rest of that 1-year period to turn in additional information or evidence to support the claim.
With the standard claim process, the claimant needs to turn in the information and evidence as soon as possible.
With the standard claim process, the claimant has up to 1 year from the date the VA receives the claim to turn in any information and evidence.

If the VA decides a claim under the standard process before 1 year from the date the VA receives the claim, the claimant will have the rest of that 1-year period to turn in additional information or evidence to support the claim.
When filing a claim, the claimant will be able to upload all supporting documents and evidence, like income information and any medical records related to the claim.

If the claimant is claiming non-service-connected pension with Housebound or Aid and Attendance benefits, the claimant and their doctor will need to fill out a form called an Examination for Housebound Status or Permanent Need for Regular Aid and Attendance (VA Form 21-2680).

If the claimant is in a care facility and claiming non-service-connected pension with Housebound or Aid and Attendance benefits, the claimant should also fill out a Request for Nursing Home Information in Connection with Claim for Aid and Attendance (VA Form 21-0779).
If the claimant is claiming a child in school between the ages of 18 and 23, the claimant should fill out a Request for Approval of School Attendance (VA Form 21-674).
If the claimant is claiming benefits for a seriously disabled child, the claimant should turn in all private medical records for the child's disabilities.
You can use this tool to check the status of a VA claim or appeal for compensation.
You can use this tool to track your disability compensation including claims based on special needs like an automobile or clothing allowance.
You can use this tool to track your Veterans or Survivors Pension benefits.
You can use this tool to track your Special monthly compensation such as Aid and Attendance.
You can use this tool to track your Dependency and Indemnity Compensation (DIC) to help pay for a Veteran's burial and funeral expenses.
You can use this tool to track your Burial allowance.
You can use this tool to check the status of a claim or appeal for VA health care.
You can use this tool to check the status of a claim or appeal for GI Bill or other education benefits.
You can use this tool to check the status of a claim or appeal for Vocational rehabilitation and employment.
You can use this tool to check the status of a claim or appeal for A home loan.
You can use this tool to check the status of a claim or appeal for Certificate of Eligibility (COE).
You can use this tool to check the status of a claim or appeal for A Specially Adapted Housing (SAH) or Special Housing Adaptation (SHA) grant.
You can use this tool to check the status of a claim or appeal for Life insurance.
You can use this tool to check the status of a claim or appeal for A pre-need determination of eligibility to be buried in a VA national cemetery.

To use this tool, you'll need to have one of these free accounts: A Premium My HealtheVet account, or A Premium DS Logon account used for eBenefits and milConnect, or that you can create here on VA.gov, or A verified ID.me account.
Once you're signed in, you can go to your "My VA" dashboard to check your VA claim or appeal status.
In the "Track Claims" section of your "My VA" dashboard, you'll see a summary of the latest status information for any open claims or appeals you may have.
You can click on the "View Status" button for a specific claim to go to a page with more details about that claim's status and supporting evidence.
Supporting evidence for a claim may include documents like a doctor's report or medical test results.
When you check your VA claim or appeal status, you'll see where your claim or appeal is in the review process, and when the review is expected to be completed.

When you check your VA claim or appeal status, you can view details such as any evidence you've filed online, any evidence VA has requested from you, any additional evidence, your claim type, what you've claimed, and your representative for VA claims.
You can only upload documents online to support your initial claim, but you can't upload documents online to support an appeal.
You won't see documents that you sent to VA by mail or fax, or that you brought to VA in person, or that VA has restricted to protect confidentiality or privacy.
This is a secure website that follows strict security policies and practices to protect your personal health information.
If you print or download anything from the website, you'll need to take responsibility for protecting that information.
If you have more questions, you can call VA at 800-827-1000, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. ET.
Totally disabled or terminally ill policyholders may be eligible for certain benefit options if they have VA life insurance coverage.
The spouse of a totally disabled or terminally ill policyholder may also be eligible for certain options if diagnosed with a terminal illness.

The document provides information about SGLI extension for policyholders who become disabled, waiver of premiums for policyholders who become totally disabled, and accelerated benefits for terminally ill policyholders.

A policyholder may be able to keep their SGLI coverage for up to 2 years after the date they left the military if they are within 2 years of their separation date and totally disabled or have certain conditions.
A waiver of premiums means a policyholder won't have to pay their life insurance premiums.

A policyholder may be able to get a waiver of their life insurance premiums if they have a mental or physical disability that prevents them from being able to hold a job, they are covered under Service-Disabled Veterans Life Insurance (S-DVI), their total disability happens before they are 65 years old but after the effective date of their life insurance policy, and their total disability continues for at least 6 months in a row.
Eligible Veterans, service members, and covered spouses of service members can get accelerated benefits.
With accelerated benefits, a policyholder can get up to 50% of the face value of their coverage in increments of $5,000 paid to them before death.

A policyholder or their covered spouse may be able to get accelerated benefits early if they have SGLI, Family SGLI, or VGLI life insurance, and they or their covered spouse has a written statement from a doctor saying they have 9 months or less to live.
Only the insured service member or Veteran may apply for accelerated benefits, and no one may apply on their behalf.
In the case of a terminally ill spouse, only the insured may apply for accelerated benefits.
The document provides instructions on how to apply for accelerated benefits depending on the type of coverage the policyholder has (SGLI, VGLI, or Family SGLI).
The remaining amount of the face value of the insurance policy is paid to the designated beneficiary or beneficiaries upon the policyholder's death.
In the case of a terminally ill spouse, the remaining amount of the insurance policy is paid to the insured upon the spouse's death.
The Affordable Care Act (ACA) is also known as the health care law.
The Affordable Care Act (ACA) was created to expand access to coverage, control health care costs, and improve health care quality and care coordination.
You do not have to pay a penalty if you do not have health insurance in 2019 or any year after that.

Through the end of 2018, the Affordable Care Act (ACA) required all U.S. taxpayers to have health coverage that met a minimum standard called the minimum essential coverage requirement unless they qualified for an exemption due to certain life events, financial status, or other factors.
If you had affordable health coverage options, but chose not to buy health insurance through the end of 2018, you would have to pay a fee when filing your taxes.
The fee for not having health insurance through the end of 2018 was known as an individual shared responsibility payment.
The individual shared responsibility payment for not having health insurance through the end of 2018 was also sometimes called the penalty, fine, or individual mandate.
Congress changed the part of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) related to the individual shared responsibility payment for plans starting in 2019 and after.
The individual shared responsibility payment no longer applies starting in plan year 2019 for which you will file taxes in April 2020.
If you did not have coverage or an exemption in 2018, you may still have to pay a fee when you file your 2018 taxes in April 2019.

Your health coverage meets the minimum essential coverage requirement for 2018 if you were signed up for one of the following programs: the VA health care program, the Civilian Health and Medical Program of the Department of Veterans Affairs (CHAMPVA), CHAMPVA through the Program of Comprehensive Assistance to Family Caregivers, the Spina Bifida Health Care Benefits Program, or a Department of Defense TRICARE plan.
If you were covered under one of the programs listed above in 2018, you will not have to pay the fee when you file your 2018 taxes.
The Affordable Care Act (ACA) does not change your VA health benefits or your out-of-pocket costs.
If you are not signed up for a VA or Department of Defense health care program, you may be able to get coverage through the Health Insurance Marketplace.
Open enrollment for 2019 Health Insurance Marketplace coverage is over.

You can still enroll or change plans for 2019 Health Insurance Marketplace coverage if you have certain life changes or qualify for free or low-cost coverage through Medicaid or the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP).
We offer the help you need to build your career and find the opportunities that are right for you.
We offer many programs and services that may help including free health care and, in some cases, free limited dental care.
We can also help you connect with resources in your community, like homeless shelters or faith-based organizations.

In 1973, a fire occurred at the National Personnel Records Center (NPRC) in St. Louis, Missouri.
The fire destroyed the records held for Veterans who were discharged from the Army and Air Force during certain periods of time.
The records of Veterans discharged from the Army between November 1, 1912, and January 1, 1960, may have been destroyed in the 1973 NPRC fire in St. Louis.
The fire destroyed 80% of the records held for Veterans discharged from the Army during the time period between November 1, 1912, and January 1, 1960.
The 1973 NPRC fire did not involve records for Army retirees and Reservists who were alive on July 12, 1973.

The records of Veterans discharged from the Air Force between September 25, 1947, and January 1, 1964, with surnames beginning with Hubbard and running through the end of the alphabet, may have been destroyed in the 1973 NPRC fire in St. Louis.

The fire destroyed 75% of the records held for Veterans discharged from the Air Force during the time period between September 25, 1947, and January 1, 1964, with surnames beginning with Hubbard and running through the end of the alphabet.
To reconstruct military records, the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) submits a specific request to the NPRC for any additional service records they may have or can find for the Veteran.
With the information provided by the VA, the NPRC searches for documents that may help to reconstruct the Veteran's records.

The NPRC may reach out to other government agencies to reconstruct portions of the Veteran's service treatment records by reviewing unit records, morning reports, and hospital admission records from the surgeon general's office.
To get the records needed to support a VA disability compensation claim, the Veteran should fill out the National Archives Request for Information Needed to Reconstruct Medical Data (NA Form 13055).
The NA Form 13055 will be used by the VA as a request to the NPRC to reconstruct the Veteran's records.
The Veteran should provide information about their assignments during service, including unit, company, battalion, regiment, squadron, group, and wing, on the NA Form 13055.

The Veteran can provide supplemental records or documents to help decide their VA disability compensation claim, such as statements from service medical personnel, certified buddy statements or affidavits from fellow service members, military accident and police reports, examination reports related to employment or insurance, letters or photographs from their time in service, prescription records, and photocopies of any service treatment records or medical reports from private hospitals, clinics, or doctors who treated them during service or shortly after separation.

The Veteran should submit their disability compensation claim, NA Form 13055, and any supporting documents either online, by mail, in person, or with the help of a trained professional, such as an accredited attorney, claims agent, or Veterans Service Officer (VSO).
If you fall far behind on your mortgage payments, your mortgage servicer (the company that handles collecting the money for your lender) can take your house to cover the money owed.
This process is called foreclosure.
Find out how our VA loan technicians can help you avoid foreclosure and keep your house.
If you are a Veteran or the surviving spouse of a Veteran, we will provide financial counseling even if your loan is not a VA direct or VA-backed loan.
If you have a VA direct or VA-backed loan, you can contact us anytime to request that we assign a VA Loan Technician to your loan.
Our technicians can offer you financial counseling and help you deal with your servicer or work with you directly in the case of a VA direct loan.
If you have a VA direct or VA-backed loan and it is 61 days past due, we will automatically assign a VA Loan Technician to your loan.
If you are late with a mortgage payment, or think you might be late with your next payment, contact your loan servicer right away.
The sooner you contact your loan servicer, the sooner they can help you find a solution.
If you are nervous about contacting your servicer, or if you would like our help and advice, please contact a VA Loan Technician at 1-877-827-3702.
There are 6 general ways you can try to avoid a foreclosure: Repayment plan, Special forbearance, Loan modification, Extra time to arrange a private sale, Short sale, Deed in lieu of foreclosure.
A Repayment plan lets you go back to making your regular payments, with an added amount each month to cover the ones you have missed.
A Special forbearance plan gives you some extra time to repay the missed mortgage payments.
A Loan modification plan lets you add the missed mortgage payments and any related legal costs to your total loan balance, and you and your servicer then come up with a new mortgage payment schedule.
An Extra time to arrange a private sale plan lets you delay a foreclosure so you have time to sell your home.

A Short sale plan means your servicer might agree to a short sale, where the servicer will accept the total proceeds from the home sale even if it is less than the full amount you owe on the mortgage as full payment of the debt you owe.
A Deed in lieu of foreclosure plan lets you avoid the foreclosure process by signing over the deed to the home to your servicer, and the home will then belong to the servicer.
Our VA Loan Technicians can help you figure out which option is best for you.
Contact a VA Loan Technician at 1-877-827-3702.

You have 1 year from the date on your decision to request a decision review.
When you choose to file a Supplemental Claim, you are adding new evidence that supports your case or identifying evidence for review.
A reviewer will determine whether the new evidence changes the decision when you file a Supplemental Claim.
When you choose to request a Higher-Level Review, you are asking for another review of the same evidence.
A senior reviewer will take another look at your case and determine whether the decision can be changed based on a difference of opinion or an error when you request a Higher-Level Review.
You can request a Higher-Level Review of an initial claim or Supplemental Claim decision.
The Higher-Level Review option is not available after a Higher-Level Review or Board decision.
A judge at the Board of Veterans Appeals in Washington, D.C., will review your case when you request a Board Appeal.
You can request a Board Appeal after an initial claim, Supplemental Claim, or Higher-Level Review decision.
You cannot request two Board Appeals in a row.
You have the option to bring an action in a United States district court.
You have 6 years to bring an action in a United States district court after accrual of the right for which the claim is made.
If you disagree with the Board's decision and have new and relevant evidence that supports your case, you can file a Supplemental Claim.
You can appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims after a Board decision.
You do not need to do anything while you wait for a decision review unless VA sends you a letter asking for more information.
If VA schedules exams for you, be sure not to miss them while waiting for a decision review.
A Veterans Service Organization or VA-accredited attorney or agent can help you request a decision review.
If you are using VA educational assistance, and you are struggling with the coursework, VA may help you pay for a tutor.

You can get this benefit if you are using VA educational assistance and you meet all of the following requirements: You are enrolled in an educational program for half-time or more, You are taking a course that is difficult, You have to take the course as part of your educational program.
Veterans are covered for this benefit.
The benefit you can get is money to pay for a tutor.
VA will not pay more than $100 per month for tutoring.
VA will not pay more than $1,200 total for tutoring.
To get this benefit, your course instructor or teacher at your school must agree that you need a tutor and write a letter on your behalf.
The instructor should send the letter to your school's certifying official and add a copy to your VA student file.
If your school approves your need for a tutor, it will assign you a tutor and confirm the tutor's hourly pay.
After you get tutoring, you, your tutor, and your school's certifying official must fill out and sign an Application for Individualized Tutorial Assistance VA Form 22-1990t.
If you are using the Post-9/11 GI Bill, your instructor must also sign section 18 of VA Form 22-1990t.
You can download VA Form 22-1990t in PDF format.
The form must be signed and dated on or after the date of the last certified tutoring session, which is item 12b on the form.
If you are using the Montgomery GI Bill (MGIB), you can get up to $600 before VA charges your benefits.
If you are using the Post-9/11 GI Bill or Dependents Educational Assistance (DEA), VA will not charge your GI Bill benefits.
Reservists using the Reserve Educational Assistance Program (REAP) benefit cannot also get tutorial assistance.

VA offers many programs and services that may help if you're homeless or at risk of becoming homeless, including free health care and, in some cases, free limited dental care.
VA can help you connect with resources in your community, like homeless shelters or faith-based organizations, if you're homeless or at risk of becoming homeless.
You can call the National Call Center for Homeless Veterans at 877-424-3838 for help 24 hours a day, 7 days a week if you're homeless or at risk of becoming homeless.
You'll talk privately with a trained VA counselor for free if you call the National Call Center for Homeless Veterans.
You can contact your nearest VA medical center and ask to talk with the VA social worker if you're homeless or at risk of becoming homeless.
If you're a female Veteran who is homeless or at risk of becoming homeless, you can ask for the Women Veterans Program Manager at your nearest VA medical center.
You can find the nearest VA medical center if you're homeless or at risk of becoming homeless.
If you're a Veteran in crisis or concerned about one, you can connect with VA's caring, qualified Veterans Crisis Line responders for confidential help.
Many of VA's Veterans Crisis Line responders are Veterans themselves.
VA's Veterans Crisis Line service is private, free, and available 24/7.
You can chat online with a trained VA staff member if you're a Veteran in crisis or concerned about one.

VA-backed home loans are a type of VA home loan.

Veterans need to apply for a VA home loan Certificate of Eligibility (COE).
Surviving spouses of Veterans or spouses of Veterans who are missing in action or being held as Prisoners of War may be eligible for a VA home loan COE.
