VA provides disability compensation pay for conditions related to military service.
VA offers pension benefits for wartime Veterans or surviving spouses or children.
The VA Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (VR&E) program helps service-connected disabled Veterans with employment options and training if required.
VA offers life insurance options for service members, Veterans, and family members.
How to apply for VA Voc Rehab and Employment is about finding out how to apply for VA Voc Rehab and Employment also known as Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment, VR&E, or Chapter 31 benefits.

If you already have a VA disability rating, you can sign in to your eBenefits account, select Apply, click Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment Benefits, select the Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment benefit you are applying for, and if you are eligible, VA will invite you to an orientation session at your nearest VA regional benefit office.
You can go to eBenefits to apply for VA Voc Rehab and Employment if you already have a VA disability rating.
If you are a service member who has not yet received a service-connected disability rating, you do not need to wait for a rating.

Service members who have not yet received a service-connected disability rating can fill out VA Vocational Rehabilitation - Getting Ahead After You Get Out VA Form 28-0588 to apply for VA Voc Rehab and Employment.

You may be eligible for VR&E benefits and services if you are in at least one of the following situations: going through the Physical Evaluation Board process, expecting an other than dishonorable discharge and have a VA memorandum rating of 20% or more, or entered in the Integrated Disability Evaluation System (IDES).

Severely injured active-duty service members can automatically receive VR&E benefits before VA issues a disability rating, because of Sec. 1631 of the National Defense Authorization Act PL 110-181, which has been extended to September 30, 2018, through Sec. 724 of Public Law 113-291.

After you apply for VA Voc Rehab and Employment, VA will schedule a meeting for you with a Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor (VRC) to find out if you have an employment handicap and if you are eligible for VR&E benefits and services.

You have an employment handicap if your service-connected disability limits your ability to prepare for, obtain, and maintain suitable employment, which is a job that does not make your disability worse, is stable, and matches your abilities, aptitudes, and interests.
After VA makes an entitlement decision, you and your VRC will work together to develop a rehabilitation plan, which outlines the rehabilitation and other services that VR&E will provide.
You can also meet with VRCs called VetSuccess on Campus (VSOC) counselors at schools participating in the VetSuccess on Campus (VSOC) program.
A rehabilitation plan is a written plan that outlines the resources VA will use to help you find employment.

Depending on your situation, your VRC will work with you to choose one of the following support-and-services tracks to help you find and keep a job, and live as independently as possible: reemployment with a former employer, job placement and counseling services for new employment, help with starting your own business to help you find work in a different field that better suits your abilities and interests, long-term training or services if you cannot return to work right away, or independent living services.

After your VRC creates your rehabilitation plan, they will help you put your plan into action, provide ongoing counseling, and help you get tutorial assistance, job training, work-readiness support, and medical referrals.
You can upload evidence to support your disability claim through our claim tracking tool.
The claim tracking tool helps you check the status of your claim.
If you filed a standard disability claim, you should upload evidence as soon as you can.
You can continue uploading documents for up to one year from the date we receive your claim.
If you don't provide any evidence or give us the information we need to help you get evidence within 30 days, we may make a decision on your claim earlier.
If we decide your claim early, you'll still have the rest of the one-year period to provide more information or evidence.
If you upload more evidence after you've submitted a fully developed claim, we'll remove your disability claim from the Fully Developed Claims program and process it as a standard claim.
If we decide your claim earlier than one year from the date we received the claim, you'll still have the rest of the year to provide any additional information or evidence.

You should upload the following kinds of documents to support your disability claim: Federal and state records, Private medical treatment records, Supporting statements, Disability Benefits Questionnaires (DBQs), Any additional forms needed to support your claim.

Federal and state records include: Your military medical records, Your military personnel records, Any Social Security Administration or other federal or state medical treatment records that support your claim if you've served in either of these branches, Any treatment or personnel records from your National Guard or Reserve unit.
If you don't have copies of federal and state records, you can ask us to request them for you as part of the claim process.
Private medical treatment records include: Doctor's reports, X-rays, Medical lab or test results.
You should upload private medical treatment records if you've seen a non-VA health care provider for diagnosis or treatment.
Supporting statements should be from people who know about, or who you've talked to about, your claimed medical condition and how and when it occurred.
You can ask for supporting statements from: People who served with you, Service members, Your family and friends, Clergy members, Law enforcement officers.
Disability Benefits Questionnaires (DBQs) are forms that ask for specific information we need to determine a disability rating for different medical conditions.
You can help speed up your claim by using Disability Benefits Questionnaires (DBQs).
You can ask your VA or non-VA community health care provider to fill out one or more Disability Benefits Questionnaires (DBQs).
You can search for Disability Benefits Questionnaires (DBQs) to download by form name or by symptom.
In some cases, you may need to turn in one or more additional forms to support your disability claim.
You cannot upload evidence to support an appeal.
You can only upload evidence to support your initial disability claim.
Service-Disabled Veterans Life Insurance (S-DVI) provides low-cost coverage to eligible service members.
If you have a service-connected disability, you can find out how to apply for S-DVI online or by mail.

You can apply for S-DVI if all of the following are true: You were released from active duty on or after April 25, 1951, and did not receive a dishonorable discharge. You were rated for a service-connected disability even if only 0%. You are in good health except for any service-connected conditions. You apply within 2 years from the date the Department of Veterans Affairs grants your new service-connected disability.
An increase of a rating or a rating of Individual Unemployability, meaning you cannot work, does not qualify you for S-DVI.
If you carry the basic S-DVI coverage and become totally disabled and unable to work, you can apply to get up to $30,000 more in coverage, which is called supplemental S-DVI coverage.

You may be able to get $30,000 of supplemental S-DVI coverage if both of the following are true: You apply for the coverage within 1 year from the date you get notice of the grant of waiver. You are younger than age 65.
Service-Disabled Veterans Life Insurance covers veterans.

If you have received an other than honorable, bad conduct, or dishonorable discharge, you may not be eligible for VA benefits. There are 2 ways you can try to qualify: Find out how to apply for a discharge upgrade. Learn about the VA Character of Discharge review process.
Service-Disabled Veterans Life Insurance provides up to $10,000 of coverage and up to $30,000 of supplemental coverage.

To get Service-Disabled Veterans Life Insurance benefits, you need to apply in one of two ways: Apply for basic S-DVI online. Fill out an Application for Service-Disabled Veterans Life Insurance VA Form 29-4364, download it, fax it to 888-748-5822, or mail it to the Department of Veterans Affairs Regional Office and Insurance Center RH PO Box 7208 Philadelphia, PA 19101.

To apply for supplemental S-DVI, you must have already applied for and been granted a waiver of premiums. You need to file an Application for Supplemental Service-Disabled Veterans Insurance VA Form 29-0188 or send a letter requesting this insurance over your signature. You must apply for the coverage within one year from the date you receive notice of the grant of waiver of premiums.

Your premium rate, the amount you will pay each month for your Service-Disabled Veterans Life Insurance coverage, depends on your age, the amount of insurance you want, and the coverage plan requested.
The Service-Disabled Veterans Insurance RH Information and Premium Rates VA pamphlet 29-9 provides the premium rates and a description of the plan options.
Under certain conditions, the basic S-DVI policy provides for a waiver of premiums for veterans who are totally disabled. You must pay your premiums for supplemental S-DVI.

If you have questions about Service-Disabled Veterans Insurance or a VA life insurance policy that starts with a V, RH, J, RS, K, or W, you can call the VA Life Insurance Center at 800-669-8477 from 8:30 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. ET.

If you have a severe service-connected disability that the Department of Veterans Affairs has concluded was caused or made worse by your service, you may be able to get Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI).
In the event of your death, Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance can help your family pay off the home mortgage on a home that has been adapted to meet your needs.
To get Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance, you will need to apply for the Department of Veterans Affairs Specially Adapted Housing (SAH) Grant.
The Specially Adapted Housing Grant can help you buy, build, or make changes like installing ramps or widening doorways to a home so you can live more independently.
When you receive a Specially Adapted Housing Grant, your Loan Guaranty agent will tell you if you qualify for Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance and will help you apply.
You can find out if you qualify for a Specially Adapted Housing Grant and how to apply.
You can find out if you qualify for Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance and how to apply.
If you qualify for VA health care benefits, you may be able to get some or all of your vision care through VA.
If you have VA health care benefits, VA will cover your routine eye exams and preventive vision testing like testing for glaucoma.
To schedule an eye exam, you need to talk to your VA primary care provider or contact your nearest VA medical center or clinic.
If you are a blind or low vision Veteran, you may be able to get more advanced vision care and rehabilitation services.

VA will cover the cost of your eyeglasses if at least one of the following requirements is met: You have a compensable service-connected disability (a disability linked to your military service for which you are receiving VA disability payments), you are a former prisoner of war (POW), you were awarded a Purple Heart, you receive benefits under Title 38 United States Code (U.S.C.) 1151, or you receive an increased pension based on your being permanently housebound and in need of regular aid and attendance.

VA will also cover the cost of your eyeglasses if you have at least one of the following issues: Vision problems caused by an illness or the treatment of an illness for which you are receiving VA care (such as stroke, diabetes, multiple sclerosis, or vascular disease), vision problems caused by an injury or the treatment of an injury for which you are receiving VA care (such as a reaction to prescribed medicines, cataract surgery or other surgeries of the eye, ear, or brain, traumatic brain injury or polytrauma), functional impairment (parts of your body that do not work as well as they should) or cognitive impairment (a problem with memory or thinking skills that is severe enough to make it hard for you to do everyday tasks), or vision and/or hearing loss (called dual sensory impairment) that is severe enough to interfere with your ability to take an active role in your own health care and eyeglasses would help to reduce the impact of your impairment.
For more information about VA covering the cost of eyeglasses, you need to contact the prosthetic representative at your nearest VA medical center or clinic.
If you are the spouse, surviving spouse, dependent child, or family caregiver of a Veteran or service member, you may qualify for health care benefits.
In certain cases, you may also qualify for health care benefits due to a disability related to your Veteran's service.
If you are the family member of an active-duty, retired, or deceased service member, National Guard Soldier, Reservist, or Medal of Honor recipient, you may qualify for the TRICARE program.
The TRICARE program provides comprehensive health coverage, including health plans, prescription medicines, dental plans, and programs for people with special needs.
The Department of Defense's Defense Health Agency manages the TRICARE program.

If you are the current or surviving spouse or child of a Veteran with disabilities or a service member who died in the line of duty, and you do not qualify for TRICARE, you may be able to get health insurance through the Civilian Health and Medical Program of the Department of Veterans Affairs (CHAMPVA).
Through the CHAMPVA program, the Department of Veterans Affairs covers the cost of some of your health care services and supplies, which is called cost sharing.

If you are a family member caring for a Veteran with disabilities who was injured in the line of duty on or after September 11, 2001, you may qualify for health care benefits and other caregiver support through the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers.

If you lived at U.S. Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune or Marine Corps Air Station MCAS in North Carolina with an active-duty Veteran who was your spouse or parent for at least 30 cumulative days from August 1953 through December 1987, you may have had contact with contaminants in the drinking water there.
Scientific and medical evidence has shown an association between exposure to these contaminants at Camp Lejeune and the development of certain diseases later on.
If you now have one of the related conditions, you may qualify for health care benefits through the Department of Veterans Affairs' Camp Lejeune Family Member Program.

If you are the biological child of a Korean or Vietnam War Veteran and you have been diagnosed with spina bifida, you may qualify for disability benefits, including health care benefits, through the Spina Bifida Health Care Benefits Program.

If you are the biological child of a woman Vietnam War Veteran and you have been diagnosed with certain birth defects, you may qualify for Department of Veterans Affairs health care benefits through the Children of Women Vietnam Veterans Health Care Benefits Program.
These benefits may help pay for services needed to treat your covered birth defect and related medical conditions.

If you qualify for CHAMPVA or the Spina Bifida or Children of Women Vietnam Veterans programs, you can get prescription benefits through your local pharmacy or through the Department of Veterans Affairs' Meds by Mail program.
You may be able to get disability benefits if you have an illness the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs believes is caused by Agent Orange, which is called a presumptive disease.
You may be able to get disability benefits if at least one of the following is true: You came into contact with Agent Orange while serving in the military.

You may be able to get disability benefits if at least one of the following is true: You served in or near the Korean Demilitarized Zone for any length of time between September 1, 1967, and August 31, 1971.
You may be able to get disability benefits if at least one of the following is true: You served in the Republic of Vietnam for any length of time between January 9, 1962, and May 7, 1975.
You may be able to get disability benefits if at least one of the following is true: You served aboard a vessel on the inland waterways of Vietnam.

You may be able to get disability benefits if at least one of the following is true: You served aboard a vessel operating not more than 12 nautical miles seaward from the demarcation line of the waters of Vietnam and Cambodia as detailed in Public Law 116-23, the Blue Water Navy Vietnam Veterans Act of 2019.
The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs covers veterans and qualified dependents for Agent Orange exposure benefits.
The kinds of benefits you can get from the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for Agent Orange exposure include health care, compensation payments, and an Agent Orange Registry health exam.
To get benefits from the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for Agent Orange exposure, you need to file a claim for disability compensation.

If you have an illness the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs believes is caused by Agent Orange, you will not need to show that the problem started during or got worse because of your military service.
The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs refers to illnesses believed to be caused by Agent Orange as presumptive diseases.

To file a claim for disability compensation with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for an Agent Orange related illness, you need to submit a medical record that shows you have an Agent Orange related illness.

To file a claim for disability compensation with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for an Agent Orange related illness, you need to submit a military record that shows one of the following: You served in the Republic of Vietnam for any length of time between January 9, 1962, and May 7, 1975.

To file a claim for disability compensation with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for an Agent Orange related illness, you need to submit a military record that shows one of the following: You served in or near the Korean Demilitarized Zone for any length of time between September 1, 1967, and August 31, 1971.

To file a claim for disability compensation with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for an Agent Orange related illness, you need to submit a military record that shows one of the following: You were aboard a U.S. military vessel that entered the inland waterways of Vietnam.

To file a claim for disability compensation with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for an Agent Orange related illness, you need to submit a military record that shows one of the following: You served aboard a vessel operating not more than 12 nautical miles seaward from the demarcation line of the waters of Vietnam and Cambodia as detailed in Public Law 116-23, the Blue Water Navy Vietnam Veterans Act of 2019.

To file a claim for disability compensation with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for an Agent Orange related illness, you need to submit a military record that shows one of the following: You were exposed to herbicides in a location other than Vietnam or the Korean Demilitarized Zone.

If you have an illness that is not on the list of Agent Orange related diseases from the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, but you believe was caused by Agent Orange, you need to provide scientific and medical evidence that the condition is related to exposure to Agent Orange.

If you have an illness that is not on the list of Agent Orange related diseases from the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, but you believe was caused by Agent Orange, you need to show that the problem started during or got worse because of your military service.
Scientific proof that an illness is related to Agent Orange exposure may include an article from a medical journal or a published research study.

To file a claim for disability compensation with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for an illness believed to be caused by Agent Orange but not on the list of presumptive diseases, you need to submit a medical record that shows you have a current disability.

To file a claim for disability compensation with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for an illness believed to be caused by Agent Orange but not on the list of presumptive diseases, you need to submit a medical record that shows there is a connection between Agent Orange exposure and your current disability.

To file a claim for disability compensation with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for an illness believed to be caused by Agent Orange but not on the list of presumptive diseases, you need to submit a military record that shows one of the following: You served in the Republic of Vietnam for any length of time between January 9, 1962, and May 7, 1975.

To file a claim for disability compensation with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for an illness believed to be caused by Agent Orange but not on the list of presumptive diseases, you need to submit a military record that shows one of the following: You served in or near the Korean Demilitarized Zone for any length of time between September 1, 1967, and August 31, 1971.

To file a claim for disability compensation with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for an illness believed to be caused by Agent Orange but not on the list of presumptive diseases, you need to submit a military record that shows one of the following: You came into contact with Agent Orange in a location other than Vietnam or the Korean Demilitarized Zone.
If you need help filing a claim with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, you can call 800-827-1000 or TTY 800-877-8339.
If you need help filing a claim with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, you can go to your nearest VA regional benefit office.
If you need help filing a claim with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, you can get help from a trained professional trusted to help with VA-related claims.

The U.S. military used Agent Orange to clear plants and trees during the Vietnam War.
If you served in Vietnam or in or near the Korean Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) during the Vietnam Era or in certain related jobs, you may have had contact with the herbicide Agent Orange.
The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs refers to having contact with Agent Orange as having a presumption of contact.

You may be able to get disability benefits from the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs if you have an illness the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs believes is caused by Agent Orange, called a presumptive disease, and at least one of the following is true: you came into contact with Agent Orange while serving in the military, you served in or near the DMZ for any length of time between September 1, 1967, and August 31, 1971, or you served in the Republic of Vietnam for any length of time between January 9, 1962, and May 7, 1975, including serving aboard a vessel on the inland waterways, or on a vessel operating not more than 12 nautical miles seaward from the demarcation line of the waters of Vietnam and Cambodia as detailed in Public Law 116-23, the Blue Water Navy Vietnam Veterans Act of 2019.
The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs has a list of diseases related to Agent Orange.
The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs provides information on what kinds of service may have put you in contact with Agent Orange.
Veterans and qualified dependents are covered for benefits related to Agent Orange exposure.
The benefits you can get from the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for Agent Orange exposure include health care, compensation payments, and an Agent Orange Registry health exam.

To get benefits from the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs for an illness believed to be caused by Agent Orange, you need to file a claim for disability compensation and submit supporting documents.

If you have an illness the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs believes is caused by Agent Orange, you do not need to show that the problem started during or got worse because of your military service.
The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs refers to illnesses believed to be caused by Agent Orange as presumptive diseases.

To file a claim for disability compensation for an Agent Orange-related illness, you need to submit a medical record showing you have the illness and a military record showing you served in the Republic of Vietnam between January 9, 1962, and May 7, 1975, served in or near the Korean Demilitarized Zone between September 1, 1967, and August 31, 1971, were aboard a U.S. military vessel that entered the inland waterways of Vietnam, served aboard a vessel operating not more than 12 nautical miles seaward from the demarcation line of the waters of Vietnam and Cambodia as detailed in Public Law 116-23, the Blue Water Navy Vietnam Veterans Act of 2019, or were exposed to herbicides in a location other than Vietnam or the Korean Demilitarized Zone.

If you have an illness that is not on the list of Agent Orange-related diseases but you believe was caused by Agent Orange, you need to provide scientific and medical evidence that the condition is related to exposure to Agent Orange, or show that the problem started during or got worse because of your military service.

To file a claim for disability compensation for an illness believed to be caused by Agent Orange but not on the list of Agent Orange-related diseases, you need to submit a medical record showing you have a current disability and a connection between Agent Orange exposure and your current disability, and a military record showing you served in the Republic of Vietnam between January 9, 1962, and May 7, 1975, served in or near the Korean Demilitarized Zone between September 1, 1967, and August 31, 1971, or came into contact with Agent Orange in a location other than Vietnam or the Korean Demilitarized Zone.
The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs provides an Agent Orange help line at 800-749-8387 and an email address GW/AOHelpline@vba.va.gov for questions about Agent Orange exposure.
The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs offers an Agent Orange Registry health exam if you think you may have had contact with Agent Orange or other herbicides while serving in the military.

You may have had contact with Agent Orange if you served in Vietnam between January 9, 1962, and May 7, 1975, or in or near the Korean Demilitarized Zone between September 1, 1967, and August 31, 1971.
You may have had contact with Agent Orange if you served on U.S. Navy and Coast Guard ships or other vessels in or near Vietnam between January 9, 1962, and May 7, 1975.
You may have had contact with Agent Orange if you served on Thailand military bases between January 9, 1962, and May 7, 1975.
You may have had contact with Agent Orange if you served on C-123 airplanes between January 9, 1962, and May 7, 1975.
You may have had contact with Agent Orange if you served in testing and storage areas outside of Vietnam between 1944 and a yet-to-be-determined date.

VA education benefits help Veterans, service members, and their qualified family members with needs like paying college tuition, finding the right school or training program, and getting career counseling.
The document provides information on how to apply for and manage the education and training benefits earned by Veterans.
The document has a section titled 'Get GI Bill and other education benefits'.

The 'Get GI Bill and other education benefits' section includes information about GI Bill benefits, eligibility, how to apply, what to do after applying, Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment, Educational and Career Counseling Chapter 36, VA education benefits for dependents and survivors, and other educational assistance programs.
The document has a section titled 'Manage your Veterans education benefits'.

The 'Manage your Veterans education benefits' section includes information on viewing VA payment history, checking Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits, transferring Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits, changing GI Bill school or program, changing VA direct deposit information, checking VA appeal status, verifying school enrollment, and applying to restore GI Bill benefits.
The document has a section titled 'More information and resources'.

The 'More information and resources' section includes information on the GI Bill Comparison Tool, Post-9/11 GI Bill and other VA education benefits rates, how to choose GI Bill approved schools, CareerScope assessment, VA education debt and GI Bill overpayment, GI Bill questions and customer help, GI Bill School Feedback Tool, education forms and resources, stories of how Veterans and service members use the GI Bill, and other helpful education resources.

The document provides information on other VA benefits and services such as VA transition assistance, Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment, home loan benefits, Veteran-owned small business support, and jobs for Veterans.
The document mentions the GI Bill Comparison Tool to learn about education programs and compare benefits by school.
The document provides ways to contact VA, including asking a question online, calling the GI Bill Hotline, calling the VA benefits hotline, calling eBenefits technical support, and calling MyVA311.
The document includes information for school administrators and a link to the Veterans Benefits Administration website.
The document provides options to get updates through Veterans benefits email updates and follow VA on various social media platforms.

VA Aid and Attendance benefits and Housebound allowance provide monthly payments added to the amount of a monthly VA pension for qualified Veterans and survivors.
If you need help with daily activities, or you are housebound, you can find out if you qualify for VA Aid and Attendance or Housebound benefits.

To be eligible for VA Aid and Attendance benefits as a Veteran or survivor, at least one of the following must be true: You need another person to help you perform daily activities, like bathing, feeding, and dressing, or You have to stay in bed or spend a large portion of the day in bed because of illness, or You are a patient in a nursing home due to the loss of mental or physical abilities related to a disability, or Your eyesight is limited even with glasses or contact lenses you have only 5/200 or less in both eyes; or concentric contraction of the visual field to 5 degrees or less.

To be eligible for Housebound benefits as a Veteran or survivor, you must get a VA pension and you must spend most of your time in your home because of a permanent disability (a disability that does not go away).
You cannot get VA Aid and Attendance benefits and Housebound benefits at the same time.
You can apply for VA Aid and Attendance or Housebound benefits by sending a completed VA form to your pension management center (PMC).
The VA form to apply for VA Aid and Attendance or Housebound benefits is VA Form 21-2680 Examination for Housebound Status or Permanent Need for Regular Aid and Attendance.
You can have your doctor fill out the examination information section of VA Form 21-2680.
You can include other evidence, like a doctor's report, with your VA form to show that you need Aid and Attendance or Housebound care.

You can include details about what you normally do during the day and how you get to places to help show what kind of illness, injury, or mental or physical disability affects your ability to do things, like take a bath, on your own.
If you are in a nursing home, you will also need to fill out VA Form 21-0779 Request for Nursing Home Information in Connection with Claim for Aid and Attendance.
You can apply for VA Aid and Attendance or Housebound benefits in person by bringing your information to a VA regional office near you.
The time it takes VA to make a decision on your claim depends on the order in which claims are received, unless a claim requires priority processing.

Si vous servez dans les forces armées américaines en service actif, y compris la Garde nationale active et la Réserve avec une solde fédérale, vous pouvez être admissible aux avantages de la VA pendant et après votre service.
Si vous êtes un membre traditionnel ou technique de la Garde nationale et de la Réserve, vous pouvez également être admissible à certains avantages de la VA.

Vous pouvez obtenir des soins de santé mentale gratuits pendant un an après votre séparation, quelle que soit votre situation de décharge, votre historique de service ou votre admissibilité aux soins de santé de la VA.

Si vous avez besoin de soutien pour un problème de santé mentale spécifique ou si vous avez des problèmes de sommeil, de contrôle de la colère ou de réadaptation à la vie civile, vous n'êtes pas seul et nous pouvons vous aider.
Pour accéder aux services de santé mentale gratuits de la VA immédiatement, vous pouvez appeler ou vous présenter à tout centre médical de la VA à tout moment, jour ou nuit.
Vous pouvez également appeler ou vous présenter à tout centre Vet pendant les heures de clinique.
Vous pouvez appeler le 1-877-222-VETS (1-877-222-8387) du lundi au vendredi, de 8h00 à 20h00, heure de l'Est.
Si vous avez une perte auditive, vous pouvez appeler le TTY au 1-800-877-8339.
Vous n'avez pas besoin d'être inscrit aux soins de santé de la VA pour obtenir des soins.
Le GI Bill et d'autres avantages éducatifs sont des avantages de la VA que vous pouvez utiliser pendant et après votre service.
Le certificat d'admissibilité pour un prêt immobilier garanti par la VA est un avantage de la VA que vous pouvez utiliser pendant et après votre service.
L'assurance-vie pour vous et votre famille est un avantage de la VA que vous pouvez utiliser pendant et après votre service.
La demande de prestations d'invalidité avant la libération est un avantage de la VA à temps sensible à considérer lors de votre séparation ou de votre retraite.
La conversion de votre assurance-vie après votre séparation est un avantage de la VA à temps sensible à considérer lors de votre séparation ou de votre retraite.
Le counseling éducatif et professionnel est un avantage de la VA à temps sensible à considérer lors de votre séparation ou de votre retraite.
Les soins de santé de la VA pour les membres en service actif sont un avantage de la VA à temps sensible à considérer lors de votre séparation ou de votre retraite.
La réadaptation professionnelle et l'emploi sont un avantage de la VA à temps sensible à considérer lors de votre séparation ou de votre retraite.
L'indemnisation pour invalidité est un autre avantage de la VA à considérer en tant que vétéran.
Le soutien aux petites entreprises appartenant à des vétérans est un autre avantage de la VA à considérer en tant que vétéran.
Le programme de pension pour vétérans est un autre avantage de la VA à considérer en tant que vétéran.
L'allocation pour aide et assistance ou confinement à domicile est un autre avantage de la VA à considérer en tant que vétéran.
Les subventions pour le logement en cas d'invalidité sont un autre avantage de la VA à considérer en tant que vétéran.
D'autres options d'assurance-vie sont un autre avantage de la VA à considérer en tant que vétéran.
La détermination préalable de l'admissibilité à l'inhumation dans un cimetière national de la VA est un autre avantage de la VA à considérer en tant que vétéran.

If you're serving on active duty in the United States uniformed services, including active National Guard and Reserve with federal pay, you may be eligible for VA benefits both during service and after separation or retirement.
If you're a traditional or technical member of the National Guard and Reserve, you may also be eligible for some VA benefits.
You can get free mental health care for a year after separation no matter your discharge status, service history, or eligibility for VA health care.
If you need support for a specific mental health problem or if you're having problems sleeping, controlling your anger, or readjusting to civilian life you are not alone.
You can access free VA mental health services right away by calling or walking in to any VA medical center anytime, day or night.
You can access free VA mental health services right away by calling or walking in to any Vet Center during clinic hours.
You can access free VA mental health services right away by calling 1-877-222-VETS (1-877-222-8387).
The VA mental health services phone number 1-877-222-VETS (1-877-222-8387) is available Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. ET.
If you have hearing loss, you can call TTY: 1-800-877-8339 to access free VA mental health services.
You don't need to be enrolled in VA health care to get VA mental health care.
You can find out if you qualify for VA education benefits to help pay for school or training.
If you qualify for the Post-9/11 GI Bill, you can learn how to transfer your unused benefits to your spouse or dependent children.
VA education benefits are open to service members and Veterans active duty, Guard, and Reserve.
You can review the requirements for getting a Certificate of Eligibility (COE) to buy, build, improve, or refinance a home.
The Certificate of Eligibility for a VA-backed home loan is open to service members and Veterans active duty, Guard, and Reserve.
You can find out if you qualify for and how to manage your SGLI coverage.
You can learn about life insurance coverage options for you and your family after separation or retirement.
Life insurance benefits are open to service members and Veterans active duty, Guard, and Reserve.
If you have an illness or injury that you believe was caused or made worse by your service, you can learn how to file a disability claim through the Benefits Delivery at Discharge program.
The Benefits Delivery at Discharge program may help speed up your disability claim so you can get your benefits sooner.
You'll need to file a disability claim through the Benefits Delivery at Discharge program 180 to 90 days before separation.
The Benefits Delivery at Discharge program is open to active-duty service members, Guard members, and Reservists.
You can find out how to convert your SGLI coverage to a Veterans' Group Life Insurance (VGLI) or commercial policy.
You can learn about other options for life insurance coverage if you have service-connected disabilities.
In some cases, you must act within 120 days of separation to ensure no lapse in life insurance coverage.
Converting life insurance after separation is open to service members and Veterans active duty, Guard, and Reserve.
You can get free educational and career counseling (also called Chapter 36) to support transitioning to a civilian career.
You'll need to apply for educational and career counseling between 6 months before and 1 year after separation.
Educational and career counseling is open to active-duty service members and Veterans only.
You can learn about your health care options after separation or retirement and how to apply for VA health care when you receive your separation or retirement orders.
If you're a combat Veteran, you can apply right away for VA health care to take advantage of 5 years of enhanced eligibility.
VA health care for active-duty service members and after separation or retirement is open to active-duty service members and Veterans only.
If you have a service-connected disability that limits your ability to work or prevents you from working, you can find out how to apply for vocational rehabilitation.
You can apply for vocational rehabilitation up to 12 years from when you receive your notice of separation or your first VA disability rating.
Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment is open to service members and Veterans active duty, Guard, and Reserve.
You can file a claim for disability compensation for conditions related to your military service.
You can manage your disability compensation benefits over time.
Disability compensation is open to Veterans active duty, Guard, and Reserve.
If you served on active duty, you can register to do business with VA and get support for your Veteran-owned small business.
If you have a service-connected disability related to active-duty service or training, you may qualify to register as a service-disabled Veteran-owned small business.
Support for Veteran-owned small businesses is open to Veterans active duty, Guard, and Reserve.

If you served on active duty during wartime, are at least 65 years old or have a service-connected disability, and have limited or no income, you can find out if you qualify for Veterans Pension benefits.
The Veterans Pension program is open to active-duty Veterans only.
If you need help with your daily activities or you're housebound, you can check whether you're eligible to have increased aid added to your monthly Veterans Pension payments.
Aid and attendance or housebound allowance is open to active-duty Veterans only.
If you have a service-connected disability, you can find out how to apply for a housing grant to make changes to your home so you can live more independently.
Disability housing grants are open to Veterans active duty, Guard, and Reserve.
You can explore life insurance coverage options and services for you and your family.
You can manage your life insurance policy online.
Additional life insurance options are open to Veterans active duty, Guard, and Reserve.
You can apply for a pre-need eligibility decision letter to confirm that you qualify for burial in a VA national cemetery.
A pre-need eligibility decision letter can help you pre-plan for burial in a VA national cemetery.
A pre-need eligibility decision letter can make the process easier for your family members in their time of need.
Pre-need eligibility determination for burial in a VA national cemetery is open to active-duty Veterans only.
You may be eligible for Educational and Career Counseling if you meet both of the requirements listed below.
You are the dependent of a Veteran.

You are eligible for a VA education benefit, including: The Post-9/11 GI Bill Chapter 33, The Montgomery GI Bill Active Duty MGIB-AD Chapter 30, The Montgomery GI Bill Selected Reserve MGIB-SR Chapter 1606, Reserve Education Assistance Program REAP Chapter 1607.
You can get educational and vocational counseling through VR&E.
You can get help with exploring your abilities and interests through VR&E.
You can get help with mapping out a path to employment through VR&E.
You can get help with planning the best use of your VA benefits through VR&E.
In certain cases, you may be able to get other education and employment benefits and services for dependents.
You may qualify for other benefits and services for dependents if you are the child of a Vietnam or Korean War Veteran and have certain birth defects.

You may qualify for other benefits and services for dependents if you are the dependent child or spouse of a Veteran who has died or is permanently and totally disabled as the result of active service.
To apply for Chapter 36 services, you need to log in to your eBenefits account.
To apply for Chapter 36 services, you need to click Additional Benefits on your dashboard in eBenefits.
To apply for Chapter 36 services, you need to click Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment Program in eBenefits.
To apply for Chapter 36 services, you need to apply for Education and Career Counseling in eBenefits.
If you are eligible for Chapter 36 services, you will be invited to meet with a Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor (VRC).
The Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor (VRC) will work with you to map out a career path.
You can apply online for Chapter 36 services through eBenefits.
VA Blue Button is a feature of the health management portal within My HealtheVet.
VA Blue Button lets you view, print, save, download, and share information from your VA medical record and personal health record.
With VA Blue Button, you can better manage your health needs and communicate with your health care team.
With VA Blue Button, you can download a customized Blue Button report with information from your VA medical records, personal health record, and in some cases your military service record.
With VA Blue Button, you can download a Health Summary that includes specific information from your VA medical record like your known allergies, medications, and recent lab results.
With VA Blue Button, you can build your own personal health record that includes information like your self-entered medical history, emergency contacts, and medicines.
With VA Blue Button, you can monitor your vital signs and track your diet and exercise with online journals.
With VA Blue Button, you can share a digital copy of the personal health information you entered yourself with your VA health care team through Secure Messaging.
You can use all the features of VA Blue Button if you are enrolled in VA health care and registered as a patient in a VA health facility.
You can use all the features of VA Blue Button if you have an Advanced or Premium My HealtheVet account, a Premium DS Logon account used for eBenefits and milConnect, or a verified ID.me account.
To access your medical records with VA Blue Button, go to your Welcome page dashboard and click on Health Records.
From the Health Records page, you can choose to access your VA Blue Button report, your VA Health Summary, or your VA Medical Images and Reports.
To add information to your personal health record with VA Blue Button, click on Track Health in the blue navigation menu at the top of the page.
VA Blue Button is a secure website that follows strict security policies and practices to protect your personal health information.
If you print or download anything from the VA Blue Button website, you need to take responsibility for protecting that information.
You can get answers to frequently asked questions about VA Blue Button and related tools within My HealtheVet.
You can contact the My HealtheVet Help Desk online or by calling 877-327-0022 (TTY: 800-877-8339) for assistance with VA Blue Button.
The Veterans Health Information Exchange (VHIE) program lets VA share your health information with participating community care providers and the Department of Defense.
The VHIE program helps your VA and non-VA providers better coordinate your care.
The VHIE program keeps your personal health information more secure.
The VHIE program improves your care by helping your providers make more informed decisions.
The VHIE program ensures your providers have up-to-date information, like your current medications and allergies.
The VHIE program saves you time and money.
You can opt out of sharing your information through the VHIE program by mail or in person.

To opt out of the VHIE program by mail, fill out, sign, and date VA Form 10-10164 Opt Out of Sharing Protected Health Information and mail it to the Release of Information (ROI) office at your nearest VA medical center.
To opt out of the VHIE program in person, visit your VA medical center's ROI office and provide a completed, signed VA Form 10-10164.

If you change your mind and want to share your health information through the VHIE program, complete and submit VA Form 10-10163 Request for and Permission to Participate in Sharing Protected Health Information to the ROI office at your nearest VA medical center.
The VHIE program uses secure technology to share information between VA and participating community health care providers who treat you.
The VHIE program shares information only with community care providers and organizations that have partnership agreements with VA and are part of VA's approved, trusted network.
For more information about the VHIE program, you can call the toll-free number 844-698-2311.
The VA Welcome Kit can help guide you to the benefits and services you've earned.
Your VA benefits and services can support you in different ways based on where you are in life.

You can keep your VA welcome kit handy so you can turn to it throughout your life like when it's time to go to school, get a job, buy a house, get health care, retire, or make plans for your care as you age.
You can download your VA Welcome Kit.
You can print out copies of your VA Welcome Kit in black and white PDF or in color PDF.
You can share the VA Welcome Kit guide with friends or family members who need help with their benefits too.
The VA Welcome Kit provides guides to VA benefits and services for Veterans and for family members.
The guide for Veterans includes information on applying for VA health care, getting started with mental health services, applying for a disability rating, and applying for education benefits.
The guide for family members includes information on getting started with caregiver benefits and applying for survivor benefits.

You can explore VA.gov to learn about your benefits related to disability, health care, education and training, housing assistance, careers and employment, life insurance, pension, burials and memorials, records, and benefits for spouses, dependents, survivors, and family caregivers.
VA life insurance can offer financial security for Veterans, service members, and their spouses and dependent children.
VA life insurance options and eligibility allow finding out which life insurance plans one may qualify for and the benefits one will receive with each plan.
For totally disabled or terminally ill policyholders of VA life insurance, one can find out if one can get one's insurance premium waived or receive one's benefits early in certain situations.
If one is enrolled in a VA life insurance plan, one can find out if one can get free financial planning and online will preparation services.
One can access one's VA life insurance policy online to check the policy's status, update one's information, or pay one's premium online.
One can update one's beneficiaries for VA life insurance to keep the information up to date about who one wants to receive one's insurance proceeds.
Updating beneficiaries for VA life insurance will make it easier for one's family members to file a claim in their time of need.
One can file a claim for VA life insurance benefits under one's policy.
One can track the status of one's VA life insurance appeal.
One can find out when and how one can convert one's VA life insurance to a commercial policy.

If one has received a denial letter for Traumatic Injury Protection Life Insurance benefits that instructs one to use VA Form SGLV 8600A, one can file one's appeal by the date provided in one's letter.
One can enroll in VGLI Auto Pay to sign up to pay one's Veterans' Group Life Insurance premium automatically from one's bank account.
If one thinks VA may owe one funds from a VA insurance policy, one can search VA's unclaimed funds records by the qualifying Veteran's name.
VA provides a life insurance needs calculator and VGLI comparison questionnaire to help decide how much life insurance one needs.
VA provides facts on common myths, rumors, and misconceptions about SGLI and VGLI insurance.
VA provides information about the SGLI Online Enrollment System (SOES) for enrolling in Servicemembers' Group Life Insurance.
One can contact VA to ask a question about one's VA life insurance policy or file a claim for benefits.
VA provides forms one needs to apply for and manage one's VA life insurance benefits.
VA provides publications and handbooks for downloading related to VA life insurance.
VA provides information about the law requiring VA to pay all benefits by electronic funds transfer.

VA provides information on medical conditions that may make one uninsurable, which may make it hard for one to get private life insurance after one separates from service, and what to do to make sure one has coverage.
VA provides the truth about the rumors that there are special dividends for Veterans who don't have an active government life insurance policy.
VA provides help with planning a burial, ordering a headstone or other memorial item, and applying for survivor and dependent benefits.
VA provides information on eligibility for tax-free monthly payments as a wartime Veteran or surviving spouse or child through VA pension benefits.
VA provides information on how to apply for and manage VA health care benefits.
VA life insurance can offer financial security for Veterans, service members, and their spouses and dependent children.

If you qualify for VA dental care benefits, you may be able to get some or all of your dental care through VA.
You can find out how to get VA dental care or how to buy dental insurance if you don't qualify.
Whether you can get VA dental care benefits for some or all of your dental care depends on a number of factors, like your military service history and your current health and living situation.
Based on these factors, VA places you into a benefits class and you get the specific benefits assigned to that class.
If you are in Class I, you may qualify for any needed dental care.
If you are in Class IIC, you may qualify for any needed dental care.

If you are in Class IV and you are being paid at the 100% disabling rate not based on a temporary rating for a reason such as a long stay in the hospital or rehab care, you may qualify for any needed dental care.

If you are in Class II and all of the following are true: you didn't receive a dishonorable discharge, you apply for dental care within 180 days of discharge or release, and your DD214 certificate of discharge doesn't show that you had a complete dental exam and all needed dental treatment before you were discharged, you may qualify for one-time dental care.
If you got a dental award letter from VBA dated before 1955 stating that your dental conditions aren't compensable, then you are no longer eligible for Class II outpatient dental treatment.
If you are in Class IIA, you may qualify for any dental care needed to make sure you have and can keep a functioning dentition (a working set of teeth).
A Dental Trauma Rating VA Form 10-564-D or VA Regional Office Rating Decision letter VA Form 10-7131 will tell you the tooth/teeth/condition that are trauma rated.
If you are in Class III, you may qualify for dental care to treat the oral conditions that a VA dental care provider concludes are directly making your service-connected health condition worse.

If you are in Class V, you may qualify for dental care that a VA dental care provider concludes is needed to achieve at least one of the following goals: make it possible for you to be in the vocational rehab program, make it possible for you to reach the goals of your vocational rehab program, prevent you from having to stop your rehab program, help you get back to your rehab program faster if you've had to stop and are in interrupted or leave status, help you get back to your rehab program faster if you've had to stop and are in discontinued status because of an illness, injury, or dental condition, make it possible for you to get and adjust to a job during the period of employment assistance, or make it possible for you to be fully independent in your daily living.
If you are in Class VI, you may qualify for dental care to treat the dental issue that a VA dental care provider finds is making the health condition you're being treated for harder to treat.

If you are in Class IIB, you may qualify for a one-time course of dental care that a VA dental care provider concludes you need to achieve at least one of the following goals: relieve your pain, help you get a job, or treat your moderate, severe, or complicated and severe gingival and periodontal conditions (gum infections that can lead to pain, swelling, and bone and tooth loss if not treated).

If you are in inpatient status, you may qualify for dental services that a VA dental care provider working with your primary care provider concludes you need to manage a health condition a doctor is currently treating you for.
You can apply online for VA dental care benefits by filling out the 10-10EZ health care application.
VA provides dental care to qualified Veterans at over 200 dental clinics across the country, including Alaska and Puerto Rico.
You can find a VA dental clinic near you.

You may be able to buy dental insurance at a reduced cost through the VA Dental Insurance Program (VADIP) if at least one of the following is true: you are signed up for VA health care, or you are signed up for the Civilian Health and Medical Program (also called CHAMPVA), a health insurance program for dependents of Veterans.
Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI) offers mortgage protection insurance to the families of Veterans with severe service-connected disabilities who have adapted a home to fit their needs.
To be eligible for Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI), a person must have a severe disability that was caused or made worse by their service.

To be eligible for Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI), a person must have received a Specially Adapted Housing (SAH) grant to buy, build, or make changes like installing ramps or widening doorways to a home so they can live more independently.
To be eligible for Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI), a person must have the title of the home.
To be eligible for Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI), a person must have a mortgage on the home.
To be eligible for Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI), a person must be under 70 years old.
Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI) provides up to $200,000 in mortgage life insurance paid directly to the bank or other lender that holds the mortgage.
The money from Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI) will be paid directly to the bank or other lender that holds the mortgage, not to a life insurance beneficiary.
The amount of coverage for Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI) will equal the amount still owed on the mortgage, but will not be more than $200,000.
Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI) is a decreasing-term insurance, which means the coverage amount goes down as the mortgage balance goes down.
If the mortgage is paid off, the Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI) coverage will end.
Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI) has no loan or cash value and it does not pay dividends.
To get Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI) benefits, a person must first apply for a Specially Adapted Housing (SAH) grant.
If a person gets the Specially Adapted Housing (SAH) grant, their loan guaranty agent will tell them if they qualify for Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI).
If a person already has a Specially Adapted Housing (SAH) grant, they should ask their agent about Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI).
To apply for Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI), a person must fill out a Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance Statement (VA Form 29-8636).
A person must apply for Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI) before their 70th birthday.

The premium for Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI) will be based on the person's age, the current balance of their mortgage loan, how many more mortgage payments they need to make to pay off their mortgage, and the amount of VMLI coverage they need.
The home covered by Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI) must be the person's primary residence.

To keep Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI) coverage, a person must let the Department of Veterans Affairs know if they move, transfer their mortgage from one lender to another, liquidate their mortgage, refinance their home, or sell their property.

The VR&E Self-Employment track is for service members or Veterans with a service-connected disability and an employment barrier who have the strong desire, skills, and drive to run a successful business.
The VR&E Self-Employment track can help service members or Veterans with a service-connected disability start their own business.

To be eligible for the VR&E Self-Employment track benefits, the following must be true: the service member or Veteran has an employment barrier or handicap, the service member or Veteran is enrolled in VR&E, and the service member's or Veteran's service-connected disability makes it hard for them to prepare for, obtain, and maintain suitable employment.
Suitable employment is a job that does not make the service member's or Veteran's disability worse, is stable, and matches their abilities, aptitudes, and interests.

The VR&E Self-Employment track benefits include coordination services and help with developing a proposed business plan, analysis of the business concept, training in small-business operations, marketing, and finances, and guidance in getting the right resources to implement the business plan.
After the service member or Veteran develops their business plan, the VA will review it and evaluate whether self-employment and the proposed business are viable options.
To get the VR&E Self-Employment track benefits, the service member or Veteran first needs to apply for VR&E benefits and then work with their Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor (VRC).

If the service member or Veteran has their VA disability rating, they can apply for the VR&E Self-Employment track benefits by signing in to their eBenefits account, clicking on Additional Benefits, clicking on Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment Program, and applying for the Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment program.
If the service member or Veteran is eligible for the VR&E Self-Employment track benefits, the VA will invite them to an orientation session at their nearest VA regional benefit office.

The VA offers opportunities to get training and practical hands-on work experience at the same time through programs like the VR&E Special Employer Incentives (SEI) program for eligible Veterans who face challenges getting a job, and the VR&E Non-Paid Work Experience (NPWE) program for eligible Veterans and service members who have an established career goal and learn easily in a hands-on environment or are having trouble getting a job due to lack of work experience.
The VA has VR&E employment coordinators located at VA regional offices and many out-based locations who can help service members or Veterans access the employment services available to them.
The VA has counselors to help service members or Veterans transition from military to college life.
The VA provides links to more resources outside VA that can help service members or Veterans in their job search.

If a service member or Veteran participating in a VR&E employment program lost their housing because of a natural or other disaster, they may qualify for 2 more months of the Employment Adjustment Allowance by contacting their VR&E counselor.
Service members or Veterans may want to consider registering with the Office of Small & Disadvantaged Business Utilization (OSDBU) to get support for their Veteran-owned small business.
You may be able to get VA health care benefits if you served in the active military, naval, or air service and didn't receive a dishonorable discharge.

If you enlisted after September 7, 1980, or entered active duty after October 16, 1981, you must have served 24 continuous months or the full period for which you were called to active duty, unless any of the following descriptions are true for you: You were discharged for a disability that was caused or made worse by your active-duty service, You were discharged for a hardship or early out, You served prior to September 7, 1980.

If you're a current or former member of the Reserves or National Guard, you must have been called to active duty by a federal order and completed the full period for which you were called or ordered to active duty.
If you had or have active-duty status for training purposes only, you don't qualify for VA health care.
If you've received an other than honorable, bad conduct, or dishonorable discharge, you may not be eligible for VA benefits.

There are 2 ways you can try to qualify if you received an other than honorable, bad conduct, or dishonorable discharge: Find out how to apply for a discharge upgrade, Learn about the VA Character of Discharge review process.

You may qualify for enhanced eligibility status meaning you'll be placed in a higher priority group, which makes you more likely to get benefits if at least one of the following requirements is true: You receive financial compensation payments from VA for a service-connected disability, You were discharged for a disability resulting from something that happened to you in the line of duty, You were discharged for a disability that got worse in the line of duty, You are a recently discharged combat Veteran, You get a VA pension, You are a former prisoner of war (POW), You have received a Purple Heart, You have received a Medal of Honor, You get or qualify for Medicaid benefits, You served in Vietnam between January 9, 1962, and May 7, 1975, You served in Southwest Asia during the Gulf War between August 2, 1990, and November 11, 1998, You served at least 30 days at Camp Lejeune between August 1, 1953, and December 31, 1987.
If none of the above apply to you, you may still qualify for care based on your income.
You need to fill out the Application for Health Benefits Form 10-10EZ to apply for VA health care benefits.
You or someone with legal authority to represent you has to sign the Form 10-10EZ and include the date it was signed.
If you are using a legal authority, you will need to include a copy of the form with your application.
If you sign with an X, 2 people you know have to also sign certifying that they saw you sign the form.
You can mail your application to this address: Health Eligibility Center, 2957 Clairmont Rd., Suite 200, Atlanta, GA 30329.
To fill out your application in person, find the nearest VA Medical Center at this link: Find the nearest VA Medical Center or Clinic.
You can also get help from your state's Department of Veterans Affairs: Find your state's Department of Veterans Affairs.

You can get help filling out your VA health care application in the following ways: Call the toll-free hotline at 877-222-8387, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. ET, Get help from an accredited representative (a trained professional trusted to help with VA-related claims), Request a representative, Find your state's Veterans agency.
When you apply for VA health care, you'll be assigned 1 of 8 priority groups.
This priority group system helps to make sure that Veterans who need immediate care can get signed up quickly.
Your priority group may affect how soon you get signed up for health care benefits and how much, if anything, you'll have to pay toward the cost of your care.
Whether or not you have other health insurance coverage doesn't affect the VA health care benefits you can get.
If you're retiring, you're eligible for TRICARE and may also qualify for certain VA health care benefits.
If you're separating from service due to a service-connected illness or injury, you may be eligible for VA health care benefits and certain TRICARE benefits.

If you're an OEF/OIF/OND combat Veteran who has just returned from service, you can receive free medical care for any condition related to your service in Iraq or Afghanistan for 5 years after discharge.
You can visit healthcare.gov to find out if you qualify for health insurance.

You may still be able to get care for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), other mental health problems like depression or substance abuse, and mental and physical health problems linked to military sexual trauma (MST) through VA.
You can call the general VA hotline at 800-827-1000, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. ET to find out what your care options may be.
VA health care benefits cover routine eye exams and preventive tests.
In some cases, you may get coverage for eyeglasses or services for blind or low vision rehabilitation through VA.
In certain cases, you may receive dental care as part of your VA health benefits.
If you have an illness or injury that was caused or made worse by your active-duty service, you may be able to get disability compensation.
Veterans Group Life Insurance (VGLI) is a type of life insurance coverage that veterans may be able to keep after leaving the military for as long as they continue to pay the premiums.

To be eligible for VGLI, a veteran must meet at least one of the following requirements: the veteran had part-time Servicemembers Group Life Insurance (SGLI) as a member of the National Guard or Reserves and suffered an injury or disability that disqualified the veteran for standard premium insurance rates while on duty, the veteran had SGLI while in the military and is within 1 year and 120 days of being released from an active-duty period of 31 or more days, the veteran is within 1 year and 120 days of retiring or being released from the Ready Reserves or National Guard, the veteran is within 1 year and 120 days of assignment to the Individual Ready Reserves (IRR) of a branch of service or to the Inactive National Guard (ING), including members of the United States Public Health Service Inactive Reserve Corps (IRC), or the veteran is within 1 year and 120 days of being put on the Temporary Disability Retirement List (TDRL).
VGLI covers veterans and former service members.
VGLI provides life insurance benefits ranging from $10,000 to $400,000, based on the amount of SGLI coverage the veteran had when leaving the military.
When leaving the military, a veteran can sign up for VGLI coverage up to the amount they had through SGLI.
A veteran can increase their VGLI coverage by $25,000 every 5 years up to $400,000 until they are 60 years old.
To get VGLI benefits, a veteran needs to apply for VGLI within one year and 120 days of leaving the military.
If a veteran signs up for VGLI within 240 days of leaving the military, they do not need to prove they are in good health.
If a veteran signs up for VGLI after the 240-day period, they need to submit evidence that they are in good health.

A veteran can apply for VGLI through the Office of Servicemembers Group Life Insurance (OSGLI) using the Prudential website, online through OSGLI, online through eBenefits, or by mail or fax using the Application for Veterans Group Life Insurance (SGLV 8714) form.
To reinstate an expired VGLI policy, a veteran needs to fill out an Application for Reinstatement of VGLI Coverage (SGLV 180) form.
VGLI premium rates are based on the veteran's age and the amount of insurance coverage they want.
A veteran can choose and update their beneficiaries, the people who will receive the money from their life insurance policy if the veteran dies.

A veteran can update their beneficiary information by accessing their policy online through Prudential Life Insurance Company of America or by filling out a VGLI Beneficiary Designation (SGLV 8721) form and faxing or mailing it to OSGLI.
A veteran can convert their VGLI policy into a commercial civilian policy at any time, at standard premium rates, without having to provide proof of good health.

To convert a VGLI policy, a veteran needs to choose a new insurance company that participates in the VGLI conversion program, apply at the local sales office of the chosen company, and provide a VGLI Conversion Notice letter from OSGLI confirming their VGLI coverage.
The conversion policy must be a permanent policy, such as a whole life policy, and cannot be a term, variable life, or universal life insurance policy.
Supplementary policy benefits like Accidental Death and Dismemberment or Waiver of Premium for Disability are not considered part of the conversion policy.
If a veteran needs help with their claim, they can call the Office of Servicemembers Group Life Insurance (OSGLI) at 800-419-1473 or email the Prudential Insurance Company.
For a service member who is terminally ill, a family member would file a Claim for Accelerated Benefits (SGLV 8284) form to request an advance insurance payment.
For a family member to receive an insurance payment after the death of a service member, they would file a Claim for Death Benefits (SGLV 8283) form.
Veterans can get free VA health care for any illness or injury that VA determines is related to their military service (called 'service connected').

VA also provides certain other services for free, including readjustment counseling and related mental health services, care for issues related to military sexual trauma (MST), and a registry health exam to determine if a Veteran is at risk of health problems linked to their military service.

Veterans may need to pay a fixed amount (called a 'copay' or 'copayment') for some types of care, tests, and medications they receive from a VA health care provider or an approved community health care provider to treat conditions not related to their service.

Whether or not Veterans will need to pay copays and how much they will pay depends on their disability rating, income level, military service record, and which of VA's 8 priority groups they are assigned to when they enroll in VA health care.

If a Veteran has a service-connected condition that VA has rated at 50% or more disabling or that VA has determined makes the Veteran unable to work (called 'unemployable'), or if the Veteran has received a Medal of Honor, VA will assign them to priority group 1 and they won't pay copays for any types of care, tests, or medications.

If a Veteran is not already receiving VA disability compensation or pension payments, or doesn't have special eligibility factors like receiving the Medal of Honor, VA will ask for information about their income as part of the health care enrollment process (called an 'income assessment' or 'financial assessment', formerly known as a 'means test').

VA is required by law to collect income information from Veterans to help determine if they are eligible for VA health care based on their income, and whether they will need to pay copays for certain types of care or medications.
If a Veteran qualifies for VA health care 'enhanced eligibility status', they won't need to provide their income information.

If a Veteran doesn't qualify for enhanced eligibility status but agrees to pay copays for their care, they don't have to provide their financial information, but VA may decline their enrollment and won't be able to consider their eligibility for free medications or beneficiary travel pay.

If a Veteran served in combat after the Gulf War or in combat against a hostile force after November 11, 1998, they don't have to provide their income to qualify for 5 years of free VA health care for any illness that may be related to their military service, but they can still provide their income to help VA determine if they are eligible for a higher priority group, beneficiary travel pay, or free care for conditions not related to their service.

If a Veteran was exposed to Agent Orange in or near Vietnam, ionizing radiation in certain service locations or jobs, or environmental contaminants in the Persian Gulf, they don't have to provide their income information to qualify for free care related to their exposure, but they can still provide their income to help VA determine if they are eligible for a higher priority group, beneficiary travel pay, or free care for conditions not related to their service.

To provide income information, a Veteran needs to provide their gross household income for the previous year, which means the total amount of money the Veteran and anyone living with them in their home earned within one calendar year, before taxes, including income from work as well as any other sources.
If a Veteran's spouse, partner, or dependent child also contributes income to the family, the Veteran needs to include this income in their application.

If the income information a Veteran provides shows that their income falls below VA's limits and qualifies them for free VA health care, medications, or both, VA is required by law to verify the information by confirming it with the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and the Social Security Administration (SSA).
VA usually begins the income verification process in July, the year after a Veteran reports their income.

If the information VA receives from the IRS and the SSA shows that a Veteran has income above VA's limits, VA will send a letter notifying the Veteran and their spouse or partner if their income is part of the Veteran's household income, and the Veteran will have the chance to dispute the information or send documents showing they have additional deductible expenses that VA should consider.

If a Veteran doesn't respond to VA's letter about their income being above the limits, after 45 days VA will send a reminder letter, and after 75 days VA will assume the information from the IRS and the SSA is correct and will send the Veteran a letter explaining the changes in their eligibility or copay status and how they can appeal the decision.

If a Veteran responds by disputing the information in VA's letter, VA will assign an income verification case manager to work with the Veteran and their representative (if they choose to have one) to guide them through the process and help them find any authorized deductions that may reduce their total gross household income below VA's limits, and VA tries to resolve all cases within 75 days.

If VA's review shows that a Veteran's income is still above VA's limits, VA will send the Veteran a final letter explaining that they will need to pay copays for future care as well as for any care they received during the year for which VA reviewed their income, and VA will also explain how the Veteran can appeal the decision.

If a Veteran completed a financial assessment to find out if they were eligible for cost-free medications or for beneficiary travel pay but not for free VA health care, they will need to provide updated income information each year.

If VA determines that a Veteran is eligible for free VA health care because their household income is below VA's income limit, the Veteran doesn't have to provide updated income information each year, as VA will receive their income information from the IRS and the SSA each year to confirm that they are still eligible for free VA health care.

VA will contact a Veteran only if the income information VA receives from the IRS and the SSA changes the Veteran's eligibility or copay requirements, and if the Veteran disagrees with the information, they can keep using VA health care services while VA reviews their situation.

Even when not required, VA encourages Veterans to report changes in their income, and it's also important for Veterans to let VA know about changes to their personal information like their address, phone number, dependents, or other health insurance, which they can do any time by using VA's Health Benefits Update Form (VA Form 10-10EZR).
