Educational and Career Counseling is a VA Chapter 36 benefit.

To get free Veteran Educational and Career Counseling services, you may be eligible if you are leaving active service soon, if you have been discharged within the past year, or if you are the dependent of a Veteran.

You can get Educational and Career Counseling services if one of the following is true: You will be discharged from active duty within 6 months, you separated from active duty not more than one year ago, you qualify as a Veteran or service member for educational assistance under a VA educational program, or you are currently receiving VA education benefits.
If you are the dependent of a Veteran, you may also qualify for Educational and Career Counseling.

The benefits of Educational and Career Counseling include counseling to help you decide which civilian or military jobs you want, counseling to help you find a training program or job, educational and career counseling to help you deal with issues that get in the way of your success in training or employment, and academic and adjustment counseling.
To get these benefits, you first need to apply for Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment benefits.
Then, you will work with your Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor (VRC).
To apply online, you need to sign in to your eBenefits account, select Apply, click Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment Benefits, and apply for Education and Career Counseling.
If you are eligible, you will be invited to an orientation session at your nearest VA regional benefit office.

You can also apply by mail by filling out an Educational/Vocational Counseling Application VA Form 28-8832, downloading VA Form 28-8832 PDF, mailing the completed form to your nearest VA regional benefit office, and if you qualify, you will be invited to an orientation session at a VA regional benefit office near you.
You can watch a video to learn more about VR&E Chapter 36 services.
You can use CareerScope to find careers you might enjoy.

GI Bill benefits help you pay for college, graduate school, and training programs.
Since 1944, the GI Bill has helped qualifying Veterans and their family members get money to cover all or some of the costs for school or training.
If you applied for and were awarded Post-9/11 GI Bill education benefits, your GI Bill Statement of Benefits will show you how much of your benefits you've used and how much you have left to use.
The GI Bill Comparison Tool and Veterans Service Organizations can help you explore options and find out what benefits you can get.
The Post-9/11 GI Bill provides education benefits if you need help paying for school or job training and you've served on active duty after September 10, 2001.
If you have unused Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits, you can transfer your benefits to your spouse or dependent children.
The GI Bill provides information about education benefit rates for tuition and books for qualifying Veterans and their family members.
If you plan to study at a foreign school, you can use VA benefits to cover your tuition and fees.
If you're looking to earn an undergraduate or graduate degree, you can get VA benefits to help pay for courses.
The Montgomery GI Bill Active Duty (MGIB-AD) program provides benefits if you served at least 2 years on active duty.

The Montgomery GI Bill Selected Reserve (MGIB-SR) program provides education benefits if you're a member of the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps or Coast Guard Reserve, Army National Guard, or Air National Guard.
If you're a dependent spouse or child of a Veteran, you may qualify for education benefits or job training under the Survivors and dependents assistance program.
The Yellow Ribbon Program can help pay tuition costs that the Post-9/11 GI Bill doesn't cover if your school participates in the program.
If your college tuition costs more than what's covered by the Tuition Assistance program, you can get more money to cover tuition costs through the Tuition Assistance Top-Up program.
The $600 Buy-Up program allows you to get more money each month through your GI Bill monthly payments.
If you're using VA educational benefits and you're struggling with the coursework, you can get help paying for a tutor through the Tutorial assistance program.
If you have any concerns about your GI Bill school, you can submit them to the VA through the GI Bill School Feedback Tool.

The Harry W. Colmery Veterans Educational Assistance Act, also called the Forever GI Bill, requires the VA to share certain information about your eligibility and benefits with schools, unless you ask the VA not to share the information through the opt out of sharing VA education benefits information option.
You can get disability compensation monthly payments and other benefits for illnesses or other conditions, like the ones listed below.
These are illnesses and conditions we believe may be caused by contact with harmful chemicals or other hazardous materials while serving in the military.
As many as 60,000 Veterans volunteered for medical research for the U.S. biological and chemical programs between 1942 and 1975.
You can get medical care through the U.S. Army if you volunteered for this research and have an injury or illness directly caused by your participation.

If you served in the Republic of Vietnam or in or near the Korean Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) during the Vietnam Era or in certain related jobs you may have had contact with Agent Orange, an herbicide used to clear plants and trees during the war.
If you worked in certain military jobs, you may have had contact with asbestos toxic fibers once used in many buildings and products.

If you served in the Republic of Vietnam, in Thailand, or in or near the DMZ during the Vietnam Era and your child has spina bifida or certain other birth defects your child may be eligible for disability benefits.
If you served at the German bombing of Bari, Italy, in World War II or worked in certain other jobs, you may have had contact with mustard gas or lewisite.

If you served at Camp Lejeune or MCAS New River between August 1953 and December 1987, you may be at risk for certain illnesses believed to be caused by contaminants found in the drinking water during that time.
If you served in the Southwest Asia theater of operations, you may be at risk of certain illnesses or other conditions linked to this region, known as Gulf War Illness.
If you served in Afghanistan, you may be at risk of certain illnesses or other conditions linked to this region, known as Gulf War Illness in Afghanistan.
If you were part warfare testing for Projects 112 or Shipboard Hazard and Defense (SHAD) from 1962 to 1974, you may be at risk of illnesses believed to be caused by chemical testing.

If you served in the post-WWII occupation of Hiroshima or Nagasaki, were imprisoned in Japan, worked with or near nuclear weapons testing, or served at a gaseous diffusion plant or in certain other jobs, you may be at risk for illnesses believed to be caused by radiation exposure.
If you served in Iraq, Afghanistan, Djibouti, or near Atsugi, Japan, you may have had contact with toxic chemicals in the air, water, or soil, known as specific environmental hazards.
You can request a Board Appeal after an initial claim decision.
You can request a Board Appeal after a Supplemental Claim decision.
You can request a Board Appeal after a Higher-Level Review decision.
You can't request two Board Appeals in a row.
You have the option to add new evidence for a judge to review when requesting a Board Appeal.
You'll have to submit new evidence within 90 days from the date VA receives your Board Appeal form if you choose to add new evidence.
Adding new evidence for the Board Appeal will take longer.
You have the option to request a hearing with a judge when requesting a Board Appeal.
A video conference hearing for a Board Appeal will take place at a VA location near you.
Requesting a hearing for a Board Appeal will take longer.
At a Board Appeal hearing, you and the judge will have a conversation.
At a Board Appeal hearing, the judge will listen to your testimony.
At a Board Appeal hearing, the judge may ask you a few questions.
If you have a representative for your Board Appeal, your representative may help you at the hearing.
The Board Appeal hearing will be transcribed and added to your appeal file.
You can add new and relevant evidence within 90 days after the Board Appeal hearing, but it isn't required.
To request a Board Appeal, you need to fill out the Decision Review Request: Board Appeal VA Form 10182.
The Decision Review Request: Board Appeal VA Form 10182 can be downloaded as a PDF.
To request a Board Appeal, you have three options to appeal to a Veterans Law Judge: Direct Review, Evidence Submission, or Hearing Request.
The Direct Review option for a Board Appeal allows a Veterans Law Judge to review your case as quickly as possible.
The Evidence Submission option for a Board Appeal allows you to submit additional evidence for a Veterans Law Judge to review.
The Hearing Request option for a Board Appeal allows you to request a video conference hearing with a Veterans Law Judge at a nearby VA location.
At a Board Appeal Hearing Request, you and a Veterans Law Judge will have a conversation, and they'll ask you questions about your appeal.
The Board Appeal Hearing Request will be transcribed and added to your appeal file.
To request a Board Appeal, you need to list the issue(s) you want to appeal in Part III of VA Form 10182.
You can include all or just some of the issues VA decided when listing issues for a Board Appeal in Part III of VA Form 10182.
You'll need to list the issue you disagree with and the VA decision date for each issue when listing issues for a Board Appeal in Part III of VA Form 10182.
To submit the Decision Review Request: Board Appeal VA Form 10182, you can apply by mail, in person, or by fax.
To apply for a Board Appeal by mail, you need to send the completed VA Form 10182 to the address: Board of Veterans Appeals, PO Box 27063, Washington, D.C. 20038.
To apply for a Board Appeal in person, you need to bring your completed VA Form 10182 to a regional benefit office.
To apply for a Board Appeal by fax, you need to fax your completed VA Form 10182 to 844-678-8979.
You can also ask a regional benefit office for a copy of VA Form 10182 to fill out for a Board Appeal.
You can also call the VA toll-free hotline at 800-827-1000, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. - 9:00 p.m. ET, to request VA Form 10182 for a Board Appeal.
You have 1 year from the date on your decision to request a Board Appeal.
If you're one of multiple people claiming the same benefit (which is rare), you have 60 days to request a Board Appeal.
If you disagree with the Board's decision and have new and relevant evidence that supports your case, you can file a Supplemental Claim after a Board decision.
You can also appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims after a Board decision.
After you request a decision review like a Board Appeal, you don't need to do anything while you wait unless VA sends you a letter asking for more information.
If VA schedules exams for you after you request a decision review like a Board Appeal, be sure not to miss them.
You can track the status of your appeal after requesting a decision review like a Board Appeal.
A Veterans Service Organization or VA-accredited attorney or agent can help you request a decision review like a Board Appeal.
You can get answers to frequently asked questions about decision reviews like a Board Appeal.
The Post-9/11 GI Bill (Chapter 33) helps you pay for school or job training.
If you've served on active duty after September 10, 2001, you may qualify for the Post-9/11 GI Bill (Chapter 33).

To be eligible for Post-9/11 GI Bill (Chapter 33) benefits, you must meet at least one of the following requirements: You served at least 90 days on active duty either all at once or with breaks in service on or after September 11, 2001. You received a Purple Heart on or after September 11, 2001, and were honorably discharged after any amount of service. You served for at least 30 continuous days all at once, without a break in service on or after September 11, 2001, and were honorably discharged with a service-connected disability. You are a dependent child using benefits transferred by a qualifying Veteran or service member.

If you're a member of the Reserves who lost education benefits when the Reserve Educational Assistance Program (REAP) ended in November 2015, you may qualify to receive restored benefits under the Post-9/11 GI Bill.
If you qualify for other VA education benefits too, you'll have to pick which benefit you'd like to use, and this is an irrevocable decision, meaning you can't change your mind.

Through the Post-9/11 GI Bill (Chapter 33), you can receive up to 36 months of benefits, including: Tuition and fees, where if you qualify for the maximum benefit, the VA will cover the full cost of public, in-state tuition and fees, with caps for private and foreign schools that are updated each year. Money for housing if you're in school more than half time, based on the cost of living where your school is located. Money for books and supplies, up to $1,000 per school year. Money to help you move from a rural area to go to school, a one-time payment of $500 if you live in a county with 6 or fewer people per square mile and you're either moving at least 500 miles to go to school or have no other option but to fly by plane to get to your school.

The specific amount you'll receive through the Post-9/11 GI Bill (Chapter 33) will depend on how much active service you've had since September 10, 2001, calculated as a percentage of the maximum benefit.

If your service ended before January 1, 2013, your Post-9/11 GI Bill (Chapter 33) benefits will expire 15 years after your last separation date from active service, and you must use all of your benefits by that time or you'll lose whatever's left.

If your service ended on or after January 1, 2013, your Post-9/11 GI Bill (Chapter 33) benefits won't expire thanks to a new law called the Forever GI Bill - Harry W. Colmery Veterans Educational Assistance Act.

To get Post-9/11 GI Bill (Chapter 33) benefits, you'll need to apply, and the benefit amount depends on which school you go to, how much active-duty service you've had since September 10, 2001, and how many credits or training hours you're taking.

If you've already applied for and were awarded Post-9/11 GI Bill education benefits, your GI Bill Statement of Benefits will show you how much of your benefits you've used and how much you have left to use.

Through the Post-9/11 GI Bill (Chapter 33), you may qualify for additional benefits: If you need more money to cover higher private-school or out-of-state tuition, you can apply for the Yellow Ribbon Program. If you're a qualified service member, you can transfer all 36 months or a portion of your Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits to a spouse or child, with the transfer approved by the Department of Defense. If you're the child or surviving spouse of a service member who died in the line of duty after September 10, 2001, you may qualify for the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship (Fry Scholarship).

You can use your Post-9/11 GI Bill (Chapter 33) benefits in many ways to advance your education and training, including: Working toward an undergraduate or graduate degree, with tuition assistance, tutorial assistance, and top-up benefits. Training for a specific career, trade, or industry through vocational/technical training, non-college degree programs, on-the-job training, apprenticeships, entrepreneurship training, and flight training, with test fees covered. Working while you study through co-op training and work study programs. Taking classes from home through correspondence training, independent and distance learning.

Previously, GI Bill beneficiaries were paid Monthly Housing Allowance (MHA) based on the main or branch campus of the school they were enrolled in, with the most advantageous rate applied if they attended classes at more than one location.
Now, under Section 107 Location-Based Housing Allowance, MHA is based on the campus location where the student physically attends the majority of their classes.

The VA defines the following campus types: Main campus is a location where the main administrative and academic offices of an educational institution are located. Branch campus is a location of an educational institution that is geographically apart from and operationally dependent on the main campus of the educational institution. Extension campus is a location that is geographically apart from the main or branch campus but is on that campus for the performance of administrative tasks.

If you think you had contact with Agent Orange, an herbicide used to clear trees and plants during the Vietnam War, or other herbicides while serving in the military, you can request a VA Agent Orange Registry health exam.
Even if you don't have a known illness, the VA Agent Orange Registry health exam could alert you to illnesses that may be related to contact with herbicides.

By being part of the VA Agent Orange Registry, you're also helping your fellow Veterans by giving the VA information so the VA can better understand and serve those affected by Agent Orange related illnesses.

You can get a VA Agent Orange Registry health exam if you served in Vietnam between 1962 and 1975 for any length of time, including in the inland waterways (Brown Water Navy) and within the 12-mile territorial seas (Blue Water Navy).
You can get a VA Agent Orange Registry health exam if you served in Korea in a unit in or near the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) anytime between April 1, 1968, and August 31, 1971.

You can get a VA Agent Orange Registry health exam if you served in Thailand as a U.S. Air Force Veteran on Royal Thai Air Force (RTAF) bases near U-Tapao, Ubon, Nakhon Phanom, Udorn, Takhli, Korat, and Don Muang near the air base perimeter anytime between February 28, 1961, and May 7, 1975.

You can get a VA Agent Orange Registry health exam if you served in Thailand as a U.S. Army Veteran as perimeter security personnel on RTAF bases in Thailand anytime between February 28, 1961, and May 7, 1975.

You can get a VA Agent Orange Registry health exam if you served in Thailand as a U.S. Army Veteran on some small Army installations in Thailand anytime between February 28, 1961, and May 7, 1975 if you were a member of a military police (MP) unit or assigned a job with duty placing you at or near the base perimeter.

You can get a VA Agent Orange Registry health exam if you served in other locations, but you had contact with herbicides during a military operation or while testing, transporting, or spraying herbicides for military purposes.
The VA Agent Orange Registry health exam is free for qualified Veterans.
To schedule your VA Agent Orange Registry health exam, contact your local VA environmental health coordinator.

The VA Agent Orange Registry health exam will include your history of contact with Agent Orange and other herbicides, your health history including any major illnesses or surgeries you may have had, a physical exam that may be needed like blood tests, X-rays, or other imaging tests, and medical tests.
A VA health care provider will go over your VA Agent Orange Registry health exam and test results with you.
You'll also get a letter with the details of your VA Agent Orange Registry health exam results.
The VA Agent Orange Registry health exam isn't a VA claim exam (also known as a compensation and pension, or C&P, exam).
You don't need to have the VA Agent Orange Registry health exam to get other VA benefits.
To get disability benefits, you'll need to file a claim.
You don't need to sign up for the VA health care system to get a VA Agent Orange Registry health exam.
The VA Agent Orange Registry health exam is based on your memory of service, not on your military records.
The VA Agent Orange Registry health exam will not confirm if you had contact with Agent Orange.
You can get another free VA Agent Orange Registry health exam if you have a new illness in the future.
Your family members can't get a VA Agent Orange Registry health exam. The exam is only for qualified Veterans.
To make an appointment for a VA Agent Orange Registry health exam, contact your local VA environmental health coordinator.
CHAMPVA is a program through which the Department of Veterans Affairs covers the cost of some of your health care services and supplies.

You can only get health care through CHAMPVA if you do not qualify for TRICARE and at least one of the following descriptions is true for you: You are the spouse or child of a Veteran who has been rated permanently and totally disabled for a service-connected disability by a VA regional benefit office. You are the surviving spouse or child of a Veteran who died from a VA-rated service-connected disability. You are the surviving spouse or child of a Veteran who was at the time of death rated permanently and totally disabled from a service-connected disability. You are the surviving spouse or child of a service member who died in the line of duty.
A service-connected disability is a disability that the Department of Veterans Affairs has concluded was caused or made worse by the Veteran's active-duty service.
A permanent disability is one that is not expected to improve.
A Veteran who is the qualifying CHAMPVA sponsor for their family may also qualify for the VA health care program based on their own Veteran status.
If two spouses are both Veterans who qualify as CHAMPVA sponsors for their family, they both may now qualify for CHAMPVA benefits.

To apply for CHAMPVA for a newborn baby, you need to: Get a Social Security number for the baby by applying at the nearest Social Security Administration office. Set up the baby's status as a dependent of the Veteran sponsor by contacting your nearest VA regional benefit office.
If you are the surviving spouse of a qualifying CHAMPVA sponsor and you remarry before age 55, you no longer qualify for CHAMPVA as of midnight on the date of your remarriage.
If you are the surviving spouse of a qualifying CHAMPVA sponsor and you remarry on or after your 55th birthday, you can keep your CHAMPVA benefits.

If you are the surviving spouse of a qualifying CHAMPVA sponsor and you remarry, but the remarriage ends by death, divorce, or annulment, you may qualify again for CHAMPVA on the first day of the month after your remarriage ends or December 1, 1999, whichever date is later.
If you are covered under CHAMPVA and you turn 18 years old, you need to send proof that you are enrolled full time in college or another educational institution to keep getting benefits.
If you were covered under CHAMPVA as the stepchild of a Veteran, and you leave the Veteran's household because of a divorce or remarriage, you no longer qualify for CHAMPVA.
If you are a family member caring for a Veteran with disabilities, and you are not entitled to care or services through another health plan, you may qualify for CHAMPVA.

If the Veteran you are caring for was seriously injured in the line of duty on or after September 11, 2001, you may qualify for health care benefits and other caregiver support through the Program of Comprehensive Assistance to Family Caregivers.
CHAMPVA is always the second payer to Medicare.
If you are under 65 years old, you are eligible for CHAMPVA if you have both Medicare Parts A and B, and are otherwise eligible for CHAMPVA.
If you are 65 years old or older, you are eligible for CHAMPVA if you are eligible for Medicare.
If you turned 65 before June 5, 2001, and you are entitled to either Medicare Part A or B, you also need to enroll in Medicare Part B to be eligible for CHAMPVA.
You do not need to enroll in Medicare Part D to qualify for CHAMPVA.
With CHAMPVA, you will be covered for services and supplies when the Department of Veterans Affairs determines they are medically necessary and were received from an authorized provider.

Covered services under CHAMPVA include: Ambulance service, Ambulatory surgery, Durable medical equipment (DME), Family planning and maternity, Hospice, Inpatient services, Mental health services, Outpatient services, Pharmacy prescription medicines, Skilled nursing care, Transplants.

To apply for CHAMPVA benefits, you need to submit: Application for CHAMPVA Benefits (VA Form 10-10d), Other Health Insurance Certification (VA Form 10-7959c), and Documents related to your Medicare status.
If you qualify for Medicare for any reason, you need to submit a copy of your Medicare card when applying for CHAMPVA.

If you are 65 years old or older and do not qualify for Medicare, you need to send documentation from the Social Security Administration that confirms you do not qualify for Medicare benefits under anyone's Social Security number when applying for CHAMPVA.

Optional documents that can speed up the processing of your CHAMPVA application include: The page from the VBA rating decision showing your Veteran is permanently and totally disabled or the death rating if you are a survivor, Your Veteran's DD214 Certificate of Release or Discharge from Active Duty or Report of Separation, Documents related to any dependent children you are including in your application (birth certificate, adoption papers, school certification of full-time enrollment for children ages 18-23), If you are a surviving spouse who remarried but is once again single, a copy of the legal document that ended your marriage (divorce decree, death certificate, or annulment decree).
You need to sign and date your CHAMPVA application. If your Veteran is applying for you as a spouse, they also need to include the date of the marriage on the application.
You need to mail or fax your CHAMPVA application to the specified address or fax number provided.

After you apply for CHAMPVA, the Department of Veterans Affairs will review your application to ensure it is complete and includes all required forms. If it is not complete, they will return it to you with more instructions.

If you send all required and optional documents for your CHAMPVA application, and your application is complete, it will take about 6 weeks after the Department of Veterans Affairs receives your package until you get your CHAMPVA ID card and related materials.

If you send only the required documents for your CHAMPVA application, it may take 2 to 8 months since the Department of Veterans Affairs will need to confirm your information with other federal agencies.
VA education benefits are for survivors and dependents.

You may be eligible for VA education benefits (Chapter 35 benefits) if you are the child or spouse of a service member and one of the following is true of the service member: The service member died in the line of duty after September 10, 2001.

You may be eligible for VA education benefits (Chapter 35 benefits) if you are the child or spouse of a service member and one of the following is true of the service member: The service member is missing in action or was captured in the line of duty by a hostile force.

You may be eligible for VA education benefits (Chapter 35 benefits) if you are the child or spouse of a service member and one of the following is true of the service member: The service member was detained or held by force while in the line of duty by a foreign government or power.

You may be eligible for VA education benefits (Chapter 35 benefits) if you are the child or spouse of a service member and one of the following is true of the service member: The service member is in the hospital or getting outpatient treatment for a service-connected permanent and total disability, and is likely to be discharged for that disability.
A service-connected permanent and total disability is a disability resulting from your service that does not go away.

You may be eligible for VA education benefits (Chapter 35 benefits) if you are the child or spouse of a Veteran and one of the following is true of the Veteran: The Veteran is permanently and totally disabled due to a service-connected disability.

You may be eligible for VA education benefits (Chapter 35 benefits) if you are the child or spouse of a Veteran and one of the following is true of the Veteran: The Veteran died while on active duty or as a result of a service-connected disability.

If you are a dependent who does not meet the above criteria, you may still qualify for VA education benefits if the Veteran or service member transferred some or all of their Post-9/11 GI Bill entitlement to you while they were on active duty.
The benefits you can get include: Education and training, Money for tuition, Money for housing, Money for books and supplies.
To get these benefits, you will need to apply for VA education benefits (Chapter 35 benefits).

There are 2 main GI Bill programs offering educational assistance to survivors and dependents of Veterans: The Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship (Fry Scholarship) is for children and spouses of service members who died in the line of duty after September 10, 2001.

The Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance (DEA) program offers education and training to qualified dependents of Veterans who are permanently and totally disabled because of a service-related condition or who died while on active duty or as a result of a service-related condition.
You may qualify for both the Fry Scholarship and the DEA program, but you can use only one of them.
You will have to pick one program when you apply for VA education benefits (Chapter 35 benefits).
Once you have made the decision to use either the Fry Scholarship or the DEA program, you cannot switch to the other program.
If you have other forms of health care coverage like a private insurance plan, Medicare, Medicaid, or TRICARE, you can use VA health care benefits along with these plans.

VA has to bill your private health insurance provider for any care, supplies, or medicine VA provides to treat your non-service-connected conditions (illnesses or injuries that aren't related to your military service).
VA doesn't bill Medicare or Medicaid, but VA may bill Medicare supplemental health insurance for covered services.
You won't have to pay any unpaid balance not covered by your health insurance provider.
Depending on your assigned priority group, you may have a copay for non-service-connected care.

Giving VA your health insurance information helps you because: When your private health insurance provider pays VA for your non-service-connected care, VA may be able to use the funds to offset part or all of your VA copayment.
Your private insurer may apply your VA health care charges toward your annual deductible (the amount of money you pay toward your care each year before your insurance starts paying for care).
Whether or not you have health insurance coverage doesn't affect the VA health care benefits you can get.
Being signed up for VA health care meets your Affordable Care Act (ACA) health coverage requirement of having minimum essential health coverage.
You don't need any other insurance to meet the ACA requirement.
VA will update this site if the ACA changes with new laws.
It's always a good idea to let your VA doctor know if you're receiving care outside VA.
This helps your provider coordinate your care to help keep you safe and make sure you're getting care that's proven to work and that meets your specific needs.
You can save money if you drop your private health insurance, but there are risks.
VA encourages you to keep your private health insurance because: VA doesn't normally provide care for Veterans' family members.
So, if you drop your private insurance plan, your family may not have health coverage.
VA doesn't know if Congress will provide enough funding in future years for VA to care for all Veterans who are signed up for VA health care.
If you're in one of the lower priority groups, you could lose your VA health care benefits in the future.
If you don't keep your private insurance, this would leave you without health coverage.
If you have Medicare Part B coverage for doctors and outpatient services and you cancel it, you won't be able to get it back until January of the following year.
You may also have to pay a penalty to get your Medicare Part B coverage back (called reinstating your coverage).

VA encourages you to sign up for Medicare as soon as you can because: VA doesn't know if Congress will provide enough funding in future years for VA to provide care for all Veterans who are signed up for VA health care.
If you're in one of the lower priority groups, you could lose your VA health care benefits in the future.
Having Medicare means you're covered if you need to go to a non-VA hospital or doctor so you have more options to choose from.

If you delay signing up for Medicare Part B coverage for doctors and outpatient services and then need to sign up later because you lose your VA health care benefits or need more choice in care options, you'll pay a penalty.
This Medicare Part B penalty gets bigger each year you delay signing up and you'll pay it every year for the rest of your life.

If you sign up for Medicare Part D coverage for prescription drugs, you'll be able to use it to get medicine from non-VA doctors and fill your prescriptions at your local pharmacy instead of through the VA mail-order service.
There's no penalty for delaying Medicare Part D.
You'll need to choose which benefits to use each time you receive care.
To use VA benefits, you'll need to get care at a VA medical center or other VA location.
VA will also cover your care if VA pre-authorizes you (meaning VA gives you permission ahead of time) to get services in a non-VA hospital or other care setting.
You may need to pay a VA copayment for non-service-connected care.
If you go to a non-VA or VA authorized care facility, Medicare may pay for other services you may need during your stay.
Or, if VA only authorizes some services in a non-VA location, then Medicare may pay for other services you may need during your stay.
You should check your Medicare plan, so you know which care locations and services you're covered for.
VA may bill and accept reimbursement from High Deductible Health Plans (HDHPs) for medical care and services to treat your non-service-connected conditions.
If you have an HDHP linked to a Health Savings Account (HSA), you can use your HSA to pay your VA copayments for non-service-connected care.
VA may also accept reimbursement from Health Reimbursement Arrangements (HRAs) for care VA provides to treat your non-service-connected conditions.

As a result of the VA MISSION Act of 2018, VA no longer needs permission to bill health insurance providers for care related to a sensitive diagnosis (like alcohol or drug abuse, alcoholism, HIV or HIV testing, sickle cell anemia, or other diagnoses included in Public Law 38 U.S.C. 7332-protected information).

Before submitting any claims for care related to a sensitive diagnosis, VA notified Veterans of this change by sending a one-time notice to all Veterans who had signed a release of information refusing to allow VA to bill for care related to a sensitive diagnosis in the past.
The Federal Register also published this change.

VA is now submitting claims to health insurance carriers for all non-service-connected care, even if VA doesn't have a signature or written authorization permitting VA to disclose protected information on these claims or in Veterans' medical records.
VA is required by law to bill your health insurance (including your spouse's insurance if you're covered under the policy).
The money collected goes back to VA medical centers to support health care costs provided to all Veterans.
You can submit a restriction request asking VA not to disclose your health information for billing purposes, but VA is not required to grant your request.
To submit a restriction request, you should contact your nearest VA health facility and ask to talk with the privacy officer.
You can also ask to talk with the billing office for more information.
Family Servicemembers Group Life Insurance (FSGLI) offers coverage for the spouse and dependent children of service members covered under full-time SGLI.
A service member is eligible for FSGLI if the service member is on active duty and covered by full-time SGLI.
A service member is eligible for FSGLI if the service member is a member of the National Guard or Ready Reserve covered by full-time SGLI.
Spouses of service members covered under SGLI are covered by FSGLI.
Dependent children of service members covered under SGLI are covered by FSGLI.
FSGLI provides up to a maximum of $100,000 of coverage for a spouse, not to exceed the service member's SGLI coverage.
FSGLI provides $10,000 for each dependent child.
Dependent children get free coverage under FSGLI.
If a service member's civilian spouse is signed up for full-time SGLI, the civilian spouse will automatically be insured under FSGLI.
If a service member's civilian spouse is signed up for full-time SGLI, the premium for the civilian spouse's FSGLI coverage will automatically be taken out of the service member's pay.
If a service member married on or after January 2, 2013, the service member's military spouse will not be automatically covered under FSGLI.
If a service member married on or after January 2, 2013, the service member needs to sign up their military spouse for FSGLI.

If a service member is a member of the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, Coast Guard, or National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the service member needs to sign up their military spouse for FSGLI online through the SGLI Online Enrollment System (SOES).
To access SOES, a service member needs to go to milConnect, sign in, go to Benefits, Life Insurance SOES-SGLI Online Enrollment System, and sign up their military spouse.
A service member can log in to SOES with their CAC or DS Logon using Internet Explorer as soon as they receive notice that they can start using SOES.

If a service member is part of the Public Health Service, the service member needs to fill out the Spouse Coverage Election and Certificate SGLV 8286A and turn it in to their unit's personnel officer to sign up their military spouse for FSGLI.
A service member will pay a premium for their spouse's FSGLI coverage, which will increase as the spouse ages.
If a spouse is signed up in the Defense Enrollment Eligibility Reporting System (DEERS), the FSGLI premium will automatically be deducted from the service member's pay.
If a spouse is not signed up in DEERS, the service member will still be responsible for premiums and back payments of unpaid premiums for the spouse's FSGLI coverage.
A service member can make changes to their spouse's FSGLI coverage, such as reducing, turning down, or canceling it.

If a service member is a member of the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, Coast Guard, or National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the service member needs to submit changes to their spouse's FSGLI coverage online through the SGLI Online Enrollment System (SOES).
To access SOES, a service member needs to go to milConnect, sign in, go to Benefits, Life Insurance SOES-SGLI Online Enrollment System, and update their spouse's coverage and beneficiary information.
A service member can log in to SOES with their CAC or DS Logon using Internet Explorer as soon as they receive notice that they can start using SOES.

If a service member is part of the Public Health Service, the service member needs to fill out the Spouse Coverage Election and Certificate SGLV 8286A and turn it in to their unit's personnel officer to make changes to their spouse's FSGLI coverage.
Dependent children are automatically covered under FSGLI, and this coverage cannot be turned down, reduced, or canceled.
A service member does not pay anything for their dependent children's FSGLI coverage.
FSGLI provides dependent coverage at no cost until the child is 18 years old.
FSGLI may extend dependent coverage beyond age 18 if the child is a full-time student.
FSGLI may extend dependent coverage beyond age 18 if the child becomes permanently and totally disabled before turning 18 and cannot support themselves.

A service member's spouse has the option to convert their spousal FSGLI coverage to a permanent, individual insurance policy such as whole life within 120 days from the date of the service member's separation from the military, divorce from the spouse, written election to end spousal SGLI coverage, written election to end their SGLI coverage, or death.
If a service member's spouse converts their spousal FSGLI coverage to an individual insurance policy, the spouse becomes solely responsible for all aspects of the policy, including premium payments.
A service member's spouse cannot convert other types of policies such as term, variable, or universal life insurance when converting their spousal FSGLI coverage.

Supplementary policy benefits such as accidental death and dismemberment or a waiver of the premium for disability are not considered part of the conversion policy when a service member's spouse converts their spousal FSGLI coverage.
If a service member's spouse wants to convert their FSGLI coverage, the spouse must choose a company from the list of companies that take part in the conversion program.
If a service member's spouse wants to convert their FSGLI coverage, the spouse must apply at the local sales office of the company they chose.

If a service member's spouse wants to convert their FSGLI coverage, the spouse must give a copy of the most recent Leave and Earnings Statement (LES) to the agent, showing the deduction for spousal SGLI.

If a service member's spouse wants to convert their FSGLI coverage, the spouse must provide proof of coverage with one of the following documents: the service member's separation document (DD214 or NGB-22), written orders, the Certificate of Dissolution of Marriage between the spouse and the service member, the service member's FSGLI spousal declination, the service member's SGLI declination, or the service member's proof of death (DD1300: Report of Casualty or a civilian death certificate).
To request an advance insurance payment for a spouse who is terminally ill, a service member would file a Claim for Accelerated Benefits SGLV 8284A.
To tell FSGLI about the death of a family member covered by the policy, a service member would file a Report of Death of Family Member SGLV 8700.
To receive an insurance payment from FSGLI in their time of need, a service member would file a Claim for Family Coverage Death Benefits SGLV 8283A.
The Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment program is also called Voc Rehab, VR&E, or Chapter 31 benefits.
The Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment program offers 5 support-and-services tracks to help Veterans and service members with a service-connected disability that impacts their ability to work.
The Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment program offers a Reemployment track to help Veterans and service members with the right to return to the civilian job they held before deployment.

The Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment program offers a Rapid Access to Employment track to provide employment counseling and job-search support if Veterans and service members want a job that matches their existing skills.
The Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment program offers a Self-Employment track to help service members or Veterans with a service-connected disability start their own business.

The Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment program offers an Employment through Long-Term Services track to provide vocational training to help Veterans and service members develop new job skills if they are eligible.

The Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment program offers an Independent Living track to provide services that can help Veterans and service members live as independently as possible if they cannot return to work right away.
If you need help filing a claim or appeal, you may want to work with an accredited attorney, a claims agent, or a Veterans Service Officer (VSO).
We trust these professionals because they are trained and certified in the VA claims and appeals processes and can help you with VA-related needs.
VSOs work on behalf of Veterans and service members as well as their dependents and survivors.
To be an accredited representative or a VSO, one needs to: Pass an exam, Pass a background check, Take continuing-education courses to make sure they are providing the most up-to-date information.
Recognized organizations and individuals can legally represent a Veteran, service member, dependent, or survivor before VA.
Non-recognized organizations and individuals can provide information, but cannot be representatives.

Accredited representatives and VSOs can help you understand and apply for VA benefits, such as: Financial support (monthly payments), Education, Vocational Rehabilitation & Employment (VR&E), Home loans, Life insurance, Pension, Health care, Burial benefits.

These trained professionals can also: Help you gather supporting documents like a doctor's report or medical test results, File a claim or appeal on your behalf, Provide added support, such as helping with transportation to medical appointments or emergency funds.
Veterans Service Officers work for Veterans Service Organizations (both are called VSOs), as well as for local government offices.
In general, no individual or organization may charge you a fee to help you file your initial application for benefits, but they may charge you for unusual expenses.
It is only after VA has made a decision about your original claim that VA-accredited claims agents and attorneys may charge for their services.
You should ask upfront what, if any, fees you will be charged.
If you believe a claims agent or attorney charged a fee that is too high, you can challenge it.

You can find an accredited representative or a VSO in 1 of 2 ways: Go to eBenefits to find a local representative including a recognized VSO, an attorney, or a claims agent by state/territory, zip code, or the organization's name, or search the VA Office of the General Counsel's list to find VA-recognized organizations and VA-accredited individuals by name, city, state, or zip code.
To set up an accredited representative or a VSO to work on your behalf, you can either use eBenefits or fill out a form and mail it in.
To use eBenefits, you can let VA know you will be working with a representative or change your current representation.
To have a VSO help you, you can fill out an Appointment of Veterans Service Organization as Claimant's Representative VA Form 21-22 and mail it to your nearest VA regional office.
To have a claims agent or attorney help you, you can fill out an Appointment of Individual as Claimant's Representative VA Form 21-22a and mail it to your nearest VA regional office.
You need to speak to the service organization or representative before you send your request.
We offer housing grants for Veterans and service members with certain service-connected disabilities so they can buy or change a home to meet their needs and live more independently.
Changing a home might involve installing ramps or widening doorways.

You may be able to get a Specially Adapted Housing (SAH) grant if you are using the grant money to buy, build, or change your permanent home (a home you plan to live in for a long time) and you meet both of the requirements listed below.
To get an SAH grant, both of these must be true: You own or will own the home.
To get an SAH grant, both of these must be true: You have a qualifying service-connected disability.
Qualifying service-connected disabilities for an SAH grant include: The loss or loss of use of more than one limb.
Qualifying service-connected disabilities for an SAH grant include: The loss or loss of use of a lower leg along with the residuals (lasting effects) of an organic (natural) disease or injury.
Qualifying service-connected disabilities for an SAH grant include: Blindness in both eyes having only light perception along with the loss or loss of use of a leg.
Qualifying service-connected disabilities for an SAH grant include: Certain severe burns.

Qualifying service-connected disabilities for an SAH grant include: The loss or loss of use of one or both lower extremities (feet or legs) after September 11, 2001, that makes it so you cannot balance or walk without the help of braces, crutches, canes, or a wheelchair.
Only 30 Veterans and service members each fiscal year (FY) can qualify for an SAH grant based on the loss of extremities after September 11, 2001.

If you qualify for but do not receive an SAH grant in 2019 because the cap was reached, you may be able to use this benefit in FY 2020 or future years if the law continues to give the authority to offer these grants and the new FY cap is not exceeded.
For FY 2019, you may be able to get up to 3 grants for a total of up to $85,645 through the SAH grant program.

You may be able to get a Special Housing Adaptation (SHA) grant if you are using the grant money to buy, build, or change your permanent home (a home you plan to live in for a long time) and you meet both of the requirements listed below.
To get an SHA grant, both of these must be true: You or a family member own or will own the home.
To get an SHA grant, both of these must be true: You have a qualifying service-connected disability.
Qualifying service-connected disabilities for an SHA grant include: Blindness in both eyes with 20/200 visual acuity or less.
Qualifying service-connected disabilities for an SHA grant include: The loss or loss of use of both hands.
Qualifying service-connected disabilities for an SHA grant include: Certain severe burns.
Qualifying service-connected disabilities for an SHA grant include: Certain respiratory or breathing injuries.
For FY 2019, you may be able to get up to 3 grants for a total of up to $17,130 through the SHA grant program.
You may be able to get a Temporary Residence Adaptation (TRA) grant if you meet both of the requirements listed below.
To get a TRA grant, both of these must be true: You qualify for an SAH or SHA grant.
To get a TRA grant, both of these must be true: You are living temporarily in a family member's home that needs changes to meet your needs.
If you qualify for an SAH grant, you can get up to $37,597 through the TRA grant program for FY 2019.
If you qualify for an SHA grant, you can get up to $6,713 through the TRA grant program for FY 2019.
You can apply online right now for an SAH, SHA, or TRA grant by going to the eBenefits website.
To apply online for an SAH, SHA, or TRA grant, you will need to sign in to eBenefits with your DS Logon basic or premium account.
If you do not have a DS Logon account, you can register for one on the eBenefits site.
The Veterans Pension program provides monthly payments to wartime Veterans who meet certain age or disability requirements, and who have income and net worth within certain limits.
To be eligible for the Veterans Pension program, you did not receive a dishonorable discharge.
To be eligible for the Veterans Pension program, your yearly family income and net worth meet certain limits set by Congress.
Your net worth for the Veterans Pension program includes all personal property you own except your house, your car, and most home furnishings, minus any debt you owe.
Your net worth for the Veterans Pension program includes the net worth of your spouse.

To be eligible for the Veterans Pension program, at least one of the following must be true about your service: You started on active duty before September 8, 1980, and you served at least 90 days on active duty with at least 1 day during wartime.

To be eligible for the Veterans Pension program, at least one of the following must be true about your service: You started on active duty as an enlisted person after September 7, 1980, and served at least 24 months or the full period for which you were called or ordered to active duty with some exceptions with at least 1 day during wartime.

To be eligible for the Veterans Pension program, at least one of the following must be true about your service: You were an officer and started on active duty after October 16, 1981, and you had not previously served on active duty for at least 24 months.
To be eligible for the Veterans Pension program, at least one of the following must be true: You are at least 65 years old.
To be eligible for the Veterans Pension program, at least one of the following must be true: You have a permanent and total disability.
To be eligible for the Veterans Pension program, at least one of the following must be true: You are a patient in a nursing home for long-term care because of a disability.
To be eligible for the Veterans Pension program, at least one of the following must be true: You are getting Social Security Disability Insurance or Supplemental Security Income.

To decide eligibility for VA pension benefits, the following wartime periods are recognized under current law: Mexican Border period from May 9, 1916, to April 5, 1917, for Veterans who served in Mexico, on its borders, or in adjacent waters.
To decide eligibility for VA pension benefits, the following wartime periods are recognized under current law: World War I from April 6, 1917, to November 11, 1918.
To decide eligibility for VA pension benefits, the following wartime periods are recognized under current law: World War II from December 7, 1941, to December 31, 1946.
To decide eligibility for VA pension benefits, the following wartime periods are recognized under current law: Korean conflict from June 27, 1950, to January 31, 1955.

To decide eligibility for VA pension benefits, the following wartime periods are recognized under current law: Vietnam War era from February 28, 1961, to May 7, 1975, for Veterans who served in the Republic of Vietnam during that period.

To decide eligibility for VA pension benefits, the following wartime periods are recognized under current law: Vietnam War era from August 5, 1964, to May 7, 1975, for Veterans who served outside the Republic of Vietnam.

To decide eligibility for VA pension benefits, the following wartime periods are recognized under current law: Gulf War from August 2, 1990, through a future date to be set by law or presidential proclamation.
If you have received an other than honorable, bad conduct, or dishonorable discharge, you may not be eligible for VA pension benefits.
If you have received an other than honorable, bad conduct, or dishonorable discharge, there are 2 ways you can try to qualify for VA pension benefits: Find out how to apply for a discharge upgrade.

If you have received an other than honorable, bad conduct, or dishonorable discharge, there are 2 ways you can try to qualify for VA pension benefits: Learn about the VA Character of Discharge review process.
You may be able to get disability benefits if you didn't receive a dishonorable discharge and you meet the requirements listed below.

Both of these must be true: You have an illness that's on our list of illnesses believed to be caused by radiation or that doctors say may be caused by radiation, and your illness started within a certain period of time as shown along with the list of illnesses.

You must have had contact with ionizing radiation in one of these ways while serving in the military: You were part of atmospheric nuclear weapons testing, or you served in the postwar occupation of Hiroshima or Nagasaki, or you were a prisoner of war (POW) in Japan, or you worked as an x-ray technician, in a reactor plant, or in nuclear medicine or radiography while on active duty or during active or inactive duty for training in the Reserves, or you did tasks like those of a Department of Energy (DOE) employee that make them a member of the Special Exposure Cohort (See 42 U.S.C. 7384L(14)).

You may also qualify for disability benefits if you served in at least one of the below locations and capacities: You were part of underground nuclear weapons testing at Amchitka Island, Alaska, or you were assigned to a gaseous diffusion plant at Paducah, Kentucky, or you were assigned to a gaseous diffusion plant at Portsmouth, Ohio, or you were assigned to a gaseous diffusion plant at Area K-25 at Oak Ridge, Tennessee.
Veterans are covered.
The kind of disability benefits you can get are health care and compensation payments.

To get these benefits, you'll need to file a claim for disability compensation and provide the evidence supporting documents listed below: Medical records showing that you've been diagnosed with one of the illnesses on our list of those believed to be caused by radiation or that your doctor states may be caused by radiation exposure, and service records showing that you were part of one of the radiation risk activities described above.

When you file your claim, we'll ask the military branch that you served with or the Defense Threat Reduction Agency to give us a range of how much radiation they think you may have come into contact with.
We'll use the highest level of the range they report to decide on your benefits.
The Reserve Educational Assistance Program (REAP) ended on November 25, 2015.
Under the National Defense Authorization Act of 2016, some REAP benefits will remain in place for 3 more years.
If someone was actively using REAP benefits on or before November 24, 2015, they can keep using their REAP benefits until November 25, 2019.

Someone fits the description of actively using REAP benefits on or before November 24, 2015 if they were already attending a school or training program on November 24, 2015, or during the last semester, quarter, or term ending before that date.
If someone applied for REAP benefits, but they did not start school until after November 24, 2015, they are no longer eligible to receive REAP benefits.
If someone applied for REAP benefits after November 24, 2015, they are not eligible to receive REAP benefits.

If the Department of Veterans Affairs determined that someone was eligible for REAP benefits, but they lost their benefits when the program ended, they can credit their REAP eligibility toward their Post-9/11 GI Bill eligibility if they meet both of the following requirements: they established REAP eligibility before November 25, 2015, and they lost eligibility when the REAP program was retired on November 25, 2015.

If someone credits their REAP eligibility toward their Post-9/11 GI Bill eligibility, they will receive one month or a partial month of Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits for each month or partial month of remaining REAP benefits up to a maximum of 36 months.

If someone credits their REAP eligibility toward their Post-9/11 GI Bill eligibility, they will not be eligible for 48 months of entitlement based on their previous eligibility for REAP and their new eligibility under the Post-9/11 GI Bill.

If someone credits their REAP eligibility toward their Post-9/11 GI Bill eligibility, they will be entitled to the 60% payment tier under the Post-9/11 GI Bill regardless of the length of their Post-9/11 active-duty service.
If someone would like to switch their benefits from REAP to the Post-9/11 GI Bill, they should call 888-GI-BILL-1 (888-442-4551), Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. ET.
If you can't work because of a service-connected disability, you may qualify for Individual Unemployability.
Individual Unemployability means you may be able to get disability compensation or benefits at the same level as a Veteran who has a 100% disability rating.

You may be able to get disability benefits if you have at least 1 service-connected disability rated at 60% or more disabling, or 2 or more service-connected disabilities with at least 1 rated at 40% or more disabling and a combined rating of 70% or more.
You may be able to get disability benefits if you can't hold down a steady job that supports you financially (known as substantially gainful employment) because of your service-connected disability.
Odd jobs (marginal employment) don't count for substantially gainful employment.
In certain cases (for example, if you need to be in the hospital often) you may qualify for disability benefits at a lower disability rating.
Veterans are covered for Individual Unemployability benefits.
The benefits you can get for Individual Unemployability include health care and compensation payments.
To get Individual Unemployability benefits, you'll need to file a claim for disability compensation.

When filing a claim for Individual Unemployability benefits, you'll have to provide evidence (supporting documents like a doctor's report or medical test results) showing that your disability prevents you from holding down a steady job.
The VA will also review your work and education history when you file a claim for Individual Unemployability benefits.

An example is provided of a Veteran with a service-connected heart condition and a 60% disability rating who was able to work until last year when she began to get chest pain when doing anything physical, like walking or lifting boxes.
The Veteran's doctor told her to retire as soon as possible.
The Veteran filed a claim for more disability compensation.
The VA reviewed the Veteran's work and education history and agreed that she was individually unemployable because of her service-connected disability.
The VA increased the Veteran's disability compensation to the same rate as a 100% disabled Veteran.
To file a claim for Individual Unemployability benefits, you'll need to fill out a Veteran's Application for Increased Compensation Based on Unemployability (VA Form 21-8940).
To file a claim for Individual Unemployability benefits, you'll need to fill out a Request for Employment Information in Connection with Claim for Disability Benefits (VA Form 21-4192).
Vous pouvez obtenir des prestations d'invalidité si les descriptions suivantes sont vraies pour vous.
Vous devez avoir une maladie que nous croyons causée par l'Agent Orange, appelée maladie présumée.
Au moins une des conditions suivantes doit également être vraie :
Votre dossier militaire doit montrer qu'entre le 9 janvier 1962 et le 7 mai 1975, vous étiez à bord d'un navire militaire américain qui a opéré dans les eaux intérieures du Vietnam.

Vous avez servi sur un navire à moins de 12 milles nautiques des eaux du Vietnam et du Cambodge, comme détaillé dans la loi publique 116-23, la loi de 2019 sur les anciens combattants de la marine des eaux bleues du Vietnam.
Les anciens combattants et les personnes à charge qualifiées sont couverts.
Vous pouvez obtenir des soins de santé, des paiements de compensation et un examen de santé du registre de l'Agent Orange.
Vous devrez déposer une demande d'indemnisation pour invalidité et soumettre vos documents justificatifs.
Si vous avez une maladie que nous croyons causée par l'Agent Orange, vous n'aurez pas besoin de montrer que le problème a commencé pendant ou s'est aggravé en raison de votre service militaire.
Lorsque vous déposez votre demande, vous devrez soumettre un dossier médical montrant que vous avez une maladie liée à l'Agent Orange.

Vous devrez également soumettre un dossier militaire montrant que vous étiez à bord d'un navire de la marine ou de la garde côtière américaine qui est entré dans les eaux intérieures, ou que vous avez servi au Vietnam entre le 9 janvier 1962 et le 7 mai 1975.

Si vous avez une maladie qui ne figure pas sur la liste des maladies liées à l'Agent Orange, mais que vous croyez avoir été causée par l'Agent Orange, vous devrez fournir des preuves scientifiques et médicales que la condition est liée à l'exposition à l'Agent Orange.
Vous devrez également montrer que le problème a commencé pendant ou s'est aggravé en raison de votre service militaire.

Lorsque vous déposez votre demande, vous devrez soumettre un dossier médical montrant que vous avez une invalidité actuelle et qu'il existe un lien entre l'exposition à l'Agent Orange et votre invalidité actuelle.

Vous devrez également soumettre un dossier militaire montrant que vous étiez à bord d'un navire de la marine ou de la garde côtière américaine qui est entré dans les eaux intérieures, ou que vous avez servi au Vietnam entre le 9 janvier 1962 et le 7 mai 1975.
Si votre demande a été rejetée par le passé, vous pouvez déposer une nouvelle demande en raison du changement de loi.
Dans certains cas, si votre demande est approuvée, vous serez payé rétroactivement à la date de votre demande initiale.

Vous pouvez obtenir de l'aide pour déposer votre demande en appelant le 800-827-1000 ou le 800-877-8339 (TTY), en vous rendant dans le bureau régional des prestations le plus proche, ou en obtenant l'aide d'un professionnel formé.
The Yellow Ribbon Program can help you pay for higher out-of-state, private school, or graduate school tuition that the Post-9/11 GI Bill doesn't cover.
You may be eligible for the Yellow Ribbon Program if you and your school meet the requirements listed below.

To qualify for the maximum benefit rate under the Post-9/11 GI Bill, at least one of the following must be true: you served at least 36 months on active duty either all at once or with breaks in service, you received a Purple Heart on or after September 11, 2001, and were honorably discharged after any amount of service, you received a Fry Scholarship on or after August 1, 2018, you served for at least 30 continuous days all at once, without a break on or after September 11, 2001, and were discharged after 60 days with a service-connected disability, you are a dependent child using benefits transferred by a Veteran or a service member who has served for at least 36 months on active duty and qualifies at the 100% level, you are receiving the Fry Scholarship beginning August 1, 2018.
At this time, you are not eligible for the maximum benefit rate under the Post-9/11 GI Bill if you are an active-duty service member or the spouse of an active-duty service member.

As of August 1, 2022, you may become eligible for the maximum benefit rate under the Post-9/11 GI Bill if you are an active-duty service member who qualifies at the 100% level, or the spouse using the transferred benefits of an active-duty service member who qualifies at the 100% level.

For your school to meet the requirements for the Yellow Ribbon Program, all of the following must be true: your school offers the Yellow Ribbon Program, your school hasn't offered the Yellow Ribbon benefit to more than the maximum number of students in their agreement with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, your school has certified your enrollment with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs and provided Yellow Ribbon Program information.

If you qualify for the Yellow Ribbon Program, your school will contribute a certain amount toward your extra tuition and fees through a grant, scholarship, or similar program, and the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs will match the contribution.
To get the Yellow Ribbon Program benefit, you must apply for Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits, turn in your Certificate of Eligibility (COE) to your school, and wait for your school's decision.
Your school will decide whether it has already enrolled the maximum number of students for the program period, and how much funding you will receive.

Your school will apply the Yellow Ribbon Program benefit to the final amount after adding up tuition and mandatory fees, and subtracting any aid you have received from other sources such as scholarships, grants, and your Post-9/11 GI Bill tuition payment.
You will get a notice from your school about whether it has accepted you into the program and how much money you will receive for tuition.
The amount of funding you will receive through the Yellow Ribbon Program depends on the school and the agreement it has with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs.
Schools can choose to offer different amounts to students based on student status (undergraduate, graduate, doctoral) and type of school (college or professional).
The school's agreement with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs states how much the school will contribute and how much the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs will match.

The combined contribution from the school and the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs makes up all or part of the difference between what the Post-9/11 GI Bill will pay and the unmet tuition and fees.
You do not have to attend full-time to be in the Yellow Ribbon Program.

Yellow Ribbon funds may cover any mandatory required fees for your education program, but not fees that are not mandatory, such as room and board, study abroad (unless your degree program requires it), penalty fees like fees for late registration, returned checks, or parking fines.
You may receive Yellow Ribbon benefits for the summer term if your school still has Yellow Ribbon funds available for the per-student maximum contribution for the summer term.
The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs requires a new Yellow Ribbon Program agreement each year.

If your school has an approved agreement with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs and continues to participate in the program, they must continue to offer the Yellow Ribbon benefits to you the next year as long as you meet all of the following requirements: you make acceptable progress toward completing your program according to your school, you stay enrolled in the school without a break following the school's policy, and you have money left in your Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits.
If you transfer to a different school, your new school needs to offer Yellow Ribbon benefits and accept your application for you to continue in the program.
Your first school's decision does not affect your new school's decision.
Even if you stay enrolled, keep progressing in your program, and have money left in your Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits, your school can choose to offer a different amount each year.
Your school must notify you if they plan to stop offering the Yellow Ribbon Program.
If you take fewer courses, the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs will pay less toward your tuition and fees, and your school will also reduce the amount they pay.
The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs bases refunds on each school's refund policy, and you will need to pay back any overpayments made to the school that they do not refund.

If the school still offers the Yellow Ribbon Program, they must continue to give you funding as long as you meet all of the following requirements: you make acceptable progress toward completing your program according to your school, you stay enrolled in the school without a break following the school's policy, and you have money left in your Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits.
Active-duty service members can apply for VA health care once they have received their separation or retirement orders.
A service member's eligibility for VA health care and other health care coverage depends on their service history and other factors.

Returning OEF/OIF/OND combat Veterans can receive free VA health care for up to 5 years after discharge or release for any condition related to their service in Operation Enduring Freedom (OEF) in Afghanistan, Operation Iraqi Freedom (OIF), or Operation New Dawn (OND) in Iraq.
This period of free VA health care for returning OEF/OIF/OND combat Veterans is called an enhanced eligibility period.

To qualify for the enhanced eligibility period for OEF/OIF/OND combat Veterans, a service member must have: (1) Served in a theater of combat operations after November 11, 1998, (2) Been discharged or released from active service on or after January 29, 2003, and (3) Not received a dishonorable discharge.

VA uses military service documentation, combat service medals, combat tax exemption, imminent danger pay, or hostile fire pay to determine if a service member served in a theater of combat operations.

If a service member qualifies for enhanced eligibility as an OEF/OIF/OND combat Veteran, VA will enroll them right away in priority group 6 or a higher priority group based on their income or service-connected disability.

OEF/OIF/OND combat Veterans with enhanced eligibility receive free care and medications for any condition that may be related to their combat service, but may need to pay copays for care and medications that are clearly not related to their military service.

OEF/OIF/OND combat Veterans with enhanced eligibility stay enrolled in VA health care even after their enhanced eligibility period ends, and are reassigned to the highest priority group they qualify for at that time.
OEF/OIF/OND combat Veterans with enhanced eligibility may be eligible for one-time dental care if they apply within 180 days of discharge or separation.

Veterans who have recently separated from active duty, including active National Guard or Reserve duty, may be eligible for VA health care based on their service history, VA disability rating, income, and other factors.
Veterans who had active-duty status for training purposes only do not qualify for VA health care.
Recently separated Veterans and their families may qualify for temporary health coverage through the Department of Defense's TRICARE program.
National Guard and Reserve members' coverage options after separation depend on their military status before separation.
Military retirees may be eligible for the Department of Defense's TRICARE program, and their family members may also qualify for care.
Military retirees need to enroll in TRICARE within 90 days after their retirement date, even if they were already enrolled in TRICARE on active duty.
Military retirees may also be eligible for certain VA health care benefits.

Service members being medically retired from active duty may be eligible to receive care through VA for any service-connected disabilities and may also qualify to receive all other care through TRICARE.
Eligible family members of service members being medically retired may also qualify for care through TRICARE.
Service members can apply for VA health care as soon as they have received their separation or retirement papers, and will be enrolled once they have separated or retired if determined eligible.

Service members may be able to use VA health care while still on active duty if they need emergency or urgent care, or if they have a valid TRICARE referral or authorization and the VA health facility has a VA/DoD sharing agreement.

VA's Concierge for Care (C4C) team will call recently separated service members to help them learn about and apply for VA health care benefits, process their application over the phone, and help them schedule their first VA medical appointment.

Si su discapacidad relacionada con el servicio limita su capacidad para realizar actividades de la vida diaria como bañarse, vestirse, acceder a la comunidad e interactuar con otros y no puede regresar al trabajo de inmediato, puede calificar para servicios de vida independiente a través de la Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (VR&E) Independent Living track.
También puede recibir estos servicios mientras trabaja para encontrar un trabajo si ese es un objetivo que usted y su Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor (VRC) han creado.
En ambos casos, su VRC puede ayudarlo a restaurar sus actividades de la vida diaria.

Puede ser elegible para servicios de vida independiente si es un miembro del servicio o veterano con una discapacidad relacionada con el servicio que es elegible para los beneficios de VR&E, y cumple con todos los requisitos enumerados a continuación: tiene una discapacidad de empleo grave (SEH), sus discapacidades le impiden buscar o regresar al trabajo, y necesita servicios para vivir de la manera más independiente posible.

Tener una discapacidad de empleo significa que su discapacidad relacionada con el servicio limita su capacidad para prepararse, obtener y mantener un empleo adecuado, un trabajo que no empeore su discapacidad, sea estable y se ajuste a sus habilidades, aptitudes e intereses.

Dependiendo de sus necesidades, los servicios pueden incluir: evaluación y asesoramiento para identificar sus necesidades y objetivos, consultas domiciliarias con especialistas, referencia a recursos de apoyo, orientación para ayudarlo a comprender si es elegible para los programas de vivienda adaptativa de VA.
Estos programas pueden ayudarlo a realizar cambios en su hogar, como ampliar las puertas o agregar rampas, para que pueda vivir de manera más independiente.
Estos servicios generalmente duran hasta 24 meses. En algunos casos, es posible que pueda utilizar los servicios por más tiempo que este.
Primero, deberá solicitar los beneficios de VR&E. Luego, trabajará con su Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor (VRC).

Si tiene su calificación de discapacidad de VA, siga estos pasos para aplicar: inicie sesión en su cuenta de eBenefits, haga clic en Beneficios adicionales en su tablero, haga clic en Programa de Rehabilitación Vocacional y Empleo, solicite el Programa de Rehabilitación Vocacional y Empleo.
Si es elegible, lo invitaremos a una sesión de orientación en su oficina regional de beneficios de VA más cercana.

Si es elegible, un VRC trabajará con usted para determinar la gravedad de su discapacidad relacionada con el servicio, si está listo para trabajar y si se beneficiará de los servicios de vida independiente.
Su VRC lo ayudará a crear un plan de vida independiente personalizado y por escrito que satisfaga sus necesidades.

Traumatic Injury Protection (TSGLI) also known as Servicemembers Group Life Insurance Traumatic Injury Protection provides short-term financial support to help eligible service members recover from a severe injury.
If you were covered by SGLI and experienced a traumatic injury while serving in the military, you can find out how to file a claim for TSGLI or appeal a past decision.
You may be able to get TSGLI if you were insured by SGLI when you experienced a traumatic injury, and you meet all of the requirements listed below.

To be eligible for TSGLI, all of the following must be true: You have a scheduled loss that is a direct result of the traumatic injury, you suffered the traumatic injury before midnight on the day that you left the military, you suffered a scheduled loss within 2 years (730 days) of the traumatic injury, you have survived for a period of not less than 7 full days from the date of the traumatic injury (the 7-day period begins on the date and time of the traumatic injury and ends 168 full hours later), and you were an active-duty military member, a Reservist, a National Guard member, on funeral-honors duty, or on 1-day muster duty.

To qualify for TSGLI, none of the following can be true of your injury: Your injury can't be self-inflicted on purpose or the result of an attempt at self-injury, your injury can't involve the use of an illegal drug or a controlled substance that was given or taken without the advice of a medical doctor, your injury can't be the result of medical or surgical treatment of an illness or disease, your injury can't occur while you're committing or trying to commit a felony, and your injury can't be the result of a physical or mental illness or disease (not including illness or disease caused by a wound infection, a chemical, biological, or radiological weapon, or accidentally swallowing a contaminated substance).

You may be able to get retroactive TSGLI (meaning that it takes effect starting from a date in the past) if you were injured between October 7, 2001, and November 30, 2005, and you meet all of the TSGLI qualifications listed above.
