For retroactive TSGLI, you can use this benefit no matter where the injury happened, whether you were on or off duty, and no matter if your SGLI coverage was in effect when you got injured.
The previous requirement that you must have been injured during Operations Enduring or Iraqi Freedom (OEF or OIF) has been removed for retroactive TSGLI.
Service members covered by SGLI are covered for TSGLI.
Through TSGLI, you may get $25,000 to $100,000 in short-term financial support to help in your recovery from a traumatic injury.
You're automatically covered through TSGLI if you're signed up for full-time SGLI.
TSGLI insurance covers you even if your injury happened while you were off duty.

To get TSGLI payments (including retroactive TSGLI payments), you'll need to apply by filling out the Application for TSGLI Benefits (SGLV 8600) form and faxing, emailing, or mailing it to the address of your service branch on the front page of the form.
If you're denied TSGLI benefits, first look at the denial letter you received from your branch of service.
Your denial letter will tell you if you should use the TSGLI Appeal Request Form (SGLV 8600A) and how long you'll have to submit your appeal.
If your denial letter says to complete the TSGLI Appeal Request Form, fill it out and submit it to your branch of service.
If you have SGLI coverage, your SGLI premium (which is automatically deducted from your base pay) includes a $1-per-month flat-rate premium for TSGLI.
The $1-per-month flat-rate premium for TSGLI is all you'll pay for this benefit.
VA offers long-term care services for sick or disabled Veterans.
VA's long-term care services include 24/7 nursing and medical care.
VA's long-term care services include physical therapy.
VA's long-term care services include help with daily tasks like bathing, dressing, making meals, and taking medicine.
VA's long-term care services include comfort care and help with managing pain.
VA's long-term care services include support for caregivers who may need skilled help or a break so they can work, travel, or run errands.
VA's long-term care services are provided in settings like nursing homes, assisted-living centers, private homes, adult day health centers, and Veterans' own homes.
Nursing homes are settings where Veterans can get VA's long-term care services.
Assisted-living centers are settings where Veterans can get VA's long-term care services.
Private homes are settings where Veterans can get VA's long-term care services.
Adult day health centers are settings where Veterans can get VA's long-term care services.
Veterans' own homes are settings where Veterans can get VA's long-term care services.
To access VA's long-term care services, a Veteran must be signed up for VA health care.
To access VA's long-term care services, VA must conclude that the Veteran needs a specific service to help with ongoing treatment and personal care.
To access VA's long-term care services, the service or space in the care setting must be available near the Veteran.
VA may consider a Veteran's service-connected disability status or insurance coverage when determining access to long-term care services.
To find out how to access VA's long-term care services, a Veteran can contact their VA social worker.
To find out how to access VA's long-term care services, a Veteran can call VA's toll-free hotline at 877-222-8387, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. ET.
If a Veteran is not currently in the VA health care program, they can apply for benefits to access VA's long-term care services.
VA covers some long-term care services under a Veteran's standard health benefits if the Veteran is signed up for VA health care.
A Veteran may need to pay a copay for some covered long-term care services.
For long-term care services not covered under VA health care benefits, a Veteran may be able to pay through Medicaid, Medicare, or private insurance.
VA provides information and support to help Veterans set goals and priorities and make decisions about long-term care.
VA provides information and support to help Veterans find services and resources for geriatric elder and long-term care.
VA provides information about geriatric and long-term care as well as how to deal with diseases like Alzheimer's and dementia.
VA provides nursing home care in three different settings: Community Living Centers, Community Nursing Homes, and State Veterans Homes.
In Community Living Centers, Veterans can live full-time and have access to nursing and medical care as well as help with daily tasks 24 hours a day.
In Community Nursing Homes, Veterans can live full-time and have access to nursing and medical care as well as help with daily tasks 24 hours a day near their home and family.
In State Veterans Homes, Veterans can live full-time and have access to nursing and medical care as well as help with daily tasks 24 hours a day in state-owned and -managed centers.
Veterans may be able to get VA benefits to help pay for nursing home care, depending on their income and level of service-connected disability.
VA provides community residential live-in care in settings like medical foster homes, adult family homes or adult foster homes, and assisted living facilities.
In community residential live-in care settings, a trained professional provides care and support with daily tasks 24 hours a day.
Community residential live-in care settings are not run, staffed, or paid for by VA, but VA inspects and approves each one.
Veterans may be able to use VA benefits to help pay for extra services like visits from a VA health care provider in community residential live-in care settings.
If signed up for VA health care, Veterans can get help managing their disability or health condition while living at home.
The services a Veteran qualifies for while living at home depend on their needs and availability in their area.
Veterans may be able to use more than one service at a time while living at home.
Home-based primary care is a service where a VA health care team, led by a VA doctor, provides services like nursing care, physical therapy, and help with daily tasks in a Veteran's home.
Homemaker/home health aide (H/HHA) services involve a trained caregiver supervised by a registered nurse who comes into a Veteran's home to help with self-care.
Adult day health care is a program Veterans can go to during the day for social activities, companionship, recreation, care, and support.

Hospice care involves skilled caregivers who come into a Veteran's home to provide comfort care to the Veteran and their family if the Veteran has a terminal condition with less than 6 months to live and is no longer seeking treatment other than to ease pain.

Palliative care involves skilled caregivers who come into a Veteran's home to provide comfort care to help ease pain and control symptoms so the Veteran can do as much as possible in their daily life.

If signed up for VA health care, Veterans can get skilled home health care where health care providers from a community-based home health agency come to their house to provide care like wound care, physical therapy, social work support, and help with daily tasks.
Home Telehealth is a service where a VA care coordinator keeps track of a Veteran's health remotely using special equipment in the Veteran's home and checks in by phone if needed.
If there are any signs of a problem with Home Telehealth, the VA care coordinator works with the Veteran, VA doctor, and nurse to figure out what to do next.

Veterans may be able to get respite care as part of their VA health care benefits, where a person comes into the Veteran's home or the Veteran goes to a program outside their home while their family caregiver takes a break.
Other services like adult day health care or skilled health aide services can also help support caregivers.
VA offers Geriatric Patient Aligned Care Team (GeriPACT) services in about two-thirds of VA medical centers.

GeriPACT provides expert care to Veterans with challenging health care needs due to conditions like more than one complex chronic disease, dementia or cognitive decline, geriatric syndromes, or caregiver burden.
GeriPACT is not for Veterans with untreated substance abuse or who only need a prescription refill for a medicine like Aricept used to treat Alzheimer's disease.
Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance is a program.
The Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance program is also called Chapter 35.

If you are the child or spouse of a Veteran or service member who has died, is captured or missing, or has disabilities, you may be able to get help paying for school or job training through the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance program.
You may be able to get Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits if the Veteran or service member is permanently and totally disabled due to a service-connected disability.
You may be able to get Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits if the Veteran or service member died while on active duty or as a result of a service-connected disability.
You may be able to get Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits if the Veteran or service member is missing in action or was captured in the line of duty by a hostile force.
You may be able to get Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits if the Veteran or service member was forcibly detained held or interned in the line of duty by a foreign entity.

You may be able to get Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits if the Veteran or service member is in the hospital or getting outpatient treatment for a service-connected permanent and total disability and is likely to be discharged for that disability effective December 23, 2006.
If you are the child of a Veteran or service member, you can get Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits if you are between the ages of 18 and 26, except in certain cases.

If you are the child of a Veteran or service member and over 18 years old and using Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance, you cannot get Dependency and Indemnity Compensation from the Department of Veterans Affairs.
If you are the child of a Veteran or service member and join the military, you cannot use the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefit while on active duty.
If you are the child of a Veteran or service member and want to use the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefit after you leave the service, you cannot have a dishonorable discharge.
Military service can extend your eligibility for the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefit, but this increase does not usually go past your 31st birthday.

If you are the spouse of a Veteran or service member, your Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits start on the date the Department of Veterans Affairs concludes that you qualify or on the date of the Veteran's death, and last for 10 years.

If the Veteran was rated as permanently and totally disabled, with an effective date that is 3 years after discharge, and you are the spouse of the Veteran, you will qualify for Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits for 20 years from that effective date, according to a new policy that began on October 10, 2008.
The Department of Veterans Affairs will not pay Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits for training you started before October 10, 2008, if you are the spouse of a Veteran.
If the service member died on active duty and you are the spouse, your Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits end 20 years from the date of death.

If you are the spouse of a Veteran or service member, you can get Dependency and Indemnity Compensation payments from the Department of Veterans Affairs and use Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits.

The Department of Veterans Affairs will send you a monthly payment through the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance program to help you cover the cost of college or graduate degree programs.

The Department of Veterans Affairs will send you a monthly payment through the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance program to help you cover the cost of career-training certificate courses.
The Department of Veterans Affairs will send you a monthly payment through the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance program to help you cover the cost of educational and career counseling.
The Department of Veterans Affairs will send you a monthly payment through the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance program to help you cover the cost of apprenticeships.
The Department of Veterans Affairs will send you a monthly payment through the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance program to help you cover the cost of on-the-job training.
If you began using the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance program to pay for your school or training before August 1, 2018, you can get benefits for up to 45 months.
If you began using the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance program on or after August 1, 2018, you can get benefits for up to 36 months.
If you qualify for both the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance program and the Fry Scholarship, you will need to pick one or the other.
Once you make the choice between the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance program and the Fry Scholarship, you cannot switch to the other program.

If you are the child of a service member who died in the line of duty before August 1, 2011, you can use both the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance program and the Fry Scholarship and get up to 81 months of education and training.

If you are the child of a service member who died in the line of duty before August 1, 2011, and use both the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance program and the Fry Scholarship, you will need to use one program at a time.

The Department of Veterans Affairs may prescribe special restorative training, if needed, to help you overcome or lessen the effects of a physical or mental disability so you can work toward your educational or training goal through the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance program.
The Department of Veterans Affairs may approve special vocational training you may need due to a physical or mental disability through the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance program.
The special benefits for physical or mental disabilities through the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance program will not include medical or psychiatric care.

To get Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits, you should first contact your school's certifying official to make sure your program is approved for Department of Veterans Affairs benefits.
To get Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits, you can apply online.

To get Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits, you can apply by mail by filling out a Dependents Application for VA Education Benefits VA Form 22-5490 and mailing it to the regional processing office for your state.
The address for the regional processing office for your state to mail the Dependents Application for VA Education Benefits VA Form 22-5490 is on the last page of the form.

If you have not started school or a training program for the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits, you can get help from a trained professional trusted to help with Department of Veterans Affairs-related claims.

If you have not started school or a training program for the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits, you can get more information about schools and see if the Department of Veterans Affairs has approved your program using the GI Bill Comparison Tool.
If you have already started your program for the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits, you should take your application to your school or employer.

If you have already started your program for the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance benefits, you should ask your school to fill out a VA Enrollment Certification VA Form 22-1999 and send it to the Department of Veterans Affairs along with your application.
Different programs cover Veterans (VGLI), service members (SGLI), and family members (FSGLI).
You may also be able to get short-term financial coverage through TSGLI to help you recover from a traumatic severe injury.

If you are disabled because of an injury or illness caused or made worse by your active service, you may be able to get coverage through S-DVI to continue your life insurance beyond 2 years after you leave the military.
If you are ending your military tour of duty soon, you will need to get new coverage quickly.
In some cases, you must act within 120 days of leaving the military to be sure there is no break in your coverage.
Servicemembers Group Life Insurance (SGLI) is group life insurance while you are serving.
Family Servicemembers Group Life Insurance (FSGLI) is coverage for your spouse and dependent children (children who rely on you for financial support).
Traumatic Injury Protection (TSGLI) is short-term financial support to help you recover from a severe injury.
Veterans Group Life Insurance (VGLI) is group life insurance once you have ended your service.

Service-Disabled Veterans Insurance (S-DVI) is life insurance that you can continue beyond 2 years after you leave the military if you are disabled because of an injury or illness caused or made worse by your active service.
Veterans Mortgage Life Insurance (VMLI) is mortgage protection insurance for a home that has been adapted to meet your needs if you have a severe service-connected disability.
The Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers supports family members caring for a Veteran with disabilities.
The Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers recognizes that family caregivers enhance the health and well-being of Veterans they care for in their home.
The VA MISSION Act aims to give more family caregivers access to the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers.
The VA MISSION Act will expand access to the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers in two phases.

In the first phase of the expansion under the VA MISSION Act, family caregivers of Veterans who were seriously injured in the line of duty on or before May 7, 1975, will become eligible for the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers.

In the second phase of the expansion under the VA MISSION Act, after two years, family caregivers of Veterans who were seriously injured in the line of duty between May 7, 1975, and September 10, 2001, will become eligible for the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers.
The VA MISSION Act website provides ongoing updates on the expansion of the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers.
The caregiver support line at 855-260-3274 provides information about support services for family caregivers.
To qualify for the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers, the Veteran being cared for must meet two requirements.

The first requirement for the Veteran to qualify for the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers is that the Veteran has a serious injury including traumatic brain injury, psychological trauma, or other mental disorder that was caused or made worse by their active-duty service on or after September 11, 2001.

The second requirement for the Veteran to qualify for the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers is that the Veteran cannot perform one or more activities of daily living and/or needs supervision or protection based on symptoms of lasting neurological damage or injury.
An application process is required to determine eligibility for the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers.
The application for the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers is the Application for the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers (VA Form 10-10CG).

The Application for the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers (VA Form 10-10CG) requires identification and health coverage information for both the caregiver and the Veteran, and signatures from both.

The Application for the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers (VA Form 10-10CG) can be mailed to the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers Health Eligibility Center at 2957 Clairmont Road NE, Ste 200, Atlanta, GA 30329-1647.
The Application for the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers (VA Form 10-10CG) can be submitted in person to the local VA medical center caregiver support coordinator.

The Caregiver Support Line at 855-260-3274 can provide the name of the local caregiver support coordinator for submitting the Application for the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers (VA Form 10-10CG).

An online caregiver support coordinator search tool is available to find the local caregiver support coordinator for submitting the Application for the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers (VA Form 10-10CG).
The VA information line at 877-222-8387 can provide assistance in filling out the Application for the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers (VA Form 10-10CG).
The Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers allows a Veteran to appoint one primary caregiver and up to two secondary caregivers.

For the primary caregiver in the Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers, benefits may include caregiver education and training, a monthly stipend payment, travel, lodging, and financial assistance when traveling with the Veteran to receive care, access to health care benefits through the Civilian Health and Medical Program of the Department of Veterans Affairs (CHAMPVA) if not already qualified for another health care plan, mental health services and counseling, and up to 30 days per year of respite care.
VA Vocational Rehabilitation (Chapter 31) is a program.

If you have a service-connected disability that limits your ability to work or prevents you from working, the VA Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment VR&E program also referred to as Chapter 31 can help.
The VA Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment VR&E program can help you explore employment options.
The VA Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment VR&E program can help you with any required training needs.
In some cases, your family members may also be eligible for certain benefits from the VA Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment VR&E program.
The VR&E program has support-and-services tracks for service members and Veterans with service-connected disabilities.
The VR&E program support-and-services tracks can help service members and Veterans learn new skills.
The VR&E program support-and-services tracks can help service members and Veterans find a new job.
The VR&E program support-and-services tracks can help service members and Veterans start a business.
The VR&E program support-and-services tracks can provide educational counseling to service members and Veterans.
The VR&E program support-and-services tracks can help service members and Veterans return to their former job.
You can find out if you can get VR&E benefits and services as a service member or Veteran.
You can find out how to apply for VR&E benefits and services as a service member or Veteran.

If you're wounded, injured, or fall ill while serving and can't perform your duties, you can find out how you can access VR&E services as soon as possible through the Integrated Disability Evaluation System IDES.
Dependent family members can find out if they're eligible for certain counseling services, training, and education benefits from the VR&E program.
The VetSuccess on Campus program can help you find out if counselors can help you transition from military to college life.
External resources outside VA can help you in your job search.
You may be able to get VA disability benefits or compensation if you have a current illness or injury known as a condition that affects your body or mind.

You must meet at least one of the following requirements to be eligible for VA disability benefits or compensation: You served on active duty, active duty for training, or inactive duty training, and you have a disability rating for your service-connected condition.

At least one of the following must be true for you to be eligible for VA disability benefits or compensation: You got sick or injured while serving in the military and can link this condition to your illness or injury (an inservice disability claim), or you had an illness or injury before you joined the military and serving made it worse (a preservice disability claim), or you have a disability related to your active-duty service that didn't appear until after you ended your service (a postservice disability claim).

Presumed disabilities that may qualify for VA disability benefits or compensation include: A chronic long-lasting illness that appears within one year after discharge, or an illness caused by contact with contaminants toxic chemicals or other hazardous materials, or an illness caused by your time spent as a prisoner of war (POW).
Veterans and qualified dependents are covered by VA disability benefits.
If you received an other than honorable, bad conduct, or dishonorable discharge, you may not be eligible for VA disability benefits.

There are two ways to try to qualify for VA disability benefits if you received an other than honorable, bad conduct, or dishonorable discharge: Find out how to apply for a discharge upgrade, or learn about the VA Character of Discharge review process.

You may be able to get VA disability benefits for conditions such as: Chronic long-lasting back pain resulting in a current diagnosed back disability, breathing problems resulting from a current lung condition or lung disease, severe hearing loss, scar tissue, loss of range of motion problems moving your body, ulcers, and cancers caused by contact with toxic chemicals or other dangers.
You may also be able to get VA disability benefits for: Traumatic brain injury (TBI), posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), depression, and anxiety.
If you have signs of an illness that started within a year after you were discharged from active service, you may be able to get disability benefits.
Frequently asked questions about decision reviews are provided.

The page includes sections on what is new and relevant evidence, what is Duty to Assist, what to do if the deadline for submitting a request is missed, what to expect if a call with a senior reviewer is requested, what to expect if a hearing with a Veterans Law Judge is requested, what to do if the review option needs to be changed after submitting a form, and how to opt in if a legacy claim or appeal needs to be considered in the modernized system.
New evidence is information that VA did not have before the last decision.
Relevant evidence is information that could prove or disprove something about a case.
VA cannot accept a Supplemental Claim without new and relevant evidence.
Evidence can be submitted by the claimant or VA can be requested to get the evidence, such as medical records.
VA's Duty to Assist requires VA to assist in getting evidence, such as medical records, that is needed to support a case.
VA's Duty to Assist applies during the initial claim and if a Supplemental Claim is filed.
VA's Duty to Assist does not apply if a Higher-Level Review or Board Appeal is requested.
However, the reviewer or judge will look at whether VA met its Duty to Assist during the initial claim or Supplemental Claim, and if not, they will have VA correct that error.
The review may take longer if VA's Duty to Assist needs to be corrected.
If the deadline for submitting a request is missed, the claimant can add new and relevant evidence and file a Supplemental Claim.
If the deadline is missed, the effective date for benefits will generally be tied to the date VA receives the new request, not the date VA received the initial claim.
If the deadline is missed, the claimant can send a letter to VA requesting that it revise the decision based on a Clear and Unmistakable Error (CUE).
CUE is a specific and rare kind of error.
To prove CUE, the claimant must show that the correct facts, known at the time, were not before VA or that VA incorrectly applied the law as it existed at the time.
It must be undebatable that an error occurred and that this error changed the outcome of the case.
Misinterpretation of the facts or a failure by VA to meet its Duty to Assist are not sufficient reasons for CUE.
Guidance from a qualified representative should be sought for CUE, as it can only be requested once per decision.
If a Board decision is disagreed with, the decision will have information on additional ways to address errors.

If an informal conference with a senior reviewer is requested on the Higher-Level Review option, the senior reviewer will call the phone number provided on the Higher-Level Review form to schedule a time to discuss the case.
The senior reviewer will try to reach the claimant or representative by phone twice.
If no one answers, the senior reviewer will leave a voice mail.
During the call, the claimant and/or representative can talk about why they think the decision should be changed and identify errors.
There will not be transcripts of this call.
The claimant has the option to request a hearing with a Veterans Law Judge.
A video conference hearing will take place at a VA location near the claimant.
At the hearing, the claimant and the judge will have a conversation.
The judge will listen to the claimant's testimony.
The judge may ask the claimant a few questions.
The claimant's representative, if they have one, may help the claimant at the hearing.
The hearing will be transcribed and added to the claimant's appeal file.
The claimant can add new and relevant evidence within 90 days after the hearing, but it is not required.
If the claimant wants to change the review option after submitting a form, they can send in a new decision review request form within 1 year from the date on the VA decision.
The claimant must include a letter that says they want to withdraw the existing review and switch to a different option.
If a Board Appeal was requested and the claimant wants to switch to a different appeal option, they can send in a new Board Appeal form with a different option selected.
The claimant can switch appeal options within 1 year from the date on the VA decision or 60 days from the date the original form was submitted.
The claimant cannot select a different appeal option if they have already submitted evidence or had a hearing.

If the claimant disagrees with a VA decision received before February 19, 2019, they can opt in to the modernized review system after receiving a VA Statement of the Case (SOC) or Supplemental Statement of the Case (SSOC).
To get a SOC or SSOC, the claimant must file a Notice of Disagreement (VA Form 21-0958) within 1 year of the date on the decision.

After receiving a SOC or SSOC on the issue in the Notice of Disagreement, the claimant has 60 days or the remainder of the 1-year period following the decision appealed, whichever is later, to opt in to the modernized system.

To opt in, the claimant must submit one of the following forms and check the SOC/SSOC opt-in box: Decision Review Request: Supplemental Claim (VA Form 20-0995), Decision Review Request: Higher-Level Review (VA Form 20-0996), or Decision Review Request: Board Appeal (VA Form 10182).
You can take part in the Veterans work-study program if you meet all of the requirements listed below.
All of these must be true for you to take part in the Veterans work-study program: You are enrolled at least three-quarter time in a college degree, vocational, or professional program.
All of these must be true for you to take part in the Veterans work-study program: You have found an open job either at a nearby VA facility or in a VA-related role at your school.
All of these must be true for you to take part in the Veterans work-study program: You can finish the work-study contract while you still qualify for education benefits.
All of these must be true for you to take part in the Veterans work-study program: You are using an approved VA education benefits program to pay for your education or training.

The approved VA education benefits programs include: Post-9/11 GI Bill for Veterans, Post-9/11 GI Bill for family members using transferred benefits, Montgomery GI Bill Active Duty (MGIB-AD), Montgomery GI Bill Selected Reserve (MGIB-SR), Veterans Educational Assistance Program (VEAP), Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance (DEA), National Call to Service, Vocational rehabilitation and employment.
Dependents who qualify under 38 U.S.C. Chapter 35 may use work study only while enrolled at a school in one of the 50 states.
You can get paid to work a part-time job while you study in the Veterans work-study program.
To get the benefits of the Veterans work-study program, you need to apply by filling out an Application for Work-Study Allowance VA Form 22-8691.
If you have any questions about the Veterans work-study program, you can contact the VA regional processing office that handles your claim.
If you have questions about other sources of financial assistance, you can contact your school's financial aid office.
In the Veterans work-study program, you can get a job that is related to VA work, meets your interests, and fills a need.
In the Veterans work-study program, you can work for a VA facility.
In the Veterans work-study program, you can work for a Department of Defense, Coast Guard, that oversees MGIB-SR or REAP or National Guard location.
In the Veterans work-study program, you can work for a State Veterans agency to help Veterans get Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment benefits.

In the Veterans work-study program, you can work for a Center of Excellence for Veteran Student Success to support the academic, financial, physical, and social needs of Veteran students that the VA runs together with a college, university, or other institution of higher learning.
In the Veterans work-study program, you can work for a cooperative program, college, university, or other institution of higher learning in any Veteran-related role.

In a Veteran-related role in the Veterans work-study program, you could help Veteran students with general questions about Veteran benefits, process documents for Veterans, or maintain and organize Veteran-related files.
In the Veterans work-study program, you will earn an hourly wage that is the same as the federal minimum wage or your state minimum wage, whichever is greater.
If your school usually pays students more for the job you are doing in the Veterans work-study program, they may pay you the difference between the amount the VA pays and their usual rate.
In the Veterans work-study program, you may elect to be paid in advance for 40% of the hours in your work-study agreement, or for 50 hours, whichever is fewer.

After you have worked the hours covered by your first payment in the Veterans work-study program, the VA will pay you each time you finish 50 hours of service or every other week, whichever comes first.
In the Veterans work-study program, you can work during or between enrollment periods.
In the Veterans work-study program, you cannot work more hours total than 25 times the number of weeks in your enrollment period.
For example, if you are enrolled for a semester that lasts for 15 weeks in the Veterans work-study program, you can work up to 375 hours for that enrollment period.
The Montgomery GI Bill Active Duty (MGIB-AD) can help you pay for education and training programs.
To qualify for the MGIB-AD program, you must have served at least 2 years on active duty and been honorably discharged.

To be eligible for education benefits through the MGIB-AD program under Category I, all of the following must be true: you have a high school diploma, GED, or 12 hours of college credit, you entered active duty for the first time after June 30, 1985, your military pay was reduced by $100 a month for the first 12 months of service, and at least one of the following is true: you served continuously without a break for 3 years, you served continuously without a break for 2 years if that was your agreement when you enlisted, or you entered the Selected Reserve within a year of leaving active duty (called the 2 by 4 program).

To be eligible for education benefits through the MGIB-AD program under Category II, all of the following must be true: you have a high school diploma, GED, or 12 hours of college credit, you entered active duty before January 1, 1977 or before January 2, 1978, under a delayed enlistment program contracted before January 1, 1977, you served at least 1 day between October 19, 1984, and June 30, 1985, and stayed on active duty through June 30, 1988 or through June 30, 1987, if you entered the Selected Reserve within 1 year of leaving active duty and served 4 years, and you had at least 1 day of entitlement left under the Vietnam Era GI Bill Chapter 34 as of December 31, 1989.

To be eligible for education benefits through the MGIB-AD program under Category III, all of the following must be true: you have a high school diploma, GED, or 12 hours of college credit, you do not qualify for MGIB under categories I or II, your military pay was reduced by $1,200 before separation, and one of the following is true: you were on active duty on September 30, 1990, and involuntarily separated (not by your choice) after February 2, 1991, you were involuntarily separated on or after November 30, 1993, or you chose to voluntarily separate under either the Voluntary Separation Incentive (VSI) program or the Special Separation Benefit (SSB) program.

To be eligible for education benefits through the MGIB-AD program under Category IV, both of the following must be true: you have a high school diploma, GED, or 12 hours of college credit, and your military pay was reduced by $100 a month for 12 months or you made a $1,200 lump-sum contribution (meaning you paid it all at once). Additionally, one of the following must be true: you were on active duty on October 9, 1996, had money left in a VEAP account on that date, and chose MGIB before October 9, 1997, or you entered full-time National Guard duty under title 32, USC, between July 1, 1985, and November 28, 1989, and chose MGIB between October 9, 1996, and July 9, 1997.
Under the MGIB-AD program, you may get up to 36 months of education benefits, which will be paid monthly.

The amount of benefits you will receive under the MGIB-AD program depends on your length of service, the type of educational or training program you choose, your category as defined above, whether you qualify for a college fund or kicker, and how much you have paid into the $600 Buy-Up program.
You usually have 10 years to use your MGIB-AD benefits, but this may change depending on your situation.

To get MGIB-AD benefits, you must first make sure that the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) has approved your program before you enroll, either by contacting the school or using the GI Bill Comparison Tool.
If you have questions about whether your program has been approved for VA educational benefits, you can call the VA at 888-GIBILL-1 (888-442-4551) or submit a question through the GI Bill website.
If your program has not been approved by the VA, you will need to ask the school to request approval, as the VA cannot take any action until an official from your school (not you) requests approval.
If your program is not approved by the VA, you will have to pay all costs at the school, including tuition and fees.
To apply for MGIB-AD benefits, you can submit your Application for VA Benefits (VA Form 22-1990) online, by mail, in person, or with the help of a trained professional.

After applying for MGIB-AD benefits, you must ask your school or training program to certify your enrollment, which may be done by someone in the financial aid, Veterans affairs, registrar, admissions, counseling, training, finance, or human resources office.

To continue receiving MGIB-AD benefit payments, you will need to verify your enrollment at the end of each month, either online through the Web Automated Verification system (WAVE) or by phone at 877-823-2378.

You can use your MGIB-AD education benefits in various ways to advance your education and training, including for remedial courses (classes some students must take to build up their basic skills in math, reading, or English before they can take regular college courses), deficiency courses (classes some students must take in order to be admitted to a certain college), and refresher courses (brief courses that help people review and improve their knowledge in a certain subject area).
You may qualify for more than one VA education benefit, but you will need to decide which one to receive, as you cannot receive benefits under more than one program at a time.
If you are eligible for more than one VA education benefit, the VA can help you make the decision of which one to receive by calling 888-GI-BILL-1 (888-442-4551).
GI Bill is a registered trademark of the United States Department of Veterans Affairs (VA).
You'll need to sign in to eBenefits to view your VA payment history.
To use the feature to view your VA payment history, you'll need a Premium DS Logon account.
Your My HealtheVet or ID.me credentials won't work on the eBenefits website.
You can go to eBenefits to sign in, register, or upgrade your DS Logon account to Premium.
You can go to eBenefits to view payments.
If you're a Veteran, you'll see a history of your past VA payments for: Disability compensation, Pension benefits, Education benefits.

If you're the survivor of a Veteran or service member, you'll see a history of your past VA payments for: Survivors pension benefits, Survivors' and Dependents' Educational Assistance Chapter 35 benefits, Dependency and Indemnity Compensation (DIC).
If your decision notice shows at least a 10% disability rating, you'll get your first disability compensation payment within 15 days.
If you don't get a disability compensation payment within 15 days, you should call the Veterans Help Line at 800-827-1000 (TTY: 800-829-4833).
The Veterans Help Line is available Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. ET.
You can change your direct deposit or contact information in either of these ways: Change your information online, or Contact your nearest VA regional benefit office or eligibility office.
You can sign in to VA.gov and change your address and other contact information in your VA.gov profile.

Changing your address and other contact information in your VA.gov profile will update your information across disability compensation, pension benefits, claims and appeals, Vocational Rehabilitation & Employment (VR&E), and VA health care.
You can find out how to change your address on file with VA.

You should contact VA if you have other changes to your information, such as a change in your marital status, having a baby, adopting a child, or experiencing any other life change that could affect your rating or payment.
If you have a disability rating of 30% or higher, you may be able to add eligible dependents to your VA disability compensation to get a higher payment (also called a benefit rate).
You can find out how to add eligible dependents.
If your disability gets worse, you can file a claim for an increase in VA benefits.
You can file for a VA disability increase.
The process for Board hearings has changed.
If you're appealing a VA decision under the new process, keep reading below to learn how to request and prepare for a hearing.
You'll follow the new process if you're appealing a VA decision you received on or after February 19, 2019.
You'll follow the new process if you're participating in the Rapid Appeals Modernization Program.
You'll follow the new process if you're opting into the new process using VA Form 10182.
If you're using VA Form 9 to appeal a VA decision you received before February 19, 2019, go to the Board of Veterans' Appeals (BVA) Hearing page.
You can request a video conference hearing if you want to provide testimony to a judge about your appeal.
The hearing will be transcribed and added to your appeal file.
You aren't required to have a hearing.
A Board hearing is always optional.
When you fill out the Decision Review Request: Board Appeal VA Form 10182, select block 11c, 'Hearing with a Veterans Law Judge'.
You'll get a notice in the mail at least 30 days before your hearing is scheduled.
The notice will let you know the date and time of the hearing and where it's located.
You can bring new and relevant evidence to your hearing to share with the judge.
You also have 90 days after the day of your hearing to submit new evidence for the judge's review.
Please don't submit new evidence prior to your hearing.
A representative who's trained in the appeals process can help you prepare for your hearing and for the conversation with the judge.
Your representative must be a VA-accredited lawyer, claims agent, or someone from a Veterans Service Organization (VSO).
To start, the judge will swear you in, asking you to take an oath that you'll tell the truth during the hearing.
You and the judge will have a conversation.
The judge will listen to your testimony and may ask you a few questions.
Your representative, if you have one, may help you at the hearing.
You'll tell the judge why you think you qualify for the VA benefits in your appeal.
You'll answer any questions the judge has about your appeal.
You'll share any new evidence with the judge.
Hearings usually last 30 minutes.
Your hearing will be transcribed and added to your appeal file.
You'll be asked if you'd like a copy of the transcript for your personal records.
The judge will review the hearing and the other evidence in your appeal file before making a decision.
When the 90-day time period for submitting new evidence closes, your case will be placed on the docket for a decision by a judge.
If you don't have new evidence to submit, you can waive the 90-day time period that's automatically added to your appeal.
Some Veterans Service Organizations will ask for time to make additional arguments in support of your case, so contact your representative first if you're thinking of waiving this time period.
You'll need to send a written request to the Board of Veterans Appeals providing good cause to reschedule your hearing at least 2 weeks before your hearing.
Include your name, the VA file number for your appeal, and the reason why you need a new hearing date in the written request.
Send your written request to the Board using the address or fax number listed below.
If your hearing is less than 2 weeks away, you'll need to file a motion explaining why you need to reschedule.
Examples of good cause for rescheduling would include if you, your representative, or a witness are sick or you had trouble getting records.
A judge will review your request, and you'll receive a notice in the mail when the judge decides if the hearing can be rescheduled.
You won't lose your place in line if you reschedule your hearing.
The Board of Veterans Appeals schedules hearings in docket order the order in which they receive requests.
You'll keep the same docket date, and your hearing will be rescheduled to the earliest date possible.
If you change your mind about having a hearing, you can write to the Board to withdraw (cancel) your hearing request.
Withdrawing your hearing request won't speed up your appeal unless you also switch to the Direct Review appeal option, which can only be done at certain times.
If you switch to a different appeal option, you'll keep the same docket date and your appeal will be decided at the same time as other appeals with the same date.
However, the time it takes to get a decision is different on each docket.
If you need to withdraw your hearing request, you or your representative should send a written request at least 2 weeks before your hearing.
Include your name, the VA file number for your appeal, and the reason you're withdrawing the appeal in the written request.
You still have the option to submit new evidence, as long as you send it to the Board within 90 days of withdrawing your hearing request.
Send your written request to the Board using the address or fax number listed below.
You can mail a written request to reschedule or withdraw your Board hearing to Board of Veterans Appeals, PO Box 27063, Washington, D.C. 20038.
You can fax your request to reschedule or withdraw your Board hearing to 844-678-8979.
You can submit new evidence for the judge to review within 90 days of the day of your hearing by mail or fax.

You may be eligible for additional VA disability compensation for a dependent spouse if you meet both of the following requirements: You are eligible for VA disability compensation, and you have a combined disability rating of at least 30%.

You may be eligible for additional VA disability compensation for a dependent child if you meet both of the following requirements: You are eligible for VA disability compensation, and you have a combined disability rating of at least 30%.

You may be eligible for additional VA disability compensation for a dependent parent if you meet both of the following requirements: You are eligible for VA disability compensation, and you have a combined disability rating of at least 30%.
Adding a dependent may make you eligible to receive a higher VA disability compensation payment also called a benefit rate.
A spouse is considered a dependent by VA.
VA recognizes same-sex marriages and common-law marriages when considering a spouse as a dependent.
A parent is considered a dependent by VA if you are directly caring for them and their income and net worth are below a certain amount.
An unmarried child including an adopted child or stepchild is considered a dependent by VA.

For an unmarried child to be considered a dependent by VA, one of the following must be true: The child is under 18 years old, or the child is between the ages of 18 and 23 years old and enrolled in school full time, or the child became permanently disabled before they turned 18.

If you have not yet filed a claim for VA disability compensation, you can file a claim for additional compensation for a dependent at the same time as you file your original claim for disability compensation.
If you receive a combined VA disability rating of at least 30%, VA will automatically consider your eligibility for additional compensation for your dependent.

If you have one or more dependents but did not claim them when you originally filed for VA disability compensation, and you have a combined disability rating of at least 30%, you can file a claim for additional disability compensation now.
You can file a claim for additional VA disability compensation whenever you add a dependent if you have a combined disability rating of at least 30%.

You can add a dependent if: You get married, you have or adopt a child, your child is between 18 and 23 years old and enrolled in school full time, VA determines that your child who is at least 18 years old became permanently disabled before turning 18, or you become the caregiver for a parent whose income and net worth is below a certain amount.
To file a claim for additional VA disability compensation for a child or spouse, you can file a claim online through the eBenefits website.
If you are claiming your child who became permanently disabled before they turned 18, you will need to submit all private medical records relating to the child's disabilities with your application.

If your dependent is a child who is between 18 and 23 years old and attending school full time, you will also need to submit a Request for Approval of School Attendance VA Form 21-674 with your application.
To file a claim for additional VA disability compensation for a dependent parent, you will need to fill out and submit a Statement of Dependency of Parent VA Form 21P-509 by mail or fax.
You can work with an accredited Veterans Service Officer (VSO) for help with your claim for additional VA disability compensation for a dependent.
VSOs are trusted professionals because they are trained and certified in the VA claims and appeals process.

You can file a claim for additional VA disability compensation by mail or fax using the following forms: For a spouse or a child under 18 years of age, you will need to fill out a Declaration of Status of Dependents VA Form 21-686c. For a child who is between 18 and 23 years old and attending school full time, you will need to fill out both VA Form 21-686c and a Request for Approval of School Attendance VA Form 21-674. For a dependent parent, you will need to fill out a Statement of Dependency of Parent VA Form 21P-509.
If you file your claim for additional VA disability compensation for a dependent online, VA will recognize the day you start the online claim process as the date VA received your claim.
If VA decides you are eligible for additional disability compensation for a dependent, VA will pay you back to the date you started the online claim process.

If you file a claim for additional VA disability compensation for a dependent by mail or fax, VA may pay you back to the date of your marriage or the birth or adoption of your child if all of the following are true: You had already received a combined disability rating of at least 30% at the time of the marriage, birth, or adoption, you file your claim for additional disability compensation for the dependent within a year of the marriage, birth, or adoption, and you respond within a year to VA's request for any more information or evidence needed to confirm your claim.

If it has been more than one year since you got married or had or adopted a child, VA may not pay you back to the date of the marriage, birth, or adoption for additional disability compensation for the dependent.
Instead, VA may pay you back only to the date VA received your claim for additional disability compensation for the dependent or, in some cases, up to a year before this date.
VA will begin paying you additional disability compensation for a dependent within 2 weeks after approving your claim.
You can check if VA has added your dependent and made you eligible for additional compensation by signing in to your eBenefits account and clicking the Dependents link under the My Profile section.
If your dependent is listed in eBenefits, you should be eligible for additional VA disability compensation for them.
If your dependent is not listed in eBenefits, you should file a claim for the additional benefit.
If you and your spouse are both Veterans with a combined disability rating of at least 30%, you can both receive additional VA disability compensation for each other and for your children.
If you and your spouse are both Veterans, it will take VA longer to process your claim for additional disability compensation for a dependent if your spouse is also a Veteran.

If you file your claim for additional VA disability compensation for a dependent online, and VA decides you are eligible, VA will pay you back to the date you started the online claim process even if your spouse is also a Veteran.
You can submit a request through eBenefits asking VA to stop paying additional disability compensation for a spouse or child.
It will take VA more time to process a request to stop paying additional disability compensation for a child than for a spouse, but the online process is still faster than submitting a paper request.
If you get divorced, you should notify VA right away so VA does not continue paying you additional disability compensation for your former spouse and, if applicable, stepchildren after the divorce.
You do not need to send or upload supporting documents to eBenefits if you get divorced and need to notify VA to stop paying additional disability compensation for your former spouse.
If VA continues paying you benefits that you are not eligible for, VA may withhold money from future payments until you have paid VA back.
If your child is between 18 and 23 years old and enrolled in school full time, you will need to update your child's school information in eBenefits.
VA will track your child's age based on the date of birth you give VA when you submit your claim for additional disability compensation for the child.
When your child turns 18, VA will stop paying additional disability compensation for them unless you let VA know they are enrolled in school full time.
After you file your disability benefits claim, we may ask you to have a claim exam also known as a compensation and pension, or C&P, exam.
If you miss your scheduled exam, we may not be able to reschedule you right away, and your claim may be delayed while you wait for a new appointment.
If you miss your scheduled exam, we may need to rate your claim as-is.
If we rate your claim as-is, we'll base our decision about your disability benefits only on the evidence we have in your file, which may not be enough.
The VA claim exam will help us rate your disability.
Your disability rating will be based on how severe your disability is.
Your disability rating will affect how much disability compensation you'll receive.
Disability compensation may include things like monthly payments and enrollment in the VA health care program.
We'll ask you to have a claim exam only if we need more information to decide your claim.
If you have enough medical evidence in your file to support your claim, we won't ask you to have a claim exam.
Medical evidence may include doctor and hospital reports, test results, and other documents.
The staff at your local VA medical center or a local doctor's office that we partner with will contact you to schedule your VA claim exam.
The staff will either send you a letter by mail with the date and time of your exam, or call you to find a time that works for you.
Make sure both the VA regional office and the VA medical center nearest you have your up-to-date address, phone number, and email address so you get your exam notice in time.
Call the number provided right away to confirm the time and location of your exam.
It's important not to miss your scheduled exam, so you'll want to double check that you have the right place and time.
If you can't make it to your appointment, let us know right away.
To reschedule your appointment: Call 800-827-1000, or Go to your nearest VA regional benefit office.
You don't need to bring anything to your VA claim exam.
If you have any new non-VA medical records like records from a recent surgery or illness, please be sure to submit them before your appointment.
The health care provider can't review new information during the exam.
If you have children, you'll need to plan ahead for childcare during your exam.
Because you and the doctor may discuss sensitive topics, children shouldn't be in the room with you.
On the day of the exam, you'll want to wear comfortable clothes so you can move freely while the doctor exams you.
A VA claim exam isn't like a normal medical exam or other VA health care visits.
The doctor won't treat you for any illness or injury during the VA claim exam.
The doctor won't give you referrals to other health care providers during the VA claim exam.
The doctor won't prescribe medicine during the VA claim exam.
The purpose of the VA claim exam is to gather information that will help us make a decision on your claim.
During your VA claim exam, the doctor may review your claim file with you.
During your VA claim exam, the doctor may ask you questions based on the medical records in your claim file.
The questions may include questions from the Disability Benefits Questionnaire for each service-connected condition you're claiming.
During your VA claim exam, the doctor may perform a basic physical exam.
During your VA claim exam, the doctor may ask you to get other tests like X-rays or blood work if needed.
If you have any questions about what's happening during your exam, feel free to ask the doctor.
The doctor's job is to examine you during the VA claim exam, not to make any decisions about your claim.
The doctor won't be able to answer questions about the claims process during the VA claim exam.
After your VA claim exam, the doctor will write up a report and send it to a VA claims processor to be added to your claim file.
Your VA claim exam may be very short, or it may last an hour or more.
The length of your VA claim exam depends on the conditions you've claimed and whether we need more information to make a decision.
The required questions the doctor asks about a knee injury may take only a few minutes during the VA claim exam.
The questions for a more complex illness or injury could take much longer during the VA claim exam.
A mental health evaluation usually lasts 2 to 4 hours during the VA claim exam.
Your in-person visit is only one part of the claim review process during the VA claim exam.
The doctor will also spend time outside the exam carefully reviewing your records during the VA claim exam.
Either a VA doctor or a non-VA doctor who we've contracted with will do the VA claim exam.
You can also have your own doctor examine you and fill out the necessary forms for the VA claim exam.
The doctor will give the exam results to our VA claims processors.
Our VA claims processors will decide your claim based on the exam results, plus your other medical and military records.
If you have questions about the claims process, call your nearest VA regional benefit office.
If you miss your VA claim exam, contact us right away to let us know why you didn't make it.
If you have what we consider to be a good reason for missing your exam called good cause, we'll work with you to reschedule your exam.
Examples of good cause might be an illness or the death of someone in your immediate family.
We'll review all the evidence in your file after your VA claim exam.
We'll assign your disability rating after your VA claim exam.
We'll send you a decision notice (a letter letting you know your disability rating) after your VA claim exam.
Each claim is different, but it usually takes us about 3 to 4 months to process a claim from start to finish after your VA claim exam.
The processing time for your claim depends on how complex your claim is and how many conditions you've claimed after your VA claim exam.
To get a copy of the final report from your VA claim exam, you can: Contact your nearest VA regional benefit office, or Call us at 800-827-1000 and request an appointment to view your file.

Our VA claims processors will review: The information you've given us, The medical records, The report from the doctor who handled your claim exam, and the results of any ordered medical tests, Statements from you and others about your claim, Your military medical and personnel records.
We may ask you to have a claim exam if you appeal your disability benefits decision.

You can download helpful PDFs about the VA claim exam process, including: VA claim exam fact sheet, VA claim exam tips, VA claim exam FAQs, Step-by-step VA claim process, Mental health exam fact sheet, Review exams fact sheet.

You can watch our VA claim exams video series, which offers videos on how to prepare for your VA claim exam, how to use disability benefits questionnaires (DBQs), and what to expect at claim exams for the most common disability claims.
After you file your claim, you can learn how VA assigns disability ratings, which will affect how much disability compensation you'll receive.
After you file your claim, you can check the claim and appeal status to track the status of your disability claims and appeals.
After you file your claim, you can learn about the appeals process if you disagree with your disability rating decision.

Si eres un veterano, puedes ser elegible para los beneficios y servicios de Rehabilitación Vocacional y Empleo (VR&E) si no recibiste una baja deshonrosa y tienes una calificación de discapacidad relacionada con el servicio de al menos 10% de VA y solicitas los servicios de VR&E.

El período básico de elegibilidad termina 12 años después de la fecha en que recibiste el aviso de tu fecha de separación del servicio militar activo o tu primera calificación de discapacidad relacionada con el servicio de VA.
El período básico de elegibilidad puede extenderse si un Consejero de Rehabilitación Vocacional (VRC) determina que tienes una discapacidad de empleo grave (SEH).

Tener una discapacidad de empleo significa que tu discapacidad relacionada con el servicio limita tu capacidad para prepararte, obtener y mantener un empleo adecuado, que no empeore tu discapacidad, sea estable y se ajuste a tus habilidades, aptitudes e intereses.

Si aún estás en servicio activo, puedes ser elegible para los beneficios y servicios de VR&E si tienes una calificación de discapacidad previa al alta del 20% o más y pronto dejarás el servicio militar, o estás participando en el proceso del Sistema Integrado de Evaluación de Discapacidades (IDES) o esperando el alta debido a una condición médica resultante de una lesión o enfermedad grave ocurrida en el cumplimiento del deber.

Los miembros del servicio activo gravemente lesionados pueden recibir automáticamente los beneficios de VR&E antes de que VA emita una calificación de discapacidad, debido a la Sección 1631 de la Ley de Autorización de Defensa Nacional (PL 110-181).

Si recibiste una baja que no fue honorable, por mala conducta o deshonrosa, puedes intentar calificar solicitando una actualización de la baja o a través del proceso de revisión del carácter de la baja de VA.
Puedes solicitar los servicios de VR&E en línea a través de eBenefits, incluso si eres un miembro del servicio sin una calificación de discapacidad aún.

Los servicios de VR&E pueden incluir una evaluación completa para determinar tus habilidades, destrezas e intereses para el empleo, asesoramiento vocacional y planificación de la rehabilitación para servicios de empleo, servicios de empleo como capacitación laboral, desarrollo de currículos y otros servicios de preparación para el trabajo, ayuda para encontrar y mantener un empleo, capacitación en el trabajo (OJT), aprendizajes y experiencias de trabajo no remuneradas, capacitación postsecundaria, servicios de rehabilitación de apoyo y servicios de vida independiente.

Si eres elegible para los beneficios de la Ley GI Bill y estás participando en un programa de VR&E, puedes optar por recibir la tasa de manutención de la Ley GI Bill Post-9/11 en lugar de la tasa de asignación de manutención del Capítulo 31.

El programa de Incentivos Especiales para Empleadores (SEI) de VR&E ofrece oportunidades para obtener capacitación y experiencia práctica de trabajo al mismo tiempo para veteranos elegibles que enfrentan desafíos para conseguir un empleo.

El programa de Experiencia de Trabajo No Remunerada (NPWE) de VR&E es para veteranos y miembros del servicio elegibles que tienen una meta profesional establecida y aprenden fácilmente en un entorno práctico o tienen dificultades para conseguir un empleo debido a la falta de experiencia laboral.
VR&E tiene coordinadores de empleo ubicados en las oficinas regionales de VA y muchas ubicaciones externas que pueden ayudarte a acceder a los servicios de empleo disponibles para ti.
VR&E ofrece consejeros para ayudarte en la transición de la vida militar a la vida universitaria a través del programa VetSuccess on Campus.
VR&E proporciona enlaces a recursos externos fuera de VA que pueden ayudarte en tu búsqueda de empleo.
Si estás participando en un programa de empleo de VR&E y perdiste tu vivienda debido a un desastre natural u otro, puedes calificar para 2 meses adicionales de la Asignación de Ajuste de Empleo.
A Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) is a secure ID card that keeps your personal information safe while giving VA the information needed to easily access your VA health record.
You will use your Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) to check in to your appointments at VA medical centers.
You may also use your Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) to get discounts offered to Veterans at many stores, businesses, and restaurants.
You cannot use your Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) as a credit card or insurance card.
Your Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) does not pay copays or authorize care at non-VA health facilities.
To get your Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC), you need to be enrolled in VA health care.
If you are not already enrolled in VA health care, you need to find out how to apply for VA health care.
After you receive your VA health care welcome call, you need to contact your nearest VA medical center and ask to speak with the enrollment coordinator.
The enrollment coordinator can help you arrange to get your picture taken for your new Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC).
You can also ask for help with getting your picture taken at your next VA health care appointment.
When you get your picture taken for your Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC), you need to show a current form of primary identification.

The current form of primary identification you need to show when getting your picture taken for your Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) can be a state-issued driver's license, a U.S. passport or passport card, or other government ID issued by a federal, state, or local government agency.
The primary identification you show when getting your picture taken for your Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) must show your picture and date of birth.

If the primary identification you show when getting your picture taken for your Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) does not show your address, you need to bring a separate document to confirm your address.

The separate document you can bring to confirm your address when getting your picture taken for your Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) may include your electric bill, cable bill, voter registration card, or another mailed document.
After VA takes your picture for your Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC), VA will process your VHIC and send it to you by mail.
You should receive your Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) within 10 days after VA takes your picture.

If it has been more than 10 days since you had your picture taken and you have not received your Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC), you should call the VA medical center where you had your picture taken.

If it has been more than 10 days since you had your picture taken and you have not received your Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC), you can also call VA at 877-222-8387 (Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. ET).
If you have hearing loss and it has been more than 10 days since you had your picture taken and you have not received your Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC), you can call TTY: 711.
If your Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) is lost or stolen, you can request a replacement card at the VA medical center where you had your picture taken.

To request a replacement Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) if your card is lost or stolen, you need to bring your driver's license, passport, or other government ID or be able to answer a series of challenge questions so VA can verify your identity before giving you a new card.

If you have changed your medical center since getting your original Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) and your card is lost or stolen, you can contact the medical center where you currently receive care to request a replacement card.
If your Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) is lost or stolen, you can also call VA at 877-222-8387 (Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. ET) to request a replacement card.

If you call VA to request a replacement Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) because your card is lost or stolen, VA staff will need to verify your identity with a series of challenge questions before sending you a new card.
If you have an old Veterans identification card, you should destroy it by cutting it up or shredding it.
VA wants all Veterans who are enrolled in VA health care to have the new Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC).
The new Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) offers more security to protect your personal information compared to old Veterans identification cards.
The new Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) offers helpful new features, including 'VA' printed in braille to help Veterans with low vision quickly recognize the card.
The new Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) also displays your latest branch of service emblem and a list of any special awards you may have received.
You can transfer education benefits if you are on active duty or in the Selected Reserve and you meet the requirements listed below.

At least one of these must be true: You have completed at least 6 years of service on the date your request is approved and you agree to add 4 more years of service, or You have completed at least 10 years of service on the date your request is approved, cannot commit to add 4 more years of service because of either a policy or statute, but agree to serve for the maximum amount of time allowed.
This must also be true: The person getting benefits has enrolled in the Defense Enrollment Eligibility Reporting System (DEERS).
Qualified dependents are covered.

If the Department of Defense (DoD) approves the Transfer of Entitlement (TOE), your spouse or dependent children can apply for up to 36 months of benefits, and may be able to get money for: Tuition, Housing, Books and supplies.

These conditions apply to family members using transferred benefits: Spouses may use the benefit right away, may use the benefit while you are on active duty or after you have separated from service, do not qualify for the monthly housing allowance while you are on active duty, may use the benefit for up to 15 years after your separation from active duty.

Children may start to use the benefit only after you have finished at least 10 years of service, may use the benefit while you are on active duty or after you have separated from service, may not use the benefit until they have gotten a high school diploma or equivalency certificate, or have reached 18 years of age, qualify for the monthly housing allowance even when you are on active duty, do not have to use the benefit within 15 years after your separation from active duty, but cannot use the benefit after they have turned 26 years old.
Your dependents may still qualify even if a child marries or you and your spouse divorce.
However, service members and Veterans can revoke (cancel) or change a Transfer of Entitlement (TOE) at any time.
If you want to totally revoke transferred benefits for a dependent and you are still in the service, please turn in another transfer request for the dependent through milConnect.
If a dependent's transfer eligibility (ability to get a TOE) has been totally revoked, you cannot transfer benefits again to that dependent.
While you are still on active duty, you will request to transfer, change, or revoke a Transfer of Entitlement (TOE) through milConnect.
You cannot apply for a TOE through the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA).

If the DoD approves the TOE, your family members may apply for benefits online or by mail by filling out and mailing an Application for Family Member to Use Transferred Benefits VA Form 22-1990E to the nearest VA regional benefit office.

Once you leave active duty, you can still provide a future effective date for when the TOE can be used, change the number of months transferred, or revoke the TOE by submitting a written request to VA through milConnect.
If you have VA life insurance, the easiest way to manage your policy is online.
You can use your online portal to check your policy's status to make sure it's up to date.
You can use your online portal to pay your premium, which is the amount you'll pay each month to keep your coverage.
You can use your online portal to find out about your plan and renewal options, which will depend on which type of plan you have.
You can use your online portal to update your beneficiary, which is the person you've picked to get the money from your policy if you die.
You'll want to review your beneficiary information at least once a year to make sure the name and contact information is still correct.
You'll also need to review the information and make any changes if you get divorced, have a child, or go through other big life changes.

If you have a VA life insurance policy with a file number that starts with a V, RH, J, RS, K, or W or if you'd like to apply for service-disabled life insurance, which is life insurance for Veterans who have become disabled as a result of serving in the military, you can access your policy online through VA.

If you have a Veterans Group Life Insurance (VGLI) policy with a VGLI control number, you can access your policy online through the Office of Servicemembers' Group Life Insurance at Prudential Insurance Company of America.
Prudential Insurance Company of America works with VA to provide Servicemembers' Group Life Insurance (SGLI) and Veterans' Group Life Insurance (VGLI) benefits to service members and Veterans.
The VA Dental Insurance Program (VADIP) offers discounted private dental insurance for Veterans and family members who meet certain requirements.

To be eligible for VADIP, one of the following must be true: You are a Veteran who is enrolled in VA health care, or you are the current or surviving spouse or dependent child of a Veteran or service member, and you are enrolled in the Civilian Health and Medical Program of the VA (CHAMPVA).
VADIP provides coverage throughout the United States and its territories, including Puerto Rico, Guam, the U.S. Virgin Islands, American Samoa, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands.
While some Veterans enrolled in VA health care are eligible for free dental care from VA providers, many are not.
Others may be eligible for free care for some, but not all, of their dental needs.
If you are not eligible for free VA dental care, VADIP can help you buy private dental insurance at a reduced cost.
If you are eligible for free VA care for some of your dental needs, you can buy a VADIP plan if you want added dental insurance.
Signing up for VADIP will not affect your ability to get free VA dental care.

VADIP plans cover many common dental procedures, such as diagnostic services, preventive dental care to manage oral health problems and restore function (called endodontic or restorative services), root canals and other services, dental surgery, and emergency dental care.
The costs for your VADIP coverage will depend on the insurance company and plan you choose.
Based on your VADIP plan, you will pay the full insurance premium for each individual on your plan and any required copays when you get care.
You can read coverage details and compare VADIP plans and premium rates from Delta Dental and MetLife.
To enroll in a VADIP plan, you can enroll online at Delta Dental or MetLife once you have chosen a plan from one of these providers.
After you enroll in a VADIP plan, you can also use your insurance provider's website to manage your plan and benefits online.
