If you were covered during the VADIP pilot program from 2013 to 2017, you need to enroll again to get new coverage, as some of the plan options and fees may have changed.
The VA is currently allowed by law to continue the VADIP program until December 31, 2021.
For questions about Delta Dental VADIP plans, you can call 855-370-3303.
For questions about MetLife VADIP plans, you can call 888-310-1681.
The Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship is a scholarship for children and dependents of Veterans.
If your parent or spouse was an active-duty service member who died in the line of duty on or after September 11, 2001, you may qualify for the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship.

You may be able to get benefits under the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship if you are the child or surviving spouse of an active-duty service member who died in the line of duty on or after September 11, 2001.
As the child of a service member, you can be married or unmarried to get the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship.
If you turned 18 or graduated from high school before January 1, 2013, you can get the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship until you are 33 years old.
If you turn 18 or graduate from high school after January 1, 2013, you can get the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship at any age over 18 or after you graduate, whichever comes first.

If your parent died in the line of duty before August 1, 2011, you may qualify for both the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship and the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance (DEA) program.
You can use only one program at a time, either the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship or the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance (DEA) program.
The combined benefits of the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship and the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance (DEA) program are capped at 81 months of full-time training.
If you are receiving Dependency and Indemnity Compensation (DIC), you will need to give up those payments when you start to use the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship.
As the spouse of a service member, if you remarry, you will no longer be eligible for the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship.
You can still get Dependency and Indemnity Compensation (DIC) payments while using the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship.
With the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship, you may be able to get up to 36 months of benefits, including money for tuition, housing, books, and supplies.

The money for tuition under the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship covers full in-state tuition costs at public schools and up to $22,805.34 per year for training at private or out-of-state schools.
To get the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship, you should choose a school and contact the school's certifying official to make sure your program is approved for VA benefits.

You can apply for the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship online or by filling out a Dependents Application for VA Education Benefits (VA Form 22-5490) and sending it to the VA regional benefit office where you want to go to school.
If you are not legally an adult, your parent or guardian must sign the application for the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship.

If you have already started your educational program, ask a certifying official from your school or your employer to fill out a VA Enrollment Certification (VA Form 22-1999) and submit it online using VA Online Certification (VA-ONCE).
If you qualify for both the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship and the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance (DEA) program, you need to choose which program you want to use.
Once you choose between the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship and the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance (DEA) program, you cannot change your mind.

If your parent died in the line of duty before August 1, 2011, you can use both the Marine Gunnery Sergeant John David Fry Scholarship and the Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance (DEA) program, but you can use only one program at a time.
Servicemembers Group Life Insurance (SGLI) offers low-cost term coverage to eligible service members.
If a service member meets certain criteria, the service member will automatically be signed up for SGLI.
A service member may be able to get full-time SGLI coverage if the service member is an active-duty member of the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, or Coast Guard.

A service member may be able to get full-time SGLI coverage if the service member is a commissioned member of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) or the U.S. Public Health Service (USPHS).
A service member may be able to get full-time SGLI coverage if the service member is a cadet or midshipman of the U.S. military academies.

A service member may be able to get full-time SGLI coverage if the service member is a member, cadet, or midshipman of the Reserve Officers Training Corps (ROTC) engaged in authorized training and practice cruises.

A service member may be able to get full-time SGLI coverage if the service member is a member of the Ready Reserve or National Guard, assigned to a unit, and scheduled to perform at least 12 periods of inactive training per year.
A service member may be able to get full-time SGLI coverage if the service member is a volunteer in an Individual Ready Reserve (IRR) mobilization category.

If a service member is in nonpay status with the Ready Reserve or National Guard, the service member may be able to get full-time SGLI coverage if the service member is scheduled for 12 periods of inactive training for the year and drilling for points rather than pay.
If a service member is in nonpay status with the Ready Reserve or National Guard and qualifies for full-time SGLI coverage, the service member must pay the premiums directly.
SGLI covers service members.
With SGLI, a service member can get coverage up to the top limit of $400,000 in $50,000 increments.
With SGLI, a service member can get 120 days of free coverage from the date the service member left the military.
With SGLI, a service member can get an extension of free coverage for up to 2 years if the service member is totally disabled when the service member leaves the military.
With SGLI, a service member can get part-time coverage if the service member is a Reserve member who does not qualify for full-time coverage.
If a service member qualifies for SGLI, the service member will automatically be signed up through the service member's service branch.
A service member can choose the service member's level of SGLI coverage or even refuse coverage completely.

A service member can choose the service member's beneficiaries (the people the service member picks to get the money from the service member's life insurance policy if the service member dies) and change them as needed.

If a service member is a member of the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, Coast Guard, or National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the service member should submit changes to beneficiaries or SGLI coverage online through the SGLI Online Enrollment System (SOES).

If a service member is a member of the Public Health Service, the service member should submit changes to beneficiaries or SGLI coverage by filling out the Servicemembers Group Life Insurance Election and Certificate (SGLV 8286) and giving it to the service member's unit's personnel officer.
If a service member has SGLI coverage, the service member will pay a monthly premium that will be automatically taken out of the service member's base pay.
The current basic SGLI premium rate is 7 cents per $1,000 of insurance coverage.
The SGLI premium includes an additional $1 per month for Traumatic Injury Protection coverage (TSGLI).

When a service member leaves the military, the service member can apply for Veterans Group Life Insurance (VGLI) within 1 year and 120 days from the service member's discharge for up to the amount of coverage the service member had through SGLI.
When a service member leaves the military, the service member can convert the service member's SGLI policy into a civilian policy within 120 days from the date the service member left the military.

A service member may be able to keep the service member's SGLI coverage for up to 2 years after the date the service member left the military if the service member is within 2 years of the service member's separation date and the service member is totally disabled at the time of the service member's discharge and unable to work.

A service member may be able to keep the service member's SGLI coverage for up to 2 years after the date the service member left the military if the service member is within 2 years of the service member's separation date and the service member has had total loss of hearing in both ears that leaves the service member unable to talk even in a whisper without the help of an artificial device, loss of speech, or permanent long-lasting loss of use of both of the service member's hands, feet, or eyes, or one hand and one foot, or one hand or foot and one eye.

To apply for the Servicemembers Group Life Insurance Disability Extension (SGLI-DE), a service member needs to fill out the SGLI Disability Extension Application (SGLV 8715) and send it to the OSGLI address listed on the application.

If a service member gets approved for the SGLI-DE, the service member will receive a notice 20 months after the service member's separation date letting the service member know that the service member's SGLI-DE will end and that the service member now has the option to pay a premium for Veterans Group Life Insurance (VGLI).
If a service member pays the premium for VGLI, the service member will be able to keep the service member's life insurance coverage for as long as the service member keeps paying the premiums.

If a service member has questions about Servicemembers or Veterans Group Life Insurance, the service member can call the Office of Servicemembers Group Life Insurance (OSGLI) at 800-419-1473, or email the Prudential Insurance Company.
To request an advance insurance payment for a service member who is terminally ill, a family member would file a Claim for Accelerated Benefits (SGLV 8284).
To receive an insurance payment in their time of need, a family member would file a Claim for Death Benefits (SGLV 8283).

To help a service member get short-term financial support while recovering from a traumatic injury, a family member would work with the service member to file an Application for TSGLI Benefits (SGLV 8600).
As a Veteran, you are protected under the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act (USERRA).
This means you cannot be disadvantaged in your civilian career because of your service.
If you are a Veteran with a service-connected disability, the Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (VR&E) Reemployment track can help your employer accommodate your needs.
Your Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor (VRC) can provide a full range of rehabilitation services.
Your Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor (VRC) can refer you directly to the Department of Labor to begin the process.
The Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (VR&E) Reemployment track can help you return to your former job and support your employer in meeting your needs.
You may be eligible for help if you are a Veteran with a service-connected disability and you meet all of the requirements listed below.
You must have an employment barrier or handicap.
You must be enrolled in Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (VR&E).
You must want to return to your former job.
Having an employment handicap means your service-connected disability limits your ability to prepare for, obtain, and maintain suitable employment.
Suitable employment is a job that does not make your disability worse, is stable, and matches your abilities, aptitudes, and interests.
The Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (VR&E) Reemployment track can help with the process of returning to the job you held before you deployed.
To get these benefits, you will need to apply for Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (VR&E) benefits first.
Then, you will work with your Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor (VRC).

If you have your VA disability rating, you can follow these steps to apply: Sign in to your eBenefits account, click Additional Benefits on your dashboard, choose Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment Program, apply for the Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment program.
If you are eligible, the VA will invite you to an orientation session at your nearest VA regional benefit office.
You can go to eBenefits to apply for the Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (VR&E) program.
If you have not yet received a disability rating, there is information on how to apply.

The VA offers opportunities to get training and practical hands-on work experience at the same time through programs like the VR&E Special Employer Incentives (SEI) program for eligible Veterans who face challenges getting a job.

The VA offers opportunities to get training and practical hands-on work experience at the same time through programs like the VR&E Non-Paid Work Experience (NPWE) program for eligible Veterans and service members who have an established career goal and learn easily in a hands-on environment or are having trouble getting a job due to lack of work experience.
The VA also offers VR&E employment coordinators located at VA regional offices and many out-based locations who can help you access the employment services available to you.
The VA also offers counselors to help you transition from military to college life.
The VA also offers links to more resources outside VA that can help you in your job search.
If you are participating in a VR&E employment program and lost your housing because of a natural or other disaster, you may qualify for 2 more months of the Employment Adjustment Allowance.
To qualify for 2 more months of the Employment Adjustment Allowance, you must contact your VR&E counselor for more information.
If you flew on or worked with C-123 aircraft in Vietnam or other locations, you may have had contact with Agent Orange.
The U.S. military used Agent Orange to clear trees and plants during the Vietnam War.
C-123 aircraft sprayed Agent Orange during the Vietnam War.
The C-123 aircraft still had traces of Agent Orange in them afterward while they were being used, up until 1986.
You can get disability compensation and other benefits for illnesses believed to be caused by contact with Agent Orange.

For active-duty service members, you may be able to get disability benefits if the following is true: You have an illness believed to be caused by contact with Agent Orange called a presumptive disease.

For active-duty service members, you may be able to get disability benefits if the following is also true: You served in a regular Air Force unit location where a C-123 aircraft with traces of Agent Orange was assigned.

For active-duty service members, you may be able to get disability benefits if the following is also true: Your flight, ground, or medical duties put you in regular and repeated contact with C-123 aircraft that had traces of Agent Orange.
If you have an illness believed to be caused by Agent Orange, you won't need to show the problem started during or got worse because of your military service.
Certain diseases are believed to be the result of exposure to herbicides, and are referred to as "presumptive diseases".
For Reservists, you may be able to get disability benefits if the following is true: You have an illness believed to be caused by Agent Orange called a presumptive disease.

For Reservists, you may be able to get disability benefits if the following is also true: You were assigned to flight, ground, or medical crew duties at one of the following locations: Lockbourne/Rickenbacker Air Force Base in Ohio (1969-1986), Westover Air Force Base in Massachusetts (1972-1982), or Pittsburgh International Airport in Pennsylvania (1972-1982).
The types of disability benefits you can get include health care and compensation payments.
To get these benefits, you'll need to file a claim for disability compensation.
When filing a claim, you'll have to show that you had exposure to Agent Orange while serving in the military.

You can upload supporting documents along with your online application, including: Discharge or separation papers (DD214 or other separation documents), USAF Form 2096 (unit where you were assigned), USAF Form 5 (aircraft flight duties), USAF Form 781 (aircraft maintenance duties), dependency records (marriage certificate and children's birth certificates), and medical evidence (doctor's report or medical test results).
If you need help filing your claim, you can call the C-123 hotline at 800-749-8387 or email the St. Paul regional benefit office.
You can get help from a trained professional trusted to help with VA-related claims.
More information about C-123 aircraft Agent Orange claims is available in the C-123 Aircraft Agent Orange Exposure claims fact sheet PDF.
Increased disability rating can be obtained for time spent in a VA hospital or a VA-approved hospital for a service-connected disability related to military service.
A service-connected disability is a disability related to military service.

To get increased disability compensation or benefits with a temporary 100% disability rating for the time spent in the hospital, the following conditions must be met: The Veteran spent more than 21 days in a VA hospital or other approved hospital for a service-connected disability, or The Veteran was under hospital observation for more than 21 days at VA's expense for a service-connected disability.
The benefits that can be obtained are: Health care, Increased compensation payments for the time the Veteran spent in the hospital.
To get these benefits, the Veteran needs to file a claim for disability compensation.
If the Veteran was not in a VA hospital, when filing the claim, the Veteran needs to provide a hospital discharge summary showing the length and cause of the hospital stay.

An example is provided: A Veteran with a 40% service-connected disability rating for diabetes had to stay in a VA hospital after going into a diabetic coma. The Veteran needed to stay in the hospital for 25 days because of the coma and related infections. The Veteran's rating was raised to 100% during the hospital stay. After the Veteran got out of the hospital, the disability rating went back to 40%.
You may be able to continue your education by using part of your military pay to help cover the cost of school.
You can get Veterans Educational Assistance Program (VEAP) benefits if you meet all of the requirements listed below.
You entered service for the first time between January 1, 1977, and June 30, 1985.
You opened and put money into your VEAP account before April 1, 1987.
You put in $25 to $2,700 on your own.
You finished your first period of service and did not receive a dishonorable discharge.
If you are currently on active duty, you must have at least 3 months of contributions available to use your VEAP benefits.
The VEAP benefits include money for tuition.
To get VEAP benefits, you need to make sure the VA has approved your selected program.
If you have questions, the VA Education Call Center at 888-442-4551 can help you and your school understand the requirements.
If you have hearing loss, you can call TTY: 711 for assistance.
You can also go to a VA regional benefit office near you for help.
If you have not started training yet, you can submit an Application for VA Education Benefits (VA Form 22-1990) online.
You can also apply for VEAP benefits by mail, in person, or with the help of a trained professional.
If you are on active duty, you will need to have your Education Services Officer approve your enrollment and your Commanding Officer verify your service.
If you are not on active duty, you will need to send a copy of your DD214, Certificate of Release, or Discharge from Active Duty.

If you have already started training, you need to take your VA Form 22-1990 application and the member copy of your DD214 to your school or employer and ask them to complete VA Form 22-1999, Enrollment Certification, and send all the forms to the VA.
You can download VA Form 22-1990 in PDF format.
You need to ask your school or training official to verify your enrollment with the VA.
The VA will review your application and let you know if they need anything else.

The types of training, programs, and fees covered under VEAP education benefits include undergraduate and graduate degree programs, co-op training, non-college degree programs, technical or vocational courses, flight training, on-the-job training and apprenticeships, test fees, entrepreneurship training, and correspondence training.
In some cases, the VA will help you pay for remedial courses, deficiency courses, and refresher courses.
The amount of VEAP benefits you can get, up to 36 months, will depend on how much money you put into your VEAP account every month.
You have 10 years from your release from active duty to use your VEAP benefits.
If you do not use the money after 10 years, the VA will automatically refund it to you.
If you are on active duty and want to use VEAP, you must have at least 3 months of contributions in the fund.
You can withdraw the money in your VEAP account if you do not meet basic qualifying requirements or if you formally ask for a refund.
To ask for a refund, you need to complete an Application for Refund of Educational Contributions (VA Form 22-5281) and send it to your nearest VA regional benefit office.
You can download VA Form 22-5281 in PDF format.
You can get the address of your nearest VA regional benefit office from the VA.

Si usted prestó servicio en la Base del Cuerpo de Marines Camp Lejeune o en la Estación Aérea del Cuerpo de Marines MCAS New River en Carolina del Norte, es posible que haya estado en contacto con contaminantes en el agua potable allí.
La evidencia científica y médica ha demostrado una asociación entre la exposición a estos contaminantes durante el servicio militar y el desarrollo posterior de ciertas enfermedades.

Si usted tiene servicio calificado en Camp Lejeune y un diagnóstico actual de una de las condiciones enumeradas a continuación, es posible que pueda obtener beneficios por discapacidad: leucemia en adultos, anemia aplásica y otros síndromes mielodisplásicos, cáncer de vejiga, cáncer de riñón, cáncer de hígado, mieloma múltiple, linfoma no Hodgkin, enfermedad de Parkinson.
Las personas cubiertas son: veteranos, reservistas, miembros de la Guardia Nacional.
Los tipos de beneficios que se pueden obtener son: atención médica, pagos de compensación.

Para obtener estos beneficios, deberá presentar una reclamación de compensación por discapacidad y proporcionar los siguientes documentos de respaldo: sus registros militares que muestren que prestó servicio en Camp Lejeune o MCAS New River durante al menos 30 días desde agosto de 1953 hasta diciembre de 1987 mientras estaba en servicio activo, o en la Guardia Nacional o las Reservas, y registros médicos que indiquen que tiene 1 o más de las 8 enfermedades en la lista de condiciones presuntivas.

Puede presentar una reclamación en línea en VA.gov, en línea en eBenefits, con la ayuda de un representante acreditado como un oficial de servicio para veteranos (VSO), o con la ayuda de una oficina regional de beneficios de VA.

Los veteranos y sus familiares también están cubiertos para recibir atención médica si el veterano prestó servicio en Camp Lejeune o MCAS New River durante al menos 30 días acumulativos desde agosto de 1953 hasta diciembre de 1987.

Como familiar, deberá presentar una reclamación de compensación por discapacidad y proporcionar los siguientes documentos de respaldo: un documento que pruebe su relación con el veterano que prestó servicio activo durante al menos 30 días en Camp Lejeune, un documento que pruebe que vivió en Camp Lejeune o MCAS New River durante al menos 30 días desde agosto de 1953 hasta diciembre de 1987, y registros médicos que muestren que tiene una de las 15 condiciones enumeradas, así como la fecha del diagnóstico y el tratamiento recibido.

Deberá proporcionar evidencia de que pagó gastos médicos por su condición reclamada durante uno de los siguientes períodos: entre el 1 de enero de 1957 y el 31 de diciembre de 1987 (si vivió en Camp Lejeune durante este período, se le reembolsará la atención recibida a partir del 6 de agosto de 2012 y hasta 2 años antes de la fecha de su solicitud), o entre el 1 de agosto de 1953 y el 31 de diciembre de 1956 (si vivió en Camp Lejeune durante este período, se le reembolsará la atención recibida a partir del 16 de diciembre de 2014 y hasta 2 años antes de la fecha en que solicite los beneficios).

Puede presentar una reclamación completando el Formulario VA 10-10068 (Solicitud del Programa para Miembros de la Familia de Camp Lejeune), enviándolo por fax al 512-460-5536 o por correo a: Department of Veterans Affairs Financial Services Center, PO Box 149200, Austin, TX 78714-9200.
Dos pozos de agua en la base que fueron cerrados en 1985 contenían estos químicos: tricloroetileno (TCE), percloroetileno (PCE), benceno, cloruro de vinilo y otros compuestos.
When you sign up for VA health care, you become part of the country's largest integrated health care system with more than 1,200 care locations serving nearly 9 million Veterans each year.
You'll receive regular care at one VA location of your choice.
If you need specialized medical treatments and services, we may refer you to other locations as well.
Your health care team will use our electronic medical record system to coordinate your care no matter where you are.

Care settings may include: VA medical centers, VA community-based outpatient clinics (CBOCs), Vet Centers, VA Community Living Centers and other assisted living or residential live-in settings, your own home.
VA medical centers offer a range of services.
All VA medical centers provide traditional hospital-based services like surgery, critical care, mental health, and physical therapy.
Most VA medical centers provide medical and surgical specialty services like oncology (cancer care), geriatrics (elder care), and neurology (care for conditions of the brain and nervous system).
Some VA medical centers also offer advanced services like organ transplants and plastic surgery (reconstructing or repairing parts of the body in the treatment of traumatic injury).
VA community-based outpatient clinics (CBOCs) provide the most common outpatient services like health and wellness visits so you can take care of routine appointments in a more convenient location.
The VA keeps expanding its network of CBOCs to more rural locations so it can help you access care closer to home.
Vet Centers provide community-based counseling, outreach, and referral services to Veterans who served in a combat zone as well as to their families.
Mobile Vet Centers also help bring care to more rural locations.

VA Community Living Centers and other assisted living or residential live-in settings provide support for Veterans who need more intense nursing care and help with everyday tasks like bathing, dressing, or taking medicines.
If needed, you may get medical treatment, nursing care, or help with everyday tasks in the comfort of your own home.
If you're enrolled in VA health care, you may be able to receive care from a provider in your local community through community care if the nearest VA location can't provide the services you need.
You may be able to get care at a VA outpatient clinic, at a mobile Vet Center, in your own home, from a provider in your local community, or by calling 911 or going to the nearest emergency room.
The VA considers an emergency to be a condition that a reasonable person believes will put your health or life at risk if you don't get treatment right away.
If you're far from a VA medical center, the VA may pay for emergency care in a non-VA setting.

You should contact your nearest VA medical center as soon as possible and ask to talk to the patient transfer or patient administration representative if you receive emergency care in a non-VA setting.
Payment for emergency care in a non-VA setting ends when a VA provider concludes that you're stable enough to be transferred to a VA medical center.
You should let the VA know right away if you're moving so they can help set up care in your new location.
To change your address, you can call the VA at 877-222-VETS (877-222-8387), Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. ET.
If you're moving outside the U.S., you'll need to sign up for the VA's Foreign Medical Program.

Through the Foreign Medical Program, the VA will pay for certain needed health care services received in foreign countries to treat a service-connected disability or a disability that's making a service-connected condition worse.
You should let the VA know in advance if you're planning to travel so they can plan for your care at a VA location near where you'll be staying.
You should give your VA care team at least 4 to 6 weeks notice if possible when planning to travel.
You should provide your VA care team with your travel destination and temporary address, a telephone number, your arrival and departure dates, and any specific care concerns when planning to travel.
The VA can also mail prescription refills to you at your temporary address when traveling, but you should allow about 2 weeks for the refills to arrive.
You can schedule VA health care appointments by phone or through the VA's online scheduling tool.
The VA may be able to help you get to and from appointments in certain cases, or pay you back for the cost of transportation if you qualify for help.
The VA may be able to help with travel expenses if you need to travel for care.

You can get care right away for minor injuries and illness, like pink eye or ear infections, at urgent care facilities or walk-in retail health clinics that are part of the VA's community provider network.

To use urgent care facilities or walk-in retail health clinics in the VA's community provider network, you'll need to be enrolled in VA health care and have received care from the VA within the past 24 months.
You can apply to find out in advance if you can be buried in a VA national cemetery.
This is called a pre-need determination of eligibility.
A pre-need determination of eligibility can help make the burial planning process easier for your family members in their time of need.
Pre-need means before the time of need.
This application is for planning for your own burial in advance.
You should not complete this form if you are requesting burial at the time of need.

To be eligible for burial in a VA national cemetery, one of the following must describe you: A Veteran who did not receive a dishonorable discharge when you separated from the military, The spouse or dependent child of a service member or Veteran, even if the service member or Veteran has already passed away, In some cases, the adult dependent child of a service member or Veteran if you are not married.

VA bases its decision of whether or not you qualify for burial in a VA national cemetery on your service history or the service history of the Veteran or service member who is sponsoring your application for burial as a spouse, surviving spouse, or unmarried adult child.
If a service member dies on active duty, they are eligible for burial without a pre-need decision letter.
You need to choose the VA national cemetery where you would prefer to be buried.
This application is only for VA national cemeteries.
If you would like to be buried in a state or tribal Veterans cemetery, you need to contact that specific cemetery ahead of time to find out about their pre-need program.
Some state Veterans cemeteries require that you live in that state or have other rules around eligibility.
You can apply for a pre-need determination of eligibility from VA and also from a state or tribal Veterans cemetery.
This application does not apply to Arlington National Cemetery or the United States Soldiers and Airmen's Home National Cemetery.
If you would like to be buried in either of these Department of the Army cemeteries, you need to call 877-907-8585.
Getting a pre-need determination of eligibility does not guarantee you will be buried in a specific VA national cemetery.
VA does not take reservations at any VA national cemetery.
VA asks where you prefer to be buried so they can try to help fulfill your final wishes.
To apply, you need to gather the supporting documents and information listed.
If you do not have everything on the list, you can still apply and VA will help by finding the supporting documents they need.
The more information you can give VA when you apply, the faster they can review your application and give you a decision.
VA will contact you if they need you to provide additional information.
You need to fill out an application for each person requesting a pre-need eligibility determination.
If both you and your spouse are applying, you will each need to fill out your own application.

To apply, you need your or your sponsor's: Social Security number, Date and place of birth, Military status and service history like service dates, discharge character, and rank commonly found on the DD214 or other separation documents, Discharge papers DD214 or other separation documents.
If you do not have discharge papers, you need to find out how to request the DD214.
If you are applying as a spouse, surviving spouse, or unmarried adult child, you also need your personal information, including your Social Security number.
If you are applying on behalf of someone else, you also need supporting documents showing you have the authority to apply for that person.

You need to fill out one of these forms: Appointment of Veterans Service Organization as Claimant's Representative VA Form 21-22, Appointment of Individual as Claimant's Representative VA Form 21-22a.
If you are applying for an unmarried adult child of a Veteran or service member, you also need to provide supporting documents with information about the child's disability.
The Veteran or guardian of the child should also ask the child's current doctor to verify the documents.

These documents should include all of the following information: The date of the disability's onset, A description of the disability, mental or physical, A description of how dependent the disabled child is on the Veteran, The marital status of the child.
You can apply online right now.
You can also apply by mail by filling out an Application for Pre-need Determination of Eligibility for Burial in a VA National Cemetery VA Form 40-10007.
The person applying for a pre-need determination must sign the form.

If that person is under 18 years old, mentally unable to make decisions for themselves (sometimes called mentally incompetent), or physically unable to sign the form, a spouse, parent, or court-appointed representative may sign the form.

If you are signing the form on behalf of someone else, you need to: Select box 33B on the form and provide your name, address, phone number, and email address in blocks 34 through 37, Provide supporting documents that show why the person applying cannot sign, Provide supporting documents that show your relationship to the person applying.
You need to send your completed application with copies of your supporting documents to: National Cemetery Scheduling Office, PO Box 510543, St. Louis, MO 63151.
You should not send the originals of your DD214 and other supporting documents since VA cannot return them. Send copies only.
You can fax your application to VA at 855-840-8299.
If you need help filling out your application, you can call VA's toll-free hotline at 877-222-8387.
You can also get help from a trained professional trusted to help with VA-related claims, like an accredited representative or Veterans Service Officer (VSO).
You can find a representative or your state's Veterans agency.
These services are free. No one should ever ask you to pay them to help you fill out VA Form 40-10007 or file your request.
After you apply, VA will let you know when they have received your application and how long they think it will take to make a decision.
VA has received a large number of pre-need eligibility applications, and it is slowing down their approval process.
VA is sorry for the delay.
For more information, you can call 877-222-8387.
You should wait to hear back about your application rather than applying again.

If you suffered an added disability or your existing injury or disease got worse while you were getting VA medical care or taking part in a VA program designed to help you find, get, or keep a job, you may be able to get compensation.

You may be able to get compensation from VA if you suffered an added disability or your existing disability got worse as the direct result of any of the following reasons and the added disability wasn't a reasonably expected result or complication of treatment: VA carelessness or negligence, VA medical or surgical treatment, a VA health exam, a VA vocational rehabilitation course (under 38 U.S.C. Chapter 31), or VA compensated work therapy (CWT) (under 38 U.S.C. 1718).
Veterans are covered for compensation from VA.
The kind of benefit that can be obtained is compensation.
To get these benefits, you'll need to file a claim for disability compensation.
When filing a claim for disability compensation, you'll have to show that the added disability happened because of VA medical care or a VA program designed to help you find, get, or keep a job.
Any compensation payments awarded will be in the same way as if your disability was related to your military service, a service-connected disability.
VA health care covers regular checkups with your primary care provider.
VA health care covers appointments with specialists like cardiologists, gynecologists, and mental health providers.
VA health care provides access to Veterans health care services like home health and geriatric elder care.
VA health care provides medical equipment, prosthetics, and prescriptions.
VA offers many programs and services that may help homeless or at-risk Veterans, including free health care and, in some cases, free limited dental care.
VA can help homeless or at-risk Veterans connect with resources in their community, like homeless shelters or faith-based organizations.
Veterans can call the National Call Center for Homeless Veterans at 877-424-3838 for help 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, and talk privately with a trained VA counselor for free.
Veterans can contact their nearest VA medical center and ask to talk with the VA social worker.
Female Veterans can ask for the Women Veterans Program Manager at their nearest VA medical center.
Veterans in crisis or concerned about one can connect with VA's caring, qualified Veterans Crisis Line responders for confidential help 24/7.
VA health care benefits cover how VA health care works and which Veterans health care services are covered.
VA provides information on eligibility for Veterans health care benefits and how priority groups work.
VA provides instructions on how to apply for VA health care online, by phone, by mail, or in person.
Veterans can apply online for VA health care using VA Form 10-10EZ.
VA provides information on what to expect after applying for VA health care and next steps.
VA provides information on family and caregiver health benefits and eligibility as a spouse, surviving spouse, dependent child, or caregiver.
Veterans can refill and track their VA prescriptions online.
Veterans can communicate privately with their VA health care team through VA Secure Messaging.
Veterans can schedule and view their VA appointments by phone, online, or through Secure Messaging.
Veterans can view, download, and print their VA lab and test results online.
Veterans can order hearing aid batteries and prosthetic socks online for home delivery.
Veterans can set up their personal health record and download reports to share with their VA and non-VA doctors through VA Blue Button.
Veterans can update their personal, financial, or insurance information after enrolling in the VA health care program using VA Form 10-10EZR.
Veterans can pay their VA copay bill securely online, by phone or mail, or in person, and find out what to do if they're struggling to make payments.
Veterans can track the status of an open VA health care appeal.
Veterans can find out how to apply for reimbursement for their travel to a VA health facility.
VA provides information on current copay rates for different types of care, tests, and medications.
VA provides mental health services for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), psychological effects of military sexual trauma (MST), depression, grief, anxiety, and other needs.
VA provides information on how to get care for specific needs like women's health, and service-related health concerns like Agent Orange-related diseases or Camp Lejeune water contamination.

VA provides information on health concerns linked to exposures during military service and special VA health registries for documenting Veterans' exposure to Agent Orange, depleted uranium, ionizing radiation, airborne hazards, and other hazardous materials.
VA offers programs to help Veterans get and stay healthy in both body and mind.
If enrolled in VA health care, Veterans may be able to receive care from a provider in their local community through community care.
VA provides information on what Veterans need to know about the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and what it means for their VA health care coverage.
Veterans may be able to participate in the Million Veteran Program, a voluntary research study to better understand the role genes play in health.
VA provides information about VA facilities, such as how quickly Veterans can be seen and what other Veterans say about their experiences.
VA informs Veterans about their basic rights and responsibilities when receiving care at a VA health facility or living in a VA community living center.
VA provides information on how to file a claim for disability compensation and manage disability benefits.
VA offers life insurance options and information on how to apply as a service member, Veteran, or family member.
VA provides information on aid and attendance benefits and housebound allowance for Veterans or surviving spouses with disabilities who may be eligible for increased pension pay.
VA provides information on Veterans burial benefits, how to plan a burial service, and how survivors can get compensation.
VA offers education and training benefits, such as the GI Bill, to help pay for college and training programs.
Whether you just returned from a deployment or have been home for 40 years, it's never too late to get help for PTSD (posttraumatic stress disorder).
Getting counseling or treatment can help you manage your symptoms and keep them from getting worse.
The National Center for PTSD is the world leader in PTSD research, education, and treatment.
You can find out how to access PTSD health services through VA.
If you're a Veteran in crisis or concerned about one, you can connect with the caring, qualified Veterans Crisis Line responders for confidential help.
Many of the Veterans Crisis Line responders are Veterans themselves.
The Veterans Crisis Line service is private, free, and available 24/7.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night, you can call 800-273-8255, then select 1, start a confidential Veterans chat, or text 838255.
If you have hearing loss, you can call TTY: 800-799-4889 for the Veterans Crisis Line.
You can also call 911, go to the nearest emergency room, or go directly to your nearest VA medical center, regardless of your discharge status or if you're enrolled in VA health care.

VA provides almost 200 PTSD treatment programs across the country that offer 1-to-1 mental health assessment and testing to figure out if you have PTSD, medicine proven to work for treating PTSD, 1-to-1 psychotherapy (also called talk therapy) including proven methods like Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT), 1-to-1 family therapy, group therapy for special needs like anger or stress management or combat support, and group therapy for Veterans who served in certain combat zones or who've been through similar traumas.
PTSD specialists provide regular outpatient care to Veterans with PTSD in each VA medical center across the U.S.
Special residential (live-in) or inpatient care programs found in each region of the U.S. help Veterans with severe PTSD symptoms who have trouble doing normal daily activities like going to work.
Providers offer added PTSD care in some of the large community-based outpatient clinics.

If you don't live near a VA medical center or clinic, the mental health providers can counsel you over the phone (called telemental health care), or they can refer you to a Vet Center or health care provider near you.
To access VA services for PTSD, you first need to apply for VA health care.

Once you've signed up for VA health care, if you have a VA primary care provider, you can talk to them about your concerns, and they can help you figure out if you have PTSD and offer treatment and support as needed.

If you don't have a VA primary care provider or have never been seen in a VA hospital or clinic, you can call the general information hotline at 800-827-1000, contact your local VA medical center, or contact a VA PTSD program near you.

If you've served in a combat zone, you can get free private counseling, alcohol and drug assessment, and other support at one of the 300 community Vet Centers, even if you don't have VA health benefits.

If you're homeless or at risk of becoming homeless, you can visit the VA website to learn about VA programs for homeless Veterans, contact the National Call Center for Homeless Veterans at 877-424-3838 for help 24 hours a day, 7 days a week (a trained VA counselor will offer information about VA homeless programs, health care, and other services in your area, and the call is free and confidential), or call or visit your local VA Community Resource and Referral Center (even if you don't qualify for VA health care, the staff can help you find non-VA resources you may qualify for in your community).

If you have symptoms of PTSD and suffered a serious injury, personal trauma, sexual trauma, or were threatened with injury, sexual assault, or death while serving in the military, you may be able to get disability compensation (monthly payments) or other benefits from VA.
You can find more information and support in the Understanding PTSD and PTSD Treatment booklet, which provides information about PTSD symptoms and treatment.
The National Center for PTSD website provides information about PTSD treatment and support.
The Make the Connection and About Face websites offer resources and stories of Veterans who've overcome PTSD and other mental health challenges.
You can use the PTSD Coach Online to help manage stress.
The self-help resources guide provides books, web resources, and mobile applications recommended by VA experts.
You can call the VA general information hotline at 800-827-1000 for more information and support.
After you apply for an eligibility determination, you will find out what happens after you apply for a pre-need eligibility determination for burial in a VA national cemetery.

The amount of time it takes VA to make a decision depends on: The number of applications VA is reviewing, and How much information you provided in your application, and Whether you provided your or your sponsor's DD214 or other separation documents along with your application.
VA has received a large number of pre-need eligibility applications, and it is slowing down VA's approval process.
VA will let you know when VA has received your application and how long VA thinks it will take to make a decision.
VA is sorry for the delay.
For more information, you can call 877-222-8387, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. ET.
You should wait to hear back about your application rather than applying again.
You do not need to do anything while you wait.
VA will contact you if VA needs more information to make a decision.
If you qualify for burial benefits, you will receive a VA burial and memorial benefits folder from VA in the mail.

The VA burial and memorial benefits folder will include: A letter telling you if you can be buried in a VA national cemetery, which is called your pre-need decision letter, A National Cemetery Administration brochure and a burial benefits information sheet, which will tell you more about the benefits you will receive, A copy of the supporting documents you submitted with your application.
After you receive your pre-need decision letter and folder, you should keep your pre-need decision letter and folder in a safe place.

After you receive your pre-need decision letter and folder, you should talk to your family members or authorized representative about your burial wishes including any memorialization requests and inscriptions and make sure they know where your benefits folder is located.
At the time of need, the person arranging your burial should call the National Cemetery Scheduling Office at 800-535-1117 to request a burial.
At the time of need, the person arranging your burial will need your pre-need eligibility determination letter.
VA will also keep a copy of your pre-need application, the decision letter, and your supporting documents in VA's system to help speed up burial arrangements.
When your family member or authorized representative requests your burial, VA will confirm your pre-need eligibility determination based on the laws in effect at that time.
If you qualify for burial in a VA national cemetery, you will receive burial benefits at no cost to your family.
The burial benefits include: Opening and closing of the grave, A burial liner provided by the government, A headstone or marker provided by the government, Perpetual ongoing care of the gravesite.
The person arranging your burial can also request additional honors and memorial items.
If you are a Veteran, your surviving spouse or other family members may also qualify for survivor benefits, including help paying for funeral costs.
Your family members can make arrangements for your burial at a private cemetery even if VA has already sent you a pre-need decision letter.
There is no need to contact VA about a change of plans to be buried at a private cemetery.
Even if you are buried at a private cemetery, your family members can still request a headstone or marker at the time of need.
To request a headstone or marker for a private cemetery burial, the family member can make this request using the Claim for Standard Government Headstone or Marker VA Form 40-1330.

To make a request for a headstone or marker for a private cemetery burial, the family member should print out VA Form 40-1330, fill it out, and mail the completed form to: Memorial Products Service 41B, Department of Veterans Affairs, 5109 Russell Road, Quantico, VA 22134-3903.
If you do not qualify for burial benefits, VA will send you a denial decision letter explaining the reasons or basis of VA's denial.
If you do not qualify for burial benefits, VA will also send you a form called Your Rights to Seek Further Review of Our Decision VA Form 20-0998 along with your denial letter.
The form Your Rights to Seek Further Review of Our Decision VA Form 20-0998 explains your rights to appeal or to request another review, and how to submit more evidence.
You can send VA more supporting documents whether or not you choose to appeal the pre-need decision.
The amount of time you have to appeal the decision or request another review depends on which option you use to request a review or to appeal.
Each option to request a review or appeal has a different time requirement.

Your options to request a review or appeal include: Add new and relevant evidence file a Supplemental Claim, Ask for a new look from a senior reviewer request a Higher-Level Review, Appeal to a Veterans Law Judge request a Board Appeal.

Your family member or authorized representative can still apply for your burial in a VA national cemetery at the time of need, even if you did not qualify for burial benefits based on an earlier pre-need eligibility decision.
VA will make the final decision of whether you qualify for burial at the time of need.
Laws and personal circumstances may change earlier eligibility decisions.
You can update your information at any time by calling VA's toll-free hotline at 877-222-8387.
VA's toll-free hotline is available Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. ET.
There are many types of identification cards you can use to show you are a Veteran.
You only need to have one of them for this purpose.
A Department of Defense (DoD) Identification Card is used to show your military status and to get access to services at military bases.
You may also use a DoD Identification Card to get discounts offered to Veterans at many stores, businesses, and restaurants.
If you have a DoD Identification Card, you do not need to request another type of photo ID card to prove you are a Veteran or to get retail or business discounts.

You may be eligible for a DoD Identification Card if one of the following descriptions is true for you: You are retired from the military, you are on active duty, or you are in the National Guard, the Reserves, the Selected Reserves, or Inactive Ready Reserve.
Depending on your status, the DoD issues either a Common Access Card (CAC) or a Uniformed Services ID Card (USID).
For both types of DoD cards, you will need to either be a sponsor or have a sponsor.

You will need to fill out an Application for Identification Card/DEERS Enrollment (DD Form 1172-2) and turn in your completed application to a Real-Time Automated Personnel Identification System (RAPIDS) office for processing.
When you are enrolled in VA health care, you get a Veteran Health Identification Card (VHIC) that you use to check in to your appointments at VA medical centers.
You may also use a VHIC to get discounts offered to Veterans at many stores, businesses, and restaurants.
If you have a VHIC, you do not need to request another type of photo ID card to prove you are a Veteran or to get retail or business discounts.
You need to be enrolled in VA health care to receive a Veteran Health Identification Card.
A Veteran ID Card (VIC) is a form of photo ID you can use to get discounts offered to Veterans at many stores, businesses, and restaurants.
When you have a VIC, you will not need to carry around your military discharge papers or share sensitive personal information to receive discounts.
If you have a VIC, you do not need to request another type of photo ID card to prove you are a Veteran or to get retail or business discounts.

You may be eligible for a VIC if you meet both of the following requirements: You served on active duty, in the Reserves, or in the National Guard (including the Coast Guard), and you received an honorable or general discharge under honorable conditions.
If you received an other than honorable, bad conduct, or dishonorable character of discharge, you are not eligible for a Veteran ID Card.
If you have an uncharacterized or unknown discharge status, your eligibility will have to be verified before your application is approved.
At this time, all 50 states and Puerto Rico offer a Veteran designation (an identifying mark printed on state-issued driver's licenses or IDs).
The type of Veteran designation may vary from state to state.
If you have a Veteran's designation, you may be able to get discounts offered to Veterans at many stores, businesses, and restaurants.
Most states ask you to provide a copy of your discharge papers (DD214) or other separation documents.
Some states may require additional documents.
You should check with your state's Department of Motor Vehicles about what you need to apply for a Veteran's designation for your state.
A college or university co-op training program lets you get full-time work experience in between periods of going to school full time.
You may be able to get help paying for some of your costs like books, tuition, and housing if you are part of a co-op.

To get education benefits for co-op training, all of the following must be true: You are using VA educational assistance, you are enrolled at an approved Institution of Higher Learning (IHL), and you are in an educational program that requires part-time study and part-time work or training.
Veterans are covered for co-op training education benefits.
The benefits for co-op training include help paying for tuition, money for books, and money for housing.
The amount covered for co-op training depends on the benefit used.
For the Post-9/11 GI Bill, if the program is at a public IHL, the VA pays the actual costs for public in-state tuition and fees.
For the Post-9/11 GI Bill, if the program is at a private or foreign IHL, the VA pays the lesser of the national maximum or the actual costs for in-state tuition and fees.
For the Post-9/11 GI Bill, the VA also pays for some of the cost of housing and books.
For all other GI Bill programs, the VA pays a monthly rate that depends on which GI Bill program you qualify for.
You can request a Higher-Level Review of an initial claim or Supplemental Claim decision.
The option of requesting a Higher-Level Review is not available after a Higher-Level Review or Board Appeal.
The option of requesting a Higher-Level Review is not available if you are one of multiple people claiming the same benefit, which is rare.

If you request an informal conference with a senior reviewer, they will call the phone number that you or your representative provided on the Higher-Level Review form to schedule a time to discuss your case with you.
The senior reviewer will try to reach you or your representative by phone twice.
If no one answers, the senior reviewer will leave a voice mail.
During the call, you and/or your representative can talk about why you think the decision should be changed and identify errors.
There will not be transcripts of the call with the senior reviewer.
To request a Higher-Level Review, you need to fill out the Decision Review Request: Higher-Level Review VA Form 20-0996.
The most common benefit type is compensation, but if you are unsure, you should check your VA decision.
You cannot select multiple benefit types on the form, you have to complete a separate form for each type.
You can optionally request a call (informal conference) with the reviewer by selecting times and listing a phone number in Part II of the form.
A reviewer will call you 2-4 weeks after VA processes your request for an informal conference.
In Part III of the form, you need to list the issue(s) you want reviewed.
You can include all or just some of the issues VA has decided.
For each issue, you need to list the issue you disagree with and the VA decision date.
If you have new and relevant evidence, you should select another review option instead of Higher-Level Review.
To apply for a Higher-Level Review, you need to fill out the Decision Review Request: Higher-Level Review VA Form 20-0996 and submit it by mail, in person, or by fax.
The mailing address for submitting the form depends on the benefit type and your location.
For compensation benefits, the mailing address is: Department of Veterans Affairs, Claims Intake Center, PO Box 4444, Janesville, WI 53547-4444.
For pension/survivors benefits, the mailing address depends on your location and is provided in the document.

For other benefit types like National Cemetery Administration, Education, Veterans Health Administration, Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment, Insurance, and Loan guaranty, you need to refer to your decision for instructions on how to submit the form.
You can also bring your completed form to a regional benefit office in person.
Alternatively, you can fax your completed form and any supporting documents to 844-531-7818.
You can also request a copy of the form by calling the VA toll-free hotline at 800-827-1000, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. - 9:00 p.m. ET.
You have 1 year from the date on your decision to file a Higher-Level Review.
After you request a decision review, you do not need to do anything while you wait, unless VA sends you a letter asking for more information.
If VA schedules exams for you, be sure not to miss them.
You can track the status of your claim after requesting a decision review.
A Veterans Service Organization or VA-accredited attorney or agent can help you request a decision review.
You can get answers to frequently asked questions about decision reviews on the VA website.
You can use GI Bill benefits for college as a Veteran, service member, or qualified dependent.
You can learn about payment rates for undergraduate and graduate degree courses at institutions of higher learning like a 4-year university, community college, or graduate school.
The VA decides your payment amounts based on the number of classes you go to and the hours spent in those classes.

For most undergraduate degrees, a college considers: 12 or more hours full time, between 9 and 11 hours three-quarter time, between 6 and 8 hours half time, less than 6 hours reimbursable at a rate that's no more than the tuition and fees charged for the course.
The school decides how to rate each hour for graduate-level programs.
For example, if a graduate program at your school considers a 2-hour class full time, the VA will pay you the full-time rate.

You can take classes at more than one school under the GI Bill as long as: the classes at both schools count toward your degree, and the school granting your degree considers the classes at the second school to be required in order to get your degree.
The GI Bill won't pay you to take the same class twice unless you get a failing grade in a class that the school requires for graduation.
After earning your first degree, you can use any GI Bill benefits you have left over to pay for classes for another degree.
The VA issues payments after each month's classes.
For example, you'll get the payment for November classes in December.
For the Post-9/11 GI Bill, the VA pays: tuition and fees directly to the school, money for books to you at the beginning of the term, housing allowance to you at the end of each month.
If you were a part of chemical and biological warfare testing through Project 112 or Project Shipboard Hazard and Defense (SHAD), you may be at risk for certain illnesses.
The Department of Defense's Deseret Test Center in Fort Douglas, Utah, conducted this testing, which took place aboard ships and on land in various locations from 1962 to 1974.

You may be able to get disability benefits from VA if you meet both of the requirements listed below: You were part of Projects 112 or SHAD testing from 1962 to 1974, and you have an illness believed to be caused by the testing.
Veterans and qualified survivors are covered for disability benefits related to Project 112 or Project SHAD.
The disability benefits that can be obtained include health care and compensation payments.
To get these benefits, you'll need to file a claim for disability compensation.
You can call the VA Special Issues Helpline at 800-749-8387 or file a claim online to get disability benefits related to Project 112 or Project SHAD.
If you were part of Projects 112 or SHAD from 1962 to 1974 and want to know more about a certain test site, ship, or unit, you can see the declassified Department of Defense fact sheets.

If you have a question about the tests, if you have any information that can help show you were part of them including whether you may have been part of them, or if you need to contact the Department of Defense regarding Project 112 or Project SHAD, you can call 800-497-6261.
You may be able to get a temporary 100% disability rating and disability compensation or benefits if you have an immobilizing disability.

You may be able to get disability benefits if you have had surgery or received other treatment at a VA hospital, approved hospital, or outpatient center for a disability related to your military service called a service-connected disability.

For you to get disability benefits after surgery, the following two conditions must be true: The surgery required a recovery time of at least one month. The surgery or treatment was for a service-connected disability.

For you to get disability benefits after surgery, the following condition must also be true: The surgery resulted in severe issues that have not totally healed, such as surgical wounds, stumps of recent amputations, being unable to move due to being put in splints or casts to help with healing known as therapeutic immobilizations, being unable to leave your house known as house confinement, or being required to use a wheelchair or crutches.
If you did not have surgery, the following condition must be true for you to get disability benefits: You had one or more major joints immobilized by a cast.
The disability benefits cover veterans.
The disability benefits can include health care while you recover, added compensation payments, and a temporary 100% disability rating.
To get these benefits, you will need to file a claim for disability compensation.
Recovery time from either a surgery or the immobilization of a joint by a cast without surgery requires a temporary 100% disability rating for a service-connected disability.
The temporary 100% disability rating may continue for 1 to 3 months depending on your unique case.
You may be able to get an extension for up to 3 more months if your case is severe.

In the example provided, a veteran had a left knee injury that resulted in a 30% disability rating. As the knee problem got worse, the veteran's VA doctor recommended surgery to stop more damage from happening. Since the doctor would not know if the surgery was successful until 3 months after the veteran's 1-week stay in the hospital, the veteran was granted a temporary 100% disability rating for 3 months.
You may be able to get a Certificate of Eligibility (COE) if you didn't receive a dishonorable discharge and you meet the minimum active-duty service requirement based on when you served.
You can apply online right now for your COE by going to eBenefits.

You may still be able to get a COE if you were discharged for one of the following reasons: hardship, the convenience of the government, reduction in force, certain medical conditions, or a service-connected disability (a disability related to your military service).

If you have received an other than honorable, bad conduct, or dishonorable discharge, you may not be eligible for VA benefits. You can try to qualify by applying for a discharge upgrade or through the VA Character of Discharge review process.
You may be able to get a COE if you are the surviving spouse of a Veteran or the spouse of a Veteran who is missing in action or being held as a Prisoner of War (POW).

You may be able to get a COE if you meet at least one of the following requirements: you are a U.S. citizen who served in the Armed Forces of a government allied with the United States in World War II, or you served as a member in certain organizations such as a Public Health Service officer, a cadet at the United States Military, Air Force, or Coast Guard Academy, a midshipman at the United States Naval Academy, an officer of the National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration, or a merchant seaman during World War II.

You may be able to restore an entitlement you used in the past to buy another home with a VA direct or VA-backed loan if you meet at least one of the following requirements: you have sold the home you bought with the prior loan and have paid that loan in full, a qualified Veteran-transferee agrees to assume your loan and substitute their entitlement for the same amount of entitlement you used originally, or you have repaid your prior loan in full but haven't sold the home you bought with that loan (you can only do this one time). To request an entitlement restoration, you need to fill out a Request for a Certificate of Eligibility (VA Form 26-1880) and send it to the VA regional loan center for your state.
VA provides primary care services for women Veterans.
VA provides general services like disease prevention and nutrition counseling for women Veterans.
VA provides female-specific services like birth control, preconception counseling, and menopausal support hormone replacement therapy for women Veterans.
VA provides screenings like cervical cancer screens (Pap smears) and breast cancer screens (mammograms) for women Veterans.
VA provides mental health services for depression, posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and substance use problems for women Veterans.
VA provides free, confidential private counseling and treatment for mental and physical health conditions related to military sexual trauma (MST) for women Veterans.
VA provides specialty services for women Veterans.
VA provides screening and management of chronic (long-lasting) conditions like heart disease and diabetes for women Veterans.
VA provides screening and management of sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) like HIV/AIDS and hepatitis for women Veterans.
VA provides maternity care and other reproductive health services for women Veterans.
VA provides treatment for sexual problems, urinary incontinence, and other issues for women Veterans.
VA provides prosthetic and sensory aid (PSA) services like prosthetic limbs, hearing aids, and post-mastectomy items for women Veterans.
VA provides referrals for physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech-language therapy, and other rehabilitation therapies for women Veterans.
VA provides homebound and long-term care for women Veterans who meet specific requirements.
VA cannot provide abortion services by law.

VA is expanding fertility services to include counseling and treatment using assisted reproductive technologies including in vitro fertilization (IVF) for Veterans and spouses of Veterans who have a service-connected disability that makes it impossible for them to have a baby without the help of fertility treatment.
Women Veterans who are currently signed up for VA health care can reach a VA health care provider at their local VA medical center by phone 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
VA provides services for women Veterans who are homeless.
VA provides services for women Veterans who are victims of intimate partner violence.
VA provides education and training services for women Veterans who want education and training.
VA provides employment help services for women Veterans who want employment help.
VA provides vocational rehabilitation job training services for women Veterans who want vocational rehabilitation job training.
To access women's health care services through VA, women Veterans must first apply for VA health care.

Once signed up for VA health care, women Veterans can talk to their primary care provider to access women's health services, or contact the Women Veterans Program Manager at their local VA medical center.
Women Veterans can contact their local VA medical center and ask for the Women Veterans Program Manager to access women's health services.
Women Veterans can call the Women Veterans Call Center at 855-829-6636 to connect with their local Women Veterans Program Manager to access women's health services.
Women Veterans can chat online with a trained Women Veterans Call Center representative to access women's health services.
Women Veterans can look for women's health services specific to their nearest VA medical center on the website of the VA health care system that the medical center is part of.
If women Veterans do not have VA health care benefits, they can contact the Women Veterans Call Center to figure out their benefits and take the next step to getting care.

If women Veterans have served in a combat zone, they can get free private counseling, alcohol and drug assessment, and other support at VA's community Vet Centers, even if they do not have VA health care benefits.
If women Veterans are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless, they can visit VA's website to learn about VA programs for homeless Veterans, even if they do not have VA health care benefits.

If women Veterans are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless, they can contact the National Call Center for Homeless Veterans at 877-424-3838 for help 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, even if they do not have VA health care benefits.

If women Veterans are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless, they can visit their local VA Community Resource and Referral Center for help finding non-VA resources in their community, even if they do not qualify for VA health care.
Women Veteran victims of military sexual trauma (MST) can get help through VA, even if they do not have a service-connected disability rating or do not qualify for other VA services.
Women Veteran victims of military sexual trauma (MST) do not need to have reported the MST or have other proof that it happened to get help through VA.
VA's women's health website provides information about how VA helps women Veterans stay well.
VA's Center for Women Veterans website provides information about health care and other benefits and programs for women Veterans.
VA's Women Veterans Call Center representatives can help women Veterans understand their VA benefits and find the right services to fit their needs.
A VA Survivors Pension offers monthly payments to qualified surviving spouses and unmarried dependent children of wartime Veterans.
A VA Survivors Pension has income and net worth limits set by Congress.

To be eligible for a VA Survivors Pension as a surviving spouse, the following conditions must be met: the surviving spouse has not remarried after the Veteran's death, the deceased Veteran did not receive a dishonorable discharge, and the deceased Veteran's service meets at least one of the following requirements: the Veteran entered active duty on or before September 7, 1980, and served at least 90 days on active military service, with at least 1 day during a wartime period, or the Veteran entered active duty after September 7, 1980, and served at least 24 months or the full period for which they were called or ordered to active duty with some exceptions, with at least 1 day during a wartime period, or the Veteran was an officer and started on active duty after October 16, 1981, and had not previously served on active duty for at least 24 months.
To be eligible for a VA Survivors Pension as a surviving spouse, the surviving spouse's yearly family income and net worth must meet certain limits set by Congress.

A surviving spouse's net worth for a VA Survivors Pension equals the value of everything the surviving spouse owns except their house, car, and most home furnishings, minus any debt the surviving spouse owes.

The following wartime periods are recognized by VA to decide eligibility for pension benefits: Mexican Border period from May 9, 1916, to April 5, 1917, for Veterans who served in Mexico, on its borders, or in adjacent waters, World War I from April 6, 1917, to November 11, 1918, World War II from December 7, 1941, to December 31, 1946, Korean conflict from June 27, 1950, to January 31, 1955, Vietnam War era from February 28, 1961, to May 7, 1975, for Veterans who served in the Republic of Vietnam during that period, and from August 5, 1964, to May 7, 1975, for Veterans who served outside of the Republic of Vietnam, Gulf War from August 2, 1990, through a future date to be set by law or presidential proclamation.

To be eligible for a VA Survivors Pension as the child of a deceased wartime Veteran, the child must be unmarried and meet at least one of the following requirements: the child is under age 18, or the child is under age 23 and attending a VA-approved school, or the child is unable to care for themselves due to a disability that happened before age 18.

An individual can apply for a VA Survivors Pension by mail by filling out an Application for DIC, Death Pension, and/or Accrued Benefits VA Form 21-534EZ and mailing it to the pension management center for their state.
An individual can apply for a VA Survivors Pension in person by bringing their application to a VA regional office near them.
An individual can apply for a VA Survivors Pension with the help of a trained professional called an accredited representative to get help applying for VA survivors pension benefits.
The time it takes VA to make a decision on a VA Survivors Pension claim depends on the order in which the claim was received, unless the claim requires priority processing.
Usted o alguien con poder legal para representarlo tiene que firmar la forma VA 10-10EZ, e incluir la fecha en que fue firmada.
Si esta usando un poder legal, tendra que incluir una copia de la forma con su solicitud.
Si firma con una X, 2 personas que usted conoce tienen que tambien firmar acertando que lo vieron firmar la forma VA 10-10EZ.
Puede mandar su solicitud por correo a esta direccion: Health Eligibility Center 2957 Clairmont Rd., Suite 200 Atlanta, GA 30329.
Para llenar su solicitud en persona, encuentre el Centro Medico de Veteranos mas cercano.
Puede recibir ayuda por medio del Departamento de Veteranos de su estado.
You must add evidence VA didn't have before that's relevant to your case.

You can file a Supplemental Claim within 1 year of a decision if you have new evidence, unless one of these rare situations applies to you: You have a Fiduciary claim, or You have a Multiple party claim.
New evidence is information that VA didn't have before the last decision.
Relevant evidence is information that could prove or disprove something about your case.
You can submit evidence yourself, or you can ask VA to get evidence, like medical records, that's at a VA medical center or other federal facility.
VA can't accept your Supplemental Claim without new and relevant evidence.
To file a Supplemental Claim, fill out the Decision Review Request: Supplemental Claim VA Form 20-0995.
You can download VA Form 20-0995 in PDF format.
In Part I on the VA Form 20-0995, you must select a benefit type.
The most common benefit type is compensation, but if you're unsure, check your VA decision.
You can't select multiple benefit types on VA Form 20-0995.
You must complete a separate VA Form 20-0995 for each benefit type.
In Part II on the VA Form 20-0995, you must list the issue(s) you want VA to review.
You can include all or just some of the issues VA decided on VA Form 20-0995.
On VA Form 20-0995, you must list the issue you disagree with and the VA decision date.
You must gather new and relevant evidence to submit with VA Form 20-0995.
You must add supporting documents or identify evidence you'd like VA to gather for review on VA Form 20-0995.
On Part III of VA Form 20-0995, you must list the location of VA evidence.
VA can help you get evidence if it's at a VA medical center or other federal facility.
The VA Form 20-0995 includes instructions for completing the form.
If you don't have evidence to submit, please select another review option.
You can learn more about the review options on the VA website.
To apply for a Supplemental Claim, fill out the Decision Review Request: Supplemental Claim VA Form 20-0995.
