You can send the completed VA Form 20-0995 and any supporting documents to the benefit office that matches the benefit type you selected on the form by mail.
For compensation benefits, send the VA Form 20-0995 to: Department of Veterans Affairs, Claims Intake Center, PO Box 4444, Janesville, WI 53547-4444.

For pension/survivors benefits if you live in AK, AZ, CA, CO, HI, ID, IA, KS, MN, MT, NB, NV, NM, ND, OK, OR, SD, TX, UT, WA, WY, Mexico, Central America, South America, or the Caribbean, send the VA Form 20-0995 to: Department of Veterans Affairs, Claims Intake Center, Attention: St. Paul Pension Center, PO Box 5365, Janesville, WI 53547-5365. You can also fax it to 844-655-1604.

For pension/survivors benefits if you live in CT, DL, FL, GA, ME, MD, MA, NH, NJ, NY, NC, PA, RI, SC, VT, VA, WV, DC, Puerto Rico, or Canada, send the VA Form 20-0995 to: Department of Veterans Affairs, Claims Intake Center, Attention: Philadelphia Pension Center, PO Box 5206, Janesville, WI 53547-5206. You can also fax it to 844-655-1604.

For pension/survivors benefits if you live in AL, AR, IL, IN, KY, LA, MI, MS, MO, OH, TN, or WI, send the VA Form 20-0995 to: Department of Veterans Affairs, Claims Intake Center, Attention: Milwaukee Pension Center, PO Box 5192, Janesville, WI 53547-5192. You can also fax it to 844-655-1604.
For National Cemetery Administration benefits, refer to your decision for instructions on how to submit the VA Form 20-0995.
For Education benefits, refer to your decision for instructions on how to submit the VA Form 20-0995.
For Veterans Health Administration benefits, refer to your decision for instructions on how to submit the VA Form 20-0995.
For Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment benefits, refer to your decision for instructions on how to submit the VA Form 20-0995.
For Insurance benefits, refer to your decision for instructions on how to submit the VA Form 20-0995.
For Loan guaranty benefits, refer to your decision for instructions on how to submit the VA Form 20-0995.
You can bring your completed VA Form 20-0995 and any supporting documents to a regional benefit office in person.
You can find a regional benefit office near you on the VA website.
You can fax your completed VA Form 20-0995 and any supporting documents to 844-531-7818.
You can also ask a regional benefit office for a copy of the VA Form 20-0995 to fill out.
You can call the VA toll-free hotline at 800-827-1000, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. - 9:00 p.m. ET, to request a copy of the VA Form 20-0995.
You have 1 year from the date on your decision to file a Supplemental Claim.
After you request a decision review, you don't need to do anything while you're waiting unless VA sends you a letter asking for more information.
If VA schedules exams for you, be sure not to miss them.
You can track the status of your claim on the VA website.
A Veterans Service Organization or VA-accredited attorney or agent can help you request a decision review.
You can get help requesting a decision review from the VA website.
You can get answers to frequently asked questions about decision reviews on the VA website.
How to apply for a VA home loan Certificate of Eligibility is the first step in getting a VA direct or VA-backed home loan.
A VA home loan Certificate of Eligibility confirms for your lender that you qualify for the VA home loan benefit.
To prepare before starting your application for a VA home loan Certificate of Eligibility, if you are a Veteran, you will need a copy of your discharge or separation papers DD214.

To prepare before starting your application for a VA home loan Certificate of Eligibility, if you are an active-duty Servicemember, you will need a statement of service signed by your commander, adjutant, or personnel officer showing this information: Your full name, Your Social Security number, Your date of birth you entered duty, The date, The duration of any lost time, The name of the command providing the information.

To prepare before starting your application for a VA home loan Certificate of Eligibility, if you are a current or former activated National Guard or Reserve member, you will need a copy of your discharge or separation papers DD214.

To prepare before starting your application for a VA home loan Certificate of Eligibility, if you are a current member of the National Guard or Reserves and have never been activated, you will need a statement of service signed by your commander, adjutant, or personnel officer showing this information: Your full name, Your Social Security number, Your date of birth you entered duty, The date, Your total number of creditable years of service, The duration of any lost time, The name of the command providing the information.

To prepare before starting your application for a VA home loan Certificate of Eligibility, if you are a discharged member of the National Guard and were never activated, you will need: Your Report of Separation and Record of Service NGB Form 22 for each period of National Guard service, and Your Retirement Points Statement NGB Form 23 and proof of the character of service.

To prepare before starting your application for a VA home loan Certificate of Eligibility, if you are a discharged member of the Reserves and were never activated, you will need: A copy of your latest annual retirement points, and Proof of your honorable service.
You can apply for your VA home loan Certificate of Eligibility online right now through eBenefits.
You can apply for your VA home loan Certificate of Eligibility through our Web LGY system, in some cases, you can get your Certificate of Eligibility through your lender using our Web LGY system.

You can apply for your VA home loan Certificate of Eligibility by mail, to apply by mail, fill out a Request for a Certificate of Eligibility VA Form 26-1880 and mail it to the address listed on the form.
Applying for your VA home loan Certificate of Eligibility is only one part of the process for getting a VA direct or VA-backed home loan.
Your next steps for getting a VA direct or VA-backed home loan will depend on the type of loan you are looking to get and on your lender.
For most VA-backed home loans, the lender will be a private bank or mortgage company.
For the Native American Direct Loan, the Department of Veterans Affairs will be your lender.
You can get education benefits if you meet all of the requirements listed below.
All of these must be true: You're eligible for or already get VA educational assistance as a Veteran, service member, Reservist, or qualified dependent.
All of these must be true: We've approved your program.
All of these must be true: Your program is at an institution of higher learning where you'll earn a standard associate's degree or higher, or a degree of equal value at that foreign school.

Exception: Family members who qualify for Survivors and Dependents Educational Assistance can get VA benefits while in approved postsecondary (after high school) non-college degree programs at training locations in the Philippines.
You can get money for school.
You can get money for your housing costs during enrollment.
We'll accept degrees from schools in foreign countries that are similar to degrees granted by accredited U.S. colleges and universities.
Accredited means that a group of experts has confirmed the school meets certain recognized quality standards.
For private schools overseas, the degree must be of equal value to those granted by public colleges and universities in the same country.
For private schools overseas, the school must have the same entrance requirements.
Independent study courses must be accredited by a nationally recognized accrediting association.
You can use the GI Bill Comparison Tool to see what benefits you can get at the school you want to attend.
Exception: Programs at schools located in the United States that offer courses in a foreign country through the Department of Defense don't qualify as foreign training.
Exception: Year abroad and similar programs offered by schools in the United States don't qualify as foreign training.
Before you enroll, make sure we've approved your school for education benefits.
You can contact the school or use the GI Bill Comparison Tool to find out if we've approved your program for VA educational benefits.
You'll need to give us the name of the foreign school, the complete address, and the name of the program you want to enroll in.
We'll let you know if your program has already been approved.
If you still have questions about the school or program, you can submit a question to us using the GI Bill website.
You can also send us a request for information about your program's approval status by mail.
You can send your request to: Foreign School Approval Group 22-EDU VA Regional Office 130 S. Elmwood Avenue Suite 601 Buffalo, NY 14202.
If you or your qualified dependent want to enroll in a program that we haven't approved, you'll need to ask the school to request approval.
We can't take any action until an official from your school (not you) requests approval.
If we don't approve your program, you'll have to pay all costs at the school, including tuition and fees.
You should apply for benefits.
You should find out how to apply.
You should turn in your application to us at least 90 days before you leave for your new school.
We'll decide what benefits you get based on your school's location.
If you get approved for benefits, turn in your Certificate of Eligibility (COE) to the school's certifying official to show that you qualify for VA benefits.
Your school's certifying official will submit your enrollment information with a VA Enrollment Certification (VA Form 22-1999).
Note: You won't get payments until we've received and processed your enrollment information.
You should make arrangements for school and travel.
You should be sure you have enough money to cover all your needs until VA payments begin.
You should make arrangements with the school for acceptance, enrollment, payment of tuition and fees, and housing.
You should make arrangements for travel including your passport, visa, and vaccinations, as required.
You should ask about your school's or host country's requirements for health insurance.
In some cases, you may not be able to start classes until you've made health insurance arrangements.
You should give written permission for school officials to release necessary information to us.
If you don't do this, it could affect when you get benefits.
If you plan to attend the foreign school for more than one year, tell the school within 120 days of when you want to re-enroll for another year.
You should ask the certifying official to submit an enrollment certification for you.
Normally, foreign schools certify their students for one academic year.
So you'll need to make sure the school knows your plans for continued enrollment to avoid any delay in getting your benefits.

If you're training in the Republic of the Philippines, American Samoa, Guam, Midway, Puerto Rico, Wake Island, any of the islands in the Federated States of the Marshall Islands, the Republic of Micronesia, or the Republic of Palau, our Muskogee Regional Processing Office will process your claim.
If you're training in the U.S. Virgin Islands or any other foreign country or area, our Buffalo Regional Processing Office will process your claim.
To get more information or help with your application, you can ask a question online.
If you're in the United States, you can call 888-GI-BILL-1 (888-442-4551), Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. ET.
If you're in the United States, you can go to a VA regional benefit office near you.
If you have hearing loss, you can call TTY: 711.
If you're outside the United States, you can call +1-918-781-5678, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. ET.
This is not a toll-free number.
You can also get help from local representatives of Veterans organizations and the American Red Cross.
You can also go to a foreign service post.
You can also contact the Canadian Department of Veterans Affairs for Canadian schools only.
The National Call to Service program allows you to choose an education benefit as an alternative to the Montgomery GI Bill (MGIB).

To qualify for the National Call to Service program, you must have completed your initial entry training and then continued to serve on active duty for 15 months in a military occupational specialty designated by the Secretary of Defense.

To qualify for the National Call to Service program, you must have then served, without a break in service, either an additional period of active duty as determined by the Secretary of Defense or a period of 24 months in active status in the Selected Reserve.

To qualify for the National Call to Service program, you must have then spent the rest of your obligated service, without a break in service, on active duty in the Armed Forces, or in the Selected Reserve, or in the Individual Ready Reserve, or in AmeriCorps, or another domestic national service program jointly designated by the Secretary of Defense.
The National Call to Service program covers veterans.

Under the National Call to Service program, you may choose one of the following benefits: a cash bonus of $5,000, or repayment of a qualifying student loan not more than $18,000, or educational assistance equal to the 3-year monthly MGIB rate for 12 months, or educational assistance equal to 50% of the less-than-3-year monthly MGIB rate for 36 months.
To get the benefits of the National Call to Service program, you can apply online.
If you enlist under the National Call to Service program, you do not qualify for the MGIB, unless you reenlist at a later date for an additional period of service.
To enroll in the National Call to Service program and see if you qualify, you should contact your recruiter.
The National Call to Service program benefit affects your service contract.
The National Call to Service program is administered by the VA for the Department of Defense.

If you are the surviving spouse, child, or parent of a service member who died in the line of duty, or the survivor of a Veteran who died from a service-related injury or illness, you may be able to get a tax-free monetary benefit called VA Dependency and Indemnity Compensation (VA DIC).
If the VA denied your Blue Water Navy Veteran's service-connected disability claim in the past, you may be eligible for DIC benefits based on the Blue Water Navy Vietnam Veterans Act of 2019.

Veterans who served on a Blue Water Navy vessel offshore of the Republic of Vietnam, or on another U.S. Navy or Coast Guard ship operating in the coastal waterways of Vietnam between January 9, 1962, and May 7, 1975, are now entitled to a presumption of service connection for illnesses related to Agent Orange exposure due to Public Law 116-23, also known as the Blue Water Navy Vietnam Veterans Act of 2019.

You may be eligible for VA benefits or compensation for surviving spouses if you meet the requirements listed below and provide evidence with your claim showing that one of the descriptions below is true for the Veteran or service member.
You married the Veteran or service member before January 1, 1957.
You married the Veteran or service member within 15 years of their discharge from the period of military service during which the qualifying illness or injury started or got worse.
You were married to the Veteran or service member for at least 1 year.

You had a child with the Veteran or service member, are not currently remarried, and either lived with the Veteran or service member without a break until their death or, if separated, were not at fault for the separation.
If you remarried on or after December 16, 2003, and you were 57 years of age or older at the time you remarried, you can still continue to receive compensation.
The service member died while on active duty, active duty for training, or inactive-duty training.
The Veteran died from a service-connected illness or injury.

The Veteran did not die from a service-connected illness or injury, but was eligible to receive VA compensation for a service-connected disability rated as totally disabling for a certain period of time.
If the Veteran's eligibility was due to a rating of totally disabling, they must have had this rating for at least 10 years before their death.
If the Veteran's eligibility was due to a rating of totally disabling, they must have had this rating since their release from active duty and for at least 5 years immediately before their death.

If the Veteran's eligibility was due to a rating of totally disabling, they must have had this rating for at least 1 year before their death if they were a former prisoner of war who died after September 30, 1999.
Totally disabling means the Veteran's injuries made it impossible for them to work.

You may be able to get compensation as a surviving child if you meet the requirements listed below and provide evidence with your claim showing that one of the descriptions below is true for the Veteran or service member.
You are not married.
You are not included on the surviving spouse's compensation.
You are under the age of 18 or under the age of 23 if attending school.
If you were adopted out of the Veteran's or service member's family, but meet all other eligibility criteria, you still qualify for compensation.

You may be able to get compensation as a surviving parent if both of the descriptions below are true for you and you provide evidence with your claim showing that one of the descriptions below is true for the Veteran or service member.
You are the biological, adoptive, or foster parent of the Veteran or service member.
Your income is below a certain amount.
The VA defines a foster parent as someone who served in the role of a parent to the Veteran or service member before their last entry into active service.
The service member died from an injury or illness while on active duty or in the line of duty while on active duty for training.
The service member died from an injury or certain illnesses in the line of duty while on inactive training.
The Veteran died from a service-connected illness or injury.
The benefits you can get are tax-free monetary benefits.

If you are the surviving spouse or child of a service member who died while on active duty, your military casualty assistance officer will help you to complete an Application for DIC, Death Pension, and/or Accrued Benefits by a Surviving Spouse or Child (VA Form 21P-534a) and mail the form to the correct VA regional benefit office.
If you are the surviving spouse or child of a Veteran, you need to fill out an Application for DIC, Death Pension, and/or Accrued Benefits (VA Form 21P-534EZ).
If you are a surviving parent, you need to fill out an Application for Dependency and Indemnity Compensation by Parent (VA Form 21P-535).
You can apply for this benefit by mailing the form to the Pension Management Center (PMC) for your state.
You can apply for this benefit by working with an accredited representative.
You can apply for this benefit by getting help filing your claim.
You can apply for this benefit by going to a VA regional benefit office and getting help from a VA employee.
Mustard gas is also known as sulfur mustard, yperite, or nitrogen mustard.
Lewisite is a natural compound that contains the poison arsenic.

You may be able to get disability benefits if you have a disability believed to be caused by contact with mustard gas or lewisite and your military record shows you had contact with mustard gas or lewisite.

If you were in the Army and served in Bari, Italy, Bushnell, FL, Camp Lejeune, NC, Camp Sibert, AL, Dugway Proving Ground, UT, Edgewood Arsenal, MD, Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, Ondal, India, Rocky Mountain Arsenal, CO, or San Jose Island, Panama Canal Zone, you may be eligible for disability benefits related to mustard gas or lewisite exposure.

If you were in the Navy and served in Bari, Italy, Camp Lejeune, NC, Charleston, SC, Great Lakes Naval Training Center, IL, Hart s Island, NY, Naval Training Center, Bainbridge, MD, Naval Research Laboratory, VA, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, or USS Eagle Boat 58, you may be eligible for disability benefits related to mustard gas or lewisite exposure.
Some service members who took part in testing in Finschhafen, New Guinea or Porton Down, England may be eligible for disability benefits related to mustard gas or lewisite exposure.
Select merchant seamen were also exposed at Bari, Italy and may be eligible for disability benefits related to mustard gas or lewisite exposure.
Veterans are covered for disability benefits related to mustard gas or lewisite exposure.
The disability benefits that can be received for mustard gas or lewisite exposure include health care and compensation payments.

To get disability benefits related to mustard gas or lewisite exposure, you need to file a claim for disability compensation and claim an actual disease or disability believed to be caused by your contact with one of these chemicals.
When filing a claim for disability benefits related to mustard gas or lewisite exposure, you need to share any military records that show you had contact with blistering agents.

If you need help filing your disability claim related to mustard gas or lewisite exposure, you can contact the VA via email at mustardgas@vba.va.gov or get help from a trained professional trusted to help with VA-related claims.
As many as 60,000 Veterans volunteered for medical research for the U.S. Biological and Chemical Programs.

If you volunteered for research involving chemical and biological testing between 1942 and 1975 and have an injury or disease directly caused by your participation in this testing, you can get medical care through the U.S. Army.
Veterans technology education courses are available.

If you want to gain computer experience to start or advance your career in the high-technology industry, you can find out if you are eligible for the Veteran Employment Through Technology Education Courses (VET TEC) program.
The VET TEC program matches you with a leading training provider to help you develop high-tech skills.
To be eligible for the VET TEC program, you must not be on active duty.
To be eligible for the VET TEC program, you must qualify for VA education assistance under the GI Bill.
To be eligible for the VET TEC program, you must have at least one day of unexpired GI Bill entitlement.
To be eligible for the VET TEC program, you must be accepted into a program by a VA-approved training provider.
Your VET TEC training will not count against your GI Bill entitlement.
You need only one day of unexpired GI Bill benefits to participate in the VET TEC program.
The VET TEC program covers training in computer software.
The VET TEC program covers training in computer programming.
The VET TEC program covers training in data processing.
The VET TEC program covers training in information science.
The VET TEC program covers training in media applications.
Through the VET TEC program, you can get tuition for a full-time high-tech training program.
Through the VET TEC program, you can get money for housing during your training.

If you attend your VET TEC training program in person, your housing stipend will be equal to the monthly military Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) for an E-5 with dependents, based on the zip code where you attend your training.
If you participate in an online VET TEC program, your housing stipend will be half of the BAH national average for an E-5 with dependents.
If you do not attend a VET TEC training for a full month, your housing payment will be prorated for the days you train.
To apply for the VET TEC program, you need to fill out an Application for Veteran Employment Through Technology Education Course (VA Form 22-0994).
If you are determined to be eligible for VET TEC, you will then apply to the VA-approved training provider of your choice.
Your VET TEC training provider may review your qualifications to assess whether you will be able to successfully complete their training program and find meaningful, relevant employment.
The VET TEC program is a five-year pilot program.
You can participate in the VET TEC program as long as the funding is available.
If you have not already applied for VA education benefits, you will also need to fill out an Application for VA Education Benefits (VA Form 22-1990).
You can browse the list of VA-approved VET TEC training providers.

A VET TEC training provider is considered preferred if the training facility agrees to refund tuition and fees if a student does not find meaningful employment within 180 days of completing the program.
After you complete your VET TEC training, you will receive a certification of your new skills.
If you have questions about the VET TEC program or how to apply, you can call 888-GIBILL1 (1-888-442-4551) Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. ET.
If you have hearing loss, you can call TTY: 711 for information about the VET TEC program.
You can email VETTEC.VBABUF@va.gov for information about the VET TEC program.
You have 1 year from the date on your decision to request a decision review.
The Supplemental Claim option is not available for fiduciary claims.
You can file a new claim if you have new evidence.
You can ask for a new look from a senior reviewer by downloading VA Form 20-0996: Higher-Level Review PDF.
When you choose a Higher-Level Review, you are asking for another review of the same evidence.
A senior reviewer will take another look at your case and determine whether the decision can be changed based on a difference of opinion or an error in a Higher-Level Review.
You can request a Higher-Level Review of an initial claim.
The Higher-Level Review option is not available after a Higher-Level Review or Board Appeal.
You can appeal to a Veterans Law Judge by downloading VA Form 10182: Board Appeal PDF.
A judge at the Board of Veterans Appeals in Washington, D.C., will review your case in a Board Appeal.
You can request a Board Appeal after an initial claim or Higher-Level Review decision.
You cannot request two Board Appeals in a row.
If you disagree with the Board's decision and have new and relevant evidence that supports your case, you can file a Supplemental Claim after a Board decision.
You can also appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims after a Board decision.
You do not need to do anything while you wait for a decision review unless VA sends you a letter asking for more information.
If VA schedules exams for you, be sure not to miss them during a decision review.
You can track the status of your appeal during a decision review.
A Veterans Service Organization or VA-accredited attorney or agent can help you request a decision review.
You can get answers to frequently asked questions about decision reviews.

If you got a decision notice from the United States Department of Veterans Affairs that confirms your disability rating, the rating that measures the severity of your disability, you may be able to get disability compensation or benefits.
Disability compensation may include financial compensation payments as well as other benefits like health care or job training.

If you haven't gotten your decision notice, you can check your status, contact your nearest VA regional benefit office, call the United States Department of Veterans Affairs at 800-827-1000, or contact the United States Department of Veterans Affairs online.
If your decision notice shows at least a 10% disability rating, you'll get your first payment within 15 days.
The United States Department of Veterans Affairs will pay you either by direct deposit or check.
If you don't get a payment after 15 days, you can call the Veterans help line at 800-827-1000, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. ET.
If you disagree with your disability rating, you can file an appeal.
You'll need to file an appeal within 1 year of getting your decision notice.
If you served on active duty and didn't receive a dishonorable discharge, you may be able to get VA health care.
VA health care includes access to VA doctors and care, plus medical equipment, prosthetics, and prescriptions.
You can apply for VA health care.
If you're in good health other than your disability caused by service in the military, you can buy Service-Disabled Veterans Insurance (S-DVI), a government life insurance policy.
You can apply for S-DVI online or call 800-669-8477, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. ET.
You can get VA support for college or job training under special programs.
You can talk with a VA education counselor to find out what education benefits you may be able to get.
If you're 30% or more disabled due to a disability caused by service in the military, you can get financial support and benefits for your qualified dependents.

You can check with your local or state VA offices for other benefits you may be able to get like help with buying a home or making changes to your home to make it more accessible, or help with getting a job.
You can find your state's Veterans Affairs website.
If you have a 100% disability rating, you may be able to get dental care and access to commissaries and exchanges.
If you can't work due to your disability caused by service in the military even without a 100% rating, you can apply for Individual Unemployability.
If you need special clothing because of your injuries, you may be able to get money to buy new clothes through the annual clothing allowance benefit.

It's important to update your information with the United States Department of Veterans Affairs when you have a new address, a change to your marital status, or any other life change that could affect your rating or payment.
If your disability gets worse, you can file a claim for an increase in benefits.
You can update your information in 1 of 2 ways: make the change directly in eBenefits, or contact your nearest VA regional benefit office.
A Veteran ID Card (VIC) is a form of photo ID you can use to get discounts offered to Veterans at many restaurants, hotels, stores, and other businesses.
To be eligible for a Veteran ID Card, you must have served on active duty, in the Reserves, or in the National Guard (including the Coast Guard).
To be eligible for a Veteran ID Card, you must have received an honorable or general discharge under honorable conditions.
If you received an other than honorable, bad conduct, or dishonorable character of discharge, you are not eligible for a Veteran ID Card.
If you have an uncharacterized or unknown discharge status, the Department of Veterans Affairs will have to verify your eligibility before approving your application for a Veteran ID Card.

To apply for a Veteran ID Card, you will need your Social Security number, a digital copy of your DD214, DD256, DD257, or NGB22 that you can upload, a copy of a current and valid government-issued ID (such as a driver's license, passport, or state-issued identification card), and a digital color photo of yourself from the shoulders up that meets certain requirements.

After you apply for a Veteran ID Card, the Department of Veterans Affairs will check your eligibility and verify that your character of discharge meets eligibility requirements, the ID you submitted is valid, and the image you have chosen to appear on the card meets the photo requirements.
If you have an unknown or uncharacterized discharge status, your application for a Veteran ID Card will take more time to process while the Department of Veterans Affairs verifies your eligibility.
You can sign in to your AccessVA account to check the status of your Veteran ID Card application.
To request a replacement for a lost or stolen Veteran ID Card, you should send an email to vic@va.gov.
If you have any questions or need help with your Veteran ID Card application, you should send an email to vic@va.gov.
Your Veteran ID Card will not replace your Veteran Health Identification Card or your Department of Defense ID Card.

You cannot use your Veteran ID Card to prove your eligibility for any federal benefits, access military bases or installations, access military commissaries or exchanges, present as a form of identification at the airport, check into a VA hospital, show as proof of retirement from the Armed Forces, or show as proof of wartime service to get a special license plate from the Department of Motor Vehicles.
If you are a Veteran in a mental health crisis and you are thinking about hurting yourself or you know a Veteran who is considering this act now, you are not alone, and you can get help.

To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night: Call 800-273-8255, then select 1. Start a confidential Veterans chat. Text 838255. If you have hearing loss, call TTY: 800-799-4889.
You can also: Call 911. Go to the nearest emergency room. Go directly to your nearest VA medical center. It does not matter what your discharge status is or if you are enrolled in VA health care.
Our specially trained suicide prevention coordinators available in each VA medical center across the country can help you get the counseling and services you need.
Our Vet Centers can help you and your family readjust to life at home after you have returned from serving in a combat zone.
Our Veterans Benefits Administration offices can help you access benefits for disability compensation monthly payments, job training, home loans, and more.
You can get information about suicide prevention and the support we offer by visiting our suicide prevention website.
You can go to our Make the Connection website to get resources and watch stories of Veterans who have overcome depression and other mental health challenges.
Many Veterans do not show any signs of an urge to harm themselves before doing so.

Some Veterans may show signs of depression, anxiety, low self-esteem, or hopelessness, like: Seeming sad, depressed, anxious, or agitated most of the time. Sleeping either all the time or not much at all. Not caring about what they look like or what happens to them. Pulling away from friends, family, and society. Losing interest in hobbies, work, school, or other things they used to care about. Expressing feelings of excessive guilt or shame, failure, lack of purpose in life, or being trapped.

They may also change the way they act, and start to: Perform poorly at work or school. Act violently or take risks like driving fast or running red lights. Do things to prepare for a suicide like giving away special personal items, making a will, or seeking access to guns or pills.
If you are a family member or friend of a Veteran who is having trouble adjusting to life at home, we can help through our national Coaching Into Care program.

Through our Coaching Into Care program, our licensed psychologists and social workers will talk with you by phone, free of charge, to help you find your way around the VA system and figure out the best way to help the Veteran you care about.
All calls to the Coaching Into Care program are confidential and private.
To speak with a VA coach, call 888-823-7458, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. ET.
To get tips and resources for spouses, parents, and Veterans, visit the Coaching Into Care website.
VA education benefits can help you pay your tuition.
VA education benefits can help you pick out a school.
VA education benefits can help you choose a career.
If you are an active-duty service member, you may be able to get VA education benefits through the GI Bill and other educational assistance programs.
If you are a Veteran, you may be able to get VA education benefits through the GI Bill and other educational assistance programs.
If you are a member of the National Guard, you may be able to get VA education benefits through the GI Bill and other educational assistance programs.
If you are a member of the Reserves, you may be able to get VA education benefits through the GI Bill and other educational assistance programs.
If you are a qualified survivor, you may be able to get VA education benefits through the GI Bill and other educational assistance programs.
If you are a qualified dependent, you may be able to get VA education benefits through the GI Bill and other educational assistance programs.
You may be able to get benefits through the Post-9/11 GI Bill if you have served on active duty for at least 90 days after September 10, 2001.
The Montgomery GI Bill Active Duty (MGIB-AD) program requires that you served at least 2 years on active duty.
The Montgomery GI Bill Active Duty (MGIB-AD) program requires that you were honorably discharged.
The Montgomery GI Bill Active Duty (MGIB-AD) program requires that you have a high school diploma, GED, or 12 hours of college credit.
The Montgomery GI Bill Selected Reserve (MGIB-SR) program is for members of the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps or Coast Guard Reserves, Army National Guard, or Air National Guard.

The Montgomery GI Bill Selected Reserve (MGIB-SR) program requires that you have either a 6-year service obligation you agreed to serve 6 years in the Selected Service, or are an officer in the Selected Reserve who agreed to serve 6 years in addition to your initial service obligation.
You may be able to get help paying for school tuition, testing fees, and advanced licensing and certifications through other VA educational assistance programs.
You may be able to get entrepreneurship training to help start or improve a small business through other VA educational assistance programs.
You may be able to get Educational and Career Counseling (also called Chapter 36) if you will be discharged from active duty within 6 months.

You may be able to get Educational and Career Counseling (also called Chapter 36) if you separated from active duty not more than 1 year ago, did not receive a dishonorable discharge, and qualify as a Veteran for educational assistance under a VA educational program.

If you have a service-connected disability that limits your ability to work or prevents you from working, you may be eligible for Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment benefits and services like help exploring employment options and getting more training if required.
If you received an other than honorable, bad conduct, or dishonorable discharge, you may not be eligible for VA benefits.
If you received an other than honorable, bad conduct, or dishonorable discharge, you can try to qualify for VA benefits by applying for a discharge upgrade.
If you received an other than honorable, bad conduct, or dishonorable discharge, you can try to qualify for VA benefits by going through the VA Character of Discharge review process.
In some cases, the dependent or surviving spouse and children of a Veteran can get educational assistance through a GI Bill program.
If you have not used all of your Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits, you may be able to transfer up to 36 months of benefits to your spouse or a dependent child.

If you have a service-connected disability that limits your ability to work or prevents you from working, your dependent family members may be eligible for Educational and Career Counseling and other support through the Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment program.
To apply for Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment or educational and career counseling benefits and services, you will need to use a different application.
Vous pouvez programmer les funérailles d'un vétéran ou d'un membre de la famille.
Vous pouvez découvrir comment faire les préparatifs des funérailles pour un vétéran, un conjoint ou un membre de la famille à charge.
Si vous avez une lettre de décision préalable qui confirme l'admissibilité, vous pouvez commencer par choisir un directeur de funérailles pour vous aider à planifier les funérailles.
Soit vous, soit le directeur de funérailles, peut appeler le Bureau national de planification des cimetières au 800-535-1117 pour demander des funérailles.
La lettre de décision préalable n'identifie pas un cimetière ou un lieu de sépulture spécifique, car il n'est pas possible de les réserver à l'avance.
Dans certains cas, nous pouvons revoir votre admissibilité au moment de votre décès, car les lois et les circonstances peuvent avoir changé depuis votre demande préalable.
Vous n'avez rien d'autre à faire que de vous préparer, vous et votre famille, pour les funérailles.
Vous pouvez découvrir à quoi s'attendre lors d'un service funèbre ou commémoratif militaire.
Si vous n'avez pas de lettre de décision préalable, vous pouvez commencer par choisir un directeur de funérailles pour vous aider à planifier les funérailles.
Soit vous, soit le directeur de funérailles, devrez suivre 3 étapes pour programmer les funérailles.
Vous devrez rassembler les informations et les documents nécessaires pour identifier le défunt lorsque vous appelez le Bureau national de planification des cimetières.

Vous aurez besoin du DD214 ou d'autres documents de démobilisation du vétéran ou du membre du service dont le service militaire sera utilisé pour déterminer l'admissibilité aux funérailles dans un cimetière national des VA.
La démobilisation du service du vétéran ou du membre du service doit avoir été effectuée dans des conditions autres que déshonorable.
Nous pouvons également avoir besoin d'autres documents pour vérifier un lien avec un vétéran ou le statut d'une personne à charge.
Ces documents peuvent inclure un certificat de décès, des lettres de votre médecin, un jugement de divorce, une déclaration de la Sécurité sociale ou d'autres documents à l'appui de votre demande.
Vous pouvez découvrir quels documents de démobilisation nous acceptons avec votre demande.
Vous pouvez découvrir comment demander le DD214 du vétéran.
Si vous ne trouvez pas ces documents, veuillez nous demander de l'aide lorsque vous appelez.
Il peut nous falloir 48 heures ou plus pour vérifier l'admissibilité si vous n'avez pas de documents de démobilisation.
Les documents de démobilisation ne sont généralement pas nécessaires pour la programmation lorsqu'un vétéran ou une personne à charge admissible est déjà inhumé dans un cimetière national.

Vous aurez également besoin de ces informations sur le défunt : nom, genre, numéro de sécurité sociale ou numéro de service militaire, identifiant de vétéran, date de naissance, lien avec le membre du service ou le vétéran dont le service militaire sera utilisé pour décider de l'admissibilité, situation de famille, date de décès et code postal et comté au moment du décès.
Vous aurez besoin de ces informations sur le plus proche parent vivant du défunt : nom, lien avec le défunt, numéro de sécurité sociale, numéro de téléphone, adresse.
Vous pouvez également avoir besoin de plus d'informations dans certains cas.
Si la personne était mariée, vous aurez également besoin du statut du conjoint survivant en tant que vétéran, membre du service ou membre de la famille.
Si la personne a des enfants handicapés, vous aurez besoin du statut et des informations détaillées pour tout enfant handicapé qui pourrait être inhumé à l'avenir dans un cimetière national.

Si le conjoint de la personne est décédé précédemment et a été inhumé dans un cimetière national des VA, vous aurez besoin du nom complet du conjoint ainsi que de la section et du numéro du site où il est inhumé.
Vous devrez décider des détails des funérailles et rassembler toutes les informations connexes.
Vous devrez nous dire où vous préféreriez que le vétéran, le conjoint ou le membre de la famille à charge soit inhumé.
Vous pouvez trouver un cimetière national des VA.
Vous pouvez trouver un cimetière d'État pour les vétérans.
Vous devrez nous dire le type de funérailles que vous souhaitez pour la personne (cercueil ou crémation) et la taille du cercueil ou de l'urne funéraire.
Vous devrez nous dire le type de monument commémoratif que vous souhaitez pour la sépulture, comme une pierre tombale, un marqueur de tombe, un couvercle de niche ou un médaillon.
Vous devrez nous dire l'inscription ou l'emblème religieux que vous souhaitez sur la pierre tombale ou le marqueur.

Si la personne est un vétéran ou un réserviste, vous devrez également nous dire si vous souhaitez des honneurs funèbres ou des articles commémoratifs, comme un drapeau de funérailles, un certificat commémoratif présidentiel ou d'autres honneurs militaires possibles au-delà du jeu de la Sonnerie aux morts et du pliage et de la présentation du drapeau.
Vous pouvez demander des monuments commémoratifs pour les sépultures et des honneurs funèbres.
Vous pouvez en apprendre davantage sur les honneurs funèbres militaires.
Le directeur de funérailles que vous avez choisi peut vous aider avec ces étapes.
Pour une inhumation dans un cimetière national, vous pouvez envoyer par fax tous les documents de démobilisation au Bureau national de planification des cimetières au 866-900-6417.

Vous pouvez également numériser et envoyer par courriel les documents à NCA.Scheduling@va.gov avec le nom de la personne pour laquelle vous demandez des prestations de funérailles dans la ligne d'objet.
Ensuite, vous pouvez appeler le 800-535-1117 pour confirmer la demande de funérailles.
Assurez-vous d'avoir toutes les informations mentionnées dans la section Préparer.
Le Bureau national de planification des cimetières est ouvert tous les jours de 8h00 à 19h30, heure de l'Est.
Le bureau est fermé le jour de l'Action de grâce, le jour de Noël et le jour de l'An.
Les inhumations dans les cimetières nationaux ont lieu du lundi au vendredi.
Lorsqu'il y a un jour férié fédéral un lundi ou un vendredi, les cimetières peuvent programmer des inhumations soit le jour férié réel, soit l'un des jours du week-end férié.
Le Bureau national de planification des cimetières peut vous indiquer les heures d'inhumation disponibles pour chaque cimetière.
Vous devrez contacter directement un cimetière national dans certains cas.
Vous devrez contacter un cimetière national directement pour programmer une inhumation pour un membre du service actif.
Vous devrez contacter un cimetière national directement pour annuler ou reporter une inhumation.
Vous devrez contacter un cimetière national directement pour modifier toute information que vous avez déjà fournie au bureau de planification.
Vous devrez contacter un cimetière national directement pour demander une exhumation et/ou un transfert vers un autre cimetière national.

Vous devrez contacter un cimetière national directement pour obtenir des informations spécifiques à ce cimetière, comme ce qui peut être inscrit sur une pierre tombale, la politique concernant les fleurs et les heures d'ouverture.
Si vous avez des questions sur le programme d'inhumation en mer, veuillez contacter le Bureau des affaires mortuaires de la Marine des États-Unis au numéro gratuit 866-787-0081.
Le Bureau des affaires mortuaires de la Marine est ouvert du lundi au vendredi, de 8h30 à 17h00, heure de l'Est.
Vous pouvez obtenir plus d'informations sur le programme d'inhumation en mer.

Si vous êtes le conjoint officiel (le conjoint légalement reconnu) ou un membre de la famille légalement désigné d'un vétéran, vous pouvez obtenir une aide financière pour les frais de funérailles et d'inhumation.
Vous pouvez découvrir comment demander une allocation de funérailles pour vétéran.
You may still be able to get disability compensation payments or other benefits if you have a disability that isn't listed on this site as being linked to military service.

If you're a Veteran with a disability that the Department of Veterans Affairs has concluded is the result of an illness or injury caused or made worse by your active-duty service (called a service-connected disability), you may be able to get special compensation to help with disabilities.

If your service-connected disability prevents you from driving, you may be able to get money to help buy a specially equipped vehicle or make needed changes to your existing vehicle (this is called an automobile allowance and adaptive equipment).

If you were exposed to specific chemicals while serving in Vietnam, Thailand, or the Korean Demilitarized Zone, and your child has spina bifida or other birth defects, your child may be eligible for disability benefits (this is called birth defects linked to Agent Orange).

If your clothing has been damaged by your prosthetic or orthopedic device or by medicine you're taking for a skin condition, you may be able to get money to help buy new clothes (this is called replacing damaged clothing).
If you're recovering from surgery or other treatment that has left you unable to move, you may be able to get temporary disability payments or other benefits (this is called convalescence).
If you're a Veteran, you may be able to get dental care through the Department of Veterans Affairs.

If you spent time in a Department of Veterans Affairs or Department of Veterans Affairs-approved hospital for a service-connected disability, you may be able to get benefits like disability payments for that time (this is called time spent in a hospital).
If you can't work because of your service-connected disability, you may be able to get increased disability payments (this is called Individual Unemployability).

If you suffered an added disability while getting Department of Veterans Affairs medical care or taking part in a Department of Veterans Affairs program designed to help you find, get, or keep a job, you may be able to get disability payments (this is called Title 38 U.S.C. 1151 disabilities).

If you recently ended your active military service and you have a service-connected disability, you may be able to get temporary disability payments or other benefits right away (this is called prestabilization).
At VA, we take a team approach to health care with you at the center.
Research shows this kind of approach leads to better quality care, more satisfied patients, and fewer hospital visits.
After you sign up for VA health care and choose your main VA location, VA will assign you to a health care team called a Patient Aligned Care Team or PACT.
Your Patient Aligned Care Team (PACT) will be made up of you, those who support you like your family members and caregivers, and your health care providers.
Your Patient Aligned Care Team (PACT) will include a primary care provider, which is your main doctor, nurse practitioner, or physician's assistant.

Your Patient Aligned Care Team (PACT) will include a clinical pharmacist, which is a pharmacist who works with you and your primary care provider to make sure you're taking the medicines that are right for you and your overall health.

Your Patient Aligned Care Team (PACT) will include a registered nurse (RN) care manager, which is a nurse who makes sure your care is coordinated across all providers and services, and meets your health goals and your plan for care.

Your Patient Aligned Care Team (PACT) will include a licensed practical nurse (LPN) or medical assistant and clerk team members, who help to support you and the other health care providers on your team.
When you need other services to meet your goals and needs, your Patient Aligned Care Team (PACT) may call other providers like social workers or specialists to help with your care.
Your Patient Aligned Care Team's (PACT) goal is to plan for all the care you need to help you stay healthy and well throughout your life.

Your Patient Aligned Care Team (PACT) will build a partnership with you, where you'll be an active member of the team, and you'll work with your team to plan and make decisions to meet your personal health goals.
Your Patient Aligned Care Team (PACT) will offer wellness care, education, and lifestyle coaching to help you stay healthy.

Your Patient Aligned Care Team (PACT) will provide or arrange for preventive care, such as immunizations like flu shots to prevent illness and screenings to help find diseases like cancer in their earliest stages when treatment is most likely to be successful.

Your Patient Aligned Care Team (PACT) will help you get care in the ways that work best for you, which may include personal visits with your primary care provider, group clinics, and 24/7 telephone care.
You can also get online educational information and secure messaging with your Patient Aligned Care Team (PACT) through the My HealtheVet portal.
Members of your Patient Aligned Care Team (PACT) will meet often to talk with you and each other about your progress and goals.
Members of your Patient Aligned Care Team (PACT) will coordinate any care you may need from specialists outside the team.
You'll choose the main VA location where you'd like to get care, and VA will assign you a health care team including your primary care provider based on the location you choose.
If you decide you want to change to a different primary care doctor, you'll need to talk to your health care team leader or to the patient advocate at your VA medical center.

Your Patient Aligned Care Team (PACT) will have a plan in place if your primary care provider is away or leaves VA, to ensure you always have access to a qualified primary care provider and that you keep getting the ongoing care you need to continue with your health care plan.
If you're enrolled in VA health care, you may be able to receive care from a provider in your local community through community care, depending on your situation.
For information on how to apply, see Parking for People with Disabilities.
Parking for People with Disabilities is a link.
Reserved parking for people with disabilities ensures safe and equal access to goods and services.
Access to goods and services is access which most of us take for granted.
This publication explains the rules that businesses and all drivers should observe about reserved parking spaces.
This publication presents information on how to obtain license plates and parking permits that allow individuals with severe disabilities to use specially-marked parking spots.
Reserved parking for people with disabilities is a legal requirement, not just a courtesy.
You can help support the law by parking in reserved spaces only if you have a permit or plates for people with disabilities.
You can help support the law by parking in reserved spaces only when the person who received the permit or plates is actually in the vehicle.
Please avoid parking in the access aisle or striped area next to a reserved parking space - it is not a parking zone.
The access aisle or striped area next to a reserved parking space is needed for access by people who use wheelchairs and specially-equipped vehicles.
It is important to respect each other.
Please, be parking considerate.

A qualifying disability is one or more of the following impairments, disabilities or conditions that are both permanent in nature and affect mobility: Use of portable oxygen, Legal blindness, Limited use, or no use, of one or both legs, Inability to walk 200 feet without stopping, A neuro-muscular dysfunction that severely limits mobility, A Class III or IV cardiac condition American Heart Association standards, Severe limitation in the ability to walk due to an arthritic, neurological or orthopedic condition, Restriction because of lung disease to such an extent that forced respiratory expiratory volume for one second, when measured by spirometry, is less than one liter, or the arterial oxygen tension is less than sixty mm/hg of room air at rest, Any other physical or mental impairment not previously listed which constitutes an equal degree of disability, and imposes unusual hardship in the use of public transportation and prevents the person from getting around without great difficulty.

A temporary parking permit, valid for six months, may be issued when a person has a temporarily disabling condition that makes the person unable to walk without a cane, crutches, a walker or other assisting device.

To qualify for the license plates or the parking permit, you must present proof of the disability from a medical doctor MD, doctor of osteopathy DO, doctor of podiatric medicine DPM, licensed in NYS only or optometrist OD, for blindness.
Only these medical professionals are considered "doctors" as the term is used in this publication.
A doctor licensed in New York or another state may certify for conditions #1 through #8 previously listed.
Only doctors licensed in New York State may certify for condition #9.
A podiatrist must be licensed in NYS, and may certify applicants only for severe disabilities of the foot.

You may provide one of these proofs of disability: Have your doctor fill out the Medical Certification, Part II, on the "Application for License Plates and Parking Permits for People with Severe Disabilities" MV-664.1, a statement from a hospital, clinic or medical facility, the NYS Office of Vocational Rehabilitation in the NYS Department of Education, or the NYS Commission for the Blind and Visually Handicapped in the Office of Children and Family Services for verification of legal blindness.

If you have an obvious, visible, permanent disability, such as the complete or partial loss of a leg or foot, the requirement for a medical statement may be waived by a DMV supervisor if you are applying for the license plates, or by the local issuing agent if you are applying for a permit.

If you have moved to NYS and want to apply for New York State license plates or a parking permit for people with disabilities, you must provide proof of disability listed in 1 - 3 of the sections above even if you had parking privileges in your former state.
Your out-of-state permit cannot be accepted in exchange for a NYS permit or plates.
If you already have license plates for people with disabilities, a locality may accept your registration as proof for issuing a permit.
Under the New York State Vehicle & Traffic Law Section 392, it is a criminal violation misdemeanor to make a false statement or give false information on an application for license plates.

It is also a misdemeanor under the NYS Penal Law Section 210.45 to make a false statement or provide misinformation to obtain a parking permit for a person with a disability, and is punishable by fines from $250 to $1,000.
Additional civil penalties from $250 to $1,000 may also be imposed under Section 1203-a 4 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law.
These penalties also apply to doctors providing certifications, as well as applicants.
The Department of Motor Vehicles issues license plates for people with permanent disabilities for use on passenger cars, motorcycles, vans, and pickup trucks not used for commercial purposes.
You do not have to be a resident of New York State or even a licensed driver to obtain the license plates, but you must be at least 16 years old to register a vehicle.
License plates with the Universal Symbol of Access are only issued for a vehicle registered in the name of the person who has the disability.
Each individual with a disability may have only one set of license plates.
If you cannot register the vehicle in the name of the disabled person, refer to the section on Parking Permits.
You may apply at any state or county motor vehicle office for a second set of license plates for another family member who also has a disability.

In addition to providing the documentation for registering the vehicle, you also must provide the family member's driver license, proof of disability and a completed Application for License Plates and Parking Permits for People With Severe Disabilities MV-664.1.
Personalized license plates up to six characters with the Universal Symbol of Access are available for an additional charge.
You should contact NYS DMV Custom Plates Unit at P.O. Box 2775, Albany, NY 12220 for personalized license plates.

If your vehicle already has a valid registration with New York license plates and you already have a permanent parking permit for people with disabilities that was issued in New York State, you must present this permit and a copy of the MV-664.1 showing the medical certification or doctor's statement used to obtain the parking permit.
The medical certification must be dated no more than one year prior to the application for the license plates.
Do NOT apply if you hold only a temporary parking permit.
To apply, you must complete a Vehicle Registration/Title Application MV-82 and pay a fee for the new plates displaying the Universal Symbol of Access.
If this transaction is done at any time other than at renewal, a $3.75 transaction fee will be charged.

If your vehicle already has a valid registration with New York license plates and you do NOT already have a permanent parking permit for people with disabilities, bring proof of your disability, your current New York plates and registration receipt to any state or county motor vehicle office.
You will be required to fill out a Vehicle Registration/Title Application MV-82 and pay a fee for the new plates showing the Universal Symbol of Access.
If this transaction is done at any time other than at renewal, a $3.75 transaction fee will be charged.
Do NOT apply if you hold only a temporary parking permit.

If you are registering your vehicle for the first time, and you do not already have a permanent parking permit for people with disabilities, you must provide all of the items required for an original vehicle registration plus the proof of disability.
There is no additional fee for renewing a vehicle registered with plates for people with disabilities.
You do not have to provide proof of disability when you renew your vehicle registration.
However, when you sign your registration renewal notice you are certifying, under penalty of the law, that you have a severe disability and are eligible to have the license plates.
Making a false certification is a misdemeanor.
You must live in New York State to be eligible for a permanent parking permit, but you need not be a licensed driver or own a vehicle.
You must apply in the locality in which you live.
A temporary parking permit, valid for six months, is available for a non-resident with a qualifying disability.
State law requires every city, town and village to appoint an agent usually the city, town or village clerk to issue parking permits for people with disabilities.
You should contact your city, town or village clerk to find out which local agency issues the permits.
There is no fee for the permit.
DMV does not issue the parking permits.
Localities follow the same general guidelines for issuing the permit as the DMV does for plates, but there may be some differences from one locality to another.
Most issuing agents accept an MV-664.1.
The MV-664.1 form is available at any motor vehicle office, by request from a DMV Call Center, and from the DMV Internet Office.
However, some localities have their own application form, and not all localities issue temporary permits.
You should contact your local issuing agent for specific information on how to obtain a permit in your area.
A permit is issued to any person with a qualifying disability.
This enables the permit may be used in any vehicle in which that person is riding.
A local issuing agent also may issue parking permits to a state facility or an agency licensed by the state or locality.
The permits will be issued only for vehicles primarily used to transport people with qualifying disabilities.

To apply, the agency must provide a written request on its own letterhead describing its facility or agency, a copy of their New York State facility license and a list of the vehicles they use to transport people with disabilities.
Each "permanent" or temporary permit has an expiration date.
An expired permit is not valid and cannot be used.
If your permit is due to expire, contact your local issuing agent to find out about the renewal procedures in your area.
If your disability is not permanent, you may qualify for a temporary permit valid for up to six months.
To apply for a temporary permit, you must present the same proof of disability as required for a permanent permit.
The temporary permit will allow the same access to reserved parking spaces.
If you have a temporary parking permit that is due to expire, and you still have a qualifying disability, you must obtain a new medical certification before you can apply for another parking permit.
The permit is designed to hang from the rearview mirror when parked, but should be removed when the vehicle is being operated.
If you lose your permit or it is stolen, immediately report it to the locality that issued the permit.
Any vehicle that has a license plate or valid permit displaying the Universal Symbol of Access may use parking spaces designated for use by a person with a disability.
The person to whom the license plate or permit was issued must be traveling in the vehicle in order to use these spaces.
Plates and permits do not allow you to disobey state or local parking regulations.
Plates and permits also do not exempt you from parking fees unless a locality has adopted an ordinance to that effect.
The fine for illegally parking in a space reserved for people with disabilities is $50 to $150, plus a mandatory $30 surcharge.

It is a serious misuse of license plates and permits for people with disabilities when someone other that the person with a disability uses the plates or permit to park in a space reserved for people with disabilities.
These license plates or parking permits are valid only when the person with a disability who received the plates or permit is driving the vehicle or is a passenger in it.

If you misuse plates or a parking permit or allow someone else to use them, the DMV may revoke the license plates or the locality that issued the permit may revoke the permit, or they may deny renewal.
Off-street parking spaces for people with disabilities are required by law at shopping centers that have five or more retail stores, and signs must be posted.
Spaces reserved for people with disabilities must be located as close to the shopping center as possible and distributed to provide convenient access.
A facility owner who does not comply may be fined up to $250.
On-street parking spaces reserved for people with disabilities are designated by local law or ordinance.
If you have a question about parking for people with disabilities on a particular street, contact the authorities responsible for maintaining the street.
State and local laws and building codes also require reserved parking for people with disabilities at other facilities and when new parking lots are constructed.
If you have a question about reserved parking at any facility with off-street parking, contact the facility management or the local building inspector.

State, county or local law enforcement officers are authorized to enter the parking lot of any shopping center or other facility described in the State Building Code to enforce laws governing the use of parking spaces reserved for people with disabilities.
New York City does not set aside reserved spaces on its streets for persons with disabilities.
Reserved parking spaces are only available off-street, in parking lots for shopping centers/malls, office/apartment buildings and college campuses.
You can use the vehicle plates for people with disabilities or a state permit for people with disabilities to park in reserved spaces in those off-street lots.
However, the NYC Department of Transportation issues a City permit a rectangular dashboard permit that allows persons with severe disabilities to park at most curbsides on NYC streets.
City permits are issued to people with a permanent disability that so severely affects their ability to walk that they require the use of a private automobile.
The New York City parking permit is not valid outside of NYC.
For more information or to obtain an application for a NYC permit, call 718 433-3100 or visit the NYC Department of Transportation's website.
New York State honors out-of-state plates and permits for people with disabilities.
Most other states also honor New York's permits and plates.

To be sure if you travel to another state, check with the police or motor vehicle agency of the other state about whether they honor New York State issued license plates or permits for people with disabilities.
Apply for plates or a permit for people with disabilities only if you have a qualifying disability.
When parked, hang the parking permit from the vehicle's inside rearview mirror.
Remove the permit from the mirror before driving.
Use the parking spaces reserved for people with disabilities only if you have the license plates or parking permit, and only when the person with a disability is driving or riding in the vehicle.
Never park in the access aisle or striped area next to a reserved parking space.
The access aisle or striped area next to a reserved parking space allows access to the parking space by people with wheelchairs and specially-equipped vehicles.
The access aisle or striped area next to a reserved parking space is not a parking zone.
Do NOT allow others to misuse your plates or permit.
When you use the license plates or parking permit for people with disabilities, you are NOT exempt from parking regulations or fees.

To apply in New York City for the state parking permit or the special New York City disability parking permit for people with disabilities, please contact: The NYC Department of Transportation, Bureau of Parking Permits and Customer Service Unit 30-30 Thomson Avenue, 2nd Floor Long Island City, NY 11101-3045 Telephone: 1-718-433-3100 TTY: 1-212-504-4115 website: http://www.nyc.gov/html/dot/html/motorist/pppdinfo.shtml.
Personalized license plates up to six characters with the Universal Symbol of Access are available for an additional charge.
You should contact NYS DMV Custom Plates Unit at P.O. Box 2775, Albany, NY 12220 for personalized license plates.
You can contact DMV Call Center telephone numbers for more information.

If the seller has a title certificate that was transferred to the seller by the previous owner, and the title certificate displays the name of the previous owner, the seller must get a title certificate that displays the name of the seller.
The seller must use the Application for Title Only PDF MV-82TON form to get a title certificate that displays the name of the seller.
The seller must follow the instructions carefully when using the MV-82TON form.
The seller must not use the MV-82TON form to apply for both a vehicle registration and a title certificate at the same time.
The seller must not use the MV-82TON form to replace a lost title certificate.
If the seller cannot get a title certificate that displays their name, the seller can contact the DMV to get more information.
If the NY State transferable registration is lost, the current owner can apply for a duplicate registration document at a DMV office.

The current owner must use the Application for Registration or Title PDF MV-82 and the instructions for Registering / Titling a Vehicle in New York State PDF MV-82.1 to apply for a duplicate registration document.
The current owner can transfer the ownership with the duplicate registration, even if the registration is expired.
The current owner must also complete a bill of sale to transfer ownership with a duplicate registration.
The current owner must get proof of ownership at purchase.

If the NY State transferable registration is lost and the DMV cannot issue a duplicate, the current owner can apply for Certification of NY State Registration for Transfer of Non-Titled Vehicle Form MV-353.
The DMV must verify that the vehicle was registered to the current owner before issuing Form MV-353.
The current owner must provide proof of identity to get Form MV-353.
There is a fee of $10 for Form MV-353.
The current owner can use Form MV-353 and a bill of sale to transfer ownership of a non-titled vehicle.
If the DMV cannot issue a transferable registration or Form MV-353, the registration applicant must show other evidence of ownership.
The registration applicant can show an old registration, an original Manufacturer's Certificate of Origin, or an original Manufacturer's Statement of Origin as evidence of ownership.
If the proof of ownership is not available, the registration applicant can use the MV-51B for proof of ownership.

If the seller did not register the vehicle, the boat, the ATV or the snowmobile, the seller can give the buyer a completed MV-51, the original proof of ownership that the seller received from the previous owner, and a bill of sale.
If there are other previous owners, the seller must also give the buyer proofs of all previous transfers of ownership.
The seller must also give the buyer a bill of sale.
If the seller did not provide proof of ownership, the buyer must contact the seller and get a bill of sale, and a registration receipt or Form MV-353 transferred to the buyer.
If the buyer cannot get proof of ownership from the seller, the buyer must write to the owner and request that the owner transfer the acceptable proof of ownership to the buyer.
The buyer must mail the proof of ownership request to the owner using certified mail with a return receipt.

If the certified letter is returned by the US Postal Service, the buyer must bring all relevant items to a DMV office, including the returned certified letter in its envelope, not opened, a pencil tracing, a photo or a police statement that shows the vehicle identification number, an explanation of how the buyer got the vehicle and how the buyer tried to get acceptable proof of ownership, a notarized affidavit, other documents that are evidence of ownership, and a completed Statement of Ownership PDF MV-51B.
If the proof of ownership for a non-titled vehicle, boat, or snowmobile is not a NY State transferable registration, the local DMV office will issue a non-transferable registration.
The owner can use the vehicle, boat or snowmobile with a non-transferable registration, but cannot transfer ownership to another person.

The DMV Title Services Bureau will examine the proofs of ownership and will mail to the owner either a transferable registration or a letter explaining why the DMV cannot issue a transferable registration.

The I LOVE NY Adventure Custom Plates are available to individuals that hold a currently valid NYS Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC) issued Sporting License and/or a NYS Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation issued Empire Passport.
The I LOVE NY Adventure Custom Plates are available in passenger, commercial and motorcycle registration classes.
The I LOVE NY Adventure Custom Plates allow you to proudly display your love of the outdoors.

The fee noted for each renewal of the I LOVE NY Adventure Custom Plates is the $15 annual I LOVE NY fee + the personalization fee if applicable and does not include the regular registration renewal fees due upon each renewal.
If your registration for the I LOVE NY Adventure Custom Plates is renewed every two years (passenger and commercial class), the fee is $30 at renewal.
If your registration for the I LOVE NY Adventure Custom Plates is for a motorcycle class which renews every 1 year, a $15 I LOVE NY fee will be due at each renewal.

If you purchased a LIFETIME NYS Parks issued Empire Passport or DEC issued LIFETIME Sporting License in 2014, the fees noted above except personalization fees, if applicable are waived for your first plate purchase and first renewal only of the I LOVE NY Adventure Custom Plates.
The personalization fee for the I LOVE NY Adventure Custom Plates is $31.25 for passenger and commercial registration classes and $18.75 for motorcycle registration class.

To obtain the I LOVE NY Adventure Custom Plates for a passenger or commercial registration class vehicle, you may order them online at I LOVE NY Adventure Custom Plates Gallery or by mail by completing the Application for Custom Plates (CP-30) and mailing it to the Custom Plates Unit at NYS Department of Motor Vehicles.
To obtain the I LOVE NY Adventure Custom Plates for a motorcycle registration class, you must order them by mail, no online ordering is possible.
A copy of your driver license and a copy of your sporting license or Empire Passport must accompany the application form for the I LOVE NY Adventure Custom Plates.
The I LOVE NY Adventure Custom Plates cannot be ordered in a DMV office.

DMV has teamed with the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC) and the Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation (Parks) to offer a new convenient service for purchasers of DEC issued Lifetime Sporting Licenses and Parks issued Lifetime Empire Passports and Boating Safety Certificates.
Beginning February 3, 2014, your driver license, permit or non-driver ID can show evidence that you possess one of these new NYS Adventure Licenses.
The lifetime recreational license icons will be displayed on the DMV photo document.
More information about purchasing a NYS Adventure License may be obtained at the NYS website.

New lifetime sporting license purchasers and those that complete a boating safety course can opt to have icons added to their NYS Driver license and non-driver ID when you purchase your lifetime sporting license, or complete your boating safety certification training.
Effective May 1, 2014, all individuals born on or after May 1, 1996 are now required to successfully complete an approved course in boater education in order to operate a motorboat.
Those purchasing a Lifetime Empire Passport will be automatically issued a new license at no cost with the icons added.

You may request the icons be added to your DMV photo document in two ways: online using the Online Sporting License System at the NYS website or by visiting a NYS Department of Motor Vehicles office and presenting the required proof.

When visiting the DMV office to add the icons to your DMV photo document, there is a $12.50 new document fee ($5.00 for non-driver ID holders) unless you are renewing your photo document during your visit.
A 'lifetime' driving record contains all the license information DMV currently has available about a driver.
The lifetime driving record will display all information still in DMV's possession regardless of the data retention requirements found in Vehicle and Traffic Law.
The lifetime driving record may not include information that dates back to when a driver was initially granted driving privileges.
A standard driver license abstract only contains information that DMV is still required to keep.
For example, most suspensions and revocations are only shown on the standard driving record abstract for 4 years from the date the suspension or revocation ended.
A lifetime driving record will show suspensions and revocations that are older than 4 years.
Each driving record abstract contains information grouped within several sections.

The 'Header' section includes the individual's information as applicable deceased name, mailing address, City, State, ZIP Code, mailing county name as it appears on document, DMV ID Number, Client ID Number from your NY State driver license, learner permit or non-driver photo ID card, date of birth (DOB), gender/sex, height, eye color, temporary visitor, military veteran, organ donor, suspension and revocation summary that limit the driving privilege, restrictions, adventure license credentials.
The form 'Driver License Class Descriptions' (MV-500C) provides a list and explanation of driver license restrictions.
The header is followed by a 'Summary' section that includes license class/privilege, document status including commercial and 19A, document expiration date, date of road test eligibility.
The 'Current License' section includes current license class, current license expiration date that expand the driving privilege, any endorsements that was issued, type of document.
