The 'Non-Driver ID' section includes issue date, expiration date.
The 'Permit History' section includes permit classes and the dates they were applied for, date the permit document expired that limit or expand the permit privilege, any restrictions or endorsements.
The 'Activity' section may include driver license related course completion, Commercial Driver License (CDL) history, license reciprocity information.
The 'Class/Privilege' section includes class/Privilege of the driver holds or has held, effective date for each class/Privilege, date each license class/Privilege was posted to the license record.
The 'Document' section includes type of document, license class, issue date.
The 'Merges' section only appears on the abstract if the driver has ever had license under a different Customer Identification Number (CID) than the one shown in the 'Header' section.

If present, the 'Merges' section will show which CIDs were merged, the resulting CID the merged CID was put on the record, the date, any other name connected to the merged CIDs, any other Dates of Birth (DOB) connected to the merged CIDs, any other gender connected to the merged CIDs.
On the 'Lifetime' driving record, the 'Suspensions and Revocations' section is divided into two sub-sections, 'Non-Scofflaws' and 'Scofflaws'.
Non-scofflaws and Scofflaws will be listed separately, in order by effective date, from newest to oldest.
For out of state courts, the court's address and phone number are recorded as provided by the issuing jurisdiction.
Non-scofflaws: The type of sanction imposed suspension or revocation which results from reasons other than failure to answer a summons or pay a fine/surcharge/assessment.

The following fields may appear for Non-scofflaws: Suspension/Revocation Date, Incident Date if applicable, Reason reason for sanction, Order Number, Case Number if applicable, Ticket Number if applicable, Class Affected, Civil Penalty if applicable, Termination Fee if applicable, Length of Sanction, Clear On clearance date, Reason reason for clearance, Out of State Information if applicable, Rescission if applicable.
Scofflaws: The suspension imposed as a result of failure to answer a summons or pay a fine/surcharge/assessment.
The following fields may appear for Scofflaws: Suspension Date, Reason reason for sanction, Order Number, Ticket Number, Court Name, Clear On clearance date, Reason reason for clearance.
The 'CONVICTIONS/BAIL FORFEITURES' section lists conviction and bail forfeitures in order of violation date.

The following fields may appear for CONVICTIONS/BAIL FORFEITURES: Conviction/Forfeiture violation description, Violation Date, Conviction Date, Location, Penalty if applicable, Points if applicable, Commercial Vehicle, Hazmat, Ticket Number.
The 'VESSEL/SNOWMOBILE' section lists suspensions and convictions for boats and snowmobiles.
The 'Vessel/Snowmobile Privilege Suspensions' section lists boat and snowmobile suspensions in order of effective date.

The following fields may appear for Vessel/Snowmobile Privilege Suspensions: Suspension Effective Date, Reason reason for sanction, Order Number, Ticket Number if applicable, Civil Penalty if applicable, Period length of sanction, Clear On clearance date, Reason reason for clearance.
The 'Vessel/Snowmobile Convictions' section lists boat and snowmobile convictions in order of violation date.
The following fields may appear for Vessel/Snowmobile Convictions: Conviction, Violation Date, Convicted On, Ticket Number if applicable, Location, Penalty if applicable.
The 'ACCIDENTS' section lists accidents in order of accident date.
The following fields will appear for ACCIDENTS: Accident Date, County, Case Number, Accident Type, Accident Reports Filed.
The 'ADDRESS HISTORY' section lists addresses on file in order of effective date.
The following fields will appear for ADDRESS HISTORY: Posted effective date, Type, Address, County, Country.
If you suspect that your DMV abstract contains incorrect information, you should contact the DMV Call Center.
The information about the individual's name, address, DMV ID Number, etc. is found at the top of the driving record, but the word 'Header' is not part of the abstract.
The information about license class/privilege, document status, expiration date, etc. is found at the top of the driving record, but the word 'Summary' is not part of the abstract.
The DMV lists an accident on the records of every driver in the accident.
An accident that appears on a driving record does not assign the fault to that driver.
The DMV does not determine the fault in an accident.
A driving school is a commercial business authorized by DMV's Bureau of Driver Training Programs to provide driving instruction for hire.
A driving school could include behind-the-wheel driving lessons.
DMV issues driving school licenses to those qualified to conduct a driving school business.
The driving school license must be clearly displayed at the place of business.
Upon meeting certain additional requirements, driving schools may also provide the DMV approved 5-Hour Pre-licensing Course to individuals who want to obtain a driver license.
Upon meeting certain additional requirements, driving schools may also teach the basic 30-hour instructor's course, now known as the, for driving school instructors.
A driving school instructor is someone who works for a licensed driving school, teaching customers of the school how to drive motor vehicles safely.
DMV issues an Instructor Certificate MV-524 to driving schools for instructors once they are certified to teach for the school.
The driving school instructor must carry this Instructor Certificate MV-524 at all times while driving instructions are given or when accompanying a driver license applicant to the road test site.
Upon meeting certain additional requirements, a driving school instructor may be certified to teach the DMV approved 5-Hour Pre-licensing Course to individuals who want to obtain a driver license.
A driving school must meet several requirements, which are identified in Commissioner's Regulations Part 76 PDF and Section 394 of the New York State Vehicle and Traffic Law PDF.
A driving school must have an office that is open to the public.
A driving school must have at least 50 square feet of space dedicated to the operation of the driving school business.
A driving school must have driving school license hours of operation when the office is open to the public.
A driving school must state that the applicant must be given a receipt for all payments.
A driving school must have a sign displaying acceptable receipts and contracts.
A driving school must have acceptable record-keeping.
A driving school must have at least one certified driving instructor that has at least 1,000 hours of behind-the-wheel instruction experience.
A driving school must have a DMV-approved classroom either at the business location or off-site.
A driving school must have at least one certified driving school instructor that is approved to teach the Pre-Licensing Course.
All vehicles used for driving instruction or testing by a driving school must be reported to DMV using a List of Driving School Vehicles PDF form MV-527.
Each vehicle used by a driving school for driving instruction or testing must also be equipped with a Student Driver sign, and dual-control brake and rear-view mirrors for the instructor.
All employees of a driving school who are not instructors must be reported to DMV using a Personal History PDF form MV-521.1.
If a driving school instructor is terminated, the driving school must notify DMV using a Driving School Instructor Termination Notice PDF form MV-526.
The owner of a driving school must make sure that all advertisements printed, electronic or otherwise for the school comply with Section 76.21 of the Commissioner's Regulations PDF.
If a business is approved as a driving school, DMV may conduct periodical inspections and audits to make sure the driving school is following the requirements.
A driving school must also follow all of the rules and regulations of the municipality in which the driving school business is operating.
A driving school instructor can only be certified when he/she is employed by a licensed driving school.
A driving school instructor must meet several requirements, which are identified in Section 76.15 of the Commissioner's Regulations PDF.
A driving school instructor must be at least 21 years of age.
A driving school instructor must have a driver's license that has been valid for at least 2 years preceding application in the class of vehicle that the instructor intends to teach in.
A driving school instructor's driver's license must not have been suspended or revoked in the last 2 years.
A driving school instructor must show an acceptable driving record.
A driving school instructor must have a high school or high school equivalency diploma.
A driving school instructor must pass the required tests, which include a vision test, road sign test, written test, and driving school instructor driving test.

Driving school instructors must also complete a course in driver training and traffic safety, approved by the commissioner, consisting of at least 30 hours known as the, before the first renewal of their instructor certificate.
The 30-hour course for driving school instructors is taught by various community colleges and driving schools that have been approved by DMV to provide this course.
A driving school instructor who wants to teach the Pre-licensing Course must also successfully complete a 30-hour Teaching Techniques and Methodology course, which is a college-level course.
A driving school instructor who wants to teach the Pre-licensing Course must also have at least one year experience as a behind-the-wheel certified driving school instructor.
DMV makes driver license and vehicle registration information available for a fee using three methods: contract sales, pay-per-search and over-the-counter.
Anyone who accesses DMV information must comply with the federal Driver's Privacy Protection Act (DPPA).
The DPPA was enacted by Congress after a careful debate about why states should be allowed to share DMV data.
The DPPA prohibits states from disclosing a driver's personal information to anyone who does not have what the DPPA considers a permissible use.
The DPPA defines personal information as an individual's photograph, social security number, driver identification number, name, address, telephone number and medical information.
Information on crashes, driving violations, and driver's status is not considered personal information.
DMV sells social security numbers.
In accordance with the federal DPPA and NY State law, DMV sells registration and vehicle data through an open procurement process every two years.

The successful bidders of the open procurement process cannot use DMV information for any purposes other than those in connection with the issuance of a manufacturer's warranty, safety recall or similar notices important things that keep the public safe.
The data sold by DMV can be used for statistical compilations and analysis, which do not contain any personal, identifying information.
DMV does not permit successful bidders of the open procurement process to use the data for surveys, marketing, or solicitations.
DMV collects approximately $2.2 million per year from contract sales.
To access DMV data for legitimate DPPA purposes, DMV offers a pay-per-search service.
In accordance with NY State law, anyone requesting access to the pay-per-search service must apply to DMV and sign an agreement identifying their permissible use under the DPPA.
Upon verification and approval of their application, a search account is established for the requestor of the pay-per-search service.

The majority of search account holders of the pay-per-search service are insurance companies, who must rate and monitor drivers, and investigate claims, and employers who are required to monitor their employees' driving records.
Each search on the pay-per-search service costs $7 and is logged by DMV.
Search account holders of the pay-per-search service must have a DPPA permissible use for every search performed, and DMV monitors their compliance through an audit program.
DMV collects approximately $58 million per year from pay-per-search sales.

Anyone can visit a State or County DMV office to purchase a driver license record as long as the requestor provides sufficient and specific information that identifies one and only one record, and provides a DPPA permissible use.
Each over-the-counter search at a State or County DMV office is $10.
DMV collects approximately $3.0 million per year from over-the-counter sales.

The DMV information shared with bus companies, employers, insurance companies, researchers, and motor vehicle manufacturers, through each of the three sharing methods, makes our lives safer and more convenient.
If the DMV information were not made available, traffic safety and commerce would be negatively impacted.
School districts and private school bus companies are required to know about their drivers' driving history before they hire them to transport children and other passengers.
Access to DMV information enables school bus companies to make informed decisions about whom to hire.

Once hired, DMV requires bus operators to conduct regular searches of their drivers' records to confirm nothing negative happens during their employment that would impact their ability to safely continue to drive school buses.
The same scenario of requiring access to DMV information applies to businesses transporting hazardous materials.
All of us want to know the driver of a vehicle hauling dangerous materials is qualified to drive, properly trained, and possesses a valid Commercial Driver License (CDL).
NY State laws require hazardous material companies to only hire and employ drivers who are qualified and have valid licenses.
Employers of hazardous material drivers must regularly obtain their employees' license records from DMV.
When you are shopping for automobile insurance online, you expect a rate quote within minutes.
Insurance companies are able to provide immediate rate quotes because they have direct pay-per-search access to DMV information.
Insurance companies check your driving history to issue an immediate rate quote.
If insurance companies could not conduct searches on DMV information, they would require you to purchase your driver record and send it to them before issuing you a quote.

This practice of requiring customers to purchase and send their driver records would make it more difficult for customers to shop for affordable rates, and could increase the potential for fraudulently altered or unreliable driver records.
Purchasing a used car does not automatically register you as an owner of that vehicle with the manufacturer.
Manufacturers rely on DMV's contract sales program to find and notify current owners of vehicles affected by safety recalls.
Recalls do not only jeopardize the safety of the owner/operator of the affected vehicle, they could also affect the safety of every other person sharing the road with that potentially unsafe vehicle.
DMV's information sharing programs are critical to improving public safety and making everyone's life more convenient.
When DMV creates a LENS roster, DMV issues a personal user ID and password to the applicant.
If the applicant's organization has more than one person who may use LENS, DMV will gladly issue additional user IDs.
Every LENS user may have their own personal logon.
Every LENS user should have their own personal logon.
LENS users should not share their logon or password with others.

To get an additional user ID, the applicant should email DMV at [email protected] with all of the following: the applicant's 5-digit LENS roster number, the user's NY State Driver license / non-driver ID number, the user's full name, the business name, the user's business address, the user's business telephone number, the user's business email address.
DMV will then send the user ID to the user's business email address.
DMV will mail the password to the user's personal license / ID mailing address.
The password is the only LENS information that DMV ever sends to a user's personal mailing address.
DMV will not send a password to an office address.

If a LENS user leaves the applicant's organization, the applicant can remove them by completing the following steps: log on to LENS, visit the LENS Main Menu and select Customer Information, select User Profile Maintenance, click Search to list all of the applicant's LENS users, find the departing user and check the corresponding Remove box, click Process.

If a LENS user leaves the applicant's organization and the applicant cannot log in to LENS, the applicant should email DMV at [email protected], identify the user and the applicant's LENS customer number.
DMV will disable the departed user's access to the applicant's LENS roster.
If someone is taking on another user's duties, the applicant should follow the instructions for requesting additional user IDs.
The applicant should not share the former user's ID and password with the new user.
DMV will not provide support to any person who is using another person's user ID.
DMV may revoke shared user IDs upon discovery.
If the license / ID is from another state, the applicant should send: state, name, address, ID number and expiration date.
The death of a family member can be a busy and difficult time.
When someone dies, they often leave outstanding issues that need to be resolved.
On this page, you will find information that will help you take care of any issues with the deceased individual's driver's license and vehicle registration and title.

If your loved one has passed away, please mail a copy of the death certificate and a photocopy of their license or ID if you have it to the DMV License Production Bureau at P.O. Box 2688 ESP Albany, NY 12220-0668.
This will prevent further mailings or identity theft.
It may be possible to request a refund of the deceased individual's registration fee.
The DMV will issue the refund to the name of the estate.
To request a refund, surrender the vehicle plates at a DMV office and request a transfer receipt, not a refund receipt.

Have the executor of the deceased's estate send these items to the address listed on the request for refund: a completed and signed Request for Refund PDF MV-215, with 'deceased' written on the form, a photocopy of the death certificate, the transfer receipt.
If the estate of the registrant is settled, call the DMV Revenue Accounting Unit at 518-474-0902.
Use the checklist to help you transfer the ownership when the vehicle owner is deceased PDF MV-843.
The DMV has more information on how to transfer ownership of a vehicle if someone is deceased.
The Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) has amended commercial driver license standards.
This regulation is referred to as the 'CDL Permit Rule'.
The regulation mandated compliance by July 8, 2015.
The New York State DMV implemented the rules in phases, from April through July of 2015.
The New York State DMV refers to the Commercial Learner Permit as 'CLP'.
The New York State DMV refers to the Commercial Driver License as 'CDL'.
When you schedule or update a CDL Skills Test road test appointment, you will not be able to schedule an appointment within the first 14 days from the issuance of the CLP.
The CDL Permit Rule broadens the criteria used during CLP and CDL license applications to check for open suspensions and revocations in other states.
New York State will reject any application where a driver has any open suspension or revocation in any state.
The New York State DMV will send CLP holders a notification if their medical certification status becomes 'Not Certified'.
Once the New York State DMV sends the notification, it will cancel the CLP if the CLP holder does not re-certify within 55 days.
The New York State DMV can send employers a notification of these status changes if they subscribe to the NY State License Event Notification Service (LENS).
The New York State DMV will send passenger carriers enrolled in the 19-A system notifications of CLP cancellation events.

New CDL restrictions defined below by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) may affect CLP holders when taking a Skills Test in a vehicle without full airbrakes and/or a manual transmission: E - No Manual Transmission Equipped CMV, L - No Airbrake Equipped CMV, Z - No Full Airbrake Equipped CMV restrictions.
If the vehicle used for your skills test has an automatic transmission, and this is your first road test in a commercial motor vehicle (CMV), you will be given an E restriction.
If the vehicle used for your skills test has no form of airbrakes, and this is your first road test in a CMV, you will be given an L restriction.
If you have a CDL with an L restriction and you test in a vehicle with air over hydraulic brakes, you will be upgraded from an L to a Z restriction.
CLPs will no longer be issued with the Double/Triple Trailer T endorsement.
The T endorsement can be issued only to a driver holding a CDL.
CLPs issued with a Passenger P or School Bus S endorsement will automatically get a new federally mandated 'No Passengers in CMV Bus' P restriction.
CLPs issued with a Tank Vehicles N endorsement will automatically get a federally mandated 'No Cargo in CMV Tank Vehicle' X restriction.
The P and X restrictions are issued for the CLP only.
The CDL that is issued after all required tests have been passed will not have the P or X restrictions.
The CDL Permit Rule added 5 new restrictions, which required New York State to change the letter assigned to existing restrictions.
These restriction changes go into effect June 4, 2015.
The New York State DMV will send drivers a new CLP and/or CDL document with these changes printed on them after their next CLP or CDL application.
All CLP and CDL transactions, with the exception of replacements (duplicates), will require proof of legal presence in the United States.
Drivers who can prove U.S. citizenship or lawful permanent residency will only need to provide this proof on or after June 18, 2015.
A record of this verification will be retained on the driver's record.
Drivers with temporary visitor status will need to provide proof of legal presence in the U.S. with every CLP and CDL transaction, except for replacements.
Because the federal regulations require submission of additional proofs in person, drivers cannot renew their CLP and/or CDL by mail.
CLP and CDL documents for drivers who are U.S. citizens or lawful permanent residents will have the legend 'NON-DOMICILED' printed on documents issued on or after June 18, 2015.
The legend 'TEMPORARY VISITOR' and the expiration date of their legal status documentation will continue to be displayed on the CLP and/or CDL document for temporary visitors.
For all CLP and CDL transactions, with the exception of replacements, the New York State DMV will require proof of New York State residence.
Proof of residence is required every time for all drivers.
The DMV Document Guide lists all acceptable legal presence and New York State residence proof documents.
You must provide the original documents, not photocopies, for both legal presence and New York State residence requirements.
CLP documents will have the warning 'VALID ONLY WHEN ACCOMPANIED BY A NYS LICENSE' printed on them.
Interim non-photo licenses and permits will only be valid for 60 days from the date they are issued.
New York State is now required to apply federally mandated commercial suspensions and revocations to CLP holders.

Federally mandated commercial suspensions and revocations that affect a driver's commercial privilege will now run consecutive (one to follow the other) with any other open commercial suspension or revocation on record.

New federally mandated one year commercial revocations will be issued for drivers that are found guilty, or convicted of, falsifying, misrepresenting, or fraud in connection with an application for a CLP/CDL, self-certification, driving type, or Medical Examiner's Certificate.
CLPs will be valid for only 180 days with one renewal for an additional 180 days, after which the holder will have to apply for a new CLP, including retaking any required knowledge tests.
New York State will void and return an applicant's current CLP or CDL document when issuing a new CLP/CDL document.

Section 140 of the New York State Transportation Law is amended to provide that no employer will allow an employee to operate a commercial motor vehicle during any period in which the operator does not have a valid CLP or CDL, does not have a CLP or CDL with the proper class or endorsement, violates any restriction on the CLP or CDL, has a suspended, revoked, or disqualified CLP or CDL, or has more than one CLP or CDL.
You can find the 'CDL Permit Rule' in its entirety in 49 CFR Parts 383, 384, and 385 and as posted on the Federal Register (Vol. 76, No. 89 / Monday, May 9, 2011 / Rules and Regulations).
The DMV License Event Notification Service (LENS) is a resource.
The New York State Vehicle and Traffic Law is a resource.
The Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) is a resource.
The DMV regulates all repair shops in New York State.
The DMV regulates all inspection stations in New York State.
The DMV regulates all dealers in New York State.
The DMV regulates all junk vendors in New York State.
The DMV regulates all salvage vendors in New York State.
The DMV regulates other automotive related businesses in New York State.
To file a complaint against a DMV regulated automotive business, the complainant must first attempt to resolve the issue with the management of the business.
The complainant must keep a written record of all contacts with the management of the DMV regulated automotive business in addition to details about the inspection, repair, or sale.
Copies of work orders and invoices are proof of the complainant's attempts to resolve the problem with the DMV regulated automotive business.

If a satisfactory resolution is not reached and the complainant wishes to file a complaint, the complainant must submit a Vehicle Safety Complaint Report PDF VS-35 along with any supporting documents to the DMV Consumer & Facilities Services Complaint Unit.

To submit the Vehicle Safety Complaint Report PDF VS-35 electronically, the complainant must download the complaint report to their personal device and attach and email the completed report as well as any supporting documents to [email protected]
The DMV staff will communicate with the complainant through email regarding the complaint against the DMV regulated automotive business.

The complainant can also submit the Vehicle Safety Complaint Report PDF VS-35 and supporting documents by mail to the DMV Consumer & Facilities Services Complaint Unit at the address: Bureau of Consumer & Facility Services, Department of Motor Vehicles, P.O. Box 2700-ESP, Albany, NY 12220-0700.
The complainant can also submit the Vehicle Safety Complaint Report PDF VS-35 and supporting documents by fax to the DMV Consumer & Facilities Services Complaint Unit at the fax number: 518-486-4102.
The complainant can also contact the DMV Consumer & Facilities Services Complaint Unit by phone at 1-518-474-8943 between 8:30 a.m. and 4:15 p.m., Monday - Friday.
The DMV staff will not investigate a complaint against a DMV regulated automotive business until a completed VS-35 Complaint Report has been received.
The DMV does not investigate complaints against DMV regulated automotive businesses that have been filed anonymously.
There is a 90-day limit on reporting incidents related to a NYS Repair Shop to the DMV.
The DMV cannot accept complaints against Repair Shops beyond the 90-day limit or 3,000 miles, whichever comes first.
The DMV cannot resolve disputes over the terms of manufacturer or third party warranties or guarantees.
If the complainant feels they have a NYS Lemon Law complaint, they should see Lemon Law Complaints.
Once a complaint against a DMV regulated automotive business has been filed, a Consumer Services Representative (CSR) from the DMV will be assigned to handle the complaint.

If the Consumer Services Representative (CSR) is unable to resolve the complaint against the DMV regulated automotive business, the case will be sent to an Automotive Facilities Inspector for a formal investigation and possibly a hearing.
The process of resolving a complaint against a DMV regulated automotive business could take several weeks to several months, depending on the complaint.
Other related automotive businesses that the DMV regulates include vehicle dismantlers, salvage pools, mobile car crushers and itinerant vehicle collectors.
The DMV cannot take action against a DMV regulated automotive business unless the DMV can find adequate evidence to substantiate the claim against the business.
If the DMV regulated automotive business does not have a current registration, there are limitations on any fines and penalties that may be recovered from the business.

For additional information on the investigation and hearing process for complaints against DMV regulated automotive businesses, the complainant should see the DMV's 'What to Expect if You File a Complaint Against a DMV Regulated Business'.

If the complainant has questions regarding a complaint they placed against a DMV regulated automotive business or the complaint process in general, they should contact the DMV Complaint Unit at 1-518-474-8943.
The office hours for the DMV Complaint Unit are Monday - Friday, 8:15am - 4:15pm.
Personalized plates are standard series plates that have a combination of numbers and letters that you select, for an additional fee in addition to your regular vehicle registration fee.
For passenger and commercial plates, the initial cost for personalized plates is $60.00 and the annual fee is $31.25.
For motorcycle plates, the initial cost for personalized plates is $35.00 and the annual fee is $18.75.
You can use personalized plates on passenger vehicles, commercial vehicles, motorcycles and trailers.
Your requested personalized plate combination is subject to review by the DMV.
The DMV is not required to issue your requested personalized plate combination.
The maximum number of characters you can use for a personalized plate depends on the plate type you are registering.
You can have up to eight characters on a standard series personalized plate.
You can have up to six characters on a personalized plate for a motorcycle.
You can have up to six characters on a picture personalized plate.
The state image on some personalized plates counts as a character.
Personalized plates that give the appearance of an official plate or the configuration of special registration classes are restricted.
Personalized plate combinations that are considered obscene, derogatory or offensive are restricted.
Personalized plate combinations that do not have one letter are restricted.
Personalized plate combinations that consist of six numbers followed by one letter are restricted.
The use of the letter 'O' between two numbers to make what appears to be a number is restricted for personalized plates.
The use of the letter 'I' as the first or last characters on a personalized plate when the other characters are all numbers is restricted.
The use of the number zero '0' between two letters to form a word is restricted for personalized plates.
The use of the number zero '0' and the letter 'O' to form a word or number is restricted for personalized plates.
Picture plates can be personalized for an additional fee in addition to your picture plate and regular registration fee.
The annual fee for a personalized picture plate is in addition to your vehicle registration renewal fee and will be paid when you renew your registration.
A registration renewal for two years will include two annual fees for a personalized picture plate.
A character for personalized plates is a letter A - Z, number 0 - 9 or space.
Each space counts as one character for personalized plates.
Personalized plate combinations that include 'POLICE' or 'NYS' are not allowed.
Personalized plate combinations such as '2O3', '2OO3', or 'JAN2OO3' are not allowed.
Personalized plate combinations such as 'I45678' or '45678I' are not allowed.
Personalized plate combinations such as 'P00L' and 'P0LE' are not allowed.
Personalized plate combinations such as 'PO0L' or '2O03' are not allowed.
A non-exempt diesel-powered motor vehicle may be subject to either the OBDII emissions inspection or the diesel emissions inspection.
Additional information about these inspections may be found on the table below.

All non-exempt diesel-powered vehicles registered in the NYMA or Diesel Emissions Metropolitan Area (DEMA) (some registrations may or may not show they are within DEMA), with a maximum gross weight (MGW) (as indicated on the vehicle registration certificate) over 8,500 pounds, must get an annual diesel emissions inspection.
The diesel emissions inspection must occur at the same time as the annual safety inspection.
The DEMA includes the five boroughs of New York City, and Nassau County, Suffolk County, Rockland County, and Westchester County.
The model year does not exempt a vehicle from the inspection.
Section 79.2 of the inspection regulations provides information about vehicles that are exempt.

All diesel-powered vehicles registered outside of the Diesel Emissions Metropolitan Area (DEMA), with a maximum gross weight (MGW) over 8,500 pounds, do not require an annual diesel emissions inspection, but may be subject to a random roadside diesel emissions inspection.

All model year 1997 or newer non-exempt diesel-powered vehicles, registered anywhere in New York State, with a gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR) less than 8,501 pounds, must get an annual OBDII emissions inspection, and are not subject to the diesel emissions inspection.

All model year 1996 or older diesel-powered vehicles, registered anywhere in New York State, with a gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR) less than 8,501 pounds, are not subject to the OBDII emissions inspection, the low-enhanced emissions inspection, or the diesel emissions inspection.
The Diesel Opacity Emissions inspection is not required in other areas of NY State, or for vehicles registered out-of-state.

However, the NY State Department of Environmental Conservation, the NY State Department of Transportation, or the NY State Police can test any diesel-powered vehicle that has a MGW of more than 8,500 lbs. at any roadside inspection site that is located on any New York State highway.
If a vehicle fails the roadside inspection, a traffic ticket can be issued.

When an existing diesel emissions inspection certificate expires while the vehicle is outside the DEMA, that resident may apply to the Department of Motor Vehicles for a 'Temporary Certificate Emissions Waiver' (VS-1078).
Temporary Certificate Emissions Waiver is only available at DMV Issuing Offices.

The temporary emissions waiver certificate when displayed on the vehicle along with a valid New York Safety Inspection Certificate will allow the vehicle to be operated while the vehicle is outside the DEMA.
The Temporary Certificate of Emissions Waiver will be valid for ten (10) days from the date that the vehicle returns to the NYMA.
Regulation 79.1 of the NY State DMV Motor Vehicle Inspection Regulations (pdf CR-79) provides information about the Temporary Certificate of Emissions Waiver.
The diesel emissions inspection occurs at the time of the annual safety inspection and is conducted at a diesel emissions inspection station.
A non-diesel emissions inspection station in the New York Metropolitan Area (NYMA) can conduct other inspections but cannot inspect vehicles that are subject to the diesel emissions inspection.
The Inspection Groups and Fee Chart (pdf VS-77) provides information about the fee for the diesel emissions inspection.
To become a diesel emissions inspection station, the inspection station must purchase a DMV-approved smokemeter from a vendor.
A station can conduct an emissions inspection on a diesel-powered vehicle if the station is licensed to conduct a safety inspection for that specific type of vehicle.

To prove that an approved smokemeter was purchased, the station must send a photocopy of the invoice to the NYS DMV Bureau of Consumer & Facility Services Application Unit at P.O. Box 2700, Albany, NY 12220-0700.
For questions about becoming a diesel emissions inspection station, call 1-518-474-0919.
GVWR stands for gross vehicle weight rating.
MGW stands for maximum gross weight.
NYMA stands for New York Metropolitan Area.
Leandra's Law was signed into law on November 18, 2009.
Leandra's Law was signed into law in honor of Leandra Rosado.
Leandra Rosado was an 11-year old killed while she rode in a vehicle with the intoxicated mother of one of her friends.
In response to the tragedy of Leandra Rosado's death, the NY State Legislature made several changes to the Vehicle and Traffic Law VTL.
Leandra's Law strengthened the penalties against motorists who drink and drive.
Leandra's Law requires that any person sentenced for Driving While Intoxicated on or after August 15, 2010 must have an ignition interlock device installed on any vehicle they own or operate.
The driver will have an "ignition interlock" restriction added to their driver license under Leandra's Law.
Leandra's Law established a new Class E Felony.
Under Leandra's Law, no person shall operate a motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol or drugs while a child who is 15 years of age or younger is a passenger in the vehicle.
A court must sentence a person convicted under Leandra's Law to a period of probation or to a conditional discharge.
A court must require the installation and use of an ignition interlock device in any motor vehicle owned or operated by a person convicted under Leandra's Law.
The ignition interlock device must remain in the vehicle for at least 12 months under Leandra's Law, unless otherwise permitted by the court.
A court that sentences a person for a conviction on or after August 15, 2010 must impose a conditional discharge or probation under Leandra's Law.
A condition of the sentence under Leandra's Law must be the installation and use of an ignition interlock device in any motor vehicle the person owns or operates.
An ignition interlock device connects to a motor vehicle ignition system and measures the alcohol content in the breath of the operator.
The ignition interlock device prevents the vehicle from being started until the motorist provides an acceptable breath sample.
If ignition interlock is ordered by a court, the system must be installed on each vehicle the motorist owns or operates.
The ignition interlock device must remain installed for at least six months.
The ignition interlock restriction will be added to the driver license record even if the license is revoked.
The ignition interlock restriction will appear on the back of the driver license document as "interlock device".
Courts and probation departments will direct convicted motorists to vendors for ignition interlock installation.
The NY State Division of Criminal Justice Services website provides details on ignition interlock device vendors and information from the manufacturers of the device.

To remove the ignition interlock restriction from a driver license, the ignition interlock monitor must give a form that states that the person is no longer required to install and maintain the ignition interlock device in motor vehicles they own or operate.

To remove the ignition interlock restriction from a driver license, the person must take the form from the ignition interlock monitor to a local DMV office and apply for a new document without the restriction.
Benefits Planner: Survivors is a section about planning for your survivors.
Social Security can help your family if you have earned enough Social Security credits through your work.
You can earn up to four credits each year.
In 2019, you earn one credit for each $1,360 of wages or self-employment income.
When you have earned $5,440, you have earned your four credits for the year.
The number of credits needed to provide benefits for your survivors depends on your age when you die.
No one needs more than 40 credits (10 years of work) to be eligible for any Social Security benefit.
The younger a person is, the fewer credits they must have for family members to receive survivors benefits.
Benefits can be paid to your children and your spouse who is caring for the children even if you don't have the required number of credits.
They can get benefits if you have credit for one and one-half years of work (6 credits) in the three years just before your death.
There are about five million widows and widowers receiving monthly Social Security benefits based on their deceased spouse's earnings record.
For many of those survivors, particularly aged women, those benefits are keeping them out of poverty.
Widows and widowers can receive: reduced benefits as early as age 60 or full benefits at full retirement age or older.
Widows and widowers can receive benefits as early as age 50 if they're disabled AND their disability started before or within seven years of your death.
Widows and widowers can receive benefits at any age, if they have not remarried, and if they take care of your child who is under age 16 or disabled and receives benefits on your record.

If applying for disability benefits on a deceased worker's record, they can speed up the application process if they complete an Adult Disability Report and have it available at the time of their appointment.
Social Security uses the same definition of disability for widows and widowers as it does for workers.
If you have a surviving divorced spouse, they could get the same benefits as your widow or widower provided that your marriage lasted 10 years or more.
Benefits paid to a surviving divorced spouse won't affect the benefit amounts your other survivors will receive based on your earnings record.
If your former spouse is caring for your child who is under age 16 or disabled and gets benefits on your record, they will not have to meet the length-of-marriage rule.
The child must be your natural or legally adopted child.
Your unmarried children who are under 18 (up to age 19 if attending elementary or secondary school full time) can be eligible to receive Social Security benefits when you die.
Your child can get benefits at any age if they were disabled before age 22 and remain disabled.
Besides your natural children, your stepchildren, grandchildren, step grandchildren or adopted children may receive benefits under certain circumstances.
For further information on children receiving benefits, view the publication.

You must have been providing at least half of your parent's support and your parent must not be eligible to receive a retirement benefit that is higher than the benefit Social Security could pay on your record.
Generally, your parent also must not have married after your death; however, there are some exceptions.
In addition to your natural parent, your stepparent or adoptive parent may receive benefits if they became your parent before you were age 16.
How much your family could receive in benefits depends on your average lifetime earnings.
The higher your earnings were, the higher their benefits would be.
Social Security calculates a basic amount as if you had reached full retirement age at the time you die.
Examples of monthly benefit payments: Widow or widower, full retirement age or older - 100 percent of your benefit amount.
Examples of monthly benefit payments: Widow or widower, age 60 to full retirement age - 71 to 99 percent of your basic amount.
Examples of monthly benefit payments: Disabled widow or widower, age 50 through 59 - 71 percent.
Examples of monthly benefit payments: Widow or widower, any age, caring for a child under age 16 - 75 percent.
Examples of monthly benefit payments: A child under age 18 (19 if still in elementary or secondary school or disabled) - 75 percent.
Examples of monthly benefit payments: Your dependent parent, age 62 or older - One surviving parent - 82 percent.
Examples of monthly benefit payments: Your dependent parent, age 62 or older - Two surviving parents - 75 percent to each parent.
Percentages for a surviving divorced spouse would be the same as above.
There may also be a special lump-sum death payment.
There's a limit to the amount that family members can receive each month.
The limit varies, but it is generally equal to between 150 and 180 percent of the basic benefit rate.
If the sum of the benefits payable to family members is greater than this limit, the benefits will be reduced proportionately.
Any benefits paid to a surviving divorced spouse based on disability or age won't count toward this maximum amount.
You can get an estimate of the benefits your family could receive if you died right now by using the online tool or Benefit Calculators.
There are limits on how much survivors may earn while they receive benefits.
Benefits for a widow, widower, or surviving divorced spouse may be affected by several additional factors.
If your widow, widower, or surviving divorced spouse remarries before they reach age 60 (age 50 if disabled), they cannot receive benefits as a surviving spouse while they're married.
If your widow, widower, or surviving divorced spouse remarries after they reach age 60 (age 50 if disabled), they will continue to qualify for benefits on your Social Security record.
However, if their current spouse is a Social Security beneficiary, they may want to apply for spouse's benefits on their record.
If that amount is more than the widow's or widower's benefit on your record, they will receive a combination of benefits that equals the higher amount.
If your widow, widower, or surviving divorced spouse receives benefits on your record, they can switch to their own retirement benefit as early as age 62.
This assumes they're eligible for retirement benefits and their retirement rate is higher than their rate as a widow, widower, or surviving divorced spouse.
In many cases, a widow or widower can begin receiving one benefit at a reduced rate and then, at full retirement age, switch to the other benefit at an unreduced rate.

If your widow, widower, or surviving divorced spouse will also receive a pension based on work not covered by Social Security, such as government or foreign work, their Social Security benefits as a survivor may be affected.

You should apply for disability benefits as soon as you become disabled.
If you are ready to apply now, you can: Complete your application online.
If you are ready to apply now, you can: Call the Social Security Administration's toll-free telephone number.
If you are deaf or hard of hearing, you can call the Social Security Administration at TTY Call.
If you are deaf or hard of hearing, you can visit your local Social Security office.
If you wish to help another person apply for disability benefits, please read the relevant information.
The kind of information you should have when applying for disability benefits includes: Your Social Security number and proof of your age.

The kind of information you should have when applying for disability benefits includes: Names, addresses, and phone numbers of doctors, caseworkers, hospitals, and clinics that took care of you and the dates of your visits.
The kind of information you should have when applying for disability benefits includes: Names and dosages of all the medications you are taking.

The kind of information you should have when applying for disability benefits includes: Medical records from your doctors, therapists, hospitals, clinics, and caseworkers, that you already have in your possession.
The kind of information you should have when applying for disability benefits includes: Laboratory and test results.
The kind of information you should have when applying for disability benefits includes: A summary of where you worked and the kind of work you did.
The kind of information you should have when applying for disability benefits includes: Your most recent W-2 form or, if you were self-employed, a copy of your federal tax return.
The kind of information you should have when applying for disability benefits includes: Social Security numbers and proof of age for each family member who may qualify for benefits.
The kind of information you should have when applying for disability benefits includes: Proof of marriage, if your spouse is applying for benefits, as well as dates of prior marriages, if applicable.
If you don't have all the documents you need, don't delay filing for disability benefits. The Social Security Administration will help you get the information you need.
The Social Security Administration's Disability Starter Kit will help you get ready for your disability interview or online application.
Disability Starter Kits are available in English or Spanish for adults and children under age 18.
The online Application for Benefits includes links to information that will help you complete the form.
If the Social Security Administration decides you do not meet the qualifications for disability benefits, you have the right to ask them to look at your application again.
The notice you receive from the Social Security Administration that says you don't qualify will explain how to appeal their decision and the time period in which you must make the request.
If the Social Security Administration decides you don't qualify because you are not disabled under their rules, you can appeal their decision online.
The online disability report will ask you for updated information about your medical condition and any treatment, tests, or doctor visits since the Social Security Administration made their decision.
For non-medical reasons, you can appeal the Social Security Administration's decision online.
You also may call the Social Security Administration's toll-free number at 1-800-772-1213 to request an appeal.
People who are deaf or hard of hearing can call the Social Security Administration's toll-free TTY number, 1-800-325-0778, to request an appeal.
People who don't have enough work credits to be eligible for Social Security Disability benefits may possibly qualify for Supplemental Security Income (SSI) if they have limited income and resources.
For more information about Supplemental Security Income (SSI), please read "Your income and resources" on page 5 of the Social Security Administration's Supplemental Security Income (SSI) booklet.

If you are ready to apply now, you can: Complete your application online.
If you are ready to apply now, you can: Call the Social Security Administration's toll-free telephone number.
If you are deaf or hard of hearing, you can call the Social Security Administration at TTY number.
If you are deaf or hard of hearing, you can visit your local Social Security office.
If you wish to help another person apply for disability benefits, you should read the provided information.
To apply for disability benefits, you need to provide information about yourself, including: Your Social Security number and proof of your age.

To apply for disability benefits, you need to provide information about family members, including: Social Security numbers and proof of age for each family member who may qualify for benefits.

If you don't have all the documents you need, don't delay filing for disability benefits. The Social Security Administration will help you get the information you need.
