For more information about Supplemental Security Income (SSI), you should read the 'Your income and resources' section on page 5 of the Social Security Administration's Supplemental Security Income (SSI) booklet.
If you legally change your name because of marriage, divorce, court order, or any other reason, you need to tell Social Security so that you can get a corrected card.
If you are working, you also need to tell your employer.

If you do not tell Social Security when your name changes, it may: Prevent your wages from being posted correctly to your Social Security record, which may lower the amount of your future Social Security benefits.
If you do not tell Social Security when your name changes, it may: Cause delays when you file your taxes.
You must present original documents or copies certified by the agency that issued them.
Social Security cannot accept photocopies or notarized copies.
All documents must be current not expired.
Social Security cannot accept a receipt showing you applied for the document.
Social Security may use one document for two purposes.
For example, Social Security may use your U.S. passport as proof of both citizenship and identity.
If you have not already established your U.S. citizenship with Social Security, Social Security needs to see proof of U.S. citizenship.
Social Security can accept only certain documents as proof of U.S. citizenship.

The documents that Social Security can accept as proof of U.S. citizenship include: U.S. passport, Certificate of Naturalization N-550/N-570, Certificate of Citizenship N-560/N-561, Certificate of Report of Birth DS-1350, Consular Report of Birth Abroad FS-240, CRBA.
Social Security requires this documentation only if you have NOT already established U.S. citizenship with Social Security.
If you need to change your name on your Social Security card, you must show Social Security proof of your legal name change.

The documents that Social Security may accept to prove a legal name change include: Marriage document, Divorce decree, Certificate of Naturalization showing the new name, Court order approving the name change.

If the document you provide as evidence of a legal name change does not give Social Security enough information to identify you in Social Security's records or if you changed your name more than two years ago (four years ago if you are under 18 years of age), you must show Social Security an identity document in your prior name as shown in Social Security's records.
Social Security will accept an identity document in your old name that has expired.

If you do not have an identity document in your prior name, Social Security may accept an unexpired identity document in your new name as long as Social Security can properly establish your identity in Social Security's records.
Social Security can accept only certain documents as proof of identity.
As proof of identity, Social Security must see: U.S. driver's license, State-issued non-driver identification card, U.S. passport.
If you do not have one of these specific documents or you cannot get a replacement for one of them within 10 days, Social Security will ask to see other documents.

Any documents submitted, including the following, must be current not expired and show your name, identifying information (date of birth or age) and preferably a recent photograph: Employee identification card, School identification card, Health insurance card (not a Medicare card), U.S. military identification card.
Your new Social Security card will have the same number as your previous card, but will show your new name.
Social Security will mail your card as soon as Social Security has all of your information and has verified your documents.

Si cambia su nombre, se convierte en ciudadano estadounidense o su estado migratorio o autorización de trabajo ha cambiado, debe informar al Seguro Social para que podamos actualizar nuestros registros y, cuando sea necesario, emitir una nueva tarjeta.
Cuando solicite un reemplazo o una tarjeta de Seguro Social corregida, debe mostrarnos prueba de su identidad, estado migratorio y autorización de trabajo.
Si necesita cambiar o corregir cualquier información en su tarjeta de Seguro Social, necesita mostrarnos ciertos documentos sobre el cambio.
El Seguro Social solo puede aceptar ciertos documentos.
El Seguro Social le pedirá ver sus documentos de inmigración actuales de los Estados Unidos.

Los documentos aceptables incluyen: Tarjeta de Residente Permanente I-551, Registro de Llegada/Salida I-94 con pasaporte extranjero vigente o sello de admisión en el pasaporte extranjero vigente, o Documento de Autorización de Empleo I-766 (EAD), permiso de trabajo del Departamento de Seguridad Nacional (DHS).
Debe presentar documentos originales o copias certificadas por la agencia que los emitió.
No se pueden aceptar fotocopias o copias notariadas.
Todos los documentos deben estar vigentes, no vencidos.
No se puede aceptar un recibo que muestre que solicitó el documento.
Se puede usar un documento para dos propósitos.
Por ejemplo, se puede usar su pasaporte estadounidense como prueba de ciudadanía e identidad.
Si cambia legalmente su nombre debido a matrimonio, divorcio, orden judicial o cualquier otra razón, debe informar al Seguro Social.
Si está trabajando, también debe informar a su empleador.

Si no informa cuando cambia su nombre, puede: Evitar que sus salarios se registren correctamente en su registro del Seguro Social, lo que puede reducir el monto de sus futuros beneficios del Seguro Social. Causar retrasos cuando presente sus impuestos.
Debe mostrarnos prueba de su cambio legal de nombre.
Los documentos que el Seguro Social puede aceptar para probar un cambio legal de nombre incluyen: Documento de matrimonio, sentencia de divorcio, orden judicial que aprueba el cambio de nombre.

Si el documento que proporciona como evidencia de un cambio legal de nombre no nos brinda suficiente información para identificarlo en nuestros registros o si cambió su nombre hace más de dos años (cuatro años si es menor de 18 años), debe mostrarnos un documento de identidad con su nombre anterior como se muestra en nuestros registros.
Se aceptará un documento de identidad con su nombre anterior que haya vencido.

Si no tiene un documento de identidad con su nombre anterior, podemos aceptar un documento de identidad vigente con su nuevo nombre, siempre que podamos establecer correctamente su identidad en nuestros registros.
Si se le asignó un número de Seguro Social para fines no laborales, se aplican reglas especiales.
Si el DHS no lo autorizó a trabajar, cambiaremos su nombre en nuestros registros, pero no podemos emitirle una tarjeta corregida.
Si no tiene permiso para trabajar, pero necesita una tarjeta de Seguro Social por otras razones, consulte 'Si no tiene permiso para trabajar' para obtener más información.
Recuerde que no puede usar un número de Seguro Social asignado para fines no laborales para trabajar.
Si lo usa para trabajar, informaremos al DHS.
Si se le emite una nueva tarjeta, tendrá el mismo número que su tarjeta anterior, pero mostrará su nuevo nombre.
Se le enviará su tarjeta por correo tan pronto como tengamos toda su información y hayamos verificado sus documentos de inmigración.

Para probar su estado migratorio en los Estados Unidos, debe mostrarnos su documento de inmigración actual de los Estados Unidos, como: Formulario I-551 Tarjeta de Residente Permanente Legal, Visa de Inmigrante Legible por Máquina, I-766 Documento de Autorización de Empleo (EAD), permiso de trabajo, o Registro de Llegada/Salida I-94 o sello de admisión en el pasaporte extranjero vigente.
Si es un estudiante F-1 o M-1, también debe mostrarnos su Certificado de Elegibilidad para Estatus de Estudiante No Inmigrante I-20.
Si es un visitante de intercambio J-1 o J-2, debe mostrarnos su Certificado de Elegibilidad para Estatus de Visitante de Intercambio DS-2019.
En general, solo los no ciudadanos que tienen permiso del DHS para trabajar pueden solicitar un número de Seguro Social.
Si es un trabajador extranjero, solo necesitamos ver su Registro de Llegada/Salida I-94 o sello de admisión en su pasaporte extranjero vigente que muestre una clase de admisión que permita trabajar.
Es posible que deba mostrar su Documento de Autorización de Empleo I-766 (EAD), permiso de trabajo del DHS.

Si está legalmente presente en los Estados Unidos y planea solicitar autorización de trabajo, puede solicitar autorización de trabajo del Departamento de Seguridad Nacional (DHS), Servicios de Ciudadanía e Inmigración de los Estados Unidos (USCIS) y solicitar una tarjeta de Seguro Social de la Administración del Seguro Social al mismo tiempo.
Para obtener más información sobre este proceso, lea 'Solicite su número de Seguro Social mientras solicita su permiso de trabajo'.
Si presenta evidencia de un estado legal autorizado para trabajar junto con evidencia de su cambio de nombre, podemos emitirle una tarjeta corregida con su nuevo nombre.

Si es un estudiante F-1 y es elegible para trabajar en el campus, debe proporcionar una carta de su funcionario escolar designado que: Lo identifique, confirme su estado escolar actual e identifique a su empleador y el tipo de trabajo que está o estará haciendo.
También necesitamos ver evidencia de ese empleo, como un recibo de pago reciente o una carta de su empleador.
Su supervisor debe firmar y fechar la carta.
La carta debe describir: Su trabajo, la fecha de inicio de su empleo, la cantidad de horas que está o estará trabajando y el nombre y número de teléfono de su supervisor.

Si es un estudiante F-1 autorizado para trabajar en capacitación práctica curricular, debe proporcionarnos su Formulario I-20 con la página de empleo completada y firmada por su funcionario escolar designado.
Si es un estudiante F-1 y tiene un permiso de trabajo I-766 del DHS, debe presentarlo.
Si es un estudiante J-1, pasante o visitante internacional, debe proporcionar una carta de su patrocinador.
La carta debe estar en papel membretado del patrocinador con una firma original que autorice su empleo.
Los no ciudadanos admitidos legalmente pueden obtener muchos beneficios y servicios sin un número de Seguro Social.

No necesita un número para hacer negocios con un banco, registrarse en la escuela, presentar exámenes educativos, obtener un seguro de salud privado, solicitar programas de almuerzo escolar o solicitar vivienda subsidiada.
No puede obtener un número de Seguro Social con el único propósito de obtener una licencia de conducir.
Si aún no ha establecido su ciudadanía estadounidense con nosotros, necesitamos ver prueba de su ciudadanía estadounidense.
Solo podemos aceptar ciertos documentos como prueba de ciudadanía estadounidense.

Estos incluyen: Pasaporte estadounidense, Certificado de Naturalización N-550/N-570, Certificado de Ciudadanía N-560/N-561, Certificado de Reporte de Nacimiento DS-1350, Reporte Consular de Nacimiento en el Extranjero FS-240 (CRBA).
Solo requerimos documentación de ciudadanía si es ciudadano estadounidense y aún NO ha establecido su ciudadanía estadounidense con nosotros.
If you legally change your name because of marriage, divorce, court order or any other reason, you need to tell Social Security so that you can get a corrected card.
If you are working, also tell your employer.

If you do not tell Social Security when your name changes, it may prevent your wages from being posted correctly to your Social Security record, which may lower the amount of your future Social Security benefits.
If you do not tell Social Security when your name changes, it may cause delays when you file your taxes.
Social Security cannot accept photocopies or notarized copies.
Social Security cannot accept a receipt showing you applied for the document.
All documents must be current not expired.
Social Security may use one document for two purposes.
For example, Social Security may use your U.S. passport as proof of both citizenship and identity.
If you have not already established your U.S. citizenship with Social Security, Social Security needs to see proof of U.S. citizenship.
Social Security can accept only certain documents as proof of U.S. citizenship.
These documents include a U.S. birth certificate or U.S. passport.
This documentation is only required if you have not already established citizenship with Social Security.
If you need to change your name on your Social Security card, you must show Social Security proof of your legal name change.

Documents Social Security may accept to prove a legal name change include a marriage document, divorce decree, Certificate of Naturalization showing the new name, or court order approving the name change.

If the document you provide as evidence of a legal name change does not give Social Security enough information to identify you in their records or if you changed your name more than two years ago (four years ago if you are under 18 years of age), you must show Social Security an identity document in your prior name as shown in their records.
Social Security will accept an identity document in your old name that has expired.

If you do not have an identity document in your prior name, Social Security may accept an unexpired identity document in your new name, as long as they can properly establish your identity in their records.
Social Security can accept only certain documents as proof of identity.
An acceptable document must be current (not expired) and show your name, identifying information, date of birth or age, and preferably a recent photograph.
For example, as proof of identity Social Security must see your U.S. driver's license, state-issued non-driver identification card, or U.S. passport.
If you do not have one of these specific documents or you cannot get a replacement for one of them within 10 days, Social Security will ask to see other documents.

Any documents submitted, including the following, must be current (not expired) and show your name, identifying information, date of birth or age, and preferably a recent photograph: employee identification card, school identification card, health insurance card (not a Medicare card), or U.S. military identification card.
Your new Social Security card will have the same number as your previous card, but will show your new name.
Social Security will mail your card as soon as they have all of your information and have verified your documents.
Si cambia legalmente el nombre de su hijo debido a una adopción, orden judicial o cualquier otra razón, debe informar al Seguro Social para que su hijo pueda obtener una tarjeta corregida.
Si su hijo está trabajando, también debe informar al empleador de su hijo.

Si no informa al Seguro Social cuando cambia el nombre de su hijo, puede: Retrasar su reembolso de impuestos o el reembolso de su hijo; y Evitar que los salarios de su hijo se registren correctamente en el registro del Seguro Social de su hijo, lo que puede reducir el monto de los futuros beneficios del Seguro Social de su hijo.
Debe presentar documentos originales o copias certificadas por la agencia que los emitió.
El Seguro Social no puede aceptar fotocopias o copias notariadas.
Todos los documentos deben estar vigentes, no vencidos.
El Seguro Social no puede aceptar un recibo que muestre que solicitó el documento.
Si no ha establecido previamente la ciudadanía estadounidense de su hijo con el Seguro Social, necesitan ver prueba de la ciudadanía estadounidense.
El Seguro Social solo puede aceptar ciertos documentos como prueba de la ciudadanía estadounidense.

Estos incluyen: Certificación del Informe de Nacimiento DS-1350; Informe Consular de Nacimiento en el Extranjero FS-240; Pasaporte de los EE. UU.; Certificado de Naturalización N-550/N-570; o Certificado de Ciudadanía N-560/N-561.
Si necesita cambiar el nombre en la tarjeta de Seguro Social de su hijo, debe mostrar prueba del cambio legal de nombre de su hijo.

Los documentos que el Seguro Social puede aceptar para probar el cambio legal de nombre de su hijo incluyen: Decreto final de adopción con el nuevo nombre; Certificado de Naturalización que muestra el nuevo nombre; u Orden judicial que aprueba el cambio de nombre.

Si el documento que proporciona como evidencia del cambio legal de nombre de su hijo no les da suficiente información para identificar a su hijo en sus registros o si cambió el nombre de su hijo hace más de cuatro años, debe mostrarles un documento de identidad con el nombre anterior de su hijo como se muestra en sus registros.
El Seguro Social aceptará un documento de identidad con el nombre anterior de su hijo que haya vencido.

Si no tiene un documento de identidad con el nombre anterior de su hijo, el Seguro Social puede aceptar un documento de identidad vigente con el nuevo nombre de su hijo, siempre que puedan establecer correctamente la identidad de su hijo en sus registros.
El Seguro Social solo puede aceptar ciertos documentos como prueba de la identidad de su hijo.
Un documento aceptable debe mostrar el nombre de su hijo, información de identificación (es decir, edad, fecha de nacimiento o nombres de los padres) y preferiblemente una fotografía reciente.

El Seguro Social generalmente puede aceptar un documento de identidad sin foto si tiene suficiente información para identificar al niño, como el nombre y la edad del niño, la fecha de nacimiento o los nombres de los padres.
El Seguro Social prefiere ver el pasaporte de los EE. UU. de su hijo.

Si ese documento no está disponible, el Seguro Social puede aceptar la tarjeta de identificación no de conducir emitida por el estado de su hijo; Decreto de adopción; Registro médico, clínico u hospitalario; Registro religioso; Registro de la escuela o guardería; o Tarjeta de identificación escolar de su hijo.
El Seguro Social también debe ver prueba de su identidad.
Un documento aceptable debe estar vigente (no vencido) y mostrar su nombre, información de identificación (fecha de nacimiento o edad) y preferiblemente una fotografía reciente.
Por ejemplo, como prueba de identidad, el Seguro Social debe ver su: Licencia de conducir de los EE. UU.; Tarjeta de identificación no de conducir emitida por el estado; o Pasaporte de los EE. UU.
Si no tiene uno de estos documentos específicos o no puede obtener un reemplazo para uno de ellos dentro de los 10 días, el Seguro Social le pedirá que muestre otros documentos.

Cualquier documento presentado, incluyendo los siguientes, debe estar vigente (no vencido) y mostrar su nombre, información de identificación (fecha de nacimiento o edad) y preferiblemente una fotografía reciente: Tarjeta de identificación de empleado; Tarjeta de identificación escolar; Tarjeta de seguro médico (no una tarjeta de Medicare); o Tarjeta de identificación militar de los EE. UU.
La nueva tarjeta de su hijo tendrá el mismo número que la tarjeta anterior de su hijo, pero mostrará un nuevo nombre.
El Seguro Social enviará por correo la tarjeta de su hijo tan pronto como tenga toda la información de su hijo y haya verificado los documentos de su hijo.
Si cambia legalmente el nombre de su hijo debido a una adopción, orden judicial o cualquier otra razón, debe informar a la Seguridad Social.
Si su hijo está trabajando, también debe informar al empleador de su hijo.

Si no informa cuando cambia el nombre de su hijo, puede: Retrasar su reembolso de impuestos o el reembolso de su hijo; y Evitar que los salarios de su hijo se registren correctamente en el registro de la Seguridad Social de su hijo, lo que puede reducir el monto de los futuros beneficios de la Seguridad Social de su hijo.
Debe presentar documentos originales o copias certificadas por la agencia que los emitió.
No se pueden aceptar fotocopias o copias notariadas.
Todos los documentos deben estar vigentes, no vencidos.
No se puede aceptar un recibo que muestre que solicitó el documento.

Para probar el estatus migratorio de su hijo en los EE. UU., debe mostrar el documento de inmigración actual de su hijo en los EE. UU., como: Formulario I-551 Tarjeta de Residente Permanente Legal, Visa de Inmigrante Legible por Máquina; I-766 Documento de Autorización de Empleo, EAD, permiso de trabajo; o I-94 Registro de Llegada/Salida o sello de admisión en el pasaporte extranjero vigente.
Si su hijo es un estudiante F-1 o M-1, debemos ver el Certificado de Elegibilidad I-20 de su hijo para el Estatus de Estudiante No Inmigrante.
Si su hijo es un visitante de intercambio J-1 o J-2, debe ver el Certificado de Elegibilidad DS-2019 de su hijo para el Estatus de Visitante de Intercambio.
En general, solo los no ciudadanos que tienen permiso para trabajar del DHS pueden solicitar un número de Seguro Social.

Si es un trabajador extranjero, solo necesitamos ver un Registro de Llegada/Salida I-94 o un sello de admisión en el pasaporte extranjero vigente, que muestre una clase de admisión que permita trabajar.
Algunos trabajadores extranjeros deben mostrar su Documento de Autorización de Empleo I-766, EAD, permiso de trabajo del DHS.
Si presenta evidencia del estatus legal autorizado para trabajar de su hijo junto con evidencia del cambio de nombre, podemos emitir una tarjeta corregida con el nuevo nombre de su hijo.
Sin embargo, si asignamos un número de Seguro Social a su hijo para fines no laborales, se aplican reglas especiales.
Si su hijo no está autorizado para trabajar por el DHS, cambiaremos el nombre de su hijo en nuestros registros, pero no podemos emitir una tarjeta corregida.
Su hijo no puede usar un número de Seguro Social asignado para fines no laborales para trabajar.
Si su hijo lo usa para trabajar, informaremos al DHS.

Si es un estudiante F-1 y es elegible para trabajar en el campus, debe proporcionar una carta de su funcionario escolar designado que: Lo identifique; Confirme su estatus escolar actual; e Identifique a su empleador y el tipo de trabajo que está o estará haciendo.
También necesitamos ver evidencia de ese empleo, como un recibo de pago reciente o una carta de su empleador.
Su supervisor debe firmar y fechar la carta.
La carta debe describir: Su trabajo; Su fecha de inicio de empleo; La cantidad de horas que está o estará trabajando; y El nombre y número de teléfono de su supervisor.

Si es un estudiante F-1 autorizado para trabajar en capacitación práctica curricular (CPT), debe proporcionarnos su Formulario I-20 con la página de empleo completada y firmada por su funcionario escolar designado.
Si es un estudiante F-1 y tiene un permiso de trabajo I-766 del DHS, debe presentarlo.
Si es un estudiante J-1, pasante estudiantil o visitante internacional, debe proporcionar una carta de su patrocinador.
La carta debe estar en papel membretado del patrocinador con una firma original que autorice su empleo.
Si necesita cambiar el nombre en el registro de la Seguridad Social de su hijo, debe mostrarnos prueba del cambio legal de nombre de su hijo.

Los documentos que la Seguridad Social puede aceptar para probar el cambio legal de nombre de su hijo incluyen: Decreto final de adopción con el nuevo nombre; Orden judicial que aprueba el cambio de nombre.

Si el documento que proporciona como evidencia del cambio legal de nombre de su hijo no nos brinda suficiente información para identificar a su hijo en nuestros registros o si cambió el nombre de su hijo hace más de cuatro años, debe mostrarnos un documento de identidad con el nombre anterior de su hijo como se muestra en nuestros registros.
Aceptaremos un documento de identidad con el nombre anterior de su hijo que haya vencido.

Si no tiene un documento de identidad con el nombre anterior de su hijo, es posible que aceptemos un documento de identidad vigente con el nuevo nombre de su hijo, siempre que podamos establecer correctamente la identidad de su hijo en nuestros registros.
La Seguridad Social le pedirá ver el documento de inmigración actual de su hijo en los EE. UU. del DHS.

Los documentos de inmigración aceptables incluyen: Tarjeta de Residente Permanente I-551 de su hijo; Registro de Llegada/Salida I-94 con pasaporte extranjero vigente o sello de admisión en el pasaporte extranjero vigente; o Documento de Autorización de Empleo I-766, EAD, permiso de trabajo del DHS.
También debemos ver prueba de su identidad.
Un documento aceptable debe estar vigente, no vencido, y mostrar su nombre, información de identificación, fecha de nacimiento o edad y, preferiblemente, una fotografía reciente.

Por ejemplo, como prueba de identidad, la Seguridad Social debe ver su: Licencia de conducir de los EE. UU.; Tarjeta de identificación no de conductor emitida por el estado; o Pasaporte de los EE. UU.
Si no tiene uno de estos documentos específicos o no puede obtener un reemplazo para uno de ellos dentro de los 10 días, le pediremos que muestre otros documentos.

Cualquier documento presentado, incluidos los siguientes, debe estar vigente, no vencido, y mostrar su nombre, información de identificación, fecha de nacimiento o edad y, preferiblemente, una fotografía reciente: Tarjeta de identificación de empleado; Tarjeta de identificación escolar; Tarjeta de seguro médico (no una tarjeta de Medicare); Tarjeta de identificación militar de los EE. UU.; o Registro de doctor, clínica u hospital.
Si no es ciudadano de los EE. UU., la Seguridad Social le pedirá ver su documento de inmigración actual en los EE. UU. del DHS.

Los documentos de inmigración aceptables incluyen su: Formulario I-551 incluye visa de inmigrante legible por máquina con pasaporte extranjero vigente; I-94 o sello de admisión en el pasaporte extranjero vigente; o Documento de Autorización de Empleo I-766, EAD, permiso de trabajo del DHS.
Si emitimos una nueva tarjeta para su hijo, tendrá el mismo número que la tarjeta anterior de su hijo, pero mostrará un nuevo nombre.
Enviaremos por correo la tarjeta de su hijo tan pronto como tengamos toda la información de su hijo y hayamos verificado sus documentos de inmigración.
If you legally change your child's name because of adoption, court order or any other reason, you need to tell Social Security so that you can get a corrected card.
If your child is working, also tell your child's employer.
If you do not tell Social Security when your child's name changes, it may delay your tax refund or your child's refund.

If you do not tell Social Security when your child's name changes, it may prevent your child's wages from being posted correctly to your child's Social Security record, which may lower the amount of your child's future Social Security benefits.
You must present original documents or copies certified by the agency that issued them.
Social Security cannot accept photocopies or notarized copies.
All documents must be current not expired.
Social Security cannot accept a receipt showing you applied for the document.
If you have not already established your child's U.S. citizenship with Social Security, Social Security needs to see proof of U.S. citizenship.
Social Security can accept only certain documents as proof of U.S. citizenship, including a U.S. birth certificate or U.S. passport.
If you need to change the name on your child's Social Security card, you must show Social Security proof of your child's legal name change.

Documents Social Security may accept to prove your child's legal name change include a final adoption decree with the new name, a court order approving the name change, or an amended birth certificate with the new name.

If the document you provide as evidence of your child's legal name change does not give Social Security enough information to identify your child in Social Security's records or if you changed your child's name more than four years ago, you must show Social Security an identity document in your child's prior name as shown in Social Security's records.
Social Security will accept an identity document in your child's old name that has expired.

If you do not have an identity document in your child's prior name, Social Security may accept an unexpired identity document in your child's new name, as long as Social Security can properly establish your child's identity in Social Security's records.
Social Security can accept only certain documents as proof of your child's identity.
An acceptable document must show your child's name, identifying information (i.e., age, date of birth, or parents' names) and preferably a recent photograph.
Social Security generally can accept a non-photo identity document if it has enough information to identify the child such as the child's name and age, date of birth or parents' names.
Social Security prefers to see the child's U.S. passport.

If the child's U.S. passport is not available, Social Security may accept the child's state-issued non-driver's identification card, adoption decree, doctor, clinic or hospital record, religious record, school daycare center record, or school identification card.
Social Security also must see proof of your identity.
An acceptable document for proving your identity must be current (not expired) and show your name, identifying information (date of birth or age) and preferably a recent photograph.
As proof of your identity, Social Security must see your U.S. driver's license, state-issued non-driver identification card, or U.S. passport.
If you do not have one of these specific documents or you cannot get a replacement for one of them within 10 days, Social Security will ask to see other documents.

Any documents submitted, including an employee identification card, school identification card, health insurance card (not a Medicare card), or U.S. military identification card, must be current (not expired) and show your name, identifying information (date of birth or age) and preferably a recent photograph.
Your child's new Social Security card will have the same number as your child's previous card, but will show a new name.
Social Security will mail your child's card as soon as Social Security has all of your child's information and has verified your child's documents.
You must present original documents or copies certified by the agency that issued them.
We cannot accept photocopies or notarized copies.
All documents must be current not expired.
We cannot accept a receipt showing you applied for the document.
We can accept only certain documents as proof of U.S. citizenship.
These include: U.S. passport, Certificate of Naturalization N-550/N-570, Certificate of Citizenship N-560/N-561, Certificate of Report of Birth DS-1350, Consular Report of Birth Abroad FS-240, CRBA.
You must present your foreign birth certificate if you have it or can get it within 10 days.

If you do not have a foreign birth certificate or cannot get it within 10 days, we will consider other documents such as your passport or a document issued by the Department of Homeland Security DHS as evidence of your age.
Anyone age 12 or older requesting an original Social Security number must appear in person for an interview.
We will ask for evidence to show you do not have a Social Security number.

If you lived outside the United States for an extended period, a current or previous passport, school and/or employment records, and any other record that would show long-term residence outside the United States could be used to show you do not have a Social Security number.

If you have lived in the United States and you are applying for an original Social Security number, we may ask you for information about the schools you attended or we may ask you to provide copies of tax records that would show you were never assigned a Social Security number.
We can accept only certain documents as proof of identity.
An acceptable document must be current not expired and show your name, identifying information date of birth or age and preferably a recent photograph.
As proof of identity Social Security must see your: U.S. driver's license, State-issued non-driver identification card, or U.S. passport.
If you do not have one of these specific documents or you cannot get a replacement for one of them within 10 days, we will ask to see other documents.

Any documents submitted, including the following, must be current not expired and show your name, identifying information date of birth or age and preferably a recent photograph: Employee identification card, School identification card, Health insurance card not a Medicare card, or U.S. military identification card.
We may use one document for two purposes.
For example, we may use your U.S. passport as proof of both citizenship and identity.
However, you must provide at least two separate documents.
In general, only noncitizens who have permission to work from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) can apply for a Social Security number.
If you do not have permission to work but need a Social Security number for other purposes, see 'If you do not have permission to work' for further information.
You must present original documents or copies certified by the agency that issued them.
We cannot accept photocopies or notarized copies.
All documents must be current (not expired).
We cannot accept a receipt showing you applied for the document.

To prove your U.S. immigration status, you must show us your current U.S. immigration document, such as: Form I-551 (Lawful Permanent Resident Card), Machine Readable Immigrant Visa with your unexpired foreign passport, I-766 (Employment Authorization Document, EAD, work permit), or I-94 Arrival/Departure Record or admission stamp in the unexpired foreign passport.
If you are an F-1 or M-1 student, you also must show us your I-20 Certificate of Eligibility for Nonimmigrant Student Status.
If you are a J-1 or J-2 exchange visitor, you must show us your DS-2019 Certificate of Eligibility for Exchange Visitor Status.
In general, only noncitizens who have permission to work from DHS can apply for a Social Security number.
If you are a foreign worker, we only need to see your I-94 Arrival/Departure Record or admission stamp in the unexpired foreign passport showing a class of admission permitting work.
Some foreign workers must show their I-766 Employment Authorization Document (EAD, work permit) from DHS.

If you are an F-1 student and eligible to work on campus, you must provide a letter from your designated school official that: Identifies you, Confirms your current school status, and Identifies your employer and the type of work you are, or will be, doing.
We also need to see evidence of that employment, such as a recent pay slip or a letter from your employer.
Your supervisor must sign and date the letter from your employer.
The letter from your employer must describe: Your job, Your employment start date, The number of hours you are, or will be, working, and Your supervisor's name and telephone number.

If you are an F-1 student authorized to work in curricular practical training (CPT), you must provide us your Form I-20 with the employment page completed and signed by your designated school official.
If you are an F-1 student and have a work permit (I-766) from DHS, you must present it.
If you are a J-1 student, student intern or international visitor, you must provide a letter from your sponsor.
The letter from your sponsor should be on sponsor letterhead with an original signature that authorizes your employment.
Lawfully admitted noncitizens can get many benefits and services without a Social Security number.

You do not need a Social Security number to conduct business with a bank, register for school, apply for educational tests, obtain private health insurance, apply for school lunch programs or apply for subsidized housing.
You cannot get a Social Security number for the sole purpose of obtaining a driver's license.

If you do not have permission to work, you may apply for a Social Security number only if: A federal law requires you to provide your Social Security number to get a particular benefit or service, or A state or local law requires you to provide your Social Security number to get general assistance benefits for which you already have qualified.
If you need a Social Security number to meet these state or local requirements, you must bring us a letter from the government agency.
The letter from the government agency must be on letterhead stationery (no form letters or photocopies).

The letter from the government agency must: Specifically identify you as the applicant, Cite the law requiring you to have a Social Security number, Indicate that you meet all the agency's requirements, except having the number, and Contain an agency contact name and telephone number.
If you need a number for tax purposes and you are not authorized to work in the United States, you can apply for an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number from the Internal Revenue Service (IRS).
You can visit the IRS in person or call the IRS toll-free number, 1-800-TAXFORM (1-800-829-3676), and request Form W-7 Application for IRS Individual Taxpayer Identification Number.
If you are assigned a number for non-work purposes, you cannot use it to work.

You may not be affected by these limits if you can prove you need the Social Security card to prevent a significant hardship.
You must present original documents or copies certified by the agency that issued them.
Social Security cannot accept photocopies or notarized copies.
All documents must be current not expired.
Social Security cannot accept a receipt showing you applied for the document.
You may be able to request your replacement Social Security card online.
The online service is a fast and secure way to get a replacement Social Security card.
If you are age 18 or older with a U.S. mailing address and have a mySocial Security account, you can apply for a replacement Social Security card online.
For more information about creating a mySocial Security account and getting a replacement Social Security card online, visit the Social Security Number and Card website.
If you have not already established your U.S. citizenship with Social Security, Social Security needs to see proof of U.S. citizenship.
Social Security can accept only certain documents as proof of U.S. citizenship.
These documents include a U.S. birth certificate or U.S. passport.
Social Security can accept only certain documents as proof of identity.
An acceptable document must be current not expired and show your name, identifying information date of birth or age and preferably a recent photograph.
As proof of identity, Social Security must see your U.S. driver's license, State-issued non-driver identification card, or U.S. passport.
If you do not have one of these specific documents or you cannot get a replacement for one of them within 10 days, Social Security will ask to see other documents.

Any documents submitted, including the following, must be current not expired and show your name, identifying information date of birth or age and preferably a recent photograph: employee identification card, school identification card, health insurance card not a Medicare card, or U.S. military identification card.
Social Security may use one document for two purposes.
For example, Social Security may use your U.S. passport as proof of both citizenship and identity.
You can replace your child's Social Security card for free if it is lost or stolen.
However you may not need to get a replacement card.
Knowing your child's Social Security number is what's important.
You are limited to three (3) replacement cards in a year and 10 during a lifetime.
Legal name changes do not count toward these limits.
You may not be affected by these limits if you can prove you need the card to prevent a significant hardship.
You must present original documents or copies certified by the agency that issued them.
The Social Security Administration cannot accept photocopies or notarized copies.
All documents must be current (not expired).
The Social Security Administration cannot accept a receipt showing you applied for the document.
If you have not previously reported the child's U.S. citizenship to the Social Security Administration, the Social Security Administration needs to see proof of U.S. citizenship.

The Social Security Administration can accept only certain documents as proof of U.S. citizenship, including: Certification of Report of Birth (DS-1350), Consular Report of Birth Abroad (FS-240, CRBA), U.S. passport, or Certificate of Citizenship (N-560/N-561).
For proof of your child's identity, the Social Security Administration can accept only certain documents.
An acceptable document for proof of your child's identity must show your child's name, identifying information (i.e., age, date of birth, or parents' names), and preferably a recent photograph.

The Social Security Administration generally can accept a non-photo identity document for your child if it has enough information to identify the child, such as the child's name and age, date of birth, or parents' names.
The Social Security Administration prefers to see the child's U.S. passport as proof of identity.

If the child's U.S. passport is not available, the Social Security Administration may accept the child's: state-issued non-driver's identification card, adoption decree, doctor/clinic/hospital record, religious record, school/daycare center record, or school identification card.
The Social Security Administration also must see proof of your (the parent's) identity.
An acceptable document for proof of your identity must be current (not expired) and show your name, identifying information (date of birth or age), and preferably a recent photograph.
As proof of your identity, the Social Security Administration must see your: U.S. driver's license, state-issued non-driver identification card, or U.S. passport.
If you do not have one of these specific documents or cannot get a replacement within 10 days, the Social Security Administration will ask to see other documents.

Any documents submitted as proof of your identity, including the following, must be current (not expired) and show your name, identifying information (date of birth or age), and preferably a recent photograph: employee identification card, school identification card, health insurance card (not a Medicare card), or U.S. military identification card.
The Social Security Administration may use one document for two purposes, for example, using your U.S. passport as proof of both citizenship and identity.
You can replace your child's Social Security card for free if it is lost or stolen.
You are limited to three replacement cards in a year and 10 during a lifetime for your child's Social Security card.
Legal name changes and other exceptions do not count toward these limits for your child's Social Security card replacement.
Changes in immigration status that require card updates may not count toward these limits for your child's Social Security card replacement.
You may not be affected by these limits for your child's Social Security card replacement if you can prove you need the card to prevent a significant hardship.
In general, only noncitizens who have permission to work from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) can apply for a Social Security number for their child.
If your child does not have permission to work but needs a Social Security number for other purposes, see "If your child does not have permission to work" for further information.
You must present original documents or copies certified by the agency that issued them for your child's Social Security card replacement.
The Social Security Administration cannot accept photocopies or notarized copies of documents for your child's Social Security card replacement.
All documents must be current (not expired) for your child's Social Security card replacement.
The Social Security Administration cannot accept a receipt showing you applied for the document for your child's Social Security card replacement.

To prove your child's U.S. immigration status for Social Security card replacement, you must show your child's current U.S. immigration document, such as: I-551 Lawful Permanent Resident Card, Machine Readable Immigrant Visa; I-766 Employment Authorization Document (EAD), work permit; or I-94 Arrival/Departure Record or admission stamp in the unexpired foreign passport.
If your child is an F-1 or M-1 student, the Social Security Administration must see your child's I-20 Certificate of Eligibility for Nonimmigrant Student Status for Social Security card replacement.
If your child is a J-1 or J-2 exchange visitor, you must see your child's DS-2019 Certificate of Eligibility for Exchange Visitor Status for Social Security card replacement.
In general, only noncitizens who have permission to work from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) can apply for a Social Security number for their child.

For children with work-authorization, the Social Security Administration only needs to see an I-94 Arrival/Departure Record or admission stamp in the unexpired foreign passport showing a class of admission permitting work for Social Security card replacement.
Some children must show their I-766 Employment Authorization Document (EAD), work permit from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for Social Security card replacement.

If you are an F-1 student and eligible to work on campus, you must provide a letter from your designated school official that: Identifies you; Confirms your current school status; and Identifies your employer and the type of work you are, or will be, doing for your child's Social Security card replacement.

For an F-1 student eligible to work on campus, the Social Security Administration also needs to see evidence of that employment, such as a recent pay slip or a letter from your employer for your child's Social Security card replacement.

The letter from the employer for an F-1 student eligible to work on campus must be signed and dated by the supervisor, and must describe: Your job; Your employment start date; The number of hours you are, or will be, working; and Your supervisor's name and telephone number for your child's Social Security card replacement.

If you are an F-1 student authorized to work in curricular practical training (CPT), you must provide the Social Security Administration your Form I-20 with the employment page completed and signed by your designated school official for your child's Social Security card replacement.

If you are an F-1 student and have a work permit (I-766) from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), you must present it to the Social Security Administration for your child's Social Security card replacement.
If you are a J-1 student, student intern or international visitor, you must provide a letter from your sponsor to the Social Security Administration for your child's Social Security card replacement.

The letter from the sponsor for a J-1 student, student intern or international visitor should be on sponsor letterhead with an original signature that authorizes your employment for your child's Social Security card replacement.
If your child does not have permission to work, lawfully admitted noncitizens can get many benefits and services without a Social Security number.

You do not need a Social Security number for your child to conduct business with a bank, register for school, apply for educational tests, obtain private health insurance, apply for school lunch programs or apply for subsidized housing if your child does not have permission to work.
You cannot get a Social Security number for your child for the sole purpose of obtaining a driver's license if your child does not have permission to work.

If your child does not have permission to work, the child may apply for a Social Security number only if: A federal law requires your child to provide a Social Security number to get a particular benefit or service; or A state or local law requires you to provide your child's Social Security number to get general assistance benefits for which you already have qualified.

If your child needs a Social Security number to meet state or local requirements and does not have permission to work, you must bring the Social Security Administration a letter from the government agency.

The letter from the government agency for a child who needs a Social Security number but does not have permission to work must be on letterhead stationery (no form letters or photocopies), and: Specifically identify your child as the applicant; Cite the law requiring your child to have a Social Security number; Indicate that your child meets all the agency's requirements, except having the number; and Contain an agency contact name and telephone number.

If you need a Social Security number for your child for tax purposes and your child is not authorized to work in the United States, you can apply for an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number for your child from the Internal Revenue Service (IRS).

To apply for an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number for your child from the IRS if your child is not authorized to work in the United States, you can visit the IRS in person or call the IRS toll-free number, 1-800-TAXFORM (1-800-829-3676), and request Form W-7A Application for Taxpayer Identification Number for Pending U.S. Adoptions.
If you are assigned a Social Security number for your child for non-work purposes, you cannot use it to work for your child.
If you use a Social Security number assigned to your child for non-work purposes to work, the Social Security Administration will inform the Department of Homeland Security (DHS).
For your child's identity, the Social Security Administration will ask to see your child's current Department of Homeland Security (DHS) document.

Acceptable documents for your child's identity include: I-551 Permanent Resident Card; I-94 Arrival/Departure Record with unexpired foreign passport; or I-766 Employment Authorization Document (EAD), work permit from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS).
If your child does not have a current Department of Homeland Security (DHS) document, the Social Security Administration can accept only certain documents as proof of your child's identity.
An acceptable document for your child's identity must show your child's name, identifying information (i.e., age, date of birth, or parents' names) and preferably a recent photograph.

The Social Security Administration generally can accept a non-photo identity document for your child if it has enough information to identify the child such as the child's name and age, date of birth or parents' names.

If a document with your child's name and age, date of birth or parents' names is not available, the Social Security Administration may accept the following for your child's identity: State-issued non-driver's identification card; Adoption decree; Doctor, clinic or hospital record; Religious record; School/daycare center record; or School identification card.
For your identity, the Social Security Administration also must see proof of your identity.
An acceptable document for your identity must be current (not expired) and show your name, identifying information (date of birth or age) and preferably a recent photograph.
For example, as proof of your identity, the Social Security Administration must see your: U.S. driver's license; State-issued non-driver identification card; or U.S. passport.

If you do not have one of these specific documents for your identity or you cannot get a replacement for one of them within 10 days, the Social Security Administration will ask to see other documents.

Any documents submitted for your identity, including the following, must be current (not expired) and show your name, identifying information (date of birth or age) and preferably a recent photograph: Employee identification card; School identification card; Health insurance card (not a Medicare card); or U.S. military identification card.
If you are not a U.S. citizen, the Social Security Administration will ask to see a current Department of Homeland Security (DHS) document for your identity.

Acceptable documents for your identity if you are not a U.S. citizen include: I-551 Permanent Resident Card; I-94 Arrival/Departure Record with unexpired foreign passport; I-766 Employment Authorization Document (EAD), work permit from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS).
The Social Security Administration may use one document for two purposes, for example, using a Department of Homeland Security (DHS) work permit as proof of both immigration status and identity.
You can replace your child's Social Security card for free if it is lost or stolen.
You are limited to three replacement cards in a year and 10 during a lifetime.
Legal name changes and other exceptions do not count toward these limits.
Changes in immigration status that require card updates may not count toward these limits.
You may not be affected by these limits if you can prove you need the card to prevent a significant hardship.
You must present original documents or copies certified by the agency that issued them.
Social Security cannot accept photocopies or notarized copies.
All documents must be current not expired.
Social Security cannot accept a receipt showing you applied for the document.
If you have not already established the child's U.S. citizenship with Social Security, Social Security needs to see proof of U.S. citizenship.
Social Security can accept only certain documents as proof of U.S. citizenship, including a U.S. birth certificate or U.S. passport.
This documentation is only required if your child has not already established citizenship with Social Security.
While you can use a birth certificate to prove age or citizenship, you cannot use it as proof of identity for your child.
Social Security needs evidence that shows the child continues to exist beyond the date of birth.
Social Security can accept only certain documents as proof of your child's identity.
An acceptable document for proving your child's identity must show your child's name, identifying information (i.e., age, date of birth, or parents' names) and preferably a recent photograph.
Social Security generally can accept a non-photo identity document if it has enough information to identify the child such as the child's name and age, date of birth or parents' names.
Social Security prefers to see the child's U.S. passport as proof of identity.

If the child's U.S. passport is not available, Social Security may accept the child's state-issued non-driver's identification card, adoption decree, doctor/clinic/hospital record, religious record, school/daycare center record, or school identification card.
Social Security must also see proof of your identity.
An acceptable document for proving your identity must be current (not expired) and show your name, identifying information (date of birth or age) and preferably a recent photograph.
For example, as proof of your identity, Social Security must see your U.S. driver's license, state-issued non-driver identification card, or U.S. passport.
If you do not have one of these specific documents or cannot get a replacement within 10 days, Social Security will ask to see other documents.

Any documents submitted for proving your identity, including employee identification card, school identification card, health insurance card (not a Medicare card), or U.S. military identification card, must be current (not expired) and show your name, identifying information (date of birth or age) and preferably a recent photograph.
If you are not a U.S. citizen, Social Security will ask to see a current DHS document.

Acceptable DHS documents include I-551 Permanent Resident Card, I-94 Arrival/Departure Record with unexpired foreign passport or admission stamp in the unexpired foreign passport, or I-766 Employment Authorization Document (EAD) or work permit from DHS.
Social Security may use one document for two purposes, for example, using your U.S. passport as proof of both citizenship and identity.
The document provides information about the Benefits Planner for Retirement.
It mentions an Online Calculator (WEP Version) that allows users to estimate their Social Security benefit.
The document states that for the most accurate estimates, users need to use the Detailed Calculator.
Users need to enter all their past earnings, which are shown on their online statements, to use the Detailed Calculator.
The document notes that the Online Calculator is updated periodically with new benefit increases and other benefit amounts.
It states that users' benefit estimates in the future may differ from those calculated today using the Online Calculator.
The Online Calculator works on PCs and Macs with Javascript enabled.
Some browsers may not allow users to print the table shown by the Online Calculator.
The document mentions that if a user's birthday is on January 1st, their benefit is figured as if their birthday was in the previous year.
It states that if a user qualifies for benefits as a Survivor, their full retirement age for survivors benefits may be different.
Social Security pays disability benefits to people who can't work because they have a medical condition that's expected to last at least one year or result in death.
Social Security provides information and services for managing disability benefits online for people who receive Social Security disability benefits.
The online application for disability benefits is currently only available in English.
The online application for disability benefits gives the option to schedule an appointment to apply for benefits in a preferred language other than English.

People can apply for disability benefits online if they: Are age 18 or older, Are not currently receiving benefits on their own Social Security record, Are unable to work because of a medical condition that is expected to last at least 12 months or result in death, Have not been denied disability benefits in the last 60 days.

People can file for Supplemental Security Income (SSI) online if they: Are between the ages of 18 and 65, Have never been married, Aren't blind, Are a U.S. citizen residing in one of the fifty states, District of Columbia, or the Northern Mariana Islands, Haven't applied for or received SSI benefits in the past, Are applying for Social Security Disability Insurance at the same time as their SSI claim.
Social Security provides information to determine if someone is eligible to receive Social Security Disability Benefits.

A Social Security representative will contact the applicant by telephone or by mail for any additional information needed for the disability benefits applications after the online process is finished.
People can schedule an appointment with a local Social Security office to file an application for disability benefits.
People can call 1-800-772-1213 (TTY 1-800-325-0778) from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m., Monday through Friday or contact their local Social Security office to apply for disability benefits.
To apply for disability benefits online, people need to: Print and review the Adult Disability Checklist, Complete the Disability Benefit Application.

Information needed to apply for disability benefits includes: Date and place of birth and Social Security number, Information about current and former spouses, Names and dates of birth of minor children, Bank or financial institution's Routing Transit Number and account number for electronic deposit of benefits, Contact information for someone who knows about the applicant's medical conditions, Detailed information about medical illnesses, injuries or conditions including names, addresses, phone numbers, patient ID numbers and dates of treatment for all doctors, hospitals and clinics, Names of medicines and who prescribed them, Names and dates of medical tests and who sent the applicant for them.

Information needed to apply for disability benefits includes: Amount of money earned last year and this year, Name and address of employer for this year and last year, Copy of W-2 form, Beginning and ending dates of any active U.S. military service before 1968, List of jobs up to 5 that the applicant had in the 15 years before becoming unable to work and the dates worked at those jobs, Information about any workers' compensation, black lung, and/or similar benefits filed or intended to file for.

Documents that may be needed to apply for disability benefits include: Birth certificate or other proof of birth, Proof of U.S. citizenship or lawful alien status if not born in the U.S., U.S. military discharge paper if had military service before 1968, W-2 forms and/or self-employment tax returns for last year, Medical evidence already in possession such as medical records, doctors' reports, and recent test results, Award letters, pay stubs, settlement agreements or other proof of any temporary or permanent workers' compensation-type benefits received.
Social Security accepts photocopies of W-2 forms, self-employment tax returns or medical documents, but must see the original of most other documents, such as birth certificate.
Social Security will return original documents, such as birth certificate, to the applicant after examining them.
When mailing documents to Social Security, the applicant must include their Social Security number so the documents can be matched with the correct application.
The applicant should not write anything on the original documents when mailing them to Social Security.

The applicant should not mail foreign birth records or any documents from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), formerly the Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS), especially those required to be kept with them at all times, as these documents are extremely difficult, time-consuming and expensive to replace if lost, and some cannot be replaced.
Instead of mailing foreign birth records or DHS/INS documents, the applicant should bring them to a Social Security office where they will be examined and returned.

Advantages of applying for disability benefits using the online process include: Starting the disability claim immediately without waiting for an appointment, Applying from the convenience of home or any computer, Stopping and returning to the saved application before submission, Avoiding trips to a Social Security office, Completing the process online even if living outside the United States.

After receiving the online application for disability benefits, Social Security will: Provide confirmation of the application either electronically or by mail, Review the application, Contact the applicant by telephone or by mail if more information or documentation is needed, Inform the applicant if other family members may be able to receive benefits on the applicant's record, or if the applicant may be able to receive benefits on another person's record, such as a spouse or parent, Process the application, Mail the decision to the applicant.

Other ways to apply for disability benefits include: By phone - Call 1-800-772-1213 from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. Monday through Friday (TTY 1-800-325-0778 for deaf or hard of hearing), In person - Visit the local Social Security office (call first to make an appointment), If not living in the U.S. or its territories - Contact the nearest U.S. Social Security office, U.S. Embassy or consulate.
Social Security pays disability benefits to people who can't work because they have a medical condition that's expected to last at least one year or result in death.
Social Security provides information and services for managing disability benefits online for people who receive Social Security disability benefits.
The online application for disability benefits is currently only available in English.
The online application for disability benefits gives the option to schedule an appointment to apply for benefits in a preferred language other than English.

People can apply for disability benefits online if they: Are age 18 or older, Are not currently receiving benefits on their own Social Security record, Are unable to work because of a medical condition that is expected to last at least 12 months or result in death, and Have not been denied disability benefits in the last 60 days.

People can file for Supplemental Security Income (SSI) online if they: Are between the ages of 18 and 65, Have never been married, Aren't blind, Are a U.S. citizen residing in one of the fifty states, District of Columbia, or the Northern Mariana Islands, Haven't applied for or received SSI benefits in the past, and Are applying for Social Security Disability Insurance at the same time as their SSI claim.
Social Security provides information to determine if someone is eligible to receive Social Security Disability Benefits.

A Social Security representative will contact the applicant by telephone or by mail for any additional information needed for the disability benefits applications after the online process is finished.

People can schedule an appointment with a local Social Security office to file an application for disability benefits by calling 1-800-772-1213 (TTY 1-800-325-0778) from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m., Monday through Friday, or by contacting their local Social Security office.
To apply for disability benefits online, people need to: Print and review the Adult Disability Checklist, and Complete the Disability Benefit Application.

To apply for disability benefits online, people should have the following information: Their date and place of birth and Social Security number, The name, Social Security number and date of birth or age of their current spouse and any former spouse, The dates and places of marriage and dates of divorce or death if appropriate, Names and dates of birth of their minor children, Their bank or other financial institution's Routing Transit Number and account number if they want the benefits electronically deposited, Name, address and phone number of someone who knows about their medical conditions and can help with their application, Detailed information about their medical illnesses, injuries or conditions, The amount of money earned last year and this year, The name and address of their employer for this year and last year, A copy of their W-2 form(s), The beginning and ending dates of any active U.S. military service they had before 1968, A list of the jobs (up to 5) that they had in the 15 years before they became unable to work and the dates they worked at those jobs, Information about any workers' compensation, black lung, and/or similar benefits they filed, or intend to file for.

Social Security may ask applicants to provide documents to show that they are eligible, such as: Birth certificate or other proof of birth, Proof of U.S. citizenship or lawful alien status if they were not born in the United States, U.S. military discharge paper if they had military service before 1968, W-2 forms and/or self-employment tax returns for last year, Medical evidence already in their possession, Award letters, pay stubs, settlement agreements or other proof of any temporary or permanent workers' compensation-type benefits they received.
Social Security accepts photocopies of W-2 forms, self-employment tax returns or medical documents, but must see the original of most other documents, such as birth certificates.
Social Security will return original documents, such as birth certificates, to applicants after examining them.
Applicants should not delay applying for disability benefits because they do not have all the documents, as Social Security will help them get the documents.
When mailing documents to Social Security, applicants must include their Social Security number so that the documents can be matched with the correct application.
Applicants should not write anything on the original documents when mailing them to Social Security.

Applicants should not mail foreign birth records or any documents from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), formerly the Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS), especially those they are required to keep with them at all times, as these documents are extremely difficult, time-consuming and expensive to replace if lost, and some cannot be replaced.
Instead of mailing foreign birth records or DHS/INS documents, applicants should bring them to a Social Security office where they will be examined and returned.

The online disability application process offers several advantages: Applicants can start their disability claim immediately without waiting for an appointment, Apply from the convenience of their own home or on any computer, Stop and return to their saved application before submission, Avoid trips to a Social Security office, Complete the process online even if they live outside the United States.

After receiving an online disability application, Social Security will: Provide confirmation of the application either electronically or by mail, Review the application, Contact the applicant by telephone or by mail if more information or documentation is needed, Inform the applicant if other family members may be able to receive benefits on their record, or if they may be able to receive benefits on another person's record, such as their spouse or parent, Process the application, Mail the decision to the applicant.
People can also apply for disability benefits by phone by calling 1-800-772-1213 from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. Monday through Friday, or by calling TTY 1-800-325-0778 if they are deaf or hard of hearing.
People can also apply for disability benefits in person by visiting their local Social Security office and making an appointment.
If people do not live in the United States or one of its territories, they can contact the nearest U.S. Social Security office, U.S. Embassy or consulate to apply for disability benefits.
Benefits Planner: Retirement is the title of the document.
When you start receiving Social Security retirement benefits, some members of your family may also qualify to receive benefits on your record.
If members of your family qualify, your spouse or child may receive a monthly payment of up to one-half of your full retirement benefit amount.
The payments to your spouse or child will not decrease your retirement benefit.
The value of the benefits your family may receive, added to your own, may help you decide if taking your benefits sooner may be more advantageous.
Benefits paid to your spouse will not decrease your retirement benefit.
The value of the benefits your spouse may receive, added to your own, may help you decide if taking your benefits sooner may be more advantageous.
If one of your children also qualifies for benefits, there is a limit to the amount Social Security can pay your family.
The total amount Social Security can pay your family depends on your benefit amount and the number of family members who also qualify on your record.
The total amount Social Security can pay your family varies, but generally the total amount you and your family can receive is about 150 to 180 percent of your full retirement benefit.
If any of your qualified family members apply for benefits with you, Social Security will ask you for their Social Security numbers and their birth certificates.

Even if your spouse has never worked under Social Security, your spouse may be able to get benefits if they are at least 62 years of age and you are receiving or eligible for retirement or disability benefits.
Your spouse can also qualify for Medicare at age 65.
If your spouse qualifies for benefits on their own record, Social Security will pay that amount first.

If the benefit on your record is higher than the benefit on your spouse's own record, your spouse will get an additional amount on your record so that the combination of benefits equals that higher amount.

If your spouse begins receiving benefits between age 62 and their full retirement age, the amount will be permanently reduced by a percentage based on the number of months up to their full retirement age.
If your spouse is under full retirement age and works while receiving benefits, their benefits may be affected by the retirement earnings test.
If your spouse also qualifies on their own record, their application will include both benefits.
If your spouse receives benefits at their full retirement age, the spouse's benefit cannot exceed one-half of your full retirement amount.

You should apply as soon as you become disabled.
If you apply for Social Security disability benefits, the benefits will not begin until the sixth full month of disability.
The Social Security disability waiting period begins with the first full month after the date the Social Security Administration decides your disability began.

For Supplemental Security Income (SSI), the Social Security Administration pays SSI disability benefits for the first full month after the date you filed your claim, or, if later, the date you become eligible for SSI.
You can apply for Disability benefits online.
You can apply for Disability benefits by calling the Social Security Administration's toll-free number, 1-800-772-1213.
The Social Security Administration's representatives can make an appointment for your application to be taken over the telephone or at any convenient Social Security office.
People who are deaf or hard of hearing may call the Social Security Administration's toll-free "TTY" number, 1-800-325-0778, between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. on Monday through Friday.
The Disability Starter Kit will help you get ready for your disability interview or online application.
Disability Starter Kits are available for adults and for children under age 18.
The Disability Starter Kits provide information about the specific documents and the information that the Social Security Administration will request from you.

The Disability Starter Kits provide general information about the disability programs and the Social Security Administration's decision-making process that can help take some of the mystery out of applying for disability benefits.
The publication "Disability Evaluation Under Social Security" is also known as "The Blue Book" and provides medical criteria for evaluating Social Security disability claims.
The publication "Social Security Disability Benefits" provides information about benefits.
The publication "Benefits For Children With Disabilities" provides information about benefits for children with disabilities.
The publication "What You Need To Know When You Get Disability Benefits" provides information about what you need to know when you get disability benefits.
The publication "Working While Disabled...How We Can Help" provides information about working while disabled and how the Social Security Administration can help.
The publication "Medicare" provides information about Medicare.
The publication "Receiving Your Benefits By Direct Deposit" provides information about receiving your benefits by direct deposit.
The publication "Social Security: When You'll Get Your Benefit" provides information about when you will get your Social Security benefit.
The publication "Disability Planner" provides information about disability planning.
You should apply as soon as you become disabled.
If you apply for Social Security disability benefits, the benefits will not begin until the sixth full month of disability.
The Social Security disability waiting period begins with the first full month after the date the Social Security Administration decides your disability began.

For Supplemental Security Income (SSI), the Social Security Administration pays SSI disability benefits for the first full month after the date you filed your claim, or, if later, the date you become eligible for SSI.
You can apply for Disability benefits online.
You can apply for Disability benefits by calling the Social Security Administration's toll-free number, 1-800-772-1213.
The Social Security Administration's representatives can make an appointment for your application to be taken over the telephone or at any convenient Social Security office.
People who are deaf or hard of hearing may call the Social Security Administration's toll-free "TTY" number, 1-800-325-0778, between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. on Monday through Friday.
The Disability Starter Kit will help you get ready for your disability interview or online application.
Disability Starter Kits are available for adults and for children under age 18.
The Disability Starter Kits provide information about the specific documents and the information that the Social Security Administration will request from you.
