Certain members of your family may also qualify for benefits on your record when you start receiving disability benefits.
Benefits may be paid to your spouse.
Benefits may be paid to your divorced spouse.
Benefits may be paid to your children.
Benefits may be paid to your disabled child.
Benefits may be paid to your adult child disabled before age 22.
If any of your qualified family members apply for benefits, the Social Security Administration will ask for their Social Security numbers and their birth certificates.
If your spouse is applying for benefits, the Social Security Administration may also ask for proof of marriage and dates of prior marriages, if applicable.
Each family member may be eligible for a monthly benefit of up to 50 percent of your disability benefit amount.
There is a limit to the amount the Social Security Administration can pay your family.
The total amount you and your family can receive is generally between 150 and 180 percent of your disability benefit.
If the sum of the benefits payable on your account is greater than the family limit, the benefits to the family members will be reduced proportionately.
Your benefit will not be affected if the sum of the benefits payable on your account is greater than the family limit.
Benefits are payable to your spouse when your spouse is age 62 or older, unless your spouse collects a higher Social Security benefit based on your spouse's earnings record.
The spouse benefit amount will be permanently reduced by a percentage based on the number of months until your spouse's full retirement age.
Benefits are payable to your spouse at any age if your spouse is caring for your child under age 16 or disabled.
Your spouse would receive these benefits until the child reaches age 16.

At the time when the child reaches age 16, the child's benefits continue, but your spouse's benefits stop unless your spouse is old enough to receive retirement benefits at age 62 or older or survivor benefits as a widow or widower at age 60.
If your spouse is eligible for retirement benefits on your spouse's own record, the Social Security Administration will always pay that amount first.
If the spouse benefit that is payable on your record is a higher amount, your spouse will get a combination of benefits that equals that higher amount.
If your spouse will also receive a pension based on work not covered by Social Security, such as government or foreign work, your spouse's Social Security benefit on your record may be affected.
If you are divorced, even if you have remarried, your ex-spouse may qualify for benefits on your record.

If your ex-spouse will also receive a pension based on work not covered by Social Security, such as government or foreign work, your ex-spouse's Social Security benefit on your record may be affected.

To qualify on your record, your ex-spouse must have been married to you for at least 10 years, be at least 62 years old, be unmarried, and not be eligible for an equal or higher benefit on your ex-spouse's own Social Security record, or on someone else's Social Security record.
When you qualify for Social Security disability benefits, your children may also qualify to receive benefits on your record.
Your eligible child can be your biological child, adopted child, or stepchild.
A dependent grandchild may also qualify for benefits on your record.

To receive benefits, the child must be unmarried and be under age 18, or 18-19 years old and a full-time student no higher than grade 12, or 18 or older and have a disability that started before age 22.
Normally, benefits stop when children reach age 18 unless they are disabled.

If the child is still a full-time student at a secondary or elementary school at age 18, benefits will continue until the child graduates or until two months after the child becomes age 19, whichever is first.

If Social Security is not able to process your online request, you will receive specific information on how to contact Social Security by phone or schedule an appointment.

If you will receive a pension for work not covered by Social Security such as government employment, any Social Security benefits you may be eligible to receive on your spouse's record may be reduced.
This type of benefit reduction is called Government Pension Offset (GPO).
Some individuals are exempt from the Government Pension Offset (GPO).

To estimate your future spouse's, widow's, or widower's benefits under the Government Pension Offset (GPO), you need two things: The estimated "gross" monthly amount of your pension from your government job not covered by Social Security, and the estimated monthly amount of your Social Security benefit as a spouse, widow, or widower before the effect of Government Pension Offset (GPO).

If you will be eligible for spouse's benefits and have access to your spouse's estimate: Find the estimated amount of the retirement benefit your spouse would be eligible to receive at full retirement age, divide this amount in half and round down to the nearest dollar, and this is your estimated spouse's benefit if you retire at full retirement age.

If you will be eligible for a Social Security retirement benefit based on your own earnings as well as a higher benefit based on your spouse's earnings, it will also affect your benefits as a spouse, widow, or widower.

To get a more accurate estimate of how the government pension you will receive for work not covered by Social Security will affect the part of your benefit based on your spouse's work: Enter the estimated "gross" monthly amount of the government pension in today's dollars you will receive for work not covered by Social Security in Step #1 of "Calculate Your Benefits", use your most recent estimate to determine your estimated retirement benefit based on your own earnings, subtract the estimated amount of your retirement benefit from the estimated amount of your spouse's, widow's, or widower's benefit before Government Pension Offset (GPO), enter that amount in Step #2 of "Calculate Your Benefits" and select "Compute", and the amount in #3 of "Calculate Your Benefits" is your estimated spouse's, widow's, or widower's benefit after Government Pension Offset (GPO) is applied.

If you retire before full retirement age: Your benefit amount as a spouse will be reduced, and the reduction will vary based on your date of birth with the maximum reduction for benefits starting at age 62 being 30 percent for someone born in 1946 and increasing to 35 percent for those born in 1960 or later.

For more information about your estimated benefit amount if you retire before reaching full retirement age, please call the Social Security Administration's toll free number at 1-800-772-1213, call their TTY number at 1-800-325-0778 if you are deaf or hard of hearing, or contact your local Social Security office.

If you will be eligible for widow's or widower's benefits or you do not have access to your spouse's estimate or records, please call the Social Security Administration's toll free number at 1-800-772-1213, call their TTY number at 1-800-325-0778 if you are deaf or hard of hearing, or contact your local Social Security office.

If you will be eligible for a Social Security retirement benefit based on your own earnings as well as a higher benefit based on your spouse's earnings, it will also affect your benefits as a spouse, widow, or widower.

To get a more accurate estimate of how the government pension you will receive for work not covered by Social Security will affect the part of your benefit based on your spouse's work: Enter the estimated "gross" monthly amount of the government pension in today's dollars you will receive for work not covered by Social Security in Step #1 of "Calculate Your Benefits", use your most recent estimate to determine your estimated retirement benefit based on your own earnings, subtract the estimated amount of your retirement benefit from the estimated amount of your spouse's, widow's, or widower's benefit before Government Pension Offset (GPO), enter that amount in Step #2 of "Calculate Your Benefits" and select "Compute", and the amount in #3 of "Calculate Your Benefits" is your estimated spouse's, widow's, or widower's benefit after Government Pension Offset (GPO) is applied.

If you will be eligible for widow's or widower's benefits or you do not have access to your spouse's estimate or records, please call the Social Security Administration's toll free number at 1-800-772-1213, call their TTY number at 1-800-325-0778 if you are deaf or hard of hearing, or contact your local Social Security office.

Even if you have never worked under Social Security, you may be able to get spouse's retirement benefits if you are at least 62 years of age and your spouse is receiving retirement or disability benefits.
You can also qualify for Medicare at age 65.
If you are divorced, you may still be able to get benefits on your ex-spouse's record.
For information on the requirements for Divorced Spouse's Benefits, read "If You Are Divorced".
You can receive the spouse's benefit no matter what your age is if you are caring for their child who is also receiving benefits.
If you qualify and apply for your own retirement benefits and for benefits as a spouse, the Social Security Administration always pays your own benefits first.
If your benefits as a spouse are higher than your own retirement benefits, you will get a combination of benefits equaling the higher spouse benefit.
If you begin receiving benefits between age 62 and your full retirement age, the amount will be permanently reduced by a percentage based on the number of months up to your full retirement age.
If you are under full retirement age and you continue to work while receiving benefits, your benefits may be affected by the retirement earnings test.
At your full retirement age, your benefit as a spouse cannot exceed one-half of your spouse's full retirement amount.

If you were born before January 2, 1954 and have already reached full retirement age, you can choose to receive only the spouse's benefit and delay receiving your retirement benefit until a later date.
If your spouse is full retirement age and applying for spouse's benefits only, they can apply online by using the retirement application.
Your spouse can also contact the Social Security Administration to schedule an appointment.
If your spouse's birthday is January 2, 1954 or later, the option to take only one benefit at full retirement age no longer exists.
If your spouse files for one benefit, they will be effectively filing for all retirement or spousal benefits.
If you will receive a pension for work not covered by Social Security such as government employment, the amount of your Social Security benefits on your spouse's record may be reduced.
Benefits paid to you as a spouse will not decrease your spouse's retirement benefit.
The value of the benefits you may receive, added to your spouse's benefits, may help your spouse decide if taking benefits sooner may be more advantageous.
If one of your spouse's children also qualifies for benefits, there is a limit to the amount the Social Security Administration can pay family members.
The total depends on your spouse's benefit amount and the number of family members who also qualify on the same record.
The total varies, but generally the total amount the worker (your spouse) and their family members can receive is about 150 to 180 percent of the worker's full retirement benefit.
You can apply for Social Security retirement, spouse's, divorced spouse's or Medicare benefits online by using the Social Security Retirement/Medicare Benefit Application.

If your spouse is already receiving benefits when you apply, or if you and your spouse apply at the same time, the Social Security Administration will also check your eligibility for benefits as a spouse.
If you qualify, your application will automatically serve as a request for spousal benefits.
You can apply for Social Security benefits by phone by calling 1-800-772-1213.
If you are deaf or hard of hearing, you can call the Social Security Administration at TTY 1-800-325-0778.
You can apply for Social Security benefits in person by visiting your local Social Security office and making an appointment.
If you do not live in the U.S. or one of its territories, you can contact the nearest U.S. Social Security office, U.S. Embassy or consulate.
If you are interested in information about benefits for your family, go to "Benefits For Your Family".
If you never married or had children, go to "How You Apply For Retirement Benefits Or Medicare".

Social Security offers an online retirement application that you can complete in as little as 15 minutes.
The online retirement application is so easy.
You can apply for retirement benefits from the comfort of your home or office at a time most convenient for you.
There's no need to drive to a local Social Security office or wait for an appointment with a Social Security representative when applying for retirement benefits online.
In most cases, once your online application for retirement benefits is submitted electronically, you're done.
Social Security will process your online application for retirement benefits and contact you by telephone or by mail if any further information is needed.

If you prefer to complete your application for retirement benefits in a language other than English, the online application will give you the option to schedule an appointment to apply for benefits in your preferred language.
The online application for retirement benefits is currently only available in English.

You can apply online for retirement benefits or benefits as a spouse if you: are at least 61 years and 8 months old; Are not currently receiving benefits on your own Social Security record; have not already applied for retirement benefits; and want your benefits to start no more than 4 months in the future.
Social Security cannot process your online application for retirement benefits if you apply for benefits more than 4 months in advance.
If you already have Medicare, you can still use the online application to apply for retirement benefits.

If you don't have Medicare but are within 3 months of age 65, you can use the online application to apply for: both retirement and Medicare; or just Medicare, if you aren't ready to receive retirement benefits yet.
Your 'full retirement age' for Social Security retirement benefits, depending on your date of birth, may be between age 66 and 67.
Your 'full retirement age' for Social Security retirement benefits could affect the amount of your benefits and when you want the benefits to start.
You may start receiving Social Security retirement benefits as early as age 62 or as late as age 70.
Your monthly Social Security retirement benefits will be reduced if you start them any time before 'full retirement age'.
If you elect to receive Social Security retirement benefits before you reach full retirement age, you should understand how continuing to work can affect your benefits.
Delayed retirement credits may be added to your Social Security retirement benefits if they start after your full retirement age.
Many of us will live much longer than the average retiree, and most women live longer than men.
More than one in three 65 year olds today will live to age 90, and more than one in seven will live to age 95.
Social Security retirement benefits, which last as long as you live, provide valuable protection against outliving savings and other sources of retirement income.
You'll want to choose a retirement age for Social Security retirement benefits based on your circumstances so you'll have enough income when you need it.

Some of the things you should think about before you decide when to begin your Social Security retirement benefits include: how long you think you will receive benefits, your health and whether anyone else in your family can get benefits on your record.
You can find out what documents and information you need to apply for Social Security retirement benefits by reading the 'Checklist for Online Medicare, Retirement, and Spouses Applications'.
To use the online application for Social Security retirement benefits, you select the 'Apply for Retirement Benefits' button.

You'll be asked to create or sign in to your my Social Security account and then go through a series of screens that will ask you questions about yourself, your family, and your work when using the online application for Social Security retirement benefits.
You can complete your online application for Social Security retirement benefits in a single session or start the application now and finish it sometime later.
If you get stuck on a question in the online application for Social Security retirement benefits, you can skip it and go back later.
When you get to the end of the online application for Social Security retirement benefits, Social Security will let you know if there are any questions you still need to answer.

If you can't complete your online application for Social Security retirement benefits because you need to look something up, or for any other reason, you can 'Return to a Saved Application' later without losing the information you entered.
You may not be able to use periods, commas, and other special characters when you answer some of the questions in the online application for Social Security retirement benefits.

After you completely fill out the online application for Social Security retirement benefits, Social Security will ask you to confirm the truthfulness of the answers to the best of your knowledge, under penalty of perjury, and your response will be recorded.
You can be held liable for intentionally providing false or misleading information in the online application for Social Security retirement benefits.
You 'sign' the online application for Social Security retirement benefits electronically by clicking on the 'Submit Now' button.
The only person who can 'sign' the online application for Social Security retirement benefits is the person who is applying for benefits.
A legal representative or person helping cannot sign the online application for Social Security retirement benefits.
Using the online application for Social Security retirement benefits allows you to avoid trips to your Social Security office, saving you time and money.
Using the online application for Social Security retirement benefits allows you to answer questions on your schedule.
Using the online application for Social Security retirement benefits allows you to start and stop the application without losing any of the information you entered.
Using the online application for Social Security retirement benefits allows you to have a chance to correct mistakes.
Using the online application for Social Security retirement benefits allows you to go back and make changes until you finish the application.
Using the online application for Social Security retirement benefits allows you to be given a chance to review your answers and go back and make corrections before you submit the application.
If you have trouble answering a question in the online application for Social Security retirement benefits, you can find additional information in the [More Info] links.
You don't need to mail your online application for Social Security retirement benefits.
When you're finished with the online application for Social Security retirement benefits, you just click 'Submit Now' to send your application to Social Security.
You'll get a receipt for your online application for Social Security retirement benefits that you can print and keep for your records.
You can check the status of your online application for Social Security retirement benefits using the confirmation number included in your receipt.

However, if you choose to apply for Social Security retirement benefits more than two months in the future, you will not be able to check the status of your online application until one month before you start receiving benefits.
For security reasons, there are time limits for viewing each page of the online application for Social Security retirement benefits.
You will receive a warning after 25 minutes without doing anything on a page of the online application for Social Security retirement benefits, and you will be able to extend your time on the page.
After the third warning of inactivity on a page of the online application for Social Security retirement benefits, you must move to another page or your work on that page will be lost.
Once Social Security receives your online application for retirement benefits, they will review it.
After reviewing your online application for Social Security retirement benefits, Social Security will contact you if they need more information or if they need to see your documents.
Social Security will let you know if you may be able to receive Social Security retirement benefits on another person's record, such as your spouse, after reviewing your online application.
Social Security will let you know if other family members may be able to receive Social Security retirement benefits on your work record after reviewing your online application.

When Social Security has all of the necessary information and documents for your online application for retirement benefits, they will process your application and send you a letter about their decision in the mail.
You can also apply for Social Security retirement benefits by phone by calling 1-800-772-1213 or TTY 1-800-325-0778 from 7 AM to 7 PM Monday through Friday.
You can also apply for Social Security retirement benefits in person by visiting your local Social Security office and calling first to make an appointment.
If you do not live in the U.S. or one of its territories, you can also contact the nearest U.S. Social Security office, U.S. Embassy or consulate to apply for Social Security retirement benefits.
Social Security offers an online retirement application that you can complete in as little as 15 minutes.
The online retirement application is easy to use.
You can apply for retirement benefits from the comfort of your home or office at a time most convenient for you using the online retirement application.
There's no need to drive to a local Social Security office or wait for an appointment with a Social Security representative when using the online retirement application.
In most cases, once your online retirement application is submitted electronically, you're done.
Social Security will process your online retirement application and contact you by telephone or by mail if any further information is needed.
The online retirement application is currently only available in English.

If you prefer to complete your retirement application in a language other than English, the online retirement application will give you the option to schedule an appointment to apply for benefits in your preferred language.

You can apply online for retirement benefits or benefits as a spouse if you: are at least 61 years and 8 months old; are not currently receiving benefits on your own Social Security record; have not already applied for retirement benefits; and want your benefits to start no more than 4 months in the future.
Social Security cannot process your online retirement application if you apply for benefits more than 4 months in advance.
If you already have Medicare, you can still use the online retirement application to apply for retirement benefits.

If you don't have Medicare but are within 3 months of age 65, you can use the online retirement application to apply for: both retirement and Medicare; or just Medicare, if you aren't ready to receive retirement benefits yet.
Your 'full retirement age' for Social Security benefits depends on your date of birth and may be between age 66 and 67.
Your 'full retirement age' could affect the amount of your Social Security benefits and when you want the benefits to start.
You may start receiving Social Security retirement benefits as early as age 62 or as late as age 70.
Your monthly Social Security retirement benefits will be reduced if you start them any time before your 'full retirement age'.
If you elect to receive Social Security retirement benefits before you reach full retirement age, you should understand how continuing to work can affect your benefits.
Delayed retirement credits may be added to your Social Security retirement benefits if they start after your full retirement age.
Many people will live much longer than the average retiree, and most women live longer than men.
More than one in three 65 year olds today will live to age 90, and more than one in seven will live to age 95.
Social Security retirement benefits, which last as long as you live, provide valuable protection against outliving savings and other sources of retirement income.
You should choose a Social Security retirement age based on your circumstances so you'll have enough income when you need it.

Things you should think about before you decide when to begin your Social Security retirement benefits include: how long you think you will receive benefits, your health and whether anyone else in your family can get benefits on your record.
You can find out what documents and information you need to apply for Social Security retirement benefits by reading the 'Checklist for Online Medicare, Retirement, and Spouses Applications'.

To use the online Social Security retirement application, you select the 'Apply for Retirement Benefits' button, create or sign in to your my Social Security account, and then go through a series of screens that will ask you questions about yourself, your family, and your work.
You can complete your online Social Security retirement application in a single session or start the application and finish it sometime later.
If you get stuck on a question in the online Social Security retirement application, you can skip it and go back later.
When you get to the end of the online Social Security retirement application, Social Security will let you know if there are any questions you still need to answer.

If you can't complete your online Social Security retirement application because you need to look something up, or for any other reason, you can 'Return to a Saved Application' later without losing the information you entered.

After you completely fill out the online Social Security retirement application, Social Security will ask you to confirm the truthfulness of the answers to the best of your knowledge, under penalty of perjury, and your response will be recorded.
You can be held liable for intentionally providing false or misleading information in the online Social Security retirement application.
You 'sign' the online Social Security retirement application electronically by clicking on the 'Submit Now' button.
The only person who can 'sign' the online Social Security retirement application is the person who is applying for benefits.
A legal representative or person helping cannot sign the online Social Security retirement application.

Using the online Social Security retirement application has benefits such as: avoiding trips to your Social Security office, answering questions on your schedule, not having to complete the application the same day you started it, being able to start and stop the application without losing information, having a chance to correct mistakes, being able to go back and make changes until you finish the application, being given a chance to review your answers and go back and make corrections before submitting the application, having access to additional information in [More Info] links if you have trouble answering a question, not needing to mail your application, getting a receipt for your online application, being able to print the receipt and keep it for your records, and being able to check the status of your online application.
For security reasons, there are time limits for viewing each page of the online Social Security retirement application.
You will receive a warning after 25 minutes without doing anything on a page of the online Social Security retirement application, and you will be able to extend your time on the page.
After the third warning on a page of the online Social Security retirement application, you must move to another page or your time will run out and your work on that page will be lost.
Once Social Security receives your online retirement application, they will review it.
After reviewing your online retirement application, Social Security will contact you if they need more information or if they need to see your documents.
Social Security will let you know if you may be able to receive benefits on another person's record, such as your spouse, after reviewing your online retirement application.
Social Security will let you know if other family members may be able to receive benefits on your work record after reviewing your online retirement application.
When Social Security has all of the necessary information and documents, they will process your online retirement application and send you a letter about their decision in the mail.
You can also apply for Social Security retirement benefits by phone by calling 1-800-772-1213 or TTY 1-800-325-0778 from 7 AM to 7 PM Monday through Friday.
You can also apply for Social Security retirement benefits in person by visiting your local Social Security office and calling first to make an appointment.
If you do not live in the U.S. or one of its territories, you can also contact the nearest U.S. Social Security office, U.S. Embassy or consulate to apply for Social Security retirement benefits.
The document is in English.
There is no one 'best age' for everyone to start receiving Social Security benefits.
The decision of when to apply for Social Security benefits should be based on individual and family circumstances.
The monthly Social Security benefit amount can differ substantially based on the age when a person starts receiving benefits.
If a person starts receiving Social Security benefits before their full retirement age, their benefit will be smaller but they will receive it for a longer period of time.
If a person starts receiving Social Security benefits at or after their full retirement age, they will receive a larger monthly benefit for a shorter period of time.
The amount a person receives when they first get Social Security benefits sets the base for the amount they will receive for the rest of their life.
If a person plans to continue working, there are limits on how much they can earn each year between age 62 and full retirement age and still get all their Social Security benefits.
Depending on the amount of a person's Social Security benefit and their earnings for the year, they may have to give up some of their benefits.
If a person's earnings will be high, they may decide to wait until full retirement age to start their Social Security benefits.
Once a person reaches full retirement age, there is no limit on how much they can earn.

After a person reaches full retirement age, the Social Security Administration recalculates their benefit amount to give them credit for any months in which they did not receive a benefit because of their earnings.
When additional earnings appear on a person's record, the Social Security Administration checks whether they will increase the person's monthly benefit amount.
If additional earnings increase a person's monthly benefit amount, the Social Security Administration sends the person a letter telling them their new benefit amount.
A person can apply for Medicare at age 65 and start receiving Social Security retirement benefits later.
When planning for retirement, a person should plan for the long term.
A man who turned 65 in 2014 can expect to live about another 19.3 years on average.
A woman who turned 65 in 2014 can expect to live about another 21.6 years on average.
About one out of every four 65-year-olds today will live past age 90.
One out of 10 65-year-olds today will live past age 95.

If a person comes from a long-lived family, they may need the extra money from Social Security benefits more in later years, particularly if they may outlive pensions or annuities with limits on how long they are paid.
If a person is not in good health, they may decide to start their Social Security benefits earlier.
If a person stops working, not only will they lose their paycheck, but they may also lose valuable employer-provided health insurance.
Although there are exceptions, most people will not be covered by Medicare until they reach age 65.
An employer should be able to tell a person if they will have retiree health benefits or if they can temporarily extend their health insurance coverage after they retire.
If a person is married and their spouse is employed, they may be able to switch to their spouse's health insurance.
Medicare usually starts when a person reaches age 65.

If a person decides to delay starting their Social Security benefits, they should contact the Social Security Administration about 3 months before they turn age 65 to check about applying for Medicare.
Even if a person has health insurance through a current or former employer or as part of their severance package, they should still check to see whether they need to sign up for Medicare.
Some health insurance plans change automatically at age 65.
If a person needs to sign up for Medicare but does not, their Medicare coverage may be delayed and cost more.
The Social Security Administration's Medicare booklet provides information on general and special enrollment periods and what may happen if a person delays signing up for Medicare.
If a person is eligible for Social Security benefits on another record, they may have additional options.

If a person qualifies for Social Security benefits as a widow, widower, or surviving divorced spouse on another record, they may choose to apply for survivors benefits now and delay their retirement benefit until later.
If a person delays receiving their Social Security retirement benefit until their full retirement age or later, their retirement benefit will be higher.

If a person was born before January 2, 1954 and has already reached their full retirement age, and is eligible for a spouse's or divorced-spouse's benefit and their own retirement benefit, they can choose to receive only the spouse's benefit and delay receiving their retirement benefit until a later date.
If a person's birthday is January 2, 1954 or later, the option to take only one Social Security benefit at full retirement age no longer exists.
If a person files for one Social Security benefit, they will be effectively filing for all retirement or spousal benefits.
If a person does not need their Social Security benefits immediately, they may decide to wait beyond full retirement age to receive delayed retirement credits.
If a person is within 4 months of age 65, or older, and has health insurance through an employer or former employer, they should check to see whether they need to sign up for Medicare.
Some health insurance plans change automatically at age 65.
A person may choose early retirement and increase the value of their Social Security benefits by investing them instead of spending them.
If a person is receiving early retirement from their employer, some company pensions include a Social Security-equivalent supplement that stops automatically at age 62.
The Social Security-equivalent supplement stops at age 62 because employers assume the person will apply for their Social Security retirement benefits at age 62.

If a person's spouse or minor or disabled children will also qualify for benefits from the person's Social Security record, the value of their benefits, added to the person's own, may help the person decide if taking their benefits sooner is their best choice.

If a person's spouse or ex-spouse's date of birth is January 2, 1954 or later and they become eligible to receive a higher benefit on the person's Social Security record while receiving retirement benefits, they can no longer delay filing for the additional benefit.
If a person's spouse files for one Social Security benefit, they will be effectively filing for all retirement or spousal benefits.
When a person starts their Social Security retirement benefits also affects the amount their surviving spouse may receive.
If a person starts their Social Security benefits before full retirement age, the Social Security Administration cannot pay their surviving spouse the full benefit amount from the person's record.
If a person was receiving reduced Social Security benefits, the Social Security Administration bases the survivors benefit on that reduced amount.
If a person starts their Social Security benefits after full retirement age, their surviving spouse may receive the person's full benefit amount plus any accumulated delayed retirement credits.

The Retirement Estimator gives estimates based on your actual Social Security earnings record.
These are just estimates.
We can't provide your actual benefit amount until you apply for benefits.
The amount may differ from the estimates provided because: Your earnings may increase or decrease in the future.
After you start receiving benefits, they will be adjusted for cost-of-living increases.
Your estimated benefits are based on current law.
The law governing benefit amounts may change because, by 2035, the combined trust fund reserves are projected to become depleted one year later than projected last year.
Payroll taxes collected will be enough to pay only about 80 cents for each dollar of scheduled benefits.
Your benefit amount may be affected by military service, railroad employment or pensions earned through work on which you did not pay Social Security tax.
You can use the Retirement Estimator if: You have enough Social Security credits at this time to qualify for benefits.
You can use the Retirement Estimator if: You are not currently receiving benefits on your own Social Security record.
You can use the Retirement Estimator if: You are not waiting for a decision about your application for benefits or Medicare.
You can use the Retirement Estimator if: You are not age 62 or older and receiving benefits on another Social Security record.
You can use the Retirement Estimator if: You are not eligible for a Pension Based on Work Not Covered By Social Security.
If you are currently receiving only Medicare benefits, you can still get an estimate.
For more information go to the link for the publication 'Retirement Information For Medicare Beneficiaries'.
If you cannot use the Retirement Estimator or you want a survivors or disability benefit estimate, please use one of the other benefit Calculators.

If your application is approved, your first Social Security benefit will be paid for the sixth full month after the date we find that your disability began.
For example, if your disability began on June 15, 2018, your first benefit would be paid for the month of December 2018, the sixth full month of disability.
Social Security benefits are paid in the month following the month for which they're due.
This means that the benefit due for December would be paid to you in January 2019, and so on.
The amount of your monthly disability benefit is based on your lifetime average earnings covered by Social Security.

If you don't already have an estimate, you can get your online with your personal my Social Security account or use our Benefit Calculators to determine how much you would get if you became disabled right now.

If you receive certain other government benefits, such as workers' compensation, public disability benefits, or pensions based on work not covered by Social Security for example, some government or foreign employment, the Social Security benefits payable to you and your family may be reduced.

For more information about how these benefits can affect your Social Security payments, refer to the following publications: How Workers' Compensation And Other Disability Payments May Affect Your Benefit; Windfall Elimination Provision; or Government Pension Offset.

We automatically enroll you in Medicare after you get disability benefits for two years.
The two parts of Medicare we enroll you in are hospital insurance and medical insurance.
Hospital insurance Part A helps pay for inpatient hospital bills and some follow-up care.
The taxes you paid while you were working financed this coverage, so it is provided at no cost to you.
Medical insurance Part B helps pay doctors' bills, outpatient hospital care, and other medical services.
You will need to pay a monthly premium for this coverage if you want it.
Most people have both parts of Medicare.
If you have questions about this coverage, you can contact Medicare toll-free at to speak to a Medicare Customer Service Representative.
TTY users should call.

Medicare Advantage Part C: People with Medicare Parts A and Part B can choose to receive all of their health care services through plans that are offered by private companies and approved by Medicare.
For more information, we recommend you read Medicare's Prescription Drug Coverage Part D helps pay for medications doctors prescribe for treatment.
For more information on the enrollment periods for Part D, we recommend you read Medicare's page.
If you receive Medicare and have limited resources and income, you may be eligible for Extra Help with Medicare Prescription Drug Plan Costs.

If you get Medicare and have low-income and few resources, your state may pay your Medicare premiums and, in some cases, other Medicare costs for which you are normally responsible such as deductibles and coinsurance.
Only your state can decide if you qualify for this assistance.
To find out if you do, contact your state or local welfare office or Medicaid agency.
For additional information about the program, please go to the Medicare's page.
If you need additional information about the other parts of Medicare, please read the "Who Can Get Medicare?" section of our Medicare booklet or visit Medicare.gov.

We should be notified immediately when a person dies.
You cannot report a death or apply for survivors benefits online.
If you need to report a death or apply for benefits, you can call 1-800-772-1213 (TTY 1-800-325-0778).
You can speak to a Social Security representative between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. Monday through Friday.
You can also visit your local Social Security office.
An appointment is not required, but if you call ahead and schedule one, it may reduce the time you spend waiting to speak to someone.
If you are getting benefits on your spouse's or parent's record, you generally will not need to file an application for survivors benefits.
The Social Security Administration will automatically change any monthly benefits you receive to survivors benefits after they receive the report of death.
The Social Security Administration may be able to pay the Special Lump-Sum Death Payment automatically.
If you are getting retirement or disability benefits on your own record, you will need to apply for the survivors benefits.
The Social Security Administration will check to see whether you can get a higher benefit as a widow or widower.
If you are not getting benefits, you should apply for survivors benefits promptly because, in some cases, benefits may not be retroactive.
To apply for Widows/Widowers or Surviving Divorced Spouse's Benefits, you may need certain information and documents.
To apply for Child's Benefits, you may need certain information and documents.
To apply for Mother's or Father's Benefits, you must have a child under age 16 or disabled in your care, and you may need certain information and documents.
To apply for the Lump-Sum Death Payment, you may need certain information and documents.
To apply for Parent's Benefits, you must have been dependent on your child at the time of his or her death, and you may need certain information and documents.
If you don't have all the documents you need, don't delay applying for Social Security.
In many cases, your local Social Security office can contact your state Bureau of Vital Statistics and verify your information online at no cost to you.
If the Social Security Administration can't verify your information online, they can still help you get the information you need.
We should be notified immediately when a person dies.
You cannot report a death or apply for survivors benefits online.
If you need to report a death or apply for benefits, you can call 1-800-772-1213 TTY 1-800-325-0778.
You can speak to a Social Security representative between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. Monday through Friday.
You can also visit your local Social Security office.
An appointment is not required, but if you call ahead and schedule one, it may reduce the time you spend waiting to speak to someone.
If you are getting benefits on your spouse's or parent's record, you generally will not need to file an application for survivors benefits.
The Social Security Administration will automatically change any monthly benefits you receive to survivors benefits after they receive the report of death.
The Social Security Administration may be able to pay the Special Lump-Sum Death Payment automatically.
If you are getting retirement or disability benefits on your own record, you will need to apply for the survivors benefits.
The Social Security Administration will check to see whether you can get a higher benefit as a widow or widower.
If you are not getting benefits, you should apply for survivors benefits promptly because, in some cases, benefits may not be retroactive.

You may need to provide information and documents when you apply for Widows/Widowers or Surviving Divorced Spouse's Benefits, Child's Benefits, Mother's or Father's Benefits, Lump-Sum Death Payment, or Parent's Benefits.
You must have a child under age 16 or disabled in your care to apply for Mother's or Father's Benefits.
You must have been dependent on your child at the time of his or her death to apply for Parent's Benefits.
If you don't have all the documents you need, don't delay applying for Social Security.
In many cases, your local Social Security office can contact your state Bureau of Vital Statistics and verify your information online at no cost to you.
If the Social Security Administration can't verify your information online, they can still help you get the information you need.
One of Social Security's most important responsibilities is protecting your investment and personal information.
Social Security takes this responsibility very seriously.
Social Security has a robust cybersecurity program in place to help it succeed.
Social Security's security process follows federal guidelines.
Social Security's security process includes additional security measures.
The additional security measures allow Social Security to be sure that you are who you say you are when you conduct online business with Social Security.
To protect the privacy of your identity and your information, Social Security is using a new identity verification process.
The new identity verification process requires you to sign in with a username and password.
The new identity verification process offers extra security.
The new identity verification process complies with federal laws, regulations, and guidelines.
In addition to your username and password, you can choose either your cell phone or email address as your second identification method when you sign in to or register for my Social Security.
Two forms of identification when signing in will help better protect your account from unauthorized use and potential identity fraud.
Each time you sign in to your account, you will complete two steps.
The first step is to enter your username and password.
The second step is to enter the security code Social Security sends by text message or email, depending on your choice.
Cell phone provider text message and data rates may apply if you choose to receive your one-time security code through text message.
If you choose to receive your one-time security code through email, you can add NO-REPLY@ssa.gov to your contact list to make sure it does not go into your spam or junk folder.
For additional tips to help you stay safe and secure online, please visit the Federal Trade Commission's OnGuard Online.
If you are unable or unwilling to create an online account, you may still create an account in person by visiting your local Social Security office.
Social Security offers you the choice to add extra security when you create an online account.
In the past, Social Security told you that it would never ask for your credit card number or other financial information.
Social Security has changed its policy for this one service.
Now, Social Security may ask you for the last eight digits of your Visa, MasterCard, or Discover credit card, or some other financial information.
Once you give Social Security this additional information, Social Security will send you a letter in the mail in five to 10 business days.
You will need this letter to complete the voluntary process to add extra security.
You can upgrade to extra security or disable it at any time.
Adding extra security does not change the way that you sign in to your account.
You must still sign in with your username, password, and a unique security code Social Security will provide each time you sign in.
Internet scam artists use clever phishing schemes to defraud millions of people each year.
Phishing is the practice of using social engineering techniques over email to trick a recipient into revealing personal information, clicking on a malicious link, or opening a malicious attachment.
Most emails from Social Security will come from a .gov email address.
If an email address does not end in .gov, use caution before opening attachments or clicking on pictures or links in the email.
Currently, Social Security sends emails from no-reply@ssa.gov, subscription.service@subscriptions.ssa.gov and ThankYou@ssa.gov.
In a few instances, Social Security uses marketing firms to raise awareness of Social Security's online services, including creating a my Social Security account.
Social Security allows these marketing firms to send email directly to individuals.
Any links you find within these emails should always point to a .gov/ web address.
Links, logos, or pictures in the body of an official Social Security email will always direct you to an official Social Security website.
To verify the web address of a link or picture, hover over it with your mouse until a text box appears with the web address.
The web address that appears in the text box is the actual address you will be directed to and it should always end in .gov/.
A forward slash should always follow the .gov domain.
An example of a valid web address is https://www.ssa.gov/myaccount/.
Links to the official Social Security website will always begin with https://www.socialsecurity.gov/ or https://secure.ssa.gov/.
Examples of fraudulent websites pretending to direct you to Social Security include https://www.socialsecurity.gov.gmx.de/ and http://www.socialsecurity.gov.bx.co.rx/setup.
If you are not certain that an email you received came from Social Security or one of its marketing firms, do not respond to the email or click on any links contained in the email message.
Report the incident by forwarding the suspicious email to the U.S. Computer Emergency Readiness Team US-CERT at phishing-report@us-cert.gov.
To verify the sender of an email, exercise caution when receiving email from a sender you don't know or haven't heard from in a long time.
Hover over the From email address to ensure it matches the displayed email or name of the sender.
Look for poor choices in wording, phrasing, or spelling in the email.
If an email includes a business name, telephone number, or website link, verify the legitimacy of these items by searching for the official number or website in a search engine.
Do not respond to emails requesting personal information.
Reputable businesses and public agencies will not ask you for personal information in an email.
To avoid security problems, please keep your web browser up to date.
For more information about phishing, go to OnGuard Online.

If you are divorced, but your marriage lasted 10 years or longer, you can receive benefits on your ex-spouse's record even if they have remarried if: You are unmarried; You are age 62 or older; Your ex-spouse is entitled to Social Security retirement or disability benefits; and The benefit you are entitled to receive based on your own work is less than the benefit you would receive based on your ex-spouse's work.
If you remarry, you generally cannot collect benefits on your former spouse's record unless your later marriage ends whether by death, divorce, or annulment.
If your ex-spouse has not applied for retirement benefits, but can qualify for them, you can receive benefits on their record if you have been divorced for at least two years.
If you are eligible for retirement benefits on your own record and divorced spouse's benefits, Social Security will pay the retirement benefit first.
If the benefit on your ex-spouse's record is higher, you will get an additional amount on your ex-spouse's record so that the combination of benefits equals that higher amount.
If you continue to work while receiving benefits, the retirement benefit earnings limit still applies.
If you are eligible for benefits this year and are still working, you can use Social Security's earnings test calculator to see how those earnings would affect your benefit payments.
If you will also receive a pension based on work not covered by Social Security, such as government work, your Social Security benefit on your ex-spouse's record may be affected.
The Social Security disability insurance program pays benefits to you and certain family members if you worked long enough and paid Social Security taxes.
Your adult child also may qualify for benefits on your earnings record if he or she has a disability that started before age 22.
The Supplemental Security Income (SSI) program pays benefits to disabled adults and children who have limited income and resources.
For most people, the medical requirements are the same under both the Social Security disability insurance program and the Supplemental Security Income (SSI) program.
Disability is determined by the same process under both the Social Security disability insurance program and the Supplemental Security Income (SSI) program.

If you apply for Social Security disability or Supplemental Security Income (SSI), you are asked for information about your medical condition, work, and education history to help decide if you are disabled under the rules.
Additional information about the Supplemental Security Income (SSI) program can be found at "What Is Supplemental Security Income?"
If you are an Advocate, Attorney, or Third Party Representative and you are helping someone prepare an online Social Security benefit application, there are some things you should know.
Disability is a subject you may read about in the newspaper.
You may not think of disability as something that might actually happen to you.
Your chances of becoming disabled are probably greater than you realize.
Studies show that just over one in four of today's 20-year-olds will become disabled before reaching age 67.
While we spend a lot of time working to succeed in our jobs and careers, few of us think about ensuring that we have a safety net to fall back on should we become disabled.
The Social Security program can provide valuable help to you in the area of disability.
The disability planner helps you find out how you can qualify and apply for benefits.
The disability planner helps you find out what happens if your application is approved.
The disability planner helps you find out who can receive benefits on your earnings record.
The disability planner helps you find out what you need to know about receiving disability benefits.
The disability planner helps you find out when Medicare coverage starts for Social Security disability beneficiaries.
The disability planner helps you find out what happens if you go back to work.
The Social Security program pays disability benefits under two programs: The Social Security disability insurance program and the Supplemental Security Income (SSI) program.
The Social Security disability insurance program pays benefits to you and certain family members if you worked long enough and paid Social Security taxes.
Your adult child also may qualify for benefits on your earnings record if he or she has a disability that started before age 22 under the Social Security disability insurance program.
The Supplemental Security Income (SSI) program pays benefits to disabled adults and children who have limited income and resources.
For most people, the medical requirements are the same under both the Social Security disability insurance program and the Supplemental Security Income (SSI) program.
Disability is determined by the same process under both the Social Security disability insurance program and the Supplemental Security Income (SSI) program.

Whether you apply for Social Security disability or Supplemental Security Income (SSI), the Social Security Administration asks you for information about your medical condition, work, and education history to help decide if you are disabled under their rules.
Additional information about Supplemental Security Income (SSI) can be found at "What Is Supplemental Security Income?"
If you are an Advocate, Attorney, or Third Party Representative and you are helping someone prepare an online Social Security benefit application, there are some things you should know.
Direct Deposit is a simple, safe, and secure way to get benefits.

If you need us to send your payment to a bank or credit union account, have all of the following information ready when you apply: Social Security number, Bank routing transit number, Account type (checking or savings), Account number.
You can set up or change your direct deposit of benefit payment online by logging in to your my Social Security account.

To set up or change direct deposit online, you need to: Log in to your my Social Security account, Select the blue Benefits & Payment Details link on the right side of the screen, Scroll down and select the Update Direct Deposit button, Choose if you are the owner or co-owner of the bank account, Enter your bank account information and select Next, Review and verify your banking information and select Submit, Select Done.
You can also decide when your change to direct deposit will take effect by using the My Profile tab within your my Social Security account.
Creating a free my Social Security account takes less than 10 minutes and lets you set up or change your direct deposit.
As of March 1, 2013, you are required to receive your Social Security or Supplemental Security Income (SSI) benefit payments electronically.
If you applied for Social Security or Supplemental Security Income (SSI) benefits before March 1, 2013 and did not sign up for electronic payments at that time, you are strongly urged to do so now.
If you don't have a bank account, you can visit the Treasury's Go Direct website or call the helpline at 1-800-333-1795 for information on switching to an electronic payment.

If you have questions or need help understanding how to set up or change direct deposit online, you can call the Social Security Administration's toll-free number at 1-800-772-1213 or visit your local Social Security office.
If you are deaf or hard of hearing, you can call the Social Security Administration's toll-free TTY number at 1-800-325-0778 between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. Monday through Friday.

You can also decide when your change to direct deposit will take effect by using the My Profile tab within your my Social Security account.
Creating a free my Social Security account takes less than 10 minutes and lets you set up or change your direct deposit.

If you applied for Social Security or Supplemental Security Income (SSI) benefits before March 1, 2013 and did not sign up for electronic payments at that time, you are strongly urged to do so now.
If you don't have a bank account, you can visit Treasury's Go Direct website at www.godirect.gov or call their helpline at 1-800-333-1795 for information on switching to an electronic payment.

If you have questions or need help understanding how to set up or change direct deposit online, you can call Social Security's toll-free number at 1-800-772-1213 or visit your local Social Security office.
If you are deaf or hard of hearing, you can call Social Security's toll-free TTY number at 1-800-325-0778 between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. Monday through Friday.
To create a my Social Security account, you will be asked to verify your identity by providing personal information about yourself and answering questions that only you are likely to know.
To create a my Social Security account, you will be asked to create a username and password you will use to access your online account.

To create a my Social Security account, you will be asked to confirm your email address or phone number by entering a one-time security code within 10 minutes of receiving it in order to help keep your personal information safe.
If you have a security freeze or fraud alert on your credit report, you can still open a my Social Security account by temporarily lifting it.

To open a my Social Security account if you have a security freeze or fraud alert on your credit report, you can contact the Identity Services Provider and request that they temporarily lift your security freeze or fraud alert.

To open a my Social Security account if you have a security freeze or fraud alert on your credit report, you can create a my Social Security account online after lifting the security freeze or fraud alert.

To open a my Social Security account if you have a security freeze or fraud alert on your credit report, you can reinstate the security freeze or fraud alert with the Identity Services Provider if needed.
When you request a temporary lift of your credit freeze or fraud alert, the Identity Services Provider may automatically reinstate it after your temporary lift expires.
If you do not want to temporarily lift your security freeze or fraud alert, you can visit your local Social Security office to open an account in person.
For more information on security freezes and fraud alerts, you can read the Federal Trade Commission's Credit Freeze FAQs.
Your personal my Social Security account is for your use only.
Social Security is dedicated to protecting the information and resources entrusted to it, including your personal information and investment.
For your protection, you are the only one who can create your personal my Social Security account for your own exclusive use.
No one can create or use a my Social Security account on your behalf, even with written permission.

You should not share the use of your my Social Security account with anyone else under any circumstances, as unauthorized use of this service is a misrepresentation of your identity to the federal government and could subject you to criminal or civil penalties, or both.

When you request a temporary lift of your credit freeze or fraud alert, the Identity Services Provider may automatically reinstate it after your temporary lift expires.
If you do not want to temporarily lift your security freeze or fraud alert, you can visit your local Social Security office to open an account in person.
For more information on security freezes and fraud alerts, you can read the Federal Trade Commission's Credit Freeze FAQs.

Our mission is to deliver Social Security services that meet the changing needs of the public.
It's not unusual for a benefit recipient's circumstances to change after they apply or became eligible for benefits.
If you, or a family member, receive Social Security or Supplemental Security Income (SSI), certain life changes may affect eligibility for an increase in your federal benefits.
If your spouse or ex-spouse dies, you may become eligible for a higher Social Security benefit.

To find out if you, or a family member, might be eligible for a benefit based on another person's work, or a higher benefit based on your own work, see the information about benefits on the Social Security website.
You can also use the Benefit Eligibility Screening Tool (BEST) to find out if you could get benefits that Social Security administers.
The Benefit Eligibility Screening Tool (BEST) will list benefits for which you might be eligible and tell you more information about how to qualify and apply based on your answers to questions.
If your spouse or ex-spouse has died, you may be eligible for a higher survivor benefit based on his or her work.
The death of an ex-spouse may allow you to be eligible for a higher survivor benefit even if you are already receiving a survivor benefit on another spouse.
If you are at least age 65, you may be eligible for cash benefits on your own record.
If you are full retirement age or older, you can work and receive your monthly Social Security benefits, no matter how much you earn.
If your child had enough work credits and was providing at least half of your support, you may be eligible for a higher parent's benefit based on his or her work.
If you have worked, you may be eligible for a higher retirement benefit based on your own work.
If you have worked, you may be eligible for a higher disability benefit based on your own work.
If you are at least 62 years old and unmarried, you may be eligible for a benefit based on a former spouse's work if that marriage lasted 10 years or more.
You may be eligible for spouse's benefits if you have in your care a child who is under age 16 or disabled prior to age 22.
Your child may be eligible for benefits based on your work.
If you served in the U.S. military, you may be eligible for benefits through the Veterans Administration.

If you are unmarried and under age 18 or were disabled prior to age 22, and your parent is deceased or receiving Social Security benefits, you may be eligible for child benefits based on your parent's work.
You may be able to get additional income through the Supplemental Security Income program, which helps seniors and the disabled who have limited income and financial resources.
If you are receiving benefits, there are certain life events that you are required to report.
Failure to report a change may result in an overpayment.
Our website is a valuable resource for information about all of Social Security's programs.
You can call Social Security toll-free at 1-800-772-1213.
Social Security treats all calls confidentially.
Social Security can answer specific questions from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m., Monday through Friday.
Generally, you'll have a shorter wait time if you call Social Security during the week after Tuesday.
Social Security can provide information by automated phone service 24 hours a day.
You can use Social Security's automated response system to tell them a new address or request a replacement Medicare card.
If you are deaf or hard of hearing, you may call Social Security's TTY number, 1-800-325-0778.
Social Security has a second representative monitor some telephone calls to ensure you receive accurate and courteous service.

The Social Security website is a valuable resource for information about all of Social Security's programs.
You can do a number of things online on the Social Security website.
You can call Social Security toll-free at 1-800-772-1213.
Social Security treats all calls confidentially.
Social Security can answer specific questions from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m., Monday through Friday.

Social Security retirement benefits are increased by a certain percentage depending on date of birth if you delay your retirement beyond full retirement age.
The benefit increase no longer applies when you reach age 70, even if you continue to delay taking benefits.
If you've already reached full retirement age, you can choose to start receiving benefits before the month you apply.
Social Security cannot pay retroactive benefits for any month before you reached full retirement age or more than 6 months in the past.
If you decide to delay your retirement, be sure to sign up for just Medicare at age 65.
If you do not sign up for Medicare at age 65, in some circumstances your Medicare coverage may be delayed and cost more.
Social Security is not recommending that you start your retirement benefits at age 62, your full retirement age, age 70, or any age in between.
The document provides additional information that may help you decide what's right for you regarding early or late retirement and retirement information for Medicare beneficiaries to consider.
Social Security retirement benefits are increased by a certain percentage depending on date of birth if you delay your retirement beyond full retirement age.
The benefit increase no longer applies when you reach age 70, even if you continue to delay taking benefits.
If you've already reached full retirement age, you can choose to start receiving Social Security retirement benefits before the month you apply.
Social Security cannot pay retroactive benefits for any month before you reached full retirement age or more than 6 months in the past.
If you decide to delay your retirement, be sure to sign up for just Medicare at age 65.
If you do not sign up for Medicare at age 65, in some circumstances your Medicare coverage may be delayed and cost more.

The Supplemental Security Income (SSI) program pays benefits to disabled adults and children who have limited income and resources.
The Supplemental Security Income (SSI) program pays benefits to people 65 and older without disabilities who meet the financial limits.
People who have worked long enough may also be able to receive Social Security disability or retirement benefits as well as Supplemental Security Income (SSI).
You can now file for Supplemental Security Income (SSI) online but only if you meet certain requirements.

You are eligible to file online for Supplemental Security Income (SSI) if you: Are between the ages of 18 and 65; Have never been married; Aren't blind; Are a U.S. citizen residing in one of the fifty states, District of Columbia, or the Northern Mariana Islands; Haven't applied for or received Supplemental Security Income (SSI) benefits in the past; and Are applying for Social Security Disability Insurance at the same time as your Supplemental Security Income (SSI) claim.
You can schedule an appointment with a local Social Security office to file an application for Supplemental Security Income (SSI).

You can call 1-800-772-1213 (TTY 1-800-325-0778) from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m., Monday through Friday or contact your local Social Security office to file an application for Supplemental Security Income (SSI).
Social Security does not yet have an online application for Children's benefits for Supplemental Security Income (SSI).
You can visit 'Apply For Disability Benefits Child Under Age 18' to apply for your child for Supplemental Security Income (SSI).
You can complete the online Child Disability Report if you are ready to apply now for Supplemental Security Income (SSI) for your child.
To apply for Supplemental Security Income (SSI) for a person age 65 and older, you can call 1-800-772-1213.
If you are deaf or hard of hearing, you can call TTY 1-800-325-0778 to apply for Supplemental Security Income (SSI) for a person age 65 and older.
You can visit your local Social Security office to apply for Supplemental Security Income (SSI) for a person age 65 and older.
If your Supplemental Security Income (SSI) application was recently denied, you can file an SSI appeal online.
You can create a my Social Security account if you already receive Supplemental Security Income (SSI) benefits.
The Supplemental Security Income (SSI) program pays benefits to disabled adults and children who have limited income and resources.
SSI benefits are also payable to people 65 and older without disabilities who meet the financial limits.

You can schedule an appointment with a local Social Security office to file an application for SSI.
You can call 1-800-772-1213 (TTY 1-800-325-0778) from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m., Monday through Friday or contact your local Social Security office to apply for SSI.
Social Security does not yet have an online application for Children's benefits.
You can complete the online Child Disability Report if you are ready to apply for SSI for a child with a disability.
To apply for SSI for a person age 65 and older, you can call 1-800-772-1213 or visit your local Social Security office.
If you are deaf or hard of hearing, you can call 1-800-325-0778 (TTY) to apply for SSI for a person age 65 and older.
If your SSI application was recently denied, you can file an SSI appeal online.
If you already receive SSI benefits, you can create a my Social Security account.
Full retirement age is the age at which a person may first become entitled to full or unreduced retirement benefits.
No matter what your full retirement age also called "normal retirement age" is, you may start receiving benefits as early as age 62 or as late as age 70.
You can retire at any time between age 62 and full retirement age.
If you start benefits early, your benefits are reduced a fraction of a percent for each month before your full retirement age.
The chart below lists age 62 reduction amounts and includes examples based on an estimated monthly benefit of $1000 at full retirement age.
Select your year of birth to find out how much your benefit will be reduced if you retire between age 62 and full retirement age.
There are advantages and disadvantages to taking your benefit before your full retirement age.
The advantage is that you collect benefits for a longer period of time.
The disadvantage is your benefit is reduced.
Each person's situation is different.

It is important to remember: if you delay your benefits until after full retirement age, you may be eligible for delayed retirement credits that would increase your monthly benefit; that there are other things to consider when making the correct decision about your retirement benefits; and to contact Social Security before you decide when to retire.

The disadvantage is your benefit is reduced.

In most cases, you will continue to receive benefits as long as you are disabled.
There are certain circumstances that may change your continuing eligibility for disability benefits.
Your health may improve to the point where you are no longer disabled.
You go back to work.
The law requires that we review your case from time to time to verify that you are still disabled.
We tell you if it is time to review your case.
We also keep you informed about your benefit status.
In general, your benefits will continue as long as you are disabled.
How often we review your case depends on whether your condition is expected to improve.
If medical improvement is expected, your case will normally be reviewed within six to 18 months after your benefits start.
If medical improvement is possible, your case will normally be reviewed no sooner than three years.
If medical improvement is not expected, your case will normally be reviewed no sooner than seven years.
Two things can cause us to decide that you are no longer disabled and to stop your benefits.
If you work at a level we consider substantial, we can decide that you are no longer disabled and stop your benefits.
In 2019, average earnings of $1,220 or more per month are usually considered substantial.
In 2019, average earnings of $2,040 or more per month if you are blind are usually considered substantial.
If we decide that your medical condition has improved to the point that you are no longer disabled, we can stop your benefits.
You are responsible for promptly reporting any improvement in your condition.
You are responsible for promptly reporting if you return to work.
The booklet we send you when your application is approved explains what you need to report to us.
If you're like most people, you would rather work than try to live on disability benefits.
There are special rules that help you keep your cash benefits and Medicare while you test your ability to work.
We call these rules "work incentives".
For more information about Social Security work incentives, read Working While Disabled: How We Can Help.
In most cases, you will continue to receive benefits as long as you are disabled.
However, there are certain circumstances that may change your continuing eligibility for disability benefits.
For example, your health may improve to the point where you are no longer disabled.
For example, you go back to work.
The law requires that the Social Security Administration review your case from time to time to verify that you are still disabled.
The Social Security Administration tells you if it is time to review your case.
The Social Security Administration also keeps you informed about your benefit status.
In general, your benefits will continue as long as you are disabled.
