If a student answers 'No' to the FAFSA questions concerning being homeless, the student should contact the student's financial aid office to explain the student's situation.
Homeless means lacking fixed or regular housing.
A student may be homeless if the student is living in shelters, parks, motels, hotels, cars, or temporarily living with someone else because the student has nowhere else to go.
If a student answered 'Yes' to one or more of the dependency status questions, then for federal student aid purposes, the student is considered to be an independent student.
If a student is considered an independent student, the student will not provide information about the student's parents on the FAFSA form.
If a student answered 'No' to every dependency status question, then for federal student aid purposes, the student is considered to be a dependent student.
If a student is considered a dependent student, the student must provide information about the student's parents on the FAFSA form.
Not living with parents or not being claimed by parents on tax forms does not make a student an independent student for purposes of applying for federal student aid.
Law school students and health profession students may be required to provide parent information regardless of their dependency status.
The parent information is used in determining eligibility for programs such as Health Professions Student Loans from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.
The 'Am I Dependent or Independent? Worksheet' is a resource to help students determine their dependency status when filling out the FAFSA form.
If a student's legal parents are married to each other, the student should report information about both of them on the student's FAFSA form.
If a student's legal parents are not married to each other and live together, the student should report information about both of them on the student's FAFSA form.

A student's legal parents are the student's biological or adoptive parents, or the student's parents as determined by the state (for example, if the parent is listed on the student's birth certificate).
The 'Who's My Parent When I Fill Out My FAFSA?' graphic helps dependent students determine which parent's information to include on the FAFSA form.
If a student does not live with the student's parents, the student still must answer the questions about the student's parents if the student is considered a dependent student.

If a student's parents are not going to help the student pay for college and refuse to provide information for the student's FAFSA form, the student cannot be considered independent of the student's parents just because they refuse to help with this process.
If a student does not provide the student's parents' information on the FAFSA form, the application will be considered rejected, and the student might not be able to receive any federal student aid.

If a student does not provide the student's parents' information on the FAFSA form, the most the student would be able to get (depending on what the financial aid office at the student's college decides) would be a loan called an unsubsidized loan.
The FAFSA instructions will tell a student what to do if the student's parents are not supporting the student and will not provide their information.

If a student has no contact with the student's parents and does not know where they live, or the student has left home due to an abusive situation, the student should fill out the FAFSA form and then immediately get in touch with the financial aid office at the college or career school the student plans to attend.
The financial aid staff will tell a student what to do next if the student has special circumstances that prevent the student from providing parent information on the FAFSA form.
This is a request for supplemental information in connection with your application for a Federal Direct PLUS Loan through the William D. Ford Federal Direct Loan Program.
Some schools may have a different process for obtaining the additional information needed to process your Direct PLUS Loan application.
The information that you provide will be sent to the school that you select.
The school you select will use the information collected to determine your eligibility for a Direct PLUS Loan and process your application.

Before you can receive a Direct PLUS Loan, you must complete a Direct PLUS Loan Master Promissory Note, which explains all of the terms and conditions of Direct PLUS Loans and constitutes your legally binding agreement to repay all Direct PLUS Loans that you receive under the Direct PLUS Loan Master Promissory Note.
You will have an opportunity to complete the Direct PLUS Loan Master Promissory Note after you complete the Direct PLUS Loan Request.
The Direct PLUS Loan Application allows you to authorize the school to use your loan funds to satisfy other educationally related charges after tuition and fees, and room and board have been paid.
You are not required to provide this authorization.
If you have placed a security freeze on your credit file, you must lift or remove the freeze at each credit bureau before you continue.
Your application will not be processed if you have a security freeze.
You or your business must register and title at a DMV office any vehicle you own or lease.
Registrations don't need to be in the owner's name, or for only one person.
Auto dealers can register and title vehicles, and issue plates and charge a fee for this.
You must register your vehicle at the DMV within 180 days of the effective date on your insurance ID card.
To register a vehicle, you need to bring the original title or other proof of ownership.
To register a vehicle, you need to bring the current NY State Insurance ID card for auto liability insurance.
To register a vehicle, you need to bring the bill of sale and proof of sales tax payment / sales tax form.
To register a vehicle, you need to bring your NY State driver license, permit, non-driver ID, or other proof of identity.
To register a vehicle, you need to bring payment for fees and taxes or proof of an exemption.
To register a vehicle, you need to bring a Vehicle Registration Application (PDF MV-82).
If you register for a business or organization, you also need to bring proof of incorporation.
For quicker service, you can make a reservation online before visiting DMV offices in certain counties.
When you register a vehicle, the DMV will give or mail you 1 or 2 vehicle plates unless you transfer a registration from another vehicle registered in New York.
When you register a vehicle, the DMV will give or mail you a registration window sticker.
When you register a vehicle, the DMV will give or mail you a registration document.
When you register a vehicle, the DMV will give or mail you a 10-day inspection extension sticker if you did not get the vehicle from a New York State auto dealer.
If applicable, the DMV will also send you a new title certificate within 90 days when you register a vehicle.
All vehicles registered in New York State must get a safety inspection at a DMV-licensed inspection station every 12 months.
All vehicles registered in New York State must get a safety inspection when the ownership of the vehicle is transferred.
The fees for registering a vehicle depend on the vehicle weight and where you live.
First-time registration fees normally include the sales tax, a vehicle plate fee or registration transfer fee, a title certificate fee in most counties, and a vehicle use tax.
First-time registration fees normally include either a 1 or 2 year registration fee, depending on the type of registration.
You can estimate the registration fees you will need to pay.

The DMV accepts cash, most credit, pinless debit or prepaid cards, American Express, Discover Card / Novus, MasterCard, VISA, a personal check or a money order payable to the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles as payment for registration fees.
You can split your payment between cash and check if you need to.
You do not need to be a United States resident to register a vehicle in New York as long as you meet the registration requirements.
In an effort to protect consumers, the DMV would like to inform you about New York State laws pertaining to vehicle identification numbers (VINs) on vehicles or motorcycles.
Most vehicles must comply with California emission standards.
The DMV shares information about vehicle registrations.
Your insurance company will give you 2 barcoded original NY State Insurance ID cards or provide you with access to your digital electronic NY State Insurance ID Card.
Your insurance company will send an electronic notice of insurance coverage to the DMV.
Your NY State Insurance ID cards and the electronic notice together verify your insurance coverage.
You must register your vehicle within 180 days of the effective date on your Insurance ID Card.
You need to bring one copy or form of your Insurance ID Card with you when registering a vehicle.
The DMV office will keep the paper Insurance ID Card you provide.
You need to keep the other paper Insurance ID Card with the vehicle as your proof of insurance.
Anyone operating your vehicle must be able to provide proof of insurance.

For vehicles model year 1973 or newer, you need to provide either a NY State Certificate of Title (original or certified copy, not a photocopy) with the transfer ownership section completed by the seller, or acceptable proof of ownership from another state (original or certified copy, not a photocopy).

For vehicles model year 1972 or older, you need to provide either a NY State Transferable Registration (original or certified copy, not a photocopy) and bill of sale, or acceptable proof of ownership from another state (original or certified copy, not a photocopy).

You can use the Vehicle Bill of Sale (PDF MV-912) form, or create your own bill of sale that includes the vehicle year and make, vehicle ID number (VIN) or hull ID (HIN), date of the sale, purchase price, and names and signatures of buyer and seller.
You need to provide a bill of sale even if you got the vehicle as a gift.
If you bought your vehicle from another person in a private sale, both you (the buyer) and the seller must complete the sales tax form at NY State Department of Tax and Finance (DTF-802).
The DMV calculates the sales tax and issues a payment receipt.

If you were not a resident of New York when you purchased the vehicle, you can use the Claim for Sales and Use Tax Exemption Title / Registration Motor Vehicle, Trailer, All-Terrain Vehicle (ATV), Vessel (Boat), or Snowmobile (Sales Tax Form PDF DTF-803) at NY State Department of Tax & Finance to receive a non-resident exemption from NY State sales tax.
You must be at least 16 years old to register a vehicle, except for ATV and boat registrations.
You can use a New York State driver license, learner permit, or non-driver ID card that is current or expired less than 2 years as proof of identity and age when registering a vehicle.
If you don't have a NY State driver license, learner permit, or non-driver ID card, you can use other kinds of proof of identity and age when registering a vehicle.
The 10-day inspection extension sticker allows you 10 days from the registration date to get the vehicle inspected in New York.
Any New York State or out-of-state inspection issued to the previous registrant is not valid after the vehicle is registered to you.
You must get the vehicle inspected after registering it.

As of September 27, 2019, the Driver Improvement Unit is reviewing applications that were received by mail on or before the following dates: Regular Applications less than 3 - July 18, 2019, Multiple Alcohol Applications 3 or more - July 22, 2019.
A serious traffic offense or multiple offenses can result in the revocation of your NY State driver license or driving privilege.
A revocation means your NY State driver license is cancelled, and you must apply for a new NY State driver license once the revocation period is over.
You may also be required to take the written and driving tests again after a revocation of your NY State driver license.
For most revocations, you must first request and receive approval from the DMV Driver Improvement Unit (DIU) before you can apply for a new driver license at a DMV office.
If you are licensed in another state, you must obtain approval from DIU to have your NY State driving privilege restored.
DIU must examine your full driver record to see if you can be approved under NY State laws and requirements.
The fastest and easiest way to request approval is online, although some drivers with complex records may need to submit their request to DIU in writing.
If you request approval online, the system will automatically determine if you are eligible to submit an online request.
If you are not eligible to submit an online request, the system will list the reason you are not eligible and explain your next steps.
If you are eligible to submit an online request, the system will explain any additional payments or actions required before you can receive approval.
If you are eligible to submit an online request, the system will issue your approval immediately if you are eligible.
The processing of mailed requests can take up to 12 weeks.
You cannot request approval online if you were never issued a New York State driver license, learner permit, or non-driver ID.
You cannot request approval online if your revocation was for an uninsured accident. You must contact the DMV Insurance Services Bureau in this case.

You cannot request approval online if, as part of a reexamination of your ability to safely operate a motor vehicle, you were required to take a DMV road test and your driver license was revoked because you failed the road test. In this case, you must contact your local DMV office.

You cannot request approval online if you have a valid or suspended conditional or restricted license or a current or former participant in the Impaired Driver Program. In this case, you must apply at a local Motor Vehicle office when you are eligible to receive your full license back.
You cannot request approval online if your last full driver license issued was a Commercial Driver License (CDL).
You cannot request approval online if your revocation was a result of a conviction arising out of a fatal crash.
You cannot request approval online if your revocation was a result of a conviction arising out of a Penal Law violation.
Before you can request approval online, you must wait until the revocation period has been completely served before you submit your request.

Before you can request approval online, you must resolve and clear any suspensions, including answering or paying fines imposed for traffic tickets. You cannot receive approval if your license is suspended as well as revoked.
To check if your license is suspended, you must sign up for MyDMV and use the MyLicense service.
Before you can request approval online, you must sign up for a MyDMV account.
To sign up for a MyDMV account, you must have the ID number from your NY State driver license, permit or non-driver ID.
You do not need to provide your photo document number to sign up for a MyDMV account.
Your Social Security Number (SSN) must be on file with the NY State DMV to sign up for a MyDMV account.
Before you can request approval online, you must be prepared to pay a re-application fee, if required, by credit or debit card. The system will tell you the amount you must pay.

If you owe any of the following fines or penalties, they must be paid before you can submit your request for approval online: suspension termination fee, driver license civil penalty, Driver Responsibility Assessment.

If you begin to request approval online and owe additional fees or penalties, you will receive instructions for submitting payment. After you submit payment, you can complete your request for approval online.

If your sentence from a court includes serving a term of probation and the conditions include restrictions on reapplying for a license/privilege, you must provide certain documentation before you can request approval online.

The required documentation for probation conditions restricting license reapplication includes: a copy of your conditions of probation and a letter granting permission to apply for a driver license from the court that sentenced you or from the probation office that you must report to, with the letter on court or probation letterhead; or if your probation was terminated, a letter from the court/probation department on their letterhead stating the date your probation was terminated; or if the conditions of your probation do not include driving restriction, a copy of the conditions.
You must mail or fax the required probation documentation to DIU before you can complete your request for restoration online after it is received by DIU.

If you have two or more alcohol/drugged driving convictions in 25 years, you are required to complete an alcohol evaluation and/or treatment within one year from the date of the final review before you can request approval online.
Your alcohol evaluation and/or treatment provider must electronically notify DMV of your successful completion. Paper proof submitted by you will not be accepted.

You can find acceptable alcohol evaluation and treatment providers within NY State by accessing the NY State Office of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse Services (OASAS) website and searching for approved providers.

For alcohol evaluation and treatment services provided outside of New York State, the provider must be on the approved list of providers on the Substance Abuse & Mental Health Service Administration (SAMHSA) website.
Alcohol evaluation and treatment providers will need form DS-449 Alcohol and Drug Abuse Rehabilitation Program Summary, which they can obtain from the Driver Improvement Unit.

If you owe any DMV fees (suspension termination fee, civil penalty or Driver Responsibility Assessment), they must be paid before applying for a license or the processing of your application will be delayed.

If you are currently suspended for failing to pay child support, you must contact your local child support collection unit to make a payment and have the suspension cleared before you can proceed with applying for a new driver license.

By law, DMV cannot clear a child support suspension unless directed to do so by the Office of Temporary Disability (OTDA). Once OTDA electronically notifies DMV to clear the suspension, you may continue with submitting your online request for relicensing.

If you are currently suspended for failing to pay New York State taxes, you must contact the NY State Department of Tax and Finance (DTF) or call their number to make a payment and have the suspension cleared before you can proceed with applying for a new driver license.

By law, DMV cannot clear a delinquent tax suspension unless directed to do so by DTF. Once DTF electronically notifies DMV to clear the suspension, you may continue with submitting your online request for relicensing.

If you are currently suspended for failing to file an acceptable accident report with DMV, you must fax a completed Report of Motor Vehicle Accident form MV-104 to the provided fax number before you can proceed with applying for a new driver license.
Once the Report of Motor Vehicle Accident form is processed, you may continue with submitting your online request for relicensing.
If you have open traffic tickets or owe fines to a court, you must contact the court of record, address the outstanding tickets, and pay all fines before you may apply for a license.
Once the court notifies DMV that the tickets have been satisfied, you may continue with submitting your online request for relicensing.
Any additional convictions of moving violations or other incidents added to your driving record can make you ineligible for approval or may delay the approval process.
After you receive approval to apply for a new driver license via email, you must follow the directions in the email to be successful when applying at your local DMV office.

If you are licensed by another state and receive approval for restoration of your NY State driving privilege via email, you may resume driving in NY State if you have a valid out-of-state driver license.
For revoked NY State driver license holders who were approved for relicensing following a revocation, you cannot drive until your new NY State driver license is issued by a DMV issuing office.
You may be required to take vision, written and/or road tests to qualify for a new license after being approved for relicensing following a revocation.
To request approval online, you must first create a MyDMV account.

To create a MyDMV account, you will need your New York State Driver License, Permit or Non-Driver ID and your Social Security Number. It is very important that you read the instructions on the website for applying online before you begin.
If you request approval by mail, it can take up to 12 weeks for DIU to process your request.
If you request approval by mail, you must wait until 30 days before the revocation period ends to send your request.

If you need to request approval to apply for a new license by mail, you must complete an Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card (MV-44), leaving the 'I am applying for' boxes blank.
If you do not know your NY State driver license number when requesting approval by mail, you can leave that box blank on the MV-44 form.

If you reside out-of-state and need to request that your NY State driving privilege be restored, you must complete the Request for NY State Driving Privileges form (DS-115) and mail it to the Driver Improvement Unit.

If you are convicted of a moving violation or another incident that affects your New York State driving record after you send your request by mail, you may become ineligible for approval or need to wait longer for processing.
A $100 re-application fee must accompany your driver license application (MV-44 form) or request for reinstatement of driving privileges when requesting approval by mail.
The $100 re-application fee may be paid by check or money order made payable to the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles when requesting approval by mail.

If you apply for restoration by mail and owe any suspension termination fee, driver license civil penalty, or Driver Responsibility Assessment, they must be paid before your application can be approved.

To apply for a new license after revocation by mail, you must submit a completed Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card (MV-44), a non-refundable $100 fee, and any pertinent additional documentation.

The additional documentation may include: a copy of your conditions of probation and a letter granting permission to apply for a license, a letter stating the date your probation was terminated if applicable, proof of completing required alcohol evaluation and treatment if you have multiple alcohol/drug convictions, payment of any owed DMV fees, proof of clearing suspensions for unpaid child support/taxes/accident reports/traffic tickets, etc.
Your application and documentation should be mailed to the Driver Improvement Unit at the provided address.

The Driver Improvement Unit (DIU) will make a determination based on your lifetime driving record and mail you a response with instructions on your next steps, whether your application is denied or approved.

Motorists who have previously held licenses/permits from other states or had alcohol/drug convictions in other states will be sent an additional form to complete and return to DIU before a final review can be completed.

If your driver license application is denied by DIU, you have four options: 1) Accept the denial and take no further action, 2) Request reconsideration of the denial within 60 days by submitting the required form and documentation, 3) Submit an appeal of your revocation to the DMV Appeals Board within 60 days, or 4) Submit another application for re-licensure, subject to the $100 fee.
If you request reconsideration of a denial, you may submit documentation of any unusual, extenuating and compelling circumstances only once per relicensing application.
To request reconsideration, you must explain in detail each circumstance and provide credible, verifiable documentation from third parties to support your claims.
If you do not provide credible, verifiable documentation for each circumstance claimed in a request for reconsideration, your request will be denied.
Unusual, extenuating and compelling circumstances alone do not warrant granting an approval if your driving history indicates a continued risk to highway safety.
Requests for reconsideration after denial must be submitted to the Driver Improvement Bureau within 60 days of the date of your denial letter. Late requests will not be considered.

To submit an appeal of your revocation to the DMV Appeals Board, you must mail the appeal form, your appeal, and a copy of your denial letter to the Appeals Board within 60 days of the denial letter date.
Appeal requests received after 60 days will be rejected by the Appeals Board.
By law, the Appeals Board cannot consider an appeal filed after 60 days or review arguments/claims not first submitted to the Driver Improvement Bureau.
Do not submit claims of unusual, extenuating and compelling circumstances to the Appeals Board.

You may submit another application for re-licensure to the Driver Improvement Unit at any time, subject to the $100 fee, but be aware it will be reviewed under the same standards that resulted in the previous denial.
If your driver license application is approved by DIU, you will receive an approval packet with instructions specific to you.
Follow the instructions in the approval packet to apply for your new driver license.
Depending on your record, you may be approved with a Problem Driver Restriction and an Ignition Interlock Device (IID) requirement.
You may be required to install and maintain an IID on any vehicles you own or operate before going to the DMV office to apply for your permit/license.

To apply for your permit/license after approval, bring the required items from the approval packet to any local DMV office, including the approval notice, completed MV-44 form, IID installation confirmation, proof of identity, and Social Security card.
The Problem Driver Restriction and IID requirement is authorized under regulations and requires you to have an IID installed for 5 years in any vehicle you own or operate.
After relicensing, you cannot drive any vehicle without the IID installed except during employment hours if required for your job, with documentation from your employer.

Drivers with an A2 Problem Driver restriction can only operate a vehicle to/from employment/education, during employment/education if required, to/from medical appointments, to/from DMV offices for license amendments, and to/from childcare necessary for employment, for 5 years.
Any violations/convictions during the 5-year period may result in withdrawal of approval and denial of future restoration requests.
If licensed in another state and approved for NY driving privilege restoration, you may resume driving in NY with a valid out-of-state license.
Additional convictions or incidents added to your record can make you ineligible for approval or delay the process, regardless of applying for a NY license or driving privilege.
To request restoration of a driving privilege if licensed out-of-state, you must request approval by mail from the Insurance Services Bureau at the provided address.

VA mental health services allow you to find out how to access services for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), psychological effects of military sexual trauma (MST), depression, grief, anxiety, and other needs.
You can use some VA mental health services even if you are not enrolled in VA health care.
If you are a Veteran in crisis or concerned about one, you can connect with the Veterans Crisis Line responders for confidential help.
Many of the Veterans Crisis Line responders are Veterans themselves.
The Veterans Crisis Line service is private, free, and available 24/7.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night, you can call 800-273-8255, then select 1.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night, you can start a confidential Veterans chat.
To connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder anytime day or night, you can text 838255.
If you have hearing loss, you can call TTY: 800-799-4889 to connect with a Veterans Crisis Line responder.
You can also call 911 if you are a Veteran in crisis.
You can also go to the nearest emergency room if you are a Veteran in crisis.
You can also go directly to your nearest VA medical center if you are a Veteran in crisis.
It does not matter what your discharge status is or if you are enrolled in VA health care to access help for being a Veteran in crisis.
You can get free mental health care for a year after separation no matter your discharge status, service history, or eligibility for VA health care.
If you need support for a specific mental health problem or if you are having problems sleeping, controlling your anger, or readjusting to civilian life, you are not alone and VA can help.
To access free VA mental health services right away, you can call or walk in to any VA medical center anytime, day or night.
To access free VA mental health services right away, you can find your nearest VA health facility.
To access free VA mental health services right away, you can call or walk in to any Vet Center during clinic hours.
To access free VA mental health services right away, you can find your nearest Vet Center.
To access free VA mental health services right away, you can call 1-877-222-VETS (1-877-222-8387).
The VA phone number 1-877-222-VETS (1-877-222-8387) is available Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. ET.
If you have hearing loss, you can call TTY: 1-800-877-8339 to access free VA mental health services right away.
You do not need to be enrolled in VA health care to get VA mental health care.
To connect with other resources for Veterans and transitioning service members, you can visit the Department of Defense (DoD) Military OneSource website.
To connect with other resources for Veterans and transitioning service members, you can visit the VA mental health site for transitioning service members.
To connect with other resources for Veterans and transitioning service members, you can read about the VA's commitment to supporting transitioning Veterans.
If you need support for a specific mental health problem or if you are having problems sleeping, controlling your anger, or readjusting to civilian life, you are not alone and VA can help.
Over 1.7 million Veterans received mental health services at VA last year.
VA mental health services range from peer support with other Veterans to counseling, therapy, medication, or a combination of these options.
The goal of VA mental health services is to help you take charge of your treatment and live a full and meaningful life.
If you are already using VA medical services, you can ask your primary care provider to help you make an appointment with a VA mental health provider to schedule your first appointment.
If you are not already using VA medical services, you can contact your nearest VA medical center or Vet Center to talk about your needs and schedule your first appointment.
If you are not sure what kind of help you need, you can call 877-222-8387 to find the right resources for your needs.
The VA phone number 877-222-8387 is available Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. ET.
If you have hearing loss, you can call TTY: 800-877-8339 if you are not sure what kind of help you need.
You may be able to use one or more of the VA's online care options if it is hard for you to get to a VA facility in person.
The Veteran Training online self-help portal allows you to use tools to help manage your anger, develop parenting and problem-solving skills, and more.
The tools on the Veteran Training online self-help portal are based on proven mental health practices that have successfully helped other Veterans and families.
The Veteran Training online self-help portal is free, and you do not have to sign in or provide any personal information to use the tools.
VA has partnered with the Department of Defense (DoD) to create free smartphone applications you can use to help manage your physical and mental health.
The VA smartphone applications include apps to help you deal with stress, quit smoking, and more.

If you are enrolled in VA health care, you can ask any of your providers to help connect you with the VA telemental health program to connect with a VA mental health provider through a computer or mobile device.

The BeThere peer assistance program, in partnership with Military OneSource, offers support to service members including National Guard soldiers and Reservists, their families, and transitioning Veterans up to 365 days after separation or retirement.
Through the BeThere peer assistance program, you can talk privately with peer coaches who are Veterans, service members, or military spouses.
To talk with a peer coach through the BeThere peer assistance program, you can call Military OneSource's free, confidential peer support services at 800-342-9647.
The Military OneSource peer support services are available 24 hours a day, 365 days a year.
If you are a combat Veteran, you can visit one of the VA Vet Centers to get free individual and group counseling for you and your family.
You can access Vet Center services even if you are not enrolled in VA health care and are not receiving disability compensation.
Vet Center services include military sexual trauma (MST) counseling, readjustment counseling, bereavement grief counseling, employment counseling, and substance abuse assessment and referral.
You can call 877-927-8387 to talk with a fellow combat Veteran about your experiences, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year.
If you would like to connect with other Veterans, families, and local services, you can visit the VA's Make the Connection website.
The Make the Connection website connects millions of Veterans, and their family members and friends, to local VA and community mental health resources.
The Make the Connection website allows you to access referral resources and hear Veteran testimonials of strength and recovery.
Being diagnosed with a mental health condition or seeking mental health care does not automatically put work-related credentials, such as security clearances, at risk.

Most employers recognize that healthy employees who get help when they need it are more productive and effective in their jobs than those who are not performing at their best because they are not feeling well.
If you do not qualify for VA health care, you may still be able to get certain health care services, like care for needs linked to military sexual trauma.
You can call the VA general hotline at 800-827-1000 to find out what your care options may be if you do not qualify for VA health care.
The VA general hotline at 800-827-1000 is available Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. ET.

If you do not qualify for VA health care, you can get free private counseling, alcohol and drug assessment, and other support for combat Veterans and families at one of the VA's 300 community Vet Centers.
If you do not qualify for VA health care, you can contact the National Call Center for Homeless Veterans at 877-424-3838 for help 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
A trained VA counselor at the National Call Center for Homeless Veterans will offer information about VA homelessness programs, health care, and other services in your area.
The call to the National Call Center for Homeless Veterans is free and confidential.
If you do not qualify for VA health care, you can call or visit your local VA Community Resource and Referral Center.
Even if you do not qualify for VA health care, the staff at the VA Community Resource and Referral Centers can help you find non-VA resources you may qualify for in your community.
You can apply for VA health care to access more services if you do not qualify for VA health care.
To learn more about whether you are eligible for VA services, you can call your nearest VA medical center.
To learn more about whether you are eligible for VA services, you can call 877-222-8387 to find the right resource for your needs.
If you have hearing loss, you can call TTY: 800-877-8339 to learn more about whether you are eligible for VA services.
The VA phone number 877-222-8387 is available Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. ET.
You will start receiving help the day you reach out to VA for mental health services.
VA offers same-day services to make sure they can either address your mental health needs or schedule the right follow-up care right away.
The specific care you receive from VA will depend on how urgent your needs are and the level of treatment you are looking for.
Same-day VA mental health services may include meeting face-to-face with a VA health care provider, including walk-in appointments at a clinic or urgent care center.
Same-day VA mental health services may include having a telehealth or video care appointment with a VA provider.
Same-day VA mental health services may include talking by phone with a VA nurse who can offer medical advice (called nurse triage).
Same-day VA mental health services may include communicating with a VA provider through Secure Messaging.
Same-day VA mental health services may include scheduling a future appointment.
Same-day VA mental health services may include getting a prescription filled.

VA offers treatment and support for a range of mental health problems, including posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), depression, thoughts of suicide, issues related to military sexual trauma (MST), substance use problems, bipolar disorder, and schizophrenia.
VA also treats anxiety-related conditions, such as generalized anxiety disorder, panic disorder, social anxiety, and specific phobias.
VA mental health services include short-term, inpatient care for Veterans with severe or life-threatening mental illness.
VA mental health services include outpatient care for Veterans with serious mental illness who have a lot of trouble functioning in daily life.

VA mental health services include regular outpatient care, which may include care provided over the phone, for Veterans facing a difficult time in their lives who would be best helped by getting treatment or living in a structured setting for a period of time.

VA mental health services include rehabilitation treatment and residential live-in programs for Veterans with mental health problems and other needs like those related to homelessness, job training, and education.
VA mental health services include primary care for many common mental and behavioral problems to help Veterans join the work force and live well in the community.
VA mental health services include supported work settings.
VA also provides care to Veterans in crisis, including emergency mental health care 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, through VA medical centers and some local, non-VA hospitals.
VA also provides care to Veterans in crisis through the Veterans Crisis Line, which offers support 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, for Veterans in crisis and their families and friends.

In addition to online resources, caregiver support coordinators at your nearest VA medical center and a caregiver peer support mentoring program can help connect caregivers to one another for support and learning.
To get support as a caregiver, you can find a local caregiver support coordinator.
To get support as a caregiver, you can call the Caregiver Support Line at 855-260-3274, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m.
You can contact the VA's Coaching into Care program to speak directly with a licensed psychologist or social worker, free of charge.

The licensed psychologists or social workers in the Coaching into Care program can provide information about mental health and VA services, as well as tips for how to begin the conversation about treatment with a loved one.
To reach a licensed psychologist or social worker through the Coaching into Care program, you can contact Coaching into Care online.
To reach a licensed psychologist or social worker through the Coaching into Care program, you can call 888-823-7458, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m.
You can use the VA facility locator to search for VA health facilities near you.
Military OneSource provides expert support to connect military personnel and their families with the best available resources to fit their needs.
For support from Military OneSource, you can visit the Military OneSource website or call 800-342-9647 anytime, day or night.
The Psychological Health Resource Center works to improve the lives of Veterans, service members, and their families by advancing excellence in psychological health care, readiness, and prevention.
The National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is a 24/7, 365-day-a-year emergency mental health hotline that offers support for people experiencing a mental health crisis.
To reach the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline, you can start an online chat.
To reach the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline, you can call 800-273-8255.
The American Foundation for Suicide Prevention provides mental health resources for people struggling with thoughts of suicide.
The American Foundation for Suicide Prevention also offers supportive educational tools for concerned family, friends and peers.

The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) offers free, confidential help with treatment referral and information services for individuals and families facing mental health and/or substance use disorders.
Support from SAMHSA is available 24/7, 365-days-a-year, in both English and Spanish.
To reach SAMHSA's National Helpline, you can call 1-800-662-HELP (800-662-4357).

The National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) builds better lives for millions of Americans affected by mental illness by providing education programs for families and individuals living with mental health problems.
The Jed Foundation works closely with teenagers and young adults who may be experiencing mental stress or may be at risk for suicide during times of change.
Mental Health America advocates for policies that promote mental health and the rights of people living with mental health problems.
Mental Health America also provides education and connections to mental health resources.
VA health care covers regular checkups with your primary care provider.
VA health care covers appointments with specialists like cardiologists, gynecologists, and mental health providers.
VA health care provides access to Veterans health care services like home health and geriatric elder care.
VA health care provides medical equipment, prosthetics, and prescriptions.
The National Call Center for Homeless Veterans offers help 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
The National Call Center for Homeless Veterans allows you to talk privately with a trained VA counselor for free.
You can contact your nearest VA medical center and ask to talk with the VA social worker.
If you are a female Veteran, you can ask for the Women Veterans Program Manager at the nearest VA medical center.
The Veterans Crisis Line responders provide confidential help for Veterans in crisis or concerned about one.
Many of the Veterans Crisis Line responders are Veterans themselves.
The Veterans Crisis Line service is private, free, and available 24/7.
You can chat online with a trained VA staff member through the Veterans Crisis Line.
VA health benefits cover how VA health care works and which Veterans health care services are covered.
VA health benefits eligibility determines if you are eligible for Veterans health care benefits and how priority groups work.
VA Form 10-10EZ allows you to start your Veterans health care application online.
After applying for VA health care, you can find out when to expect a decision on your application and what to do next.
Family and caregiver health benefits determine if you qualify for VA medical benefits as a spouse, surviving spouse, dependent child, or caregiver.
You can order a prescription refill and track your shipment online through VA.
VA Secure Messaging allows you to communicate privately with your VA health care team.
You can schedule and view your VA appointments by phone, online, or through Secure Messaging.
You can view, download, and print your VA lab and test results.
You can order hearing aid batteries and prosthetic socks online for home delivery through VA.
VA Blue Button allows you to set up your personal health record and download reports to share with your VA and non-VA doctors.
VA Form 10-10EZR allows you to update your personal, financial, or insurance information after you are enrolled in the VA health care program.
You can pay your VA copay bill securely online, by phone or mail, or in person.
If you are struggling to make VA copay payments, you can find out what to do.
You can check the status of an open VA health care appeal.
You can find out how to apply for reimbursement for your travel to a VA health facility.
VA health care copay rates provide information on current copay rates for different types of care, tests, and medications.
VA mental health services allow you to access care for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), psychological effects of military sexual trauma (MST), depression, grief, anxiety, and other needs.
VA provides care for specific needs like women's health, and information about service-related health concerns like Agent Orange-related diseases or Camp Lejeune water contamination.
VA provides information on health concerns linked to exposures during military service.
VA health registries allow you to join and document your exposure to Agent Orange, depleted uranium, ionizing radiation, airborne hazards, and other hazardous materials.
VA offers programs to help you get and stay healthy in both body and mind.
If you are enrolled in VA health care, you may be able to receive care from a provider in your local community through community care.
The Affordable Care Act (ACA) provides information on what you need to know about the ACA and what it means for Veterans.
The Million Veteran Program allows you to be a part of a voluntary research study to better understand the role genes play in health.
VA provides information about your VA facility, like how quickly you can be seen and what other Veterans say about their experiences.
VA patient rights and responsibilities outline your basic rights and responsibilities when you receive care at a VA health facility or live in a VA community living center.
VA disability compensation pay allows you to file a claim for disability compensation and manage your disability benefits.
VA life insurance provides options and information on how to apply as a service member, Veteran, or family member.
VA aid and attendance benefits and housebound allowance determine if you can get increased pension pay as a Veteran or surviving spouse who has disabilities.
VA burial benefits and memorial items provide information on Veterans burial benefits, how to plan a burial service, and how to get compensation as a survivor.
VA education and training benefits allow you to apply for and manage GI Bill and other education benefits to help pay for college and training programs.
The MISSION Act aims to make it easier for you to get health care through VA facilities, mobile clinics, telehealth, and community providers.
Manage Your Retirement Benefits is the title of the document.
Successfully filing for retirement benefits isn't the end of your Social Security journey.
The document has resources to save you time on important retirement tasks.
The document has resources to keep you in control of your Social Security account benefits through a free my Social Security account.
A free my Social Security account makes it easy to manage your information.
You can create a my Social Security account.
The document has sections on understanding your benefits, informing Social Security of changes, using Social Security's resources and services, and keeping your information secure.
Effectively managing your retirement benefits is an ongoing part of retired life.
Understanding what you're entitled to, staying up to date on program changes, and making sure Social Security has your current information is a solid foundation for managing your retirement benefits.
You can help ensure you get the retirement benefits you should by reviewing the basics like how Social Security determines your benefit amount and who else in your family might be eligible.
You can visit Social Security's Learn About Retirement Benefits page to make sure you know the basics of retirement benefits.

You can stay up to date on the latest Social Security information by subscribing to Social Security's Social Security Matters blog, checking annual Cost-of-Living Adjustments (COLA) updates, subscribing to Social Security's Email Digest, and creating a personal my Social Security account.
The Social Security Matters blog provides tips, tools, and updates on Social Security issues important to you.
The Cost-of-Living Adjustments (COLA) updates inform you about any impact to your monthly benefit amount.
The Email Digest provides information on policy changes, agency news, and notifications on important events.
A personal my Social Security account allows you to receive important notices online through the Message Center.
The Message Center is a secure, convenient portal where you can receive sensitive communications that Social Security doesn't send through email or text.
You can explore the benefits you may be due and benefits for your family on Social Security's website.
The document has frequently asked questions (FAQs) about what a my Social Security online account is and how to get one, and how to sign up for Medicare.
You should remember to tell Social Security whenever there's a change in your life circumstance that could affect your benefits.

Common changes to notify Social Security about include moving, getting married or divorced, changing your name, adopting a child, no longer caring for a child who receives benefits, a change in non-citizen status, starting to get a pension from work not covered by Social Security, leaving the United States for more than 30 days, becoming unable to manage your funds, being convicted of a criminal offense, and the death of a beneficiary.
If you already receive Social Security benefits, you can update much of your information online with your personal my Social Security account.
If you need to make a change that cannot be done through my Social Security, you can contact Social Security for additional support.
The document provides information on how Social Security can help you when a family member dies.
The document has frequently asked questions (FAQs) about how to change your address and what to do when someone dies.

The document lists Social Security's most popular online services, including checking your application status, setting up or changing direct deposit, getting a proof of income letter, getting a Social Security 1099 (SSA-1099) form, requesting a replacement Social Security card, opting out of certain mailed notices, and advanced designation of representative payee.
Social Security continues to expand the services available online.
You can visit Social Security's online services page to see a complete list of services, including the newest services to help you manage your information.
You can search Social Security's comprehensive FAQs section for help with specific retirement issues.
If you need help with managing your benefits and cannot find the answer or service on Social Security's website, you can visit their contact us page for other ways to get support.
Identity theft affects millions of people each year and can cause serious financial and identity-related problems.
You should protect yourself by securing your personal information, taking the time to understand the threat of identity theft, and exercising caution.
Social Security is diligently working at national, regional, and local levels to combat fraud that undermines their mission to serve the American public.

You can take steps to help protect your personal information, such as not routinely carrying your Social Security card, never saying your Social Security number aloud in public, being aware of phishing scams (emails, internet links, texts, and phone calls) that try to trick you into revealing personal information, and creating a my Social Security account to help you keep track of your records.
You can visit Social Security's 'If You Want Extra Security' page to learn about extra verification steps they can add to your account.

If you receive a suspicious call from someone claiming to be from Social Security, you should hang up and then report details of the call to the Office of the Inspector General by submitting a report online.
The document provides additional information on protecting personal information, fraud prevention and reporting, and legal enforcement and financial penalties.

The document has frequently asked questions (FAQs) about what to do if you get a call claiming there's a problem with your Social Security number or account, and how Social Security protects your identity when you use a my Social Security account.
Your registration is the sticker placed on your windshield.
Your registration is the paper registration certificate that you must keep in your vehicle.
You or your business must register and title at a DMV office any vehicle you own or lease.
Registrations do not need to be in the owner's name, or for only one person.
Auto dealers can register and title vehicles.
Auto dealers can issue plates.
Auto dealers can charge a fee for registering and titling vehicles.
You can renew your registration online.
You can print a 10 day document to use until your new registration arrives in the mail when renewing online.
If your vehicle has been altered or stretched to increase the number of passengers, you cannot renew your registration online.
If there are other special circumstances, you cannot renew your registration online.
You can change your address for your vehicle registration.
You can change your name or other information for your vehicle registration.
You can check the status of your vehicle registration.
You can replace your vehicle registration and get a temporary document.
You can surrender return plates and cancel your vehicle registration.
You can tell DMV if your new registration has not come in the mail.
You can transfer a registration to another vehicle you own.
There is information on registration suspensions due to parking tickets.
There is information on registration suspensions due to toll violations.
There is information on registration suspensions due to insurance lapses.
You must register any vehicle owned by you or your business at a DMV office.
There is general information about registering a vehicle.
There are specific requirements for different vehicle types when registering a vehicle.
You must complete DMV's Document Guide to make sure you have the correct proofs of identification and other documents before you come to the DMV to register a vehicle.
There is information about registering agricultural and farm vehicles.
There is information about registering a vehicle for a deceased owner.
There is information about registering homemade vehicles and trailers.
There is information about registering imported vehicles.
There is information about registering a vehicle with more than one owner or registrant.
There is information about registering a vehicle with no title for a newly purchased vehicle.
There is information about registering pick-up trucks as passenger class vehicles.
There is information about registering a vehicle for someone else.
There is information about registering a vehicle while you are out-of-state.
There is information about registering an out-of-state vehicle.
There is information about abandoned and unclaimed vehicles.
There is information about applying for Clean Pass.
There is information about motorized devices that cannot be registered in New York.
There is information about power of attorney for vehicle registration.
There is information about transferring vehicle ownership to another person.
There is information about vehicle modifications and registration class.
There is information about salvage vehicles.
There are resources for businesses regulated by DMV, such as inspection stations, dealers, transporters, and repair shops.
There is information to determine if a car was flooded or stolen.
There is information if a family member has died regarding vehicle registration.
There are military and veteran's resources regarding vehicle registration.
There is information about moving to New York or out of New York regarding vehicle registration.
There are tips for buying a vehicle.
DMV does not handle parking violations or regulate parking.
If you receive a parking ticket, you must respond to the locality where they were issued, not DMV.
If you fail to answer parking tickets, the locality can notify the DMV which can prevent the renewal of your vehicle registration, or suspend your vehicle registration.
There is a list of local traffic courts in New York State.

The vehicle types that must be registered if driven on a public road include cars, SUVs, vans, pick-up trucks, motorcycles, trailers, custom and homemade trailers, agricultural and farm vehicles, boats, ATVs, mopeds, and snowmobiles.
There are some motorized devices that cannot be registered in New York.
When you surrender your vehicle plates to the DMV, you may be eligible to transfer the remaining registration credit to another vehicle you want to register.
When you surrender your vehicle plates to the DMV, you may be eligible to get a refund for the registration fee.
You get a refund or registration transfer credit for your vehicle plate fee.
You get a refund or registration transfer credit for the title certificate fee you paid when you registered the vehicle.
You get a refund or registration transfer credit for any other fee or tax.
If you transfer your remaining registration to another vehicle, your new registration will expire the same day as your old registration.
You can only use the transfer credit for a new original registration.
You cannot use the transfer credit for a registration renewal.
Here is an example to show how your refund amount is determined.
You paid $137.50 to register your vehicle for two years.
The amount you paid included $62.50 for the two years of the registration ($31.25 per year).
The amount you paid included $50.00 for the title certificate.
The amount you paid included $25.00 for the vehicle plates.
You surrender the vehicle plates during the first year of the registration.
You qualify for a refund of $30.25 when you surrender the vehicle plates during the first year of the registration.
The refund of $30.25 is a refund of the $31.25 fee for the second year of the registration with the $1 processing fee subtracted.
There is no refund of other fees or taxes.
When you surrender your plates, your Receipt FS-6T indicates if you are eligible to receive a refund.
If you are eligible for a refund and you do not request a transfer receipt, the DMV will process your refund automatically and you will receive it in the mail in several weeks.
If you are not eligible for a refund or you request a transfer receipt, the DMV office issues a Receipt FS-6T that you can use to transfer the registration to another vehicle.
You can apply for a refund of the 2-year registration fee ONLY if the registration was never used and it is not more than 60 days from the date the registration was issued.
For example, if you renewed the registration but never used the new registration sticker, you can apply for a refund of the 2-year fee that you paid when you renewed the registration.
A processing fee of $1 is subtracted from the refund amount for a 2-year refund.
The registration sticker cannot be used if you apply for a full 2-year refund.
If the sticker was attached to the windshield or the vehicle plate, you cannot remove the sticker and apply for a full refund.
To apply for a full 2-year refund, you must surrender the vehicle plates and the unused registration sticker and stub at a DMV office and request a 2-year refund.
If eligible for the 2-year refund, the DMV office will issue a receipt that displays "two year refund".

If you have already received a refund for the 2nd year of the registration fee and you have the UNUSED registration sticker and stub, you may be eligible to apply for the 1st year of the registration fee.
You have a maximum of 60 days after the date the registration was issued to apply for the 1st year of the registration fee.

To apply for a refund of the first-year registration fee, you must send the following items to the address on the Request for Refund MV-215 form: a completed and signed Request for Refund MV-215, the original registration document stub, the unused registration sticker.
The DMV will process a refund of the first-year fee if eligible.
You can get a refund if you changed your name.

To get a refund if you changed your name, you must follow these instructions: surrender the vehicle plates at a DMV office and request a transfer receipt (not a refund receipt), send these items to the address on the Request for Refund MV-215 form: completed and signed Request for Refund MV-215, proof that the name has changed (a photocopy of the marriage certificate, the divorce documents or other court papers), the transfer receipt.
The DMV will issue your refund in your new name, if eligible.
It is possible to get a refund if the registrant died.
To get a refund if the registrant died, the DMV will issue the refund to the name of the estate.

To get a refund if the registrant died, you must follow these instructions: surrender the vehicle plates at a DMV office and request a transfer receipt (not a refund receipt), have the executor of the deceased's will send these items to the address listed on the Request for Refund MV-215: completed and signed Request for Refund MV-215 with "deceased" written on the form, a photocopy of the death certificate, the transfer receipt.
If the estate of the registrant is settled, you must call the DMV Revenue Accounting Unit at 518-474-0902 to request a 'Next of Kin' form.
If the estate of the registrant is settled, you must send the 'Next of Kin' form, Request for Refund MV-215 and the transfer receipt to the address on form MV-215.
The refund is issued in the name of the next of kin if the estate of the registrant is settled.
You are only eligible for a full refund if the registration sticker is unused.
If the sticker was attached to the windshield or the vehicle plate, you CANNOT remove the sticker and apply for a refund.
You can appeal a Traffic Violations Bureau (TVB) conviction online or by mail.
You must file your appeal within 30 days of the date of conviction.
You must pay a $10 non refundable appeal fee for each conviction appealed within 30 days of the date of conviction.
Your submission of an appeal online or by mail does not mean that your appeal has been accepted.
The DMV Appeals Board must determine that your appeal meets legal requirements.
You can appeal online if you have been convicted in a NYS Traffic Violations Bureau (TVB) for a traffic offense.
The conviction occurred within the last 30 days.
The traffic ticket must display the words "Traffic Violations Bureau" at the bottom.
If the traffic ticket does not display the words "Traffic Violations Bureau" at the bottom, you cannot file an appeal with the Department of Motor Vehicles.
At the end of the online transaction, you will get a 3-digit Appeal Access number.
You can use the 3-digit Appeal Access number later to check the status of your appeal.
You can appeal one transaction conviction online at a time.
To appeal online, you will need the TVB traffic ticket number from your conviction.
A sample traffic ticket is provided.
To appeal online, you will need either your DMV ID Number or Client ID Number from your NYS driver license, learner permit or non-driver photo ID card.
A sample driver license is provided.
To appeal online, you will need your full name, date of birth, and gender as they appear on the traffic ticket.
To appeal online, you will need your mailing address.
Please note that any address you enter for the appeal will not automatically update your DMV driver license or vehicle records.
To appeal online, you will need an explanation of the valid reasons for your appeal, which is called an "Appeal Argument".
If an attorney will represent you in the appeal, you will need to provide the attorney's name and mailing address.
If you request a stay of a suspension or revocation that resulted from the conviction, you will need to provide a written "Stay Argument".
You must notify the DMV Appeals Board in writing immediately of any change of address that occurs after an appeal is filed.
You can mail DMV any exhibits or arguments that cannot be submitted online.
Evidence, exhibits or documents not submitted to and considered by the hearing officer may not be filed with the appeal.
You cannot cancel your online appeal transaction after you verify your information or submit your payment.
You cannot edit your original Appeal Argument or any Additional Appeal Arguments after you submit online.
If you request a transcript to be reviewed for your online appeal, you may submit an additional Appeal Argument.
The Additional Argument must be submitted within 30 days after the transcript you ordered has been sent to you from the Transcriber.

To submit an Additional Argument after receiving your transcript, you need to access the transaction again and enter either the ticket number, your DMV ID Number or Client ID Number from your NYS driver license, learner permit or non-driver photo ID card, or your name, date of birth, and 3-digit Appeal Access Number.
To appeal by mail, you need to use the Traffic Violations Bureau Appeal (AA-33) form.
To appeal by mail, you need to mail your appeal and $10 appeal fee to DMV Appeals Board, P.O. Box 2935, Albany, NY 12220-0935.
To appeal a DMV determination other than a TVB conviction or penalty, you need to use the Appeal From DMV Hearing Determination (AA-33A) form.
You cannot appeal a TVB conviction by phone.
You cannot submit an appeal at a TVB office.
The Appeals Board will acknowledge receipt of your appeal form and fee with a letter.
You can use the TVB Traffic Ticket Appeal service to check the status of your appeal filed online.

To check the status of your appeal filed online, you will need to provide the ticket number, your DMV ID Number or Client ID Number from your NYS driver license, learner permit or non-driver photo ID card, or your name, date of birth, and 3-digit Appeal Access Number.
Your appeal fee is not refundable, whether your appeal is rejected, or the conviction or penalty is affirmed, reversed, remanded, or modified.

The DMV Appeals Board will reject your appeal if your appeal form and fee are not filed in a timely manner, your appeal does not meet the requirements of NYS law, the matter is not legally allowed to be appealed, or you fail to meet DMV requirements for appeals.

For default convictions, you can appeal the denial of your application to reopen the default conviction only after the DMV TVB Default Unit has denied your Application to Reopen a Default Conviction (AA-3.3).
You cannot appeal convictions that occurred in a local court, resulted from a parking ticket, or resulted from a criminal violation with the Department of Motor Vehicles.
You must appeal these kinds of penalties and convictions with the local court or parking violations authority.
The Stay Argument must explain the reasons why you need a stay.
Filing an appeal does not change your obligation to pay the fine, surcharge, or other fees.
The DMV will not grant a stay of a suspension for failure to pay a fine, surcharge or suspension termination fee.
To submit exhibits or arguments that cannot be submitted through the online transaction, you need to mail them to the DMV Appeals Board.

If you submit the additional exhibits and/or arguments at the time you file the appeal online, you need to check the box in the transaction that indicates that you will mail additional exhibits and/or arguments for your appeal.
If you order a transcript for your appeal, you must mail the additional arguments to the Appeals Board within 30 days after the transcript you ordered has been sent to you.
If you do not want or need a transcript, you must mail the exhibits and/or arguments within 10 days of the day you submit your appeal.
Evidence, exhibits or documents not submitted to and considered by the hearing officer may not be filed with the appeal.
The Appeals Board uses the US Postal Service postmark, if legible, to determine if your documents are timely.
You need to keep your proof of mailing and a copy of anything you send to the Appeals Board.
You need to write the summons number of the appealed ticket on the front of the envelope and on all exhibits and/or arguments.
You need to mail your documents to DMV Appeals Board, P.O. Box 2935, Albany, NY 12220-0935.
If you do not want to file an appeal online, you need to use the Traffic Violations Bureau Appeal (AA-33) form.
To appeal a DMV determination other than a TVB conviction or penalty, you need to use the Appeal Form (AA-33A).
You need to mail your appeal and fee to DMV Appeals Board, P.O. Box 2935, Albany, NY 12220-0935.
Many DMV customers make easily avoidable mistakes.
These mistakes cause DMV customers significant problems.
These mistakes include encounters with law enforcement.
These mistakes include impounded vehicles.
DMV is issuing a list of the top five DMV mistakes and how to avoid them.
Forgetting to Update Address is one of the top five DMV mistakes.
By statute, you must report a change of address to DMV within ten days of moving.
This is the case for the address associated with your license.
This is also the case for the addresses associated with each registered vehicle, which may differ.
It is not sufficient to only write your new address on the back of your old license.
It is not sufficient to only tell the United States Postal Service.
It is not sufficient to only inform the police officer writing you a ticket.
If you fail to keep your address current, you will miss a suspension order.
If you fail to keep your address current, you may be charged with operating an unregistered vehicle.
Operating an unregistered vehicle is a misdemeanor.
If you fail to keep your address current, you may be charged with aggravated unlicensed operation.
Aggravated unlicensed operation is a misdemeanor.
This really happens, but the good news is this is a problem that is easily avoidable.
Leaving the State Without Notifying DMV is one of the top five DMV mistakes.
States communicate with each other.
When you move to another state, be sure to tie up any loose ends regarding your New York State license or registration.
Tying up loose ends means resolving any unanswered tickets.
Tying up loose ends means resolving any suspensions.
Tying up loose ends means resolving any revocations.
Tying up loose ends means surrendering your license plates to NYS when you get to your new home state.
A license suspension or revocation in New York State could mean that your new home state will not issue you a license there.
It is important to notify DMV of your new address so that any possible mail correspondence can reach you.
Turning in your plates is important to avoid an insurance lapse.
Letting Insurance Lapse is one of the top five DMV mistakes.
New York State requires every motorist to maintain auto insurance every single day a vehicle is registered.
DMV works with insurance companies to electronically monitor your insurance coverage.
DMV knows when insurance coverage is dropped for any reason.
When insurance coverage is dropped, DMV mails you an insurance inquiry letter to allow you to clear up the problem.
DMV sends 500,000 insurance inquiry letters a year.
If the insurance inquiry letter does not resolve the problem, DMV must suspend the vehicle registration.
If the insurance problem persists after suspending the vehicle registration, DMV must suspend your driver license.
DMV suspends 300,000 registrations a year for failure to maintain insurance.
If you fail to maintain an updated address with DMV, you won't learn that you have an insurance problem.
If you fail to maintain an updated address with DMV, DMV will suspend your registration and license.
Make sure you turn in your vehicle's license plates at DMV before you cancel your insurance policy.
Insurance policies must be from a company licensed in New York State.
Understanding how Much Traffic Points Cost is one of the top five DMV mistakes.
DMV maintains a point system to track dangerous drivers.
Often, motorists convicted of a traffic ticket feel they have resolved all their motoring issues with the local court.
However, motorists later learn that the Driver Responsibility Assessment (DRA) is a separate DMV charge based on the total points they accumulate.
The $300 DRA fee can be paid in $100 annual installments over three years.
Motorists who fail to maintain an updated address with DMV may resolve their tickets with the court.
However, motorists who fail to maintain an updated address with DMV may never receive their DRA assessment because DMV does not have their new address on record.
Failure to pay the DRA will result in a suspended license.
Not Bringing Proper Documentation to DMV Office is one of the top five DMV mistakes.
About ten percent of customers visiting a DMV office do not bring what they need to complete their transaction.
These customers have to come back a second time to finish their business.
This can be as simple as not bringing sufficient funds to pay for a license renewal.
This can also be not having the proof of auto insurance required to register a car.
It is better to not visit a DMV office at all, and see if your transaction can be performed online.
Transactions that can be performed online include an address change.
Transactions that can be performed online include a registration renewal.
Transactions that can be performed online include a license renewal.
Transactions that can be performed online include replacing a lost title.
Transactions that can be performed online include paying a DRA.
Transactions that can be performed online include scheduling a road test.
DMV's award-winning website is recognized as one of the best in the nation.
DMV's website has all the answers you need to efficiently perform any DMV transaction.
Consider signing up for DMV's MyDMV service, which offers even more benefits.
Driving School Licenses are issued to businesses that qualify to operate a driving school.
These licenses are renewed for two years.
The license must be renewed before the expiration date shown on the license if the driving school wants to continue to operate the business.
Driving School Licenses can be renewed up to six 6 months after they expire.
The Driving School business cannot operate unless the license is valid.
Your application for renewal of a Driving School License must be submitted between 30 and 60 days before the license expires.
The expiration date is printed on your license.

As part of the renewal process, you must provide updated information about your driving school including: Driving School Renewal Application form MV-522, Proof of Worker's Compensation form C-105.2 or U-26.3, Disability Benefits Insurance Coverage form DB-120.1, OR a Certificate of Attestation of Exemption of Worker's Compensation and Disability Benefits Insurance Coverage form CE-200.
Payment of the license fee must be included.
You must include a check or money order for the renewal fee as identified on the application, payable to Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
Starter Checks cannot be accepted.
If your school uses vehicles for instruction, you must attach a List of Driving School Vehicles form MV-527.
If your school provides the Pre-licensing Course, you must attach a Signature Authorization List - Pre-Licensing Course form MV-278.6.
If your Driving School License expires, you must immediately stop operating your driving school business.
Your school will not be licensed to operate if your Driving School License expires.

Any services you provide through your driving school license including Instructor Certificates, account to DMV's online road test appointment scheduling system, and authorization to order Pre-Licensing Course Completion Certificates will be terminated if your Driving School License expires.
Until your new license is issued, your instructors will not be able to teach for your school if your Driving School License expires.

Until your new license is issued, your school will be unable to provide lessons to customers, teach the Pre-licensing Course if your school was approved to teach this, schedule road tests or bring customers to a road test if your Driving School License expires.
You can renew the license up to 6 months after the previous license expires.
Any operation of your business between when your driving school license expired and the new license is issued will constitute unlicensed operation of a driving school.
Unlicensed operation of a driving school could result in your having to pay a civil penalty of $1,000 and/or denial of future driving school license applications.
You must surrender your New York State vehicle plates to the New York DMV if you want to register your vehicle in another state.
You must surrender your New York State vehicle plates to the New York DMV before you end the vehicle's liability insurance coverage.
If you do not turn in your plate, the New York DMV will suspend your registration and can suspend your driver license.
If you need to surrender plates from another state, you need to surrender them to that state's DMV not the New York State DMV.

To surrender New York State plates by mail, you must remove plates and stickers including the plate frames and fasteners, complete the Plate Surrender Application PD-7 PDF for each set of plates you are surrendering, and mail the application with your plates to NYS DMV 6 Empire State Plaza Room B240 Albany, NY 12228.
The New York DMV uses the mail postmark date as the date that you surrendered your plates when surrendering by mail.
To be notified by the US Postal Service that the New York DMV received your plates when surrendering by mail, send them by registered or certified mail, and request a return receipt.
The New York DMV will mail you your FS-6 T receipt when surrendering plates by mail.

To surrender New York State plates at a DMV Office, you must remove plates and stickers including the plate frames and fasteners, complete the Plate Surrender Application PD-7 PDF for each set of plates you are surrendering, and bring the plates and PD-7 to a DMV Office.
County motor vehicle offices in New York will charge you a $1 fee to process the surrender of plates at a DMV Office.
If another person surrenders your plates for you at a DMV Office, make sure that the person gives you the FS-6 T receipt for your records.
Whether you will receive a refund when surrendering plates in New York depends on the registrations refunds for surrendered plates.
