You can surrender your plates temporarily in New York by following the special procedures to surrender plates for a season.
It is not necessary to surrender motorcycle plates in New York, but your motorcycle must be insured if you ride it.
You must surrender trailer plates in New York if the trailer does not have a valid registration, even though some trailers are not required to have liability insurance.
If your plates in New York are lost, destroyed or stolen, you need to report plates that are lost, stolen or destroyed and surrender the registration.
In cases where plates in New York are lost, destroyed or stolen, the DMV can issue you a new registration and plates.
For motorcycles in New York, you do not need to surrender motorcycle plates if there is a lapse in the liability insurance coverage, as a motorcycle must have liability insurance to be operated.
For trailers in New York, the DMV will not suspend your driver license or registration if you fail to surrender the plate, as normally a trailer does not need liability insurance.
The New York DMV recommends that you surrender any type of vehicle plate when the plate is not used to make sure that the plate is destroyed.
The Drinking Driver Program (DDP) is now called the Impaired Driver Program (IDP).
As the new name Impaired Driver Program (IDP) is being implemented, you may see the two names Drinking Driver Program (DDP) and Impaired Driver Program (IDP) interchangeably.
If you are convicted of an alcohol or drug-related driving violation in New York State, your license or privilege to drive in New York State will be revoked or suspended.

You may be eligible for a conditional license or a conditional driving privilege if you participate in New York State's Impaired Driver Program (IDP) (previously known as Drinking Driving Program (DDP)) or an approved out-of-state program.

Your Order of Suspension or Revocation from the Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) will indicate a nearby state or county motor vehicle office where you may enroll in the Impaired Driver Program (IDP) and apply for a conditional license/privilege, if applicable.
Your license suspension or revocation officially begins at your hearing or sentencing in court, unless the court gives you a Continuation of Driving Privileges (MV-1192).
Your credit for serving the suspension or revocation begins on the effective date of the Order of Suspension or Revocation.
If you receive a Continuation of Driving Privileges (MV-1192), your suspension or revocation will begin 20 days after sentencing.
It is a criminal offense to drive a motor vehicle while your license is suspended or revoked.
If you are convicted of driving under suspension or revocation, you may be fined and you may be sentenced to jail and/or probation.
If you are convicted of driving under suspension or revocation, the police may impound the vehicle you were driving when arrested.

If you are placed on probation because of a conviction of driving under suspension or revocation, you also must bring written permission from the sentencing court, or your probation officer, that allows you to apply for a license.

If you are convicted of Driving While Intoxicated (DWI), Driving While Ability Impaired (DWAI) or Driving While Ability Impaired by Drugs, or if you are found to have refused to submit to a chemical test, you will be required to pay a driver responsibility assessment each year for the next three years.
Participation in the Impaired Driver Program (IDP) will not prevent, reduce, or delay fines, fees, or penalties imposed under the driver responsibility assessment program.
DIAL-IN is a service for regularly searching DMV records for driver license, registration, vehicle title or insurance information.
The typical clients for DIAL-IN include attorneys, insurance and private investigators, process servers and building/site security personnel.
The Drivers Privacy Protection Act (DPPA) provides information about permissible uses of DMV records.

To apply for a DIAL-IN search account, one should complete the Motor Vehicle Record Search Account Application form (MV-15D) and send it to the Data Services - New Search Account at the NYS Department of Motor Vehicles.
If the DIAL-IN search account application is incomplete, it will be returned with an explanation and more instructions.
If the DIAL-IN search account application is complete, an account will be created and the account number and password will be sent to the applicant.
The DIAL-IN search account number is a seven-digit number that will never change.
According to the NYS Vehicle and Traffic Law, fees must be charged for searching DMV records using a DIAL-IN search account.
Private persons, commercial organizations, and not-for-profit organizations must pay a search fee of $7.00 for each search made with the DIAL-IN service.

Public organizations, their officers, volunteer fire companies, volunteer ambulance services, legal aid bureaus or societies, or other private entities acting pursuant to section 722 of the New York State County Law that make a search for a public purpose are exempt from the DIAL-IN search fee.
Paying customers for DIAL-IN search accounts must include a deposit with the application to cover two months of searches.
The deposit for a DIAL-IN search account is added to the account balance when the application is accepted.
Search fees for DIAL-IN searches are subtracted from the account balance.
Payment by credit card is not available for DIAL-IN search accounts at this time.
The DIAL-IN search account can be used to pay for mail-order and online searches.
If a fee must be paid for the DIAL-IN service, the account records will reflect debits, credits, and the account balance.
Information about escrow accounts for DIAL-IN search accounts is available on the Escrow Accounts page.
Business records that exist prior to performing a DIAL-IN search and establish the business purpose of the search must be kept.
Examples of business records include invoices, retainer agreements, employment applications, consent forms, accident reports, surveillance reports, and other types of records.
The Terms of Service of the DIAL-IN Search Account require maintaining business records and providing them to DMV when requested.
DMV may inquire about DIAL-IN searches performed to monitor compliance with the Terms of Service.
A response to a DMV inquiry about a DIAL-IN search must be provided, whether or not business records supporting the search exist.
If business records are not provided in response to a DMV inquiry about a DIAL-IN search, the response will be considered incomplete.
If a DIAL-IN search was performed on behalf of a client, permissible use of the client and the client-agent relationship must be shown.
If none of the known users of a DIAL-IN account performed the search inquired about by DMV, DMV must be contacted immediately.
If a response is not provided to a DMV inquiry about a DIAL-IN search, the search privileges will be suspended until a response is provided.
Records of DIAL-IN searches are public records.

If a motorist asks DMV if their records were searched, DMV will provide the name and business address of the DIAL-IN account holder, the time, date, and search criteria used to search for the records.
DMV does not disclose the DIAL-IN account numbers of account holders that performed searches.
To contact DMV about a DIAL-IN Search Account, one can write to NYSDMV DIAL-IN Accounts, Room 231, 6 Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228, call 473-2137, or email dialin@dmv.ny.gov.
DMV is upgrading its security protocols to better protect data.

To verify browser compatibility for using New York State government websites, one should visit https://encryption.ny.gov/ and update the browser to the newest version if it is not currently compatible.
You must obey the learner permit restrictions on where and when you may drive.
You must complete a 5-hour Pre-licensing Course or a high school or college Driver Education Course.
You must get an appropriate amount of supervised driving practice.
If you are under age 18, you must wait at least six months from the date you received your learner permit to schedule your road test.
The Pre-licensing Course is a DMV-approved, standardized classroom course that provides knowledge you will need as a new driver.

The Pre-licensing Course covers many important topics, including driving within the highway transportation system, driver habits and skills, feelings, attitudes and risk taking, alcohol, other drugs and driving.
You can find the Pre-licensing Course curriculum and other information in the Pre-Licensing Course Instructor's Manual MV-277.
The Pre-licensing Course is available through high schools, colleges, and many driving schools.
To find providers of the Pre-licensing Course in your area, look online or in your telephone directory for Driving Instruction.
When you successfully complete the Pre-licensing Course, you will be given a Pre-licensing Course Certificate MV-278.
If you complete a high school or college driver education course, you will receive a Student Certificate of Completion MV-285, and you do not need a Pre-licensing Course Certificate.
You must have either a Pre-licensing Course Certificate or a Student Certificate of Completion to schedule your road test.
You must bring the original certificate to your road test to turn in to the license examiner.
Your Pre-licensing Course Certificate is valid for one year from the date it is issued.
A Student Certificate of Completion is valid for two years.
If your Pre-licensing Course Certificate expires, you must complete the course again to receive the certificate required to schedule a road test.
Your certificate must be valid on the date that you make your Road Test appointment, but can be expired on the date you take your road test.
You do not need a Pre-licensing Course Certificate or a Student Certificate of Completion if you have a valid NY State driver license and you apply to amend to another license Class.

If you are under age 18, before you take your road test you must have a minimum of 50 hours of supervised practice driving with at least 15 hours at night after sunset and at least 10 hours in moderate to heavy traffic.
You must bring to the road test a Certification of Supervised Driving MV-262 completed by your parent or guardian to certify that you have had the required hours of supervised practice driving.
You must give the MV-262 to the license examiner each time you take a road test.
It is recommended that all drivers of all ages have the required amount and type of practice driving.
It is also recommended that you take a driver education course or professional driving lessons.
There are additional requirements for motorcycle permits. See Get a motorcycle license.
For your road test, you should practice steering smoothly whether you are driving straight ahead, turning or backing up.
For your road test, you should practice accelerating smoothly and moderately without racing the engine or causing it to stall.
For your road test, you should practice braking gently and bringing the vehicle to a stop in the proper position of the lane.
For your road test, you should practice being sure your vehicle is in the correct gear and shifting into the proper gear at the right time without grinding the gears.
For your road test, you should practice obeying the posted speed limit and adjusting your speed properly due to weather, road, visibility and traffic conditions.
For your road test, you should practice keeping an adequate space cushion between your vehicle and those you are following using the two second rule.
For your road test, you should practice increasing your following distance in poor weather or visibility.
For your road test, you should practice knowing the meanings of traffic signs, signals and pavement markings, and obeying them consistently.
For your road test, you should practice stopping your vehicle before it reaches an intersecting street, and before stop lines or crosswalks if present.

For your road test, you should practice keeping your vehicle in the proper traffic lane, especially when preparing to make turns, and not allowing room for another vehicle to pass you on the side that you are turning toward.
For your road test, you should practice letting other drivers and pedestrians know which way you want to go by using your directional signals or horn consistently and at the proper times.

For your road test, you should practice looking for and identifying potential problems or hazards in the traffic around you, not just straight ahead, but behind you and on either side, by checking your mirrors frequently and looking over your shoulder behind you when changing lanes or backing up.
For your road test, you should practice anticipating possible driving errors by others and being ready to react safely to make up for their mistakes.
If you have a Class DJ or MJ learner permit, you must have a minimum of 50 hours of supervised practice driving that includes at least 15 hours of driving after sunset before you take a road test.
If you have a Class DJ or MJ learner permit, you must bring to the road test a completed Certification of Supervised Driving MV-262 signed by your parent or guardian.
If you lose your Certification of Supervised Driving, you must contact the school that issued it to obtain a replacement.
Use both the registration fee and county use tax charts to determine your registration fee and county use tax.
If this is the original registration of your vehicle, you must pay the fees for your vehicle plates $25.00 your title certificate fee of $50.00 the sales tax.
The fees listed in the chart are for commercial vehicles that weigh less than 18,000 lbs.
Diesel-powered commercial vehicles that weigh 8,501 pounds or more require an additional fee.
If you transfer vehicle plates for one vehicle to another, you cannot use this chart to calculate your fee.
Residents of New York City and several counties in New York must pay a vehicle use tax when they register a commercial vehicle or renew a commercial vehicle registration.
The DMV collects the taxes for New York City and the counties.
If you reside outside New York City and you are exempt from the vehicle use tax in the county where you reside or have a business, complete form UT-11C.
If you reside in New York City and you are exempt from the New York City vehicle use tax, get form UT-11 from a local DMV office or a DMV Call Center.

For New York City (Bronx, Kings (Brooklyn), New York (Manhattan), Queens, Richmond (Staten Island)), all passenger vehicle original registrations and renewals have a vehicle use tax of $80 for 2 years ($40 per year).
For livery and for-hire vehicles in the registration classes Livery OML, Bus (OMR), Taxi OMT in New York City, the vehicle use tax is $400 for 1 year.
For vehicles registered in New York City, there is a supplemental MCTD fee of $50 for two years ($25 per year).
The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission regulates all "TC" vehicle plates.
All registrants for "TC" vehicle plates must pay the vehicle use tax.
The chart shows the use taxes and supplemental fees for all original registrations and renewals for counties outside of New York City.
The amount of the sales tax depends on the purchase price and your locality.
You can see the current sales tax rates by jurisdiction at the Department of Taxation and Finance website.
To determine the correct fee, add 3.25% to the fee listed in the chart, and change the result to the nearest $0.25.

Several registration classes are exempt from the additional fee, including Agricultural AGR, Ambulance AMB, Farm FAR, Historical HIS, House Trailer HOU, Semi Trailer SEM, Special Purpose Commercial SPC, and Trailer TRL.
This tax applies to Medallion taxis with a plate number configuration of "TnnnnnC" or "TnnnnnnC".
This tax does not include Medallion taxis with plate number configurations: "TnnnnnT", "TnnnnnnT", "nana", "nanna", "nnnSBVa" and "nnnSBVan", where n = number, a = letter.
You can renew 1 year before and up to 2 years after your non-driver ID expires.
If your non-driver ID is expired for 2 years or more, you cannot renew it - there are no exceptions.
If you are 62 or older or you receive Supplemental Security Income (SSI), you are eligible for a reduced fee or 'No Fee' non-driver ID.
The section 'Reduced fee or 'No Fee' non-driver IDs' on this page provides more information about reduced fee or 'No Fee' non-driver IDs.
If you plan on traveling, it is recommended that you renew your non-driver ID at a DMV office to get an Enhanced or REAL ID, and avoid a second office visit later.
The section 'Learn about Enhanced, REAL ID and Standard documents' provides information about Enhanced, REAL ID and Standard documents.
You do not have to get an Enhanced or REAL ID non-driver ID.
However, if you have a Standard non-driver ID, you will not be allowed to board a domestic flight starting in October 2020 unless you have a Passport.
The guide 'Find your proofs' helps ensure you have the proofs of identification needed before you come to the DMV.
If you renew your Standard non-driver ID online, your new ID will show 'NOT FOR FEDERAL PURPOSES'.
If you already have an Enhanced or REAL ID non-driver ID, or you want to keep your Standard non-driver ID, you can renew online.
If you renew your Standard non-driver ID online, your document type will stay the same.
The link 'Renew non-driver ID online' provides information about renewing a non-driver ID online.
If you renew your Standard non-driver ID by mail, your new ID will show 'NOT FOR FEDERAL PURPOSES'.
If you already have an Enhanced or REAL ID non-driver ID, or you want to keep your Standard non-driver ID, you can renew by mail.
You cannot renew by mail if you have a REAL ID or Enhanced non-driver ID with a photo that is over 16 years old.
If you have a REAL ID or Enhanced non-driver ID with a photo that is over 16 years old, you must come into an office to take a new picture.
To renew by mail, complete the notice sent to you and return it in the envelope provided.
To renew by mail, include payment in the form of a check or money order payable to 'Commissioner of Motor Vehicles'.
If you did not receive a renewal notice, you can use an 'Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card' (MV-44 PDF) to renew by mail.
Mail the renewal application with payment to 'NYS Department of Motor Vehicles, 207 Genesee Street, Suite 6, Utica, NY 13501-2874'.
The section 'Learn more about Standard, REAL ID and Enhanced documents' provides information about Standard, REAL ID and Enhanced documents.
If you receive Supplemental Security Income (SSI) and are under age 62, your non-driver ID renewal fee is $6.50.
If you are age 62 or older, you can get a 'No Fee' non-driver ID renewal.
If you have an Enhanced non-driver ID, the additional $30.00 fee still applies for a reduced fee or 'No Fee' renewal.
To get a reduced fee or 'No Fee' renewal, you must renew by mail or at a DMV office and provide proof of your eligibility.
If you renew at a DMV office for a reduced fee or 'No Fee' renewal, you must bring an original copy of proof of your eligibility.
If you renew by mail for a reduced fee or 'No Fee' renewal, you must send a photocopy of your proof of SSI eligibility.
You cannot get a reduced fee or 'No Fee' renewal if you renew your non-driver ID online.

The following documents are accepted as proof of SSI eligibility for a reduced fee or 'No Fee' non-driver ID renewal: Notice of Award notifying you of SSI eligibility, Cost of Living Adjustment (COLA) letter, Notice of change in payment (SSA-L8151), Third Party Query (TPQY) letter, Report of Confidential Social Security Information (SSA-2258), Benefit Verification letter (you must call the Social Security Administration in advance to obtain this letter at 1-800-772-1213).
If you are age 62 or older and receive Supplemental Security Income (SSI), your non-driver ID renewal fee is $6.50.
Allow 2 weeks to receive your new non-driver ID card in the mail after renewal.
You can check the mailing status of your photo document online using the link provided.
If your new non-driver ID card is not delivered two weeks after the date the document was processed, you can contact the DMV using the link provided.
If you are turning 21 soon, wait until you are within 40 days of your 21st birthday to renew your non-driver ID.
If you renew your non-driver ID 41 days or more before your 21st birthday, your ID will have 'UNDER 21' printed on it.

If your non-driver ID renewal is processed more than 40 days before your 21st birthday, the DMV will mail you a new non-driver ID card with the words 'UNDER 21' printed on or near the date of your birthday.
As long as the Temporary Visitor status that the DMV has on file for you is not expired, you can renew your non-driver ID card online, through the mail or in an office.
If your Temporary Visitor status has been extended, you must go to a DMV office with your updated paperwork from the United States Department of Homeland Security (DHS).
If your Temporary Visitor status has been extended, the DMV will update their records to show that your Temporary Visitor status has been extended so you can renew your non-driver ID card.
If your Temporary Visitor status has been extended, your new non-driver ID card will have your new temporary visitor expiration date printed on it.
When overseas (out of the country, abroad), you must renew your non-driver ID card through the mail.
When renewing your non-driver ID card from overseas, submit the renewal notice mailed to you, or if you do not have it, an 'Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card' (MV-44 PDF).
When renewing your non-driver ID card from overseas, include the appropriate fee with your application.

When renewing your non-driver ID card from overseas, it is recommended that you send a pre-addressed priority mail return envelope with your application to ensure the ID is sent to the correct address.
Renewing your non-driver ID card anytime within the renewal period will not affect the expiration date of your new non-driver ID card or the fees.
If your non-driver ID is expired for 2 years or more, you must apply for an original non-driver ID card instead of renewing. See 'Get a non-driver ID card (NDID)' for more information.
Starting in October 2020, you will need an Enhanced or REAL ID non-driver ID to board a domestic flight unless you have a passport.
If your non-driver ID was issued before October 30, 2017 and is not Enhanced, you have a Standard document.
Newly issued Standard non-driver ID documents show 'NOT FOR FEDERAL PURPOSES' printed on them.

If you want to renew your Standard non-driver ID in an office and keep your Standard document type, follow these steps: 1) Complete the renewal notice (MV-2) mailed to you, or if you did not receive a renewal notice, use an 'Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card' (MV-44 PDF). 2) Come to a DMV office and bring your current Standard non-driver ID, your renewal notice or application, and payment.
If you renew your Standard non-driver ID online, you will need to pay the regular fees for a non-driver ID card renewal.
To register a vehicle in New York State you must have New York State issued automobile liability insurance coverage.
If you do not maintain the coverage, the DMV can suspend your vehicle registration and your driver license.
New York law requires that you have auto liability insurance coverage.
The minimum amount of liability coverage is $10,000 for property damage for a single accident.
The minimum amount of liability coverage is $25,000 for bodily injury and $50,000 for death for a person involved in an accident.
The minimum amount of liability coverage is $50,000 for bodily injury and $100,000 for death for two or more people in an accident.
Your liability insurance coverage must remain in effect while the registration is valid, even if you don't use the vehicle.
There are exceptions for motorcycles.
Your liability insurance coverage must be New York State insurance coverage, issued by a company licensed by the NY State Department of Financial Services and certified by NY State DMV.
Out-of-state insurance is never acceptable.
Your liability insurance coverage must be issued in the name of the vehicle registrant, and remain in the name of the registrant at all times.
The New York State Department of Financial Services website has more information about liability insurance and insurance companies licensed in New York: http://www.dfs.ny.gov.
There can only be 1 or 2 names on a vehicle registration as registrants.

Both the primary registrant (first name listed on the registration) and the co-registrant must sign the Vehicle Registration/Title Application PDF MV-82 and provide their proofs of identity and date of birth.
Both names must appear on the Insurance ID Card.
The DMV requires auto liability insurance to register a vehicle in New York.

When you get insurance, your insurance company will issue proof of insurance in two ways: it will give you two original NY State Insurance ID Cards (see a sample) or provide you with access to your digital electronic NY State Insurance ID Card, and send an electronic notice of insurance coverage to the DMV.
Your insurance agent or broker cannot file the electronic notice of insurance coverage.
Your NY State Insurance Identification Cards and the electronic notice of insurance together verify your insurance coverage.
The DMV needs both the NY State Insurance Identification Cards and the electronic notice of insurance.
You must register your vehicle at the DMV within 180 days of the effective date on your insurance ID card.
You must bring one copy or form of your Insurance Identification Cards with you when registering your vehicle.
The DMV office will keep the paper Insurance Identification Card.
You must keep the other paper Insurance Identification Card with the vehicle as your proof of insurance.
Anyone operating your vehicle must be able to provide proof of insurance while they are operating the vehicle.
Your insurance cards must have the same name as the name on your vehicle registration application.
The DMV will accept copies or faxes of your Insurance Identification Card.
However, the DMV will not accept a card if the DMV barcode reader cannot read/scan the barcode.
The DMV will never accept out-of-state vehicle insurance coverage of any type.
If your vehicle is registered in New York, it must have New York State auto liability insurance coverage.
Your motorcycle must have insurance coverage any time it is operated on a public road or highway.
Unlike most other motor vehicles, motorcycles are registered for one year rather than two, and all motorcycle registrations expire on April 30.
You can terminate your motorcycle liability insurance without surrendering the plate at a DMV office.
This makes it easier to put the motorcycle back on the road after winter storage.
However, under no circumstances may your motorcycle operate on public highways without liability coverage in effect.
A change on the insurance policy to a name different from the name on your registration may cause a lapse in insurance coverage, and DMV may suspend your driver license and your vehicle registration.
Your vehicle's insurance and registration must always be in exactly the same name.
You should always carry the paper or access to your digital electronic NY State Insurance ID Card in your vehicle.
When you apply for a replacement title at a DMV office, we will NOT hand you a new title while you are there.
We print all title certificates in a secure facility in Albany and mail them to the vehicle owner.
We can send you your replacement title by express mail.
Sending your replacement title by express mail will cost extra.
You will need to sign for the delivery of your replacement title if sent by express mail.
Express mail is not available between Friday at 8:30 pm and Sunday at 8:30 pm.
Sending us an application by express mail will not decrease the time it takes to review your application or issue the replacement title.
To order a replacement title online, you must be the owner of the vehicle or boat.
To order a replacement title online, you must have a current U.S. address on file with the DMV.
To order a replacement title online, the vehicle must be registered and titled in New York State.
To order a replacement title online, there can be no other changes to the information listed on the title certificate.
You cannot order a replacement title online if a title certificate was processed within the last 15 days.
You cannot order a replacement title online if the title certificate is a duplicate title certificate requesting removal of a lien.
You cannot order a replacement title online if the title certificate is an original or amended title certificate in the name of a deceased owner ordered using a Power of Attorney.
If you order your title certificate online before 8 p.m. on Tuesday, it is printed on Wednesday and mailed on Thursday.
If you order your title certificate online after 8 p.m. on Tuesday, it is printed on Thursday and mailed on Friday.
A 'business day' is a weekday that is not a state holiday.
If you order your title certificate during or before a weekend and/or a state holiday, the title certificate cannot be processed until the next business day after the weekend and/or state holiday.
An online transaction for a replacement title certificate can only be cancelled on the same day it was ordered.
We mail your new title to the current address on your title record.
If the registration for your vehicle is in your name, you can first change your address online and then replace your title.
If you have allowed someone else to register your vehicle, you cannot change the address on your title record online.
To update the address on your title record if you have allowed someone else to register your vehicle, please contact the Title Services Bureau at 1-518-486-4714.
If you file a request with the US Postal Service (USPS) to forward mail, there is no guarantee that the USPS will forward your DMV documents to the new address.

To replace a title certificate by mail, send a completed Application for Duplicate Title (PDF MV-902), proof of identity, and a personal check or money order for $20.00 payable to Commissioner of Motor Vehicles to the DMV.
To receive your replacement title certificate by standard mail, mail the required documents to: Title Bureau, NYS DMV, PO Box 2750, Albany, NY 12220-0750.
To receive your replacement title certificate by express mail, mail the required documents to: Duplicate Title Certificates, NYS DMV, 6 Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228.
Use the Title Service Bureau phone number, 1-518-486-4714, on your express mail bill when mailing for a replacement title certificate by express mail.
To replace a title certificate at a DMV office, bring a completed Application for Duplicate Title (PDF MV-902), proof of identity, and $20.00 for the replacement fee.
When you apply for a replacement title at a DMV office, you will NOT be issued the replacement title while there.
All title certificates are printed in a secure facility in Albany and are mailed to the owner.
The fastest and easiest way to apply for a replacement title is to do it online.
To apply for a title certificate only, use the Application for Title Only (PDF MV-82TON) and follow the instructions carefully.
Do not use the Application for Title Only (PDF MV-82TON) to apply for both a vehicle registration and a title certificate at the same time.
Your duplicate title certificate will be sent to the address on file at the DMV.
If you moved, learn how to change your address.
A New York State Driver License, Learner Permit, or Non-Driver ID card that is current or not expired for more than 2 years can serve as proof of both identity and age.
If you don't have a New York State Driver License, Learner Permit, or Non-Driver ID, you can provide other kinds of proof.
If you are looking to file a complaint against a repair or body shop, please report a problem with a DMV regulated automotive business.
The New York State Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) regulates all repair shops, inspection stations, dealers, vehicle dismantlers and other related businesses in New York State.
To legally operate as a repair shop, inspection station, dealer, vehicle dismantler or other related business, you must register with the DMV.
Once your application is approved, you will receive a certificate from the DMV.
Once your application is approved, you will receive a copy of the Commissioner's Regulations that pertain to your type of business.
The Commissioner's Regulations will explain your responsibilities to consumers.
You must follow all consumer protection laws and regulations.
The DMV advises all consumers who have a complaint against a dealer, inspection station, repair shop, or dismantler to make an attempt to resolve their complaint with the business manager.
If consumers are not successful in resolving their complaint with the business manager, they are advised to contact the DMV Consumer & Facilities Services Complaint Unit.
To protect your business, keep a copy of all work orders in an easy-to-access location.
If a complaint has been filed against you, a Consumer Services Representative from the DMV will contact you in an attempt to resolve this complaint.
The Consumer Services Representative will explain the nature of the complaint.
The Consumer Services Representative will also inform you of your rights, responsibilities, and your liability.
If the complaint is not resolved with the Consumer Services Representative, the case will be sent to an Automotive Facilities Inspector (AFI) for a formal investigation.
To avoid costly penalties, fines, and the loss of valuable customers, respond to all DMV inquiries in a timely manner.
The Automotive Facilities Inspector (AFI) will conduct a formal investigation.

The result of the Automotive Facilities Inspector's investigation may be no action, a warning letter (Notice of Investigation) placed in your file, or a formal administrative hearing before an Administrative Law Judge (ALJ).

When Vehicle Safety initiates the hearing process, you may be offered the opportunity through a "hearing waiver" to admit to the charges and to either pay a specified monetary penalty and/or to accept a suspension.
If the "hearing waiver" is accepted, no hearing is required.
If the offer of a "hearing waiver" is rejected, a hearing must be held.
The result of the hearing may be no action, a civil penalty, and/or a suspension or revocation of your ability to operate as a vehicle related business in New York State.
You may also be offered the opportunity to pay restitution to the consumer instead of the fines and/or penalties, or to have the penalty reduced.
You are entitled to hire an attorney and to bring that attorney to the hearing.
The DMV is the petitioner in this case and the complainant may be a witness for the case.
As a result of the hearing, the Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) may sustain some, all, or none of the charges.
As a result of the hearing, there may be no action, a warning, the imposition of a suspension, revocation, and/or civil penalties.
If the Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) only imposes civil penalties, in order to prevent the loss of your operating privilege, you must pay all fines and penalties.
You will receive a letter from the DMV shortly after the hearing.
You will have 30 days from the date of the order by the Administrative Law Judge to pay your fine or penalty.
Failure to pay any fines or penalties or to serve out your suspension will result in indefinite suspension of your business certificate and the possible assessment of a lien against your business.
However, if you pay your fine and/or penalty or serve out your period of suspension, you will be back in business after complete compliance.
If you are revoked, you must surrender all supplies and cease to operate.
You have the right to appeal any adverse decision.

If you chose to appeal, you have 60 days from the date of the Administrative Law Judge's decision to file the Appeal From DMV Hearing Determination PDF (AA-33A), which must be accompanied by the appropriate filing fee.
Your facility license, registration or certification enables you to operate in New York State.
Complaints filed and charges brought against you can result in the loss of your privilege to operate as a business in New York State.
New York law defines limited use motorcycles, which are commonly called "mopeds" or "motor scooters", as "limited use vehicles with two or three wheels".
The requirements to operate a moped are like those for motorcycles.
You must have a driver license and register your moped to drive it on streets and highways.
There are exceptions to these requirements listed in the table below.
You can never operate a moped down a sidewalk.
The DMV classifies a moped as a Class A, Class B or Class C limited use motorcycle according to its top speed.
Only a certified model of limited use motorcycle can get a registration in New York State.
Only the manufacturer can certify a moped.
Before visiting a DMV office to register your moped, please complete the Document Guide to make sure you bring the correct documents with you.
You need to bring a completed Registration/Title Application PDF MV-82.
You need to bring proof of ownership.
You need to bring proof of identity and age.
You need to bring proof of insurance, if required.
You need to bring cash, check, money order or credit/debit card for fees and sales tax or proof of sales tax payment or exemption.
For quicker service, make a reservation online before visiting offices in New York City, Westchester, Nassau, Suffolk, Rockland, Onondaga, Monroe or Albany Counties.
For all other counties, see the office locations and hours.
The class of a moped is determined by the range of the vehicle's top speed.
You must be at least 16 years old to register a vehicle in New York except a boat or ATV.
A NY State Driver License, Learner Permit, or Non-Driver ID card that is current or not expired for more than 2 years can serve as proof of both identity and age.
If you don't have one of these documents, you must provide other kinds of proof.
Refer to the Limited-use motorcycle requirements chart on this page to determine if you need insurance.
Your insurance company will issue proof of insurance by giving you two original barcoded NY State Insurance Identification Cards.
You must register your vehicle at the DMV within 180 days of the effective date on your insurance ID card.
Bring one copy of your Insurance Identification Cards with you.
The DMV office will keep it.
Keep the other card with the vehicle as your proof of insurance.
Learn more about NY State Insurance Requirements.
Learner permit restrictions apply to all permit classes.
Junior operator restrictions apply to class DJ and MJ permits and driver licenses.
See information about the Graduated License Law.
Except when making a left turn.
A Class C moped used as a rental vehicle must be insured.
Completing a Point and Insurance Reduction Program (PIRP) course does not remove a violation, conviction, or the number of points from your driving record.
Even after you complete the PIRP course, most violations, convictions and points will continue to show on your driving record for up to 4 years.
Violations and convictions involving drugs or alcohol will remain on your driving record for ten or fifteen years, depending on the violation.
If you get 11 points for traffic violations in an 18-month period, your driver license may be suspended.

Point reduction means the number of points on your driving record used to calculate the number of total points received within 18 months will be reduced by 4 points and may help you avoid a suspension.
The PIRP course sponsor will notify the DMV within 10 weeks after you complete the course.
The DMV will then reduce the active points on your driving record by up to 4 points.
If you need to verify that your PIRP course completion is on your DMV record, you can request a copy of your driving record.
If your PIRP course completion is not recorded on your driving record more than 10 weeks after you completed it, you should contact the course sponsor.
Point reduction applies only to points assessed for violations that occurred within the eighteen months immediately before PIRP course completion.
Point reduction does not affect points for earlier violations, and cannot be used as credit against future violations or points.
Point reduction cannot reduce your point total lower than zero.
If your license has already been revoked or suspended, the point reduction will not affect that action.
If a violation hearing has already been scheduled, the point reduction will not affect that action.
Point reduction does not prevent or cancel a mandatory revocation or suspension for violations such as DWI, DWAI, or three speeding violations within 18 months.
You can only use a Point & Insurance Reduction Program course to reduce points once in an 18-month period.
The DMV point system and your insurance company's point systems are separate and not related.
Point reduction on your driving record does not affect points assigned by your insurance company for violations and accidents.
Completion of a PIRP course cannot prevent or reduce the calculation of points affecting a Driver Responsibility Assessment.
You can use the DMV Road test system to schedule, confirm, cancel or reschedule a driving skills road test including CDL and motorcycle online or by phone.
If you are under age 18, you must wait at least 6 months from the date you received your learner permit to schedule your road test.
The fee for up to two road tests for a non-commercial license is included in your $10.00 driver license application fee.
If you do not pass your first two tests, you must pay another $10.00 fee for up to two more tests.
There is no refund if you do not take both tests.
For a road test for a commercial driver license (CDL), the fee for a single test is $40.00.
You need a valid New York State learner permit to take a road test.
You need an original, unexpired Pre-Licensing Course Certificate (MV-278) or a Student Certificate of Completion (MV-285) to take a road test.
You need at least one unused test available to schedule a road test.
You need the ZIP Code for the test site to schedule a road test.
You do not need to take your road test in the area of the state where you live.
The DMV Road test system offers the earliest available dates and times at sites near the ZIP Code you provide.
Road tests are almost always on weekdays, only rarely are they offered on a Saturday.
To reschedule your road test, you must cancel your appointment before you can search for a new date.
You cannot have more than one road test appointment at a time.
You can schedule, cancel or reschedule a road test online.
You can schedule a road test by phone at 1-518-402-2100.
Road tests can be cancelled, rescheduled or relocated because of bad weather or road construction.
You should check the DMV cancellations, closings and delays webpage or call 1-518-402-2100 before leaving for your road test.
You should try to arrive up to 30 minutes before the time of your road test.
If you are late for your road test, the license examiner may need to reschedule.
You need to bring your photo learner permit to your road test.
If your permit indicates you need corrective lenses, you need to bring glasses or contacts to your road test.
You need to bring your original Pre-licensing Course Certificate (MV-278) or Student Certificate of Completion (MV-285) to your road test, copies are not acceptable.
If you are under 18, you need to bring a Certification of Supervised Driving (MV-262) completed by your parent or guardian to your road test.
You need to bring a driver age 21 or older with a valid license to operate the test vehicle during your road test.
You need to bring a vehicle with a valid registration and inspection, that operates properly and is in clean condition to your road test.
For a motorcycle road test, you need to bring a properly operating, registered and inspected motorcycle.

For a motorcycle road test, you also need to bring a properly operating, registered and inspected motor vehicle and a driver with a valid driver license to transport the license examiner during your road test.
If you pass your road test, the license examiner will give you an interim license that allows you to drive.
If you are under age 18 and have a Class DJ, MJ or DJMJ driver license, you must obey the restrictions for junior drivers after passing your road test.
If you fail a non-commercial license road test, your learner permit remains valid until the expiration date.
If your learner permit expires before your next road test, you must get a new learner permit.
You can schedule another road test if you fail, but you must pay additional fees if you failed your first two road tests.
You must wait at least one day to take the road test again if you fail.
If you fail your road test, you can pay for additional tests online or by phone.

To pay for additional road tests online or by phone, you must have a valid learner permit or driver license, provide your DMV ID Number from your Learner Permit Client ID Number and your date of birth, have no other road tests currently available, and pay the fee with a credit or debit card.
You can pay additional road test fees online.
You can pay additional road test fees by phone at 1-518-402-2100.

The DMV accepts American Express Card, Discover Card/Novus, MasterCard, MasterCard Debit card without personal identification number (PIN), VISA Card, and Visa Debit Card without personal identification number (PIN) for payment.
New federal regulations require all commercial drivers to certify to the Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) the type of driving they perform or expect to perform.
Drivers that self-certify to a non-excepted driving type (NA or NI) are also required to submit a copy of their USDOT Medical Examiner's Certificate.
This is a nationwide safety initiative that affects commercial drivers in all states.
The self-certification driving types are: Non-Excepted Interstate (NI), Non-Excepted Intrastate (NA), Excepted Interstate (EI), Excepted Intrastate (EA).
Non-Excepted Interstate (NI) means commercial driving operation is permitted across state lines, and the driver is required to meet the Federal medical requirements.
Non-Excepted Intrastate (NA) means commercial driving operation is restricted to New York State only, and the driver is required to meet the Federal medical requirements.
Excepted Interstate (EI) means commercial driving operation is permitted across state lines for excepted operation only and the driver is exempt from the Federal medical requirements.
Excepted Intrastate (EA) means commercial driving operation is restricted to New York State, permitted for excepted operation only and the driver is exempt from the Federal medical requirements.

If the driver's driving type changes, the driver must go into their local DMV office to change their self-certification driving type and have their license amended to add or delete the appropriate restrictions.
A transaction fee will apply when changing the self-certification driving type.

If the driver is self-certifying to a non-excepted driving type (NA or NI), the driver will need to bring a copy of their valid USDOT Medical Examiner's Certificate if it is not already on file with DMV.
The driver cannot change their self-certification driving type online.

If the driver is eligible for an excepted operation but has a valid DOT Medical Examiner's Certificate, the driver should certify to the type of driving in which they operate or expect to operate, and their CDL will have the restrictions for that driving type.
If the driver is capable of obtaining a Medical Examiner's Certificate, then the NI driving type will allow for the broadest commercial operation capability with no license restrictions applied.

If the driver does not meet the USDOT federal medical requirements and cannot obtain a Medical Examiner's Certificate, but the driver's CDL was issued prior to 9/9/1999, the driver is eligible for Excepted Intrastate operation (EA).
For Excepted Intrastate operation (EA), the driver's CDL must have the required restrictions: K (CDL Intrastate Only) and A3 (Med Cert Exempt).
CDL holders that certify to EA can only operate a commercial motor vehicle within New York State, and cannot deliver cargo coming from, or being delivered to, another state or foreign country.

If the driver works for a "private" company that provides school bus service to local school systems and operates or expects to operate in an excepted operation such as school operation, the driver can choose EI.
School operation is defined as "school to home/home to school" operation and includes interstate operation for school operation only, but does not include field trips.
Only applicants employed by a municipality can drive for out-of-state field trips.
When the driver chooses driving type EI, the driver is limited to driving only for an excepted operation.

If the driver has a current CDL license with no restrictions, does not have a Medical Examiner's Certificate, and does not use their CDL license to drive commercially, the driver should choose the self-certification driving type that describes the type of driving that they perform or expect to perform.

If the driver expects to operate in an excepted driving type (EA or EI), a Medical Examiner's Certificate is not required, but the driver will need to have the appropriate restrictions (A3 and/or K) added to their driver's license.
If the driver expects to operate in a non-excepted driving type (NA or NI), a Medical Examiner's Certificate is required.
The driver's self-certification can be changed anytime at a local DMV office through a license amendment transaction.
If the driver's Medical Examiner's Certificate is rejected, the rejection letter indicates why it is being returned.
If information on the Medical Examiner's Certificate was incorrect, missing or illegible, the driver must contact their physician to have the form amended or another form completed.

If the Medical Examiner's Certificate was rejected because it was not completed by a doctor listed on the National Registry of Certified Medical Examiners, the driver must have a new exam completed by a doctor on the registry.
To find a certified doctor in the driver's area, the driver should visit the Federal website at National Registry of Certified Medical Examiners Search.

If the driver downgrades their license to a non-commercial class, no refund will be given as the driver will have the remainder of the renewal period as well as the two-year grace period to be granted back the CDL without re-testing requirements.
A refund is only allowed by law if the license is surrendered in full and there is 4 years or more remaining at the time of surrender.
DMV sends reminders to CDL and CLP holders who have registered to receive email and/or text reminders about the status of their medical certifications and medical variances.
To register to receive these reminders, the driver should go to "Get email and/or text reminders".
Failure to submit an updated Medical Examiner's Certificate, or medical variance, prior to the expiration date of the one on file may result in the driver's CDL being downgraded.
The driver should allow at least two weeks to process their updated documents.
Once the driver's Medical Examiner's Certificate on file expires, the driver is no longer certified to drive commercial vehicles.
A notice advising the driver of their "not certified" medical status and impending license downgrade 56 days from the date of notice will be sent to the driver.
When DMV receives the driver's new updated medical certificate, the driver will be re-certified.
If the driver's CDL was downgraded because of their "not certified" medical status, the driver will need to visit a local DMV office to upgrade their license back to a CDL.

If the driver is signed up for MyDMV or signs up at "go to MyDMV" at the DMV website and uses the service called "My License Status, Renewal and Replacement", the driver can look under "License Status" to determine their self-certification driving type, medical certification status and medical certificate expiration date.
If the driver self-certified to driving types NI & NA, the driver will have a medical certification status of either "Certified" or "Not Certified".
If the driver self-certified to EI or EA, the driver will have a medical certification status of "Not Required".
DMV is entering commercial driver self-certification and medical certification data daily, as soon as possible.
Due to the volume of responses, it could take a period of time for a driver's record to be fully updated.
Self-certification driving types data will be entered and show first, followed later by medical certification data.
There may be a period of time where an NI or NA driving type reflects a "Not Certified" medical status until the medical certification data is entered, when it will then be updated to "Certified".

The driver can contact the Medical Certification Unit by fax at 518-486-4421 or 518-486-3260, by email at [email protected], or by mail at NYS DMV Medical Certification Unit, PO Box 2601, Albany, NY 12220-0601.

If you are issued a ticket for a non-criminal moving traffic violation in the five boroughs of New York City, it will be handled by a New York State Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) Traffic Violations Bureau (TVB).

This allows courts in these areas to concentrate on criminal cases, including driving offenses, such as driving while intoxicated and driving while suspended or revoked (aggravated unlicensed operation).
However, TVBs do not handle parking violations.

If you plead not guilty to a traffic ticket in one of these TVB areas, your case will be heard by a DMV Administrative Law Judge (ALJ), an experienced attorney with special training in the Vehicle and Traffic Law.
An ALJ has the authority to decide whether or not you are guilty and to set a fine if you are found guilty.
An ALJ also has the authority to revoke or suspend your driver license and/or auto registration when required by law or when the ALJ believes it is in the interest of traffic safety.
Just as in traffic courts in other areas of the state, you may present witnesses and evidence at a hearing before an ALJ and be represented by an attorney.
If you don't answer the ticket in the time allowed, your driver license will be suspended.
Later, you could be found guilty of the charge because of your failure to respond (a default conviction).
Your license would be suspended for not paying the fine and a judgment would be entered against you.
Driving with a suspended license is a crime.
A felony conviction may result in fines of up to $5,000, jail, probation, or confiscation of your vehicle.
As the number of suspensions you have increases, the penalties also increase.
A driver is suspended for ticket not answered and fine not paid.
To plead not guilty, you can use the Traffic Ticket Pleas, Hearings and Payments online transaction or read the "not guilty" instructions and check the "not guilty" box on the back of the ticket.
You need to fill in the requested information, sign it, and mail the ticket to the Albany address listed.
DMV will send you a letter telling you when and where to go for your hearing.
If you are hearing impaired and require an interpreter, you need to include a request for one when you mail your not guilty plea.
An interpreter will be assigned to your hearing at no charge to you.
Hearings are open to the public.
You may go to any TVB office to watch hearings so you know what to expect at yours.
To plead guilty, you can use the Traffic Ticket Pleas, Hearings and Payments online transaction or read the instructions and check the "guilty" box on the back of the ticket.
You need to fill in the requested information, sign it and either mail it with your payment to the Albany address listed on the ticket or bring your payment to any TVB office.
You may pay the fine and surcharge by Visa or Mastercard, or by a check or money order payable to the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
You need to include the total fines and surcharges listed on the ticket for your violation.

You may not plead guilty by mail if the charge against you will result in license or registration suspension or revocation upon conviction such as driving without insurance or a third speeding violation within 18 months.
If you plead guilty to such a charge by mail, you will be notified that you must go to the TVB to answer the charge in person.
If your mailing address is different from the address written on the front of the ticket, you need to write the correct mailing address in the space provided on the back of the ticket.
You may request your traffic ticket hearing to be postponed and rescheduled to a different date.
For the ticket's first postponement, the appropriate TVB must receive your request by mail at least 10 days before the date of the scheduled hearing.
You may also make your postponement request in person at that office or by telephone at least one day before your hearing date.
If it would be a second or subsequent postponement for the same ticket, your request must be made in person at the appropriate TVB office at least one day before your hearing date.
Your request for a second or subsequent postponement also must include a "good cause", which is the reason you want the hearing rescheduled.
Your "good cause" is subject to approval by a TVB Administrative Law Judge.

For a traffic ticket issued within New York City, you need to mail your request to the Albany, NY, address on your ticket - the office must receive your request at least ten days before the date of your scheduled hearing.
You also may make your request in person at any TVB office in New York City, or telephone the TVB at 718-488-5710, at least one day before the date of your scheduled hearing.
For a traffic ticket to be answered to a TVB outside New York City, you need to mail your request to the TVB office indicated on your ticket.
The office must receive your request at least ten days before the scheduled hearing date.
You also may make your request in person to that TVB office or by telephone at least one day before the date of your scheduled hearing.
You are considered innocent of the charge against you unless you are proven guilty at your hearing.
You cannot be found guilty unless there is "clear and convincing evidence" that you committed the violation.
If you find it hard to understand English, you may bring someone to help you.
You need to tell the ALJ, before the hearing starts, that someone who speaks your native language and English is there to interpret.
The ALJ will listen to sworn testimony from the police officer, who will explain why you were given the ticket.
Then, you or your attorney may ask the officer questions.
You also may bring witnesses to testify for you and written evidence.
The judge may ask witnesses questions to better understand their testimony.
You do not have to testify but you may if you wish.
You cannot be found guilty just because you do not testify.
When all of the evidence and testimony have been given, the ALJ will decide whether or not you are guilty.
That decision will be based only on the evidence and testimony presented at the hearing and what the law states.
If the ALJ decides the charge against you was not proven by clear and convincing evidence, you will be found not guilty.
If the charge is proven and you are found guilty, the judge will set a fine.
Your license or registration also may be suspended or revoked, depending on the violation and your overall driving record.
If you believe the ALJ's decision was incorrect based on the facts and the law, you may file an appeal.
You can determine if you can file an appeal online or download Traffic Violations Bureau Appeal form AA-33 from the DMV web site.
The appeal form is also available at TVB offices.
You need to read the instructions carefully.
If you wish, your attorney may help you file the appeal.
You need to remember to include a payment for the appeal fees.
An appeal must be filed, and the appeal form and fees must be sent to: DMV Appeals Board, P.O. Box 2935, Albany, NY 12220-0935.
The State Department of Motor Vehicles Traffic Violations Bureaus do not handle parking tickets or violations by pedestrians.
These are usually handled by a local parking violations bureau or court.
The most common reasons your license may be suspended or revoked due to motor vehicle violations are listed.
Remember, your license also will be suspended if you do not answer a ticket or pay a fine.
An ALJ has the authority to suspend or revoke your license for violations other than those listed.
If you commit three speeding and/or misdemeanor traffic violations within 18 months, your license will be revoked for at least six months.
You are on license probation for six months after you pass a road test.
If you are found guilty of committing any two moving violations during your probation period, your license will be suspended for 60 days.

It will also be suspended for 60 days if you are found guilty of committing a single, more serious violation during the probation period, including speeding, tailgating, unauthorized racing or reckless driving.
For violations committed on or after November 1, 2014 - if you are found guilty of committing a texting/cell phone violation during the probation period, your license will be suspended for 120 days.
For texting/cell phone violations committed between July 1, 2013 and October 31, 2014, your probationary license will be suspended for 60 days.
If you are a holder of a probationary/junior license or learner permit and you are charged with a cell phone/texting violation on or after July 1, 2013, you cannot plead by mail or online.
You must appear for a hearing in a TVB office.
Most traffic violations carry violation points.
The points will be added to your record using the date the violation occurred, not the date you are found guilty.
If your violation points in any 18-month period add up to 11 or more, your license may be revoked or suspended following a hearing.
The ALJ usually holds the point hearing immediately after you are found guilty of a violation that brings your total to 11 or more points in 18 months.
A list of common violations and the number of points for each is provided.
Taking a DMV-approved accident prevention course can reduce your point total by up to four points and reduce your auto liability and collision insurance premiums by 10% for three years.
You can ask for more information at any motor vehicle office.

Suggestions for improving TVB services and operations can be written and left at a TVB office or mailed to: Director Office of Traffic Violations, Department of Motor Vehicles, 6 Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228 or Supervising ALJ Office of Traffic Violations, 801 Axinn Avenue, Garden City, NY 11530.
Additional information can be found at the provided links.
Si esta es la primera vez que registra su vehículo, debe pagar la tarifa de registro.
Si esta es la primera vez que registra su vehículo, debe pagar la tarifa de la placa del vehículo.
Si esta es la primera vez que registra su vehículo, debe pagar el impuesto de uso del condado.
Si esta es la primera vez que registra su vehículo, debe pagar el impuesto sobre las ventas.
Si esta es la primera vez que registra su vehículo, debe pagar una tarifa de certificado de título de $50.00.

Si esta es la primera vez que registra su vehículo en los siguientes 12 condados: Bronx, Kings (Brooklyn), New York (Manhattan), Queens, Richmond (Staten Island), Dutchess, Nassau, Orange, Putnam, Rockland, Suffolk y Westchester, debe pagar la tarifa MCTD 1.
Si transfiere el registro y las placas de otro vehículo, no necesita pagar las tarifas de las placas o la tarifa MCTD.
Si transfiere el registro y las placas de otro vehículo, es posible que pueda transferir las tarifas de registro a su nuevo vehículo.
Las estimaciones en línea NO incluyen el impuesto sobre las ventas.
Puede utilizar estas tablas para estimar sus tarifas de registro, impuestos de uso y tarifas suplementarias para vehículos de pasajeros.
Puede utilizar estas tablas para estimar sus tarifas de registro, impuestos de uso y tarifas suplementarias para vehículos comerciales.
No puede utilizar el servicio en línea para estimar las tarifas e impuestos para remolques o botes.
Las tarifas de registro de remolques y botes se calculan de manera diferente.

No necesita pagar el impuesto sobre las ventas cuando registra si muestra al DMV una prueba aceptable de que pagó el impuesto sobre las ventas cuando compró el vehículo, o si el registro está exento de impuestos.
You can order personalized plates for passenger vehicles.
You can order personalized plates for commercial vehicles.
You can order personalized plates for motorcycles.
Many picture plates can also be personalized.
You can browse the collection of picture plates online.

The categories of picture plates are: I Love NY Adventure, Sports, Military and Veterans, Counties and Regions of NY State, Colleges, Fraternities, Sororities, Causes, Professions, Organizations, Motorcycle Plates.
To order personalized plates online: You must have a valid New York State vehicle registration in the passenger, commercial or motorcycle registration class that does not expire within 60 days.
To order personalized plates online: The mailing address on your vehicle registration record must be your current mailing address.
To order personalized plates online: Your vehicle registration record must match your current name if your name has changed.
To order personalized plates online: You must provide your current plate number, the 3-letter registration class code and the first three letters of your last name.
To order personalized plates online: You must have a credit card that DMV accepts, and a valid email address for confirmation purposes.
To order personalized plates by mail, use the Application for Custom Plates PDF CP-30.
To order personalized plates by mail: Mail the completed form and your payment to NYS DMV Custom Plates Unit P.O. Box 2775 Albany, NY 12220.
To order personalized plates by phone: Call the Custom Plates Unit at 1-518-402-4838.
The office hours of the Custom Plates Unit are 8:00am - 4:00pm, Monday through Friday.
You can order personalized plates at a DMV office.
After your order for personalized plates is processed, you will receive new registration documents that show your current plate number and your new plate combination in approximately 10 days or less.
Allow at least six weeks for the custom plates to arrive after ordering.
Your new registration documents will be mailed separately from your new custom plates.
If you do not receive your registration documents within two weeks or your custom plates within six weeks, contact the Custom Plates Unit at 1-518-402-4838.
To protect against the fraudulent use of your current vehicle plates when you receive new plates, mark each vehicle plate with a permanent ink pen.
Do not put both vehicle plates in the recycling/garbage on the same day when you receive new plates.
You can't order personalized plates before your vehicle is registered, when renewing your registration, or before transferring a registration.
You must have a registration windshield sticker, receipt and regular series plates issued by DMV before ordering personalized plates.
To order personalized plates for people with disabilities that have the Universal Symbol of Access, call the Custom Plates Unit at 1-518-402-4838.
If your registration expires within the next 60 days, renew your registration before you order personalized plates.
Change your address online before ordering personalized plates.
You must visit a DMV office to change your name on all DMV records and documents.
DMV accepts American Express, Discover, MasterCard and VISA for payment.
Some picture or professional plates can't be purchased by mail.
Some plates are not available by phone.

Professional, emergency services, veterans and some organization plates are limited to membership and must be ordered through the organization or directly from the Custom Plates Unit, with documentation.
You can replace your license or permit including commercial and enhanced if it was lost, stolen or destroyed, or after you update your address.
You can't replace your document if it is expired.
If you are turning 21 soon, order within 40 days of your birthday.
The DMV recommends you come to the DMV now to get an Enhanced or REAL ID, and avoid a second office visit later.
Enhanced, REAL ID and Standard documents are different types of documents.
You don't have to get an Enhanced or REAL ID.
If you have a Standard document, you will not be allowed to board a domestic flight starting in October 2020 unless you have a Passport.
You should complete a guide to make sure you have the proofs of identification you need before you come to DMV.
You can find your proofs of identification on the DMV website.
If you replace your Standard document online, your new document will show 'NOT FOR FEDERAL PURPOSES'.
You are advised to not delay and get your Enhanced or REAL ID today.
If you already have an Enhanced or REAL ID, or you want to keep your Standard document, you can replace online.
If you replace online, your document type will stay the same.
You can replace your document online on the DMV website.
If you replace your Standard document by mail, your new document will show 'NOT FOR FEDERAL PURPOSES'.
You are advised to not delay and get your Enhanced or REAL ID today.
If you already have an Enhanced or REAL ID, or you want to keep your Standard document, you can replace by mail.
If you replace by mail, your document type will stay the same.

To replace by mail, you need to send a completed Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card (MV-44), photocopies of acceptable proof of identity, and payment of $17.50 check or money order payable to 'Commissioner of Motor Vehicles' to the NYS Department of Motor Vehicles at 207 Genesee Street, Suite 6, Utica, NY 13501-2874.
The fee for replacing a document is $17.50.
If you apply by mail or at a DMV office, you can pay by credit/debit card or a check or money order made out to Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
To apply online, you must use a credit/debit card.

The DMV accepts American Express Card, Discover Card/Novus, MasterCard, MasterCard Debit card without personal identification number PIN, VISA Card, and Visa Debit Card without personal identification number PIN.
If you want the fee waived for a license or permit lost due to a crime, you must apply at a DMV office and show form MV-78B completed by the police.
The DMV sends documents to the address on their records at the time of the order.
If you moved, you should first change your address, then order a replacement document.
You can change your address on the DMV website.
When you order by mail or at a DMV office, you can ask that your replacement document be sent to an address that is different from the address on your document.
You can't use a temporary address when you order online.
The DMV will mail your document to the mailing address currently on their records or an alternate address you provide.
To verify or change your address, you can use the Address Change feature on the DMV website.
It takes about 10 days for your license to come in the mail.
You can check the mailing status of your license online.
If it has been more than 2 weeks since you ordered your duplicate document, you should contact the DMV.
You do not need an eye exam when you replace your document.
Your expiration date and ID number will not change when you replace your document.
To change your name or other non-address information like photo, height, or add/remove corrective lenses, you will need to go to a DMV office.
You can change your name or other information by following the instructions on the DMV website.

If you are a qualified U.S. military veteran who was honorably discharged, and you have a NY State driver license, learner permit or non-driver photo ID card, you can have the word 'Veteran' printed on the upper left hand of your photo document.
There is no additional fee for the veteran status designation on your document, but all regular transaction fees will apply.
You can learn how to get the veteran status on your license on the DMV website.
When overseas (out of the country, abroad), you must replace your license through the mail.
When replacing your license from overseas, you must submit a completed Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card (MV-44) and include payment of $17.50.

The DMV recommends that you send a pre-addressed priority mail return envelope with your application when replacing your license from overseas to ensure that they send your license to the correct address.
As long as the Temporary Visitor status that DMV has on file is not expired, you can replace your license online, through the mail or in an office.
If your Temporary Visitor status has been extended, you must go to a DMV office with your updated paperwork from the Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS).
The DMV will update their records to show that your Temporary Visitor status has been extended so you can replace your license.
Your new license will have your new temporary visitor expiration date.
If you request a replacement driver license 41 days or more before your 21st birthday, it will say 'UNDER 21'.
Starting in October 2020, you will need an Enhanced or REAL ID to board a domestic flight unless you have a passport.
If your license or permit was issued before October 30, 2017 and is not Enhanced, you have a Standard document.
Newly issued Standard documents show 'NOT FOR FEDERAL PURPOSES'.

If you want to replace in an office and keep your Standard document type, you need to follow these steps: Step 1: Complete an Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card (MV-44). Step 2: Come to an office and bring your current license or permit, your application, and payment.
To get a free replacement for a driver license or learner permit that was stolen or was lost due to a crime, you must get form MV-78B from a police agency.
Form MV-78B is available only from police agencies, not from the DMV.
If you want your new driver license sent to an alternate address, you should include an additional note and clearly print the alternate address.
You should not write the alternate address on form MV-44.
The mailing address you write on form MV-44 must be the address that is listed on your photo document and your DMV record.
The DMV website has information about replacing a driver license.
The DMV website has related PDFs about replacing a driver license.
The DMV website has a 'mydmv' feature.
The Point and Insurance Reduction Program PIRP is a DMV - approved course designed to teach motorists critical information about Highway Safety and Accident Prevention.

To get the insurance premium reduction, the course sponsor will mail you a completion certificate within 45 business days after you complete the classroom course or 14 business days after you complete an online course.

If you present your certificate to your insurance company or agent within 90 days after course completion, your liability and collision premium reduction will begin immediately, retroactive to the date you completed the course.
If you present your certificate more than 90 days after course completion, the insurer may issue the premium discount effective from the date presented.
If you do not receive your certificate within eight weeks after completion, you must immediately contact the program sponsor.
You must take the Point and Insurance Reduction Program PIRP course once every 36 months to maintain insurance reduction benefits.
The Point and Insurance Reduction Program PIRP does not prevent general premium increases, or premium increases due to violations or accidents.
The Point and Insurance Reduction Program PIRP provides a 10% reduction for three years, from the base rate of your current liability, no - fault and collision premiums.
Only the principal operator can receive the 10% reduction from the Point and Insurance Reduction Program PIRP.
Any insured driver who is the principal operator and completes a Point & Insurance Reduction Program course will receive the 10% reduction.
If a youthful driver is already receiving a driver education reduction, you should contact your insurance company or agent to learn if both reductions will be given at the same time.
To drive taxis and other livery vehicles in New York State, you must be 18 years of age or older.

To drive taxis and other livery vehicles in New York State, you must have a driver license that is one of these classes: Class A commercial driver license (CDL), Class B CDL, Class C CDL, or Class E driver license.
If you plan on traveling, the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) recommends you come to the DMV now to get an Enhanced or REAL ID document, and avoid a second office visit later.
To change from a Class D license to a Class E license, you must complete the following steps: Step 1: Complete the Application for Standard Permit, Driver License for Non-Driver ID Card PDF MV-44.

To change from a Class D license to a Class E license, you must complete the following steps: Step 2: Determine what identification you need to bring to the DMV. If you want a REAL ID or Enhanced document, complete the document guide to know what proofs of identity to bring to an office. If you want a Standard document that will display 'NOT FOR FEDERAL PURPOSES', bring your current New York State license as proof of identity.

To change from a Class D license to a Class E license, you must complete the following steps: Step 3: Go to the DMV, surrender your Class D license, apply and pay for your Class E license (the fee depends on the expiration date of your current driver license), take the vision test or prove that you meet the vision requirements.
To change from a Class D license to a Class E license, you must complete the following steps: Step 4: Allow 2 weeks for your new Class E license to arrive in the mail.
If you do not have a New York State driver license, you must learn how to apply for your first driver license and apply for a Class E driver license instead of a Class D driver license.
The Class D license and the Class E license both require the same vision, written and road tests.
The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission (T&LC) regulates taxi drivers and livery drivers in New York City.
If you plan to drive a taxi or livery vehicle in New York City, you must contact the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission (T&LC).
Starting in October 2020, you will need an Enhanced or REAL ID document to board a domestic flight unless you have a passport.
If your New York State license or permit was issued before October 30, 2017 and is not Enhanced, you have a Standard document.
Newly issued Standard license and permits in New York State state: 'NOT FOR FEDERAL PURPOSES'.
To remove a lienholder from a title certificate, you do not need to go to your local DMV.
