You must mail the following items to the DMV: proof that the lien was satisfied (the original, photocopies are not accepted), your current title certificate (the original, photocopies not accepted), and a check or money order for $20.00 payable to 'Commissioner of Motor Vehicles'.
The mailing address is: Lien Release, NYS DMV Title Services, 6 Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228-0331.
The DMV will mail your certificate of title that does not list the lien in 60 to 90 days.
The title certificate must be mailed to you; a DMV office cannot give you the title certificate.

There are two acceptable proofs that a lien is satisfied: (1) Notice of Recorded Lien MV-901, which the lienholder can send to you with an authorized officer's signature indicating that the lien is satisfied, or (2) A letter from the lienholder printed on the official letterhead of the loan company, signed by an authorized officer, identifying the vehicle and indicating that the lien is satisfied. If the lienholder is a person and not a loan company, the letter must be notarized.
You can transfer a title certificate that has a lien listed by giving the new owner the original proof that any lien listed on the title certificate was satisfied.

When the new owner applies for a registration and title certificate, the DMV receives the title certificate and the proof that the lien is satisfied, and processes the title certificate of the new owner with the lien removed.
If the new owner does not provide the original proof that the lien is satisfied, the lienholder is listed on the title certificate of the new owner.

If your vehicle is registered in New York State and you receive the out-of-state title certificate from the lienholder, you should send the title certificate to the Title Services Bureau at the address shown above. The DMV will send you a New York State title certificate with no fee because you paid the title certificate fee when you registered your vehicle in New York.

If your title certificate is lost and you need to remove a lien, you should send an Application for a Duplicate Certificate of Title (MV-902) and the original proof that indicates that the lien is satisfied to the address above, or bring them to a DMV office. The DMV will process a duplicate title certificate that does not list the lien and mail the certificate to you. The fee is $20.00.
If you request that the DMV remove a lien when you apply for a duplicate title certificate, you can apply by mail or at a DMV office.

If your lienholder has an account with the DMV's Electronic Lien Transfer system (ELT), they can file to remove the lien electronically. If they electronically file to remove the lien, a new title will not be automatically sent to you. You will either need to send in your title, proof that the lien was satisfied, and a fee, as mentioned above, or apply for a duplicate title.
For more information about the Electronic Lien Transaction system, please see the Electronic Lien Transfer Program Business User Manual (ELT-1).
If the cause is You must immediately submit a copy of your USDOT Medical Examiners Certificate to the Medical Certification Unit.
If the cause is You must immediately submit an updated copy of your USDOT Medical Examiners Certificate to the Medical Certification Unit.
If the cause is You must contact the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) or your Medical Examiner to have this issue resolved.
You can send the required documents to DMV by mail.
The mailing address is NYS DMV Medical Certification Unit, PO Box 2601, Albany, NY 12220-0601.
You can send the required documents to DMV by fax.
The fax number is 518 486-4421 or 518 486-3260.
You can send the required documents to DMV by e-mail.
The e-mail address is [email protected]
Drivers can monitor their own CLP/CDL medical certification status through MyDMV.
Drivers can subscribe for text and/or email notifications.
Failure to respond to the NOTICE OF NON-COMPLIANCE AND LICENSE DOWNGRADE will result in your Commercial Driver License automatically being downgraded to a Non-CDL class.
Failure to respond to the NOTICE OF NON-COMPLIANCE AND LICENSE DOWNGRADE will result in your Commercial Learner Permit being cancelled as of the effective date on the notice.
You must submit your required information to the Medical Certification Unit at least 20 days before the effective date of the downgrade.
This will allow for receipt and processing time.
If the downgrade/cancellation occurs, you must complete and present an application to reinstate your commercial privileges in person at a DMV office.
All normal transaction fees will apply if the downgrade/cancellation occurs.
If you are a Commercial Learner Permit holder, you will need to retake any applicable knowledge tests you passed more than 180 days from the date you apply for reinstatement.
If you no longer want a Commercial Driver License/Commercial Learner Permit, you can get a non-commercial duplicate license online after the Effective Date on the downgrade notice.
The commercial class license document in your possession will no longer be valid after the Effective Date on the downgrade notice.
You may be charged with a violation of the Vehicle and Traffic Law (VTL) if you operate a commercial motor vehicle when not medically certified (VTL 509(7-a)).

You may be charged with a violation of the Vehicle and Traffic Law (VTL) if you operate a commercial motor vehicle when not in possession of the appropriate license to operate the vehicle (VTL 509(7)).
You may be charged with a violation of the Vehicle and Traffic Law (VTL) if you operate a commercial motor vehicle when not holding the appropriate class of license to operate the vehicle (VTL 509).
Sections 509 and 509-a are considered serious disqualifying offenses under federal and state law, when committed in a commercial motor vehicle.
If you are convicted of more than one serious disqualifying offense, your commercial driver license may be suspended.
If you purchased a vehicle at a sheriff or marshal auction, you might not have the title to that vehicle.
You can still apply for a New York State registration and a title certificate at a local DMV office if you purchased a vehicle at a sheriff or marshal auction.

To apply for a New York State registration and a title certificate at a local DMV office if you purchased a vehicle at a sheriff or marshal auction, you need to bring one of the following: a copy of the posted notice of sale, a copy of the newspaper ad containing the vehicle year, make and VIN, the name of the newspaper and the date the ad was published, a statement from the Marshal or Sheriff that they complied with the law in regard to public notification or sale.

To apply for a New York State registration and a title certificate at a local DMV office if you purchased a vehicle at a sheriff or marshal auction, you need to bring all of the following documents: a completed Vehicle Registration / Title Application PDF MV-82, the Marshal's or Sheriff's Bill of Sale which must contain a description of the vehicle year, make and VIN, the place, date, reason and circumstances of seizure, the name and address of the purchaser and the price paid, if the vehicle was sold outside New York City, a statement that all interested parties owner, lienholder, et al. were notified of the sale, if the vehicle was sold within New York City, a copy of the judgement or execution order giving the Marshal or Sheriff authority to sell the vehicle, if the vehicle was sold within New York City, a statement by the Marshal or Sheriff that they had notified or attempted to notify the owner and lienholder that the vehicle was being auctioned, the current NY State Insurance ID card auto liability insurance, your NY State driver license, permit, non-driver ID, or other proof of identity, payment for fees and taxes or proof of an exemption, if you register for a business or organization, also bring proof of incorporation.
The fees for registering a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction depend on the vehicle weight and where you live.

The first-time registration fees for a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction normally include the sales tax, a vehicle plate fee or registration transfer fee, a title certificate fee in most counties, a vehicle use tax, either a 1 or 2 year registration fee depending on the type of registration.
You can estimate the registration fees you will need to pay for a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction.

The DMV accepts cash, most credit, pinless debit or prepaid cards American Express, Discover Card / Novus, MasterCard, VISA, a personal check or a money order payable to you as payment for registering a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction.
You can split your payment between cash and check if you need to when registering a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction.
For more help on registering a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction, see Instructions Vehicle Registration / Titling Application PDF MV-82.1.
For specific information about registering various types of vehicles purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction, refer to the webpages listed on the DMV website.
You do not need to be a United States resident to register a vehicle in New York if you purchased it at a sheriff or marshal auction.
As long as you meet the registration requirements, you can register a vehicle in New York if you purchased it at a sheriff or marshal auction.

The DMV would like to inform you about New York State laws pertaining to vehicle identification numbers (VINs) on vehicles or motorcycles purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction in an effort to protect consumers.
Most vehicles purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction must comply with California emission standards.
The DMV provides information about sharing your registration information for vehicles purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction.
If you have a title for a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction, you can read more about registering the vehicle on the DMV website.

If you have a title for a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction, your insurance company will: 1) give you 2 barcoded original NY State Insurance ID cards or provide you with access to your digital electronic NY State Insurance ID Card, 2) send an electronic notice of insurance coverage to the DMV.
If you have a title for a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction, your insurance agent or broker cannot file the notice of insurance coverage to the DMV.
If you have a title for a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction, your NY State Insurance ID cards and the electronic notice together verify your coverage, and the DMV needs both.
If you have a title for a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction, you must register your vehicle within 180 days of the effective date on your Insurance ID Card.

If you have a title for a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction, you must bring one copy or form of your Insurance ID Card with you to the DMV office, and the DMV office will keep the paper card.
If you have a title for a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction, you must keep the other paper Insurance ID Card with the vehicle as your proof of insurance.
If you have a title for a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction, anyone operating your vehicle must be able to provide proof of insurance.
If you have a title for a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction, you can learn more about NY State Insurance Requirements on the DMV website.
If you have a title for a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction, you must provide proof of identity and date of birth.
If you have a title for a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction, you must be at least 16 years old except for ATV and boat registrations.

If you have a title for a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction, you can use a New York State driver license, learner permit, or non-driver ID card that is current or expired less than 2 years as proof of identity and age.

If you have a title for a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction and do not have a New York State driver license, learner permit, or non-driver ID card, you can see other kinds of proof you can use on the DMV website.
If you have a title for a vehicle purchased at a sheriff or marshal auction, see Instructions for Vehicle Registration / Title Application PDF MV-82.1 on the DMV website.
Use the both the registration fee and county use tax charts to determine your registration fee and county use tax.

If this is the original registration of your vehicle, in addition to the registration fee and county use tax, you must pay the fees for your vehicle plates $25.00 your title certificate fee of $50.00 the sales tax - the amount of the sales tax depends on the purchase price and your locality.
You can see the current sales tax rates by jurisdiction at the Department of Taxation and Finance web site.
There is a minimum 2-year fee of $32.50 for a vehicle that has 6 or more cylinders, or for an electric vehicle.
For dealers, this minimum fee is not a surcharge or an additional fee.
The chart shows the 2 year fee by vehicle weight for passenger vehicles.
Residents of New York City and several counties in New York State must pay a vehicle use tax when they register a passenger vehicle or renew a passenger vehicle registration.
If you reside outside New York City and you are exempt from the vehicle use tax in the county where you reside or have a business, complete form UT-11C.

For New York City (Bronx, Kings (Brooklyn), New York (Manhattan), Queens, Richmond (Staten Island)), for all passenger vehicle original registrations and renewals: Vehicle use tax - $30 for two years $15 per year Supplemental MCTD fee - $50 for two years $25 per year.
The chart shows the use taxes for all original registrations and renewals by the weight of the vehicle for counties outside of New York City.
Residents of the 12 counties in the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) also pay a supplemental fee for each year the registration is in effect.
Do not add $32.50 to the fee that the chart indicates or to the amount that the Estimate registration fees service calculates.
The DMV collects the taxes for the city and the counties.
Read the table below to determine if you must pay a vehicle use tax.
If you have questions about these taxes, ask the city or county where you reside or have a business.
If you reside in New York City and you are exempt from the NYC vehicle use tax, get form UT-11 from a local DMV office or a DMV Call Center.
If your vehicle is stolen, you must report it to the police and your auto insurance company as soon as possible.
The police will enter the information about the stolen vehicle into national and state auto theft computer records.
The theft of the vehicle will be noted on your vehicle title record to help prevent someone from selling the vehicle or applying for a title.
To report stolen plates, you must ask the police to complete a 'Report of Lost or Stolen Motor Vehicle Items' form MV-78B.
The form MV-78B for reporting stolen plates is different from the stolen vehicle report.
The form MV-78B is available only from police agencies, not from the DMV (Department of Motor Vehicles).
After obtaining the completed form MV-78B for stolen plates, you must make a copy of the form for your records.
You must bring the original form MV-78B to a DMV office to surrender your registration for the stolen plates.
For further information on reporting or replacing lost or stolen plates, you can refer to the 'Report or Replace Lost or Stolen Plates' section on the DMV website.
If your stolen vehicle is not recovered, you may have to transfer ownership of the vehicle to your insurance company using your title certificate.
If you have lost your title certificate for the stolen vehicle, you must apply for a duplicate title certificate.
Information on how to replace a title certificate can be found in the 'Replace a Title Certificate' section on the DMV website.
A duplicate title issued when a vehicle is stolen is marked to show that the vehicle is stolen and that the duplicate title is valid for insurance transfer only.
If your stolen vehicle is recovered before you transfer the 'insurance transfer only' title to your insurance company, you must ensure that the police have cancelled the stolen vehicle alarm.
After the police have cancelled the stolen vehicle alarm for a recovered vehicle, you must send the title to the Title Bureau along with a letter explaining that your vehicle was recovered.
The Title Bureau will then issue a regular title for the recovered vehicle.
The address for the Title Bureau is: Title Bureau, NYS DMV, PO Box 2750, Albany, NY 12220-0750.

If the vehicle was stolen before you were able to apply for registration and title in your name, you must first apply for a title in your name in order to transfer ownership to your insurance company.

To apply for a title in your name for a stolen vehicle before registration, you must obtain a letter from the insurance company on their letterhead stating that proof of ownership is required for insurance transfer only.
You must submit the letter from the insurance company along with your Application for Title [Only] MV-82TON to the DMV.
The DMV will issue a New York State Salvage Certificate MV-907A in your name for the stolen vehicle.
The MV-907A Salvage Certificate is an ownership document that can be transferred to your insurance company.
Information on how to apply for a title certificate only can be found in the 'Apply for a Title Certificate Only' section on the DMV website.
If your stolen vehicle is recovered, you must ensure that the police cancel the stolen vehicle alarm so that the recovery will be listed on your title record.
You must not use the recovered vehicle or apply for plates/registration until you are sure that the stolen vehicle alarm has been cancelled.
If the recovered vehicle is damaged or totaled, you must contact your auto insurance company before applying for plates/registration.

If the plates are recovered with your vehicle and you filed form MV-78B for stolen plates, you must bring the plates and your copy of the MV-78B to a DMV office to surrender them and apply for new plates and to reinstate your registration.

If the plates are missing when your stolen vehicle is recovered and you filed form MV-78B, you must bring your copy of form MV-78B to a DMV office and apply for new plates and reinstatement of your registration.

If the vehicle and plates are recovered before you file form MV-78B for stolen plates, and the stolen vehicle alarm has been cancelled, your registration is still active and you may continue using the registration.
You can surrender your vehicle plates at a local DMV office.
You can reinstate the registration later.
For example, you can surrender your vehicle plates and cancel liability insurance when you take your vehicle off the road for the winter.
To surrender plates in an office, you must bring your plates to a local DMV office and request a receipt for transfer.
You must not request a registration fee refund receipt.
You must remove plate frames and fasteners before you surrender the plates.
The DMV will not accept plates with frames or fasteners attached.
The DMV does not store standard vehicle plates.
If you surrender standard plates, they will be destroyed.
You can apply for reinstatement of the registration at any DMV office that processes registration transactions.
The DMV office can charge a vehicle plate fee of up to $25.00 for issuing a new set of vehicle plates.
If you surrender personalized plates or custom plates, the DMV office will store them.
You must apply for the reinstatement of the registration at the same DMV office where you surrendered your personalized plates or custom plates.
To reinstate surrendered plates, you must apply in a DMV office to reinstatement of your registration and receive vehicle plates.

To reinstate surrendered plates, you must bring the following items: a completed Application for Registration or Title (MV-82), the receipt (FS-6 T) you received when you surrendered your vehicle plates, an NY State Insurance ID Card (FS-20) that shows current insurance coverage, your proof of identity and date of birth, and a check or cash for any fees.
The registration expires on the same date as the registration you surrendered.
If you reinstate your registration within 60 days before the registration expires, you can renew the registration and pay the renewal fees.
If you have a problem driver restriction, you can drive only to and from your place of employment during the hours of your employment.

If your occupation requires the operation of a motor vehicle to and from a medical appointment which is part of a necessary medical treatment for you or a member of your household, you may be required to provide a written statement from your licensed medical provider that verifies the travel is necessary.
You can drive to and from a Motor Vehicle office to transact business related to the license / permit / privilege that contains a problem driver restriction.

If the child's attendance at the school / day-care is necessary for you to maintain employment or to maintain enrollment at an accredited school, college or university or a state-approved institution of vocational or technical training, you can drive to and from the child's school / day-care.
You can drive to and from an accredited school, college or university or a State-approved institution of vocational or technical training in which you are enrolled.
These restrictions are outlined on an attachment issued to you by the DMV.
You must carry the attachment whenever you operate a motor vehicle.
The problem driver restriction can only be applied to a class D license.
The problem driver restriction cannot be applied to any commercial driver license CDL Class A, B or C.
The problem driver restriction cannot be applied to a junior operator license Class DJ.
The problem driver restriction cannot be applied to a motorcycle operator license Class M or MJ.
The problem driver restriction cannot be applied to a class E driver license.
A driver with a CDL issued in another state cannot operate a commercial motor vehicle in New York State with a problem driver restriction on their New York State record.
You can drive through New York State with your out-of-state license with the problem driver restriction.

You must carry your completed, signed and dated problem driver restriction attachment and abide by the problem driver restrictions listed on the attachment when driving through New York State with your out-of-state license with the problem driver restriction.
There is no additional fee for the problem driver restriction.
You will pay the required driver license fees at the DMV office.
Your photo driver license or permit will have an A2 restriction displayed on the front of the document.
The words "PROBLEM DRIVER RESTRICTION" will be displayed on the back of your photo driver license or permit.
If your revocation was due to an alcohol-related incident, the problem driver restriction remains in effect for five years from the date you receive your driver license or permit.
If your revocation was not due to an alcohol related incident, the problem driver restriction remains in effect for two years from the date you receive your driver license or permit.
The problem driver restriction cannot be removed earlier.

The approval for a driver license or permit with the problem driver restriction will be withdrawn if you are convicted of any of these violations following too closely tailgating, speeding, speed contest, operating out of restriction, cell phone or texting violation, reckless driving, any two other traffic violations.
A seat belt violation by the vehicle operator is included in the violations that can lead to withdrawal of approval for a driver license or permit with the problem driver restriction.

Parking, stopping, standing, equipment, inspection or other non-moving violations are not included in the violations that can lead to withdrawal of approval for a driver license or permit with the problem driver restriction.
If the approval for a driver license or permit with the problem driver restriction is withdrawn due to a violation conviction, your driver license will be revoked for a minimum of 30 days.

If the approval for a driver license or permit with the problem driver restriction is withdrawn due to a violation conviction, you may then apply to the DIU for a new license and must pay a non-refundable $100 application fee.
If your driving history includes alcohol-related violations, you may be required to install an ignition interlock device on any and all vehicles you own and/or operate.
If you are required to install an ignition interlock device, you are also subject to the problem driving restrictions.
If you are required to install an ignition interlock device, your problem driver restriction attachment will indicate that you are required to have an ignition interlock device.
The DMV mandated ignition interlock is imposed and removed administratively by DMV.
An interlock restriction imposed by a court under Leandra's Law is imposed and removed by DMV under the orders of the court and is monitored by the court and designated monitors.
Any device that is approved by the NYS Division of Criminal Justice Services can be used as an ignition interlock device.
You can visit the Ignition Interlock page at the NYS Division of Criminal Justice Services website for a list of service center locations for ignition interlock devices.
You can visit the Ignition Interlock page at the NYS Division of Criminal Justice Services website for information about installation fees for ignition interlock devices.
The ignition interlock devices must be installed in any and all vehicles you own or operate.
The ignition interlock device must be installed for five years from the date you receive your driver license or permit if you have the problem driver restriction.
You must have the ignition interlock device installed for five years while you have the problem driver restriction.
You can be issued a traffic ticket for driving out of restriction with the problem driver restriction.
If you are convicted of driving out of restriction with the problem driver restriction, your driver license will be revoked.
An all-terrain vehicle (ATV) is any self-propelled vehicle with two or more wheels.
An ATV is manufactured for sale to be used primarily off-highway or in off-road competitions.
An ATV is no wider than 70 inches and weighs no more than 1,000 pounds.

Vehicles manufactured for off-highway use and designed exclusively for travel on snow or ice, and supported by one or more skis, belts or cleats that utilize an endless belt tread are not considered ATVs.
Snowmobiles are subject to other laws and regulations.
An ATV must be registered with the Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) if it is operated anywhere in New York State, including on the owner's property.
When registering a new or used ATV for the first time, the registration will expire each year on August 31.
For ATVs originally registered before April 1, 2005, the registrations will continue to expire each year on April 30.

ATV dealers are required by law to register every ATV they sell to New York State residents or to non-residents before the purchaser takes delivery, unless the purchaser qualifies for an exemption from registration.
A purchaser is exempt from registration when the ATV will be used exclusively: outside of New York State; at special events; for agricultural purposes; or for snow plowing other than for-hire.

Dealers must have the purchaser complete and sign a "Declaration of Exemption From Snowmobile or All-Terrain Vehicle Registration" (RV-6) if the purchaser qualifies for an exemption from registration.
Unless the purchaser qualifies for an exemption from registration, the purchaser cannot take delivery from an authorized dealer until after the ATV is registered.
If an ATV is bought from a person who is not a New York State registered ATV dealer, the ATV must be registered with the DMV.
To register an ATV, the owner must complete a "Vehicle Registration/Title Application" (MV-82) and submit it to a motor vehicle issuing office.
To register an ATV, the owner must provide proofs of ownership, sales tax payment or exemption, identity, and date of birth.
Escort driver certification is mandatory if you escort over-dimensional loads on the highways of New York State.
Escort driver certification is mandatory if you act as a flag person for over-dimensional loads.
Escort driver certification is not mandatory if you escort an over-dimensional load that is less than the requirement stated in footnote #1.
Escort driver certification is not mandatory if you are a member of the military and escort military convoys.
Escort driver certification is not mandatory if you escort state governmental vehicles.
To qualify as a certified escort driver, you must be 21 years old or older.
To qualify as a certified escort driver, you must have a valid New York State driver license or valid license in the state or jurisdiction in which you are a resident.
To qualify as a certified escort driver, you must pass the Escort Driver's Certification Test.
To get your escort vehicle driver certification, go to a DMV office that offers the escort driver certification test.
To get your escort vehicle driver certification, complete the Vehicle Escort Driver Application PDF MV-65.
To get your escort vehicle driver certification, take the written test.
You do not need to make an appointment to take the escort driver certification test.
The escort driver certification test is not offered in all DMV Offices.
If you have a NY State driver license, you must bring it with you when you go to the office to take the escort driver certification test.
If you have a driver license issued by another state, you must bring your valid driver license and additional identification with you to the office to take the escort driver certification test.
All information necessary to pass the escort driver certification test is in the Department of Transportation Certified Escort Manual PDF.
You should also be familiar with the New York State Driver's Manual to pass the escort driver certification test.
If you pass the escort driver certification test, you will be immediately certified to provide escort services for over-dimensional loads.
If you pass the escort driver certification test, you will be given a 60-day Interim Escort Driver Certificate.
Your permanent escort driver certification will be sent by mail if you pass the test.
You must have the escort driver certification in your possession when providing escort services.
The fee to take the vehicle escort test is $40.00.
Checks for the vehicle escort test must be made payable to the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
There are no additional fees for the initial escort driver certification.
You may take the written escort driver certification test again if you do not pass.
The fee is $40.00 each time you take the escort driver certification test.
If you have a New York State driver license, your Escort Driver Certificate will expire at the same time as your driver license.
If you have a driver license from another state, your Escort Driver Certificate will be valid for four years from the date it is issued.
You will receive a renewal notice in the mail for your Escort Driver Certificate.
You must follow the instructions in the renewal notice to renew your Escort Driver Certificate.
You must keep your mailing address current with NY State DMV to receive the renewal notice for your Escort Driver Certificate.
If you do not renew your Escort Driver Certificate within two years of the expiration date, you will be required to retake and pass the written test prior to being recertified.
If you have a New York State driver license, you must change your address within ten days.
If you have a New York State driver license, you must change your name within ten days.
The Bus Driver Unit cannot make address or name changes for you if you have a New York State driver license.
If you have a license issued by another state, you must notify DMV's Bus Driver Unit in writing within ten days of an address or name change.

To notify DMV's Bus Driver Unit of an address or name change if you have an out-of-state license, send your DMV ID Number, Client ID Number located on your escort certificate, former address or name, and your new address or name to the specified mailing address.
If your Vehicle Escort Card is lost, stolen, or destroyed, you may apply for a replacement by writing to DMV.
To apply for a replacement Vehicle Escort Card, send your name, address, and DMV ID Number/Client ID Number located on your escort certificate to the specified mailing address.
To apply for a replacement Vehicle Escort Card, send a check or money order for $5 made payable to the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles to the specified mailing address.
Your escort vehicle certification is not valid if your driver license or privilege is revoked or suspended in the issuing jurisdiction.
Your escort vehicle certification is not valid if you have lost your privilege to drive in New York State.
Your escort vehicle certification may also be canceled if you violate safe escort procedures or Title 17, Part 154 of the NYCRR New York Codes, Rules and Regulations.
Your escort vehicle certification may also be canceled if you become physically, mentally or medically unable to drive.
Your escort vehicle certification may also be canceled if you provide false or fraudulent information on the application for certification as an escort driver.
Depending on the nature of the violation, the driver may be subject to fines and penalties for violations related to their escort vehicle certification.
NY State does not recognize escort vehicle driver certifications issued in other states.
To legally operate an escort vehicle in NY State, you must have a valid NY State Certified Vehicle Escort Card MV-64.
You must carry the MV-64 card with your driver license when you drive an escort vehicle in NY State.

Loads that require an escort vehicle in NY State include: width exceeding 12 feet, length of 80 feet or greater, height of 14 feet or greater, or overhang of the load/vehicle exceeding the main body by greater than 10 feet.
Out of state drivers who do not have current New York State driving privileges are not eligible for escort certification.
You will receive test forms at the DMV office for the escort driver certification test.
Notes, manuals, and other study materials are not permitted during the escort driver certification test.
The DMV associate who administers the escort driver certification test is not permitted to discuss questions or offer any assistance.
You must apply for escort driver certification at a DMV Office.
Not all DMV offices offer the escort driver certification test.
If a DMV office offers the escort driver certification test, it will be indicated in the 'Office Hours' area for that office.
You can print a substitute online if your Traffic Violations Ticket (TVB) traffic ticket is lost or destroyed.
The ticket you are replacing must have the words 'Traffic Violations Bureau' at the bottom.
The ticket you are replacing must be an 'open' or unpaid ticket.
You will need the TVB traffic ticket number to print a substitute online.
You will need to enter all of the other information to determine if the DMV can locate the ticket record.

You will need either your DMV ID Number (Client ID Number from your New York State driver license, learner permit or non-driver photo ID card) or your full name, date of birth, and gender to print a substitute online.
You can print any open TVB traffic ticket you have, one at a time, after providing information for one open TVB traffic ticket.
A substitute ticket that you print from this transaction has exactly the same information as tickets printed at a TVB office.
If a traffic ticket is not available to print, the transaction will give you instructions on what you can do.
You cannot use this transaction for a ticket that was not answerable to a Traffic Violations Bureau (TVB).
The TVB does not handle parking violations or criminal driving violations (for example, DWI) or tickets answerable in a local court.
You cannot use this transaction for a ticket that has been dismissed or for which there was a conviction and the fines, fees and surcharges were all paid (a 'closed' ticket).
To amend the registration or get a replacement duplicate document for your current Repair & Body Shop, you must submit the Request for Business Amendment / Duplicate Certificate pdf MV-253 G.
You must mail the Request for Business Amendment / Duplicate Certificate pdf MV-253 G to NYS DMV Bureau of Consumer & Facility Services Application Unit P.O. Box 2700 Albany, NY 12220-0700.
You will receive a replacement document in the mail in approximately 5 to 7 business days.
NYS DMV cannot fax a copy of the replacement document to you.
To report a change of address for your business, you must complete a Statement of Ownership and/or Permission to Use Place of Business pdf VS-19.
You can call the DMV Office of Vehicle Safety and Clean Air at 1-518-474-4653 to get the Statement of Ownership and/or Permission to Use Place of Business pdf VS-19.
You can call 1-518-474-0919 to get more information about reporting a change of address for your business.
It will take 6 to 8 weeks for NYS DMV to process your application for a change of address.
Repair shops must provide a Certificate of Occupancy, local license or town letter as proof of zoning approval.
If the new location was previously registered as a repair shop, you can provide the Facility number or name of that shop as proof of zoning.
If you also have an Inspection Station License, you must see Inspection Station Cap Information.
You can sign up to get email and/or text reminders before your driver license expires.
You can sign up to get email and/or text reminders before your non-driver ID card expires.
You can sign up to get email and/or text reminders before your registration expires.
You can sign up to get email and/or text reminders before your vehicle inspection expires.
DMV will enroll you after you complete an online registration renewal transaction as part of a new initiative to save taxpayers more than $500,000 per year.
You can update your subscription at any time.
Commercial driver license (CDL) holders can sign up to get email and/or text reminders regarding the status of their medical certifications.
Commercial learner permit (CLP) holders can sign up to get email and/or text reminders regarding the status of their medical certifications.
Commercial driver license (CDL) holders can sign up to get email and/or text reminders regarding the status of their medical variances.
Commercial learner permit (CLP) holders can sign up to get email and/or text reminders regarding the status of their medical variances.

If your driver license, non-driver ID, registration, inspection, medical certification or medical variance is close to expiring when you sign up, you may not get electronic reminders until the next time it's due.
You can sign up to get email and/or text reminders online.
You received the email from mess[email protected] because you are in the DMV Electronic Reminders program.
You will not receive a response if you write to the email address mess[email protected].
To get registration renewal and inspection reminders, you must be the primary registrant first name listed on a registration, if the vehicle is registered to more than one person.
You won't get reminders if your registration is not eligible to renew, for example, you can't renew if the registration is suspended or revoked.
The email address you provide to sign up for electronic reminders will replace any other email address you provided the DMV in the past.
The DMV only keeps one email address for each customer.
You can update your electronic reminders subscription to receive email and/or text reminders as well as paper reminders by mail for your vehicle registrations.
If your vehicle registration is due to expire within the next 75 days, you will probably not receive a paper reminder.
If you want to stop receiving email and/or text reminders, you can select the 'unsubscribe' option on the Subscription Page and enter your ID number and date of birth on the unsubscribe page.
The NY State Freedom of Information Law provides access to state and local government records.
The Committee on Open Government provides more information about the NY State Freedom of Information Law.
Many DMV records are available using the Request for DMV Records PDF MV-15.
If you use the MV-15, you will often receive records sooner than if you submitted a Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request.
You may request any DMV records under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL).
Certain records or parts of records can be withheld under Section 87 of the NY State Public Officers Law when you request DMV records under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL).
When you request DMV records under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL), the DMV will send you a letter within 5 business days after the DMV receives your request.
The letter will tell you that your request under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) was received.
In most cases, the records requested under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) will be made available within 20 business days from the date of the acknowledgment letter.
In some cases, it may take longer than 20 business days to produce records under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL).
If the DMV cannot provide your records requested under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) within 20 business days, the DMV will tell you the date the records will be available.
The DMV Subject Matter List of Records provides information about records that can be requested under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL).
The Request for DMV Records PDF MV-15 should be read to determine if the records are available without a request under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL).
If the record you are requesting is available by using the MV-15, doing so may allow you to receive your records more quickly than filing a Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request.
If you decide that you are eligible to request the records under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL), you must make your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request in writing.
To make a request under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL), you can complete the Freedom of Information Law Request Form PDF MV-FOIL or write a letter that describes the records you seek.
You should include your mailing address or email address in your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request to allow the DMV to send the records to you.

If the records you are requesting under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) include personal information, you should include a photocopy of your driver license or other government issued photo ID card.
You may black out the picture on your driver license or other government issued photo ID card that you include with your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request.
You must identify your permissible use for the record you are requesting under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL).
Permissible uses for records requested under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) are listed on Page 2 of the MV-15FOIL.

You can mail your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request, form or letter to Records Access Officer, New York State Department of Motor Vehicles, FOIL Office, 6 Empire State Plaza, Room 136B, Albany, NY 12228.
You can email your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request to [email protected]
When emailing your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request, you should include your name and mailing address or email address.
When emailing your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request, you should attach a copy of your government issued photo ID, if required.
The FOIL office will respond to your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request within 5 business days of receiving the request.
The FOIL office will either provide you with the record requested under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) or acknowledge receipt of your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request.
The FOIL office will provide a time frame for when you can expect to receive the record you requested under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL).
There is a $10.00 search fee to determine if the records you requested under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) are available.
Your payment of the search fee for a Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request does not guarantee that you will receive the records that you requested.
The search fee for a Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request cannot be refunded.
The FOIL office will tell you if the records that you requested under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) are available or not available.
If the records requested under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) are available and you want paper copies, there is a copy fee of $1.00 for each page.
A page for the copy fee under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) is a single sheet of paper, whether one-sided or two-sided.
You may pay the fees for a Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request by credit card, or by a check or money order made payable to Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
The FOIL office will not release the record you have requested under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) until payment has been received in full.
Certain individuals or organizations are exempt from paying search fees for Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) requests when searches are being performed for a public purpose.

The individuals or organizations exempt from paying search fees for Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) requests for a public purpose are: government agencies, volunteer fire companies, volunteer ambulance services, public officers, boards, or bodies, legal aid bureaus or societies, or other private entities when acting pursuant to Section 722 of the New York State County Law.
Records requested under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) rarely can be produced on the same day that they are requested.
Most DMV records requested under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) are available within twenty 20 business days of the FOIL Office's written acknowledgment of your request.
If a phone number was provided with your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request, the FOIL office will call you when your records are ready to be inspected.
If no phone number was provided with your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request, you will be notified by mail when your records are ready to be inspected.

When the records you requested under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) are ready to be inspected, you will need to come to the Customer Service Counter, Room 136, Swan Street Building, Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228.
If the DMV has denied your request for a record in whole or in part under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL), you may appeal the denial.
You must appeal the denial of your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request in writing within thirty 30 days of the date of denial.
Your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) appeal must identify the date of your record request and a description of the records that were denied.

You should complete the FOIL Appeal Form PDF AA-33FI and mail it to Department of Motor Vehicles, FOIL Appeals Officer, P.O. Box 2935, Albany, New York 12220-0935 to appeal the denial of your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request.
You can make your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request in writing to the DMV FOIL Office by using the Freedom of Information Law Request Form MV-FOIL or writing a letter.

You should send the Freedom of Information Law Request Form MV-FOIL or letter to Records Access Officer, New York State Department of Motor Vehicles, FOIL Office, 6 Empire State Plaza, Room 136B, Albany, NY 12228 to make your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request.
The Driver Violation Point System gives the New York State DMV a way to identify and take action against high risk drivers.
The DMV assigns points for certain traffic violations.
If you get 11 points in an 18-month period, your driver license may be suspended.
The point system is not the only way to lose your license.
You must be convicted of the traffic violation before points are added to your driving record.
Your point total is calculated based on the date of the violation, not the date of the conviction.
The points for violations that all occurred within the last 18 months are added to calculate your point total.
Points are not assigned for any bicycle violation.
Points are not assigned for any pedestrian violation.
Points are not assigned for any parking violation.
Points are not assigned for any violation related to unregistered, unlicensed or uninsured operation.
Points are not assigned for any violation related to motor vehicle inspection, vehicle weights or dimensions or vehicle equipment other than inadequate service brakes.
Points are not assigned for any violation related to a business or the sale of goods established in the Vehicle and Traffic Law or any local law.
Points are not assigned for a violation related to the improper use of High Occupancy Vehicle Lanes in Suffolk County, between exits 49 and 57 of the Long Island Expressway.
Points are not assigned for any other violation not resulting from the operation of a motor vehicle.
If you receive 6 or more points on your New York State driving record in 18 months, you must pay a Driver Responsibility Assessment fee.
If you are convicted of a traffic violation in another state or country, points are not added to your New York State driving record, unless the violation occurred in Ontario or Quebec.
New York State has a reciprocal agreement with Quebec and Ontario.
Traffic violation convictions that occur in Quebec and Ontario are recorded on your New York State driver record.
Traffic violation convictions that occur in Quebec and Ontario have the same effect and carry the same points as convictions that occur in New York State.
Traffic violation convictions that occur in Quebec and Ontario can affect your driver violation point total and Driver Responsibility Assessment.
Insurance companies have their own point systems and can increase your premiums based on your driving record.
Taking a DMV-approved Point and Insurance Reduction Program (PIRP) course will help to prevent you from losing your license in the event you accrued 11 or more points on your driving record.
4 points are 'subtracted' for the purposes of a suspension if you have 11 or more points after taking a PIRP course.
The tickets/points do not physically come off your driving record after taking a PIRP course.
Taking a PIRP course can save 10 percent on your automobile liability and collision insurance premiums.
You can use the MyDMV 'My License, Permit or ID' service to check your points.
You will need the ID number and document number from your New York State driver license, learner permit, or Non-Driver ID to check your points through MyDMV.
If you claim that someone else committed a violation on your record, you can request a hearing.
You cannot request a DMV hearing to prove that you were not guilty of the violations.
Once 18 months have passed from the violation date, the points for that violation no longer count toward your total.
The points remain on your driving record as long as the conviction remains on your record.
The points that remain on your driving record may be used by your insurance company to increase premiums.
Your NY State Driver License will be suspended if you fail to answer a ticket for a moving violation in any state except Alaska, California, Michigan, Montana, Oregon or Wisconsin.
Your license will remain suspended until you answer the ticket.
Drivers from any state, except those from the six states listed above, will have their driver licenses suspended in their own state for failure to answer a moving violation in New York State.

The New York State DMV does not record out-of-state convictions of moving traffic violations of New York State non-commercial licensed drivers, except for traffic offenses committed in the provinces of Ontario and Quebec in Canada.

If you are 21 years of age or older when you commit an alcohol or drug related driving violation in any other state or the provinces of Ontario and Quebec in Canada and you are convicted of the violation, your New York State driver license will be revoked for at least 90 days.
Out-of-state drivers ticketed in New York State should contact the Motor Vehicle Department of their own state or province about the effect of a conviction in New York State.

If you are under the age of 21 when you commit an alcohol or drug related driving violation that occurs out-of-state and you are convicted of the violation, your New York State driver license will be revoked for at least one year.
If you have any prior alcohol or drug related driving conviction, your license will be revoked for at least one year or until the age of 21, whichever is longer.

The New York State DMV records the out-of-state convictions of any New York driver for criminal negligence, homicide, or assault, which arise out of the operation of a motor vehicle and which results in death.
As a result of any of these convictions, your NY State Driver License will be revoked.
A New York State resident must have a Class M or Class MJ driver license or learner permit to drive a motorcycle.
To get a motorcycle license, you must first get a motorcycle learner permit.
DMV offers 3 types of documents: Enhanced, REAL ID and Standard documents.
To apply for a motorcycle permit at a DMV office, you must study the NY State Motorcycle Operator's Manual MV-21MC to prepare for the written test.
To apply for a motorcycle permit at a DMV office, you must have the documents and proofs of identification you need.
To apply for a motorcycle permit at a DMV office, you must complete the DMV Document Guide to make sure you have the required proofs of identification.
If you already have a New York State learner permit or driver license, you must bring the document when applying for a motorcycle permit at a DMV office.
You must bring payment for the $10.00 application fee and the motorcycle license fee when applying for a motorcycle permit at a DMV office.
Before you schedule your motorcycle road test, it is recommended that you have at least 30 hours of practice on a motorcycle, with or without formal instruction.
Before you schedule your motorcycle road test, it is recommended that you have at least 10 hours of practice in medium to high volume traffic.
It is recommended that you consider taking the New York State Motorcycle Safety Program Basic Rider Course or instruction from a commercial driving school before scheduling your motorcycle road test.
When you practice driving with a motorcycle learner permit, you must be supervised by a driver age 21 or older who has a valid motorcycle license from any state.
The motorcycle driver who supervises you when practicing with a learner permit must be within 1/4 mile of you at all times.
When practicing with a motorcycle learner permit, you must obey the general restrictions for permit holders.
If you have a Class MJ permit, you must obey the restrictions and requirements for drivers under age 18 when practicing.
To schedule and take a motorcycle road test, see the information on 'Schedule and take a road test'.
If you do not already have another class of New York State driver license, you must complete a pre-licensing course or a Driver Education course before you can schedule a road test.
If you already have another class of New York State license, you do not need a pre-licensing course or Student Certificate of Completion to schedule a motorcycle road test.

If you pass the motorcycle road test and do not have another class of New York State driver license, you will receive your motorcycle license with your photo by mail about 2 weeks after your road test.

If you pass the motorcycle road test and already have another class of New York State driver license, you must wait at least 7 days after your road test to apply for your motorcycle license at a DMV office.

To apply for your motorcycle license at a DMV office after passing the road test and already having another class of New York State driver license, you must complete an Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card PDF MV-44.

When applying for your motorcycle license at a DMV office after passing the road test and already having another class of New York State driver license, you must mark the 'Change' box at the top of the MV-44 form and write in 'Add Class M or MJ' in the 'Other Change' box.

When applying for your motorcycle license at a DMV office after passing the road test and already having another class of New York State driver license, you must bring your temporary motorcycle license, your motorcycle permit and your current photo license.

When applying for your motorcycle license at a DMV office after passing the road test and already having another class of New York State driver license, you must pay the $12.50 fee to amend your driver license.
Both driver license classes will be listed on your new document after adding the motorcycle license class, for example, Class DM.
Your new license with the added motorcycle class expires on the same date as your previous license.
The DMV office will issue a temporary license without a photo when you apply to add the motorcycle license class to an existing New York State driver license.
You will receive your new license with the added motorcycle class by mail about two weeks after applying at the DMV office.
The motorcycle road test can be waived if you are qualified and you complete an approved course.

To get information about approved courses for waiving the motorcycle road test in your area, you can visit the New York State Motorcycle Safety Program website or call their toll-free number 1-800-446-9227.
To qualify for waiving the motorcycle road test, you must be 16 years of age or older.
To qualify for waiving the motorcycle road test, you must have a valid NY State license Class A, B, C, D, DJ or E.
To qualify for waiving the motorcycle road test, you must have a valid class M or MJ motorcycle learner permit.

To qualify for waiving the motorcycle road test, you must present either a Basic Rider Course (BRC) or a Basic Rider Course 2 License/Waiver (BRC2-LW) Course completion card issued by the NY State Motorcycle Safety Foundation within two years of completing the course.
You cannot get a waiver for a motorcycle road test if you completed a rider course given in another state.
There are waivers available in some cases for members of the U.S. Armed Forces for the motorcycle road test.
If you have a valid motorcycle license issued by another state where you are a resident, you can drive motorcycles in New York State.
If you become a resident of New York State, you should exchange your out-of-state motorcycle license for a New York State motorcycle license.
Motorcycle safety information is available from the New York State Governor's Traffic Safety Committee.
The fees you pay when you get your first motorcycle license depend on whether or not you currently have another class of NYS driver license and your exact age when you apply.
The fees for a Class M or MJ driver license, or to add class M or MJ to your current driver license, can range from $21 to $120.
A Pre-licensing Course Certificate MV-278 is valid for one year.
A Student Certificate of Completion MV-285 is valid for two years.

A member of the US Armed Forces who completes the MSF Basic Rider Course (BRC) through the military while on active duty outside of New York State can qualify to have their military BRC converted into a NY BRC and receive the road test waiver.
To surrender an IRP registration because you do not wish to renew the registration, send the apportioned plates and the cab card to the address below.
If you wish to renew at a later time and do not surrender your apportioned plates, you will be charged a registration fee for the entire year.
To surrender the IRP registration and delete the vehicle from your fleet, complete and sign the Schedule A & C pdf IRP-6.
In Part 1 of Schedule A & C pdf IRP-6, check DELETE VEHICLE and complete the sections of the form.
In Part 2 of Schedule A & C pdf IRP-6, complete the Deletion section.
Send the apportioned plates and the cab card with Schedule A & C pdf IRP-6 to the following address: International Registration Bureau, PO Box 2850 ESP, Albany, NY 12220-0850.
To surrender the IRP registration and delete the vehicle from your fleet, complete and sign form Schedule A & C pdf.
In Part 1 of Schedule A & C pdf, check DELETE VEHICLE and complete the Carrier and Fleet Information sections of the form.
In Part 2 of Schedule A & C pdf, complete the Deletion section.
Bring the completed Schedule A & C pdf, the apportioned plates, and the cab card to the Customer Service Counter, Room 136, Swan Street Building, Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228.
You may qualify for a refund of IRP registration fees you paid to NY State if the NY State IRB made an error and the error is on your invoice.
You may qualify for a refund of IRP registration fees you paid to NY State if you paid duplicate apportioned registration fees for the same vehicle or vehicles.
You may qualify for a refund of IRP registration fees you paid to NY State if you paid standard registration renewal fees in error after you changed to an IRP registration.

You may qualify for a refund of IRP registration fees you paid to NY State if you can provide proof that the last date of operation of a vehicle occurred before the effective date of the IRP registration.
To request a refund, complete Request for Refund pdf MV-215, and send it to IRB office.
DMV must subtract a $5.00 processing fee from the refund amount, and the minimum amount of a refund is $1.00.
You can request a refund only of IRP registration fees under the conditions listed above.
You cannot get a refund of cab card fees, vehicle plate fees, or IRP Temporary Authority fees.
You may request a refund of the NY State portion of an IRP registration fee paid to another jurisdiction only if the other jurisdiction made an error and the error is on your invoice.
You may request a refund of the NY State portion of an IRP registration fee paid to another jurisdiction only if you paid duplicate apportioned registration fees for the same vehicle or vehicles.

IRB must receive written verification from the other jurisdiction, including the registered weight of the vehicle, the apportioned mileage percentage, the fee paid to New York State and the reason a refund is requested.
If any apportioned plates are lost or stolen, get a completed form Report of Lost or Stolen Motor Vehicle Items MV-78B from a police agency and send form MV-78B with form IRP-6.
Surrender the apportioned plates only if no vehicle will replace the current vehicle.
You must return the unused cab card, sticker and apportioned plates within 60 days after you received them original or within 60 days of the effective date of registration renewal.
You can't surrender your IPR registration by phone.
You can call the IRB with questions at 1-518-473-5834.
You can surrender your IRP registration by mail by following the instructions on this page and Schedule A&C IRP-6.
You can surrender an IRP registration at the Customer Service Counter, Room 136, Swan Street Building, Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228.
You can't surrender an IRP registration at a DMV local office.

A Private Service Bureau (PSB) license is required of any person, firm, association or corporation engaged in the business of assisting for hire in securing licenses to drive motor vehicles, registrations, or titles of motor vehicles.
To avoid public confusion, a name that includes 'DMV' or 'Motor Vehicles' will not be approved for a Private Service Bureau (PSB).
To apply for a license to operate a Private Service Bureau (PSB), you must submit to the NY State DMV your form PSB-3 that shows your PSB name was approved by the DMV.

To apply for a license to operate a Private Service Bureau (PSB), you must submit a photocopy of a valid NY State driver license or non-driver photo ID card for the business owner and all employees of the PSB.
To apply for a license to operate a Private Service Bureau (PSB), you must submit a completed Application for a License to Operate a Private Service Bureau or Open a Branch Office (MV-372).

To apply for a license to operate a Private Service Bureau (PSB), you must submit a completed Personal History (MV-521.1) for each owner, partner, corporate officer, agent, employee and major stockholder (20% or more of stock) listed on Form MV-372.

To apply for a license to operate a Private Service Bureau (PSB), you must submit a copy of the receipt provided to clients as required by Section 77.5 of the Regulations of the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
If you do not have employees for your Private Service Bureau (PSB), you must submit a completed Form CE-200 Certificate of Attestation of Exemption from NY State Workers Compensation.
If you have employees for your Private Service Bureau (PSB), you must submit your proof of current Workers Compensation and Disability Insurance Coverage.

To apply for a license to operate a Private Service Bureau (PSB), you must submit a Business Certificate (X-201), a Business Certificate for Partnerships (X-74) or NY State Department of State Filing Receipt (DOS-1025).
To apply for a license to operate a Private Service Bureau (PSB), you must submit the application fee of $25.00 (non-refundable), payable to Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
After your application for a Private Service Bureau (PSB) license is reviewed by the DMV in Albany, it is sent to your local Motor Vehicle office.
The local Motor Vehicle office schedules an inspection for your Private Service Bureau (PSB) license application.
When the inspector visits your location for your Private Service Bureau (PSB) license application, the inspector can ask you to provide the original lease for review.

When the inspector visits your location for your Private Service Bureau (PSB) license application, the inspector can ask you to provide the original business certificate and/or corporate papers and/or filing receipt for review.
When the inspector visits your location for your Private Service Bureau (PSB) license application, the inspector can ask you to provide a sample customer receipt for review.
When the inspector visits your location for your Private Service Bureau (PSB) license application, the inspector can ask you to provide a permanent, bound book for review.
When the inspector visits your location for your Private Service Bureau (PSB) license application, the inspector can ask you to provide a filing cabinet for review.

When the inspector visits your location for your Private Service Bureau (PSB) license application, the inspector can ask you to provide your proof of Workers Compensation Insurance (if required) for review.
When the inspector visits your location for your Private Service Bureau (PSB) license application, the inspector can ask you to provide three character reference letters for review.
A Private Service Bureau (PSB) license expires every two years on June 30.
To renew your Private Service Bureau (PSB) license, use Application for Private Service Bureau License Renewal (MV372R).
You must apply for a conditional or restricted use license in person at a DMV office.
You can do this at most, but not all, Motor Vehicles offices.
You must contact your nearest office to find out where you can apply.
The DMV can issue a conditional license to a qualified driver whose NY State license has been suspended or revoked because of an alcohol or drug-related violation.
The driver must attend an Impaired Driver Program (IDP) approved by the DMV.
The Impaired Driver Program (IDP) was previously known as the Drinking Driving Program (DDP).

The DMV can issue a restricted use license to a driver who qualifies and whose license is suspended or revoked because of violations or incidents that are not alcohol or drug-related, or because of some drug-related violations.
If you have a driver license issued in another state, and you meet the other requirements, you can receive a conditional driving privilege or a restricted driving privilege to drive in NY State.
The conditions for a driver with a license from another state are the same as the conditions for a driver with a NY State driver license.
The restrictions for a driver with a license from another state are the same as the restrictions for a driver with a NY State driver license.
Getting a permit is the first step to get your driver license.
Most people apply for a Class 'D - Operator' permit.
You must be 16 or older and must apply in person at a DMV office.
You need to study the NY State Driver's Manual and take the practice tests.
The Class D and M permit tests are given in 14 languages: English, Albanian, Arabic, Bosnian, Chinese, French, Greek, Hebrew, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Polish, Russian and Spanish.
To pass the Class D and M permit test, you must get at least 14 of the 20 multiple-choice questions correct.
To pass the Class D and M permit test, you must get the correct answers to at least two of the four questions about road signs.
If you are applying for a motorcycle permit, you must get at least three out of the five motorcycle questions correct.
You need to complete a guide to make sure you have the documents and proofs of identification you need before going to the DMV.
You need to find your proofs of identification and residence.
Bringing a parent or guardian is required if you are using the 'Statement of Identity and/or Residence by Parent/Guardian PDF' MV-45.
You need to find a DMV office location and see if a reservation is necessary for the written test.
You need to apply and pay for your permit using the fee chart to estimate your cost.
You need to take your written test at the DMV office.
If you fail the written test, you can try again at no additional cost.
For quicker service, you need to make a reservation online before visiting DMV offices in New York City, Westchester, Nassau, Suffolk, Rockland, Onondaga, Monroe or Albany Counties.
For all other counties, you need to see the DMV office locations and hours.
You need to wait up to 2 weeks for your permit to come in the mail.
Your permit will be valid for approximately 5 years.
The exact expiration date of your permit depends on your date of birth and the date that you applied.
Once you have your permit, you can move onto preparing for your road test.
You must have supervised driving practice.
You must take a pre-licensing course or a driver education course before you take your road test.
You need to learn how to find a pre-licensing course and prepare for your road test.
You will need to follow all learner permit restrictions.
If you are under age 18, you must wait at least 6 months from the date you received your learner permit to schedule your road test.
Before your permit expires, you need to take your road test.
You can renew a permit.
You need to schedule and take a road test.
If you pass your road test, the examiner will give you an interim license that allows you to drive.
You need to keep the interim license with your photo permit until your new license arrives in the mail in about 2 weeks.
If you fail the road test, you need to start again at preparing for your road test.
There are special requirements to apply for a motorcycle permit/license, a commercial learner permit, a taxi license, or enhanced permit.
If you are under 18, you need a Certification of Supervised Driving PDF MV-262 completed by your parent or guardian.

To become a licensed Inspection Station by the Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) in New York State, you must consult the DMV Commissioner's Motor Vehicle Inspection Regulations (pdf CR-79) and read Facility Requirements Inspection Stations (pdf VS-143).
To apply to become an Inspection Station, you must submit the Original Facility Application (pdf VS-1) with all required documentation.
If you are applying to be a Public Inspection Station, you must also have a registered repair shop at that location.
You can call the Office of Vehicle Safety and Clean Air at 1-518-474-4653 to get the forms, or call 1-518-474-0919 to get more information.

To apply, you must submit the Original Facility Application (pdf VS-1) along with a notarized statement from the property owner, proof of your Sales Tax ID number and a copy of your Sales Tax Certificate of Authority, proof of Workers' Compensation Insurance for your employees (or indicate if you do not have employees), a photocopy of the driver's license or other government-issued photo ID for everyone listed on the application, a receipt for your purchase of the inspection station sign, all required fees payable to the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, a Filing Receipt from the NY State Department of State (for corporations or LLCs) or a Business Certificate from the County Clerk (for individuals using an assumed name or partnerships), and any additional requirements if you are also applying to be a repair shop.

If you do not have your Certificate of Authority and Sales Tax ID number yet, you must apply for them from the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance before submitting an application with DMV.

If you do not have your Proof of Business Name yet, you must obtain it before submitting an application with DMV. Corporations and LLCs must submit a copy of their Filing Receipt from the Department of State, while partnerships and individuals using an assumed name must submit a copy of their Business Certificate of Assumed Name from the county clerk.
If you do not have your proof of Workers' Compensation Insurance yet, you must obtain it before submitting an application with DMV, unless you do not have any employees.
You must submit a hard copy of your application, associated documents, and fee to the NYS DMV Bureau of Consumer & Facility Services Application Unit at P.O. Box 2700, Albany, NY 12220-0700.

During the on-site investigation, the automotive facilities inspector will check for permanently mounted signs visible from the street, proof of identification for everyone named on the application, a mailbox dedicated to your business only, a method of locking security items, heat, electricity, desk and chairs, a business phone, sufficient space to perform inspections, tools required to perform inspections for the inspection groups you are applying for, and the name and ID number of the certified inspector.
If approved, you will be issued a license once you have purchased the Computerized Vehicle Inspection System (CVIS) for those stations inspecting group 1a vehicles.
Only stations that inspect group 1a vehicles are required to have a CVIS. Opus Inspection is the current vendor providing the equipment to New York State inspection stations.

DMV does not provide official inspection station signs. You may purchase these signs from various sign shops and automotive supply stores, and the sign requirements will differ based on the types of vehicles you will be inspecting.

To apply by mail, you must send your completed application, a copy of your Sales Tax Certificate of Authority, and all fees to the NYSDMV Bureau of Consumer and Facility Services Application Unit at P.O. Box 2700, Albany, NY 12220-0700.
You can help avoid trouble with an unreliable or dishonest repair shop by following these tips.
Deal only with a registered shop.
Make sure there's a green and white 'Registered State of New York Motor Vehicle Repair Shop' sign outside the shop.
Make sure there's a valid New York State Department of Motor Vehicles DMV registration certificate inside the shop.
Use the 'Find a DMV-regulated Business' service to find a registered repair shop in your area.
Ask your family, friends and co-workers for advice on reliable repair shops in your area.
Ask your family, friends and co-workers for advice on repair shops you should avoid in your area.
Keep all records, including estimates, invoices, work orders, receipts, guarantees and warranties.
Records serve as your record of service.
Records could increase your vehicle's resale value.
If you authorize repair work by phone, write down the date and time.
If you authorize repair work by phone, write down the name of the person you spoke with.
If you authorize repair work by phone, write down any estimated price quoted.
If you authorize repair work by phone, write down other pertinent details.
Don't be afraid to ask questions.
Management of a shop should take the time to explain required repairs and prices.
Management of a shop should take the time to discuss problems.
Management of a shop should take the time to tell you about the training and experience of employees.
Under the Repair Shop Act, you have the following rights when dealing with a repair shop.
If you request it, the repair shop must give you a written estimate of the parts and labor necessary for each specific repair.
The shop may charge a reasonable fee for developing a written estimate.
The labor charge for an estimate may not exceed the shop's usual hourly labor charge.
The estimate must list each part and its cost.
The estimate must show what parts, if any, are either used or not of original quality.
The estimate must show the labor charges for each repair.
The estimate must show by what method the labor charges are calculated.
The shop may not charge more than the estimated price without your permission.
A shop may not perform any services unless you give your permission.
If the shop prepares a written work order, it must give you a copy.
If you prepare a written work order, the shop must attach it to the invoice.
If work is authorized verbally or by telephone, the invoice must show the date, time, and name of the person giving authorization.
You are entitled to the return of all replaced parts, except warranty and exchange parts.
You must ask for the return of replaced parts in writing before any work is done.
If you authorize work by phone, the shop must keep any replaced parts.
The shop must make replaced parts available when you pick up the vehicle.
When repairs are completed, the shop must give you a detailed invoice.
The invoice must list each repair done.
The invoice must list each part replaced.
The invoice must list the cost for each repair and part.
The invoice must list the cost of labor.
The invoice must show which replacement parts, if any, are used, or not of original quality.
The invoice must show the odometer reading at the time you left the vehicle for repair.
The invoice must show the odometer reading when the invoice was prepared.
If the shop promised a delivery date, that must be listed on the repair order.
If you received a written estimate, compare it with the invoice and try to resolve any questions before you pay for the repairs.
You have the right to inspect your vehicle at the shop before paying for repairs.
Inspecting your vehicle does not give you the right to remove the vehicle from the shop without paying for the repairs.
Inspecting your vehicle does not give you the right to inspect it in areas where only authorized employees are allowed.
