A shop is not required to guarantee its work.
If a shop voluntarily guarantees repairs, the terms and time limit of the guarantee must be listed on the invoice.
If you are not satisfied with the quality or price of a repair, discuss it with the management of the shop.
Many misunderstandings can be resolved through a calm, honest discussion.
First, attempt to resolve the issue with the management of the business if you have a repair problem.
Keep a written record of all contacts with management in addition to details about the repair if you have a repair problem.
Copies of work orders and invoices are proof of your attempts to resolve the problem if you have a repair problem.

If a satisfactory resolution is not reached and you wish to file a complaint, you must submit a Vehicle Safety Complaint Report PDF along with any supporting documents to the DMV Consumer & Facilities Services Complaint Unit.
To submit electronically, download the complaint report available at the link above to your personal device.
Attach and then email the completed report as well as any supporting documents to [email protected].
Please note that DMV staff will communicate with you through email.
You can also submit the complaint to the Complaint Unit, Bureau of Consumer & Facility Services, Department of Motor Vehicles, P.O. Box 2700-ESP, Albany, NY 12220-0700.
You can also submit the complaint by fax to 518 486-4102.
You can also submit the complaint by phone to 1-518-474-8943 between 8:30 a.m. and 4:15 p.m., Monday - Friday.
You can also submit the complaint by email to [email protected].
DMV staff will not investigate a complaint until a completed VS-35 Complaint Report has been received.
The department does not investigate complaints that have been filed anonymously.
There is a 90-day limit on reporting incidents related to a NYS Repair Shop.
The DMV cannot accept complaints against Repair Shops beyond the 90-day limit or 3,000 miles whichever comes first.
The DMV cannot resolve disputes over the terms of manufacturer or third party warranties or guarantees.
If you feel you have a NYS Lemon Law complaint, please see Lemon Law Complaints.
A DMV customer service representative will try to resolve the problem by discussing it with you and the shop when you file a complaint.
About half the complaints received by DMV are resolved through mediation.
If the repair problem isn't resolved, your complaint will often be referred to a DMV regional office for investigation.
A DMV inspector may contact you to ask questions or discuss your case in detail.
These inspectors are experienced automotive technicians trained to investigate and resolve complaints.
If the DMV investigation indicates the shop violated the Repair Shop Act or regulations, DMV will either send a warning letter to the shop or schedule a hearing.
If a hearing determines there were violations, DMV will take action against the shop.
This may include suspending or revoking the shop's registration and/or imposing fines.
If you suffer a financial loss due to overcharging or unnecessary or poor quality repairs, the administrative law judge presiding at the hearing may offer the shop the option of paying restitution.
The shop may then receive a shorter suspension period and/or a lower fine if it pays restitution.
DMV cannot force a shop to pay restitution.
Restitution is limited to the amount you were overcharged or the cost of proper repairs.
Other expenses, such as the cost of renting a replacement car, cannot be included in restitution.
Filing a complaint with DMV does not prevent you from seeking help from other consumer protection agencies.
Filing a complaint with DMV does not prevent you from taking the shop to court.
However, if you receive a court settlement or one is pending, restitution through DMV is not available.
Under the Repair Shop Act, thousands of dollars are returned to consumers each year through mediation and restitution.
In addition, hundreds of vehicles are repaired at no additional cost under the Repair Shop Act.
The Repair Shop Act also helps to make our highways safer by promoting quality auto repairs.
The Repair Shop Act works best when consumers take the time to shop wisely for auto repairs.
The Repair Shop Act works best when consumers keep records of their dealings with shops.
The Repair Shop Act works best when consumers discuss repairs with shop management to avoid misunderstandings.
Additional information can be found at the 'Report a problem with a DMV regulated automotive business' service.
Common changes to IRP registrations include adding or deleting vehicles.
Common changes to IRP registrations include transferring plates from one vehicle to another.
Common changes to IRP registrations include adding jurisdictions.
Common changes to IRP registrations include increasing or decreasing registered weight.
Common changes to IRP registrations include transferring a vehicle from one fleet to another fleet.
Common changes to IRP registrations include changing the fleet name.
Common changes to IRP registrations include changing the address.
To make changes to your IRP registration, you must complete Schedule A & C pdf IRP-6.
To make changes to your IRP registration, you must submit Schedule A & C pdf IRP-6 for all changes listed above.
To make changes to your IRP registration, you must provide proof of identity for all changes listed above.
To make changes to your IRP registration, you must provide proof of ownership for all add vehicle requests.

To make changes to your IRP registration, you must provide proof of NY State insurance NY State Insurance ID Card in same name as the registrant if you are adding vehicles to the fleet for all changes listed above.
To make changes to your IRP registration, you must provide proof of NY State insurance NY State Insurance ID Card in the new name if you are changing the name on the account.
To make changes to your IRP registration, you must send a check or money order made payable to the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles in the amount of $2.50 per vehicle.
To make changes to your IRP registration, you must send in proof of an established place of business for the new address for address change only.
You may use OSCAR to make some of the changes to your IRP registration online.
If you are using the United States Postal Service to make changes to your IRP registration, you must send it to International Registration Bureau, PO Box 2850 ESP, Albany, NY 12220-0850.

If you use an express mail service or other method to make changes to your IRP registration, you must send it to International Registration Bureau, NYS DMV, Room 1366 Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228.
If you send your application to make changes to your IRP registration by mail, the IRB sends you an invoice.
If additional information is required to process your application to make changes to your IRP registration, the IRB sends a request for additional information with the invoice.
Payment for making changes to your IRP registration by mail must be by certified check or money order.
You may bring your application to make changes to your IRP registration to the Customer Service Counter, Room 136, Swan Street Building, Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228.
The Customer Service Counter is open from 8:00am to 3:45pm, Monday through Friday, except state holidays.
The IRB calculates your fees for making changes to your IRP registration while you wait at the Customer Service Counter.
You may pay the fees for making changes to your IRP registration in cash, by money order or certified check at the Customer Service Counter.
You must provide payment and all required documents to receive your new IRP documents at the Customer Service Counter.
You may submit Schedule A & C pdf IRP-6 by fax to 518-486-6579 to make changes to your IRP registration.
The IRB processes changes submitted by fax to make changes to your IRP registration within 72 hours.
If you change your address, you must notify the DMV within 10 days.
To change your address for your IRP registration, you must complete Schedule A/C IRP6 and submit it along with your two proofs of new address and payment in the amount of $2.50 per vehicle.
Payment for changing your address for your IRP registration must be a check or money order payable to the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
You must send photocopies of your proofs of identity if another person brings your application to make changes to your IRP registration to the Customer Service Counter.
If you must change any information on your IRP registration that is also on your title certificate, such as the VIN, year or make, you must first apply for an amendment to your title certificate.

You must see the information on 'Change name or other information on your registration or title' for more information if you must change any information on your IRP registration that is also on your title certificate.
If you change information on your title certificate, you must send a photocopy of the changed title certificate when you apply to change information on the IRP registration.
Your local DMV office cannot amend an IRP registration.
You cannot make changes to an IRP registration by phone.
You may call the IRB with questions about making changes to your IRP registration at 1-518-473-5834.
You can make changes to your IRP registrations by mail by following the instructions on Schedule A&C IRP-6.
You can make changes to your IRP registrations at the Customer Service Counter, Room 136, Swan Street Building, Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228.
You cannot make changes to your IRP registrations at a DMV local office.
You can make some changes to your IRP registrations using OSCAR.
The driver responsibility assessment is a fee you must pay to DMV over a three year period if you are convicted of certain traffic offenses in New York State.
The driver responsibility assessment is a fee you must pay to DMV over a three year period if you accumulate 6 or more points on your driving record within 18 months.
The purpose of the driver responsibility assessment is to prevent the repeated behavior of problem drivers.
The purpose of the driver responsibility assessment is to improve traffic safety.

Effective November 18, 2004, you must pay a driver responsibility assessment if you were convicted of an alcohol or drugged driving-related traffic offense while driving a motor vehicle in New York State.
Effective November 18, 2004, you must pay a driver responsibility assessment if you were convicted of an alcohol or drugged driving-related traffic offense while driving a boat in New York State.

Effective November 18, 2004, you must pay a driver responsibility assessment if you were convicted of an alcohol or drugged driving-related traffic offense while driving a snowmobile in New York State.
Effective November 18, 2004, you must pay a driver responsibility assessment if you were found to have refused to take a chemical test for blood alcohol content in New York State.

Effective November 18, 2004, you must pay a driver responsibility assessment if you received 6 or more points on your NY State driver record within an 18 month period for convictions of traffic offenses committed in New York.

Effective November 18, 2004, you must pay a driver responsibility assessment if you received 6 or more points on your NY State driver record within an 18 month period for convictions of traffic offenses committed in Quebec.

Effective November 18, 2004, you must pay a driver responsibility assessment if you received 6 or more points on your NY State driver record within an 18 month period for convictions of traffic offenses committed in Ontario.
You must pay the driver responsibility assessment whether you have a driver license issued by New York State.
You must pay the driver responsibility assessment whether you have a driver license issued by another jurisdiction.
You must pay the driver responsibility assessment whether you do not have a driver license.
If you are convicted of an alcohol or drugged driving-related offense, the annual driver responsibility assessment is $250.
If you are convicted of an alcohol or drugged driving-related offense, the minimum amount that you must pay each year is the annual assessment.
If you are convicted of an alcohol or drugged driving-related offense, the total driver responsibility assessment for the three years is $750.
If you refuse to take a chemical test, the annual driver responsibility assessment is $250.
If you refuse to take a chemical test, the minimum amount that you must pay each year is the annual assessment.
If you refuse to take a chemical test, the total driver responsibility assessment for the three years is $750.
If you receive 6 points on your driver record for violations committed during a period of 18 months, the annual driver responsibility assessment is $100.
If you receive 6 points on your driver record for violations committed during a period of 18 months, the minimum amount that you must pay each year is the annual assessment.
If you receive 6 points on your driver record for violations committed during a period of 18 months, the total driver responsibility assessment for the three years is $300.
If you receive more than 6 points on your driver record during a period of 18 months, the annual driver responsibility assessment is $25 for each point in addition to the original six points.
If you receive more than 6 points on your driver record during a period of 18 months, the minimum amount that you must pay each year is the annual assessment.

If you receive more than 6 points on your driver record during a period of 18 months, the total driver responsibility assessment for the three years is $75 for each point in addition to the original 6 points.
If you must pay a driver responsibility assessment, DMV will send you a statement with the amount you owe.
You must pay at least the minimum amount by the payment date or your driver license will be suspended.
You can pay the full driver responsibility assessment.
The amount you owe may increase if you are convicted of additional offenses after your statement is issued.
You can pay the driver responsibility assessment online using a credit or debit card.
You must pay at least the minimum amount or you can pay the full driver responsibility assessment online.
Your name and address on DMV records must be correct to pay the driver responsibility assessment online.
You must provide the last four digits of your Social Security Number to pay the driver responsibility assessment online.
You must provide your DMV ID Number to pay the driver responsibility assessment online.
You must provide your Client ID Number from your NY State driver license, learner permit or non-driver photo ID card to pay the driver responsibility assessment online.
If your driver license is suspended because you did not pay an assessment, the suspension will be removed after your payment is processed online.
To pay the driver responsibility assessment by mail, you must send the minimum amount on your DRA statement before the payment date to the DRA Processing Center.
To pay the driver responsibility assessment by mail, you must send a check or money order payable to the DRA Processing Center.
Starter checks, cash, or credit cards cannot be accepted to pay the driver responsibility assessment by mail.
You must not include any other DMV fees or fines when paying the driver responsibility assessment by mail.
To pay the driver responsibility assessment at a DMV office, you must bring a check or money order payable to the DMV for at least the minimum amount on your statement.
If you do not pay the driver responsibility assessment by the payment date on your statement, DMV will suspend your driver license.
If you do not pay the driver responsibility assessment by the payment date on your statement, DMV will suspend your learner permit.
If you do not pay the driver responsibility assessment by the payment date on your statement, DMV will suspend your driving privileges.
The violation date on your driver responsibility assessment statement is the date that the incident occurred.
The violation date on your driver responsibility assessment statement is the date you received the ticket.
The violation date on your driver responsibility assessment statement is the date you were found guilty of the violation at a traffic court or DMV hearing.
The conviction date on your driver responsibility assessment statement is the date the assessment date.
The assessment date on your driver responsibility assessment statement is the date that DMV enters the violation on your record.
DMV uses the date of the original assessment to determine the annual statement dates for the driver responsibility assessment.
DMV uses the date of the original assessment to check your driver record for new incidents for the driver responsibility assessment.
The annual statement date on your driver responsibility assessment statement is the date DMV issued your statement.
The payment date on your driver responsibility assessment statement is the final date that you can pay to avoid a suspension of your driver license, learner permit, or driving privileges.
To learn how DMV calculates your point total, see information about the New York State driver violation point system.
To check if a suspension has been removed or to get information about the status of your driver license, sign up for a MyDMV account.
To check the number of points on your driving record, sign up for a MyDMV account.
Taking a Point and Insurance Reduction Program course does not eliminate the requirement to pay the driver responsibility assessment.
Taking a Point and Insurance Reduction Program course does not reduce the amount of the driver responsibility assessment.
You receive three annual statements for the driver responsibility assessment.
When you receive the first annual driver responsibility assessment statement, you can pay the annual assessment.
When you receive the first annual driver responsibility assessment statement, you can pay the total assessment for the three year period.
When you receive the second annual driver responsibility assessment statement, you can pay the annual assessment.
When you receive the second annual driver responsibility assessment statement, you can pay the total assessment for the two years that remain.
You can pay the total balance of driver responsibility assessments that remains at any time.
If you pay the balance of an initial driver responsibility assessment that does not include additional assessments, you will be informed that there are additional assessments.
You are not required to pay the balance of driver responsibility assessments before you receive the annual statements.
You can pay the annual driver responsibility assessment each year for three years until the balance is paid.
If you pay the balance of driver responsibility assessments, you will not receive future annual statements for assessments included in that balance.
DMV accepts American Express Card for paying the driver responsibility assessment online.
DMV accepts Discover Card/Novus for paying the driver responsibility assessment online.
DMV accepts MasterCard for paying the driver responsibility assessment online.
DMV accepts MasterCard Debit card without personal identification number (PIN) for paying the driver responsibility assessment online.
DMV accepts VISA Card for paying the driver responsibility assessment online.
DMV accepts Visa Debit Card without personal identification number (PIN) for paying the driver responsibility assessment online.
You can confirm or change your address online for the driver responsibility assessment, but you must create a MyDMV account first.
If you need to change your name for the driver responsibility assessment, you must go to a DMV office.
If you leased the vehicle from a dealer in New York State, the dealer normally registers the vehicle for you by providing all your proofs and your registration application to the DMV.
If the dealer does not provide the proofs to the DMV, you must register the vehicle at a DMV office.
To register a leased vehicle, you need a certified copy of the title certificate, original Manufacturers Statement of Origin (MSO) or Manufacturer's Certificate of Origin (MCO).
To register a leased vehicle, you need a current NY State Insurance ID card for auto liability insurance.
To register a leased vehicle, you need a NY State driver license, permit, non-driver ID, or other proof of identity.

To register a leased vehicle, you need authorization from the leasing company to register the vehicle in New York, which consists of: a letter from the leasing company that gives you permission to register the vehicle in NY State, a power of attorney from the leasing company that authorizes you to register the vehicle in NY State, the signature of a leasing company officer in box 3 on the Vehicle Registration / Title Application (MV-82) or on the Registration Authorization (MV-95).
To register a leased vehicle, you need proof of sales tax payment, sales tax exemption, or purchase price.

If you paid New York State sales tax to the leasing company or dealer on the total amount of all your lease payments, you need to provide your lease agreement that indicates that you paid the NY State sales tax, and complete the Claim for Sales Tax Exemption (DTF-803) at NY State Department of Tax and Finance.

If you did not pay New York State sales tax to the leasing company or dealer on all of your lease payments, you need to provide your lease agreement, and complete Statement of Transaction (DTF-802) at NY State Department of Tax and Finance.

If you made one payment to another state for the total amount of sales tax, you need to complete Claim for Credit of Sales Tax Paid to Another State (DTF-804) at NY State Department of Tax and Finance to request credit for the tax you paid, and then pay the balance of any NY State sales tax.

If you made monthly sales tax payments in another state, you need to complete form Statement of Transaction (DTF-802) at NY State Department of Tax and Finance, and pay the total amount of NY State sales tax in one payment for all the lease payments that remain.
Your insurance company will give you 2 barcoded original NY State Insurance ID cards or provide you with access to your digital electronic NY State Insurance ID Card.
Your insurance company will send an electronic notice of insurance coverage to the DMV.
You must register your vehicle within 180 days of the effective date on your Insurance ID Card.
You must be at least 16 years old except for ATV registrations.
You can use a NY State Driver License, Learner Permit, or Non-Driver ID card that is current or not expired for more than 2 years as proof of both identity and age.
If you don't have a NY State Driver License, Learner Permit, or Non-Driver ID card, you can use other kinds of proof for identity and age.
To register a leased vehicle, you need to bring your completed registration application and additional documents to a local DMV office.
You can make a reservation online before visiting DMV offices in New York City, Westchester, Nassau, Suffolk, Rockland, Onondaga or Monroe Counties.
You must have your New York State driver license, permit or non-driver ID to sign up for MyDMV.
You must have your Social Security Number (SSN) to sign up for MyDMV.
You must have the ZIP code currently on your New York State driver license, permit or non-driver ID record to sign up for MyDMV.
To sign up for MyDMV, go to the MyDMV homepage and click 'Sign up for MyDMV.'
To sign up for MyDMV, enter the required information and create a NY.gov ID username, or use one you already have.
Your information must match what the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles currently has on record for you to sign up for MyDMV.
Your NY.gov ID username for signing up for MyDMV can be a combination of letters, numbers, period, at (@), dash and underscore.
To sign up for MyDMV, open the email the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles sends you with your temporary password and link to MyDMV.
To sign up for MyDMV, click the 'Log in to NY.gov' button and enter your username and temporary password.
To sign up for MyDMV, create a permanent password and security questions/answers (Shared Secrets).
To sign up for MyDMV, enroll in the MyDMV services you want to use.
NY.gov allows people to access online services from various New York State government agencies with a single username.

If you have a MyDMV account and you enroll at the Online Tax Center of the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance, you can use the same NY.gov ID username and password to access services offered by both agencies.
If you already have an NY.gov ID username when you sign up for a MyDMV account, your MyDMV account will be associated with your current NY.gov ID username.
You will not need to create a new username if you already have an NY.gov ID username when you sign up for a MyDMV account.
If you forgot your NY.gov account username, use the self-service tools on the MyDMV homepage.
If you lost your temporary password and couldn't complete the sign-up process for MyDMV, go to the MyDMV homepage and click 'Sign up here.'
If you lost your temporary password and couldn't complete the sign-up process for MyDMV, enter all the required information again using the same username you used before.

If you lost your temporary password and couldn't complete the sign-up process for MyDMV, open the email the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles sends you with a new temporary password and link to MyDMV to sign in.
You may be redirected to the 'Register for MyDMV Online Services' page if you have multiple NY.gov usernames, and the username you used to sign in is not associated with your MyDMV account.

To solve the issue of being redirected to the 'Register for MyDMV Online Services' page, use the provided link to clear out your sign in information from the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles' system.

To solve the issue of being redirected to the 'Register for MyDMV Online Services' page, use the Forgot your Username tool on the NY.gov ID sign in page to get a list of all of your NY.gov ID usernames.
To solve the issue of being redirected to the 'Register for MyDMV Online Services' page, sign in with the username you created for MyDMV.
To solve the issue of being redirected to the 'Register for MyDMV Online Services' page, if you don't remember the password, you can use the 'Forgot your Password' tool.
If you still have problems signing up for MyDMV after following the instructions, contact the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles.
You cannot create a MyDMV account if you were never issued a New York State license, permit, or non-driver ID.
You need to wait until you receive your new document to create your MyDMV account if you just ordered a new driver license, learner permit, or non-driver ID but it hasn't arrived in the mail.
You can confirm or change your address online for your MyDMV account.
Make sure you enter your photo document number correctly when creating your MyDMV account. See a sample driver license for reference.

It's easy to mistake certain numbers and letters when entering your photo document number for creating a MyDMV account, such as the number 1 for the letter I, the number 0 for the letter O, the letter Q and the letter O, the number 5 and the letter S, and the number 8 and the letter B.
The temporary password for creating a MyDMV account is case sensitive. You must enter it exactly as it appears in the email.
It is best to copy and paste the temporary password from the email when creating a MyDMV account.
Your permanent password for your MyDMV account must be different from your temporary password and username.
Your permanent password for your MyDMV account must contain at least 8 characters.
Your permanent password for your MyDMV account must include at least one upper case and one lower case character.
Your permanent password for your MyDMV account must be different from your previous 12 passwords.
How to get my own driving record (abstract) is a topic.
A Standard driving record (abstract) is a type of driving record issued by the New York DMV.
A Standard driving record abstract contains information related to your record for the past few years.
If you need a record of all information DMV has, see lifetime driving records.
There is no difference between an abstract you order online, at an office or by mail.
They are certified DMV records.
They all include a certification statement and the signature of the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, as well as the same security watermark.
A Lifetime driving record is a type of driving record issued by the New York DMV.
A Commercial (CDL) driving record (abstract) is a type of driving record abstract.
You can order CDL driving record abstracts online or have your employer order them through the License Event Notification Service LENS.
You can get Standard, Lifetime and CDL abstracts online through MyDMV.
You can save and print a PDF version of your record from MyDMV.
You will have 5 days after your order to download your record from MyDMV.
The fee for ordering a record through MyDMV is $7.
To create a MyDMV account, you will need your most recent New York State driver license, permit, or non-driver ID.
You must order by mail if you do not have a New York State license, permit, or non-driver ID.
Make sure your computer and web browser have all recent updates to avoid problems downloading your record from MyDMV.

To request your Standard driving record by mail, send a completed Request for DMV Records PDF MV-15, a photocopy of your proof of identity, and a personal check or money order for $10.00 payable to 'Commissioner of Motor Vehicles' to MV-15 Processing, NYS Department of Motor Vehicles, 6 Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228.
If you would like to order your record at the same time you renew your license, mark the blue box on your renewal notice and add the $10.00 search fee to your renewal fee.
To request your Standard driving record at a DMV office, bring a completed Request for Driving Record Information PDF MV-15C, proof of identity, and $10.00 for the fee.
You cannot get CDL or Lifetime abstracts at a DMV office.
You can find a DMV office near you on the DMV website.
You can request driving record abstracts at the DMV Customer Service Counter in Albany by providing your proof of identity and paying the $10.00 search fee.
You must certify that you have a DPPA permissible use to request a driving record abstract at the DMV Customer Service Counter in Albany.
Use the Request for Driving Record Information PDF MV-15C to request a driving record abstract at the DMV Customer Service Counter in Albany.
The DMV Customer Service Counter in Albany is located at Room 136, Swan Street Building, Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228.
Driving records cannot be ordered by phone.
You will need the document number from your most recently issued document to create a MyDMV account.
If you renewed or ordered your document recently and have not received it in the mail yet, you will need to wait for it to arrive before you can create a MyDMV account.
The document number can be from either a driver license or other government-issued photo ID card.
You can black out your photo on the document used to create a MyDMV account.
Alternatively, you can use 6 points of identification to create a MyDMV account, as per the DMV Document Guide.
Cash, credit cards, personal checks and money orders are accepted as payment for DMV records.
Make checks and money orders payable to 'Commissioner of Motor Vehicles' when paying for DMV records.
An insurance lapse means that there is no liability insurance coverage for a vehicle registered in New York State for a period of time.
If there is a lapse of insurance for a vehicle registered to you, the DMV can suspend your registration and driver license.
Any amount of time that your vehicle is registered but not insured can cause a lapse in your insurance coverage.
An insurance lapse can occur between the date your insurance is cancelled and the date your new insurance begins.
An insurance lapse can occur when you surrender your vehicle plates.
An insurance lapse can occur when your registration expires.
'Other proof' of insurance for example, a vehicle registered in another state, or a vehicle repossessed or impounded is valid.
An insurance lapse can occur when your insurance company reinstates your insurance coverage.
A lapse in insurance coverage can also occur between the date you register your vehicle and the date your new insurance coverage begins.
If the registration suspension period is more than 90 days, you must surrender your vehicle registration and plates.
The DMV will also suspend your driver license if the registration suspension period is more than 90 days.
Your driver license will be suspended for the same number of days as your registration suspension if the registration suspension period is more than 90 days.
To reinstate your driver license, you must pay the DMV a $50 license suspension termination fee if the registration suspension period is more than 90 days.
Do not drive any vehicle that is not insured.
You could be arrested or ticketed if you drive without insurance (with lapsed insurance).
Your vehicle can be impounded by a law enforcement officer if you drive without insurance (with lapsed insurance).
The DMV will revoke your registration and your driver license if you drive without insurance (with lapsed insurance).
Your license and registration will be suspended if your uninsured vehicle is in a traffic crash.
You will need to pay fines and penalties if your uninsured vehicle is in a traffic crash.

If your vehicle does not have insurance and you or someone else driving your uninsured vehicle are involved in a traffic crash, the DMV will revoke your driver license and vehicle registration for at least one year.

The traffic court fine could be as much as $1,500 for driving without insurance or allowing another person to drive your uninsured vehicle if your vehicle does not have insurance and you or someone else driving your uninsured vehicle are involved in a traffic crash.

You will also need to pay the DMV a $750 civil penalty to restore your driver license if it is revoked because your vehicle does not have insurance and you or someone else driving your uninsured vehicle are involved in a traffic crash.
Your insurance company must notify the DMV electronically if your insurance coverage is cancelled.
Your insurance company must notify the DMV electronically if your insurance coverage is reinstated.
Your insurance company must notify the DMV electronically if you get new insurance coverage.
In your response to the DMV letter you must either prove that you have insurance coverage, prove that you sold the vehicle, or prove that insurance coverage was not required.
If you have insurance coverage, also ask your insurance company (do not ask your agent or broker) to file an electronic notice of insurance coverage with the DMV.
If you do not have auto liability insurance, you must surrender your vehicle plates to the DMV immediately.
Remember this simple rule: no insurance, no plates!
Keep the address for your vehicle registration and driver license current with the DMV to avoid an insurance lapse.
Have liability coverage from a company licensed by the NYS Department of Financial Services and authorized by the NYS DMV to avoid an insurance lapse.
Out-of-state coverage is never acceptable on any vehicle registered in New York.
Have your insurance company report any changes to the DMV immediately to avoid an insurance lapse.
Keep insurance coverage on your vehicle for as long as it is registered in New York to avoid an insurance lapse.
Respond to DMV Insurance Letters and Orders immediately to avoid an insurance lapse.
Surrender your vehicle registration and license plates to DMV before your New York State coverage ends for any reason to avoid an insurance lapse.
If you do not have valid auto liability insurance coverage for your vehicle, you must immediately surrender your registration and vehicle plates.
Motorcycle plates do not have to be surrendered to DMV when auto liability insurance lapses.
However, it is illegal to operate a motorcycle when it does not have proper auto liability insurance.
No, the DMV will not issue a new registration if the DMV determines that the purpose of the new registration is to avoid the suspension.

The DMV will not issue a registration if the applicant for the new registration has the same last name as the registrant whose registration is suspended, or resides at the same address as the registrant whose registration is suspended.
The DMV will not issue a registration to any person unless that person makes a sworn statement on form FS-2.
The statement on form FS-2 certifies that the purpose of the application in not to avoid the results from the current suspension.
The local DMV Office determines if the application will be accepted or rejected.
Form FS-2 is available only at a local DMV Office.
If your registration has not expired, you must surrender your plates if your license is suspended for a lapse of insurance.
A driver license becomes suspended when the lapse is 91 days or more or if the time period of the lapse has not yet been determined.

To determine the lapse period the plates must be surrendered, or the plates must be reported lost/stolen/confiscated, or the registration must expire, or the plates must be transferred to another vehicle by DMV, or DMV must receive proof of new or reinstated insurance, or DMV must receive other acceptable proof.
Once the lapse is determined, the registration, and if the lapse period is 91 days or more, your driver license will also be suspended for the same number of days.
The suspensions may not be effective on the same date.
Therefore, you may serve the suspension on the driver license first or you may serve the suspension on the registration first.
The suspension on the driver license will not end until you have paid the suspension termination fee and have served the suspension.
The registration suspension will last for the same number of days that your vehicle was registered in New York without auto liability coverage.
If you are suspended you must either surrender your plates to the DMV, or if you are eligible, pay the optional civil penalty for the entire length of the lapse.
You can register your pick-up truck as a 'passenger' class vehicle if it meets certain conditions, depending on its unladen weight.

If you have an unmodified pick-up truck with an unladen weight less than 6,001 lbs., then you may register it in the passenger class if the following conditions are met: the pick-up truck does not have any business advertisements, and the pick-up is used exclusively for non-commercial purposes.

If you have a modified pick-up truck with an unladen weight greater than 6,000 lbs., then you may register it in the passenger class if the following conditions are met: the pick-up truck does not have any business advertisements and is used exclusively for non-commercial purposes, a camper top having one or more side windows completely encloses the truck bed, the pick-up truck has seats, seat fittings, or camping equipment installed in the truck bed.
'Camping equipment' indicates that you have a bed, a stove, or a refrigerator in the vehicle.
These modifications must be permanent.
If you use the pick-up truck without the required modifications, then you must register it in the commercial registration class.
You are not required to apply for passenger class plates for your pick-up truck. You can use commercial plates.
The unladen weight of your pick-up truck is stamped on a metal plate located on the door of your vehicle.
The unladen weight is also listed on your title certificate.
The unladen weight is different from the maximum gross weight (MGW) listed on your registration documents.
Before you apply, make sure that the unladen weight of the truck is 6,000 lbs. or less.
Passenger class plates on a pick-up truck do not change the maximum gross weight (MGW) listed on the registration documents or the unladen weight listed on the title certificate.
Passenger class plates on a pick-up truck do not change the registration fees. Commercial registration fees still apply.
The DMV requests the unladen weight to verify that your pick-up truck is eligible for passenger class plates.
The DMV does not change the unladen weight or the MGW.
You must apply in person at a DMV office to get passenger class plates for your pick-up truck.
Before visiting a DMV office to register your pick-up truck as a 'passenger' class vehicle, please complete the Document Guide to make sure you bring the correct documents with you.
You must surrender your commercial plates and be sure to remove frames and fasteners when applying for passenger class plates.
The DMV office will issue new registration documents and standard passenger plates with a new number.
If you had custom plates or personalized plates, your new registration documents will list the numbers from your plates. The DMV will send you new passenger custom or personalized plates by mail.

If your pick-up truck is rented or leased, you must submit a certification form provided by the leasing company or owner of the pick-up truck which states that the truck will not be used for commercial purposes.
If your registration will expire in less than 60 days, you can renew your registration at a DMV office and change to passenger class plates when you renew.
You can also get passenger plates with no additional fee when you register a pick-up truck for the first time.
If you have a pick-up truck that has an unladen weight of 6,001 lbs. or more, you cannot apply for passenger class plates through the process described above.
If your pick-up truck weighs more than 6,000 pounds, you must modify the truck to qualify for a passenger class registration and passenger class plates.
The agency that controls a parkway decides if pick-up trucks with passenger class plates are allowed on the parkway.
To make sure you can drive your pick-up truck on a parkway, contact the agency that manages the parkway.

Some parking regulations and traffic regulations in New York City depend on the type of vehicle plates on your vehicle. Passenger class plates on your pick-up truck can change how New York City regulations affect you.
Contact New York City about their regulations regarding pick-up trucks with passenger class plates.
To apply for passenger class plates for your pick-up truck, bring your completed registration application and additional documents to a local DMV office.
Make a reservation online before visiting DMV offices in New York City, Westchester, Nassau, Suffolk, Rockland, Onondaga or Monroe Counties.
To become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must consult the DMV Commissioner's Motor Vehicle Repair & Body Shop Regulations pdf CR-82.
To become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must download and read the Repair & Body Shop business requirements pdf VS-145.
To become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must submit the Original Facility Application pdf VS-1 with all required documentation.
To become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must review the Repair Shop Zoning Requirements Letter pdf VS-146.
You can call the DMV Office of Vehicle Safety and Clean Air at 1-518-474-4653 to get the forms to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
You can call 1-518-474-0919 to get more information to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
To apply to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must submit Original Facility Application pdf VS-1.
To apply to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must have permission to use the property at the business location.

To apply to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must provide a notarized statement from property owner, lease may be contingent on facility approval, sub-lease with primary lease, mortgage, deed or receipted tax bill proof.
To apply to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must provide proof of zoning.
The Repair Shop Zoning Requirements Letter pdf VS-146 specifies the requirements for proof of zoning to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.

To apply to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must provide your Sales Tax ID number and a copy of your Sales Tax Certificate of Authority which can be found on the Department of Tax and Finance website.
To apply to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you may need a FEIN from the IRS before obtaining your Sales Tax Certificate of Authority.
To apply to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must provide proof of Workers Compensation Insurance for your employees.
If you do not have employees to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must indicate that on the application.

You can visit the NY State Workers Compensation Board website for instructions on the process to obtain proof of Workers Compensation Insurance to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
To apply to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must provide a photocopy of driver license or other government issued photo ID for everyone listed on the application.
To apply to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must provide a receipt for your purchase of the repair shop sign.
To apply to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must pay all required fees, via a check payable to the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
If you are also applying to become a dealer to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you may need to submit a separate check for MV-50 fees.
To apply to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must provide a Filing Receipt from NY State Department of State website if you are a Corporation or LLC.
To apply to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must provide a Business Certificate from the County Clerk if you are an individual using assumed name or partnership.
If you do not have proof of zoning, do not submit an application with DMV yet to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
If you do not have your Certificate of Authority yet, do not submit an application with DMV yet to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
The Certificate of Authority and Sales Tax ID number are issued by the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance DTF to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
You may apply for your Certificate of Authority by visiting the NY State DTF website to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
You must record your Sales Tax ID on the Original Facility Application to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
If you do not have your Proof of Business Name yet, do not submit an application with DMV yet to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
If you are a Corporation or LLC to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must submit a copy of your Filing Receipt from the Department of State.
Instructions to file as a Corporation or LLC can be found on the NY State Department of State website to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
If you are a Partnership or Individual Using an Assumed Name to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must submit a copy of your Business Certificate of Assumed Name.
You must contact your county clerk to obtain your business certificate if you are a Partnership or Individual Using an Assumed Name to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
If you do not have your proof of Workers Compensation Insurance yet, do not submit an application with DMV yet to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
If you have any employees (family included) to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must submit proof of Workers Compensation Insurance.
If you do not have any employees to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must indicate that on your application.

To submit your application to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV, you must send a hard copy of your application, associated documents and fee to NYS DMV Bureau of Consumer & Facility Services Application Unit P.O. Box 2700 Albany, NY 12220-0700.
DMV's Vehicle Safety's Application Processing Unit will contact you once your application is complete and accurate to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
Once your application is complete and accurate, you will be issued a repair shop registration to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
Mobile Repair Shops require an on-site investigation to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
For more information about Mobile Repair Shops, you can contact Application Processing at 1-518-474-0919 to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
DMV does not provide official repair shop signs to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
You may purchase official repair shop signs from various sign shops and automotive supply stores to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
The Motor Vehicle Repair & Body Shop Regulations pdf CR-82 82.7 specifies the requirements for official repair shop signs to become a registered Repair Shop with the New York State DMV.
Commercial CDL abstracts show expanded driver history information that is not available on a Standard Driving Record.
Commercial CDL abstracts show convictions.
Commercial CDL abstracts show suspensions.
Commercial CDL abstracts show revocations.
Commercial CDL abstracts show other licensing actions in any state in any type of vehicle.
Commercial CDL abstracts provide Medical Certification Status information.
Commercial CDL abstracts provide Self-Certification information.
Employers or organizations can get CDL Abstracts for enrolled drivers through the New York DMV License Event Notification Service LENS.
An abstract of driving record is a certified DMV record.
An abstract of driving record includes a certification statement.
An abstract of driving record includes the signature of the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
An abstract of driving record includes a security watermark.
You can save and print a PDF version of your driving record through MyDMV.
You will have until 5 days after your order to download your driving record through MyDMV.
The fee for getting your driving record through MyDMV is $7.
To create a MyDMV account, you will need a New York State license, permit or non-driver ID.
You need to make sure your computer and web browser have all recent updates to avoid problems downloading your driving record through MyDMV.
If you are unable to access MyDMV, you can mail a Request for Certified CDL Abstract PDF MV-CDL form along with the $10 fee to the DMV to the address provided on the form.
If you are unable to access MyDMV, you can have your employer order your CDL driving record abstract through LENS.
To create a MyDMV account, you will need the document number from your most recently issued document.
If you renewed or ordered your document recently and have not received it in the mail yet, you will need to wait for it to arrive before you can create a MyDMV account.
Renew a hazardous materials (HazMat) endorsement.
The driver must provide fingerprints and pass the background checks every five years to keep the HazMat endorsement.
The required fingerprinting service is being provided by Identogo.
All HazMat endorsement applicants must be fingerprinted at one of the Identogo ID centers located throughout New York State.
Fingerprinting is done by appointment only.
The driver must contact Identogo to select a fingerprinting location and schedule an appointment.
The driver must visit https://uenroll.identogo.com or call 1-877-472-6915 to attain Fingerprinting Services Information HAZ-600 to make an appointment.
The driver must bring their NYS CDL and one of the second proofs of ID that are listed on form HAZ-600.
Background checks can take 30 days or more to complete.
If the driver's endorsement expires, it will not be restored until the criminal history background checks are completed and the driver has been re-qualified by both the TSA and the DMV.
The Federal Transportation Security Administration (TSA) will notify the driver by mail of the results of the background check based on federal standards only.
The TSA website has information about the federal background checks for the HazMat endorsements.
The DMV cannot issue the HazMat endorsement until the background checks are completed and approved.

The DMV will provide a CDL with the HazMat endorsement that is valid for 90 days only if the driver applied to renew a current NYS CDL with a HazMat endorsement, and the background checks are not completed and approved before the endorsement expires.
To keep the HazMat endorsement, the driver must pass the test again within two years before their CDL expires.
The driver can take the test when they apply to renew their CDL, or they can take the test up to two years before the expiration date of their CDL.
The driver can study the hazardous materials section of the NYS Commercial Driver License Manual CDL-10, or study the Hazardous Materials Manual CDL-11 to prepare for the test.
If the driver does not pass the written test or the background checks, the DMV will issue a CDL that does not have a HazMat endorsement.
It is important that a driver whose address has changed promptly file a change of address with the NYS DMV.
If the driver does not need a HazMat endorsement, they should not take the written test and should not apply for the background checks.
When it is time to renew the CDL, the driver should follow the instructions provided with their CDL renewal notice and pay the CDL renewal fee if they do not need a HazMat endorsement.

Federal and State laws require fingerprint-based background checks for anyone who wants a hazardous materials endorsement, to determine whether that person has a criminal history and/or poses a security threat that warrants denying him or her the authorization to transport hazardous materials.

No hazardous materials endorsement may be issued, transferred or renewed unless the background checks result in a determination by the Federal Transportation Security Administration (TSA) and New York State that the person applying for the endorsement is authorized to transport hazardous materials.
To initiate background checks, the rules require that the applicant be fingerprinted, and that his or her United States citizenship or permanent legal presence in the United States be verified.
The background checks include a check of criminal history data from the NYS Division of Criminal Justice Services and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).
There is also a background check by the federal Transportation Safety Administration (TSA).
The driver must provide fingerprints even if they provided fingerprints for another application, for example for a pistol permit or employment as a security guard.
The driver must provide fingerprints for an H endorsement or an X endorsement on their CDL.
The driver must answer 80% or more of the questions correctly to pass the test.
The driver can take the test as many times as necessary until they pass the test, but they must pay a $5 fee for each test they take.
The driver cannot renew a HazMat endorsement by phone.
The driver can call or email the HazMat unit with questions at 1-518-408-2997 or [email protected]
The driver can renew a HazMat endorsement by mail by sending their application to HazMat Unit, NYS DMV, 6 Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228.
The driver cannot renew a HazMat endorsement at a DMV office.
If you are looking to file a complaint against an inspection station or certified inspector, please report a problem with a DMV regulated automotive business.
The New York State Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) regulates all repair shops, inspection stations, dealers, vehicle dismantlers and other related businesses in New York.
To legally operate as a repair shop, inspection station, dealer, vehicle dismantler or other related business, you must register with the DMV.
Once your application is approved, you will receive a certificate from the DMV.
Once your application is approved, you will receive a copy of the Commissioner's Regulations that pertain to your type of business.
The Commissioner's Regulations will explain your responsibilities to consumers.
You must follow all consumer protection laws and regulations.
The DMV advises all consumers who have a complaint against a dealer, inspection station, repair shop, or dismantler to make an attempt to resolve their complaint with the business manager.
If consumers are not successful in resolving their complaint with the business manager, they are advised to contact the DMV Consumer & Facilities Services Complaint Unit.
To protect your business, keep a copy of all work orders in an easy-to-access location.
If a complaint has been filed against you, a Consumer Services Representative (CSR) from the DMV will contact you in an attempt to resolve this complaint.
The CSR will explain the nature of the complaint.
The CSR will also inform you of your rights, responsibilities, and your liability.
If the complaint is not resolved with the CSR, the case will be sent to an Automotive Facilities Inspector (AFI) for a formal investigation.
To avoid costly penalties, fines, and the loss of valuable customers, respond to all DMV inquiries in a timely manner.
The AFI will conduct a formal investigation.
The result of the AFI's investigation may be no action, a warning letter (Notice of Investigation) placed in your file, or a formal administrative hearing before an Administrative Law Judge (ALJ).

When Vehicle Safety initiates the hearing process, you may be offered the opportunity through a "hearing waiver" to admit to the charges and to either pay a specified monetary penalty and/or to accept a suspension.
If the "hearing waiver" is accepted, no hearing is required.
If the offer of a "hearing waiver" is rejected, a hearing must be held.
The result of the hearing may be no action, a civil penalty, and/or a suspension or revocation of your ability to operate as a vehicle related business in New York State.
You may also be offered the opportunity to pay restitution to the consumer in lieu of the fines and/or penalties, or to have the penalty reduced.
You are entitled to hire an attorney and to bring that attorney to the hearing.
The DMV is the petitioner in this case and the complainant may be a witness for the case.
As a result of the hearing, the ALJ may sustain some, all, or none of the charges.
As a result of the hearing, there may be no action, a warning, the imposition of a suspension, revocation, and/or civil penalties.
If the ALJ only imposes civil penalties, in order to prevent the loss of your operating privilege, you must pay all fines and penalties.
You will receive a letter from the DMV shortly after the hearing.
You will have 30 days from the date of the order by the ALJ to pay your fine or penalty.
Failure to pay any fines or penalties or to serve out your suspension will result in indefinite suspension of your business certificate and the possible assessment of a lien against your business.
However, if you pay your fine and/or penalty or serve out your period of suspension, you will be back in business after complete compliance.
If you are revoked, you must surrender all supplies and cease to operate.
You have the right to appeal any adverse decision.
If you chose to appeal, you have 60 days from the date of the ALJ's decision to file the Appeal From DMV Hearing Determination PDF (AA-33A), which must be accompanied by the appropriate filing fee.
Your facility license, registration or certification enables you to operate in New York State.
Complaints filed and charges brought against you can result in the loss of your privilege to operate as a business in New York State.
Log in to ACH at https://secap.dmv.ny.gov/vpass/.
An escrow account is an alternative to sending a check or money order for each DMV transaction.

New York State DMV customers who frequently process any or all of the DMV products and services listed below can establish an escrow account: Copies of motor vehicle accident reports by mail - order, Bulk order driver license record abstracts, DMV Central Office record searches, DMV Central Office abstract orders, Dial - In account display searches, Dial - In account display abstract orders, Freedom of Information Law FOIL requests, License Event Notification Service LENS notifications, Bus driver Article 19A notifications, Point and Insurance Reduction Program PIRP accident prevention course filings, Motor vehicle title certificate lien filing accounts includes paper and electronic lien filings, Copies of the NYS Vehicle and Traffic Law book.
The DMV Revenue Accounts mailing address for regular mail is: DMV Revenue Accounts PO Box 2409 Albany, NY 12220 - 0409.
The DMV Revenue Accounts mailing address for express or overnight mail is: DMV Revenue Accounts Room 233A 6 Empire State Plaza Albany, NY 12228.
The DMV Revenue Accounts drop-box location is: DMV Customer Service Counter 1st Floor , Swan Street Building 6 Empire State Plaza Albany , NY 12228.
The DMV Revenue Accounts fax number is: 518 - 473 - 9644.
The DMV Revenue Accounts email address is: [email protected]
The DMV requires a minimum escrow amount of at least $200 for search accounts.
The DMV recommends keeping enough money in the escrow account to cover 2 months of transactions.
To change the escrow amount, a request must be sent to DMV Revenue Accounts on letterhead, signed and dated, and including the account number.
On the last business day of the month, the DMV automatically issues a statement of the activity in the escrow account during that month.
A debit is the amount taken, by date, from the escrow account.
Details about each debit are not available from the escrow account statement.
Only the total debit amount by date and type of product or service is available from the escrow account statement.
A credit is a payment to the escrow account by date.
Payments are posted to the escrow account by 3:00 pm on the day they are received.
The balance is the amount in the escrow account available to use.
If the balance reaches zero or a negative amount, the account is disabled.
The account cannot be used to pay for transactions until payment is received and processed.
A negative balance indicates that the account is overdrawn.
Monthly Charges to Date is the total debits to the account for the statement period.
Total Charges is the cumulative total of debits to the account.
Escrow Deficiency indicates that the balance in the account is less than the required Escrow Amount.
Pay This Amount is the payment amount necessary to return the account balance to the required Escrow Amount.
ACH Automated Clearing House Payments is the electronic transfer of funds from a bank account into the escrow account via the DMV website.
Currently, the DMV can only accept checks, money orders or ACH Automated Clearing House as payments to escrow accounts.
Account numbers must be included with payments to escrow accounts.
Payments received without account numbers will be returned.
Checks should be made payable to "NYS Department of Motor Vehicles".
The fastest way to submit a payment without using ACH is at the DMV Revenue Accounts Drop-box located at the DMV Customer Service Counter on the first floor of the Swan Street Building in Albany.
Any check or money order dropped off by 3:00 pm will be entered into the escrow account that day.
A call to 518-474-0888 must be made when dropping off payment.
The DMV Revenue Accounts addresses provided in the document can be used to make payments by regular, express or overnight mail.
The ACH payment service allows electronic transfer of funds from a bank account into the DMV escrow account via the DMV website at https://secap.dmv.ny.gov/vpass/.
The funds transferred via ACH are immediately credited to the escrow account.
Using ACH eliminates the need to send payments by mail.
An account liaison can update the business address and assign users to the system when using ACH.
Payments can be posted 7 days a week, 24 hours a day using ACH, whenever needed.

To sign up for ACH, the Authorization Agreement for Direct Deposits PDF and FM-138 ACH Liaison Designation PDF forms must be downloaded, completed, and sent to: Revenue Accounts NYS Department of Motor Vehicles PO Box 2409, Albany NY 12228.
The Authorization Agreement for Direct Deposits PDF and FM-138 ACH Liaison Designation PDF forms can also be sent by fax at 518-473-9644 or email at [email protected]
It will take approximately 2-3 weeks to set up the ACH account and liaison once the forms are received.
Questions about ACH can be directed to 518-474-0888.
If the address changes, DMV Revenue Accounts must be notified.
If using ACH, the account liaison can use the system to update the address.
If not using ACH, a letter must be sent to DMV Revenue Accounts with the old and new address, on letterhead, including the account number, and signed and dated.
To close the escrow account, a request must be sent to DMV Revenue Accounts by mail, fax or email.
The request to close the account must be on letterhead, include the account number, and be signed and dated.
If there is no letterhead, the request to close the account can be sent on the monthly statement.
If there is a remaining balance in the account when closing it, a refund check can be issued or the balance can be transferred to another DMV escrow account.
When closing the account, DMV Revenue Accounts must be informed of what should be done with any remaining balance in the account.
No matter what age you are, if you hold a learner permit, you may not drive unless accompanied by a supervising driver age 21 or older who has a valid license to operate the vehicle you are driving.
For example, only a person with a motorcycle license may supervise a person learning to drive a motorcycle.
You may not drive with a learner permit on any street within a park in New York City.
You may not drive with a learner permit on any bridge or tunnel under the jurisdiction of the Tri-borough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.
You may not drive with a learner permit on the Cross County, Hutchinson River, Saw Mill River, or Taconic State parkways in Westchester County.
You may not drive with a learner permit in a DMV road test area.
If you are under age 18 or are the parent of a driver under age 18, it is very important that you understand the Graduated Driver License (GDL) Law and the restrictions on drivers under age 18.
If you are under age 18, you must wait at least 6 months from the date you received your learner permit to schedule your road test.
If you have a motorcycle learner permit Class M, MJ or Limited MJ, your supervising driver must exercise general supervision of you while you operate the motorcycle.
If you have a motorcycle learner permit Class M, MJ or Limited MJ, your supervising driver must remain within one-quarter mile of you, keeping you in sight at all times.
The only passenger who can ride with you on the motorcycle if you have a motorcycle learner permit is your supervising driver.
If you operate a moped with any valid class of learner permit, the same passenger rules apply as for a motorcycle learner permit.
The username you used to sign in is not associated with your MyDMV account.
To solve this issue: Use this link to clear out your sign in information from our system.
This will stop you from being redirected to the 'Welcome to MyDMV' page.
If you created a MyDMV account before, go to the to use the 'Forgot your Username' tool to get a list of all of your NY.gov ID Usernames.
If you have more than one email address, be sure to check all of them.
Sign in with the username you created for MyDMV.
If you don't remember the password you can use the 'Forgot your Password' tool on the same page.
If you never created a MyDMV account before, use the sign up link.
Contact us if you continue to experience problems signing in to MyDMV after following these instructions.
You can use the tool to have your NY.gov username emailed to you.
Your NY.gov username might be your email address.
You will need to enter your name and email address to use the 'Forgot your Username' tool.
If you have more than one email address, use the 'Forgot your Username' tool for each address to make sure you retrieve your username for MyDMV.
You can use the 'Forgot your Password' tool to reset your NY.gov password.
You will need to enter your username and the security questions/answers (Shared Secrets) you chose when you created your account to use the 'Forgot your Password' tool.
New York State keeps your personal identity separate from your government employee or business partner identity.
You will need to create a personal account with a different username than the one you use for work to sign in to MyDMV.
The fee to replace your vehicle registration document and windshield sticker is $3.00.
You must apply by mail or at a DMV office if you need to replace vehicle plates or documents that were lost in a crime.
You can replace registration documents online for most vehicles.
Your computer must accept cookies to replace registration documents online.

You cannot replace registration documents online for vehicles older than model year 1973, boats, snowmobiles, All-Terrain Vehicles (ATVs), vehicles with an expired, surrendered, suspended or revoked registration, motorcycles, vehicles with plate stickers, trailers, transporter vehicles, or vehicles registered through DMV's International Registration Bureau.
You can download and print a temporary registration in PDF format that is valid for 10 days.
A copy of the temporary registration is also attached to your confirmation email.
You will get your new registration document by mail within 10 days.
To replace a registration online, you need the vehicle plate or registration number, registration class, ZIP Code for the address on your registration, and a credit or pinless debit card for payment.

To replace a registration by mail, you need to send a completed Application for Duplicate/Renewal Registration (MV-82D), a photocopy of your NY State driver license, permit, non-driver ID, or other proof of identity, and a check/money order for $3 payable to the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles to the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles Utica Processing Center.
You cannot update your name by mail.
If your address changed, you can write your new address on the application when replacing a registration by mail.

To replace a registration at a DMV office, you need to bring a completed Application for Duplicate/Renewal Registration (MV-82D), your NY State driver license, permit, non-driver ID, or other proof of identity, and $3 for payment of the fee.
Your mailing address on DMV files must be current.
You cannot change your address during the transaction to replace a registration.
You can first change your address online and then renew your registration.
There is no guarantee that the US Postal Service (USPS) will forward all DMV documents to your new address if you file a request with the USPS to forward mail.
You cannot change your name during the transaction to replace a registration.
Your new registration document will display your previous name if you recently changed your name.
If you recently changed your name, you need to read the instructions to change your name or other information on a registration or title.
There are special instructions to replace plates that were lost, stolen or destroyed, order new Empire Gold plates, and order personalized or custom plates.
Cookies are simple text files stored on your web browser to provide a means of distinguishing among users of this website.
The use of cookies is a standard practice among Internet websites.
This website occasionally uses 'session cookies' to enhance or customize your visit.
Session cookies can be created automatically on the device you use to access this website, but do not contain personal information and do not compromise your privacy or security.
This website may use the cookie feature to store a randomly generated identifier on the device you use to access the website.
A session cookie is erased during operation of your browser or when your browser is closed.
The software and hardware you use to access the website allows you to refuse new cookies or delete existing cookies.
Refusing or deleting cookies may limit your ability to take advantage of some features of this website.
You can provide proof that you now have insurance online or by mail.
If your driver license or your vehicle registration is suspended because of a lapse in automobile liability insurance coverage, you can provide proof that you now have insurance online or by mail.
After you provide your proof of insurance, the DMV will verify your coverage with your insurance company.
You can check your insurance status online.
You can also check the status of your driver license and vehicle registrations through MyDMV.
If you need written confirmation that the DMV cleared a suspension or revocation, you must order your driving record or vehicle abstract.
To provide proof online, your name and address on DMV records must be correct.
You will need your inquiry or suspension order from the DMV, which will have the vehicle plate number and 10 digit document number.

You will need your NY State Insurance Identification Card, which will have the effective date of your liability insurance coverage, policy number of your liability insurance coverage, and 3-digit code of your insurance company.
It can take 48 hours for your records to be updated after providing proof of insurance online.

To provide proof of insurance by mail, you must mail the bottom part tear strip of your insurance letter and your NY State Insurance Identification Card to NYS Department of Motor Vehicles Financial Security Bureau PO BOX 2725 Albany NY 12220 - 0725.
Legible photo copies of the insurance letter and NY State Insurance Identification Card are acceptable when providing proof by mail.
The name and vehicle information on your insurance identification card must be the same as on your vehicle registration when providing proof by mail.
You can't provide proof of insurance by phone or at a DMV office.
If your insurance company does not verify or denies the information you submitted, your driver license and/or vehicle registration will be, or will remain, suspended or revoked.
To create a MyDMV account you will need your NY State Driver License, Learner Permit, or Non-Driver ID card and the last 4 digits of your social security number.
You can order and immediately download your driving record abstract through MyDMV.
To get a copy of your vehicle registration abstract, you must use the Request For Driving and/or Vehicle Record Information PDF MV-15.
I received an insurance 'letter' or 'order' from the DMV.
Read the letter or order carefully.
See a sample letter or order carefully.
Answer the letter or order quickly.
Contact your insurance company immediately.
If there is a problem, it is your responsibility to resolve it.
If you do not resolve the problem, the DMV can suspend your vehicle registration.
If you do not resolve the problem, the DMV can suspend your driver license.
Do not use your vehicle if your insurance coverage is cancelled.
Do not use your vehicle even if you think it is a mistake.
Keep the plates while you resolve a problem with your insurance company.
Surrender your vehicle registration and plates before your insurance coverage ends.
Your response to the letter or order must either prove that you have insurance coverage.
Your response to the letter or order must prove that you sold the vehicle.
Your response to the letter or order must prove that insurance coverage was not required.
If you have insurance coverage, ask your insurance company to file an electronic notice of insurance coverage with the DMV.
Do not ask your agent or broker to file an electronic notice of insurance coverage with the DMV.
If you do not have liability insurance, you need to surrender your vehicle plates to the DMV immediately.
The letter means your insurance company notified the DMV that your insurance coverage ended.
The letter means that no other company notified the DMV about new coverage.
If you have insurance, follow the instructions in the letter.
If you have insurance, contact your company or agent about the problem.
If you have insurance, ask your company to file a notice of coverage with the DMV electronically.
If you do not have insurance, you need to surrender your vehicle registration and plates to the DMV immediately.
The letter means your insurance company notified the DMV that your insurance coverage ended.
The letter means that no other company notified the DMV about new coverage.
If you have insurance, follow the instructions in the letter.
If you have insurance, contact your company or agent about the problem.
If you have insurance, ask your company to file a notice of coverage with the DMV electronically.
If you do not have insurance, you need to surrender your vehicle registration and plates to the DMV immediately.
A driver license becomes suspended when the lapse is 91 days or more.
A driver license becomes suspended if the time period of the lapse has not yet been determined.
To determine the lapse period the plates must be surrendered.
To determine the lapse period the plates must be reported lost / stolen / confiscated.
To determine the lapse period the registration must expire.
To determine the lapse period the plates must be transferred to another vehicle by DMV.
To determine the lapse period DMV must receive proof of new or reinstated insurance.
To determine the lapse period DMV must receive other acceptable proof.
Once the lapse is determined, the registration will be suspended for the same number of days.
If the lapse period is 91 days or more, your driver license will also be suspended for the same number of days.
The suspensions may not be effective on the same date.
You may serve the suspension on the driver license first.
You may serve the suspension on the registration first.
The suspension on the driver license will not end until you have paid the suspension termination fee.
The suspension on the driver license will not end until you have served the suspension.
Surrender your plates to the DMV.
You can get your registration and new plates when the problem is corrected.
Paper proof or e-mail messages are NOT acceptable.
Your insurance agent or broker cannot file your proof of insurance electronically.
Only your insurance company can file proof of insurance electronically.
If you are not going to immediately replace your insurance coverage, you must surrender your plates.
Renew a business license or registration.
For dealers renewing online: Read the details regarding the new surety bond legislation at: https://dmv.ny.gov/dealers/dealer-surety-bond.
