To renew online, you must have the Facility Number from your Business Certificate, the Validation Number from your Business Certificate, the Federal Employer ID Number, the Social Security Number of the owner or partner or officer, the Business telephone number and email address.
You can renew a business license or registration online.
If the address of the facility has changed and you did not amend the address of the facility, you cannot renew online.

To renew with a new facility address, complete the Request for Business Amendment / Duplicate Certificate pdf and the MV-253 G Statement of Ownership and/or Permission to Use Place of Business pdf and send them to the DMV.

If an owner or partner or officer of the company that owns or operates the facility has a felony or misdemeanor conviction or forfeit since the last facility certificate renewal, complete the Facility Renewal Application VS-2 and a Statement of Ownership and/or Permission to Use Place of Business pdf VS-19 and send it to the DMV by mail.
To renew by mail, the DMV will send you a Facility Renewal Application VS-2.
Complete the Facility Renewal Application VS-2 and send it with a check for your renewal fee to NYS DMV Bureau of Consumer & Facility Services Application Unit P.O. Box 2700 Albany, NY 12220-0700.
If you do not receive your Facility Renewal Application VS-2, call the Office of Vehicle Safety and Clean Air at 1-518-474-0919.
All business registrations and Inspection Station licenses are valid for 2 years.
You can renew if the facility certificate or Inspection Station license will expire within the next 60 days.
You can renew if the facility certificate or Inspection Station license expired within the last six months.
You must first have a CDL to apply for the HazMat endorsement.
A driver with a NY State CDL must have an 'H' or an 'X' HazMat endorsement to operate commercial motor vehicles that carry hazardous materials.
The CDL Manual is CDL-10.
The Hazardous Materials Manual is CDL-11 in pdf format.
The Driver License Class Descriptions is MV-500C in pdf format.
You must be a U.S. citizen or a lawful permanent resident of the U.S. and present proof of citizenship or resident status at the time you apply for the hazardous materials endorsement.
The Important Information about the Hazardous Materials Endorsement is HAZ-11 in pdf format.
You must meet the federal medical requirements in 49 CFR Part 391 and have a valid USDOT Medical Examiner's Certificate.
You must be fingerprinted for background checks to apply for a HazMat endorsement.

Under federal law, the Federal Transportation Security Administration (TSA) may disqualify you from being authorized to transport hazardous materials if you have been convicted or found not guilty by reason of insanity of any of the crimes listed on Important Information about the Hazardous Materials Endorsement (HAZ-11 in pdf format) during the seven years before the date you apply for the endorsement.

Under federal law, the Federal Transportation Security Administration (TSA) may disqualify you from being authorized to transport hazardous materials if you have been released from incarceration in any jurisdiction for committing any disqualifying crime during the five years before the date you applied for the endorsement.

To apply for the HazMat endorsement, you must complete the Application for a Hazardous Materials Endorsement in pdf format and make a copy of one or more of the legal status documents that are listed on the form.

To apply for the HazMat endorsement, you must mail the completed Application for a Hazardous Materials Endorsement form and a copy of your legal status document to: HazMat Unit, NYS DMV, 6 Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228.
You may contact the HazMat unit if you have questions by phone at 1-518-408-2997 or email at [email protected]
You must pass a HazMat endorsement written test to get the HazMat endorsement.
You must visit a DMV office to pay the $5.00 written test fee and take the HazMat endorsement written test.
The HazMat endorsement written test result is valid until your CDL expires.
You can study the hazardous materials section of the NYS Commercial Driver License Manual (CDL-10) to prepare for the HazMat endorsement written test.
You can study the Hazardous Materials Manual (CDL-11 in pdf format) to prepare for the HazMat endorsement written test.
The required fingerprinting service for the HazMat endorsement is being provided by Identogo.
All HazMat endorsement applicants must be fingerprinted at one of the Identogo ID centers located throughout New York State.
Fingerprinting for the HazMat endorsement is done by appointment only.
You must contact Identogo to select a fingerprinting location and schedule an appointment for fingerprinting for the HazMat endorsement.
You can visit https://uenroll.identogo.com or call 1-877-472-6915 to make a fingerprinting appointment with Identogo for the HazMat endorsement.
You must bring your NY State CDL and one of the second proofs of ID that are listed on form HAZ-600 to the fingerprinting appointment with Identogo for the HazMat endorsement.
It normally takes at least 30 days from the date you submit your fingerprints to complete the background check for the HazMat endorsement.
The time period for completing the background check for the HazMat endorsement can be longer than 30 days.
The Federal Transportation Security Administration (TSA) will notify you by mail of the results of the background check for the HazMat endorsement based on federal standards only.
The TSA website has information about the federal background checks for the HazMat endorsements.
You should not request the results of background checks for the HazMat endorsement from the DMV, Identogo, or the TSA.
You should wait to receive the notifications of the results of the background checks for the HazMat endorsement in the mail.
The DMV cannot issue the HazMat endorsement until the background checks are completed and approved.

The DMV will provide a CDL with the HazMat endorsement that is valid for 90 days only if you applied to renew a current NY State CDL with a HazMat endorsement and the background checks are not completed and approved before the endorsement expires.
If you do not pass the written test or the background checks for the HazMat endorsement, the DMV will issue a CDL that does not have a HazMat endorsement.
The DMV will mail you notification of approval for the HazMat endorsement along with instructions to go into a DMV office to obtain a CDL with the HazMat endorsement.
Your new CDL with the HazMat endorsement will display the expiration date of your CDL and the expiration date of your HazMat endorsement.
The HazMat endorsement is valid for five years.

Federal and State laws require fingerprint-based background checks for anyone who wants a hazardous materials endorsement, to determine whether that person has a criminal history and/or poses a security threat that warrants denying him or her the authorization to transport hazardous materials.

No hazardous materials endorsement may be issued, transferred or renewed unless the background checks result in a determination by the Federal Transportation Security Administration (TSA) and New York State that the person applying for the endorsement is authorized to transport hazardous materials.

To initiate background checks for the HazMat endorsement, the rules require that the applicant be fingerprinted, and that his or her United States citizenship or permanent legal presence in the United States be verified.
You must answer 80% or more of the questions correctly to pass the HazMat endorsement written test.
You can take the HazMat endorsement written test as many times as necessary until you pass the test, but you must pay a $5 fee for each test you take.
You must provide fingerprints for the HazMat endorsement even if you provided fingerprints for another application, for example for a pistol permit or employment as a security guard.
You must provide fingerprints for an 'H' endorsement or an 'X' endorsement on your CDL.
The background checks for the HazMat endorsement include a check of criminal history data from the NY State Division of Criminal Justice Services and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).
The background checks for the HazMat endorsement also include a background check by the federal Transportation Safety Administration (TSA).
If you move to New York State and become a resident, you must get a New York State driver license within 30 days.
Students from other states, countries or nations who attend school in New York State are normally not considered residents of New York State.
Students from other states, countries or nations who attend school in New York State normally don't need to exchange their current driver license.
Normally, you can't have a New York State driver license and a driver license from another state at the same time.
It is a violation of Federal law to hold more than one commercial driver license (CDL).
The registration requirements to register and title a vehicle from another state in New York are generally the same as to register and title a vehicle in New York.
There are a few exceptions for out-of-state vehicles to register and title a vehicle from another state in New York.
There are a few exceptions for imported vehicles to register and title a vehicle from another state in New York.
A Temporary Visitor is defined as anyone who is not immigrating to or not residing (living) in the United States.
Temporary Visitors have U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) documentation that supports their legal status in this country.
If you have DHS documents that identify you as a Temporary Visitor, your New York State driver license, permit or non-driver ID card will have 'TEMPORARY VISITOR' on it.
If you have DHS documents that identify you as a Temporary Visitor, the expiration date from your DHS document will be on your New York State driver license, permit or non-driver ID card.
Your DMV document does not expire on the Temporary Visitor expiration date.
Your privilege to drive in New York does not expire on the Temporary Visitor expiration date.
You do not need to be a U.S. Citizen to get a New York driver license, permit or non-driver ID card.
You must have U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) documentation that supports your legal status in this country to get a New York driver license, permit or non-driver ID card.
The expiration date from your DHS document is added to your New York State permit, driver license or non-driver ID card.

If your temporary visitor status gets extended, you must bring to a DMV office a completed Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card (MV-44), your updated paperwork from the DHS, and your documents must be valid, current and verifiable 6 points of identification.
If you have a valid foreign driver license and a New York State learner permit, you can drive without a supervising driver.
If you have a valid foreign driver license and a New York State learner permit, you can drive on any street, road, highway, bridge, or tunnel, except in a DMV road test area.
If your foreign driver license is printed in any language except English, you must bring an International Driving Permit or a certified translation of your foreign driver license to the road test.
If you have a New York State learner permit and you do not have a valid foreign driver license, New York State law requires a supervising driver to ride with you.

The supervising driver must be age 21 or over and must have a valid driver license to operate the vehicle that you drive if you have a New York State learner permit and you do not have a valid foreign driver license.

According to Section 250(5) of the New York State Vehicle and Traffic Law, the term 'resident' means domiciliary, that is, one who lives in this state with the intention of making it a fixed and permanent abode.

According to Section 250(5) of the New York State Vehicle and Traffic Law, it shall be presumptive evidence that a person who maintains a place of abode in this state for a period of at least ninety days is a resident of this state.

According to Section 250(5) of the New York State Vehicle and Traffic Law, a police officer can use the presumptive evidence that a person maintains a place of abode in New York State for at least 90 days as evidence to issue a traffic ticket if that person drives in New York State without a New York State driver license or vehicle registration.
According to Section 250(5) of the New York State Vehicle and Traffic Law, a judge considers the law and the evidence of a person's intent and decides if that person is a resident of New York State.

According to Section 250(5) of the New York State Vehicle and Traffic Law, if a person pays taxes or their children attend school in another state, a judge considers these facts to decide if that person's intent is to make New York State a fixed and permanent residence.

According to Section 250(5) of the New York State Vehicle and Traffic Law, students from other states or from other nations who attend school in New York State are usually not considered residents of New York State.
The DMV does not decide if you are a resident of New York State.
The DMV does not decide if you must get a New York State driver license.
The DMV does not decide if you must register your vehicle in New York State.
If you have military experience driving commercial motor vehicles, you may apply for a waiver of the NYS CDL skills road test when you apply for a CDL.
To meet the requirements for this waiver, you must currently hold a valid New York State driver license or have a valid out of state driver license to be exchanged for a NYS driver license.
To meet the requirements for this waiver, you must meet all other requirements to qualify for a NYS CDL.

To meet the requirements for this waiver, you must be currently regularly employed or regularly employed within the last year in a military position (active duty or New York National Guard) that requires operation of a CMV.

To meet the requirements for this waiver, you must have operated a CMV of the type that the driver operates or expects to operate for at least two years immediately before the application date if in active service, or the date of being discharged from the military.

To apply for a military skills test waiver, you must present the following at a DMV office: a completed form CDL Certification for Military Waiver of Skills Tests (CDL-102), a valid NYS or out-of-state driver license, a medical certificate if required, proof of military service as listed on form CDL-102.
You must pass all applicable written tests and pay the written test fee, permit fee and license fee to apply for a military skills test waiver.
There is no skills test fee to apply for a military skills test waiver.
If you meet the requirements, the DMV will issue your CDL.
The class, endorsements and restrictions on your CDL will depend upon the type of CMV you operated in the military.
You must apply for a military skills test waiver at a DMV Office.
The Point & Insurance Reduction Program (PIRP) is approved by the Department of Motor Vehicles.
The PIRP is available through private companies or corporations called 'course sponsors' throughout New York State.
Each qualifying PIRP course must meet strict standards for the safe driving information presented and program effectiveness.
If you complete an approved PIRP course: It will help refresh your driving knowledge with a review of time-tested safe driving tips and an overview of today's vehicle and traffic laws.
If you complete an approved PIRP course: You may be eligible to reduce as many as four (4) points on your driving record.
If you complete an approved PIRP course: The DMV computer will automatically note your eligibility to receive the reduction.

If you are the principal operator of a motor vehicle, you will receive a minimum 10% reduction in the base rate of your automobile and motorcycle liability and collision insurance premiums each year for three years after completing an approved PIRP course.
Beginning in 2009, you will have two options for completing the PIRP course: the traditional classroom method or an Alternate Delivery Method (ADM), such as the Internet or other DMV approved method.
Regardless of the delivery method, each PIRP course is at least six hours long.
The motorcycle safety/accident prevention courses take substantially longer and are only available in a classroom setting.
Essential information about traffic safety issues such as driver attitude and behavior, defensive driving techniques, and the Vehicle & Traffic Law must be presented in each PIRP course.
For both the classroom and ADM methods, additional content, approach, materials and fees vary from one sponsor to the next.
For the classroom PIRP course: The course is presented in one or more classroom sessions and attendance is mandatory.
For the classroom PIRP course: No formal testing is required to complete the course.
For information on where to attend a classroom PIRP course, you can consult your local telephone book under 'Driving Instruction' or equivalent sections.

You may also contact one of the program sponsors presented in the DMV publication 'List of Course Sponsors' (C-31), available at any state or county motor vehicle office and by request from DMV Call Center.
Information on classroom PIRP courses is also available on the DMV website (dmv.ny.gov).
For the Alternate Delivery Method (ADM) PIRP course: The course will be a minimum 320 minutes.
For the ADM PIRP course: Once you register with a sponsor, you have up to 30 days to complete the course.
During the ADM PIRP course, you will be asked to identify yourself with information given at registration.
During the ADM PIRP course, you will also be asked questions regarding the content to ensure that you are taking the course.
For the ADM PIRP course: It is possible that you will be asked to register in person and/or take an exam at the end to once again ensure you are the one who completed the course.
Each ADM PIRP course sponsor's method is different, so you should contact the sponsor to determine which course best fits your needs.

You can contact approved ADM PIRP course sponsors presented in the DMV publication 'List of Course Sponsors' (C-31), available at any state or county motor vehicle office and by request from the DMV Call Center.
The most up-to-date information regarding who is approved to provide the Alternate Delivery Method PIRP course is available on the DMV website (dmv.ny.gov).
After you complete the PIRP course, the PIRP sponsor will notify the DMV within ten weeks.
After the PIRP sponsor notifies the DMV of your course completion, a notice will then be entered on your driving record.
After the notice is entered on your driving record, the DMV computer will automatically reduce your active point total by up to four points.
Completion of a PIRP course does not remove, delete, subtract, or erase any violation, conviction, or notice of original number of points from your driving record.
Even after you complete the PIRP course, most violations, convictions and points assessed will continue to show on your driving record for up to four years.
Violations and convictions involving drugs or alcohol will remain on your driving record for ten or fifteen years, depending on the violation, even after completing a PIRP course.
'Point reduction' means the DMV will not count up to four points on your driving record toward license revocation or suspension after you complete a PIRP course.
Point reduction applies only to points assessed for violations that occurred within the eighteen months immediately before PIRP course completion.
Point reduction does not affect points for earlier violations, and cannot be used as 'credit' against future violations or points.
Point reduction cannot reduce your point total lower than zero.
If your license has already been revoked or suspended, or if a violation hearing has already been scheduled, point reduction will not affect that action.
Point reduction does not prevent or cancel a mandatory revocation or suspension for violations such as DWI, DWAI, or three speeding violations within 18 months.
Points may be reduced only once in any 18-month period through the PIRP course.
The DMV point system and insurance company 'point' systems are separate and not related.
Point reduction on your driving record does not affect points assigned by your insurance company for violations and accidents.
Completion of a PIRP course cannot prevent or reduce the calculation of points affecting a 'Driver Responsibility Assessment'.
The most recent information about the Driver Responsibility Assessment program is available from the DMV website.
After completing the PIRP course, the course sponsor should mail you a completion certificate within 45 days.

If you present your PIRP course completion certificate to your insurance company or agent within 90 days after course completion, your liability and collision premium reduction will begin immediately, retroactive to the date you completed the course.
If you present your PIRP course completion certificate more than 90 days after course completion, the insurer may issue the premium discount effective from the date presented.
If you do not receive your PIRP course completion certificate within eight weeks after completion, you should immediately contact the program sponsor.
You may take the PIRP course once every 36 months to maintain insurance reduction benefits.
The PIRP course insurance reduction does not prevent general premium increases, or premium increases due to violations or accidents.
The PIRP course insurance reduction provides a 10% reduction for three years, from the base rate of your current liability, no-fault and collision premiums.
The PIRP course insurance premium reduction applies to all motor vehicles principally operated by the motorist who completes the course.
The PIRP course insurance premium reduction can be applied to only one driver for each covered vehicle.
Any insured driver who is the principal operator and completes a PIRP course will receive the insurance premium reduction.
If a youthful operator is already receiving a driver education reduction, you should check with your insurance company or agent to find out if both reductions will be given at the same time.
The table in the document shows the point values assigned to moving traffic violations by the DMV.
The points are assessed against your driving record based on the date you committed the violation, not the date you were convicted in court.
If you accumulate 11 or more points in 18 months, you will be called to a DMV hearing, after which your license may be suspended or revoked.
You will be offered the option of waiving the DMV hearing or accepting a definite period of suspension if you accumulate 11 or more points in 18 months.
Some license revocations and suspensions are mandatory and do not depend on points, such as three speeding violations within 18 months, and convictions involving alcohol or drugs.
More information about license suspensions and revocations is available in the DMV publication 'Suppose Your License Were Taken Away' (C-12), available at any motor vehicle office.
Beginning Summer 2018, there will be new rules regarding dealer record keeping.

To register as a retail dealer licensed by the Department of Motor Vehicles in New York State, one must consult the DMV Commissioner's Regulations for Motor Vehicle Dealers and Transporters (a PDF document).
To register as a retail dealer licensed by the Department of Motor Vehicles in New York State, one must download and read the Facility Requirements - Dealers / Transporters PDF document.
To register as a retail dealer licensed by the Department of Motor Vehicles in New York State, one can call the Office of Vehicle Safety and Clean Air at 1-518-474-4653 to get the forms.
To register as a retail dealer licensed by the Department of Motor Vehicles in New York State, one can call 1-518-474-0919 to get more information.
To apply for a retail dealer license, one must submit the Original Facility Application PDF document VS-1.

To apply for a retail dealer license, one must submit a copy of their complete original sealed and signed Surety Bond: Dealer Bond Under NY State Vehicle and Traffic Law Section 415 6-B PDF document VS-3 with power of attorney papers made out to their business name and address.

To apply for a retail dealer license, one must have permission to use the property at the business location, which can be demonstrated by a notarized statement from the property owner, a lease (which may be contingent on facility approval), a sub-lease with primary lease, a mortgage, a deed, or a receipted tax bill.
To apply for a retail dealer license, one must provide proof of their Sales tax ID number and a copy of their Sales Tax Certificate of Authority.
To apply for a retail dealer license, one may need a FEIN from the IRS before obtaining a Sales Tax Certificate of Authority.
To apply for a retail dealer license, one must provide proof of Workers Compensation Insurance for their employees, or indicate on the application if they have no employees.
To apply for a retail dealer license, one must provide a photocopy of a driver's license or other government-issued photo ID for everyone listed on the application.
To apply for a retail dealer license, one must provide a receipt for their purchase of the dealer's starter kit and signs.
To apply for a retail dealer license, one must pay all required fees via checks (application/license check & MV-50 check) payable to the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.

To apply for a retail dealer license, one must provide a Filing Receipt found on the NY State Department of State website if they are a Corporation or LLC, or a Business Certificate from the County Clerk if they are an individual using an assumed name or a partnership.

If one does not have their Certificate of Authority, they should not submit an application with DMV yet. The Certificate of Authority and Sales Tax ID number are issued by the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance (DTF). One may apply for these by visiting the NY State DTF website.

If one does not have their Proof of Business Name, they should not submit an application with DMV yet. Corporations and LLCs must submit a copy of their Filing Receipt from the Department of State. Instructions to file can be found on the NY State Department of State website. Partnerships and Individuals Using an Assumed Name must submit a copy of their Business Certificate of Assumed Name, which can be obtained from their county clerk.

If one does not have their proof of Workers Compensation Insurance, they should not submit an application with DMV yet. If they have any employees (including family members), they must submit proof of Workers Compensation Insurance. Instructions for this process can be found on the NY State Workers Compensation Board website. If they do not have any employees, they must indicate that on their application.

If one does not have their Surety Bond, they should not submit an application with DMV yet. DMV does not provide Surety Bonds; one must contact a surety insurance company and have them fill out the Dealer Bond Under NY State Vehicle and Traffic Law Section 415 6-B PDF document VS-3. The business name and mailing address on the bond must exactly match those on the application. The amount of the bond depends on the number of vehicles the applicant anticipates selling (for used motor vehicle dealers).

To submit the application by mail, one must send a hard copy of their application, associated documents, and fee to the following address: NYS DMV Bureau of Consumer & Facility Services Application Unit P.O. Box 2700 Albany, NY 12220-0700.

After submitting the application by mail, one will be contacted by a clerk from the Vehicle Safety's Application Processing Unit. Once the application is reviewed for completeness at the Albany office, it will be sent to a regional office for review. The regional office will contact the applicant to schedule an on-site investigation.

During the on-site investigation, the automotive facilities inspector (AFI) will check that the applicant has the following items: dealer starter kit, permanently mounted signs visible from the street. The AFI will deny the application if the signs are not clearly visible.

During the on-site investigation, the automotive facilities inspector (AFI) will check that the applicant has proof of identification (driver's license or other government-issued photo ID) for everyone named on the application.

During the on-site investigation, the automotive facilities inspector (AFI) will examine the applicant's location for the following characteristics: a clear and permanent physical barrier from other businesses that may share the location, separating display areas, signs, and offices; a display lot; a mailbox at the business address dedicated to the applicant's business only; a method of locking security items (locking cabinet, safe, etc.); heat, electricity, desk, and chairs; a business phone (a cell phone is acceptable).
If approved, the DMV will issue the applicant a certificate of registration, MV-50s (Retail Certificates of Sale), and a dealer plate letter if applicable.
DMV does not provide official dealer signs. The applicant may purchase these signs from various sign shops and automotive supply stores.

The official dealer sign must have a red background and white lettering, measure at least 3 feet wide by 2 feet tall, display 'REGISTERED Facility Number STATE OF NEW YORK MOTOR VEHICLE DEALER' in two-inch block lettering (as configured in the example shown in the footnote 1), and be permanently mounted and visible at all times from the nearest street or highway.

The starter kit components include: Book of Registry, Police Book, Bills of sale (Retail Certificate of Sale (MV-50)), Odometer Statements (except for ATV and Boat Dealers), Warranty Forms (except for ATV and Boat Dealers). All forms must comply with the current Regulations for Motor Vehicle Dealers and Transporters PDF document CR-78.

The starter kit components may be purchased through the following vendors: Automotive Dealer Supplies, Fairmount Press, Jan Horan Co., OMP Printing, SNYADS Services, NFADA Wholesale Distributors, Aratari Auto Finishers, Larry Ligarzewski Co., Genesys Systems.

DMV does not provide Surety Bonds. The applicant must contact a surety insurance company and have them fill out the Dealer Bond Under NY State Vehicle and Traffic Law Section 415 6-B PDF document VS-3. The business name and mailing address on the bond must exactly match those on the application. The amount of the bond depends on the number of vehicles the applicant anticipates selling (for used motor vehicle dealers).
To apply for a snowmobile dealer business certificate, one must use the Application for a Snowmobile Dealer Registration PDF document RV-253.
DMV does not endorse the companies listed for purchasing starter kit components or otherwise represent that DMV has any association with or oversight of these companies.
To transfer an IRP registration and apportioned plates, request that the IRB transfer the registration when you buy or register the new vehicle.
You can apply to transfer an IRP registration online through the New York State One Stop Credentialing and Registration system OSCAR.
For more information about transferring an IRP registration online, go to https://www.oscar.ny.gov/OSCR/OSCRCarrierHome.

To apply for transfer of an IRP registration by mail, mail the following completed and signed forms: Schedule A & C pdf IRP-6, proof of ownership, proof of insurance form FS-20 for the new vehicle being added to your account if applicable, clearance of the Heavy Vehicle Use Tax IRS form 2290, proof of identity, the original cab card for the vehicle being removed from the fleet, and the appropriate fee.
If you are using the United States Postal Service to transfer an IRP registration by mail, use this address: International Registration Bureau, PO Box 2850 ESP, Albany, NY 12220-0850.

If you are not using the United States Postal Service to transfer an IRP registration by mail, use this address: International Registration Bureau, NYS DMV, Room 1366 Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228.
You may bring the items described above to transfer an IRP registration at the Customer Service Counter, Room 136, Swan Street Building, Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228.
The Customer Service Counter for transferring an IRP registration is open from 8:00am to 3:45pm, Monday through Friday, except state holidays.
You can fax the items described above to transfer an IRP registration to the IRB at 518-486-6579.
Fees for transferring an IRP registration are calculated by member jurisdictions using different methods.
The NY State IRB cannot calculate the amount of your bill for transferring an IRP registration until the transfer has been processed.
The new registration for the transferred IRP registration expires on the same date as the original registration.

If the new vehicle for the transferred IRP registration weighs more than the previous vehicle, there are pro-rated registration fees for the difference in weight, administrative fees for the vehicle plate transfer, and fees for any fee increases that may have occurred since the original registration was issued.
The original cab card for the vehicle being removed from your fleet must be sent to the IRB when transferring an IRP registration.
If you do not transfer the IRP registration immediately, surrender the apportioned plates and cab card to the IRB.
Your vehicle registration will be suspended if there is a lapse of liability insurance and the apportioned plates were not surrendered when not transferring the IRP registration immediately.
The driver license of the registrant can also be suspended if the IRP registration is not transferred immediately.
See Section 9.0 of the NY State IRP Manual pdf IRP-8 for complete instructions on IRP registration transfers.
In Part 1, Type of Application Requested, of the IRP registration transfer form, check TRANSFER PLATES, and complete the Carrier, Fleet, Weight and Vehicle Information sections on the form.
If you apply to transfer an IRP registration by mail, send photocopies of your proofs of identity.
If another person brings your application to transfer an IRP registration to the Customer Service Counter, see the requirements for a second-party registration application.
You cannot transfer an IRP registration by phone.
You may call the IRB with questions about transferring an IRP registration at 1-518-473-5834.
You can transfer your IRP registration by mail by following the instructions on this page and Schedule A&C IRP-6.
You can transfer an IRP registration at the Customer Service Counter, Room 136, Swan Street Building, Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228.
You cannot transfer an IRP registration at a DMV local office.
You can fax the items described on this page to transfer an IRP registration to the IRB at 518-486-6579.
For information on how to change your address on DMV documents and records, see change address.
To change your email address, use the email reminders service.
To change information on your driver license, permit or non-driver ID, you must visit your local DMV office and bring proof of the change.
If you plan on traveling, the DMV recommends you come to the DMV now to get an Enhanced or REAL ID, and avoid a second office visit later.
The DMV provides information about Enhanced, REAL ID and Standard documents.
The DMV provides a guide to ensure you have the correct proofs of identification you need.

To update a legal change of name on DMV records, you must bring these items to a DMV office: a completed Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card (MV-44), your current license, permit or non-driver ID, or at least 6 points of proof of identity, and original or a certified copy of your U.S. marriage certificate, U.S. divorce documents or other court papers for a change of name issued in the U.S.
When you change your name on your driver license, permit or non-driver ID, you must update your photo.
If your date of birth is not correct, you must bring proof of age as listed on proofs of identity and date of birth for NY State driver license, learner permit or non-driver ID.

If you had a gender change or you are transgender, you must bring a completed Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card (MV-44), your current learner permit, driver license or non-driver ID, and proof of a gender change.
If the DMV made an error on your document, you can use the Ask DMV a Question service to request a correction, which may be done without you coming to a DMV office. There is no fee for a correction.

To change your photo, you must go to a DMV office. When you renew, there is no additional fee to update your photo. When it is not time to renew, you must bring a completed Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card (MV-44), your current license, permit, or non-driver ID, and pay a fee ($17.50 to update the photo on a license or permit, and $13 for a non-driver photo ID).

To make a reservation for quicker service, you can make a reservation online before visiting DMV offices in New York City, Westchester, Nassau, Suffolk, Rockland, Onondaga, Monroe or Albany Counties. For all other counties, you can see the office locations and hours.
The fee for an amended permit or license is $12.50. The fee for an amended non-driver ID card is $5.00.

Once ordered, your new document will come in 2 weeks. The DMV will give you a temporary non-photo driver license, learner permit or non-driver ID at the DMV office. You will receive your new document in the mail in about 2 weeks. You can check the mailing status.

If your loved one has passed away, you should mail a copy of the death certificate and a photocopy of their license or ID (if you have it) to the DMV License Production Bureau at P.O. Box 2688 ESP Albany, NY 12220-0668. This will prevent further mailings or identity theft.

To update your legal name on your vehicle registration and title, you must bring these items to your local DMV office: your current title or other acceptable proof of ownership, a completed Vehicle Registration/Title Application (MV-82), your current license, permit or non-driver ID, or at least 6 points of proof of identity and proof of date of birth, and original or a certified copy of your U.S. marriage certificate, U.S. divorce documents or other court papers for a change of name issued in the U.S.
The DMV provides a checklist to print for changing your name on a vehicle registration and title.
The DMV provides special instructions to change the name on a title after lease buyout.
For information on how to change your mailing and residence addresses on DMV documents and records, see change address.

To change other information on your vehicle registration and title, you must visit your local DMV office and bring proof of the change. If you had a gender change or you are transgender, you must bring a completed Vehicle Registration/Title Application (MV-82), your registration and title, and proof of a gender change.

If the DMV made an error on your registration or title, you can use the Ask DMV a Question service to request a correction, which may be done without you coming to a DMV office. There is no fee for a correction.

To make a reservation for quicker service, you can make a reservation online before visiting DMV offices in New York City, Westchester, Nassau, Suffolk, Rockland, Onondaga, Monroe or Albany Counties. For all other counties, you can see the office locations and hours.
There is no fee to change your name on your registration documents and title certificate.

When you apply to change your name on your registration documents and title certificate, the DMV will give you new registration documents immediately. You should allow 60 to 90 days for your new title to arrive in the mail.

Starting in October 2020, you will need an Enhanced or REAL ID to board a domestic flight unless you have a passport. If your license, permit, or ID was issued before October 30, 2017 and is not Enhanced, you have a Standard document. Newly issued Standard documents state: 'NOT FOR FEDERAL PURPOSES'.

Regardless of the genders of you and your spouse, if your marriage certificate shows both your spouse's surname and your former surname, you may change your middle name to your former surname or choose a different middle name and change your surname to your spouse's surname.

Proof of a gender change can be in the form of a written statement from a physician, psychologist, psychiatrist or other appropriate professional that is printed on letterhead. The statement must certify that one gender is your main gender and that you identify as male or female. An appropriate professional can include but is not limited to a Life Counselor, a Clinical Social Worker or other professional who is overseeing the change in gender.
If you have a 10-year non-driver ID, are age 62 or older and a recipient of Supplemental Security Income (SSI), there is no fee.

Regardless of the genders of you and your spouse, if your marriage certificate shows both your spouse's surname and your former surname, you may change your middle name to your former surname or choose a different middle name and change your surname to your spouse's surname.

Proof of a gender change can be in the form of a written statement from a physician, psychologist, psychiatrist or other appropriate professional that is printed on letterhead. The statement must certify that one gender is your main gender and that you identify as male or female. An appropriate professional can include but is not limited to a Life Counselor, a Clinical Social Worker or other professional who is overseeing the change in gender.
You can apply for a New York State registration and a title certificate by mail from outside of New York.

You will need to mail these items to a local DMV office: a completed Vehicle Registration / Title Application PDF MV-82, proof of ownership (must be original; photocopies are not accepted), proof of NY State automobile liability insurance, proof of identity and age (send photocopies; do not send original documents), payment for sales tax.
You must contact the motor vehicle agency in the other state to determine if their laws require that you register your vehicles there.
The definition of 'resident' is different in each state.
The document provides the NY State definition of 'resident'.
Once the DMV processes your application, the DMV will send you these items in one package: your registration documents, your vehicle plates, a 10-day Inspection Extension Sticker VS-1077.
You must put the 10-day Inspection Sticker on your vehicle when you enter New York State, not before.
You must mark the box on the sticker that indicates you entered New York, and write the date you entered.
The DMV will send you your title certificate separately.
Allow up to 90 days to receive your title certificate from the DMV.
Allow 6 weeks for your registration documents to arrive by mail.
It will take longer to receive your documents if you are outside of the United States.
To get registration documents by express mail, enclose a pre-paid, pre-addressed express mail package with your application.
The express mail package must be able to contain vehicle plates.

To have your registration sent to an address that is different from your registration document, include a separate note with your Vehicle Registration / Title Application PDF MV-82, and clearly print the alternate address.
Do not write the alternate address on your application.
If you write the alternate address on your application, the DMV will print the alternate address on your registration document and registration record.
The DMV cannot send the title certificate to an address different from the mailing address on your registration application.
If your vehicle is coming from another country, you need to read the instructions for how to register an imported vehicle.
Another person can submit your registration application at a DMV office for you.
To have another person submit your registration application, read the instructions for how to register a vehicle for someone else.
It is recommended to send any original documents by insured or priority mail, as it can be difficult to replace documents that are lost in the mail.

For cars, trucks and motorcycles that are model year 1973 or newer, proof of ownership can be either a NY State Certificate of Title (the original or a certified copy, not a photocopy) or acceptable proof of ownership from any other state (the original or a certified copy, not a photocopy).
The document provides information on acceptable proofs for other vehicles older than 1973, manufactured homes, boats, trailers, ATVs, snowmobiles, gifted vehicles, and vehicles with deceased owners.
Your insurance company will give you 2 barcoded original NY State Insurance ID cards or provide you with access to your digital electronic NY State Insurance ID Card.
Your insurance company will send an electronic notice of insurance coverage to the DMV.
Your insurance agent or broker cannot file the notice of insurance coverage.
Your NY State Insurance ID cards and the electronic notice together verify your insurance coverage.
The DMV needs both the Insurance ID cards and the electronic notice.
You must register your vehicle within 180 days of the effective date on your Insurance ID Card.
You must bring one copy or form of your Insurance ID Card with you to the DMV office.
The DMV office will keep the paper Insurance ID Card.
You must keep the other paper Insurance ID Card with the vehicle as your proof of insurance.
Anyone operating your vehicle must be able to provide proof of insurance.
You must be at least 16 years old to register a vehicle, except for ATV registrations.
A NY State Driver License, Learner Permit, or Non-Driver ID card that is current or not expired for more than 2 years can serve as proof of both identity and age.
If you do not have a NY State Driver License, Learner Permit, or Non-Driver ID card, the document provides information on other kinds of proof you can use.
Most states allow a non-resident to register a vehicle.
It can be easier to apply for a vehicle registration and title certificate in the other state.

If your registration expires while you are traveling, you should determine if the other state can issue an 'in-transit' permit, which allows you to transport a vehicle to New York so that you can register it.
The document provides the definition of a New York State Resident according to Section 250 5 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law.
According to the law, students from other states or other nations who attend school in NY State are normally not considered residents of NY State.
To register a vehicle by mail, you must mail your completed registration application, additional documents, and payment to a DMV office.
You can check the status of vehicle titles and liens online.
The service is not available for boat titles.
The status check service displays the following information: the title was issued by DMV, the date, the number of liens if any, the name and address of the lienholder.
The service does not display any personal information about the vehicle owner or registrant.
You must provide the following information to check a title or lien status online: the Vehicle Identification Number (VIN), the vehicle model year, the vehicle make (i.e. Ford, Jeep).
This information can be found on your vehicle's registration documents.
It can take up to 90 days to receive the title certificate from the DMV in the mail.
If it has been over 90 days and you still have not received your title, you should Email the DMV to check your title status.
To have a lien recorded on a Certificate of Title, you must submit a request either through a dealer or directly to NY State DMV and pay the required lien filing fee.

If you did that, but did not see your lien listed when you checked the status of the title certificate on this website, or if you learned from another source that the lien is either not recorded or not pending, you should notify DMV immediately by completing and emailing a Customer Lien Inquiry (MV-910) form.
The Customer Lien Inquiry (MV-910) form requires you to provide your Contact Information.
If you are a lending institution, you should include your lien filing code on the Customer Lien Inquiry (MV-910) form.
You should provide complete and accurate information for the vehicle or boat in question on the Customer Lien Inquiry (MV-910) form.
If the version of Adobe does not allow you to save the information you typed, you can print the Customer Lien Inquiry (MV-910) form and fax it to 518 486-6581.
You should click on the email address shown on the Customer Lien Inquiry (MV-910) form to open an email, or open an email and paste the address into the To line.
You should attach the completed Customer Lien Inquiry (MV-910) form to the email and send it.

You should use the Customer Lien Inquiry (MV-910) form or the email to request any other type of information or service from DMV, as DMV will disregard anything not related to a possible missing lien.
If you have questions or issues on any other matter, you should see how to contact DMV.
DMV staff will respond to your request as soon as possible.
DMV must first identify the vehicle or boat and verify its title status.
Then DMV must retrieve and review the application forms to determine the appropriate response.
These activities take time.
If your lien has not been recorded, and the correct form and fee have been filed, DMV will record your lien and send you a Notice of Recorded Lien (MV-901).
If DMV does not have the correct form and fee to record your lien, DMV will contact you to let you know what is needed.
The issue date is the date the DMV prints the title certificate.
The DMV mails the certificate after it's printed.
When you register a vehicle in New York at a DMV office, you must either pay the sales tax prove that sales tax was paid your vehicle registration is exempt from sales tax prove.
You probably also will need to pay county use tax when you register.
You must get a sales tax receipt from the DMV even if the transaction is exempt from sales tax.
If the name on the NY State Title Certificate will not change, sales tax forms and proofs are not required.
If you were not a NY State resident when you purchased the vehicle, see information below.

If you bought the vehicle from a NY State automobile dealer or an out-of-state dealer that is authorized to collect NY State sales tax, bring the dealer's bill of sale that shows that you paid NY State sales tax.

If you bought the vehicle from a NY State automobile dealer or an out-of-state dealer that is authorized to collect NY State sales tax, bring a Dealer s Bill of Sale MV-50 NY State dealer only or a completed Sales Tax Exemption {Sales Tax Form} pdf at NY State Department of Tax and Finance DTF-803 for an out-of-state dealer.
If NY State sales tax was paid to a NY State dealer, the DMV does not collect sales tax when you apply for a vehicle registration, and the DMV does not issue a sales tax receipt.

If you bought your vehicle from another person in a private sale, both you the buyer and the seller must complete the Statement of Transaction {Sales Tax Form} pdf at NY State Department of Tax and Finance DTF-802.
If you bought your vehicle from another person in a private sale, bring the Statement of Transaction {Sales Tax Form} pdf at NY State Department of Tax and Finance DTF-802 to a DMV office.
The DMV calculates and collects the sales tax, and issues a sales tax receipt if you bought your vehicle from another person in a private sale.
If you leased the vehicle, see register a leased vehicle.

If the vehicle was a gift or was purchased from a family member, use the Statement of Transaction {Sales Tax Form} pdf at NY State Department of Tax and Finance DTF-802 to receive a sales tax exemption.
If you paid out-of-state sales tax, show the out-of-state dealer bill of sale.
The out-of-state dealer bill of sale must show the purchase price and the amount of out-of-state sales tax paid to the dealer if you paid out-of-state sales tax.

Use Sales Tax Paid in Another State {Sales Tax Form} pdf at NY State Department of Tax and Finance DTF-804 form to claim credit for the state and local sales taxes you paid in the other state if you paid out-of-state sales tax.
This process can reduce the amount of your NY State sales tax if NY State and the other state have an agreement about sales tax.
Not all states have an agreement with New York about sales tax.

If you were not a resident of New York when the vehicle was purchased, use form Sales Tax Exemption {Sales Tax Form} pdf at NY State Department of Tax and Finance DTF-803 to receive a non-resident exemption from NY State sales tax.
Form DTF-803 defines the terms "non-resident" and "resident".
If you are a member of the U.S. Armed Forces and you do not reside in New York, you can defer your sales tax payment.

Complete form Sales Tax Exemption {Sales Tax Form} pdf NY State Department of Tax and Finance DTF-803 if you are a NY State resident you are now a member of the U.S. Armed Forces you do not now reside in NY State or keep a residence in NY State.
The Sales Tax Exemption DTF-803 form provides information and the definitions to defer your sales tax if you are a member of the U.S. Armed Forces and you do not reside in New York.
You must pay the sales tax when you leave the Armed Forces or you return to New York if you deferred your sales tax payment as a member of the U.S. Armed Forces not residing in New York.
For more information, visit the NY State Department of Taxation and Finance website.
DMV keeps accident reports for only 4 years from the date of the accident.
DMV keeps accident reports for rare instances that are described in Vehicle and Traffic Law Section 201.
To order a copy of an accident report by mail, use the Request for Copy of Accident Report PDF MV-198C.
To order a copy of an accident report by mail, you need the plate number of a vehicle involved in the crash/accident.
To order a copy of an accident report by mail, you need the driver license number of a person who was involved in the crash/accident.
To order a copy of an accident report by mail, you need the name and date of birth of a person who was involved in the crash/accident.
Accident reports ordered by mail are certified copies.
If DMV cannot find an accident based on the information you provide, you will be notified by DMV in a certified letter.
To order a copy of an accident report in PDF format online, use the Order and Access Motor Vehicle Accident Reports online transaction.
Accident reports available through the online transaction are certified copies that include an attestation and signature of the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
To place an online order for an accident report, you need the plate number of a vehicle involved in the crash/accident.
To place an online order for an accident report, you need the driver license number of a person who was involved in the accident.
To place an online order for an accident report, you need the 8-digit DMV case number that starts with the number 3.
You can access an accident report that you purchased online within the last 7 calendar days.
No fee is charged to access a report that you previously purchased online.
To access a previously purchased online accident report, enter your email address and the Report Confirmation Number.
Some customers have experienced problems downloading PDF documents from the DMV website.
To download PDF documents from the DMV website, make sure your operating system and web browser have been updated with all recent updates.
If the accident was filed electronically by police or occurred in one of the five boroughs of New York City, allow at least 14 days from the date of the accident before you search for the report.
If a paper form was used by police to report the accident, allow at least 30 days from the date of the accident before you search for the report.

To order an accident report, you need to be named on the accident report, or represent a person named on the report, or be a party to a civil action that arose from the accident, or represent a person who is a party to a civil action that arose from the accident.
Search fees are required by law according to Vehicle and Traffic Law Section 202.
To order an accident report by mail, you must pay a required search fee of $10.00 and an additional report fee of $15.00 for each accident report.
To order an accident report online, you must pay a required search fee of $7.00 and an additional report fee of $15.00 for each accident report.
The system will charge you separately for the search fee and for each report when ordering online.
You will receive a confirmation email for each online transaction.
You can do a free limited search to see if your report is available online.
The online system provides a list of accidents by date and county for the free limited search.
To see if a report is available in the free limited online search, search for the plate number.
If you submit a search by county and date in the free limited online search, but you do not select any reports, the search fee is not charged.
If you purchased accident reports online within the last 7 calendar days, you can access the reports again.
To access previously purchased online accident reports, enter the Report Confirmation Number displayed during the report purchase transaction and emailed to you in the transaction confirmation.
To access previously purchased online accident reports, enter the email address you entered during the previous transaction.
No fee is charged to access the reports you purchased previously online in the last 7 days.
You must exchange your out-of-state driver license from another U.S. state or territory, federal district or Canadian province within 30 days of becoming a resident of New York.
Your out-of-state driver license must have your photograph.
Your out-of-state driver license must be valid or expired less than 24 months.
Your out-of-state driver license must have been issued at least 6 months before you apply for a New York license unless it is commercial driver license that has been valid for any amount of time.
You cannot exchange your license if it is suspended or revoked.
You cannot exchange your license if it is lost or stolen.
You cannot exchange your license if it is a hardship or an "employment only driver license".
You cannot exchange your license if it is marked "non-renewable" or "non-transferable".
Your New York license will be valid for 5 years.
This transaction can only be processed in person, at a DMV office.
You will need to pass a vision test at the DMV or bring a completed Eye Test Report PDF MV-619.
You need to surrender your out-of-state license, unless it is lost or stolen.
You need to bring proof of identity.
You need to complete a guide to make sure you have the documents and proofs of identity you need.
The DMV will give you a temporary non-photo license document.
Allow 2 weeks for your new license to arrive in the mail.
For quicker service, make a reservation online before visiting offices in New York City, Westchester, Nassau, Suffolk, Rockland, Onondaga, Monroe or Albany Counties.
For all other counties, see the DMV office locations and hours.

Residents of Bronx, Kings (Brooklyn), New York (Manhattan), Queens, Richmond (Staten Island), Dutchess, Nassau, Orange, Putnam, Rockland, Suffolk and Westchester counties must pay the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee $10.
Enhanced documents have an additional $30.00 fee.
The DMV accepts cash, most credit, pinless debit or prepaid cards (American Express, Discover Card/Novus, MasterCard, VISA), a personal check or a money order payable to the DMV.

Students from other states, countries or nations who attend school in New York State are normally not considered residents of New York State, so they don't need to exchange their current driver license.
Normally, you can't have a NY State driver license and a driver license from another state at the same time, but there are exceptions.
It is a violation of Federal law to hold more than one commercial driver license (CDL).
You can drive in New York State with a valid driver license from another country.
You do not need to apply for a New York State driver license unless you become a New York State resident.
To get a New York State driver license, you must pass a written test, complete a 5-hour pre-licensing course and pass a road test.
When you pass your road test, you must give your foreign driver license to the DMV road test examiner.
The local DMV office will destroy your foreign driver license after 60 days.
If you plan to return to your home country and will need your foreign driver license, ask the road test examiner how to make sure that your foreign driver license is not destroyed.
The DMV has additional resources for drivers from other countries.
To live in a house, a home, an apartment, a room or other similar place in NYS for 90 days is considered "presumptive evidence" that you are a resident of New York State.
A police officer can use this as evidence to issue a traffic ticket if you drive in New York State without a New York State driver license or vehicle registration.
A judge considers the law and the evidence of your intent and decides if you are a resident of New York State.
If you pay taxes or your children attend school in another state, a judge considers these facts to decide if your intent is to make NYS a "fixed and permanent" residence.
According to this law, students from other states or from other nations who attend school in New York State are usually not considered residents of NYS.
The DMV does not decide if you are a resident of New York State, if you must get a NYS driver license, or if you must register your vehicle in New York State.

If your out-of-state photo driver license does not show the date it was issued, get a certified driver license record or letter from the state that issued the license that indicates the date of issue.
If you cannot get a letter or abstract, you must apply for a new, original driver license.
If your out-of-state driver license or Canadian driver license is suspended or revoked, you cannot apply for a NY State driver license.
You must remove the suspension or revocation and bring to a NY State DMV office a valid driver license that meets the requirements listed above.
Your out-of-state driver license must be a photo driver license.
Your out-of-state driver license must show that it was valid for at least 6 months.
Instead of a replacement driver license, you can apply to the previous state for a letter or certified driver abstract.
The letter or abstract must be an original document on the letterhead of the agency that issued your driver license before you submit the letter or driver abstract to the DMV.
The letter or abstract must be issued by the other state within six months.
The letter or driver abstract must contain your name, address, date of birth and driver license identification number.
The letter or driver abstract must contain the type or class of driver license and any restrictions.
The letter or driver abstract must contain a list any convictions, suspensions or revocations.
The letter or driver abstract must contain the date your driver license was issued and the expiration date of your most recent driver license.
A letter or driver abstract has no value as proof of identity or date of birth.
If you cannot provide the required documents, you must apply for an original NY State driver license.
If you move, you must report a change of residence address on your license, permit, non-driver ID or vehicle records to the DMV within 10 days.
Changing your address with the U.S. Postal Service USPS does not update your DMV records.
When you change your address for a vehicle registration, the DMV also updates the title certificate record.
You do not need to order new DMV documents with your new address.
Updating your address for a traffic ticket does not update your address on other DMV records.
There are instructions to change your name or other non-address information on the DMV website.

To change the address on your license, permit, non-driver ID and/or registration online through MyDMV, you will need the ID number and document number from your New York State driver license, learner permit, or Non-Driver ID.
If you lost your document, renewed or ordered a new one recently and have not received it in the mail yet, you will need to wait for it to arrive before you can create a MyDMV account.
You can still change your address by mail or at a DMV office even if you don't have your document yet.

To change your license, permit, non-driver ID and/or the address on your registration by mail, you must mail a completed Address Change PDF MV-232 form to NYS DMV License Production Bureau at the address PO Box 2895, Albany, NY 12220-0895.
If you want to replace your documents by mail, you must include payment according to the information on the Change Address MV-232 form.
Unless you need to change your name or you want a new photo on your license or non-driver ID, there is no need to go to a DMV office to change your address.
If you go to a DMV office to change your address, you must bring a completed Address Change PDF MV-232 form with you.
If you want to replace your documents at a DMV office, you must bring payment for the fees.
You can have different addresses on your license and registrations with the DMV.
The DMV sends documents and important notices to customers by mail.
The DMV recommends that you use the same address on all of your applications, documents, and transactions with them.
You must report your address change to both the DMV and the USPS.

When you change your address, you can write your new address on the back of your driver license, non-driver ID card or learner permit, and on the front of the registration document carefully drawing lines through the old address.
You should not write the new address on a title certificate.

If you update your address for a Traffic Violations Bureau TVB traffic ticket transaction, the update does not change the address on your driver license, non-driver ID, permit, or vehicle registration records.
If you update the address for your driver license, non-driver ID, permit, or vehicle registration records, the update does not change the address for your traffic ticket.
You can order picture or professional plates for passenger vehicles.
You can order picture or professional plates for commercial vehicles.
You can order picture or professional plates for motorcycles.
Many picture or professional plates can also be personalized.
You can browse the collection of picture and professional plates and order online directly from the pages below.

The categories of picture and professional plates are: I Love NY Adventure, Sports, Military and Veterans, Counties and Regions of NY State, Colleges, Fraternities, Sororities, Causes, Professions, Organizations, Motorcycle Plates.
You can learn more about picture and professional plates.
You can order many picture plates online.
If you wish to purchase plates for people with disabilities that have the Universal Symbol of Access, you must contact the Custom Plates Unit.
All professional and military/veteran plates, and some organization picture plates require you to provide proof or certification that you are eligible.
These plates must be ordered through the organization or the Custom Plates Unit.

To order picture or professional plates online: You must have a valid New York State vehicle registration in the passenger, commercial or motorcycle registration class that does not expire within 60 days.
The mailing address on your vehicle registration record must be your current mailing address.
Your vehicle registration record must match your current name if your name has changed.
You must provide your current plate number, the 3-letter registration class code and the first three letters of your last name.
You can see a sample registration document.
You must have a credit card that DMV accepts, and a valid email address for confirmation purposes.
To order picture or professional plates by mail, use the Application for Custom Plates pdf CP-30.
Mail the completed form and your payment to: NYS DMV Custom Plates Unit, P.O. Box 2775, Albany, NY 12220.
You can order picture or professional plates by phone.
It is faster and easier to order picture or professional plates online than by phone.
You can call the Custom Plates Unit at 1-518-402-4838 to order picture or professional plates by phone.
The office hours of the Custom Plates Unit are 8:00am - 4:00pm, Monday through Friday.
You can order picture or professional plates at a DMV office.
It is faster and easier to order picture or professional plates online than at a DMV office.
You can find a DMV office.
Professional plates can only be ordered from the Custom Plates Unit with proper proof or certification.
In approximately 10 days or less after your order is processed, you will receive new documents that show your current plate number and your new plate combination.
Allow at least six weeks for the custom plates to arrive.
Your new registration documents will be mailed separately from your new custom plates.
If you do not receive your registration documents within two weeks or your custom plates within six weeks, contact the Custom Plates Unit at 1-518-402-4838.
The office hours of the Custom Plates Unit are 8:00am - 4:00pm, Monday through Friday.
You can check the mailing status of your plate order.
Once you receive your new plates, you will want to destroy your old plates to protect against fraudulent use.
Mark each vehicle plate with a permanent marker.
Do not put both vehicle plates in the recycling/garbage on the same day.
You cannot order picture or professional plates before your vehicle is registered, when renewing your registration, or before transferring a registration.
You must have a registration windshield sticker, receipt and regular series plates issued by DMV before ordering picture or professional plates.
Call the Custom Plates Unit at 1-518-402-4838 if you have any questions.
The office hours of the Custom Plates Unit are 8:00am - 4:00pm, Monday through Friday.
If your registration expires within the next 60 days, renew your registration before you order picture or professional plates.
Change your address online before ordering picture or professional plates.
You must visit a DMV office to change your name on all DMV records and documents.
Learn more about how to change your name.
DMV accepts American Express, Discover, MasterCard and VISA for payment.
Some picture plates cannot be purchased by mail.
Some plates are not available by phone.
Professional, emergency services and some organization plates are limited to membership and must be ordered through the organization or directly from the Custom Plates Unit, with documentation.
Call the Custom Plates Unit at 1-518-402-4838 if you have any questions.
The office hours of the Custom Plates Unit are 8:00am - 4:00pm, Monday through Friday.
A driver civil penalty is a fine you must pay to DMV for certain offenses before your license or driving privilege can be restored after a suspension or revocation.
This fine is in addition to any other fines, penalties or surcharges that you must pay for a traffic conviction.
The purpose of the driver civil penalty is to prevent the repeated behavior of problem drivers and to improve traffic safety.
The quickest and easiest way is to pay a driver civil penalty online.
You must pay a driver civil penalty if your driver license or driving privilege was suspended or revoked because you violated the NY State Zero Tolerance Law for drivers under age 21.
You must pay a driver civil penalty if your driver license or driving privilege was revoked because you refused to take a chemical test for alcohol or drugs.
You must pay a driver civil penalty if you operated or permitted the operation of a motor vehicle without automobile liability insurance.
You must pay a driver civil penalty if you operated a motor vehicle involved in a traffic crash and the vehicle was not covered by automobile liability insurance.
The amount of the driver civil penalty depends on the reason for the suspension or revocation.
You may owe more than one driver civil penalty.
To pay a driver civil penalty online, you can pay with a credit or debit card.
To pay a driver civil penalty online, your name and address on DMV records must be correct.
To pay a driver civil penalty online, you must create a MyDMV account to verify or change your address.
To pay a driver civil penalty online, you must provide the last four digits of your Social Security Number.
To pay a driver civil penalty online, you must provide your DMV ID Number or Client ID Number from your NY State driver license, learner permit or non-driver photo ID card.
To pay a driver civil penalty online, you must provide your full name, date of birth and gender if you do not have a DMV ID Number or Client ID Number.
If your driver license is revoked, your payment of the driver civil penalty does not restore your privilege to drive.
If your driver license is revoked, you must request and receive approval from DMV to restore your license or driving privilege unless your revocation was for an uninsured accident.
If your revocation was for an uninsured accident, you must contact the DMV Insurance Services Bureau.

If you are suspended for a violation of the Zero Tolerance Law, you must wait until the suspension period ends, pay a suspension termination fee and have a valid driver license before you can legally drive.
To check if you have a valid driver license, you must create a MyDMV account and use the My License, Permit or ID service.
You can pay more than one driver civil penalty online at a time.
You are not required to pay all of your driver civil penalties in one transaction.
You cannot be approved for a new driver license or restoration of your driving privilege until you pay all the driver civil penalties you owe.
You can return to the online transaction later to pay additional driver civil penalties.

To pay a driver civil penalty by mail for uninsured operation or uninsured accident, you must send a certified check, personal check or money order payable to Commissioner of Motor Vehicles to the Insurance Services Bureau at NYS DMV, 6 Empire State Plaza, Room 332B, Albany, NY 12228.

To pay a driver civil penalty by mail for a chemical test refusal or violation of the Zero Tolerance Law, you must send a certified check or money order payable to Commissioner of Motor Vehicles to the Driver Improvement Unit at NYS DMV, 6 Empire State Plaza, Room 338, Albany, NY 12228.
You can pay the driver civil penalty at the DMV office listed on your suspension or revocation order, but it is much faster and easier to pay online.
If the suspension or revocation order was issued between January 1, 1981 and June 30, 1990, the driver civil penalty is $100.
If the suspension or revocation order was issued between July 1, 1990 and October 31, 1996, the driver civil penalty is $200.
If the suspension or revocation order was issued between November 1, 1996 and October 31, 2006, the driver civil penalty is $300.
If the suspension or revocation order was issued between November 1, 1992 and October 31, 1996, the driver civil penalty is $250.
If the suspension or revocation order was issued between November 1, 1996 and October 31, 2006, the driver civil penalty is $350.
If the suspension or revocation order was issued between September 1, 1983 and June 30, 1990, the driver civil penalty is $250.
If the suspension or revocation order was issued between July 1, 1990 and October 31, 1996, the driver civil penalty is $500.
If the suspension or revocation order was issued between July 1, 1990 and October 31, 1996, the driver civil penalty is $500.
If the suspension or revocation order was issued between June 1, 1972 and April 30, 1989, the driver civil penalty is $300.
If the suspension or revocation order was issued between May 1, 1989 and May 14, 2003, the driver civil penalty is $500.
If the suspension or revocation order was issued between June 1, 1972 and April 30, 1989, the driver civil penalty is $300.
If the suspension or revocation order was issued between May 1, 1989 and May 14, 2003, the driver civil penalty is $500.

The DMV accepts American Express Card, Discover Card/Novus, MasterCard, MasterCard Debit card without personal identification number PIN, VISA Card, and Visa Debit Card without personal identification number PIN for payment of driver civil penalties.
The contact information for the Insurance Services Bureau at NYS DMV is 6 Empire State Plaza, Room 332B, Albany, NY 12228.
A picture or professional plate is a vehicle plate that has the words "New York" contained in a blue banner, and a picture or logo next to the plate number.
Some personalized picture plates are available for an additional fee.
You can browse the available styles of picture and professional plates online.

The categories for picture and professional plates are: I Love NY Adventure Plates, Sports, Military and Veterans, Counties and Regions of NYS, Colleges, Fraternities, Sororities, Causes, Professions, Organizations, Motorcycle Plates.
The picture and professional plates have a variety of prices.
You can browse the available styles using the categories above to find detailed pricing information on the plate you are interested in.
Custom plates reserved for professional groups and emergency services organizations serve to identify the registrant as a member of that group.
The custom plates come with no special rights or privileges.

To exchange custom plates for standard series plates, complete a Vehicle Registration/Title Application (MV-82 form), bring the form, the plates and your NY State Driver License to a DMV office, pay a one-time plate exchange fee of $28.75, and surrender your plates.
The DMV will then issue your vehicle a set of standard series plates.
If you remove a vehicle from the road, you can store your picture or professional plates at most DMV offices.
Find a DMV office to store your picture or professional plates.
You will receive a receipt form (FS-6T) when you surrender your plates.
Verify the information listed on the receipt form (FS-6T), make sure that the receipt displays the words "Stored at Local Office", and keep this receipt.
The DMV will indicate on the registration record that the vehicle plates have been stored.
To register the vehicle again, or to use your stored picture or professional plates to register another vehicle, you must visit the office that has your vehicle plates.
Bring the receipt form (FS-6T) and the other documents required to register your vehicle when visiting the office to register the vehicle again or use the stored plates.
A detailed information packet about the custom plate picture plate development program, including the Request for the Development of Custom Plates (MV-415 form), is available.
Professional plates do not entitle you to any special parking privileges unless the city, town or village where you park your vehicle has granted such privileges.
