You can exchange a New York State driver license or learner permit that is current or that expired within the last 2 years for a New York State non-driver ID card (NDID).
You must apply by mail or in a DMV office to exchange a New York State driver license or learner permit for a New York State non-driver ID card (NDID).
You don't have to get an Enhanced or REAL ID document.
If you have a Standard document, you will not be allowed to board a domestic flight starting in October 2020 unless you have a Passport.
If you plan on traveling, it is recommended that you come to DMV now and avoid a second office visit to get an Enhanced or REAL ID document.
You can learn more about Enhanced, REAL ID and Standard documents from a provided link.
You can complete a guide to make sure you have the proofs of identification you need before you come to DMV.
You can select the "Replace, Renew, or Change my existing NY State License / ID to REAL ID or Enhanced" option to find your proofs.
If you have a Standard document, it will not be accepted as proof of identification to board a domestic flight after October 1, 2020 unless you have a Passport.
It is recommended that you come to the DMV to upgrade to an Enhanced or REAL ID document.

To exchange by mail, you need to send a completed Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card (MV-44 form), your driver license or learner permit (if current or expired for less than two years), a photocopy of your proof of Supplemental Security Income (if required), and the payment indicated in the provided chart.
The mailing address for exchanging by mail is DMV License Production Bureau, P.O. Box 2688 ESP, Albany, NY 12220-0668.
The express mail service address for exchanging by mail is DMV License Production Bureau, Room 424A, 6 Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228.
You can learn more about Standard, REAL ID and Enhanced documents from a provided link.
To prove you receive Supplemental Security Income (SSI), you must bring one of the listed original documents to the DMV, not a photocopy.

The listed documents to prove SSI include: Notice of Award notifying you that you are eligible for SSI benefits, Cost of Living Adjustment (COLA) letter, Notice of change in payment (SSA-L8151), Third Party Query (TPQY) letter, Report of Confidential Social Security Information (SSA-2258), or Benefit Verification letter (which you must call the Social Security Administration in advance to obtain).

If you want to exchange in an office and keep your Standard document type, you need to complete an Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card (MV-44 form), come to an office, and bring your current license, your application, and payment.
You can plead 'Guilty' and pay tickets answerable to TVB.
You can plead 'Not Guilty' and schedule a TVB hearing online, over the phone or in a TVB office.
You can pay tickets with a guilty decision.
You can change an earlier 'Not Guilty' plea to a 'Guilty' for tickets that do not require your appearance.
You can re-schedule a 'Not Guilty' hearing one time.
You can request to be notified by email when your traffic ticket has been entered into the system.
You can request TVB to schedule or re-schedule your tickets if no dates are available.
The Traffic Violations Bureau does not handle parking violations, red light camera tickets, criminal driving violations (for example, DWI) or tickets answerable in a local court.

To plead or pay your ticket, you will need your TVB traffic ticket number and either DMV ID Number, Client ID Number from your New York State license, permit, or non-driver ID, full name, date of birth as they appear on the traffic ticket, and gender if your license is from another state.
You can plead or pay your ticket now or schedule your hearing online.
For online plea or payment, your traffic ticket must display the words 'Traffic Violations Bureau' at the bottom and be an 'open' (unresolved) ticket.
If your address has changed and you plead Not Guilty to one or more traffic tickets, you must provide your new address so the DMV can send you a Notice of Hearing in the mail.
Providing a new address for a Not Guilty plea will not update your other DMV records.
If your name has changed and you plead Not Guilty to one or more traffic tickets, the DMV will send you a Notice of Hearing with your previous name.

To plead by mail, enter your plea on the ticket and include the appropriate fee payable to 'Commissioner of Motor Vehicles' if you are pleading guilty, and mail it to Traffic Violations Plea Unit, P.O. Box 2950 - ESP, Albany, NY 12220-0950.
You can plead to or pay a TVB ticket, and schedule a hearing at a Traffic Violations Bureau (TVB) office.
You cannot plead to or pay a TVB ticket, or schedule a hearing at a regular DMV Issuing Office.

If you have 3 or more alcohol-related convictions on your entire driving record, a plea of guilty to a violation that results in 5 or more points may result in the revocation of your license under Part 132 of the Commissioner's Regulations.
You may want to consult with an attorney before you enter your plea if you have 3 or more alcohol-related convictions on your entire driving record and the violation results in 5 or more points.
You may plead to or pay TVB bicycle/in-line skate tickets in the same way as with any other TVB tickets online, by phone, by mail or at a TVB office.
Convictions for bicycle/in-line skate offenses do not require the payment of a surcharge and do not result in points being applied to your driving record.

If you are an attorney admitted to the Bar in New York State who wants to process Not Guilty pleas and schedule hearings online for motorists who are your clients, you must submit a TVB Ticket Management for Attorneys - Application for Web Access PDF (AA-15) to the Traffic Violations Division-Attorney Scheduling.
If you plead Guilty, you must pay all fines, fees, and surcharges that result from the plea.
You cannot plead Guilty online if the conviction will result in the suspension or revocation of your driving privilege. You must appear at a TVB office in that case.

You cannot plead Not Guilty online if your driving privilege is suspended for failure to answer the ticket. If you have received a notice of pending suspension for failure to answer this ticket, you must go into a TVB office or schedule over the phone.
Your hearing must be held in the jurisdiction where the ticket was issued.
The transaction sets the earliest available date for your hearing.
You can change the date of your hearing only once, but not within 24 hours of your hearing.
If you fail to appear for your hearing, you may be convicted by default, you may need to pay additional fines, and your driving privilege will be suspended.
If you previously pleaded Not Guilty to the traffic ticket, you can change your plea to Guilty. However, in order to plead Guilty, you must pay all the fines, fees, and surcharges.
Partial payments are not accepted when changing a plea from Not Guilty to Guilty.
To avoid additional fees, you must complete the transaction of changing your plea from Not Guilty to Guilty before the date of the hearing.
After you select a Not Guilty hearing date and time, you can return to the transaction one time to select a different date and time if available.

To check for other available hearing dates and times after selecting a Not Guilty hearing date and time, enter the ticket number and other required information in Step 1, verify the information in Step 2, in Step 3 look for the ticket under 'Earlier Pleas of Not Guilty', select 'Check for Other Available Hearing Dates', and then select 'Continue' to display other available hearing dates.

If there is no button for 'Check for Other Available Hearing Dates', the hearing for the ticket was previously re-scheduled, and you cannot re-schedule again online. You must contact the TVB to re-schedule your hearing.
To enter a plea, your traffic ticket must already be in the system.
If your traffic ticket is not currently in the system, you can request to be notified by email when your record is updated.
If you do not receive a notification about your traffic ticket being in the system, you are still responsible to contact TVB and enter a plea for your ticket.
You should verify your computer privacy settings and check your spam folder for an email notification about your traffic ticket being in the system.
If you do not have the ticket number, enter all of the other information to determine if the system can locate the ticket record.
Out of state motorists must have a ticket number to plead or pay online.
I-PIRP/ADM is an acronym for the Internet Point & Insurance Reduction Program / Alternate Delivery Method.
The I-PIRP/ADM Program permits approved sponsors to provide Defensive Driving / Accident Prevention courses via the Internet or other alternate delivery methods, such as DVD or digital cable.
To receive point and insurance reduction in New York State, a course must be approved by the NY State DMV.
The NY State DMV maintains a list of approved sponsors for I-PIRP courses.
When a person completes an I-PIRP course, the person receives the same benefits as when the person completes a classroom PIRP course.
The benefits of completing an I-PIRP course include reducing the driver violation point total by a maximum of four points and saving ten percent on auto liability and collision insurance premiums.
An I-PIRP course requires a minimum of 320 minutes of instruction time.
The instruction time for an I-PIRP course does not include the time required to register, validate identity and participation, or to download and take any tests.
The I-PIRP course site has controls to ensure the person meets all the requirements and has at least 320 minutes of instruction.
The classroom PIRP course and the I-PIRP course have very similar content and information.
Both the classroom PIRP course and the I-PIRP course include 320 minutes of instruction.
The classroom PIRP course is given in one daytime session or two evening sessions.
A person can take the I-PIRP course from home, at a convenient time for the person.
A person must complete the I-PIRP course within 30 days of the date the person registers for the course.
A person can take the I-PIRP course at the person's own speed within the 30-day period.
A person can complete an I-PIRP course in as many sessions as necessary, but the person must complete the course within 30 calendar days of registration.
The data for an I-PIRP course will be stored online for each course session.
Most I-PIRP course sponsors assign a user ID and a password when a person registers for the course.
A person can use the user ID and password to log in on any computer that can access the Internet with an acceptable connection.
An I-PIRP course can have online quizzes, random tests and/or a final exam to verify participation and determine if the person understands the course content.
Some I-PIRP course sponsors may require a person to take a final exam in person.
The test requirements for an I-PIRP course will be explained before a person registers for the course, normally in the course Terms and Conditions section.
In addition to knowledge tests about course content, an I-PIRP course will have questions to help verify a person's identity and participation in the course.
The test and exam process and the effect of results can vary from one I-PIRP course sponsor to another.
A person should carefully read the information about tests before registering for an I-PIRP course.
An I-PIRP course normally requires a person to answer 70% of course content questions correctly.
In an I-PIRP course, a person normally will have two tries to get the correct answer to a question.
The tests in an I-PIRP course are timed, and a person will have limited time during a test to look for an answer that the person does not know.
It is recommended that a person review the section content before beginning the tests in an I-PIRP course.

If a person does not meet all the requirements to complete an I-PIRP course or meet the minimum test score requirements, the person cannot receive credit for course completion and cannot receive point and insurance reduction for the course.
An I-PIRP course sponsor can offer for a person to take the same course again at no additional costs, but the sponsor is not required to offer this.
The cost of an I-PIRP course is set by the course sponsor and the fee varies from one course to another course.
The cost of an I-PIRP course is stated clearly before a person registers for the course.
It is to a person's advantage to compare I-PIRP courses and their fees.
An I-PIRP course sponsor will normally require a person to pay with a credit card, but this is determined by each sponsor.
A person should check with the I-PIRP course sponsor for complete information about payment.
If an I-PIRP course sponsor cannot conduct the course or any part of the course, the sponsor must give a person the option to receive a full refund of all course fees.
An I-PIRP course sponsor can also offer a person the option to reschedule the course, if and when the course is available.
The type of equipment and technology a person needs to take an I-PIRP course depends on the alternate delivery method (ADM) of the course.
For an Internet I-PIRP course, a person must have a computer and an acceptable connection to the Internet.
For a DVD ADM I-PIRP course, a person must have a television and a DVD player.
An I-PIRP course sponsor must provide any additional technology required to deliver the course.
An I-PIRP course sponsor must inform a person of the equipment and technology requirements when the person registers for the course.
An I-PIRP course sponsor mails the course completion certificate to a person by regular mail.
An email copy of an I-PIRP course completion certificate is not valid and will not be accepted by an insurance company.
An I-PIRP course sponsor must issue the course completion certificates within 14 business days of course completion.
Some I-PIRP course sponsors offer express mail delivery options for course completion certificates at an additional fee.
The DMV does not send an I-PIRP course completion certificate directly to a person's automobile insurance company.
A person must contact the insurance company and supply the I-PIRP course completion certificate to receive insurance reduction benefits.
The DMV requires that I-PIRP course sponsors and their delivery agents provide secure websites that protect the personal information of those who take the courses.
I-PIRP course sponsors collect personal information to verify a person's identity and participation.

The personal information collected by I-PIRP course sponsors can include identity information like the DMV ID Number (Client ID Number) from a person's NY State driver license, the person's name and date of birth.
A person should use their name exactly as it appears on their New York State Driver License when providing it to an I-PIRP course sponsor, and not use nicknames.
I-PIRP course sponsors also collect credit card information for the course fee.
The identification and participation information collected by I-PIRP course sponsors can also include biometrics like keystrokes, facial recognition or voice recognition.
A person should read the privacy and security information at the website of an I-PIRP course sponsor.
I-PIRP course sponsors are required to store a person's personal information on a secure server for a time period specified by the DMV.
The DMV verifies the security of the servers that host I-PIRP courses.
Each I-PIRP course sponsor has different methods to validate that the person who registered for the course is the same person who takes the course.

Any person who attempts to defraud the I-PIRP system or who accepts an I-PIRP course completion certificate and its associated benefits without having personally completed the entire course has committed a crime and may be subject to prosecution, fines and imprisonment.
If a person does not have a New York State DMV ID Number (Client ID Number) from their NY State driver license, the ADM course completion cannot be applied to the person's license record.

A person may have to file Request for Driver and/or Vehicle Record Information form (MV-15) before attempting to take an I-PIRP ADM course if the person does not have a New York State DMV ID Number (Client ID Number) from their NY State driver license.
The seller must complete and sign the transfer ownership section of the title certificate.
The seller must sign a bill of sale even if it is a gift.
The seller must provide other acceptable proofs of ownership and transfer of ownership.
The buyer must sign the bill of sale even if it is a gift.
The buyer must pay sales tax or have proof of an exemption.
The buyer must register and title the vehicle or trailer or snowmobile, boat, moped or ATV or transfer a registration from another vehicle they own to their new vehicle.
The proofs of ownership needed to register and title a vehicle in New York are different for different types of vehicles for example, cars, trailers, boats, snowmobiles, manufactured homes.
There are acceptable proofs of ownership.
The buyer can get proof of ownership at purchase.
There is a process for a deceased owner.
The buyer can get proof of ownership at purchase.
There is a process if proof of ownership is not available.
The buyer can register and title a vehicle or trailer.
The buyer can register a snowmobile, boat or ATV.
The buyer can transfer a registration to another vehicle they own.
If the buyer does not have the title, the buyer must register the vehicle at a DMV office and cannot do this over the phone, online, or by mail.
The buyer cannot change the name on the vehicle registration or the title certificate to the name of another person.
The buyer must transfer the ownership of the vehicle.
The buyer can check the National Insurance Crime Bureau database to see if a vehicle is flood damaged.
The buyer will need the Vehicle Identification Number VIN to check if a vehicle is flood damaged.
There are DMV brochures called 'Let the Buyer Be Aware' and 'Q&A About Your Title Certificate'.
You must renew your license before it expires or you could face fines.
You can renew up to 1 year before your license expires and 2 years after there are no exceptions.
Once your license is renewed, your license expiration date will be extended for 8 years.
If you plan on traveling, the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles recommends you renew in a DMV now to get an Enhanced or REAL ID, and avoid a second office visit later.
There are Enhanced, REAL ID and Standard documents.
You don't have to get an Enhanced or REAL ID.
However, if you have a Standard document, you will not be allowed to board a domestic flight starting in October 2020 unless you have a Passport.
You can make a reservation at some DMV locations after completing the guide to make sure you have the proofs of identification and paperwork you need before you come to DMV.
You do not need a reservation to visit the DMV.
You can take a vision test at the DMV, for no additional charge.
You will receive a temporary license to use until your new license arrives by mail within 10 business days.
If you renew your Standard online, your new license will show 'NOT FOR FEDERAL PURPOSES'.
You must renew at a DMV office if you have a commercial driver license (CDL) or want to update your photo.
If you already have an Enhanced or REAL ID, or you want to keep your Standard document, you can renew online.
To renew online, you must pass an eye test by an approved provider, like a pharmacy, or have a professional complete a paper report.
You will keep the same document type you currently have (Standard, REAL ID or Enhanced) when you renew online.
You can download and print a temporary license in PDF format to use until your new license arrives in the mail within 10 business days when you renew online.
If you renew your Standard by mail, your new license will show 'NOT FOR FEDERAL PURPOSES'.
If you already have an Enhanced or REAL ID, or you want to keep your Standard document, you can renew by mail.

To renew by mail, you must complete the renewal notice mailed to you and return it with a completed Vision Test Report PDF (MV-619) or get tested by an approved vision registry provider, a check or money order payable to Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, and if you did not receive a renewal notice, you can use an Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card PDF (MV-44).
The mail address to renew by mail is: NYS Department of Motor Vehicles, 207 Genesee Street, Suite 6, Utica, NY 13501-2874.
Your renewal fee is on the renewal application mailed to you and displayed before you pay online.
The fees for different types of licenses, including the photo document fee and the supplemental Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee if required, are listed in a chart.
The additional fee for an enhanced driver license (EDL) is $30.00, added to the renewal fees for the driver license.
There is no additional fee for a REAL ID, just the normal renewal fee will be charged.
If you have any other class combined with Class M or MJ (e.g., DM), add an additional $8.00 to the fee.
If you apply by mail or at a DMV office, you can pay by credit/debit card or a check or money order made out to Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
To apply online, you must use a credit/debit card.

The DMV accepts American Express Card, Discover Card/Novus, MasterCard, MasterCard Debit card without personal identification number (PIN), VISA Card, and Visa Debit Card without personal identification number (PIN).

If you are a qualified U.S. military veteran who was honorably discharged, and you have a NY State driver license, learner permit or non-driver photo ID card, you can have the word 'Veteran' printed on the upper left hand of your photo document.
There is no additional fee for the veteran status designation on your document, but all regular transaction fees will apply.
If you are active in the military, please see the military resources for more information on renewing, and thank you for your service!
Your new license will come in about 10 business days.
You can check the mailing status of your new license online.
If it has been more than 2 weeks since you renewed, you can contact the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles.
Your address must match the one on the records of the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles.
You can first change your address online and then renew.
There is no guarantee that the US Postal Service will forward your DMV documents to your new address.
If you renew more than 40 days before your 21st birthday, your license will have 'UNDER 21'.
When out of NY State, it is recommended that you renew your NY driver license through the mail.

To renew by mail when out of state or country, you must send the renewal notice mailed to you (MV-2) or if you don't have it, use the Application for Permit, Driver License, or Non-driver ID PDF (MV-44), a Vision Test Report PDF (MV-619) completed by an eye care professional, a check or money order payable to Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, and a pre-addressed priority mail return envelope with your application.
As long as the Temporary Visitor status that DMV has on file is not expired, you can renew your license online, through the mail or in an office.
If your Temporary Visitor status has been extended, you must go to a DMV office with your updated paperwork from the United States Department of Homeland Security (DHS).
The DMV will update their records to show that your Temporary Visitor status has been extended so you can renew your license.
Your new license will have your new temporary visitor expiration date.
You cannot change the license class when you renew online.
You can make license class changes when you renew by mail or at a DMV office.
You cannot make any other class changes when you renew.
Other changes require a written test and a road test.
If you renew by mail, you must include a note about your class change in your renewal envelope.
At a DMV office, you must tell the DMV representative about the class change.
You will need to pay the renewal fee for your new driver license class.
If you drive with an expired license and get a traffic ticket, you will receive fines and penalties.
If your license is expired for 60 days or less, the fine is $25 to $40 plus state and local surcharges.
If your license is expired for more than 60 days, the fine is $75 to $300 plus state and local surcharges.
Renewal anytime within this period will not affect the expiration date of your new driver license or the fees.
If your license is expired for 2 years or more, you must apply for an original license, pass the vision test and the written test, complete a pre-licensing course and pass a Road Test.
Starting in October 2020, you will need an Enhanced or REAL ID to board a domestic flight unless you have a Passport.
If your license was issued before October 30, 2017 and is not Enhanced, you have a Standard document.
Newly issued Standard documents show 'NOT FOR FEDERAL PURPOSES'.

If you want to renew in an office and keep your Standard document type, you must complete the renewal notice (MV-2) mailed to you or if you did not receive a renewal notice, use an Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card (MV-44), come to an office, bring your current Standard license, your renewal notice or application, and payment.
Newly issued Standard licenses show 'NOT FOR FEDERAL PURPOSES'.

You can have a Vision Test Report PDF (MV-619) completed by a medical professional (physician, physician's assistant, ophthalmologist, optometrist, optician, registered nurse, nurse professional), and then enter the report information on the online transaction.
You do not need to mail or bring the Vision Test Report if you renew online.
At the start of your online renewal transaction, you will be asked if you would like to register to vote or change your party designation.
You are not required to register to vote, but you will be required to answer the question to proceed with your transaction.
If you answer yes, you will complete your voter registration application as part of your renewal transaction.

Residents of the following counties must pay a supplemental Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee: Bronx, Kings (Brooklyn), New York (Manhattan), Queens, Richmond (Staten Island), Dutchess, Nassau, Orange, Putnam, Rockland, Suffolk and Westchester.
The MCTD fee is $1.00 for every 6 months the permit or driver license will be in effect.
For an 8-year driver license, the MCTD fee is $16.

If you have a Class A, B or C with an endorsement of H or X, you must pass the hazardous materials knowledge test at a DMV office within 2 years before your renewal and pay an additional fee of $5 for the test.

If your renewal is processed less than 40 days before your birthday, the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles will mail you a driver license without the words 'UNDER 21' on or near the date of your birthday.
You can renew online if you are away and have a valid NY driver license and have had an eye exam from the last 12 months saved to the DMV Vision Registry.
However, your license will not be forwarded to you out of state or out of the country.

If you are a qualified U.S. military veteran who was honorably discharged, and you have a NY State driver license, learner permit or non-driver photo ID card, you can have the word "Veteran" printed on the upper left hand of your photo document.
There is no additional fee for the veteran status designation on your document, but all regular transaction fees will apply.
After you receive the veteran designation, it will automatically be on all of your future DMV documents when you replace or renew.
To apply, you must provide proof of an honorable discharge.

Acceptable proofs are: a U.S. Department of Defense Form DD-214 that indicates an honorable discharge, a form DD-215 if discharged before January 1, 1950, an Honorable Discharge form WD AGO 53, WD AGO 55, WD AGO 53-55, NAVPERS 553, NAVMC 78PD or NAVCG 553, or an "Enlisted Separation Paper", a Certification of Military Service NA FORM 13038 that indicates a discharge that is either "honorable" or "under honorable conditions".
If your license or permit was issued before October 30, 2017 and is not Enhanced, you have a Standard document.
A Standard document is required for boarding a domestic U.S. flight, and entering a Federal Building or Military Base starting October, 2020.
A Standard document is required for U.S. Border Crossing from Canada, Mexico and some Caribbean countries.
If you have a Standard license and want to change to a REAL ID or Enhanced while adding your veteran status, you must come into a DMV office.
To change to a REAL ID or Enhanced while adding your veteran status, you must complete a guide to make sure you have the proofs of identification you need.
To change to a REAL ID or Enhanced while adding your veteran status, you will also need to bring your proof of honorable discharge original or photocopies.

To apply by mail, you must send a completed Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card pdf MV-44, your proof of honorable discharge send photocopies, your original documents to DMV License Production Bureau Room 331, 6 Empire State Plaza Albany, NY 12228.
You cannot apply by phone or online.
If you applied to have the Veteran Indicator added to your license, permit or non-driver ID and were charged a document fee, you are entitled to a refund for the fee.
A law has been enacted that permits New York State to refund a fee paid by a veteran in order to place a veteran indicator on their DMV document.
Each eligible customer will get a letter and refund check from New York State.
A Driving School License is required of any person, firm, association or corporation engaged in the business of giving instruction in the operation of motor vehicles or motorcycles for hire.
The process of opening a driving school involves several steps.
These steps are also outlined in the form Opening a Driving School MV-299.2.
To open a driving school, you will need to meet DMV's requirements below for your place of business.
To open a driving school, you will need to meet DMV's requirements below for a qualified, experienced instructor.
To open a driving school, you will need to meet DMV's requirements below for records, receipts, etc.
To open a driving school, you will need to meet DMV's requirements below for record-keeping.
To open a driving school, you will need to have authority to operate a business in New York State and this location.
You must receive approval from DMV for the use of the name for your driving school.
The form Request for Approval of Driving School Name MV-299.3 is used to request approval of the driving school name from DMV.
Your place of business must be at least 50 square feet, which is accessible by your customers.
Your place of business must be in a suitable building as per Part 76.2 of the regulations.
Your place of business must be at least 1,500 feet from a DMV office or road test area.
The applicant must be given a receipt for all payments.
The applicant must provide a schedule of fees.
If your school will teach the Pre-licensing course, you must also have a classroom that meets DMV's requirements.
You must have an experienced instructor who holds a valid instructor's card, and has at least 1,000 hours of experience as a behind-the-wheel instructor.
You must keep appropriate records.
You must have a vehicle used for training and testing students that meets DMV's requirements.
All vehicles except motorcycles must have Student Driver signs and be equipped with dual-control brakes and mirrors for the instructors' use.

After you receive approval of your business name from DMV, you must submit the following items to DMV: your Request for Approval of Driving School Name form MV-299.3 that shows your Driving School name was approved by the DMV, a completed Driving School License Application form MV-521, the application fee of $50.00 non-refundable, a completed Personal History form MV-521.1 for each owner, partner, corporate officer, agent, employee and major stockholder, proof of current Workers Compensation and Disability Benefits Insurance Coverage if you have employees, a completed CE-200 form if you do not have employees, a X-201, a X-74 or DOS-1025 form, a copy of the lease for your proposed place of business, a Certificate of Occupancy for your proposed place of business, a copy of the receipt provided to clients as required by Section 76.8 of the Commissioner's Regulations, a copy of the Student Record Card as required by Section 76.8 of the Commissioner's Regulations, a schedule of fees for all services your driving school will provide, a list of all vehicles to be used in training and testing, an Application for Driving School Instructor Certificate MV-523 for each instructor.
All required items must be sent to the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles Bureau of Driver Training Programs at 6 Empire State Plaza, Room 327, Albany, NY 12228.
After your application is reviewed by DMV in Albany, it is sent to your local Motor Vehicle office.
Your local Motor Vehicle office will schedule an inspection.

When the inspector visits your location, be prepared to show the original lease, the original business certificate and/or corporate papers and/or filing receipt, a sample customer receipt and student record card, signs and advertising as per Commissioner Regulations Part 76.21, a permanent, bound book or record-keeping system, a filing cabinet.
If your school intends to offer the Pre-Licensing Course, you will also need to have the classroom inspected.
The classroom requirements are listed on the Request for Premise Check form MV-279.

The classroom requirements include: if the classroom facilities are combined with office space, the combined total must be at least 200 square feet, the classroom must be clean, comfortable, and easily accessible to students with disabilities, adequate seating for each student, adequate heating, ventilation, and lighting, rest room facilities easily accessible to all students, appropriate chalkboard, flipcharts, and audio/visual equipment.
After your business location is inspected and approved, you will be notified that you need to pay the driving school license fee of $50.
Your new license will be valid for one year.
Once the driving school license fee is received, your Driving School License will be mailed to you, which must be posted in plain sight in your place of business.
A Driving School Instructor Certificate will also be mailed for each of your instructors.
To remove a suspension related to an unsatisfied judgment, you must resolve the judgment.
If you were notified that there is an unsatisfied judgment suspension on your record, you must contact the attorney or court that issued the judgment.
The information on the suspension order will advise you of the name of the court and the court index number for the judgment.
The DMV cannot clear the suspension without proof from the court.
Once you receive the original documentation from the court or attorney, you must send the original documents to DMV for clearance.
If you do not know which court to contact, you can call the NY State DMV Insurance Services Bureau.

To get an unsatisfied judgment against a motorist as a result of a motor vehicle accident, collision or crash, you must file a Supporting Affirmation PDF SR-60 and the other documents listed on the affirmation SR-60.

The DMV will suspend the license and registrations if the person fails to pay or satisfy a judgment of more than $1,000 and the judgment is related to a motor vehicle accident, collision or crash which causes property damage, bodily injury or death.
The DMV will also suspend all vehicle registrations of the company the privilege to register another vehicle.
Conviction of a serious traffic violation or multiple traffic violations can result in the suspension or revocation of your driver license or privilege to drive in New York State.
It is illegal to drive in New York State when your driver license or driving privilege is suspended or revoked.
If your license or driving privilege is suspended or revoked, the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) will send a notice called an order to the address they have on file.
A suspension means your license or driving privilege will be taken away for a period of time.
You may need to pay a suspension termination fee to the New York State DMV.
Your suspension period can be definite which has a beginning and end date or indefinite, which does not end until you take a required action.
If you receive a definite suspension notice from the New York State DMV, it will tell you how long the suspension period will last.
You cannot drive until the definite suspension period ends, you pay a termination fee, and have a valid driver license again.
You can use the New York State DMV's My License, Permit or ID service to check if your license is valid.

Common reasons for definite suspensions by the New York State DMV are: you did not have automobile liability insurance, you were convicted of an alcohol or drugged driving charge, you received too many traffic tickets in a certain amount of time, you did not follow the rules for junior drivers.
If you receive an indefinite suspension notice from the New York State DMV, it will tell you what you must do to remove the suspension.

Common reasons for indefinite suspensions by the New York State DMV are: you did not answer a traffic ticket, you did not pay for a traffic ticket fine, you did not file a motor vehicle accident report, you failed to pay child support, you have unpaid New York State tax debts, you did not have automobile liability insurance.
Your license or driving privilege may be suspended by the New York State DMV due to a medical condition that affects your ability to drive safely.

If you receive an order from the New York State DMV saying your license or driving privilege is revoked, this means your license has been cancelled and you must get a new one when the revocation period ends.
In most cases, before you can get a new license from the New York State DMV after a revocation, you must first request approval from the DMV when the revocation period is over.
You may be required to take the written and driving tests again and pay a license re-application fee to the New York State DMV after a revocation.
Your application for a new license may be denied by the New York State DMV if you have a high risk driving record or fail to meet DMV requirements after a revocation.
You may also need to pay a driver civil penalty to the New York State DMV before your license or driving privilege can be restored after a revocation.

Common reasons for revocations by the New York State DMV are: you operated or permitted operation of a vehicle without insurance, you were involved in an uninsured motor vehicle accident, you were convicted of an alcohol or drugged driving charge, you were convicted of a serious traffic offense or multiple offenses, you failed a DMV road test, you made a false statement on an application for a license or registration, you were a driver in a motor vehicle crash that involved a fatality.
You can sign up for MyDMV and use the New York State DMV's My License, Permit or ID service to check if your license is suspended or revoked.
A driving privilege is your legal authority to drive in a state other than the state that issued your driver license.

If you have a driver license issued in another state, the New York State DMV can revoke your privilege to drive in New York State, but your out-of-state license may still be valid to drive in other states.
If you were suspended by the New York State DMV for an insurance lapse, you can submit proof of insurance online.
If the vehicle is not insured and the registration is still valid after an insurance lapse suspension by the New York State DMV, you must surrender your registration and plates to the DMV.
If you are required to pay the suspension termination fee to the New York State DMV, you can pay online.
If you were suspended by the New York State DMV for an alcohol or drug related violation, you can find more information on the DMV's website.
If you were suspended by the New York State DMV for receiving too many points under the New York State Driver Point System, you can find more information on the DMV's website.
If you were suspended by the New York State DMV for violating the Graduated License Law as a junior driver, you can find more information on the DMV's website.

If you were suspended by the New York State DMV because you did not answer a traffic ticket issued in New York City, the ticket will say 'Traffic Violations Bureau', and you can plead or pay for the ticket online.
If you were suspended by the New York State DMV because you did not answer a traffic ticket issued in any other part of New York State, you must contact the local court directly.
The New York State DMV's My License, Permit or ID service can give you additional information about where to respond to a traffic ticket.

If you were suspended by the New York State DMV because you did not pay a fine for a traffic ticket issued in New York City, the ticket will say 'Traffic Violations Bureau', and you can pay the fine online.
If you were suspended by the New York State DMV because you did not pay a fine for a traffic ticket issued in any other part of New York State, you must contact the local court directly.
The New York State DMV's My License service can give you additional information about where to pay for a traffic ticket.

To remove a suspension by the New York State DMV for the failure to pay child support, you must contact the local child support enforcement agency or the New York State Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance (OTDA).
The OTDA website has a list of local child support enforcement agencies for removing suspensions by the New York State DMV related to child support.
To clear suspensions by the New York State DMV related to unpaid New York State tax debts, you must contact the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance.
You must surrender the vehicle registration to the DMV.

If two vehicle plates are lost, stolen or destroyed (or one plate if the vehicle was issued only one plate, e.g. motorcycles), you need to notify the police, and ask the police to complete a police report.
You need to bring the police report to a DMV office to surrender the vehicle registration.
If the plates were lost, stolen or destroyed in New York State, you need to ask a NY State police agency to complete a 'Certification of Lost License, Permit or Plates' MV-78B.
The 'Certification of Lost License, Permit or Plates' MV-78B form is only available from law enforcement.
The 'Certification of Lost License, Permit or Plates' MV-78B form is on the DMV website.
If the plates were lost, stolen or destroyed outside of NY State, you need to get a report printed on the letterhead of a police agency in the state where the incident happened.
If you cannot get a police report, you need to write a statement that includes your plate number and explains why you cannot surrender your NY State plates.
If one plate from a set of two plates is lost, stolen or destroyed, you don't need to complete a police report.
If one plate from a set of two plates is lost, stolen or destroyed, you need to bring the plate you have to a DMV office to surrender the registration.
If you would like to replace your plates without paying a fee, you must submit a police report or an MV-78B indicating the plate was stolen or destroyed as a result of a crime.
To get new plates, you may request a new set of plates at a DMV office.
To get new plates, you need to bring the original plate or the MV-78B / police report / statement.
To get new plates, you need to bring a completed Vehicle Registration / Title Application PDF MV-82.
To get new plates, you need to bring proof of insurance.
To get new plates, you need to bring proof of your identity.
To get new plates, you need to print the checklist.
The DMV will issue you a new registration and replacement plates.
If the plate were lost or destroyed, you will need to pay for the new plates, and a fee of $3.75 to issue a new registration.
The fee for plates is $25 for a set of 2 plates.
The fee for plates is $12.50 for a vehicle that is only issued one plate (e.g. motorcycles).
You don't need to pay a fee to replace stolen plates.
To replace stolen plates, you will need to provide a police report or an MV-78B indicating that the plates were stolen or destroyed as a result of a crime.

If your vehicle was stolen, your insurance company will give you 2 barcoded original NY State Insurance ID cards (see a sample) or provide you with access to your digital electronic NY State Insurance ID Card.
If your vehicle was stolen, your insurance company will send an electronic notice of insurance coverage to the DMV (your insurance agent or broker cannot file this notice).
Your NY State Insurance ID cards and the electronic notice together verify your coverage.
The DMV needs both your NY State Insurance ID cards and the electronic notice.
You must register your vehicle within 180 days of the effective date on your Insurance ID Card.
You need to bring one copy or form of your Insurance ID Card with you.
The DMV office will keep the paper card.
You need to keep the other paper card with the vehicle as your proof of insurance.
Anyone operating your vehicle must be able to provide proof of insurance.
You can learn more about NY State Insurance Requirements.
Your proof of identity can be your NY State Driver License, Permit, or Non-Driver ID Card.
For other acceptable proofs of identity, see Proofs of Identity for Registration and Title pdf ID-82.
You can get a vehicle registration or title record (abstract).
Vehicle registration and title record abstracts are records issued by the New York DMV.
To get your vehicle registration record abstract, you can order it using form Request for DMV Records PDF MV-15.
To order your vehicle registration record abstract using form Request for DMV Records PDF MV-15, you must include your plate number or Vehicle Identification Number (VIN).

If you do not know your plate number or VIN when ordering your vehicle registration record abstract using form Request for DMV Records PDF MV-15, you must provide your name and date of birth (DOB), as well as the vehicle make and year.

To order your vehicle registration record abstract using form Request for DMV Records PDF MV-15, you must include a photocopy of your driver license or other government issued photo ID card as proof of identity.

To order your vehicle registration record abstract using form Request for DMV Records PDF MV-15, you must include a personal check or money order payable to "Commissioner of Motor Vehicles" to pay the search fee of $10.00.
You must mail your request for your vehicle registration record abstract using form Request for DMV Records PDF MV-15 to the address listed on the form.
To get your vehicle title record abstract, you can order it using form Request for DMV Records PDF MV-15.
To order your vehicle title record abstract using form Request for DMV Records PDF MV-15, you must include the Vehicle Identification Number (VIN).

If you do not know the VIN when ordering your vehicle title record abstract using form Request for DMV Records PDF MV-15, the New York DMV may be able to locate the record using their registration files by providing the name and date of birth (DOB) of the registrant, as well as the year and make for the vehicle.

To order your vehicle title record abstract using form Request for DMV Records PDF MV-15, you must include a photocopy of your driver license or other government issued photo ID card as proof of identity.

To order your vehicle title record abstract using form Request for DMV Records PDF MV-15, you must include a personal check or money order payable to "Commissioner of Motor Vehicles" to pay the search fee of $10.00.
You must mail your request for your vehicle title record abstract using form Request for DMV Records PDF MV-15 to the address listed on the form.

To get another person's records from the New York DMV, you must submit a Request for DMV Records PDF MV-15 and certify that you have a permissible use under the Driver's Privacy Protection Act (DPPA) to see the personal information of another person on DMV records.
The Driver's Privacy Protection Act (DPPA) provides information about permissible uses to see the personal information of another person on DMV records.
You can order your vehicle or title record abstracts by mail using the Request for DMV Records MV-15 form.

Beginning on October 1, 2020, the federal government will require your driver license, permit or ID card to be REAL ID compliant if you wish to use it as identification to board a domestic flight within the U.S., or enter military bases and certain federal facilities.
An enhanced driver license, permit, or non-driver ID and a valid U.S. Passport are already REAL ID compliant and can be used to board a flight.
The REAL ID Act establishes minimum security standards for state-issued driver licenses, permits and ID cards.
The REAL ID Act prohibits federal agencies, like the Transportation Security Administration (TSA), from accepting cards for official purposes from states that do not meet these standards.
New York State DMV began issuing REAL ID licenses, permits, and ID cards on October 30, 2017.

To get a REAL ID, you must bring to the DMV office the following original or certified proof documents: proof of identity, proof of Social Security Number or Social Security Number ineligibility, proof of date of birth, proof of U.S. citizenship, lawful permanent residency or temporary lawful status in the U.S., and two different proofs of New York State residence.

If the name on your license, permit, or non-driver ID application does not match the name on your identity, lawful status, and social security proofs, you must bring in court or government issued proof documenting the event causing your name change such as a marriage license, divorce decree, adoption, or court order document.
The application process for a REAL ID also requires the DMV to take a new photo.
There is no additional cost to get a REAL ID, but all normal transaction fees still apply.
If you want to apply for an Enhanced Driver License or Enhanced ID Card, there is an additional $30 fee.

A REAL ID is optional and is not needed for being licensed to drive, voting or registering to vote, entering Federal facilities that do not require a person to present identification, applying for or receiving Federal benefits, accessing health or life preserving services including hospitals and health clinics, law enforcement, or constitutionally protected activities including a defendant's access to court proceedings, or participating in law enforcement proceedings or investigations.
If you decide you do not want a REAL ID or Enhanced document, any license, permit or ID card issued after October 30, 2017 will be marked 'Not for Federal Purposes'.
If you have a U.S. Passport, it can be used for identification, boarding a plane for domestic and international flights, and entry into a federal building or military base.
TSA does not currently require children under 18 years old to provide identification when traveling with a companion within the United States, but the companion will need acceptable identification.
If you want to register your vehicle in another state, you must surrender your vehicle registration and plates to the New York DMV.
If your vehicle is registered in New York State, you must have New York insurance coverage.
The New York DMV will never accept out-of-state insurance coverage of any type for a vehicle registered in New York.
If you replace your New York State insurance coverage with out-of-state insurance, your valid insurance coverage will lapse.
If you replace your New York State insurance coverage with out-of-state insurance, the New York DMV will suspend your registration.
If you replace your New York State insurance coverage with out-of-state insurance, the New York DMV may suspend your driver license.
The New York DMV will take actions against your New York State registration and driver license even if you move out of New York.
If you register your vehicle in another state, you must immediately surrender your vehicle registration and plates to the New York DMV.
You must surrender your vehicle registration and plates to the New York DMV before the New York State liability insurance is cancelled.
If you register your vehicle in another state and surrender the New York vehicle plates to the New York DMV, you can get insurance in the other state.
Your insurance must meet the requirements of the state where your vehicle is registered.

If you registered your vehicle out of state and received a letter from the New York DMV about a lapse of insurance on the vehicle, you can send a copy of your out of state registration in your name along with a copy of your out of state insurance if available to: NYS Department of Motor Vehicles Financial Security Bureau PO BOX 2725 Albany NY 12220-0725.

All proof sent to the NYS Department of Motor Vehicles Financial Security Bureau must include the name and address of the registrant, and the year, make and vehicle identification number VIN of the vehicle.
The New York DMV will apply your proof to the NY record to reduce or clear a lapse of insurance coverage reported by your insurance company.

The adventure license is a way for holders of a New York State DMV issued photo document driver license, learner permit or non-driver identification card to have any of the various lifetime sporting/recreational licenses, privileges or certifications purchased from the Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC) and/or the Office of Parks and Historical Preservation (Parks) added to the DMV issued photo document.

The following lifetime licenses/privileges/certifications can be added as icons to a New York State DMV issued photo document: Sportsman, Boating Safety, Small Game, Big Game, Fishing, Bow Hunting, Muzzle Loading, Trapping, and the Empire Passport.
Only lifetime purchased licenses, privileges or certifications can be added to the New York State DMV issued photo documents - annual licenses cannot be added.

A person can request the icons to be added to their New York State DMV issued photo document online using the New York State website or by visiting a New York State Department of Motor Vehicles office and presenting the required proof.

To show proof of a lifetime sporting/recreational license, privilege or certification at a New York State DMV office, a person must bring the original sporting license, privilege or certification document issued by the New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation or the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation and a completed Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card (MV-44 form).
For example, to add the Lifetime Sportsman License icon, a person must bring their Lifetime Sportsman license issued by the Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC).

To add the Boating Safety Certificate icon, a person must bring their Boating Safety Certificate issued by the New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation (OPRHP), the United States Coast Guard, the Power Squadron or the United States Sailing Association.
It is not required to have the icons added to a New York State DMV issued photo document, except for the Lifetime Empire Passport which must be displayed on the DMV photo document.
There are no additional fees if the icons are requested to be added at the time of photo document renewal.

If the icons are requested to be added prior to renewal, the amendment fee as required by the Vehicle and Traffic Law must be paid ($12.50 for driver licenses/permits and $5.00 for non-driver identification cards).

A person can have the icons removed from their New York State DMV issued photo document by contacting the agency (Parks or DEC) that issued the lifetime license, privilege or credential to request they notify DMV to remove the icons, or by visiting a New York State DMV office (amendment fee applies for removal at DMV office).
There are no fees associated with requests to remove icons made to the issuing agency (Parks or DEC).

Any icon except the Empire Passport icon can be removed by visiting a New York State DMV office, with the amendment fee as required by the Vehicle and Traffic Law ($12.50 for driver licenses/permits and $5.00 for non-driver identification cards).
The document number for a New York State DMV issued photo document is located on the back of the document.
For an enhanced document, the document number is the 10 alpha-numeric digits that appear after 'ID USA' in the top line of the Machine Readable Zone.
For a non-enhanced document, the document number is located above the box with the wording 'I hereby make an anatomical gift'.

If the fee is paid to request the icons be added immediately ($12.50 for driver licenses/permits and $5.00 for non-driver identification cards), it may take approximately 2 weeks to receive the new photo document with the icons in the mail.
If the option is chosen to have the icons printed at the next document renewal, the photo document with the icons will be received after renewing the photo document.

If the new photo document with the icons is not received within 2 weeks since requesting it, for Boating Safety Certificate and Empire Passport holders, contact the Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation (Parks) via their website www.parks.ny.gov.

If the new photo document with the icons is not received within 2 weeks since requesting it, for Lifetime Sportsman, Small Game, Big Game, Bow Hunting, Trapping, Muzzle Loading, or Fishing licenses/certifications, contact the Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC) via their website www.dec.ny.gov.
If you are looking to file a complaint against a dealer or transporter business, please report a problem with a DMV regulated automotive business.
The New York State Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) regulates all repair shops, inspection stations, dealers, vehicle dismantlers and other related businesses in NY State.
To legally operate as a repair shop, inspection station, dealer, vehicle dismantler or other related business, you must register with the DMV.
Once your application is approved, you will receive a certificate from the DMV.
Once your application is approved, you will receive a copy of the Commissioner's Regulations that pertain to your type of business.
The Commissioner's Regulations will explain your responsibilities to consumers.
You must follow all consumer protection laws and regulations.
The DMV advises all consumers who have a complaint against a dealer, inspection station, repair shop, or dismantler to make an attempt to resolve their complaint with the business manager.
If consumers are not successful in resolving their complaint with the business manager, they are advised to contact the DMV Consumer & Facilities Services Complaint Unit.
To protect your business, keep a copy of all work orders in an easy-to-access location.
If a complaint has been filed against you, a Consumer Services Rep from the DMV will contact you in an attempt to resolve this complaint.
The Consumer Services Rep will explain the nature of the complaint.
The Consumer Services Rep will also inform you of your rights, responsibilities, and your liability.
If the complaint is not resolved with the Consumer Services Rep, the case will be sent to an Automotive Facilities Inspector (AFI) for a formal investigation.
To avoid costly penalties, fines, and the loss of valuable customers, respond to all DMV inquiries in a timely manner.
The AFI will conduct a formal investigation.
The result of the AFI's investigation may be no action, a warning letter (Notice of Investigation) placed in your file, or a formal administrative hearing before an Administrative Law Judge (ALJ).

When Vehicle Safety initiates the hearing process, you may be offered the opportunity through a "hearing waiver" to admit to the charges and to either pay a specified monetary penalty and/or to accept a suspension.
If the "hearing waiver" is accepted, no hearing is required.
If the offer of a "hearing waiver" is rejected, a hearing must be held.
The result of the hearing may be no action, a civil penalty, and/or a suspension or revocation of your ability to operate as a vehicle related business in New York State.
You may also be offered the opportunity to pay restitution to the consumer instead of the fines and/or penalties, or to have the penalty reduced.
You are entitled to hire an attorney and to bring that attorney to the hearing.
The DMV is the petitioner in this case and the complainant may be a witness for the case.
As a result of the hearing, the ALJ may sustain some, all, or none of the charges.
As a result of the hearing, there may be no action, a warning, the imposition of a suspension, revocation, and/or civil penalties.
If the ALJ only imposes civil penalties, in order to prevent the loss of your operating privilege, you must pay all fines and penalties.
You will receive a letter from the DMV shortly after the hearing.
You will have 30 days from the date of the order by the ALJ to pay your fine or penalty.
Failure to pay any fines or penalties or to serve out your suspension will result in indefinite suspension of your business certificate and the possible assessment of a lien against your business.
However, if you pay your fine and/or penalty or serve out your period of suspension, you will be back in business after complete compliance.
If you are revoked, you must surrender all supplies and cease to operate.
You have the right to appeal any adverse decision.
If you chose to appeal, you have 60 days from the date of the ALJ's decision to file the Appeal From DMV Hearing Determination PDF (AA-33A), which must be accompanied by the appropriate filing fee.
Your facility license, registration or certification enables you to operate in New York State.
Complaints filed and charges brought against you can result in the loss of your privilege to operate as a business in New York State.
You must pass a vision test when you apply for a driver license or to renew your license.
The test must show that you have visual acuity of at least 20/40 based on the Snellen Visual Acuity Scale in either or both eyes, with or without corrective lenses.
You may take a vision test at a DMV office.
Your vision test results may be submitted to DMV electronically by a vision care provider enrolled in the DMV Online Vision Registry.
The DMV Online Vision Registry allows you to search by ZIP Code for an enrolled provider.

Your vision test results may be submitted to DMV by a Vision Test Report PDF completed by a physician, physician's assistant, ophthalmologist, optometrist, optician, registered nurse, or nurse professional.
If you are mailing or bringing a Vision Test Report to DMV, it must be completed in English.
If your eye exam indicates you must wear corrective lenses to pass the vision test, a "B" restriction will be placed on your driver license or learner permit.
There are also restrictions for drivers with low vision.
Telescopic lenses are corrective lenses that are much more powerful than normal eyeglasses or contact lenses.
If you need telescopic lenses to pass a vision test, you must send a completed Eye Test Report for Medical Review Unit PDF form MV-80L to DMV's Medical Review Unit (MRU).
A "TELESCOPIC LENSES" restriction will be placed on your driver license or learner permit if you need telescopic lenses.
If you no longer need telescopic lenses, you can submit a new form MV-80L to remove the restriction.
If an eye care professional indicates that your vision at night is impaired, a "DAYLIGHT DRIVING ONLY" restriction will be added to your driver license or learner permit.
To remove a CORRECTIVE LENSES restriction, you must prove that you can pass a vision test without corrective lenses.
You can remove the CORRECTIVE LENSES restriction online if your vision test provider is enrolled in the DMV Online Vision Registry.
Once an enrolled provider electronically notifies DMV that you can pass a vision test without corrective lenses, the restriction will be removed when you renew your license online.

To remove the CORRECTIVE LENSES restriction at a DMV office when you renew or replace your DMV document, you can take a vision test there or provide a Vision Test Report PDF MV-619 completed by a qualified eye care provider.

If your vision care provider is enrolled in the DMV Online Vision Registry and has submitted your vision test results electronically to DMV, you will not need to submit proof or take a vision test at the DMV office.
To remove the CORRECTIVE LENSES restriction by mail before it is time to renew your driver license, you must obtain proof that you do not need corrective lenses and order a replacement document.

Proof that you do not need corrective lenses can be submitted to DMV electronically by a vision care provider enrolled in the DMV Online Vision Registry, or by a Vision Test Report PDF MV-619 completed by a physician, physician's assistant, ophthalmologist, optometrist, optician, registered nurse, or nurse professional.

To order a replacement document without the CORRECTIVE LENSES restriction by mail, you must complete an Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card PDF MV-44, pay a replacement document fee of $12.50, and provide a completed Vision Test Report PDF MV-619 if your eye care provider is not enrolled in the DMV Online Vision Registry.
You must mail these items to your local DMV office.
If the Vision Test Report MV-619 has a print date of 9/03 or earlier, the form is valid for 6 months after the date of the eye test.

If the Vision Test Report MV-619 has a print date of 3/04 or later, the vision care professional marks a box on the form to indicate if the form is valid for 6 months or for 12 months after the date of the eye test.
The fee for your first New York State driver license or permit, or a new license or permit after a revocation, depends on your age when you apply and where you live.
The total fee includes the driver license application fee.
The total fee includes the fee for the type of license.
The driver license classes provide more information about the fee for the type of license.
The total fee includes the document fees.
The total fee includes the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee, if you live in the MCTD.
Residents of the Bronx county must pay a Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee.
Residents of the Kings (Brooklyn) county must pay a Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee.
Residents of the New York (Manhattan) county must pay a Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee.
Residents of the Queens county must pay a Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee.
Residents of the Richmond (Staten Island) county must pay a Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee.
Residents of the Dutchess county must pay a Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee.
Residents of the Nassau county must pay a Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee.
Residents of the Orange county must pay a Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee.
Residents of the Putnam county must pay a Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee.
Residents of the Rockland county must pay a Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee.
Residents of the Suffolk county must pay a Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee.
Residents of the Westchester county must pay a Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee.
The Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee is $1.00 for every 6 months the permit or driver license will be in effect.
The table shows the total fees you pay.
The table does not show fees for a commercial driver licenses (CDL).
The table does not show the additional $30 fee to get an enhanced driver license (EDL) instead of a regular driver license.
The table does not show fees for a non-driver ID card.
Part of the Class M and MJ fee supports the Motorcycle Safety Program in New York State.
The fee to replace a driver license or learner permit is $17.50.
The fee to change information (amend) on a driver license or learner permit is $12.50.
There is an additional $30.00 fee for an Enhanced Driver License (EDL).
There is an additional $30.00 fee for an Enhanced Permit.
The fees you pay when you get your first motorcycle license depend on whether or not you currently have another class of New York State driver license and your exact age when you apply.
The fees for a Class M or MJ driver license, or to add class M or MJ to your current driver license, can range from $21 to $120.
The exact fee for a motorcycle license cannot be calculated until you apply.
You can receive a partial refund of the 8-year driver license fee if you qualify.
The maximum amount you can receive as a partial refund is 50% (four years) of the original 8-year driver license fee.
The partial refund does not include any application or document fees.
You can qualify for a partial refund if your driver license was valid for 8 years when it was issued.
You can qualify for a partial refund if your driver license is surrendered to the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles or to another state during the first 4 years of the 8-year period.
You can qualify for a partial refund if your driver license was not suspended or revoked when you surrendered it.
You can qualify for a partial refund if your driver license was not exchanged for a non-driver ID card.
To apply for a refund, you must apply no later than 51 months after the date your driver license was issued.
To apply for a refund, you must complete a Request for Refund of Fee Paid for Motor Vehicle Registrations and Driver Licenses (MV-215) form.
To apply for a refund, you must attach the driver license to form MV-215 if you did not already surrender your driver license.
To apply for a refund, if you exchanged your New York State driver license for a driver license in another state, you must attach a photocopy of your out-of-state driver license to form MV-215.
To apply for a refund, you must mail the required form and documents to the address listed on the form.
You must allow up to 12 weeks for the refund to be processed.
Your Standard CDL will not be accepted as proof of identification to board a domestic flight after October 1, 2020.
If you plan to travel and don't have a Passport, we recommend you upgrade to an Enhanced or REAL ID when you renew.
You must renew at a DMV office.
You must come to a DMV office to renew a commercial driver license (CDL) or commercial license permit (CLP).
You will receive a temporary license to use until your new license arrives by mail within 10 business days.
To renew your CDL, you will need to meet the federal medical certification requirements.
To renew your CDL, you will need to indicate compliance when you answer the required questions on the MV-2CDL which is included with your renewal notice.
To renew your CDL, you will need to have proof of your legal presence in the United States on DMV records.
The DMV Document Guide lists all acceptable legal presence and New York State residence proof documents.
You must provide the original documents (not photocopies), and documents submitted as proof of residence must have your current residence address on it (no P.O. Box permitted).

If you are a U.S. citizen or lawful permanent resident, you will only need to provide proof of legal presence on the first original, amendment, reciprocity or renewal application on or after June 18, 2015.
The DMV will retain the proof of legal presence on your driving record if you are a U.S. citizen or lawful permanent resident.
If you are a temporary visitor, you will need to provide proof of legal presence in the U.S. with every application.
If you are a temporary visitor, your new document will have the legend 'NON-DOMICILED' and also 'TEMPORARY VISITOR' and the expiration date of your legal status in the United States printed on it.

If you indicate the driving types 'NI Non-excepted Interstate' or 'NA Non-excepted Intrastate' on your renewal, you must provide a legible copy of your current USDOT Medical Examiner's Certificate to DMV if it is not already on file.
The Federal Requirements for Commercial Driver License (CDL) Applicants pdf MV-44.5 can help you determine your driving type.
Per new federal regulations, the DMV will check for any open suspensions or revocations you may have in any state.
If you have an open suspension or revocation, the DMV will reject your application.
The fees listed include the photo document fee and the supplemental Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee, if required.
If you have any other class combined with a motorcycle Class M or MJ (e.g., AM), add an additional $8.00 to the fee.
If you have an endorsement of H or X, you must pass the hazardous materials knowledge test at a DMV office within 2 years before your renewal and pay an additional fee of $5 for the test.

Residents of the following counties must pay a supplemental Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD) fee: Bronx, Kings (Brooklyn), New York (Manhattan), Queens, Richmond (Staten Island); Dutchess, Nassau, Orange, Putnam, Rockland, Suffolk and Westchester.
The MCTD fee is $1.00 for every 6 months the permit or driver license will be in effect.
For an 8-year driver license, the MCTD fee is $16.
You can replace your non-driver ID if it was lost or destroyed.
You can replace your non-driver ID after you update your address.
You cannot replace your non-driver ID if it expired.
If your non-driver ID expired, you must renew or apply for a new one.
The DMV recommends that you come to the DMV now to get an Enhanced or REAL ID, and avoid a second office visit later.
You don't have to get an Enhanced or REAL ID.
If you have a Standard non-driver ID, you will not be allowed to board a domestic flight starting in October 2020 unless you have a Passport.
You can replace your non-driver ID online.
If you replace your Standard non-driver ID online, your new document will show 'NOT FOR FEDERAL PURPOSES'.
If you already have an Enhanced or REAL ID, or you want to keep your Standard non-driver ID, you can replace it online.
If you replace your non-driver ID online, your document type will stay the same.
You can replace your non-driver ID by mail.
If you replace your Standard non-driver ID by mail, your new document will show 'NOT FOR FEDERAL PURPOSES'.
If you already have an Enhanced or REAL ID, or you want to keep your Standard non-driver ID, you can replace it by mail.
If you replace your non-driver ID by mail, your document type will stay the same.

To replace your non-driver ID by mail, you must mail a completed Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card PDF MV-44, photocopies of acceptable proof of identity, and payment by check or money order made out to 'Commissioner of Motor Vehicles' to the NYS Department of Motor Vehicles at 207 Genesee Street, Suite 6, Utica, NY 13501-2874.
To get a reduced fee or 'No Fee' replacement non-driver ID, you must apply by mail or at a DMV office.
You cannot apply online to get a reduced fee or 'No Fee' replacement non-driver ID.
To get a reduced fee or 'No Fee' replacement non-driver ID, you must provide proof of your eligibility for Supplemental Security Income.

Acceptable proof of eligibility for Supplemental Security Income includes a Notice of Award notifying you of SSI benefits, a Cost of Living Adjustment (COLA) letter, a Notice of change in payment SSA-L8151, a Third Party Query (TPQY) letter, a Report of Confidential Social Security Information SSA-2258, or a Benefit Verification letter obtained by calling the Social Security Administration at 1-800-772-1213.
At a DMV office, you must bring proof of Supplemental Security Income to get a reduced fee or 'No Fee' replacement non-driver ID.
By mail, you must send proof of Supplemental Security Income to get a reduced fee or 'No Fee' replacement non-driver ID.
If you are turning 21 soon, you should order a replacement non-driver ID within 40 days of your birthday to get an ID without 'UNDER 21'.
You will receive your new non-driver ID in 2 weeks.
You can check the mailing status of your photo document online.
If your document is not delivered two weeks after the date the document was processed, you can contact the DMV.
The DMV mails your new non-driver ID card to the address currently on their records or an alternate address you provide.
You can change or verify your address with the DMV.
When you apply by mail or at an office, you can ask that your replacement non-driver ID be sent to an address that is different from the address on your document.
You cannot have your replacement non-driver ID sent to a different address when you order online.
When overseas, you must replace your non-driver ID card through the mail.

When replacing your non-driver ID card from overseas, you must submit a completed Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card PDF MV-44, photocopies of acceptable proof of identity, and the appropriate fee.

When replacing your non-driver ID card from overseas, it is recommended that you send a pre-addressed priority mail return envelope with your application to ensure that the new ID is sent to the correct address.
If you need to make changes other than to your address, you will need to go to a DMV office.
Starting in October 2020, you will need an Enhanced or REAL ID to board a domestic flight unless you have a Passport.
If your non-driver ID was issued before October 30, 2017 and is not Enhanced, you have a Standard document.
Newly issued Standard non-driver ID documents show 'NOT FOR FEDERAL PURPOSES'.

If you want to replace your non-driver ID in an office and keep your Standard document type, you must complete an Application for Permit, Driver License or Non-Driver ID Card PDF MV-44, come to an office, bring your current Standard non-driver ID, the application, and payment.
If you request a replacement non-driver ID 41 days or more before your 21st birthday, it will say 'UNDER 21'.
If you want your new non-driver ID card sent to an alternate address, you must include an additional note and clearly print the alternate address.
You should not write the alternate address on form MV-44.
The mailing address you write on form MV-44 must be the address that is listed on your photo document and your DMV record.
When you purchase a vehicle from a leasing company, you must have the title issued in your name.
The title must be issued in your name before you can sell or transfer the vehicle.
You can transfer the title by mail or at a DMV office.
To transfer the title by mail, you must mail a completed Vehicle Registration / Title Application MV-82 or Application for Title MV-82TON.
If you do not have a completed Vehicle Registration / Title Application MV-82 or Application for Title MV-82TON, you can provide other types of proof.
