You must provide proof of identity such as a copy of your NYS Driver License, Permit, or Non-Driver ID card, which must be current or not expired for more than 2 years.
You must provide the New York State title or other acceptable proof of ownership.
The title must have completed buyer and seller information.
Both the leasing company and the buyer must provide their signatures, dates of transfer, and addresses on the title.
You must provide odometer and damage disclosure statements for all vehicles that are 10 years old or newer.
You must provide an FS-6T receipt issued by DMV.
To get an FS-6T, you must obtain a Claim for Sales Tax Exemption DTF-803 from the leasing company and a bill of sale and bring these items to a local DMV office.
You must provide a Dealer Retail Certificate of Sale MV-50 completed by a dealer located in New York State.
You must provide payment for the $50.00 title fee in the form of a check or money order made payable to the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.
You must mail the required documents to NYS DMV Title Services, Department of Motor Vehicles, 6 Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12228-0331.
To transfer the title at a DMV office, you must bring a completed Vehicle Registration / Title Application MV-82 or Application for Title MV-82TON.
If you do not have a completed Vehicle Registration / Title Application MV-82 or Application for Title MV-82TON, you can provide other kinds of proof.
You must provide proof of identity such as a NYS License, Permit, or Non-Driver ID card, which must be current or not expired for more than 2 years.
You must provide the New York State or out-of-state title with completed buyer and seller information.
You must provide odometer and damage disclosure statements for all vehicles that are 10 years old or newer.
You must provide the lease buyout agreement.
You must provide a lien release, if appropriate.

You must provide a Retail Certificate of Sale MV-50, or a completed Statement of Transaction Sale or Gift of Motor Vehicle, Trailer, All-Terrain Vehicle ATV, Vessel Boat, or Snowmobile {Sales Tax Form} pdf at NY State Department of Tax and Finance DTF-802 and a bill of sale.
You must provide payment for the $50.00 fee.
Your title will be mailed to you.
To find information about filing or removing a lien, dealers should see Remove or add a lienholder from a title.
New York State residents age 16 or over can apply for a New York driver license.
Most people get a class D - Operator license if 18 or older.
Most people get a class DJ - Junior Operator license if under 18.
To get a class A, B, C- commercial license (CDL), see instructions.
To get a class M - motorcycle license, see instructions.
To get a class E - taxi or limousine livery license, see instructions.
The DMV offers 3 types of licenses: Enhanced, REAL ID and Standard documents.
Before you can get a license, you must apply for a learner permit at a DMV office and take the written test.
You can prepare for the written test by reading the New York State Driver's Manual and taking practice tests.
Once you have a learner permit, you must have supervised driving practice.
Once you have a learner permit, you must take a pre-licensing course or a driver education course before you take your road test.
If you pass your road test, the examiner will give you an interim license that allows you to drive.
You must keep the interim license with your photo learner permit until your new license arrives in the mail in about 2 weeks.
Fees depend on what you are applying for, your age, and where you live.
Use the fee chart to estimate your fee.
To replace a license that was lost, stolen or destroyed, see instructions.
To renew your license, see instructions.
To restore your driving privilege and reapply for your license after a revocation, see instructions.
If you are from another state, see how to exchange your out-of-state driver license.
If you are coming to New York from another country overseas, see information about visiting or moving to New York.
If you are under age 18 or are the parent of a driver under age 18, it is very important that you understand the Graduated Driver License (GDL) Law and the restrictions on drivers under age 18.

If you are 17, you are eligible for a senior driver license Class D or M if you have a junior driver license or limited junior driver license and have completed a state-approved high school or college driver education course.
To change your junior license to a senior license, bring your junior license and the Student Certificate of Completion MV-285 that you received from your instructor to any DMV office.
You must return your certificate and junior license to receive the senior license.
If you do not change your junior license to a senior license, you are subject to the restrictions for junior drivers until you are age 18, even if you carry the completion certificate with you.
You can also give your certificate with your junior permit to the license examiner at your road test.
If you are not eligible for a senior license when you turn 18, you will automatically receive a senior license in the mail when you turn 18.
Once you pass your road test or restore a revoked driver license, you will have a 6 month probationary period.

During the probationary period, your license will be suspended for 60 days if you are convicted of any of the following: speeding, participating in a speed contest, reckless driving, following too closely, use of a mobile telephone, use of a portable electronic device (e.g. a smart phone, tablet, GPS or MP3 player), or any 2 other moving violations.
After the suspension ends, you will have a second 6 month probation period.
If you are convicted of one of the violations above or 2 other moving violations during the second probation period, your license will be revoked for at least 6 months.
When the revocation ends, you must serve another a 6 month probationary period.
For a Class D, Class DJ, and Class E driver license, the expiration date of your learner permit becomes the expiration date of your driver license.
Together the learner permit and the driver license are valid for a maximum of 5 years.
When you apply for a learner permit and a driver license, you pay the fee for the length of time that the documents are valid.
If you pass your road test, your driver license will expire on the same date as your learner permit.
When you change from a Class DJ junior license to a Class D senior license, the expiration date does not change.
You can drive in New York State with a valid driver license from another country.
You don't need to apply for a New York State driver license unless you become a New York State resident.
If you choose to get a New York driver license, when you pass your road test, you must give your foreign driver license to the DMV road test examiner.
The local DMV office will destroy your foreign driver license after 60 days.
If you plan to return to your home country and will need your foreign driver license, ask the road test examiner how to make sure that your foreign driver license is not destroyed.

According to Section 250(5) of the NY State Vehicle and Traffic Law, the term 'resident' means 'domiciliary', that is, one who lives in New York State with the intention of making it a fixed and permanent abode.
It shall be presumptive evidence that a person who maintains a place of abode in New York State for a period of at least ninety days is a resident of New York State.
To live in a house, a home, an apartment, a room or other similar place in New York State for 90 days is considered 'presumptive evidence' that you are a resident of New York State.
A police officer can use this as evidence to issue a traffic ticket if you drive in New York State without a New York State driver license or vehicle registration.
A judge considers the law and the evidence of your intent and decides if you are a resident of New York State.
If you pay taxes or your children attend school in another state, a judge considers these facts to decide if your intent is to make New York State a 'fixed and permanent' residence.
According to this law, students from other states or from other nations who attend school in New York State are usually not considered residents of New York State.
The DMV does not decide if you are a resident of New York State, if you must get a New York State driver license, or if you must register your vehicle in New York State.
Get a CDL.
Follow these steps to get your first time New York State commercial driver license CDL.
Step 1: Have a New York State driver license (Class D, Class E, or Non-CDL C) or a valid CDL from another state.
Get the New York State Commercial Driver's Manual CDL-10 online or from a DMV office or call center.
The New York State Commercial Driver's Manual CDL-10 describes the classes, the restrictions, and the endorsements of CDLs.
The Driver License Class Descriptions PDF MV-500C also includes information about the classes, the restrictions, and the endorsements of CDLs.
Step 2: Apply for a commercial learner permit at a DMV office.
You must pass the written test for the CDL that you need.
There is an application fee of $10.00 for the written test.
This $10.00 fee allows you to take all written tests (knowledge and endorsement) required for permit and license issuance applied for which are taken at the same time.
There will be an additional $5 fee for any other required tests not taken and passed at the time of initial application.
There is a fee of $40.00 to take the CDL road test (skills test).
You can pay the $40.00 road test fee when the DMV office issues your commercial learner permit, or you can pay the fee online.
You must pay the $40.00 fee before you can schedule your road test.

When you apply for a New York State CDL Class A, B, or C, you must certify that you did not hold a driver license in any state or in the District of Columbia except New York in the last 10 years or you must report every US state or the District of Columbia where you held a driver license in the last 10 years.
When you apply for a New York State CDL Class A, B, or C, you must certify that you meet the Federal medical examination requirements.
The Medical Certification Requirements provides more information about the Federal medical examination requirements.
When you apply for a New York State CDL Class A, B, or C, you must also prove your legal presence in the United States.
DMV now offers three types of license / permit documents: enhanced, REAL ID and standard documents.
If you have a Standard and want to change to a REAL ID or Enhanced, you must come into a DMV office.
You must complete a guide to make sure you have the proofs of identification you need before coming to the DMV office.
The DMV Document Guide lists all acceptable legal presence and New York State residence proof documents.
You must provide the original documents (not photocopies) to the DMV.
Documents submitted as proof of residence must have your current residence address on it (no P.O. Box permitted).
If you are a U.S. citizen or lawful permanent resident (i.e., not a temporary visitor), your Commercial Learner Permit CLP or CDL document will have the legend 'NON-DOMICILED' printed on it.
If you are a temporary visitor, the TEMPORARY VISITOR and the expiration date of your legal status documentation will continue to be displayed on the CLP and/or CDL document.
Per new federal regulations, the DMV will check for any open suspensions or revocations you may have in any state.
If you have an open suspension or revocation, the DMV will reject your application.
You must apply for a CDL at a DMV Office.
Step 3: Prepare for your road test and practice with a supervising driver.
The supervising driver must have a driver license that is valid to drive the commercial motor vehicle that you use for practice.
Step 4: Schedule your road test.
Use the Road Test Scheduling System to schedule your road test.
You cannot schedule an appointment for a date that is less than 14 days after being issued a Commercial Learner Permit CLP.
If you do not pass the road test, you must pay a fee of $40.00 before you can schedule another road test.
You can pay the $40.00 fee online with your credit card, or pay the fee at a DMV office.

New CDL restrictions defined by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration FMCSA may affect CLP holders when taking a Skills Test in a vehicle without full airbrakes and/or a manual transmission.
The 'E' restriction means 'No Manual Transmission Equipped Commercial Motor Vehicle CMV'.
The 'L' restriction means 'No Airbrake Equipped CMV'.
The 'Z' restriction means 'No Full Airbrake Equipped CMV'.
If the vehicle used for your skills test has an automatic transmission, and this is your first road test in a commercial motor vehicle CMV, you will be given an 'E' restriction.
If the vehicle used for your skills test has no form of airbrakes, and this is your first road test in a CMV, you will be given an 'L' restriction.
If the vehicle used for your skills test has air over hydraulic brakes, and this is your first road test in a CMV, you will be given a 'Z' restriction.
If you have a CDL with an 'L' restriction and you test in a vehicle with air over hydraulic brakes, you will be upgraded from an 'L' to a 'Z' restriction.

Effective May 23, 2014, the New York State DMV will no longer issue a 10-day temporary license document upon successful completion of a Commercial Driver License skills test, in order to comply with the Federal self-certification and medical certification requirements for commercial drivers.
Instead, commercial drivers will be issued a receipt indicating they must wait 1 business day before visiting a DMV office in order to obtain a Commercial Driver's License document.
The fee for a CDL depends on the expiration date and the class of your current driver license, and the date that you receive your CDL.
The local DMV office will issue a temporary CDL that is valid for 90 days.
Your photo CDL will arrive by mail in 3 to 4 weeks.
To get a New York State CDL if you have a CDL from another state, you must apply for your CDL at a DMV office and surrender your out-of-state CDL.
If your out-of-state CDL has a hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass the hazardous materials knowledge test when you apply for your New York State CDL.

If your out-of-state CDL has a hazardous materials endorsement, you must also provide fingerprints for federal and New York State background checks for criminal violations when you apply for your New York State CDL.
The federal regulations in 49 CFR Part 391 are relevant to getting a New York State CDL if you have a CDL from another state.
An all-terrain vehicle (ATV) is any self-propelled vehicle, including an off-road motorcycle, that is manufactured for use on off-road trails or in off-road competitions.
These vehicles are less than 70 inches wide and weigh less than 1,000 pounds.

You must have a valid NY State registration to ride your ATV in New York State, unless it is only used for agricultural purposes or not-for-hire snow removal on private property registered in another state to a resident of that state only used at special events competitions.
If you purchase an ATV including an off-road motorcycle from a NY State ATV dealer, the dealer is required to register it before it is delivered to you.

To register an ATV not purchased from a NY State ATV dealer, you need to bring acceptable proof of ownership, a completed Registration/Title Application (MV-82) that the NY State sales tax was paid or proof of the purchase price of the ATV, proof of identity, and cash, check, money order or credit/debit card to pay for fees.

Acceptable proof of ownership for an ATV purchased from an out-of-state ATV dealer can be a manufacturer's certificate of origin or a manufacturer's statement of origin, and the bill of sale from the dealer, the registration or the title certificate signed by the previous owner that transfers the ownership to the dealer, and a bill of sale from the dealer that transfers the ownership to you.

A bill of sale from an ATV dealer must include the name and the address of the dealer and the registration number of the dealer, your name and your address, the Vehicle Identification Number (VIN) of the ATV, the year, the make, the model, and the number of wheels of the ATV, an indication that the ATV is either used or new, an indication that the dealer collected the correct NY State sales tax.

If the ATV is transferred by a private individual, acceptable proof of ownership is a New York State or out-of-state transferable registration or title certificate signed by the previous owner to transfer ownership to you.

If the current owner did not register the ATV, acceptable proof of ownership is a transferrable registration and bill of sale that transferred ownership to the current owner, and a bill of sale that transfers ownership to you.
You don't need insurance to register your ATV, but you must have insurance unless you only drive your ATV on private property.
You must show your proof of insurance to a judge, a police officer, or any person who makes a claim of injury or property damage.
You do not need a driver license to drive an ATV, but restrictions apply to ATV drivers under the age of 16.

Children 10 to 15 years of age can drive an ATV only with adult supervision, without adult supervision on property where their parent or guardian is the owner or tenant, without adult supervision on property where ATV use is permitted and the child completed an ATV safety-training course approved by the DMV.
Children under the age of 10 may drive an ATV only with adult supervision, without adult supervision on property where their parent or guardian is the owner or tenant.
You can operate an ATV on public lands where signs indicate that ATV use is allowed.
You can only operate an ATV on private property if you have permission from the property owner.
If you purchased the ATV from an out-of-state ATV dealer, and the bill of sale indicates that the dealer collected the NY State sales tax, no additional sales tax is due.

If the out-of-state dealer collects out-of-state sales tax, you can apply for credit toward the payment of the NY State sales tax when you apply for registration in NY State, if New York and the other state have a reciprocal sales tax agreement.
If you purchased the ATV from a private seller, the seller and the buyer complete the Statement of Transaction (DTF-802), or you can show your proof of exemption or proof that the tax was paid.
A NY State Driver License, Learner Permit, or Non-Driver ID card that is current or not expired for more than 2 years can serve as proof of identity.
You need to renew your registration before it expires.
Your new registration documents will arrive in the mail in about 10 days.
Renewing early will not change the new expiration date for your new registration.
Members of the Armed Forces may have more time to renew.
You cannot renew a registration that is suspended.
You cannot renew a registration that is revoked.
You cannot renew a registration that is expired for more than 1 year.
You cannot renew a registration that has not been inspected in the past 12 months.
Some registrations are not eligible for online renewal.
You should not renew online if you are eligible for a 'no fee' renewal.
The renewal fee is on your renewal notice.
The renewal fee is displayed on your computer screen when you renew online.
To renew a registration online, you will need your registration plate number.
To renew a registration online, you will need your registration class.
To renew a registration online, you will need the last name of the person on the registration or business name.
To renew a registration online, you will need a credit or pinless debit card for payment.
To renew a registration by mail, you should mail the bottom part of your registration renewal notice MV-3 or OP-3 to the address listed on the notice.
To renew a registration by mail, you should include a personal check or money order payable to 'Commissioner of Motor Vehicles' for the fee.
If you do not have your MV-3 or OP-3 to renew by mail, you should use the Application for Duplicate/Renewal Registration PDF MV-82D.
If you do not know the correct amount to renew by mail, you should send a check payable to 'Commissioner of Motor Vehicles', but do not write the amount.
To renew a registration by mail without MV-3 or OP-3, you should mail the MV-82D and your payment to New York State Department of Motor Vehicles Utica Processing Center P.O. Box 359 Utica, NY 13503.
To renew a registration at a DMV office, you should bring your registration renewal notice MV-3 or OP-3 and payment.
If you do not have your MV-3 or OP-3 to renew at a DMV office, you should complete the Application for Duplicate/Renewal Registration PDF MV-82D.
You can renew online up to one year past the expiration date.
When you renew online, you can download and print a temporary registration that is valid for 10 days the day you renew.
Your mailing address on DMV files must be current to renew your registration.
You cannot change your mailing address during the online registration renewal transaction.
To change your mailing address before renewing online, you should first change your address online.
If you file a request with the US Postal Service (USPS) to forward mail, there is no guarantee that the USPS will forward all DMV documents to your new address.
You can still renew online if your name has changed, but the new document will display your previous name.
You cannot change your name during the online registration renewal transaction.
To change your name or other information on a registration or title after renewing online, you should follow the process for changing your name or other information.
You will need to register the vehicle at a DMV office if your name has changed.
You cannot renew registrations online for vehicles that are exempt from registration fees.
To renew a registration for a vehicle that is exempt from registration fees, you must bring documentation that proves the vehicle is eligible for exempt status to a DMV office.
You cannot renew registrations online for vehicles that require proof of insurance.
You cannot renew registrations online for vehicles that require a tax certificate.
You cannot renew registrations online for vehicles that require another document for each renewal.
You cannot renew registrations online for vehicles that weigh 55,000 lbs. or more.
You cannot renew registrations online for for-hire vehicles, including taxis, livery vehicles, and buses.
You cannot renew registrations online for semi-trailers with 6-year registrations.
You cannot renew registrations online for vehicles with an apportioned registration issued under the International Registration Plan (IRP).
You cannot renew registrations online for vehicles with an ambulance, New York Press (NYP), government or official registration.
You cannot renew registrations online for rental vehicles.
If you are eligible for a 'no fee' registration, you will need to renew at a DMV office.
If you are eligible for a 'no fee' registration, you will need to bring documentation to prove you are eligible for exempt status when renewing at a DMV office.
You should only use the temporary registration if your registration is expired or about to expire, while you wait for your new registration documents to arrive in the mail.

Unless it is exempt, your vehicle must comply with the California emissions standard if it has less than 7,500 miles on the odometer and is a model year of 1996 or newer passenger vehicle or light-duty truck that has a gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR) of 6,000 lbs. or less.
Your vehicle must comply with the California emissions standard if it is a model year 2000 or newer light-duty truck that has a GVWR of 8,500 lbs. or less.
Your vehicle must comply with the California emissions standard if it is a model year 2004 or newer medium duty vehicle that has a GVWR of 14,000 lbs. or less.
Your vehicle must comply with the California emissions standard if it has a GVWR over 14,000 lbs and is a model year 2005 or newer heavy-duty otto-cycle or diesel vehicle.

To determine if a vehicle meets the California emissions standard, look for these words or similar language on the Manufacturer's Certificate of Origin (MCO) and the emissions label under the hood: "California-Only Vehicle: This vehicle conforms to U.S. EPA and California regulations applicable to the vehicle model year [model-year] new motor vehicles introduced into commerce only for sale in California."

To determine if a vehicle meets the California emissions standard, look for these words or similar language on the MCO and the emissions label under the hood: "50-State Vehicle: This vehicle conforms to U.S. EPA and California regulations applicable to the vehicle model year [model-year] new motor vehicles."

To determine if a vehicle meets the California emissions standard, look for these words or similar language on the MCO and the emissions label under the hood: "Federal Vehicle certified for Sale in California: This vehicle conforms to U.S. EPA regulations applicable to the vehicle model year [model-year] new motor vehicles, and is certified for sale in California."

If your vehicle complies with the California emissions standard, but the MCO does not indicate compliance or you do not have an MCO, you or the automobile dealer can certify compliance on a 'Certificate of Emissions Compliance or Exemption' form MV-74.

If your vehicle is exempt from the California emissions standard, you or the automobile dealer can complete form MV-74 to certify the exemption if the vehicle has an odometer reading of more than 7,500 miles.

If your vehicle is exempt from the California emissions standard, you or the automobile dealer can complete form MV-74 to certify the exemption if you purchased the vehicle in another state to replace your previous vehicle that was damaged, stolen or had a mechanical failure while you were outside NY State.

If your vehicle is exempt from the California emissions standard, you or the automobile dealer can complete form MV-74 to certify the exemption if the vehicle was transferred to you through an inheritance or court decree.

If your vehicle is exempt from the California emissions standard, you or the automobile dealer can complete form MV-74 to certify the exemption if the vehicle was registered to you in another state when you were a resident of that state, but you are now a resident of NY State.

If your vehicle is exempt from the California emissions standard, you or the automobile dealer can complete form MV-74 to certify the exemption if you are a NY State resident who serves in the US Armed Forces and you are stationed in another state.

If your vehicle is exempt from the California emissions standard, you or the automobile dealer can complete form MV-74 to certify the exemption if the vehicle is an authorized emergency vehicle defined in Article 1 of the NY State Vehicle and Traffic Law.
Even if your vehicle meets the California emissions standard, it is subject to NY State safety and emissions inspection requirements.
The NY State Department of Environmental Conservation website www.dec.ny.gov has the regulations for the California emissions standards and other motor vehicle emissions standards.
A suspension means your driver license or privilege to drive is taken away for a period of time before it is returned.
There are two types of suspensions: definite suspension and indefinite suspension.
A definite suspension has a clear beginning and end date.
The suspension termination fee for a definite suspension is currently $50.
The suspension termination fee for breaking the NYS Zero Tolerance alcohol law is $100.
An indefinite suspension means you must do something such as answer a traffic ticket before the suspension can be cleared.
If you receive a definite suspension order from DMV, you must pay a suspension termination fee before your driver license or privilege to drive can be restored, according to the law.

To pay a definite suspension online, you must provide your name or DMV ID Number Client ID Number from your NYS driver license, learner permit or non-driver photo ID card, your date of birth and gender, and the last four digits of your Social Security Number.
Your name and address on DMV records must be correct when paying a suspension termination fee online.
Your payment does not guarantee that DMV will restore your driver license, as there may be other problems on your record.
It is your responsibility to know if your driver license or driving privilege is valid before you drive a motor vehicle.
You can pay the suspension termination fee at the office or offices shown on your suspension order.
In some cases, you can pay the suspension termination fee by mail, with instructions provided on your suspension order.
You can pay up to 10 suspension termination fees in one day online.
After paying the suspension termination fee, you can check the status of your driver license or driving privilege by signing up for a MyDMV account and using the My License service.
If you need a certified copy of your driving records, you can order a copy of your driver record.
A definite suspension lasts until your suspension period ends.
If you pay the suspension termination fee before the suspension period has ended, DMV will mail your license to you within 3 business days after the suspension period ends.

DMV will not mail your license to you if your driver license has expired, you have a commercial driver license (CDL), you have a conditional or restricted license, or you have other suspensions, revocations or problems with your driver license.

Once you pay the suspension termination fee, you can use DMV's Photo ID Document Mailing Status service after waiting for 3 business days after the suspension period ends to know if your license was mailed.

Common reasons for definite suspensions are not having automobile liability insurance, being convicted of an alcohol or drugged driving charge, receiving too many traffic tickets in a certain amount of time, and not following the rules for junior drivers.
If the effective date of your suspension order is before July 6, 2009, the suspension termination fee is $25.
An indefinite suspension means your driver license or privilege to drive was taken away because you failed to do something.
Your driver license or privilege to drive will remain suspended until you comply with the instructions on your suspension order for an indefinite suspension.
You may also be required to pay a suspension termination fee for an indefinite suspension.
Common reasons for indefinite suspensions are not answering a traffic ticket, not paying a traffic ticket fine, not filing a motor vehicle accident report, and failing to pay child support.
You can confirm or change your address online, but you must create a MyDMV account first.
If you need to change your name, you must go to a DMV office.
You can check the status of your driver license and driving privilege online if you sign up for a MyDMV account and use the MyLicense service.
If you need proof that DMV removed your suspension, you can order a certified copy of your driving record.
If you surrendered your license, DMV will mail you a new document, not the one you surrendered.
Although you can pay suspension termination fees online, you must go to a DMV office to get your commercial driver license back.
Although you can pay suspension termination fees online, you must go to a DMV office to get your full driver license back if you have a conditional or restricted license.
After you sell or give away a vehicle, you can transfer the registration and vehicle plates to another vehicle you own.

To transfer the registration and vehicle plates, you must bring the following items to a DMV office: the original title or other proof of ownership, a current NY State Insurance ID card for auto liability insurance, a NY State driver license, permit, non-driver ID or other proof of identity, a completed Application for Registration/Title PDF MV-82, and payment for fees.
For quicker service, you can make a reservation online before visiting DMV offices in New York City, Westchester, Nassau, Suffolk, Rockland, Onondaga, Monroe or Albany Counties.
For all other counties, you can see the DMV office locations and hours.
If you do not want to transfer the registration, you must surrender the vehicle plates to the DMV.
You may be eligible to receive a refund if you surrender the plates before the registration expires.
To transfer ownership of a vehicle (buy, sell, or give away), you need the following documents:

For cars, trucks, trailers & motorcycles model year 1973 or newer, you need either a NY State Certificate of Title (original or certified copy, not a photocopy) with the transfer ownership section completed by the seller, or acceptable proof of ownership from another state (original or certified copy, not a photocopy).

For cars, trucks, trailers & motorcycles model year 1972 or older, you need either a NY State Transferable Registration (original or certified copy, not a photocopy) and bill of sale, or acceptable proof of ownership from another state (original or certified copy, not a photocopy).
For other vehicles such as manufactured homes, boats, ATVs, snowmobiles, gifted vehicles, and vehicles with deceased owners, you need to see the acceptable proofs.

Your insurance company will provide you with 2 barcoded original NY State Insurance ID cards (or access to your digital electronic NY State Insurance ID Card) and send an electronic notice of insurance coverage to the DMV.
The NY State Insurance ID cards and the electronic notice together verify your insurance coverage, and both are needed.
You must register your vehicle within 180 days of the effective date on your Insurance ID Card.
You must bring one copy or form of your Insurance ID Card with you to the DMV office.
The DMV office will keep the paper Insurance ID Card, and you must keep the other paper card with the vehicle as your proof of insurance.
Anyone operating your vehicle must be able to provide proof of insurance.
You can learn more about NY State Insurance Requirements.
You must provide proof of identity and date of birth, and you must be at least 16 years old (except for ATV and boat registrations).
You can use a NY State driver license, learner permit, or non-driver ID card (current or expired less than 2 years) as proof of identity and age.
If you do not have one of these, you can see other kinds of proof you can use.

You can estimate the registration fees online if the registration is one of these classes: PAS - Passenger, COM - Commercial, RGL - Passenger, MOT - Motorcycle, ORM - Motorcycle, CSP - Commercial, ORC - Commercial, RGC - Commercial, ORG - Passenger, SPO - Passenger, SRF - Passenger.
The two vehicles must have the same registration type (passenger, commercial, motorcycle) to transfer the registration.

Pursuant to Executive Order No. 2 by Governor Andrew M. Cuomo, all licenses and registrations for New York State military personnel returning from active military duty relating to the war on terrorism and military action in Iraq will automatically be extended.

If a New York State driver license expires while the military personnel is on active duty, New York State law automatically extends license privileges throughout active military service for up to 6 months after discharge or separation.
Discharged or separated military personnel may renew an expired New York State license up to two years after the extended expiration.
No more than 30 months may have passed since discharge 6-month extension plus 24-month grace period.
Active military personnel must show proof of date of entry into military service.
If the New York State license was valid at any time during the military personnel's military service, the license can be renewed.
A discharged serviceman must show a Certificate of Discharge, DD-214.
The discharged serviceman must have been discharged within the past 30 months.
While not required, it is suggested that military personnel file a Notification of Military Service pdf MV-75 to ensure that the license record is not purged once the expiration date has passed.
New York State registrations are extended for up to 60 days from return to New York State for vehicles registered to military personnel.
The registration extension applies only to vehicles registered to military personnel.
The military personnel must show proof of military service or separation for the registration extension.
Liability insurance coverage must be maintained at all times, including the period of extension.
If there was a lapse of insurance coverage during active duty, the military personnel is required to maintain continuous coverage or surrender plates before deployed.

If the military personnel was unable to maintain continuous coverage or surrender plates before deployed, DMV has a procedure in place to exempt the military personnel from administrative actions upon return.

To be exempted from administrative actions for lapse of insurance coverage, the military personnel must provide a notarized statement that the vehicle was not used during the time in question, a copy of military ID, proof of current insurance or surrender of plates, and signed and dated copies of deployment and return papers, or DD-214 if separated from service.
The military personnel can present the required documents at any DMV office, or mail them to: Insurance Services Bureau, NYS DMV, 6 Empire State Plaza, Room 332B, Albany, NY 12228.
If the military personnel has any additional questions, the military personnel should contact the DMV Call Center.
A driving school instructor is a person who has been certified to teach individuals to drive a motor vehicle for a licensed driving school.
A certified driving school instructor may be approved to teach in one or more of the following areas: cars, trucks, buses, tractor-trailers, motorcycles.
The requirements for the Pre-licensing Course include a classroom course.
To become a driving school instructor, you must first be employed by a driving school licensed by DMV.

To become a driving school instructor, you must meet several requirements identified in Commissioner's Regulations Part 76.16, including: being at least 21 years of age, having a valid driver's license for at least 2 years preceding application in the class of vehicle that the instructor intends to teach in, not having the driver's license suspended or revoked in the last 2 years, showing an acceptable driving record, having a high school or high school equivalency diploma, passing a vision test, passing a road sign test, passing a written test, passing a driving school instructor driving test, and never having been convicted of a felony or of any crime involving violence, dishonesty, deceit, indecency, degeneracy or moral turpitude.

Before a Driving School Instructor Certificate can be renewed, the instructor must complete a course in driver training and traffic safety, approved by the Commissioner, consisting of at least 30 hours, known as the 30-hour course.
The 30-hour course is taught by various community colleges and driving schools that have been approved by DMV to provide this course.

To teach the Pre-licensing Course, an instructor must successfully complete a 30-hour Teaching Techniques and Methodology course, which is a college-level course, and have at least one year experience as a behind-the-wheel certified driving school instructor.

To become a driving school instructor, the applicant must complete an Application for Driving School Instructor Certificate, answering all questions and providing any explanations/information needed, including any documentation requested.

The Application for Driving School Instructor Certificate must be brought to the driving school owner, along with a copy of the applicant's high school or equivalency diploma, one passport-type photo of the applicant taken within the last 30 days, and a check or money order payable to Commissioner of Motor Vehicles in the amount of $10.

If the applicant's driver license is issued from a state other than New York, the applicant must include with the application a certified copy of their driving record from the state agency that issued the license.
The driving school owner must mail the application to the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles Bureau of Driver Training Programs.
Once the application is approved, the Bureau of Driver Training Programs will forward the application to the local DMV Testing & Investigations Unit.

The DMV Testing & Investigations Unit will contact the applicant to schedule testing, which consists of a vision test, a road sign test, a written test, and a behind-the-wheel instructor's driving test.

The vision test is similar to the vision test required to qualify for or renew a driver's license, and can be taken at DMV or conducted by an eye doctor or physician who completes the Vision Test Report form MV-619.
The road sign test evaluates the applicant's knowledge of road signs, which is covered in the Driver's Manual MV-21.

The written test is based on information found in the Driver's Manual MV-21, Commissioner's Regulations Part 76, and Section 394 of the New York State Vehicle & Traffic Law, and there is a study guide for the Written Test MV-368 that can be downloaded.

The behind-the-wheel instructor's driving test evaluates the applicant's ability to drive and give a student instruction in the type of vehicle the applicant wants to teach in, and the applicant must provide their own vehicle for this test.
With each application, the applicant is allowed to take the Road Sign Test and Written Test twice, and the Behind-The-Wheel Instructor's Driving Test once.
If the applicant does not pass these tests, they will have to submit a new application, including photos and $10 fee.
After passing all tests, the Bureau of Driver Training Programs will issue a Driving School Instructor Certificate MV-524 and mail it to the driving school where the applicant is employed.

The Driving School Instructor Certificate MV-524 must be carried by the instructor whenever they are teaching and whenever they take a customer to a DMV Road Test Site, and must be presented upon request.
The MV-524 only authorizes the instructor to teach for the driving school named on the certificate.

To get an additional certificate naming another driving school, the instructor must complete an Application for Driving School Instructor Certificate form MV-523 and take it to the new driving school that has hired them, along with a copy of their high school or equivalency diploma, one passport-type photo of themselves taken within the last 30 days, and a certified copy of their driving record from the state agency that issued their license if it was issued from a state other than New York.

There is no fee for an additional certificate as long as the instructor has a valid certificate with another driving school, unless the driving school the instructor is employed by is authorized by DMV to conduct these tests for their employees.
DMV's Traffic Violations Bureau (TVB) processes tickets for non-criminal moving traffic violations issued in the five boroughs of New York City.
You can read a brochure for more information about the TVB.
You can answer most TVB tickets online.
You can schedule a hearing for the traffic ticket online.
You can pay the fine and surcharge with your credit card online.
To answer your ticket by mail, you can enter your plea on the ticket and include the appropriate fee if pleading guilty.
To answer your ticket by mail, you can mail it to Traffic Violations Plea Unit, P.O. Box 2950 - ESP, Albany, NY 12220-0950.
To answer your ticket at a TVB office, you can follow the instructions on the ticket.
To answer your ticket at a TVB office, you need to bring proof of identity such as your driver license.
If you do not answer a traffic ticket on time, your driver license will be suspended.
It is a crime to drive with a suspended license.
A suspension for the failure to answer a ticket does not indicate that you are guilty of the charge.
A suspension for the failure to answer a ticket only indicates that you failed to answer the ticket.
To remove the suspension for failure to answer a ticket, you must contact the court to answer the ticket.
To remove the suspension for failure to answer a ticket, you must pay a $70 suspension termination fee.
If you continue to ignore the ticket after your license is suspended for failure to answer the ticket, you will automatically be convicted of the charge.
An automatic conviction for ignoring a ticket after license suspension is known as a 'default conviction'.
A default conviction is equivalent to a guilty finding.
If you have a default conviction, the DMV then suspends your driver license for your failure to pay the fine.
To terminate the suspension resulting from the default conviction, you must pay the fine, mandatory surcharge and the suspension termination fees.
Some convictions can cause the suspension or the revocation of your driver license.

If you have 3 or more alcohol-related convictions on your entire driving record, a plea of guilty to a violation that results in 5 or more points may result in the revocation of your license under Part 132 of the Commissioner's Regulations.
You may want to consult with an attorney before entering your plea if you have 3 or more alcohol-related convictions on your entire driving record and the violation results in 5 or more points.
In other parts of New York State, traffic violations are processed in the criminal or traffic court of the city, county, town or village where the alleged offense took place.
To answer traffic tickets in other parts of New York State, you need to contact the court directly.
A suspension due to a traffic ticket is an 'indefinite' suspension.
An indefinite suspension means your driver license or privilege to drive is taken away until you pay a suspension termination fee of $70 and have valid driver license.

To bring a vehicle from another state to register in New York, if you purchase a vehicle in another state, you will need to go through that state's DMV office to get a temporary plate and registration to transport the vehicle to New York.
Once the vehicle is in New York, you will need to follow the steps to register and title a vehicle here.

To bring a vehicle purchased in New York State to another state, you can apply for an in-transit permit, which will allow you to transport a vehicle from a location in New York State to a location outside of New York State.

To bring a vehicle purchased in New York State to another part of New York State to register, you can apply for an in-transit permit, which will allow you to transport a vehicle from a location within New York to another location within New York.
In-transit permits are valid for 30 days.
The fee for an in-transit permit is $12.50.

To apply for an in-transit permit, bring these items to a DMV office: a completed In-Transit Permit/Title Application pdf (MV-82ITP), proof of ownership, proof of identity, payment for in-transit permit fee, proof of insurance.
Print this checklist for applying for an in-transit permit.

If you are not a resident of New York State, these are acceptable proofs of insurance: name of insurance company, policy number and expiration date, effective date, insured's name and address, vehicle information including year, make and VIN, the name and address of the producer, the name and address of the insured, the name of the insurance company, the effective and expiration dates of the policy, a complete vehicle description including year, make and VIN, Any Auto, All Owned Autos, Scheduled Autos.
Vehicles that do not require insurance in New York State (e.g. light trailers) are not required to present proof of insurance.
All Insurance ID Cards must be original documents. A letter or an insurance binder can be an original document or a fax sent to a DMV office by the insurer. Photocopies are not acceptable.
You do not need to be a New York State resident to apply for an in-transit permit.

Acceptable proofs of ownership for applying for an in-transit permit are: Certificate of Title (MV-999), Manufacturer's Certificate of Origin (MCO), Manufacturer's Statement of Origin (MSO), Statement of Ownership (MV-51B), Findings DMV Administrative Hearing, Transferable Registration.
You must be at least 16 years old except for ATV and boat registrations to apply for an in-transit permit.
You must provide a driver license, learner permit, or non-driver ID card to apply for an in-transit permit. If you don't have one of these, you can use other kinds of proof.
For intrastate permits, you may also need to pay title or lien fees and sales tax.

These proofs of insurance are acceptable for applying for an in-transit permit in New York State: NY State Insurance ID Card (FS-20 or FS-21), Insurance Certificate For Hire Passenger Vehicle (FH-1 or FH-2), Corporate Surety Bond For Hire Passenger Vehicle (FH-1B or FH-2B).
The preparation date for the proof of insurance must be 7 days or less from the date of your application for the vehicle permit.

Additionally, the Temporary Insurance ID Card (FS-75) must have 'in-transit' or 'in-transit permit' printed or written on it, and you must provide an In-transit Cancellation Authorization form (this is not a DMV form) from the insurance agent or broker who prepared the card.
In New York State, every automotive dealer must register with the Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV).
A registered dealer must obey certain state and federal laws that protect your purchase of a new or used car, truck, or other motor vehicle, including one sold as 'salvage'.
New vehicles are also protected by manufacturer's warranty.
You can search for registered Automotive Dealers by using the 'Find a DMV-regulated Business' service.

When you buy a used vehicle, the dealer must certify, in writing, that it is 'in condition and repair to render, under normal use, satisfactory and adequate service upon the public highway at the time of delivery'.
The dealer certification covers the entire vehicle except items that would be obvious to the customer before the sale, such as torn upholstery, missing hubcaps, etc.
The vehicle also must have all safety equipment and emissions controls required by state and federal laws for the vehicle's model year.
A dealer also must: have the vehicle inspected before selling it to a retail customer, even if the vehicle is new.
The inspection must be done within 30 days of the date of sale and before you take delivery.
The dealer may charge you the inspection fee.
A dealer must provide service or repairs under the manufacturer's warranty if the dealer is franchised by that manufacturer.
Warranty service also may be available from other dealers franchised by the manufacturer.
A dealer must indicate, in writing, on the bill of sale whether a vehicle sold to a retail buyer is new, used, reconstructed, rebuilt salvage, or originally not manufactured to U.S. standards.
For motor vehicles that are 10 model years old or newer, the seller must complete the odometer disclosure statement on the back of the title certificate.
For vehicles older than 10 model years, odometer disclosure is not required.
The damage disclosure statement on the back of the title certificate must be completed regardless of the vehicle's age.
The DMV will not register or grant title to a salvaged vehicle without a completed salvage disclosure statement.
The DMV must examine each vehicle branded or identified by the seller as 'Rebuilt Salvage' for stolen parts before the vehicle can be registered or titled.
A dealer must complete and sign an odometer disclosure statement if the vehicle is 10 model years old or newer.
This statement is on the Retail Certificate of Sale (MV-50).
The buyer also must acknowledge and sign the odometer statement.
A dealer must indicate on the sales contract when a passenger car had been used primarily as a police car, taxicab, driver education or rental car.
If a lien is being recorded or the dealer issued number plates, the dealer MUST handle the registration for you.
The dealer may charge you up to $75 for this service, plus the actual fees for the vehicle's Certificate of Title (MV-999), registration, and license plates.
As a customer courtesy, a registered dealer may submit your completed Vehicle Registration/Title Application (MV-82) to the DMV.
The dealer also may provide a temporary certificate of registration and, if needed, new license plates.
One advantage of buying a vehicle from a private seller is the possibility of lower cost compared to buying from a dealer.
However, there are disadvantages when buying from a private seller.
A private seller does not have to follow important regulations that a dealer must obey.
A private seller rarely offers a warranty.
If you have a complaint about the vehicle or purchase from a private seller, you are on your own to resolve the problem with the seller, or in taking legal action.
You cannot file a complaint with the DMV or other consumer assistance agencies if you buy a defective vehicle in a private sale.

If you buy a vehicle 8 model years old or newer from a private seller, the DMV will NOT register or issue you a new title certificate unless the seller has completed, and you have signed, the damage disclosure statement on the reverse of the vehicle's Certificate of Title (MV-999) or have attached a completed damage disclosure on an Odometer and Damage Disclosure Statement (MV-103).
This statement indicates whether or not the vehicle's new title certificate should be branded 'Rebuilt Salvage'.
An Odometer and Damage Disclosure Statement (MV-103) is available at any motor vehicle office.
For motor vehicles that are 10 model years old or newer, the seller must complete the odometer disclosure statement on the back of the title certificate.
For vehicles older than 10 model years, odometer disclosure is not required.
The damage disclosure statement on the back of the title certificate must be completed regardless of the vehicle's age.
The DMV MUST EXAMINE EVERY VEHICLE IDENTIFIED AS 'REBUILT SALVAGE' FOR STOLEN PARTS BEFORE THE VEHICLE CAN BE REGISTERED OR TITLED.

If a vehicle has been rebuilt, originally not manufactured to U.S. standards, or reconstructed, a branding notice must be printed in capital letters on the front of the New York State title certificate.
A dealer must inform a customer, in writing, if a branded vehicle is being shown or sold to a retail customer.
This may be a notice placed on the dealer's bill of sale or handed to the customer.
You can also find a printed notice on the front of the title certificate if a vehicle previously had been returned to the manufacturer, its agent, or dealer because it did not conform to warranty.
It also will be printed on the title after a final determination of a court finding or settlement under the state's Lemon Law.
This notice will read: 'IMPORTANT: THIS VEHICLE WAS RETURNED TO THE MANUFACTURER OR DEALER BECAUSE IT DID NOT CONFORM TO ITS WARRANTY.'
The brands below may be printed on a New York State Certificate of Title (MV-999) for 1973 and newer vehicles:

REBUILT SALVAGE/NY: A vehicle with this label has been rebuilt after being wrecked, destroyed or damaged in excess of 75 percent of its retail value at the time of loss, or originally had entered New York State under a branded out-of-state title.
Previous branding includes Salvage, Rebuilt Salvage, Salvage Restored, Junk, Parts Only, Water Damage, or other description.
The Rebuilt Salvage branding will remain on the title for as long as the vehicle exists, no matter how many improvements are made to the vehicle.
NON-USA-STD: A vehicle with this label was not originally manufactured in compliance with United States emissions or safety standards, or both.
RECONSTRUCTED: A vehicle with this label has been repaired or constructed with a glider kit, but not one manufactured in two or more stages.
A glider kit includes all components of a vehicle except the power train.
It is generally used to rebuild heavy trucks or tractors that have been extensively damaged.
Passenger cars built from custom kits are not considered reconstructed vehicles.
Vehicles over 10 model years old are exempt from mileage disclosure.
For all other titled vehicles, the odometer mileage reported during the vehicle's most recent transfer of ownership is printed on the front of its New York State Certificate of Title (MV-999).
If the odometer had passed its maximum reading at the time of sale, the description 'EXCEEDS MECHANICAL LIMITS' will be printed below the reported mileage.
If the actual mileage is unknown because the odometer is broken, or has been repaired or replaced, the front of the title will be printed with 'NOT ACTUAL MILEAGE, WARNING ODOMETER DISCREPANCY.'
Vehicle price is not controlled by any government agency.
Take time to choose a vehicle that meets your needs and budget.
Before you buy a vehicle, compare prices by checking newspaper ads and visit a number of dealers and/or private sellers.
Then take it for a test drive.
If you are knowledgeable, examine the engine, transmission, drive axles, steering and suspension, brakes and electrical system.
If you do not know what to look for, it may be wise to pay a professional automotive technician to examine the vehicle.
Before you buy from a dealer, find out about dealer or manufacturer warranties, what they cover, and for how long.
Ask if the dealer performs service or subcontracts to a repair shop.
Be sure all agreements, guarantees and warranties are in writing.
Examine the vehicle in bright daylight.
Look carefully at the body for signs of collision damage or rust.
Check the paint and vinyl top, sides, or trim for signs of wear or damage.
Check all lights, lenses and mirrors for cracks or other damage.
Look inside the vehicle for signs of wear or damage that may reduce its value, such as splits or holes in the upholstery.
Make sure all seat belts are in place, and in good working condition.
Look under the rugs or mats for dampness or water damage, which could mean there are body leaks.
Open the trunk or rear hatch and check for leaks.
Examine the spare tire, taking it out if necessary.
Make sure the jack and lug wrench are there.
Examine the engine compartment for signs of rusted metal around fenders, oil leaks, or excessive dirt on the engine.
These can be signs of high mileage.
Look at and feel rubber parts such as fan belts and radiator hoses.
If they are hard, cracked or too soft, they should be replaced.
Make sure the exhaust emissions control systems are intact and working.
Start the vehicle when the engine is cold and listen to make sure it runs smoothly when cold.
While the engine warms, check the dash gauges and all inside and outside lights.
Make sure the heater, defrosters, air conditioner, windshield washer and wipers work properly.
If the vehicle is properly registered, you may choose to take it for a test drive.
The engine should accelerate smoothly, and the transmission should shift without hesitation, roughness or loud noises.
Drive the vehicle on a straight, flat surface, and let go of the steering wheel for a moment to see if the front wheels follow a straight track without pulling to either side.
When braking, there should be no unusual noise, vibration, or pulling to either side.
Your test drive should include stop-and-go driving on local streets and driving at highway speeds, over a variety of surfaces and several hills.
Note how well the vehicle runs and handles.
Also, check to see if the engine overheats.
If you are satisfied after the test drive, have the vehicle raised on a lift or jacks.
Examine the condition of the brakes, tires, front and rear suspension, exhaust system and catalytic converter.
Look for oil or fluid leaks underneath.
If you decide the vehicle is in good condition and worth the price, be sure the seller has the proper ownership and transfer documents.
Ask the seller, and examine the title certificate, for information about unsatisfied liens (bank loans, etc.).
Carefully examine all documents before you pay for the vehicle.
In a private sale, have the seller make out a bill of sale in addition to the ownership and sales tax documents.
If the proof of ownership is a Manufacturer's Certificate of Origin (MCO), the proof is the MCO and the dealer's 'Certificate of Sale' (MV-50).

If the proof of ownership is the Certificate of Title (MV-999), or a transferable registration for 1972 and older models, signed over to the dealer, the proof is the title or registration and the dealer's Certificate of Sale (MV-50) showing ownership transfer to you.
The dealer must complete, and you must acknowledge by signing, the appropriate odometer and damage disclosure statements.
If the proof of ownership is the Certificate of Title (MV-999), or a transferable registration for 1972 or older models, signed over to you, the proof is the title or registration.
The seller must complete, and you must acknowledge by signing, the appropriate odometer and damage disclosure statements.

Be sure the private seller completes the seller's section of the form 'Statement of Transaction - Sale or Gift of Motor Vehicle, Trailer, All-Terrain Vehicle (ATV), Vessel (Boat), or Snowmobile' (DTF-802).
This form certifies the purchase price and determines the sales tax you must pay when registering the vehicle.
If the form is not filled out by the seller, you will be charged sales tax based on the vehicle's current fair market value.
Before you accept the title certificate from the seller, check the front of the title for the names and addresses of lien holders.
A lien indicates the current owner owes money on a loan for the vehicle.
If a lien is listed on the title, ask the seller to give you the proof the lien has been paid - in most cases, it will be an official from the lender.
If proof is not provided, the lien holder could repossess the vehicle from you.
If you have a concern or question about the title, registration, sales tax or proof of ownership, contact the DMV Call Center or any motor vehicle office before you buy the vehicle.
Before you trade in or sell your old vehicle, be sure to remove the license plates and the windshield registration sticker, which shows your plate number.
This will help prevent you from being charged with parking tickets that do not belong to you.
Turn in the plates to a motor vehicle office unless you are transferring them to a replacement vehicle.
Always turn in your plates before you cancel liability insurance or before the insurance lapses.
If you do not, your registration will be suspended, and your driver license could be suspended as well.
When transferring the vehicle's title certificate to a new owner, you must fill out the appropriate odometer and damage disclosure statements, and sign your name at 'Seller's Signature'.
Then enter the seller's information on the sales tax form 'Statement of Transaction - Sale or Gift of Motor Vehicle, Trailer, All-Terrain Vehicle (ATV), Vessel (Boat), or Snowmobile' (DTF-802).
This form is available at any motor vehicle office and the DMV internet site.
If you have a complaint about your vehicle, bring it to the attention of the dealership management right away.
Keep a record of all contacts with the dealer about the vehicle and any repairs or adjustments made.
Keep copies of all work orders and invoices as proof of your attempts to resolve the problem.

If you cannot resolve the problem with the dealer, write to: Bureau of Consumer and Facility Services, PO Box 2700-ESP, Albany, NY 12220-0700, or phone 518 474-8943 between 8:30 a.m. and 4:15 p.m. weekdays.
If your complaint concerns a repair, you must file it with the Department of Motor Vehicles within 90 days or 3,000 miles of the repair, whichever comes first.
If your complaint does not fall within its jurisdiction, DMV will refer you to the proper agency.
New York State's new and used car lemon laws provide legal remedies for consumers who buy or lease cars.

If a car does not live up to the written warranty and cannot be repaired - or if it has not been repaired correctly after a reasonable number of attempts - the consumer could receive a refund or replacement car.

For information and assistance concerning the Lemon Laws, contact: Office of the Attorney General, Albany, NY 12224, Telephone: 1-800-771-7755 or 1-518-474-5481 or any regional office of the Attorney General.
You may also contact: Department of State, Division of Consumer Protection, Consumer Assistance Unit, 99 Washington Avenue, Albany, NY 12231-0001, Telephone: 1-800-697-1220 or 1-518-474-8583.
